translated: When someone’s mind is not ceasing, their mind is not arisen. And when someone’s mind is not arisen, their mind is not ceasing.

original: 10. Uppannuppādavāro
analyzed: uppannuppādavāraḥ
translated: The section on arisen and arising

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjittha. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ uppajjittha, tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjittha yassa vā pana cittam uppajjittha tassa cittam uppannam
translated: If there is a thought that has arisen, there is a thought that has arisen. If there is a thought that has arisen, there is a thought that has arisen.

original: Yassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ na uppajjittha. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ na uppajjittha, tassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa cittam na uppannam tassa cittam na uppajjittha yassa vā pana cittam na uppajjittha tassa cittam na uppannaṃ
translated: If there is no thought that has arisen, there is no thought that has arisen. If there is no thought that has arisen, there is no thought that has arisen.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ uppajjissati, tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjissati yassa vā pana cittam uppajjissati tassa cittam uppannam
translated: If there is a thought that has arisen, there is a thought that will arise. If there is a thought that will arise, there is a thought that has arisen.

original: Yassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ na uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ na uppajjissati, tassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa cittam na uppannam tassa cittam na uppajjissati yassa vā pana cittam na uppajjissati tassa cittam na uppannam
translated: If there is no thought that has arisen, there is no thought that will arise. If there is no thought that will arise, there is no thought that has arisen.

original: 11. Atītānāgatavāro
analyzed: atīta anāgata vāraḥ
translated: . The past and future section

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjittha, no ca tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ uppajjissati, no ca tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjittha.
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjittha no ca tassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjissati yassa vā pana cittam uppajjissati no ca tassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjittha
translated: If there is a thought that has arisen, but there is no thought that has arisen, there is a thought that will arise. If there is a thought that will arise, but there is no thought that has arisen, there is a thought that has arisen.🔽. If there is a thought that has arisen, but there is no thought that has arisen, there is a thought that will arise. If there is a thought that will arise, but there is no thought that has arisen, there is a thought that has arisen.

original: Yassa cittaṃ na uppajjittha, no ca tassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ na uppajjissati.
analyzed: yassa cittam na uppajjittha no ca tassa cittam na uppannam tassa cittam na uppajjissati
translated: There is no arising of consciousness for one for whom consciousness has not arisen, but not for one for whom consciousness has arisen.

original: Yassa vā pana cittaṃ na uppajjissati, no ca tassa cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ na uppajjittha.
analyzed: yassa vā pana cittam na uppajjissati no ca tassa cittam na uppannam tassa cittam na uppajjittha
translated: Or there is no arising of consciousness for one for whom consciousness is not arising, but not for one for whom consciousness has arisen.

original: 12. Uppannuppajjamānavāro
analyzed: uppanna uppajjamāna vāraḥ
translated: The Section on Arisen and Arising

original: Uppannaṃ uppajjamānaṃ, uppajjamānaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: uppannam uppajjamānam uppajjamānam uppannam
translated: Arisen and arising, arising and arisen.

original: Na uppannaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ, na uppajjamānaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: na uppannam na uppajjamānam na uppajjamānam na uppannam
translated: Not arisen and not arising, not arising and not arisen.

original: 13. Niruddhanirujjhamānavāro
translated: The Section on Ceased and Ceasing

original: Niruddhaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ, nirujjhamānaṃ niruddhaṃ.
analyzed: niruddham nirujjhamānam nirujjhamānam niruddham
translated: Ceased and ceasing, ceasing and ceased.

original: Na niruddhaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ, na nirujjhamānaṃ na niruddhaṃ.
analyzed: na niruddham na nirujjhamānam na nirujjhamānam na niruddham
translated: Not ceased and not ceasing, not ceasing and not ceased.

original: 14. Atikkantakālavāro🔽Yassa cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, nirujjhamānaṃ
analyzed: atikkanta kālavāro  yassa cittam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam nirujjhamānam
translated: The Section on the Time Passed

original: khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa cittaṃ. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ
analyzed: khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa cittam yassa vā pana cittam nirujjhamānam
translated: For one for whom consciousness is arising, moment after moment, the time passed is the moment that has gone by. For one for whom consciousness is ceasing, moment after moment, the time passed is the moment that has gone by.

original: khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ🔽atikkantakālaṃ tassa cittaṃ.
analyzed: khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam  atikkanta kālam tassa cittam
translated: The mind that is arising, is present, is found (there), is not absent, has not departed, has not gone beyond, is arisen, has been produced, has become manifest.

original: Yassa cittaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, na nirujjhamānaṃ🔽khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa cittaṃ. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ🔽khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, na uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ
analyzed: yassa cittam na uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam na nirujjhamānam  khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa cittam yassa vā pana cittam na nirujjhamānam  khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam na uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam
translated: The mind that is not arising, is not present, is not found (there), is absent, has departed, has gone beyond, is not arisen, has not been produced, has not become manifest.🔽The mind that is ceasing, is present, is found (there), is not absent, has not departed, has not gone beyond, is arisen, has been produced, has become manifest.

original: atikkantakālaṃ tassa cittaṃ.
analyzed: atikkanta kālam tassa cittam
translated: The mind that is not ceasing, is not present, is not found (there), is absent, has departed, has gone beyond, is not arisen, has not been produced, has not become manifest.

original: Suddhacittasāmaññaṃ
analyzed: suddha citta sāmaññam
translated: The similarity of pure minds

original: Dhammavāro
analyzed: dhammavāro
translated: The chapter on the Dhamma

original: 1. Uppādanirodhakālasambhedavāro
translated: The chapter on the distinction of the time of arising and ceasing

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati, taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati na uppajjissati. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ nirujjhissati na uppajjissati, taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati.
analyzed: yam cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati tam cittam nirujjhissati na uppajjissati yam vā pana cittam nirujjhissati na uppajjissati tam cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati
translated: The mind that is arising, is not ceasing, that mind is ceasing, is not arising. Or, the mind that is ceasing, is not arising, that mind is arising, is not ceasing.

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati nirujjhati, taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati uppajjissati. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ na nirujjhissati uppajjissati, taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati nirujjhati.
analyzed: yam cittam na uppajjati nirujjhati tam cittam na nirujjhissati uppajjissati yam vā pana cittam na nirujjhissati uppajjissati tam cittam na uppajjati nirujjhati
translated: Or any consciousness that does not cease and arise is not arising and ceasing.

original: 2. Uppāduppannavāro
analyzed: uppāda uppanna vāraḥ
translated: The Section on Arising and Having Arisen🔽Any consciousness that arises is arisen.

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yam cittam uppajjati tam cittam uppannam yam vā pana cittam uppannam tam cittam uppajjati
translated: Or any consciousness that is arisen is arising.🔽Any consciousness that does not arise is not arisen.

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati, taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati.
analyzed: yam cittam na uppajjati tam cittam na uppannam yam vā pana cittam na uppannam tam cittam na uppajjati
translated: Or any consciousness that is not arisen is not arising.

original: 3. Nirodhuppannavāro
analyzed: nirodha uppanna vāro
translated: The Section on Ceasing and Having Arisen🔽Any consciousness that ceases is arisen.

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati, taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati.
analyzed: yam cittam nirujjhati tam cittam uppannam yam vā pana cittam uppannam tam cittam nirujjhati
translated: Or any consciousness that is arisen is ceasing.🔽Any consciousness that does not cease is not arisen.

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati, taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati.
analyzed: yam cittam na nirujjhati tam cittam na uppannam yam vā pana cittam na uppannam tam cittam na nirujjhati
translated: Or any consciousness that is not arisen is not ceasing.

original: 4. Uppādavāro
analyzed: uppāda vāraḥ
translated: The Section on Arising

original: Yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha. Yaṃ vā pana cittaṃ uppajjittha, taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.

translated: Any mind that has not arisen: is that mind not arisen? Or any mind that is not arisen: has that mind not arisen?

original: 5. Nirodhavāro🔽Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati.🔽Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam nirujjhati tassa tam cittam nirujjhittha yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam nirujjhati  yassa yam cittam na nirujjhati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhittha yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam na nirujjhati
translated: The Chapter on Cessation🔽Any mind that is ceasing: has that mind ceased? Or any mind that has ceased: is that mind ceasing?🔽Any mind that is not ceasing: has that mind not ceased? Or any mind that has not ceased: is that mind not ceasing?

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam nirujjhati tassa tam cittam nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam nirujjhati
translated: Any mind that is ceasing: will that mind have ceased? Or any mind that will have ceased: is that mind ceasing?

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati.🔽Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na nirujjhati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhati  yassa yam cittam nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam nirujjhittha
translated: If anyone’s cognizance does not cease, then his cognizance will not cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will not cease, then his cognizance does not cease.🔽If anyone’s cognizance has ceased, then his cognizance will cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will cease, then his cognizance has ceased.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam na nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhittha
translated: If anyone’s cognizance has not ceased, then his cognizance will not cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will not cease, then his cognizance has not ceased.

original: 6. Uppādanirodhavāro
translated: The Chapter about Arising and Ceasing

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjati tassa tam cittam nirujjhittha yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam uppajjati
translated: If anyone’s cognizance arises, then his cognizance has ceased. Or if anyone’s cognizance has ceased, then his cognizance arises.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhittha yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhittha tassa tam cittam na uppajjati
translated: If anyone’s cognizance does not arise, then his cognizance does not cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance does not cease, then his cognizance does not arise.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjati tassa tat cittam nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhissati tassa tat cittam uppajjati
translated: If anyone’s cognizance arises, then his cognizance will cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will cease, then his cognizance arises.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjati tassa tat cittam na nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhissati tassa tat cittam na uppajjati
translated: If anyone’s cognizance does not arise, then his cognizance will not cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will not cease, then his cognizance does not arise.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjittha tassa tam cittam nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam uppajjittha
translated: If anyone’s cognizance has arisen, then his cognizance will cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will cease, then his cognizance has arisen.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjittha tassa tam cittam na nirujjhissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhissati tassa tam cittam na uppajjittha
translated: If anyone’s cognizance has not arisen, then his cognizance will not cease. Or if anyone’s cognizance will not cease, then his cognizance has not arisen.

original: 7. Uppajjamānananirodhavāro
translated: 7. The Section on Arising and Vanishing

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjati tassa tam cittam na nirujjhati yassa vā pana yam cittam na nirujjhati tassa tam cittam uppajjati
translated: The mind that arises in someone does not vanish in that person. Or, the mind that does not vanish in someone arises in that person.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjati tassa tam cittam nirujjhati yassa vā pana yam cittam nirujjhati tassa tam cittam na uppajjati
translated: The mind that does not arise in someone vanishes in that person. Or, the mind that vanishes in someone does not arise in that person.

original: 8. Uppajjamānuppannavāro
analyzed: uppajjamāna uppanna vāraḥ
translated: . The Section on Arising and What Has Arisen

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjamānam tassa tam cittam uppannam yassa vā pana yam cittam uppannam tassa tam cittam uppajjamānam
translated: The mind that is arising in someone has arisen in that person. Or, the mind that has arisen in someone is arising in that person.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjamānam tassa tam cittam na uppannam yassa vā pana yam cittam na uppannam tassa tam cittam na uppajjamānam
translated: The mind that is not arising in someone has not arisen in that person. Or, the mind that has not arisen in someone is not arising in that person.

original: 9. Nirujjhamānuppannavāro
translated: . The Section on Vanishing and What Has Arisen

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam nirujjhamānam tassa tam cittam uppannam yassa vā pana yam cittam uppannam tassa tam cittam nirujjhamānam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness is ceasing, then that consciousness has arisen. Or if anyone’s consciousness has arisen, then that consciousness is ceasing.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na nirujjhamānam tassa tam cittam na uppannam yassa vā pana yam cittam na uppannam tassa tam cittam na nirujjhamānam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness is not ceasing, then that consciousness has not arisen. Or if anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, then that consciousness is not ceasing.

original: 10. Uppannuppādavāro
analyzed: uppannuppādavāraḥ
translated: The section on what is arisen and what is arising

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppannam tassa tam cittam uppajjittha yassa vā pana yam cittam uppajjittha tassa tam cittam uppannam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness has arisen, then that consciousness is arising. Or if anyone’s consciousness is arising, then that consciousness has arisen.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppannam tassa tam cittam na uppajjittha yassa vā pana yam cittam na uppajjittha tassa tam cittam na uppannam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, then that consciousness is not arising. Or if anyone’s consciousness is not arising, then that consciousness has not arisen.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppannam tassa tat cittam uppajjissati yassa vā pana yam cittam uppajjissati tassa tam cittam uppannam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness has arisen, then that consciousness will arise. Or if anyone’s consciousness will arise, then that consciousness has arisen.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjissati, yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjissati, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppannam tassa tat cittam na uppajjissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na uppajjissati tassa tat cittam na uppannam
translated: If anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, then his consciousness will not arise. Or if anyone’s consciousness will not arise, then his consciousness has not arisen.

original: 11. Atītānāgatavāro
analyzed: atīta anāgata vāraḥ
translated: The past and future section

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha, no ca tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjissati.
analyzed: yassa yam cittam uppajjittha no ca tassa tam cittam uppannam tassa tam cittam uppajjissati
translated: If anyone’s consciousness has arisen, but his consciousness has not yet arisen, then his consciousness will arise.

original: Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjissati, no ca tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ uppajjittha.🔽Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha, no ca tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ🔽na uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjissati, no ca tassa taṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: yassa vā pana yam cittam uppajjissati no ca tassa tam cittam uppannam tassa tam cittam uppajjittha  yassa yam cittam na uppajjittha no ca tassa tam cittam na uppannam tassa tam cittam  na uppajjissati yassa vā pana yam cittam na uppajjissati no ca tassa tam cittam
translated: Or if anyone’s consciousness will arise, but his consciousness has not yet arisen, then his consciousness has arisen.🔽If anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, but his consciousness has not yet arisen, then his consciousness will not arise.

original: na uppannaṃ, tassa taṃ cittaṃ na uppajjittha.
analyzed: na uppannam tassa tat cittam na uppajjittha
translated: Or if anyone’s consciousness will not arise, but his consciousness has not yet arisen, then his consciousness has not arisen.

original: 12. Uppannuppajjamānavāro
analyzed: uppanna uppajjamāna vāraḥ
translated: The arisen and arising section

original: Uppannaṃ uppajjamānaṃ, uppajjamānaṃ uppannaṃ.
analyzed: uppannam uppajjamānam uppajjamānam uppannam
translated: Arisen and arising, arising and arisen.

original: Na uppannaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ, na uppajjamānaṃ na uppannaṃ.
analyzed: na uppannam na uppajjamānam na uppajjamānam na uppannam
translated: Not arisen and not arising, not arising and not arisen.

original: 13. Niruddhanirujjhamānavāro
translated: 13. The section on ceased and vanishing

original: Niruddhaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ, nirujjhamānaṃ niruddhaṃ.
analyzed: niruddham nirujjhamānam nirujjhamānam niruddham
translated: Ceased and vanishing, vanishing and ceased.

original: Na niruddhaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ, na nirujjhamānaṃ na niruddhaṃ.
analyzed: na niruddham na nirujjhamānam na nirujjhamānam na niruddham
translated: Not ceased and not vanishing, not vanishing and not ceased.

original: 14. Atikkantakālavāro🔽Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, nirujjhamānaṃ
analyzed: atikkanta kālavāro  yassa yam cittam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam nirujjhamānam
translated: . The section on the time that has passed🔽The mind that has arisen and has gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed, is vanishing

original: khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa taṃ cittaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa tam cittam yassa vā pana yam cittam
translated: and has gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed. The mind that is vanishing

original: nirujjhamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ
analyzed: nirujjhamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam
translated: and has gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed, has arisen

original: vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa taṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa tam cittam
translated: and has gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed.

original: Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ na uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, na nirujjhamānaṃ
analyzed: yassa yam cittam na uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam na nirujjhamānam
translated: The mind that has not arisen and has not gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed, has not vanished

original: khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa taṃ cittaṃ. Yassa vā pana yaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa tam cittam yassa vā pana yam cittam
translated: and has not gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed. The mind that has not vanished🔽and has not gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed, has not arisen🔽and has not gone beyond the moment, the time that has passed.

original: na nirujjhamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, na uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ
analyzed: na nirujjhamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam na uppajjamānam khaṇam
translated: not when it has ceased, not when it has gone beyond the moment, not when the time has gone by. Not when it has arisen,

original: khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ tassa taṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa tam cittam
translated: not when it has gone beyond the moment, not when the time has gone by. That is his consciousness.

original: Suttantacittamissakaviseso
translated: The difference in the suttas is a mixture of consciousness.

original: Yassa sarāgaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati…pe… yassa vītarāgaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa sadosaṃ🔽cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa vītadosaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa samohaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.🔽Yassa vītamohaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa saṃkhittaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa vikkhittaṃ
analyzed: yassa sa rāgam cittam uppajjati pe yassa vīta rāgam cittam uppajjati yassa sa dosam  cittam uppajjati yassa vīta dosam cittam uppajjati yassa sa moham cittam uppajjati  yassa vīta moham cittam uppajjati yassa saṃkhittam cittam uppajjati yassa vikkhittam
translated: For one who has lust, consciousness arises with lust. … For one who is without lust, consciousness arises without lust. For one who has hate,🔽consciousness arises with hate. For one who is without hate, consciousness arises without hate. For one who has delusion, consciousness arises with delusion.🔽For one who is without delusion, consciousness arises without delusion. For one who has contracted consciousness, consciousness arises contracted.

original: cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa mahaggataṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa amahaggataṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: cittam uppajjati yassa mahaggatam cittam uppajjati yassa amahaggatam cittam uppajjati
translated: For one who has distracted consciousness, consciousness arises distracted. For one who has exalted consciousness, consciousness arises exalted.🔽For one who has unexalted consciousness, consciousness arises unexalted. For one who has surpassed consciousness, consciousness arises surpassed.

original: Yassa sauttaraṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa anuttaraṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa samāhitaṃ
analyzed: yassa sauttaram cittam uppajjati yassa anuttaram cittam uppajjati yassa samāhitam
translated: For one who has unsurpassed consciousness, consciousness arises unsurpassed. For one who has concentrated consciousness, consciousness arises concentrated.

original: cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa asamāhitaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa vimuttaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: cittam uppajjati yassa asamāhitam cittam uppajjati yassa vimuttam cittam uppajjati
translated: For one who has unconcentrated consciousness, consciousness arises unconcentrated. For one who has liberated consciousness, consciousness arises liberated.

original: Yassa avimuttaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa a vimuttam cittam uppajjati
translated: … whose unliberated cognizance arises.

original: Abhidhammacittamissakaviseso
translated: The special combination of the Abhidhamma-mind.

original: Yassa kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati…pe… yassa akusalaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa abyākataṃ cittaṃ uppajjati. Yassa sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa kusalam cittam uppajjati pe yassa akusalam cittam uppajjati yassa abyākatam cittam uppajjati yassa sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttam cittam uppajjati
translated: … whose profitable cognizance arises … whose unprofitable cognizance arises … whose indeterminate cognizance arises … whose cognizance accompanied by pleasure arises …

original: (Etena upāyena yāva saraṇaaraṇā uddharitabbā.)🔽Yassa araṇaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati, tassa araṇaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati na🔽uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana araṇaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhissati na uppajjissati, tassa araṇaṃ
analyzed: etena upāyena yāva saraṇaaraṇā uddharitabbā  yassa araṇam cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati tassa araṇam cittam nirujjhissati na  uppajjissati yassa vā pana araṇam cittam nirujjhissati na uppajjissati tassa araṇam
translated: (In this way the section on the Unincluded should be extracted.)

original: cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati.
analyzed: cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati
translated: Whose unincluded cognizance arises and does not cease, does his unincluded cognizance cease and not arise? Or whose unincluded cognizance ceases and does not arise, does his unincluded cognizance arise and not cease?

original: Cittayamakamātikā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: citta yamaka mātikā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Pair of Cognizance is ended.

original: Dhammayamakaṃ🔽Paṇṇattivāro
analyzed: dhamma yamakam  paṇṇatti vāraḥ
translated: The Pairs in the True Idea

original: Padasodhanavāro
analyzed: pada sodhana vāraḥ
translated: The Section on Description🔽The Section on the Clearing Up of Terms

original: Anulomaṃ
analyzed: anulomam
translated: In the Direct Order

original: Kusalā kusalā dhammā. Kusalā dhammā kusalā.
analyzed: kusalā kusalā dhammā kusalāḥ dhammāḥ kusalā
translated: Profitable ideas are profitable. Profitable ideas are profitable.

original: Akusalā akusalā dhammā. Akusalā dhammā akusalā.
analyzed: akusalāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalā
translated: Unprofitable ideas are unprofitable. Unprofitable ideas are unprofitable.

original: Abyākatā abyākatā dhammā. Abyākatā dhammā abyākatā.
analyzed: abyākatāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatā
translated: Indeterminate ideas are indeterminate. Indeterminate ideas are indeterminate.

original: Paccanīkaṃ
analyzed: paccanīkam
translated: In the Reverse Order

original: Na kusalā na kusalā dhammā. Na kusalā dhammā na kusalā.🔽Na akusalā na akusalā dhammā. Na akusalā dhammā na akusalā.
analyzed: na kusalāḥ na kusalāḥ dhammāḥ na kusalāḥ dhammāḥ na kusalā  na akusalā na akusalā dhammā na akusalāḥ dhammāḥ na akusalā
translated: Neither wholesome nor unwholesome thoughts. Unwholesome thoughts are not wholesome.🔽Neither unwholesome nor unwholesome thoughts. Unwholesome thoughts are not unwholesome.

original: Na abyākatā na abyākatā dhammā. Na abyākatā dhammā na abyākatā.
analyzed: na abyākatā na abyākatāḥ dhammā na abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ na abyākatā
translated: Neither indeterminate nor indeterminate thoughts. Indeterminate thoughts are not indeterminate.

original: Padasodhanamūlacakkavāro
translated: The first chapter on the analysis of terms and roots

original: Anulomaṃ
analyzed: anulomam
translated: In the forward order

original: Kusalā kusalā dhammā. Dhammā akusalā dhammā.
analyzed: kusalā kusalā dhammā dhammā akusalāḥ dhammā
translated: Wholesome thoughts are wholesome thoughts. Thoughts are unwholesome thoughts.

analyzed: ananta aparimāṇa bhāṇa vāram hoti

analyzed: tathā kathā vatthu pakaraṇam saka vāde pañca sutta satāni paravāde pañca sutta satāni iti
translated: So the Kathāvatthu Manual has five hundred theses in one’s own doctrine and five hundred in another’s doctrine,

original: suttasahassaṃ samodhānetvā vibhattaṃ vācanāmaggato saṅgītiāropitanayena dīghanikāyappamāṇampi
analyzed: sutta sahassam samodhānetvā vibhattam vācanā maggato saṅgīti āropita nayena dīgha nikāya ppamāṇam pi

analyzed: vitthāriyamānam ananta aparimāṇa bhāṇavāram hoti
translated: If it were to be expanded, it would be infinite and immeasurable in terms of the number of recitations.

analyzed: tathā yamaka ppakaraṇam mūlayamakam khandha āyatana dhātu sacca saṅkhāra anusaya citta dhamma indriya yamakan ti
translated: Similarly, the Yamaka, divided into ten sections, namely, the root-twins, the aggregates, bases, elements, truths, formations, latent tendencies, consciousness, mental factors, and faculties,

analyzed: dasavidhena vibhattam vācanā maggataḥ vīsa bhāṇa vāra satam pi vitthāriyamānam ananta aparimāṇa bhāṇa vāram hoti

original: Paṭṭhānappakaraṇaṃ hetupaccayaārammaṇapaccayādicatuvīsatipaccaye gahetvā tikapaṭṭhānādicatuvīsatividhena
analyzed: paṭṭhāna ppakaraṇam hetu paccaya ārammaṇa paccaya ādi catuvīsati paccaye gahetvā tika paṭṭhāna ādi catuvīsatividhena
translated: The Paṭṭhāna, taking the twenty-two conditions, namely, the root-cause condition, the decisive-support condition, etc., and divided into twenty-two sections, namely, the three-factored condition, etc.,

original: vibhattaṃ paccekaṃ katipayabhāṇavārampi vitthāriyamānaṃ anantāparimāṇabhāṇavāraṃ
analyzed: vibhattam paccekam katipaya bhāṇa vāram pi vitthāriyamānam ananta aparimāṇa bhāṇa vāram
translated: is several recitations in the method of recitation. If it were to be expanded, it would be infinite and immeasurable in terms of the number of recitations.

original: hoti. Evaṃ anantāparimāṇānaṃ dhammānaṃ, atthānañca pasavanato, pālanato, posanato
analyzed: hoti evam ananta aparimāṇānam dhammānam atthānam ca pasavanataḥ pālanataḥ posanataḥ
translated: Thus, because it gives birth to, preserves, and nourishes infinite and immeasurable ideas and meanings,

original: ca “mātā viyāti mātikā”ti vuccati. Pālanaposanañcettha sammuṭṭhānaṃ, viraddhānañca
analyzed: ca mātā viyāti mātikā ati vuccati pālana posanam ca ittha sammuṭṭhānam viraddhānam ca
translated: it is called the “mother” . Herein, the preservation and nourishment is the origination of what is not originated and the continuation of what is originated.

original: pāḷiatthānaṃ mātikānusārena sallakkhetvā samānayanato, rakkhaṇato ca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pāḷi atthānam mātikā anusārena sallakkhetvā samānayanataḥ rakkhaṇataḥ ca veditabbam
translated: It should be understood as the root-cause of the whole of the Abhidhamma, as the basis for the method of exposition, and as the means of preserving the teaching.

original: Sā panāyaṃ paricchedato dhammasaṅgaṇīmātikā vibhaṅgamātikā dhātukathāmātikā puggalapaññattimātikā

translated: This mātikā is of seven kinds, being placed at the beginning of the seven books, namely, the Dhammasanganī, Vibhaṅga, Dhātukathā, Puggalapaññatti,

analyzed: kathā vatthu mātikā yamaka mātikā paṭṭhāna mātikā ati sattannam pakaraṇānaṃ ādimhi ṭhapitā sattavidhā hoti  tattha dhammasaṅgaṇī mātikā ādi sā api tikamātikā dukamātikā ati duvidhā tattha dvāvīsati
translated: Kathāvatthu, Yamaka, and Paṭṭhāna.🔽The mātikā of the Dhammasanganī is twofold, being either a mātikā of triads or a mātikā of dyads. The mātikā of triads consists of twenty-two triads,🔽and the mātikā of dyads consists of forty-two hundred dyads.

original: tikā tikamātikā nāma. Dvecattālīsasatadukā dukamātikā nāma, sā puna āhaccabhāsitā
analyzed: tikā tikamātikā nāma dukamātikā nāma sā punar āhacca bhāsitā
translated: This mātikā is twofold, being either the teaching of the Fully Enlightened One or the teaching of his disciples. original: sāvakabhāsitāti duvidhā. Tattha dvāvīsati tikā ceva, “hetū dhammā na hetū dhammā…pe…
analyzed: sāvaka bhāsitā ati duvidhā tattha dvāvīsati tikā ca iva hetū dhammā na hetū dhamma āpe
translated: ideas that are with co-nascence, ideas that are without co-nascence …🔽ideas that are internal, ideas that are external …🔽ideas that are clung to, ideas that are not clung to …🔽ideas that are gross, ideas that are subtle …🔽ideas that are inferior, ideas that are superior …

original: saraṇā dhammā araṇā dhammā”ti ime ca sataṃ dukāti ayaṃ āhaccabhāsitā sammāsambuddhadesitā
analyzed: saraṇāḥ dhammāḥ araṇāḥ dhammā ati ime ca satam ayam āhacca bhāsitā sammāsambuddha desitā
translated: ideas that are peaceful, ideas that are not peaceful …🔽ideas that are special, ideas that are not special …🔽ideas that are the culmination, ideas that are not the culmination …🔽ideas that are supermundane, ideas that are not supermundane …🔽ideas that are the path, ideas that are not the path …🔽ideas that are the fruit, ideas that are not the fruit …🔽ideas that are with the fruit, ideas that are without the fruit …🔽ideas that are with the root-cause, ideas that are without the root-cause …🔽ideas that are to be given attention, ideas that are not to be given attention …🔽ideas that are fit for attention, ideas that are not fit for attention …🔽ideas that are to be given attention and are fit for attention, ideas that are to be given attention but are

original: sattannaṃ pakaraṇānaṃ mātikā nāma, tadanantarā “vijjābhāgino dhammā avijjābhāgino🔽dhammā…pe… khayeñāṇaṃ anuppādeñāṇa”nti ime dvācattālīsa suttantikadukā dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherena
analyzed: sattannam pakaraṇānam mātikā nāma tad anantarāḥ vijjā bhāginaḥ dhammāḥ avijjā bhāginaḥ  dhamma āpe khaya iñāṇam anuppāda iñāṇam ti ime dvācattālīsa suttantika dukāḥ dhammasenāpati sāriputta therena
translated: The first seven books are called the Mātikā, and the next forty-two Suttas are called the Dhamma-Sariputta-Theravāda.🔽The forty-two Suttas are: “The states that are concerned with knowledge and the states that are not concerned with knowledge …🔽Knowledge of destruction and knowledge of non-recurrence.”🔽

original: ṭhapitattā sāvakabhāsitā nāma. Ime ṭhapento pana thero na sāmukkaṃsikena attano ñāṇena
analyzed: ṭhapita ttā sāvakabhāsitāḥ nāma ime ṭhapentaḥ pana theraḥ na sāmukkaṃsikena attanaḥ ñāṇena
translated: The first seven books are called the “Mātikā” . The next forty-two suttas are called the “Dhamma-Sariputta-Theravāda” . The Elder Sariputta, the General of the Dhamma, set them forth. They are called the “Sāvakabhāsita” . When the Elder set them forth, he did not do so by his own knowledge, which was like a great ocean. He set them forth in order not to tire the Elders of Abhidhamma who had come to the Suttanta.

original: ṭhapesi, ekuttariyaṃ pana ekakanipātadukanipātasaṅgītisuttadasuttarasuttehi samodhānetvā🔽ābhidhammikattherānaṃ suttantaṃ patvā akilamanatthaṃ ṭhapesi.🔽Sā puna sappadesanippadesavasena dve koṭṭhāsā honti. Ettha hi nava tikā, ekasattati🔽ca dukā sappadesānaṃ sāvasesānaṃ nāmarūpānaṃ pariggahitattā sappadesā nāma, avasesā
analyzed: ṭhapesi ekuttariyam pana ekaka nipāta duka nipāta saṅgīti sutta dasuttara suttehi samodhānetvā  ābhidhammika therānam suttantam patvā akilamana attham ṭhapesi  sā puna sappadesa nippadesa vasena dve koṭṭhāsāḥ honti ettha hi nava tikā ekasattati  ca dukā sa padesānam sa avasesānam nāma rūpānam pariggahita ttā sa padesā nāma avasesā
translated: He set them forth by combining them with the Ekuttara-Nikāya, the Dukanipāta, the Saṅgīti Sutta, and the Dasuttara Sutta.

original: terasa tikā, ekasattati ca dukā nippadesānaṃ niravasesānaṃ nāmarūpānaṃ gahitattā
analyzed: terasa tikāḥ ekasattati ca dukāḥ nippadesānam niravasesānam nāma rūpānam gahita ttā
translated: The “Mātikā” is divided into two parts, the “Sāpadāna” and the “Nippadāna” . The nine triads and seventy-one dyads are called the “Sāpadāna” because they include the “Sāva-sesa” , that is, the “Sāva-sesa” mental and material dhammas. The remaining thirteen triads and seventy-one dyads are called the “Nippadāna” because they include the “Anavasesa” , that is, the “Anavasesa” mental and material dhammas.

original: nippadesā nāma. Tesaṃ vibhāgo tattha tattheva āvi bhavissati. Tathā nāmalābhavasena
analyzed: nippadesāḥ nāma tesam vibhāgo tattha tattha iva bhavissati tathā nāma lābha vasena
translated: The rest are called indeclinables. Their analysis will be given in the appropriate places.🔽So they are twofold as getting a name according to the method of naming.

original: dvidhā. Sabbeva hi ete tikadukā ādipadavasena, sabbapadavasena cāti dvidhā nāmaṃ
analyzed: dvidhā sabbe iva hi ete tika dukāḥ ādi pada vasena sabba pada vasena ca ati dvidhā nāmam
translated: For all these triads and dyads get a name as twofold according to the method of naming by the first term and according to the method of naming by all the terms.

original: labhanti. Tattha “kusalā dhammā, akusalā dhammā, abyākatā dhammā”ti ayaṃ tāva ādipadavasena🔽laddhanāmo kusalattiko nāma. “Sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā dhammā…pe… dhammā”ti ayaṃ
analyzed: labhanti tattha kusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ ati ayam tāva ādi pada vasena  laddha nāmaḥ kusalattikaḥ nāma sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttāḥ ayaṃ
translated: Herein, firstly, the triad of profitable, etc., which gets its name according to the method of naming by the first term, is called the profitable triad, etc.;

original: sabbapadavasena laddhanāmo vedanāttiko nāma. Evaṃ sabbesampi tikadukānaṃ nāmaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabba pada vasena laddha nāmaḥ vedanāttikaḥ nāma evam sabbesam pi tika dukānam nāmam veditabbam
translated: and the triad of feeling, etc., which gets its name according to the method of naming by all the terms, is called the feeling triad, etc. This is how the name of all the triads and dyads should be understood.

original: Sā panesā pañcadasahi paricchedehi vavatthitā. Tikānaṃ hi eko paricchedo, dukānaṃ
analyzed: sā pana isā pañcadasahi paricchedehi vavatthitā tikānam hi ekaḥ paricchedaḥ dukānam
translated: It is defined by fifteen sections. For there is one section of triads and fourteen of dyads.

analyzed: cuddasa hetū dhammā na hetū dhamma ati ādayaḥ hi cha dukāḥ ganthato ca atthato ca aññamañña sambandhena

analyzed: parāmāsagocchakaḥ nāma tatas param sārammaṇa duka ādayo catuddasa dukāḥ mahantara dukā

original: anantare vuttañcāti nibbacanadvayaṃ kiñcāpi nippariyāyato ñāṇasampayuttānameva yujjati,🔽ruḷhīvasena pana taṃsadisatāya ñāṇavippayuttānampīti gahetabbaṃ. Yathā vā kusā ubhayabhāgagataṃ

translated: Among them, the profitable has the characteristic of being blameless and of having a happy outcome; the unprofitable has the characteristic of being blameworthy and of having a painful outcome; the indeterminate has the characteristic of having no outcome.

analyzed: yadi tāva ekatthāni kusalā dhammā ati idam kusalā kusalā ati vutta sadisam hoti  atha nānatthāni tika dukānam chakka catukka bhāvaḥ āpajjati padānam ca asambandhaḥ kusalā

Thus, although they have separate spheres of reference,

original: Lakkhaṇādivibhāgatoti evaṃ uddiṭṭhānaṃ dhammānaṃ lakkhaṇarasādito vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādi vibhāgato ti evam uddiṭṭhānam dhammānam lakkhaṇa rasa āditaḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: As to the analysis of their characteristics, etc.: the exposition of the states mentioned above should be known according to their characteristics, functions, etc.,

original: Phusatīti phasso. Svāyaṃ phusanalakkhaṇo, saṅghaṭṭanaraso, sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: phusati iti phassaḥ svāyam phusana lakkhaṇo saṅghaṭṭana raso sannipāta paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: It touches : this is contact. Its characteristic is touching. Its function is to impinge. It is manifested as impingement.

original: āpāthagatavisayapadaṭṭhāno. Ayaṃ hi arūpadhammopi samāno ārammaṇe phusanākārena pavattatīti
analyzed: āpātha gata visaya padaṭṭhānaḥ ayam hi arūpa dhammaḥ api samānaḥ ārammaṇe phusana ākārena pavattati iti
translated: It has as its object a visible datum that has come into focus. For this immaterial state, though immaterial, occurs in the aspect of touching the object.

original: phusanalakkhaṇo, sā cassa phusanākārappavatti ambilādidassane kheḷuppādādinā ñātabbā.
analyzed: phusana lakkhaṇo sā ca ssa phusana ākāra ppavatti ambila ādi dassane kheḷuppāda ādinā ñātabbā
translated: Its characteristic is touching. Its function is to occur in the aspect of touching. It should be understood that its manifestation is like the appearance of saliva, etc., on seeing sour things and so on.

original: Ekadesena pana anallīyamānopi rūpaṃ viya cakkhuṃ, saddo viya ca sotaṃ cittamārammaṇañca
analyzed: eka desena pana rūpam viya cakkhum saddaḥ viya ca sotam cittam ārammaṇam ca
translated: But though it does not touch the object in the way that the eye and the ear touch the visible data and sounds, respectively, it touches the object in the way that the body does.

original: saṅghaṭṭetīti saṅghaṭṭanaraso. Tikasannipātasaṅkhātassa pana attano kāraṇassa vasena
analyzed: saṅghaṭṭeti iti saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ tika sannipāta saṅkhātassa pana attanaḥ kāraṇassa vasena
translated: So its proximate cause is touching. But because it is announced by its own cause called the “threefold concurrence,”

original: paveditattā sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno, phalaṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhānena panesa vedanāpaccupaṭṭhāno🔽nāma hoti. Tajjāsamannāhārena ceva indriyena ca parikkhate visaye anantarāyena uppajjanato
analyzed: sannipāta paccupaṭṭhāno phala aṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhānena pana esa vedanā paccupaṭṭhāno  nāma hoti tajjā samannāhārena ca iva indriyena ca parikkhate visaye anantarāyena uppajjanato
translated: it has as its condition the concurrence of the three. But because of its condition in the sense of result, it has feeling as its condition.🔽It is said to have as its object a visible datum that has come into focus because it arises without obstruction in an object that is defined by the appropriate attention and faculty.

original: āpāthagatavisayapadaṭṭhānoti vuccati. Vedanādhiṭṭhānabhāvato panesa niccammā gāvī
analyzed: āpātha gata visaya padaṭṭhāno ti vuccati vedanā adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato pana esa niccammā gāvī
translated: But because it is the basis for feeling, it is called “a cow with a permanent calf.”

original: viya daṭṭhabbo. Lakkhaṇādīsu ca tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ sabhāvo vā sāmaññaṃ vā lakkhaṇaṃ

original: nāma, kiccaṃ vā sampatti vā raso nāma, upaṭṭhānākāro vā phalaṃ vā paccupaṭṭhānaṃ

original: nāma, āsannakāraṇaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Evaṃ uparipi sabbattha lakkhaṇādīnaṃ nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Vedayatīti vedanā, sā vedayitalakkhaṇā, sabhāvabhedato panesā pañcavidhā hoti – sukhaṃ
analyzed: nāma āsanna kāraṇam padaṭṭhānam nāma evam upari pi sabbattha lakkhaṇa ādīnam nānattam veditabbam  vedayati iti vedanā sā vedayita lakkhaṇā sa bhāva bhedato pana esā pañcavidhā hoti sukham
translated: the proximate cause is called the “foundation.” This is how the difference should be understood in each instance among the characteristics, etc., in the following too.

original: dukkhaṃ somanassaṃ domanassaṃ upekkhāti. Tattha iṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbānubhavanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: dukkham somanassam domanassam upekkhāti tattha iṭṭha phoṭṭhabba anubhavana lakkhaṇam
translated: It feels , thus it is feeling . Its characteristic is the act of feeling . It is of five kinds as pleasant, painful, and the three of the mental group beginning with happiness . Herein, the characteristic of pleasant feeling is the experiencing of agreeable contacts ;

original: sukhaṃ, sampayuttānaṃ upabrūhanarasaṃ, kāyikaassādapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, kāyindriyapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: sukham sampayuttānam upabrūhana rasam kāyika assāda paccupaṭṭhānam kāyindriya padaṭṭhānam

original: Aniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbānubhavanalakkhaṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, sampayuttānaṃ milāpanarasaṃ, kāyikābādhapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,

translated: The characteristic of painful feeling is the experiencing of disagreeable contacts; its function is to weaken associated states; its manifestation is bodily unrest; and its proximate cause is the body faculty.

original: nātiupabrūhanamilāpanarasā, santabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, nippītikacittapadaṭṭhānā. Ettha🔽ca sukhaṃ, dukkhañca ekantamabyākataṃ, domanassamekantamakusalaṃ, somanassupekkhā

translated: But they are respectively gross and subtle in the way that the first impact of a blow and its reverberation are.

original: pakkhavikkhepo viya, santavutti vicāro ākāse uppatitassa pakkhino pakkhapasāraṇaṃ
analyzed: pakkha vikkhepaḥ viya santa vutti vicāraḥ ākāse uppatitassa pakkhino pakkha pasāraṇam

Applied thought is associated with a wide range of consciousness; sustained thought is associated with a limited range. Applied thought is like the stretching out of wings; sustained thought is like the flapping of wings.

original: viya. So pana nesaṃ viseso paṭhamadutiyajjhānesu pākaṭo hoti. Ubhopi panete sampayuttadhammapadaṭṭhānā.

original: Piṇayatīti pīti. Sā sampiyāyanalakkhaṇā, kāyacittapīṇanarasā, pharaṇarasā vā, odagyapaccupaṭṭhānā, somanassasahagatacittapadaṭṭhānā.

translated: Rapturous is the meaning of “happiness” . Its characteristic is the gladdening of beings. Its function is to refresh the body and the mind, or its function is to flood them. It is manifested as elation. It is dependent on associated states such as joy.

original: Vīrānaṃ bhāvo, kammaṃ vā vīriyaṃ, vividhena vā upāyena īrayitabbaṃ pavattayitabbanti

analyzed: sabbāsam sampattīnam mūlam hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: it should be regarded as the root of all attainments.

original: Eko aggo visayo assāti ekaggaṃ, cittaṃ, tassa bhāvo ekaggatā, cittassa ekaggatā cittekaggatā,🔽samādhissetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sā avisāraṇalakkhaṇā, sahajātānaṃ sampiṇḍanarasā nahānīyacuṇṇānaṃ🔽udakaṃ viya, upasamapaccupaṭṭhānā, ñāṇapaccupaṭṭhānā vā, sukhapadaṭṭhānā, akusalādisādhāraṇavasena
analyzed: ekaḥ aggaḥ visayaḥ assa ati ekaggam cittam tassa bhāvaḥ ekagga tā cittassa ekagga tā citta ekagga tā  samādhiḥ etam nāmam sā a visāraṇa lakkhaṇā sahajātānam sampiṇḍana rasā na hānīya cuṇṇānam  udakam viya upasama paccupaṭṭhānā ñāṇa paccupaṭṭhānā vā sukha padaṭṭhānā akusala ādi sādhāraṇa vasena
translated: It is “one-pointed” because it has one object , and the state of that is unification; unification of cognizance is unification of cognizance;🔽this is a name for concentration. Its characteristic is non-wavering; its function is to lump together what is associated with it, like water lumping together bath-powder and soap-nut powder;

original: panetthāpi paccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānāni vuttanayena yojetvā ñātabbāni. Nivāte dīpaccīnaṃ
analyzed: pana itthā api paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānāni vutta nayena yojetvā ñātabbāni nivāte dīpaccīnam
translated: its manifestation is tranquillization, or its manifestation is knowledge; its proximate cause is pleasure. But here too the manifestation and the basis should be construed as in the case of the faculties, and the general and particular bases should be construed as in the case of the powers.🔽In a place sheltered from the wind

original: ṭhiti viya cetaso ṭhitīti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: ṭhiti viya cetasaḥ ṭhiti iti daṭṭhabbā
translated: and steadiness of cognizance should be regarded as like the steadiness of the water.🔽And here, although the four things in the profitable group

original: Ettha ca kiñcāpi ārammaṇaṃ bhinditvā anupavisantā viya kusalapakkhe cattāro dhammā🔽ārammaṇaṃ ogāhanti saddhā sati ekaggatā paññāti, teneva saddhā “okappanā”ti vuttā,
analyzed: ettha ca kiñca api ārammaṇam bhinditvā anupavisantā viya kusala pakkhe cattāro dhammā  ārammaṇam ogāhanti saddhā sati ekagga tā paññā iti tena iva saddhā okappanā ati vuttā
translated: enter the object as though penetrating it without dividing it up,🔽still faith is called “adhesion” because it “adheres” to the object by inclining to it,🔽and mindfulness is called “non-forgetting” because it “does not forget” the object by not letting it go,🔽and concentration is called “steadiness” because it “steadies” the object by not moving it,

original: sati ca “apilāpanā”ti, ekaggatā “avaṭṭhitī”ti, paññā “pariyogāhanā”ti ca vuttā. Akusalapakkhe
analyzed: sati ca apilāpanā ati ekagga tā avaṭṭhiti iti paññā pariyogāhanā iti ca vuttā akusala pakkhe
translated: and understanding is called “comprehensive-grasping” because it “comprehensively grasps” the object by investigating it.🔽And although the three things in the unprofitable group

original: ca tayo taṇhā diṭṭhi avijjāti. Tena te eva “oghā”ti vuttā. Tathāpi nesaṃ lakkhaṇādito
analyzed: ca tayo taṇhā diṭṭhi avijjā ti tena te eva oghā ti vuttā tathā api na īsam lakkhaṇa āditaḥ
translated: enter the object as though penetrating it without dividing it up, still craving is called “flooding” because it “floods” the object by flowing over it,🔽and views are called “grasping” because they “grasp” the object by misrepresenting it,🔽and ignorance is called “overwhelming” because it “overwhelms” the object by concealing it.

original: nānattampi siddhameva. Akusalapakkhe pana ekaggatā uddhaccasamāgatattā “ogāhanā”ti🔽na vuttā. Akusaladhammā hi ekavisaye sampiṇḍanakiccena samādhinā yuttāpi udakasittarajuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nānattam pi siddham eva akusala pakkhe pana ekagga tā uddhacca samāgata ttā ogāhanā ti  na vuttāḥ akusala dhammāḥ hi eka visaye sampiṇḍana kiccena samādhinā yuttā api
translated: But although that is so, their individual characteristics, etc.,🔽are nevertheless established.🔽But in the unprofitable group there is no steadiness of cognizance called “flooding” because it is associated with agitation.🔽For unprofitable states, though associated with concentration in the act of lumping together in a single field, are by nature scattered, like water sprinkled on a sandy bank.

original: viya taṅkhaṇaññeva vikiraṇasabhāvā honti. Teneva hettha upacārappanāppatti na hoti,
analyzed: viya vikiraṇa sabhāvāḥ honti tena iva ha ittha upacāra ppanā appatti na hoti
translated: That is why there is no acquisition of access and of absorption here.

original: kusaladhammā pana yasmā udakaṃ āsiñcitvā āsiñcitvā ākoṭanamajjanādīni katvā upalittaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kusala dhammā pana yasmai udakam āsiñcitvā āsiñcitvā ākoṭana majjana ādīni katvā upalitta ṭhānam
translated: But profitable states are like the place that is wetted by sprinkling and sprinkling again and so on by striking and submerging,

original: viya sakalampi divasaṃ niccalapavattanasamatthāti upacārappanāppattāpi hoti, tasmā
analyzed: sakalam pi divasam niccala pavattana samatthā ati upacāra ppanā appattā api hoti tasmā
translated: and they are capable of being directed on to the object without moving for the whole day, and so they reach access and absorption.

original: tattha ogāhanāti vuttāti gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha ogāhanā ati vuttā iti gahetabbam
translated: So it should be understood that “entering” is said of them.

original: Jīvanti tena, jīvanamattaṃ vā tanti jīvitaṃ, taṃ sahajātānupālanalakkhaṇaṃ, tesaṃ
analyzed: jīvanti tena jīvana mattam vā tanti jīvitam tam sahajāta anupālana lakkhaṇam tesam
translated: It is life, or it is just the living, that is jīvita. Its characteristic is the keeping-together of the conascent states.

original: pavattanarasaṃ, tesaññeva ṭhapanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, yāpayitabbadhammapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Attano
analyzed: pavattana rasam tesañ eva ṭhapana paccupaṭṭhānam yāpayitabba dhamma padaṭṭhānam attano
translated: Its function is to cause their occurrence. It is manifested as their stationing. Its proximate cause is the states that have to be kept going.

original: ṭhitikkhaṇe eva cetaṃ te dhamme anupāleti udakaṃ viya uppalādīni, na bhaṅgakkhaṇe.
analyzed: ṭhiti kkhaṇe eva ca itam te dhamme anupāleti udakam viya uppala ādīni na bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: For it keeps those states together at the moment of their presence, as it were, with water, like the water that keeps the flowers together. It does not do so at the moment of their dissolution.

original: Sayaṃ bhijjamānattā sayaṃ pavattitadhammasambandheneva pavattati niyāmako viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: sayam bhijjamāna ttā sayam pavattita dhamma sambandhena iva pavattati niyāmakaḥ viyā ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: It should be regarded as occurring only by the connection of the states that occur by themselves, as does a supervisor.

original: Saddahanti etāya, sayaṃ vā saddahati, saddahanamattaṃ vā esāti saddhā. Sā saddahanalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: saddahanti etāya sayam vā saddahati saddahana mattam vā esā ati saddhā sā saddahana lakkhaṇā
translated: It is faith because of believing by means of it or because of one’s own believing or because of mere believing. Its characteristic is believing.

original: okappanalakkhaṇā vā, pasādanarasā udakappasādakamaṇi viya, pakkhandanarasā vā oghuttārakavīrapuriso
analyzed: okappana lakkhaṇā vā pasādana rasāḥ udaka ppasāda kamaṇi viya pakkhandana rasāḥ vā oghuttāraka vīra puriso
translated: Or its characteristic is steadying, its function is to clarify, like the water-purifying gem, or its function is to cross over, like the hero who rescues people from a flood;

original: viya, akālusiyapaccupaṭṭhānā, adhimuttipaccupaṭṭhānā vā, saddheyyavatthupadaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: akālusiya paccupaṭṭhānā adhimutti paccupaṭṭhānā vā saddheyya vatthu padaṭṭhānā
translated: its proximate cause is non-remorse, or its proximate cause is resolve, or its proximate cause is a trustworthy matter,

original: saddhammasavanādisotāpattiyaṅgapadaṭṭhānā vā, hatthavittabījāni viya daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: vā hattha vitta bījāni viya daṭṭhabbā
translated: or its proximate cause is the factors of stream-entry, such as listening to the true Dhamma, and it should be regarded as the seeds of the hand-to-mouth man.

original: Saranti tāya, sayaṃ vā sarati, saraṇamattameva vā esāti sati. Sā apilāpanalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: saranti tāya sayam vā sarati saraṇa mattam eva vā sati sā apilāpana lakkhaṇā
translated: It is mindfulness because it remembers , or because it is itself remembered , or because it is just mere remembering . Its characteristic is non-forgetting,

original: asammosanarasā, ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā, visayābhimukhabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā vā, thirasaññāpadaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: a sammosana rasāḥ ārakkha paccupaṭṭhānāḥ visaya abhimukha bhāva paccupaṭṭhānāḥ vā thira saññā padaṭṭhānāḥ
translated: its function is not to be inattentive, its manifestation is non-confusion, or its manifestation is the state of being opposed to confusion; its proximate cause is the perception of stability,🔽or its proximate cause is the foundations of mindfulness beginning with the body, and it should be regarded as a pillar because it is firmly placed in the object,

original: kāyādisatipaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānā vā. Ārammaṇe daḷhapatiṭṭhitattā pana esikā viya, cakkhudvārādirakkhaṇato
analyzed: kāya ādi sati paṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānā vā ārammaṇe daḷha patiṭṭhita ttā pana esikā viya cakkhu dvāra ādi rakkhaṇato
translated: or as a door-keeper because it guards the door of the sense faculties.

original: dovāriko viya ca daṭṭhabbā.🔽Kāyaduccaritādīhi hirīyatīti hirī, lajjāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tehiyeva ottappatīti ottappaṃ,
analyzed: dovārikaḥ viya ca daṭṭhabbā 🔽kāya duccarita ādīhi hirīyati iti hirī adhivacanam ottappati iti ottappam
translated: It is conscience because of shrinking from wrongdoing,🔽or it is shame because of shrinking from wrongdoing,

original: pāpato ubbegassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tattha pāpato jigucchanalakkhaṇā hirī, uttāsalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: pāpataḥ ubbegassa itam adhivacanam tattha pāpataḥ jigucchana lakkhaṇā hirī uttāsa lakkhaṇam
translated: and this is a term for fear of evil. Herein, conscience has the characteristic of disgust with evil;

original: ottappaṃ. Lajjanākārena pāpakānaṃ akaraṇarasā hirī, uttāsākārena ottappaṃ. Asucimakkhitassa,🔽aggisantattassa ca ayoguḷassa gahetuṃ avisahanaṃ viya etesaṃ yathākkamaṃ jigucchanasantāsākārehi🔽pāpākaraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Vuttākāreneva ca pāpato saṃkocanapaccupaṭṭhānāni etāni, attaparagāravapadaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: ottappam lajjana ākārena pāpakānam a karaṇa rasā hirī uttāsa ākārena ottappam asuci makkhitassa  aggi santattassa ca ayaḥ guḷassa gahetum a visahanam viya etesam yathākkamam jigucchana santāsa ākārehi  pāpa ākaraṇam veditabbam vutta ākārena iva ca pāpataḥ saṃkocana paccupaṭṭhānāni etāni atta para gārava padaṭṭhānāni
translated: shame has the characteristic of dread of it. Their function is to cause avoidance of evil respectively by means of disgust and by means of dread. Just as one who is not disgusted by the filthiness of excrement will handle it if he is in a hurry to get a job done, but one who is disgusted by it will not do so even if he is in a hurry, so too, when a man is disgusted with evil he avoids it;🔽and just as one who is not afraid of a red-hot metal ball will take hold of it if he is in a hurry to get a job done, but one who is afraid of it will not do so even if he is in a hurry, so too, when a man is afraid of evil he avoids it. Their manifestation is the attitude of disgust and the attitude of dread respectively.🔽Their proximate causes are the avoidance of evil and the avoidance of disgrace respectively. They should be regarded as like a family’s old nanny goat and its old nanny goat’s kid, and as the world’s guardian deities.🔽But their origination is stated in the Description of the Dependent Origination of the Factors of Existence thus, “With ignorance as condition there are volitional formations” ,

original: kulavadhūvesiyā bhāvo viya, lokapālakāni cāti daṭṭhabbāni. Ubhinnampi panesaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kula vadhū vesiyā bhāvaḥ viya lokapālakāni ca ati daṭṭhabbāni ubhinnam pi pana esam samuṭṭhānam
translated: and their predominance is stated in the Description of the Factors of the Noble Path thus, “With the support of virtue, depending on virtue, having virtue as the basis, with non-remorse as condition there is gladness” , and so on. Their characteristic, etc., should be understood as already described under the description of the faculties.

original: adhipati sabhāvo lakkhaṇena cāti mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā yathākkamaṃ ajjhattabahiddhāsamuṭṭhānatā,
analyzed: adhipati sabhāvaḥ lakkhaṇena ca ati mātikam ṭhapetvā yathākkamam ajjhatta bahiddhā samuṭṭhāna tā
translated: They originate respectively from the internal and the external.

original: attalokādhipatitā, lajjābhayasabhāvasaṇṭhitatā, sappatissavavajjabhayadassāvitālakkhaṇatā
analyzed: atta loka adhipati tā lajjā bhaya sabhāva saṇṭhita tā sappatissava vajja bhaya dassāvita a lakkhaṇa tā
translated: They have the self and the world as their overlord. They are respectively collected together by shame and dread. Their characteristics are respectively non-transgression through fear of blame and non-transgression through fear of suffering.

original: ca aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ vitthārato vibhattā, atthikehi taṃ tattheva gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca aṭṭhasāliniyam vitthārataḥ vibhattā atthikehi tat tattha eva gahetabbam
translated: and in the Aṭṭhasālinī they are analyzed in detail. Those who want to know can look them up there.

original: Na lubbhati etena, sayaṃ vā na lubbhati, alubbhanamattameva vā tanti alobho. Adosāmohesupi🔽eseva nayo. Tesu alobho ārammaṇe cittassa agedhalakkhaṇo, alaggabhāvalakkhaṇo vā
analyzed: na lubbhati etena sayam vā na lubbhati a lubbhana mattam eva vā alobhaḥ a dosa a mohesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ tesu alobho ārammaṇe cittassa agedha lakkhaṇaḥ alagga bhāva lakkhaṇaḥ vā
translated: It is not greedy, or it does not itself greed, or it is just the state of not being greedy: thus it is non-greed .🔽The same method of explanation applies to non-hate and non-delusion.

original: kamaladale jalabindu viya, apariggaharaso muttabhikkhu viya, anallīnabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno
analyzed: kamala dale jala bindu viya a pariggaha rasaḥ mutta bhikkhu viya an allīna bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Herein, non-greed has the characteristic of non-attachment to an object, or the characteristic of non-sticking to it, like a drop of water on a lotus leaf; its function is to taste the unpossessed ; it is manifested as non-addiction, like a monk free from craving;

original: asucimhi patitapuriso viya.🔽Adoso acaṇḍikkalakkhaṇo, avirodhalakkhaṇo vā anukūlamitto viya, āghātavinayanaraso, pariḷāhavinayanaraso vā candanaṃ viya, sommabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno puṇṇacando viya.
analyzed: asucimhi patita purisaḥ  adosaḥ a caṇḍikka lakkhaṇaḥ a virodha lakkhaṇaḥ vā anukūla mittaḥ viya āghāta vinayana raso pariḷāha vinayana raso vā candanam viya somma bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno puṇṇa candaḥ viya
translated: like a man who has fallen into filth.🔽Non-hate has the characteristic of non-ill-will, or the characteristic of non-opposition, like a friendly disposition; its function is to remove annoyance, or its function is to remove fever, like sandalwood; it is manifested as amiability, like the full moon.

original: Amoho yathāsabhāvappaṭivedhalakkhaṇo, akkhalitappaṭivedhalakkhaṇo vā kusalissāsakkhittausuppaṭivedho
analyzed: amohaḥ yathā sabhāva ppaṭivedha lakkhaṇaḥ akkhalita ppaṭivedha lakkhaṇaḥ vā
translated: Non-delusion has the characteristic of penetration of individual essences as they are, or the characteristic of unerring penetration, like the penetration of a skilled surgeon’s needle;

original: viya, visayobhāsanaraso anuddhaṭo padīpo viya, asammohapaccupaṭṭhāno araññagatasudesako
analyzed: viya visaya ubhāsana rasaḥ anuddhaṭaḥ padīpaḥ viya asammoha paccupaṭṭhāno arañña gata sudesako
translated: like a lamp that has been lit, like a guide who goes in front of those who are going to a place they have never reached before.

original: viya. Tayopi cete sabbakusalānaṃ mūlabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Apica alobho cettha dānahetu, adoso sīlahetu, amoho bhāvanāhetu. Tīhipi cetehi yathāpaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: viya tayo pi ca ite sabba kusalānam mūla bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā  apica alobho ca ittha dāna hetu adoso sīla hetu amohaḥ bhāvanā hetu tīhi pi cetehi yathā paṭipāṭiyā
translated: And all these three should be regarded as the root of all profitable things.🔽Moreover, greedlessness here is the cause of giving, non-hate the cause of virtue, non-delusion the cause of development.🔽And by these three, respectively, there is the perception of renunciation, the perception of non-ill will, and the perception of harmlessness.

original: nekkhammasaññā abyāpādasaññā avihiṃsāsaññā honti, tathā adhikaūnaviparītaggahaṇānaṃ
analyzed: nekkhamma saññāḥ a byāpāda saññāḥ a vihiṃsā saññāḥ honti tathā adhika ūna viparīta ggahaṇānam
translated: And there is no taking of what is not the right occasion, no over-hastiness, no over-slowness,🔽no separation from the dear, no coming together with the not dear, no failure to obtain desired and agreeable things,

original: abhāvo, tathā piyavippayogaappiyasampayogaicchitālābhadukkhānaṃ, jātijarāmaraṇadukkhānaṃ,
analyzed: abhāvaḥ tathā piya vippayoga appiya sampayoga ecchita alābha dukkhānaṃ jāti jarā maraṇa dukkhānaṃ
translated: no suffering due to birth, ageing, disease, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair,🔽no lack of the requisites of life, no lack of friends, no lack of the requisites of virtue,

original: petanirayatiracchānagatidukkhānañca abhāvo, tathā bhogamittaattasampattipaccayabhāvo,🔽tathā kāmasukhapariccāgaattakilamathapariccāgamajjhimapaṭipattīnaṃ sambhavo, tathā
analyzed: abhāvo tathā bhoga mitta atta sampatti paccaya bhāvo  tathā kāma sukha pariccāga atta kilamatha pariccāga majjhima paṭipattīnam sambhavaḥ tathā
translated: no lack of the requisites of development,

original: asubhaappamāṇadhātusaññānaṃ, aniccadukkhaanattasaññānaṃ, dibbabrahmaariyavihārānañca
analyzed: asubha appamāṇa dhātu saññānam anicca dukkha anatta saññānam
translated: no lack of the perception of foulness, of mindfulness of in-and-out breathing, of the perception of impermanence, of the perception of suffering, of the perception of non-self, no lack of the divine abidings, of the meditations, of the immaterial states, of the ariyan concentration, of the ariyan insight, of the ariyan knowledge, of the ariyan liberation.

original: sambhavo hotīti evamādīhi nayehi tesaṃ vitthāro veditabbo.🔽Ettha ca amoho nāma paññā, sā pajānanalakkhaṇā. Viññāṇaṃ vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saññā
analyzed: sambhavaḥ hoti iti evamādīhi nayehi tesam vitthāraḥ veditabbo  ettha ca amohaḥ nāma paññā sā pajānana lakkhaṇā viññāṇam vijānana lakkhaṇam saññā
translated: The details should be understood in the way given in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽Herein, non-delusion is understanding. Its characteristic is the act of penetrating. Consciousness has the characteristic of the act of cognizing. Perception has the characteristic of perceiving.

original: sañjānanalakkhaṇā. Kiṃ panetāsaṃ saññāviññāṇapaññānaṃ nānattanti? Sañjānanavijānanapajānanameva.🔽Etāsaṃ hi samānepi jānanabhāve saññāya “nīlaṃ pīta”ntiādinā puna saññuppādakamattena🔽ākārena sañjānanamattameva hoti, ajātabuddhidārakassa viya cittavaṭṭādibhāvamattākārena🔽kahāpaṇādidassanaṃ, na tato uddhaṃ. Viññāṇassa pana yathāvuttena ca tato visiṭṭhena🔽ca aniccādinā ākārena jānanaṃ hoti, gāmikapurisassa viya yathāvuttena ceva upabhogārahatādinā
analyzed: sañjānana lakkhaṇā kim pana etāsam saññā viññāṇa paññānam nānattanti sañjānana vijānana pajānanam eva  etāsam hi samāne pi jānana bhāve saññāya nīlam pītam ti ādinā puna saññu ppādaka mattena  ākārena sañjānana mattam eva hoti ajāta buddhi dārakassa viya citta vaṭṭa ādi bhāva matta ākārena  kahāpaṇa ādi dassanam na tatas uddham viññāṇassa pana yathā vuttena ca tatas visiṭṭhena  ca anicca ādinā ākārena jānanam hoti gāmika purisassa viya yathā vuttena ca iva upabhoga arahat ādinā
translated: But what is the difference between perception, consciousness, and understanding? The act of perceiving, the act of cognizing, and the act of penetrating.

original: ca ākārena kahāpaṇādidassanaṃ, na tato uddhaṃ. Paññāya pana tehi ca yathāvuttehi
analyzed: ca ākārena kahāpaṇa ādi dassanam na tatas uddham paññāya pana tehi ca yathā vuttehi
translated: For although these three have the common characteristic of knowing, perception is only the act of perceiving in the sense of the occurrence of perception again and again, as “blue,” as “yellow,” and so on, like the mere seeing of coins, etc., as circles by one whose eye is affected with ophthalmia, and it goes no further than that. But consciousness has the act of cognizing in the way already stated and also in the distinctive way of knowing impermanence, etc., like the seeing of coins, etc., by a country person who knows their value, and it goes no further than that. But understanding has the act of penetrating in the way already stated and also in the distinctive way of knowing the three characteristics, like the seeing of coins, etc., by a merchant who knows their value, and it goes further than that.

original: nānappakārehi ca maggapātubhāvādihetūhi sabbehi ākārehi pajānanaṃ hoti, heraññikassa
analyzed: nānā pakārehi ca magga pātubhāva ādi hetūhi sabbehi ākārehi pajānanam hoti heraññikassa
translated: and it is understood in all aspects by means of the various kinds of causes such as the manifestation of the path.

original: viya yathāvuttehi ceva chekakūṭaaddhasārādisabbehi ākārehi ca kahāpaṇādidassanaṃ.
analyzed: viya yathā vuttehi ca iva cheka kūṭa addhasāra ādi sabbehi ākārehi ca kahāpaṇa ādi dassanam
translated: And understanding comes about in all aspects by means of the various kinds of causes such as the manifestation of the path, just as the man with the gold sees the kahāpaṇa coin in all its aspects, that is to say, as round, as having an edge, as having a centre boss, as being made of copper, as being the colour of copper, as having a certain weight, as being suitable for certain transactions and unsuitable for others.

original: Paññāya hi ajānitabbaṃ nāma natthi. Evaṃ sañjānanavijānanapajānanākārehi etāsaṃ nānattaṃ🔽veditabbaṃ. Ettha ca cakkhuviññāṇādīni vitakkavīriyādisahajātapaccayavirahato rūpādīsu
analyzed: paññāya hi a jānitabbam nāma natthi evam sañjānana vijānana pajānana ākārehi etāsam nānattam  veditabbam ettha ca cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni vitakka vīriya ādi sahajāta paccaya virahato rūpa ādīsu
translated: For there is nothing that is not to be known by understanding. This is how their difference should be understood as to the mode of their appearance as perceiving, discerning, and knowing.

original: saññākiccato adhikavijānanakiccaṃ kātuṃ na sakkonti, balapariṇāyakāni viya senaṅgāni🔽paññānuvattakāneva hontīti veditabbāni. Tenāha bhagavā “pañcahi viññāṇehi na kañci
analyzed: saññā kiccataḥ adhika vijānana kiccam kātum na sakkonti bala pariṇāyakāni viya senaṅgāni  paññā anuvattakāni eva honti iti veditabbāni tena āha bhagavā pañcahi viññāṇehi na kañci
translated: And here the eye consciousness, etc., are unable to perform the function of discerning because they lack the conditions of being associated with applied thought, etc., and because they have the function of perceiving only the object’s appearance as a visible datum, etc.,🔽just as the army’s generals and leaders are unable to do the work of the army.

original: dhammaṃ paṭivijānāti aññatra abhinipātamattā”tiādi.
analyzed: dhammam paṭivijānāti aññatra abhinipāta matta atiādi
translated: They should be understood as merely following after understanding. Hence it is said: “By means of the five kinds of consciousness he perceives no state of any kind whatever, only he comes to the end of his life span” , and so on.

original: Kāyapassambhanaṃ kāyapassaddhi. Cittapassambhanaṃ cittapassaddhi. Kāyoti panettha
analyzed: kāya passambhanam kāya passaddhi citta passambhanam citta passaddhi kāyaḥ ti pana ittha
translated: Tranquillization of the body is bodily tranquillity. Tranquillization of cognizance is cognizance tranquillity. Herein,

original: vedanādayo tayo khandhā. Ubhopi panetā kāyacittadarathavūpasamalakkhaṇā, kāyacittadarathanimmaddanarasā,🔽kāyacittānaṃ aparipphandasītibhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, kāyacittapadaṭṭhānā. Kāyacittānañca
analyzed: vedanā ādayo tayo khandhā ubho pi panetā kāya citta daratha vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya citta daratha nimmaddana rasā  kāya cittānam a paripphanda sīti bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā kāya cittānam ca
translated: The three aggregates beginning with feeling are the mental body. Both are characterized by the quieting of the disturbance of body and mind; their function is to eliminate the disturbance of body and mind;

original: avūpasamakarauddhaccādikilesapaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: a vūpasama kara auddhacca ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: their manifestation is the state of non-agitation of body and mind; their proximate cause is body and mind. They should be regarded as the opposites of the defilements such as agitation, etc., which prevent the quieting of body and mind.

original: Kāyalahubhāvo kāyalahutā. Cittalahubhāvo cittalahutā. Evaṃ uparipi padattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: kāya lahu bhāvaḥ kāya lahu tā citta lahu bhāvaḥ citta lahu tā evam upari pi padattho daṭṭhabbo
translated: Lightness of body is the lightness of the body. Lightness of mind is the lightness of the mind. The meaning of the words should be understood in this way throughout.

original: Kāyacittānaṃ garubhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā kāyalahutā, cittalahutā ca, tesaṃ garubhāvanimmaddanarasā,
analyzed: kāya cittānam garu bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya lahu tā citta lahu tā ca tesam garu bhāva nimmaddana rasā
translated: Lightness of body and lightness of mind are characterized by the quieting of the heaviness of body and mind; their function is to eliminate the heaviness of body and mind;

original: tesaṃ adandhatāpaccupaṭṭhānā, tesaṃ garubhāvakarathinamiddhādikilesapaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tesam adandha tā paccupaṭṭhānā tesam garu bhāva karathinamiddha ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: their manifestation is the state of non-sluggishness of body and mind; they should be regarded as the opposites of the defilements such as sluggishness, drowsiness, etc., which cause the heaviness of body and mind.

original: Kāyacittānaṃ thaddhabhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā kāyamudutā, cittamudutā ca, tesaṃ thaddhabhāvanimmaddanarasā,
analyzed: kāya cittānam thaddha bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya mudu tā citta mudu tā ca tesam thaddha bhāva nimmaddana rasā
translated: Wieldiness of body and wieldiness of mind are characterized by the quieting of unwieldiness of body and mind; their function is to eliminate unwieldiness of body and mind;

original: appaṭighātapaccupaṭṭhānā, kāyacittapadaṭṭhānā, tesaṃ thaddhabhāvakaradiṭṭhimānādikilesapaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Kāyacittānaṃ akammaññabhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā kāyakammaññatā, cittakammaññatā ca, tesaṃ
analyzed: appaṭighāta paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā tesam thaddha bhāva kara diṭṭhi māna ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā  kāya cittānam akammañña bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya kammañña tā citta kammañña tā ca tesam
translated: They should be regarded as having non-resistance as their manifestation, the body and the mind as their proximate cause, and the defilements of false view, conceit, etc., which cause rigidity as their opponent.🔽Corporeality and cognizance’s condition of being malleable and wieldy have the characteristic of allaying unmalleability and unwieldliness. Their function is to overcome unmalleability and unwieldliness.

original: akammaññabhāvanimmaddanarasā, kāyacittānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇasampattipaccupaṭṭhānā, tesaṃ🔽akammaññabhāvakarāvasesanīvaraṇapaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā. Pasādanīyavatthūsu pasādāvahā,
analyzed: akammañña bhāva nimmaddana rasā kāya cittānam ārammaṇa karaṇa sampatti paccupaṭṭhānā tesam  akammañña bhāva kara avasesa nīvaraṇa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā pasādanīya vatthūsu pasāda āvahā
translated: They are manifested as the excellence of making the body and the mind the resort. They should be regarded as having the remaining hindrances that cause unmalleability and unwieldliness as their opponent.

original: hitakiriyāsu viniyogakkhamabhāvāvahā suvaṇṇavisuddhi viyāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: hita kiriyāsu viniyoga khama bhāva āvahā viyā ti daṭṭhabbā
translated: They should be regarded as producing confidence in the objects that inspire confidence, and as producing the condition of being amenable to direction in the services that are helpful, like the purification of gold.

original: Kāyacittānaṃ agelaññabhāvalakkhaṇā kāyapāguññatā, cittapāguññatā ca, tesaṃ gelaññanimmaddanarasā,
analyzed: kāya cittānam a gelañña bhāva lakkhaṇā kāya pāguñña tā citta pāguñña tā ca tesam gelañña nimmaddana rasā
translated: Corporeality and cognizance’s condition of being wieldy have the characteristic of non-stubbornness of body and mind. Their function is to overcome stubbornness.

original: nirādīnavapaccupaṭṭhānā, tesaṃ gelaññakaraassaddhiyādikilesapaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: nirādīnava paccupaṭṭhānā tesam gelañña kara assaddhi yā ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: They are manifested as the absence of disadvantage. They should be regarded as having faith, etc., which cause stubbornness as their opponent.

original: Kāyacittānaṃ ajjavalakkhaṇā kāyujukatā, cittujukatā ca, tesaṃ kuṭilabhāvanimmaddanarasā,
analyzed: kāya cittānaṃ ajjava lakkhaṇā kāya ujuka tā citta ujuka tā ca tesam kuṭila bhāva nimmaddana rasā
translated: Pliancy of body and pliancy of mind, which have the characteristic of flexibility of body and mind, the function of removing rigidity,

original: ajimhatāpaccupaṭṭhānā, tesaṃ kuṭilabhāvakaramāyāsāṭheyyādipaṭipakkhabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: a jimha tā paccupaṭṭhānā tesam kuṭila bhāva kara māyā sāṭheyya ādi paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: the manifestation of unbending, should be regarded as the opposites of the stiffness, laziness, etc., that cause rigidity.

original: Sabbepete passaddhiādayo dhammā kāyacittapadaṭṭhānāti veditabbā.
analyzed: sabbe pete passaddhi ādayaḥ dhammā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā ti veditabbā
translated: And all these beginning with tranquillity should be understood as having as their proximate cause the four establishments of mindfulness.

original: Kiṃ panettha passaddhādayo dhammā uddhaccādiṃ vinodetuṃ na sakkonti, yena ime passaddhādayo
analyzed: kim pana ittha passaddha ādayaḥ dhammāḥ uddhacca ādim vinodetum na sakkonti yena ime passaddha ādayaḥ
translated: But why are tranquillity, etc., not able to dispel agitation, etc., so that they are not separately classified as opposites for them?

original: dhammā na visuṃ vibhattāti? No na sakkonti, ime pana sahitā eva sakkonti, itarathā🔽tesaṃ uppattiyā eva asambhavato. Yathā vā passaddhādīsu vijjamānesu mohāhirikādīnaṃ
analyzed: dhammā na visum vibhattā ati no na sakkonti ime pana sahitāḥ eva sakkonti itarathā  tesam uppattiyāḥ eva asambhavataḥ yathā vā passaddha ādīsu vijjamānesu moha āhirika ādīnam
translated: They are able, but they are able only when combined, not individually,🔽because they cannot arise individually in the way described.🔽Or just as non-delusion and shame arise as the opposites of delusion and absence of shame, respectively, in the case of tranquillity, etc.,

original: ujupaṭipakkhabhāvena amohahiriādayo honti, evametepi uddhaccādiujupaṭipakkhabhāvena
