analyzed: uju paṭipakkha bhāvena amoha hiri ādayaḥ honti evam ete api uddhacca ādi uju paṭipakkha bhāvena
translated: so these should be recognized as the opposites of agitation, etc., respectively, as desired.

original: icchitabbāti gahetabbā. Yasmā cettha dvīhi dvīhi eva yathāsakaṃ paṭipakkhā haritabbā,
analyzed: icchitabbā ati gahetabbā yasmai ca ittha dvīhi dvīhi eva yathāsakam paṭipakkhā haritabbā
translated: But since each of the two is to be taken as the opposite of each of the two,

original: tasmā te ete eva dvidhā vibhattā, na amohādayoti ñātabbā.
analyzed: tasmā te ete eva dvidhā vibhattāḥ na amoha ādayaḥ iti ñātabbā
translated: So they should be understood as twofold only, not as three.

original: Yevāpanakesu chandoti kattukāmatāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, tasmā so kattukāmatālakkhaṇo,
analyzed: yevāpanakesu chandaḥ ti kattu kāma tāya itam adhivacanam tasmā saḥ kattu kāma tā lakkhaṇo
translated: Interest is a term for desire to act. Its characteristic is desire to act.

original: ārammaṇapariyesanaraso, ārammaṇena atthikatāpaccupaṭṭhāno, tadevassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇa pariyesana rasaḥ ārammaṇena atthika tā paccupaṭṭhāno tat eva assa padaṭṭhānam
translated: Its function is seeking an object. It is manifested as the need for an object. Its proximate cause is that same object.

original: Ārammaṇaggahaṇe cāyaṃ cetaso hatthappasāraṇaṃ viya daṭṭhabbo. Ayañca yasmā virajjitabbādīsupi
analyzed: ārammaṇa ggahaṇe ca ayam cetasaḥ hattha ppasāraṇam viya daṭṭhabbaḥ ayam ca yasmā virajjitabba ādīsu pi
translated: And it should be regarded as the thrusting forward of the mind towards the apprehension of an object.

original: nekkhammādinā saha lobhavisadisena kattukāmatākārena pavattati, tasmā asekhānampi
analyzed: nekkhamma ādinā saha lobha visadisena kattu kāma tā ākārena pavattati tasmai
translated: And this occurs in the form of desire to act, which is the opposite of greed, in the case of what is to be disinterested in, etc.,🔽and so it arises even in the case of those who are without greed.

original: uppajjati. Lobho pana subhasukhādivipallāsapubbakena abhisaṅgākāreneva pavattatīti
analyzed: uppajjati lobhaḥ pana subha sukha ādi vipallāsa pubbakena abhisaṅga ākārena iva pavattati iti
translated: But greed occurs only in the form of cleaving, which is preceded by perversion about what is beautiful and pleasant, etc.

original: ayametesaṃ viseso. Evaṃ mettākaruṇādīnampi lobhādīhi viseso yathānurūpaṃ ñātabbo.
analyzed: ayam etesam visesaḥ evam mettā karuṇā ādīnam pi lobha ādīhi visesaḥ yathānurūpam ñātabbo
translated: This is the difference between them. And the difference between greed, etc., and loving- kindness, compassion, etc., should be understood in the same way as appropriate in each case.

original: Adhimuccanaṃ adhimokkho. So sanniṭṭhānalakkhaṇo, asaṃsappanaraso, nicchayapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: adhimuccanam adhimokkhaḥ so sanniṭṭhāna lakkhaṇaḥ a saṃsappana rasaḥ nicchaya paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Resolve is the resolving of consciousness and its concomitants upon an object. Its characteristic is deciding. Its function is not to waver. It is manifested as non- vacillation.

original: sanniṭṭhātabbadhammapadaṭṭhāno, ārammaṇe niccalabhāvena indakhīlo viya daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ārammaṇe niccala bhāvena inda khīlaḥ viya daṭṭhabbaḥ
translated: It should be regarded as a stake in that it is unshakable in its object.

original: Nanu ca saddhāpi adhimokkhoti vuccati. Tathā hi adhimokkhalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti🔽saddhindriyanti vuccatīti? Saccaṃ, sā ca kho sampasādanabhāvena adhimokkho, ayaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca saddhā api adhimokkhaḥ ti vuccati tathā hi adhimokkha lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti  saddhindriyam ti vuccati iti saccam sā ca kho sampasādana bhāvena adhimokkhaḥ ayam
translated: But is not faith also called resolution? For it is said: “Faith has the characteristic of confidence. It functions as a state of being non-doubting. Its manifestation is non-confusion. Its footing is a reason for confidence” .🔽And it is said: “It makes the mind masterfully act in resolution” .🔽And so it is called the faith faculty.

original: pana yathā tathā vā nicchayabhāvenāti na koci virodho.
analyzed: yathā tathā vā nicchaya bhāvena ati na koci virodhaḥ
translated: It is true, but that is resolution in the sense of confidence. This is resolution in the sense of certainty in some way or another. So there is no contradiction.

original: Kiriyā kāro, manasmiṃ kāro manasikāro, purimamanato visadisaṃ manaṃ karotītipi manasikāro,🔽svāyaṃ ārammaṇapaṭipādako vīthipaṭipādako javanapaṭipādakoti tippakāro, tattha ārammaṇapaṭipādako🔽idha manasikāro. So sāraṇalakkhaṇo, sampayuttānaṃ ārammaṇesu payojanaraso, ārammaṇābhimukhabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: kiriyā kāraḥ manasmin kāraḥ manasikāraḥ purima manataḥ visadisam manam karoti iti pi manasikāraḥ  ārammaṇa paṭipādakaḥ vīthi paṭipādakaḥ javana paṭipādako ti tippakāro tattha ārammaṇa paṭipādako  idha manasikāro so sāraṇa lakkhaṇo sampayuttānam ārammaṇesu payojana rasaḥ ārammaṇa abhimukha bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: The meaning of the word manasikāra is this: it is a doing in the mind , thus it is a mental doing ; it makes the mind different from what it was before, thus it is a mental doing ;

original: ārammaṇapadaṭṭhāno, saṅkhārakkhandhapariyāpanno. Ārammaṇapaṭipādakattena sampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇa padaṭṭhāno saṅkhāra khandha pariyāpanno ārammaṇa paṭipādaka ttena sampayuttānam
translated: It is of three kinds as placing an object in the mind , placing a cognitive series in the mind , and placing impulsion in the mind . Herein, placing an object in the mind is attention . It has the characteristic of directing . Its function is to bring about the placing of associated states on to an object. It is manifested as the state of being a condition for the arising of associated states.🔽Its proximate cause is an object. It is included in the formations aggregate.

original: sārathi viya daṭṭhabbo. Vīthipaṭipādakoti pana pañcadvārāvajjanassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: sārathi viya daṭṭhabbaḥ vīthi paṭipādakaḥ ti pana pañca dvāra āvajjanassa etam adhivacanam
translated: It should be regarded as the charioteer. The “path-maker” is a name for the five-door adverting.

original: Javanapaṭipādakoti manodvārāvajjanassa, na te idha adhippetā. Ettha cāyaṃ manasikāro🔽samannāhāramattākārena ārammaṇe sampayuttānaṃ payojako, cetanā cetokiriyābhāvena,
analyzed: javana paṭipādako ti manaḥ dvāra āvajjanassa na te idha adhippetāḥ ettha ca ayam manasikāro  samannāhāra matta ākārena ārammaṇe sampayuttānam cetanā cetaḥ kiriyā abhāvena
translated: The “runner” is a name for mind-door adverting. But these are not intended here. And here attention🔽is the instigator of the associated states in the object by its mere instigation; volition is the instigator by its act of willing;

original: vitakko pana saṅkappākārena, upanijjhāyanākārena ca abhiniropako. Teneva hettha padabhājanīye
analyzed: vitakko pana saṅkappa ākārena upanijjhāyana ākārena ca abhiniropako tena iva ha ittha pada bhājanīye
translated: and applied thought is the instigator by its act of directing the mind onto the object and by its act of adverting. That is why in the Padabhājaniya

original: “takko saṅkappoti ca, jhānaṅga”nti ca vuccatīti ayametesaṃ viseso.🔽Tesu tesu dhammesu majjhattatā tatramajjhattatā. Sā cittacetasikānaṃ samavāhitalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: takko saṅkappo ti ca jhānaṅganti ca vuccati iti ayam etesam viseso  tesu tesu dhammesu majjhatta tā tatra majjhatta tā sā citta cetasikānam samavāhita lakkhaṇā
translated: it is said, “Applied thought is called ‘thinking’ and ‘a factor of absorption’” . This is the difference here.🔽The “equanimity about things” is the neutrality of the mind towards those things. Its characteristic is the non-excess of either pleasure or pain in the mind and mental factors.

original: ūnādhikatānivāraṇarasā, pakkhapātupacchedanarasā vā, majjhattabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: ūna adhika tā nivāraṇa rasā pakkhapāta upacchedana rasā vā majjhatta bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Its function is to prevent excess. Its manifestation is non-excess.🔽It is based upon the associated states that occur in a balanced way.

original: samappavattasampayuttadhammapadaṭṭhānā. Sampayuttadhammānaṃ ajjhupekkhaṇena samappavattānaṃ
analyzed: sama ppavatta sampayutta dhamma padaṭṭhānā sampayutta dhammānam ajjhupekkhaṇena sama ppavattānam
translated: It is the neutrality of the associated states that occur in a balanced way.

original: ājānīyānaṃ ajjhupekkhakasārathi viya daṭṭhabbā.🔽Paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ hadayakampanaṃ karotīti karuṇā, kirati vā paradukkhaṃ hiṃsati
analyzed: ājānīyānam ajjhupekkhaka sārathi viya daṭṭhabbā  para dukkhe sati sādhūnam hadaya kampanam karoti iti karuṇā kirati vā para dukkham hiṃsati
translated: It should be regarded as the charioteer who looks after the thoroughbreds.

original: ca, kirīyati vā dukkhitesu pasārīyatīti karuṇā. Sā paradukkhāpanayanākārappavattilakkhaṇā,
analyzed: ca vā dukkhitesu pasārīyati iti karuṇā sā para dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavatti lakkhaṇā
translated: Compassion is the shaking of the heart of the good on seeing suffering in others; it is the scattering, the afflicting, of suffering, or it is the shaking, the spreading, of the one who suffers; thus it is compassion. It has the characteristic of occurring in the mode of removing the suffering of others.

original: paradukkhāsahanarasā, avihiṃsāpaccupaṭṭhānā, dukkhābhibhūtānaṃ anāthabhāvadassanapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: para dukkha asahana rasāḥ avihiṃsā paccupaṭṭhānāḥ dukkha abhibhūtānam anātha bhāva dassana padaṭṭhānā
translated: Its function is not to tolerate the suffering of others. It is manifested as non-cruelty. It is to be taken as having the appearance of seeing those overwhelmed by suffering as unfortunate.

original: Modanti tāya taṃsamaṅgino, sayaṃ vā modati, modanamattameva vā tanti muditā. Sā pamodalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: modanti tāya taṃsamaṅgino sayam vā modati modana mattam eva vā tanti muditā sā pamoda lakkhaṇā
translated: It is gladness because the sympathetic rejoice in it, or because one is glad oneself, or because it is mere gladness; thus it is gladness. It has the characteristic of gladdening.

original: anissāyanarasā, arativighātapaccupaṭṭhānā, sattānaṃ sampattidassanapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: a nissāyana rasā arati vighāta paccupaṭṭhānā sattānam sampatti dassana padaṭṭhānā
translated: Its function is to relish. It is manifested as the dispelling of discontent. It is to be taken as having the appearance of seeing the success of beings.

original: Kasmā panettha mettupekkhā na vuttāti? Pubbe gahitattā. Adoso eva hi sattesu hitapharaṇavasena
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha mettupekkhā na vuttā ati pubbe gahita ttā adosaḥ eva hi sattesu hita pharaṇa vasena
translated: But why is loving-kindness not mentioned here? Because it was mentioned above. For loving-kindness is simply non-hatred occurring in the mode of cherishing beings.

original: pavattiyaṃ mettā. Tatramajjhattatā eva ca iṭṭhāniṭṭhasattesu majjhattākārena pavattiyaṃ
analyzed: pavattiyam mettā tatra majjhatta tā eva ca iṭṭha aniṭṭha sattesu majjhatta ākārena pavattiyam
translated: And equanimity is simply the state of equilibrium in regard to beings who are desirable, undesirable, and so on.

original: upekkhā. Te ca dhammā niyatā, kevalaṃ pana nesaṃ sattesu mettupekkhābhāvena pavatti
analyzed: upekkhā te ca dhammā niyatā kevalam pana nesam sattesu mettu pekkhā bhāvena pavatti
translated: and equanimity. And these states are definite, but they occur only in beings through loving-kindness and equanimity.🔽They are called indefinite.

original: aniyatāti. Kāyaduccaritato virati kāyaduccaritavirati. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.🔽Lakkhaṇādito panetā tissopi kāyaduccaritādivatthūnaṃ avītikkamalakkhaṇā, tato saṃkocanarasā,
analyzed: aniyata ati kāya duccaritataḥ virati kāya duccarita virati  lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pana itā tissaḥ api kāya duccarita ādi vatthūnam avītikkama lakkhaṇā tatas saṃkocana rasā
translated: The abstinence from bodily misconduct is the abstinence from bodily misconduct. The same method applies in the case of the other two terms.🔽As to characteristic, etc.: the abstinence from bodily misconduct, etc., has the characteristic of non- transgression of the bases consisting in bodily misconduct, etc. Its function is to contract away from them.

original: tesaṃ akiriyapaccupaṭṭhānā, saddhāhirottappaappicchatādiguṇapadaṭṭhānā, pāpakiriyato
analyzed: tesam akiriya paccupaṭṭhānā saddhā hira uttappa appiccha tā ādi guṇa padaṭṭhānā pāpa kiriyato
translated: Its manifestation is non-performance of them. Its proximate cause is such special qualities as faith, conscience, shame, fewness of wishes, etc.

original: cittassa vimukhabhāvabhūtāti daṭṭhabbā. Evaṃ lakkhaṇādito vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: cittassa vimukha bhāva bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā evam lakkhaṇa āditaḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: It should be regarded as the mind’s turning away from evil-doing. This is how the exposition should be known as to characteristic, etc.

original: Saṅgahāti evaṃ ye ime imasmiṃ kāmāvacarapaṭhamakusale vibhattā ekūnacattālīsa dhammā,
analyzed: evam ye ime imasmin kāmāvacara paṭhama kusale vibhattāḥ ekūnacattālīsa dhammāḥ
translated: As to inclusion: these forty-nine states that have been analysed here in the first profitable consciousness of the sense sphere

original: sabbete khandhato catubbidhā honti – vedanākkhandho saññākkhandho saṅkhārakkhandho
analyzed: sabbe ete khandhato catubbidhāḥ honti vedanā kkhandhaḥ saññā kkhandho saṅkhāra kkhandho
translated: are all fourfold as aggregates, namely, as the feeling aggregate, the perception aggregate, the formations aggregate,

original: viññāṇakkhandhoti. Tattha rāsaṭṭhena somanassavedanā vedanākkhandho, tathā saññā
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandho ti tattha rāsaṭṭhena somanassa vedanā vedanā kkhandho tathā saññā
translated: and the consciousness aggregate. Herein, the pleasant feeling is the feeling aggregate in the sense of accumulation of pleasantness; so too the perception is the perception aggregate;

original: saññākkhandho, cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, avasesā phassādayo chattiṃsa dhammā saṅkhārakkhandhoti veditabbā.
analyzed: saññā kkhandho cittam viññāṇa kkhandho avasesā phassa ādayo chattiṃsa dhammā saṅkhāra kkhandho ti veditabbā
translated: The perception aggregate is the mind element and the perception component. The consciousness aggregate is the mind-consciousness element and the consciousness component. The remaining thirty-six dhammas are the formations aggregate.

original: Nanu ca yadi rāsaṭṭhena khandho, phassādīnaṃ tāva anekattā saṅkhārakkhandhatā yuttā,🔽kathaṃ pana vedanādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ khandhatāti? Upacārato. Paccekaṃ hi atītādibhedabhinnesu
analyzed: nanu ca yadi rāsaṭṭhena khandhaḥ phassa ādīnam tāva aneka ttā saṅkhāra kkhandha tā yuttā  katham pana vedanā ādīnam tiṇṇam khandha tā ati upacārato paccekam hi atīta ādi bheda bhinnesu
translated: But if the aggregate is in the sense of a heap, then since contact, etc., are many, it is proper that they should be the formations aggregate.🔽But how can feeling, etc., which are also many, be the other three aggregates? They are so called figuratively. For the term “aggregate,” which is established in the past, future, and present feeling, perception, and consciousness distinguished by the divisions of past, etc.,

original: vedanāsaññāviññāṇesu niruḷhopi khandha-saddo tadekadesesu ekekavedanādīsupi samudāyopacārena
analyzed: vedanā saññā viññāṇesu niruḷhaḥ api khandha saddaḥ tad eka desesu ekeka vedanā ādīsu pi samudāya upacārena
translated: is used figuratively in the individual feelings, etc., as a collective.

original: voharīyatīti tadekadesepi tabbohāro, yathā rukkhassa sākhāya chijjamānāya “rukkho
analyzed: voharīyati iti tad eka dese pi tad bohāraḥ yathā rukkhassa sākhāya chijjamānāya rukkho
translated: Therefore the term “aggregate” is applied to the individual instances of feeling, etc., just as the term “tree” is applied to the individual instances of a tree such as the trunk,🔽the branches, the leaves, etc., when they are being cut.

original: chijjatī”tiādīsu viyāti. Evaṃ khandhato catubbidhā honti.🔽Te puna āyatanato duvidhā honti – manāyatanaṃ dhammāyatananti. Sañjātisamosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: chijjati iti ādīsu viyāti evam khandhato catubbidhāḥ honti  te puna āyatanataḥ duvidhā honti manāyatanam dhammāyatanam ti sañjāti samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: Thus they are of four kinds according to aggregate.🔽They are of two kinds according to sense base: the mind base and the mental-data base.

original: hettha cittaṃ manāyatanaṃ, sesā pana aṭṭhatiṃsa dhammā dhammāyatananti. Evaṃ āyatanato
analyzed: ha ittha cittam mana āyatanam sesā pana aṭṭhatiṃsa dhammā dhamma āyatanan ti evam āyatanato
translated: Herein, the mind is the mind base, and the remaining thirty-six dhammas are the mental-data base. Thus they are of two kinds according to sense base.

original: duvidhā honti. Te puna dhātuvasena duvidhā manoviññāṇadhātu dhammadhātūti. Nissattanijjīvaṭṭhena
analyzed: duvidhāḥ honti te puna dhātu vasena duvidhā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dhammadhātu uti nissatta nijjīva ṭṭhena
translated: They are twofold as elements. Again they are twofold as elements, being the mind-consciousness element and the mental-data element.

original: hettha cittaṃ manoviññāṇadhātu, sesā dhammadhātūti. Evaṃ dhātuvasena duvidhā.🔽Tathā āhārānāhāravasena. Tattha phasso cetanā cittanti ime tayo dhammā visesapaccayattena
analyzed: ha ittha cittam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu sesāḥ dhamma dhātu uti evam dhātu vasena duvidhā  tathā āhāra anāhāra vasena tattha phasso cetanā cittanti ime tayo dhammā visesa paccaya ttena
translated: Herein, mind is the mind-consciousness element, and the rest are the mental-data element. So they are twofold as elements.

original: yathākkamaṃ “phassāhāro manosañcetanāhāro viññāṇāhāro”ti vuccanti, avasesā na āhārāti.
analyzed: yathākkamam phassa āhāraḥ manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ viññāṇa āhāro ti vuccanti avasesā na āhārā ti
translated: Likewise they are twofold as nutriment and non-nutriment. Herein, contact, volition, and consciousness are called respectively “contact as nutriment,” “nutriment as mental volition,” and “nutriment as consciousness,” because they are conditions in the specific sense of “nutriment” .🔽The rest are not nutriment.

original: Kiṃ panete paccayā na honti, ye na āhārāti vucceyyunti? No na honti, visesapaccayā
analyzed: kim pana ete paccayāḥ na honti ye na āhārā ti vucceyyuṃ ti no na honti visesa paccayā
translated: But are they not conditions? They are, but they are not specific conditions.

original: pana na honti, phassādayo pana tesaṃ dhammānaṃ visesapaccayā honti, visesato vedanādayo
analyzed: pana na honti phassa ādayaḥ pana tesam dhammānam visesa paccayāḥ honti visesataḥ vedanā ādayo
translated: Contact, etc., are specific conditions for those states, and feeling, etc.,

original: ca āharanti. Phassāhāro hi tisso vedanāyo āharati, manosañcetanāhāro tayo bhave,
analyzed: ca āharanti phassa āhāraḥ hi tissaḥ vedanāyaḥ āharati manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro bhave
translated: are nutriment in the specific sense. For contact as nutriment brings the three kinds of feeling, nutriment as mental volition brings the three kinds of becoming,

original: viññāṇāhāro paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ. Nanu ca so vipāko, idaṃ pana kusalaviññāṇanti? Kiñcāpi
analyzed: viññāṇa āhāro paṭisandhi nāma rūpam nanu ca so vipāko idam pana kusala viññāṇan ti kiñca api
translated: and nutriment as consciousness brings rebirth-linking and the first two kinds of materiality. But is not that result? And is not this consciousness profitable?

original: evaṃ, taṃsarikkhatāya pana viññāṇāhārotveva vuttaṃ. Yasmā vā ime “arūpino āhārā sampayuttakānaṃ
analyzed: evam tad sarikkha tāya pana viññāṇa āhāraḥ tu eva vuttam yasmā vā ime arūpino āhārā sampayuttakānam
translated: But it is said of the other three that they are nutriment because they are similar to it.

original: dhammānaṃ taṃsamuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ āhārapaccayena paccayo”ti vacanato kabaḷīkārāhāro
analyzed: dhammānam tad samuṭṭhānānaṃ ca rūpānaṃ āhāra paccayena paccayaḥ ti vacanataḥ kabaḷīkāra āhāro
translated: Or alternatively, these are called nutriment because, according to the passage, “The immaterial nutriments are a condition, as nutriment condition, for the states associated therewith and for the materiality originated thereby” ,

original: viya rūpakāyassa upatthambhakaṭṭhena nāmakāyassa āhārapaccayā honti, tasmā imeva
analyzed: rūpakāyassa upatthambhaka ṭṭhena nāmakāyassa āhāra paccayāḥ honti tasmai ime eva
translated: they are a nutriment condition for the mental body, as the nutriment consisting of gross or fine food is for the material body.

original: “āhārā”ti vuttāti veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ āhārānāhāravasena duvidhā.🔽Tathā indriyānindriyato. Tattha saddhā vīriyaṃ sati ekaggatā amoho cittaṃ somanassavedanā
analyzed: āhārā ati vuttā ati veditabbam evam āhāra anāhāra vasena duvidhā  tathā indriya anindriyato tattha saddhā vīriyam sati ekagga tā amohaḥ cittam somanassa vedanā
translated: So it should be understood that they are called nutriment because they are nutriment in the way already stated. This is how it is twofold as nutriment and not-nutriment.

original: jīvitanti ime aṭṭha dhammā adhipatiyaṭṭhena yathākkamaṃ “saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ🔽satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyaṃ manindriyaṃ somanassindriyaṃ jīvitindriya”nti
analyzed: jīvitanti ime aṭṭha dhammā adhipatiya ṭṭhena yathākkamam saddhā indriyam vīriya indriyam  satindriyam samādhindriyam paññindriyam manindriyam somanassindriyam jīvitindriyanti
translated: As faculties and not faculties: here faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding, the heart-basis, and the two kinds of aberration are called faculties in the sense of predominance, and the rest are not called faculties.

original: vuccanti, avasesā na “indriyānī”ti. Evaṃ indriyānindriyato duvidhā.
analyzed: vuccanti avasesāḥ na indriyāni iti evam indriya anindriyataḥ duvidhā
translated: This is how it is twofold as faculties and not faculties.

original: Tathā jhānaṅgājhānaṅgavasena. Tattha vitakko vicāro pīti somanassaṃ ekaggatāti ime
analyzed: tathā jhāna aṅga ajhāna aṅga vasena tattha vitakkaḥ vicāraḥ pi iti somanassam ekagga tā ti ime
translated: Likewise by way of jhāna factor and not a jhāna factor. Herein, applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and concentration,

original: pañca dhammā upanijjhāyanaṭṭhena “jhānaṅgānī”ti vuccanti, itare “ajhānaṅgānī”ti.
analyzed: pañca dhammā upanijjhāyana ṭṭhena jhāna aṅgāni iti vuccanti itare ajhāna aṅgāni iti
translated: these five ideas are called “jhāna factors” in the sense of being what is reflected upon, while the others are “not jhāna factors.”

original: Evaṃ jhānaṅgājhānaṅgavasena duvidhā.
analyzed: evam jhā an aṅga a jhā an aṅga vasena duvidhā
translated: So it is of two kinds as jhāna factor and not a jhāna factor.

original: Tathā maggaṅgāmaggaṅgavasena. Tattha amoho vitakko viratittayaṃ vīriyaṃ sati ekaggatāti
analyzed: tathā maggaṅga amaggaṅga vasena tattha amohaḥ vitakkaḥ virati tayam vīriyam sati ekagga tā ti
translated: Likewise by way of path factor and not a path factor. Herein, non-delusion, applied thought, the three kinds of virtue, energy, mindfulness, and concentration,

original: ime aṭṭha dhammā niyyānaṭṭhena, vimokkhaṭṭhena ca yathākkamaṃ “sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo
analyzed: ime aṭṭha dhammā niyyāna ṭṭhena vimokkha ṭṭhena ca yathākkamam sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo
translated: these eight ideas are called “path factors” in the sense of outlet and in the sense of deliverance, and they are called “right view,” “right thought,”

original: sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhī”ti nāmena “maggaṅgānī”ti🔽vuccanti, itare “amaggaṅgānī”ti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana lokiyacitte viratīnaṃ aniyatattā, yevāpanakattā
analyzed: sammā vācā sammā kammantaḥ sammā ājīvo sammā vāyāmo sammā sati sammā samādhī iti nāmena maggaṅgāni iti  vuccanti itare amaggaṅgāni iti pāḷiyam pana lokiya citte viratīnam aniyata ttā yevāpanaka ttā
translated: “right speech,” “right action,” “right livelihood,” “right effort,” “right mindfulness,” and “right concentration” respectively by name.

original: ca tā vajjetvā “pañcaṅgiko maggo hotī”ti vuccati. Evaṃ maggaṅgāmaggaṅgavasena duvidhā.
analyzed: ca tā vajjetvā pañcaṅgikaḥ maggo hoti iti vuccati evam maggaṅga a maggaṅga vasena duvidhā
translated: The others are “not path factors.” But in the texts the three kinds of virtue are omitted because they are not invariably conascent with consciousness and because they are only adventitious, and so it is said that “the path is of five factors” . So it is of two kinds as path factor and not a path factor.

original: Tathā balābalavasena. Tattha saddhāvīriyaṃ sati samādhi paññā hirī ottappanti ime satta dhammā akampiyaṭṭhena balānīti vuccanti, itare abalānīti. Evaṃ balābalavasena duvidhā.
analyzed: tathā bala abala vasena tattha saddhā vīriyam sati samādhi paññā hirī ottappanti ime satta dhammā akampiya ṭṭhena balāni iti vuccanti itare abalāni iti evam bala abala vasena duvidhā
translated: Likewise by way of strength and weakness. Herein, faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, understanding, conscience, and shame are called “strengths” in the sense of unshakeableness, the others are “weaknesses.” So it is of two kinds by way of strength and weakness.

original: Tathā hetunahetuvasena. Tattha alobho adoso amohoti ime tayo dhammā mūlaṭṭhena hetūti🔽vuccanti, itare nahetūti. Evaṃ hetunahetuvasena duvidhā. Evaṃ phassāphassavedanāvedanā
analyzed: tathā hetunā hetu vasena tattha alobhaḥ adosaḥ amohaḥ ti ime tayo dhammā mūla ṭṭhena hetu ti  vuccanti itare na hetu iti evam hetu na hetu vasena duvidhā evam phassa aphassa vedanā vedanā
translated: Likewise by way of root and non-root. Herein, non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion are called “roots” in the sense of source.

original: saññāsaññācittācittādivasenapi vuttanayānusārena yathāyogaṃ saṅgahavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: saññā saññā citta acitta ādi vasena api vutta naya anusārena yathāyogam saṅgaha vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The others are “non-roots.” So it is of two kinds by way of root and non-root. So too by way of contact and non-contact, by way of feeling and non-feeling, by way of perception and non-perception, by way of volition and non-volition, by way of consciousness and non-consciousness, etc., the classification by inclusion should be understood as appropriate in each case in the way already indicated.

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana padabhājanīyasaṅgahavāre, tadaṭṭhakathāyañca gahetabbo.
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana padabhājanīya saṅgaha vāre tad aṭṭhakathāyañca gahetabbo
translated: This is the brief treatment here. The detailed treatment, however, should be construed in the section on the analysis of the categories and in the commentary thereon.

original: Evaṃ saṅgahato vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam saṅgahataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known by inclusion.

original: Suññato cevāti evaṃ khandhādīhi saṅgahitesu tesu dhammesu tabbinimutto kārakavedakādisabhāvo
analyzed: suññataḥ ca iva ati evam khandha ādīhi saṅgahitesu tesu dhammesu tad vinimuttaḥ kāraka vedaka ādi sabhāvaḥ
translated: “And as void”: in regard to those states included by the aggregates, etc., in the sense of the voidness of a doer, an experiencer, etc., that is separate from them.

original: attā vā sassato vā bhāvo na upalabbhati. Suññā te dhammā attena vā attaniyena vā,
analyzed: attā vā sassataḥ vā bhāvaḥ na upalabbhati suññā te dhammā attena vā attaniyena vā
translated: and no self or eternal entity is found. These ideas are void of self or of anything pertaining to self.

original: kevalaṃ paṭiccasamuppannā, salakkhaṇadhāraṇato dhammamattā, niccasukhādisāravirahato
analyzed: kevalam paṭicca samuppannā sa lakkhaṇa dhāraṇataḥ dhamma mattā nicca sukha ādi sāra virahato
translated: They are mere ideas, mere dhammas, in the sense of their bearing their own particular characteristics. They are without essence, in the sense of their being devoid of any permanent, pleasant, etc., essence.

original: asārā, pavattakaniyāmakābhāvato apariṇāyakā aniccā, dukkhā, anattā, anattaniyā ca
analyzed: asārā pavattaka niyāmaka abhāvataḥ apariṇāyakā aniccā dukkhā anattā anatta niyā ca
translated: They are impermanent, painful, not-self, and void, in the sense of their being without any controlling power, since they are subject to arising and fall, and they occur in dependence on conditions.

original: hutvā pavattantīti ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana padabhājanīyasuññatavāre, tadaṭṭhakathāyañca
analyzed: hutvā pavattanti iti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana pada bhājanīya suññata vāre tad aṭṭhakathāyañca
translated: This is the brief account. The detailed account can be found in the section on the analysis of the voidness of the elements of the dependent origination and in the commentary thereon.

original: gahetabboti. Evaṃ suññato vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: gahetabbo ti evam suññatas vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to voidness.

original: Niṭṭhitā paṭhamakusalassa atthavaṇṇanā.🔽Dutiyādīsupi paṭhamakusale vuttanayena dhammuddesādinā sabbo vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽Na kevalañca ettheva, ito paresupi sabbattha heṭṭhā vuttasadisānaṃ padānaṃ, dhammānañca
analyzed: niṭṭhitā paṭhama kusalassa attha vaṇṇanā  dutiya ādīsu pi paṭhama kusale vutta nayena dhamma uddesa ādinā sabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  na kevalam ca ettha iva itas paresu pi sabbattha heṭṭhā vutta sadisānam padānam dhammānam ca
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the first profitable consciousness is ended.🔽In the second and the rest, the exposition should be understood in the way already stated under the first profitable consciousness, by way of the description of the mental factors, etc.🔽And not only here, but also in all the rest of the exposition, the meaning of the terms and ideas stated should be understood in the same way as above.

original: attho, sabbo ca vinicchayo ettha vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ito paraṃ pana apubbameva
analyzed: atthaḥ sabbaḥ ca vinicchayaḥ ettha vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ itas param pana apubbam eva
translated: But from here onwards there is nothing new to comment on.

original: vaṇṇayissāma. Dutiyacitte tāva sasaṅkhārabhāvamattameva paṭhamacittato viseso, sesaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇayissāma dutiya citte tāva sa saṅkhāra bhāva mattam eva paṭhama cittato visesaḥ sesam
translated: We shall comment on them. In the second consciousness the difference from the first is that it has only the bare form of applied thought; the rest

original: tādisameva. Dutiyakusalaṃ.🔽Tatiyepi dhammuddese amohābhāvā indriyamaggaṅgabalamūlasaṅgahesu paññindriyasammādiṭṭhimaggaṅgapaññābalaamohamūlānaṃ🔽parihāniyā saddhindriyādīnaṃ bhāvova viseso, sesaṃ tādisameva. Tathā catutthe sasaṅkhārabhāvamattameva
analyzed: tādisam eva dutiya kusalam  tatiye pi dhamma uddese amoha abhāvā indriya maggaṅga bala mūla saṅgahesu paññindriya sammādiṭṭhi maggaṅga paññā bala amoha mūlānaṃ  parihāniyā saddhi indriya ādīnam bhāvaḥ u visesaḥ sesam tādisam eva tathā catutthe sa saṅkhāra bhāva mattam eva
translated: is the same. The second profitable consciousness.

original: viseso. Tatiyacatutthāni.🔽Pañcamachaṭṭhasattamaṭṭhamesu pana sukhasomanassaṭṭhānesu upekkhābhāvo, pītiyā ca
analyzed: visesaḥ tatiya catutthāni  pañcama chaṭṭha sattama ṭṭhamesu pana sukha somanassa ṭṭhānesu upekkhā bhāvo pītiyā ca
translated: In the third announcement, too, the difference is that the faculty of wisdom, the path factor of right view, the power of wisdom, and the root of the profitable, non-delusion, are absent in the first consciousness, and the faculty of faith, etc., are present. The rest is the same. So too in the fourth. The difference is that it has only the bare form of applied thought. The third and fourth.

original: abhāvo. Teneva jhānaṅgasaṅgahavāre caturaṅgajjhānatāva viseso, sesaṃ paṭhamadutiyatatiyacatutthacittasadisameva.
analyzed: tena iva jhān aṅga saṅgaha vāre viseso sesam paṭhama dutiya tatiya catuttha citta sadisam eva
translated: But in the fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth, which are the places for pleasure and joy, equanimity is absent and there is no happiness. So in the section on the jhāna factors the difference is that they have four factors. The rest is the same as in the first, second, third, and fourth consciousnesses.

original: Upekkhāsahagatesu cettha catūsu karuṇāmuditā na uppajjantīti keci vadanti, parikammabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: upekkhā sahagatesu ca ittha catūsu karuṇā muditā na uppajjanti iti keci vadanti
translated: Herein, some say that in the four associated with equanimity neither compassion nor gladness arises, and that

original: panettha tāsaṃ uppattiyā mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ anuññātattā upacārappattā pana uppajjanti,
analyzed: pana ittha tāsam uppattiyāḥ mahā aṭṭhakathāyam anuññāta ttā upacāra ppattā pana uppajjanti
translated: But since their arising is permitted in the great commentary on the meaning of the words, they arise in access,

original: na itarāti gahetabbaṃ. Pañcamachaṭṭhasattamaṭṭhamāni.
analyzed: na itarāti gahetabbam pañcama chaṭṭha sattama ṭṭhamāni
translated: not in absorption. The fifth, sixth, and seventh and eighth are treated in the same way.

original: Visayādippabhedatoti evaṃ dhammuddesādinā vibhattāni aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalāni ārammaṇavibhāgato
analyzed: visaya ādi ppabhedato ti evam dhamma uddesa ādinā vibhattāni aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusalāni ārammaṇa vibhāgato
translated: By way of object, etc.: these eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousnesses, which have been analysed by way of description of dhammas, etc.,

original: paccekaṃ chabbidhāni honti rūpārammaṇaṃ…pe… dhammārammaṇanti. Tattha nīlādibhedabhinnā,
analyzed: paccekam chabbidhāni honti rūpa ārammaṇam pe dhamma ārammaṇam ti tattha nīla ādi bheda bhinnā
translated: are each of them sixfold by way of the division of their objects. They have visible-data objects, etc., as follows:🔽The visible-data element, classed as blue, etc.,

original: atītānāgatapaccuppannaajjhattikabāhiraoḷārikasukhumādibhedabhinnā ca vaṇṇadhātu rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽nāma. Evaṃ saddārammaṇādīsupi yathānurūpaṃ bhedo veditabbo.🔽Ettha ca phoṭṭhabbanti āpodhātuvajjitabhūtattayaṃ, dhammārammaṇanti pañcārammaṇāni
analyzed: atīta anāgata paccuppanna ajjhattika bāhira oḷārika sukhuma ādi bheda bhinnā ca vaṇṇa dhātu rūpa ārammaṇam  nāma evam yathānurūpam bhedaḥ veditabbo  ettha ca phoṭṭhabbanti āpodhātu vajjita bhūta ttayam dhamma ārammaṇanti pañca ārammaṇāni
translated: and classed as past, future, present, internal, external, gross, and so on, is called “visible-data object.”🔽So too with sound object, and so on.🔽And here “tangible data” is the triple element of physical matter excluding the water element. “Dhamma object” is the determinations classed as visible data, etc., and the unformed element, which should be understood as excluding the five kinds of object beginning with visible data. The rest is similar.

original: vajjetvā avasesā rūpārūpapaññattiyo veditabbā, sesaṃ tādisameva. Keci panettha “cakkhuviññāṇādīnamāpāthagatāni
analyzed: vajjetvā avasesā rūpa arūpa paññattiyaḥ veditabbā sesam tādisam eva keci pana ittha cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam āpātha gatāni
translated: But some say that the visible-data object for eye-consciousness, etc., is only what is reached by the eye, etc.,

original: etānārammaṇāni rūpārammaṇādivohāraṃ labhanti, anāpāthagatāni pana atītānāgatadūrasukhumādibhedabhinnāni🔽dhammārammaṇānevā”ti vadanti, taṃ na yuttaṃ dibbacakkhādīnaṃ rūpārammaṇatādivacanato.
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇa ādi vohāram labhanti anāpātha gatāni pana atīta anāgata dūra sukhuma ādi bheda bhinnāni  dhamma ārammaṇān eva ati vadanti tam na yuttam dibba cakkha ādīnam rūpa ārammaṇa tā ādi vacanato
translated: These objects are called “visible-data objects” and so on, but they are only states cognizable by mind that are not actually present.🔽They say that they are only states cognizable by mind. That is incorrect because the divine eye, etc., are said to have visible data, etc., as their object.

original: Anāpāthagatā eva hi tāni dibbacakkhuādīnaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, na ca tāni dhammārammaṇāni.
analyzed: anāpātha gatāḥ eva hi tāni dibba cakkhu ādīnam ārammaṇam na ca tāni dhamma ārammaṇāni
translated: For they are the object of the divine eye, etc., only when not actually present, and they are not states cognizable by mind.

original: Rūpādayo hi pañca paccekaṃ dvīsu dvīsu dvāresu ekasmiṃ khaṇe āpāthamāgantvā taṃtaṃdvārikajavanānaṃ,🔽tadanantare manodvārikānañca aparabhāge ca diṭṭhasutādivasenānussarantassa suddhamanodvārikānañca
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ hi pañca paccekam dvīsu dvīsu dvāresu ekasmin khaṇe āpātham āgantvā  tad anantare manodvārikā anañca apara bhāge ca diṭṭha sutā divasena anussarantassa
translated: For the five beginning with visible data come into focus in pairs in two doors in one moment and become the object of the two kinds of impulsions belonging to those doors,🔽and in the second moment they become the object of the mind-door impulsion that follows them and of the subsequent mind-element with a single function, which remembers them as “seen,” “heard,” and so on.

original: ārammaṇāni honti. Tathā hi nānāvaṇṇavicittacetiyādidassanaṃ karontassa, dhammaṃ suṇantassa,
analyzed: ārammaṇāni honti tathā hi nānā vaṇṇa vicitta cetiya ādi dassanam karontassa dhammam suṇantassa
translated: For when one is looking at a cetiya, for instance, that is variegated with various colours, or listening to the Dhamma,

original: bherisaddādīhi vā pūjādiṃ karontassa ca gandhamālādīni ghāyitvā, khādanīyabhojanīyādiñca
analyzed: bheri sadda ādīhi vā pūjā ādim karontassa ca gandha mālā ādīni ghāyitvā khādanīya bhojanīya ādin ca
translated: or worshipping with the sound of drums, etc., or smelling scents, flowers, etc., or tasting sweet foods, etc., or anointing oneself with fragrant oil, etc., or handling various objects, etc.,

original: sāyitvā, sukhasamphassāni attharaṇapāvuraṇādīni ca phusitvā manāpabhāvaṃ ñatvā tehi
analyzed: sāyitvā sukha samphassāni attharaṇa pāvuraṇa ādīni ca phusitvā manāpa bhāvam ñatvā tehi
translated: and having tasted them, and having felt the pleasant contact of the bedding, covering, etc., and having known their agreeableness, he then

original: cetiyapūjaṃ karontassa, tattha tattha akusalaṃ vā uppādentassa, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ khaṇe
analyzed: cetiya pūjam karontassa tattha tattha akusalam vā uppādentassa tasmin tasmin khaṇe
translated: worships the shrine, and while doing so he generates unprofitable thoughts here and there. At that moment

original: gayhamānāni rūpādipañcārammaṇāni sākhāya akkamanaṃ, pathaviyaṃ chāyāpharaṇañca ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: gayhamānāni rūpa ādi pañca ārammaṇāni sākhāya akkamanam pathaviyam chāyā pharaṇam ca eka kkhaṇe
translated: the five objects, visible data, etc., which are being apprehended, act as objects of the profitable and unprofitable thoughts in the same way that the tree trunk did for the bird.

original: kurumānaṃ rukkhagge nilīyamānaṃ pakkhino sarīraṃ viya yathāsakaṃ pasādañca ghaṭṭetvā🔽tasmiṃyeva khaṇe bhavaṅgacalanapaccayabhāvena manodvārepi āpāthamāgantvā tato bhavaṅgaṃ🔽vicchinditvā uppannānaṃ āvajjanādivoṭṭhabbanapariyosānānaṃ, vīthicittānaṃ, tadanantarānañca
analyzed: kurumānam rukkha agge nilīyamānam pakkhino sarīram viya yathāsakam pasādam ca ghaṭṭetvā  tasmin yeva khaṇe bhavaṅga calana paccaya bhāvena manaḥ dvāre pi āpātham āgantvā tatas bhavaṅgam  vicchinditvā uppannānam āvajjana ādi voṭṭhabbana pariyosānānam vīthi cittānam tad anantarānam ca
translated: And they impinge on the faith, etc., in the mind door in the same way that the bird’s body did for the tree trunk.🔽And at that very moment they become objects for the consciousnesses of the cognitive series beginning with adverting, which arise displacing the life-continuum, and they become objects for the profitable and unprofitable impulsion that arises next to the adverting,

original: kusalākusalādijavanānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hutvā tadanantarāsu manodvāravīthīsu ca aparabhāge
analyzed: ārammaṇam hutvā tad anantarāsu manaḥ dvāra vīthīsu ca apara bhāge
translated: and they become objects for the subsequent mind-door impulsion processes.

original: tathārūpaṃ paccayaṃ āgamma attanā pūjādikaraṇakālesu, diṭṭhasutaghāyitasāyitaphuṭṭhavasenānussarantassa,
analyzed: tathārūpam paccayam āgamma attanā pūjā ādi karaṇa kālesu diṭṭha suta ghāyita sāyita phuṭṭha vasena anussarantassa
translated: and so on, when he himself is paying homage, etc., and he recollects the special qualities of the Enlightened One in the way already described beginning with “To him who has such and such special qualities” .🔽

original: paccakkhato anubhuyyamānāni viya manodvāre ca ārammaṇāni honti.
analyzed: paccakkhatas anubhuyyamānāni viya manaḥ dvāre ca ārammaṇāni honti
translated: and when he recollects them by means of what is seen, heard, sensed and cognized, then they are objects of the mind door.

original: Athāpi pañcahi dvārehi agahitapubbāni buddharūpādīni, dibbarūpādīni ca pañcārammaṇāni
analyzed: atha api pañcahi dvārehi agahita pubbāni buddha rūpa ādīni dibba rūpa ādīni ca pañca ārammaṇāni
translated: And also when he recollects the five objects, the visible data of the Enlightened One’s body, etc., and the heavenly visible data, etc., that have not previously been apprehended by the five doors,

original: savanavasena sallakkhetvā javanakkhaṇe vā aparabhāge sutavaseneva anussaritvā vā
analyzed: savana vasena sallakkhetvā java nakkhaṇe vā aparabhāge suta vasena iva anussaritvā vā
translated: after discerning them by means of hearing, or after recollecting them by means of what is heard at the time of impulsion or later,

original: pasādaṃ, kammaphalasaddhādiṃ, lobhādiñca uppādentassāpi manodvāre āpāthamāgacchanti.🔽Abhiññānaṃ pana suddhamanodvāre eva, tasmā evaṃ pañcadvāre, manodvāre, suddhamanodvāre🔽ca āpāthagatāni atītādibhedabhinnāni sabbānipi pañcārammaṇāni kadācipi dhammārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: pasādam kamma phala saddhā ādim lobha ādiñca uppādentassa api manaḥ dvāre āpātham āgacchanti  abhiññānam pana suddha manaḥ dvāre eva tasmai evam pañca dvāre manaḥ dvāre suddha manaḥ dvāre  ca āpātha gatāni atīta ādi bheda bhinnāni sabbāni pi pañca ārammaṇāni kadāci pi dhamma ārammaṇam
translated: and he arouses confidence, or he arouses faith consisting in confidence in the fruit of kamma, etc., or he arouses greed, etc., then they are objects of the mind door.🔽But the objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge are only in the case of the pure mind door.🔽So all the five objects, classed as past, etc., that reach the threshold of the doors of five doors, of the mind door, and of the pure mind door, are never objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽But the other formations classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in states of consciousness and its concomitants, and the states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in formations other than those, are objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.

original: na honti, taditarā nāmarūpapaññattiyo dhammārammaṇanti gahetabbaṃ. Nanu cetāni iṭṭhakantamanāpāni
analyzed: na honti tad itarāḥ nāma rūpa paññattiyaḥ dhamma ārammaṇanti gahetabbam nanu ca itāni iṭṭha kanta manāpāni
translated: And the ideas classed as past, etc., that are states of non-consciousness, and the states of non-consciousness classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in formations other than those, are objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽And the ideas classed as past, etc., that are states of neither consciousness nor non-consciousness, and the states of neither consciousness nor non-consciousness classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in formations other than those, are objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽And the ideas classed as past, etc., that are states of consciousness and its concomitants, and the states of consciousness and its concomitants classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in formations other than those, are objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽And the ideas classed as past, etc., that are states of neither consciousness nor non-consciousness, and the states of neither consciousness nor non-consciousness classed as past, etc., that are ideas consisting in formations other than those, are objects of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽And the ideas classed as past, etc., that are states of consciousness

original: ārammaṇāni lobhassa vatthu, kathamettha kusalaṃ uppajjatīti? Niyamādikāraṇato. Cittaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇāni lobhassa vatthu katham ettha kusalam uppajjati iti niyama ādi kāraṇato cittam
translated: and the objects of greed are its object-field, how does the profitable come to be here? It is because of the reason of the rule, etc.,🔽for the mind,

original: hi “kusalameva mayā kattabba”nti pubbe niyamitavasena sabbattha akusalappavattiṃ🔽nivattetvā kusale pariṇāmanavasena ca abhiṇhaṃ āsevitakusalasamudācāravasena ca sappurisūpanissayādiupanissayavasena
analyzed: hi kusalam eva mayā kattabbanti pubbe niyamita vasena sabbattha akusala ppavattim  nivattetvā kusale pariṇāmana vasena ca abhiṇham āsevita kusala samudācāra vasena ca sappurisa upanissaya ādi upanissaya vasena
translated: having previously been ruled by the rule “I must only do what is profitable,” turns away from the unprofitable occurrence in all instances,🔽and it comes to be profitable by these reasons, namely, by the profitable’s being brought to mind, by the profitable’s being frequently practised, by the profitable’s being assisted by good friends’ advice, etc.,

original: ca yonisoābhujitavasena cāti imehi kāraṇehi kusalaṃ hutvā uppajjatīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca ca ati imehi kāraṇehi kusalam hutvā uppajjati iti veditabbam
translated: and by the profitable’s being properly applied.

original: Evamimesu chasu ārammaṇesu uppajjanato paccekaṃ chabbidhāni honti. Ārammaṇavavatthānakathā.🔽Evaṃ ārammaṇabhedabhinnesu rūpārammaṇaṃ tāva kusalaṃ dasapuññakiriyavatthuvasena
analyzed: evam imesu chasu ārammaṇesu uppajjanato paccekam chabbidhāni honti ārammaṇa vavatthāna kathā  evam ārammaṇa bheda bhinnesu rūpa ārammaṇam tāva kusalam dasa puñña kiriya vatthu vasena
translated: So they are each of the six kinds according to the six kinds of object that they occur with. Discussion of the definition of the object.

original: dasavidhaṃ hoti. Tattha ekekaṃ pana kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ manokammanti tividhaṃ.
analyzed: dasavidham hoti tattha ekekam pana kāya kammam vacī kammam manaḥ kammanti tividham
translated: Now, as to the profitable, firstly, that with materiality as its object is of ten kinds according to the ten profitable kamma-process categories. Herein, each of these is threefold as bodily action, verbal action, and mental action.

original: Tattha kāyadvāre pavattaṃ kāyakammaṃ, vacīdvāre pavattaṃ vacīkammaṃ, manodvāre pavattaṃ
analyzed: tattha kāya dvāre pavattam kāya kammam vacī dvāre pavattam vacī kammam manaḥ dvāre pavattam
translated: and mental action in the mind door.

original: manokammaṃ. Tattha kāyadvāranti kāyaviññatti. Vacīdvāranti vacīviññatti. Tāsaṃ vibhāgo
analyzed: manaḥ kammam tattha kāya dvāranti kāya viññatti vacī dvāranti vacī viññatti tāsam vibhāgaḥ
translated: Herein, the body door is the bodily intimation. The speech door is the verbal intimation. The analysis of these will be given in the Description of Matter .

original: rūpavibhattiyaṃ āvi bhavissati. Manodvāranti sabbaṃ cetanāsampayuttaṃ cittaṃ vuccati,🔽visesato kusalākusalaṃ. Taṃ hi sahajātānaṃ cetanānaṃ, kāyaṅgavācaṅgacopanaṃ asampāpuṇitvā🔽pavattānaṃ suddhamanokammānaṃ pavattiokāsadānato dvāranti vuccati, imesu pana tīsu
analyzed: rūpa vibhattiyam bhavissati manaḥ dvāram ti sabbam cetanā sampayuttam cittam vuccati  visesataḥ kusala akusalam tam hi sahajātānam cetanānam kāyaṅga vācaṅga copanam a sampāpuṇitvā  pavattānam suddha manokammānam pavatti okāsa dānataḥ dvāran ti vuccati imesu pana tīsu
translated: The mind door is all consciousness associated with volition,🔽especially profitable and unprofitable consciousness. For that is called a door since it is the means of occurrence for the volitions associated with it, and for the pure mental actions that occur without reaching the body and speech.🔽But the volition occurring in these three doors is called bodily action, etc.

original: dvāresu pavattā cetanā kāyakammādayo nāma. Apica pāṇātipātādayo, pāṇātipātāveramaṇiādayo
analyzed: dvāresu pavattā cetanā kāya kamma ādayaḥ nāma apica pāṇa atipāta ādayaḥ pāṇa atipāta averamaṇi ādayaḥ
translated: Moreover, killing living beings, etc., and abstinence from killing living beings, etc.,

original: ca kāyakammaṃ nāma, musāvādādayo, musāvādāveramaṇiādayo ca vacīkammaṃ nāma, abhijjhādayo,
analyzed: ca kāya kammam nāma musāvāda ādayaḥ ca vacī kammam nāma abhijjhā ādayaḥ
translated: are called bodily action. False speech, etc., and abstinence from false speech, etc., are called verbal action. Covetousness, etc.,

original: anabhijjhādayo ca manokammaṃ nāma.
analyzed: anabhijjhā ādayaḥ ca manokammam nāma
translated: and uncovetousness, etc., are called mental action.

original: Kusalapakkhe pana dānādidasapuññakiriyavatthūni ca yathārahaṃ kāyavacīmanokammāni🔽honti. Evaṃ yebhuyyavuttito cesa kāyakammādibhāvo vutto pāṇātipātādīnampi vacīdvārādīsu
analyzed: kusala pakkhe pana dāna ādi dasa puñña kiriya vatthūni ca yathāraham kāya vacī manaḥ kammāni  honti evam yebhuyya vuttitaḥ ca īsa kāya kamma ādi bhāvo vutto pāṇa atipāta ādīnam pi vacī dvāra ādīsu
translated: But in the profitable class, the bases of giving, etc., and the bodily, verbal, and mental acts as appropriate are the profitable bodily, verbal, and mental acts.🔽So this state of being bodily action, etc., is stated according to predominance. And just as, in the case of some men, the state of being a forest-dweller, etc., is due to their going on foot, etc.,

original: pavattito kesañci purisānaṃ vanacarakādibhāvo viya, dvārānañca kāyakammadvārādibhāvo🔽kesañci gāmānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmādibhāvo viya. Akusale tāva ettha pāṇātipātādikāyakammaṃ
analyzed: pavattitaḥ kesañci purisānam vana caraka ādi bhāvaḥ viya dvārānam ca kāya kamma dvāra ādi bhāvaḥ  gāmānam brāhmaṇa gāma ādi bhāvaḥ viya akusale tāva ettha pāṇa atipāta ādi kāya kammaṃ
translated: so the state of being bodily action, etc., is due to the doors, and the state of being a door of body, etc., is due to the states of being a bodily action, etc., in some instances.

original: kāyadvāre, vacīdvāre ca yathārahaṃ samuṭṭhāti, no manodvāre. Tathā musāvādādivacīkammaṃ.
analyzed: kāya dvāre vacī dvāre ca yathāraham samuṭṭhāti no manaḥ dvāre tathā musāvāda ādi vacī kammaṃ
translated: As regards the unprofitable, firstly, bodily action consisting in killing living things, etc., arises in the door of the body and in the door of speech as appropriate, but not in the door of the mind. Likewise verbal action consisting in lying, etc.

original: Pāṇātipātādinipphādanatthaṃ hi manodvāre eva cintentassa cetanābyāpādādīsu kammapathappattesu
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādi nipphādana ttham hi manaḥ dvāre eva cintentassa cetanā byāpāda ādīsu kammapatha ppattesu
translated: For when one who is thinking in the mind’s door only with a view to producing killing living things, etc., has reached the threshold of the course of action in the mental acts of choice, etc., that are associated with hate,

original: vā kammapathaṃ appattesu vā manokammesu eva pavisanato kāyakammādibhāvaṃ na pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: vā kamma patham appattesu vā manaḥ kammesu eva pavisanataḥ kāya kamma ādi bhāvam na pāpuṇāti
translated: or when he has not reached the threshold of the course of action in the mental acts of choice, etc., that are associated with greed, then he does not reach the state of being bodily action, etc., because he enters only the mental door.

original: Nanu vijjāmayenāpi kevalaṃ manokammena pāṇātipātādiṃ karontīti? Na aloṇabhojanadabbhasayanamantaparijappanādikāyavacīpayogaṃ
analyzed: nanu vijjā mayena api kevalam manaḥ kammena pāṇa atipāta ādim karonti iti na
translated: But is it not the case that one can kill living beings, etc., by mere mental action consisting in knowledge? —It is not, because that cannot succeed without the bodily and verbal effort of eating saltless food, sleeping on a bed of ashes, muttering spells, and so on.

original: vinā tassāsijjhanato. Abhijjhādimanokammaṃ pana tīsupi dvāresu samuṭṭhāti. Abhijjhāya
analyzed: vinā abhijjhā ādi manaḥ kammam pana tīsu pi dvāresu samuṭṭhāti
translated: But the mental action of covetousness, etc., arises in the three doors.

original: hi kāyena parabhaṇḍaggāhādīnaṃ, byāpādena daṇḍaparāmasanādīnaṃ, micchādiṭṭhiyā titthiyavandanādīnaṃ
analyzed: hi kāyena parabhaṇḍa ggāha ādīnam byāpādena daṇḍa parāmasana ādīnam micchā diṭṭhiyā titthiya vandanā ādīnam
translated: For when one is killing another’s cattle, etc., with the body out of covetousness, or when one is threatening with a stick, etc., out of ill will, or when one is worshipping a sect’s shrine, etc., out of wrong view,

original: karaṇakāle, vācāya parasampattipatthanāya “haññantu bajjhantū”ti anatthapatthanāya🔽ca titthiyatthutitadatthadīpanādīnañca yathākkamaṃ pavattikāle ca tassa manokammassa
analyzed: karaṇa kāle vācāya para sampatti patthanāya haññantu bajjhantu iti anattha patthanāya  ca yathākkamam pavatti kāle ca tassa mano kammassa
translated: and when one is uttering such verbal expressions of longing for another’s property as “Oh, that his might be mine!” and such verbal expressions of wishing harm as “Let him be killed, let him be destroyed!”

original: kāyavācāsu pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: kāya vācāsu pavatti veditabbā
translated: and when one is praising a sect’s doctrine, etc., that is harmful, then the mental action of covetousness, etc., should be understood as present in the three doors in the order of body, speech, and mind.

original: Kāmāvacarakusalaṃ pana pāṇātipātāveramaṇiādikaṃ kāyavacīmanokammaṃ paccekaṃ dvārattayepi
analyzed: kāmāvacara kusalam pana pāṇa atipāta averamaṇi ādikam kāya vacī manaḥ kammam paccekam
translated: But profitable bodily and verbal action and mental action of the sense sphere, such as the abstention from killing living beings, etc., occur in the three doors respectively.

original: pavattati. Tattha pāṇātipātādīhi samphappalāpapariyosānehi sattahi viramantassa tāva
analyzed: pavattati tattha pāṇātipāta ādīhi samphappalāpa pariyosānehi sattahi viramantassa tāva
translated: Herein, firstly, when someone abstains from the seven things beginning with killing living beings,

original: hatthamuddāya, vacībhedena ca samādiyanakāle, manasā viramaṇakāle ca tesaṃ kāyavacīkammānaṃ
analyzed: hattham uddāya vacī bhedena ca samādiyana kāle manasā viramaṇa kāle ca tesam kāya vacī kammānam
translated: and when he is consenting by gesture and by speech, and when he is abstaining by mind, then the occurrence of these bodily and verbal actions should be understood as taking place in the three doors.

original: tīsu dvāresu pavatti veditabbā. Anabhijjhādīhi sahagatena cetasā tajjassa kāyapayogassa,🔽“paravittupakaraṇaṃ ciraṭṭhitikaṃ hotu, sabbe sattā averā hontu, so bhagavā arahaṃ
analyzed: tīsu dvāresu veditabbā anabhijjhā ādīhi sahagatena cetasā tad jassa kāya payogassa  para vittupakaraṇam cira ṭṭhitikam hotu sabbe sattāḥ averāḥ hontu saḥ bhagavā arahan
translated: When he is doing the bodily act of giving with a mind associated with non-covetousness, etc.,

original: sammāsambuddho”tiādinā vacīpayogassa, kevalaṃ manopayogassa ca karaṇakāle manokammassa
analyzed: sammāsambuddha iti ādinā vacī payogassa kevalam manaḥ upayogassa ca karaṇa kāle mano kammassa
translated: and the verbal act of giving with the words, “May the requisites of those who want them be long-lasting,” and “May all beings be free from enmity,” and so on, and when he is doing the mere mental act of giving, then the occurrence of the mental action should be understood as taking place in the three doors.

original: tīsupi dvāresu pavatti veditabbā. Ettha ca pañcadvāre uppannāni javanāni kāyavacīkammāni
analyzed: tīsu pi dvāresu veditabbā ettha ca pañca dvāre uppannāni javanāni kāya vacī kammāni
translated: And here the impulsions arisen in the five doors are bodily and verbal actions,

original: na honti, manokammāni eva. Tāni ca na kammapathappattāni, kevalaṃ kusalādīni honti.
analyzed: na honti manaḥ kammāni eva tāni ca na kammapatha ppattāni kevalam kusala ādīni honti
translated: but they are not courses of action; they are only profitable, etc.🔽But only those arisen in the mind door are mental actions and courses of action.

original: Manodvāre paṭutarappavattāni eva hi kammapathappattāni manokammāni honti, rūpārūpajavanāni
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre paṭutara ppavattāni eva hi kammapatha ppattāni manaḥ kammāni honti rūpa arūpa javanāni
translated: The impulsions of the fine-material and immaterial kinds

original: pana ekantaṃ bhāvanāmayaṃ manokammameva manodvāre eva ca pavattanti.
analyzed: pana ekantam bhāvanā mayam manaḥ kammam eva manaḥ dvāre eva ca pavattanti
translated: are mental actions only, and they occur only in the mind door.

original: Kiñcāpi abhiññāñāṇāni viññattidvayajanakāni, tathāpi kāyavacīkammavohāraṃ na labhanti,🔽lokuttarakusalaṃ pana kāyavacīdvāresu anuppajjamānampi micchāvācākammantājīvānaṃ
analyzed: kiñca api abhiññā ñāṇāni viññatti dvaya janakāni tathā api kāya vacī kamma vohāram na labhanti  lokuttara kusalam pana kāya vacī dvāresu anuppajjamānam pi micchā vācā kammanta ājīvānam
translated: And although the kinds of direct-knowledge and the kinds of knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power produce the two kinds of intimation, still they do not have bodily and verbal action.

original: samucchedappahānakārīnaṃ viratīnaṃ vasena kāyavacīkammampi hoti, taditaramaggaṅgavasena🔽manokammampīti ekakkhaṇe tīṇipi kammāni honti, tañca bhāvanāmayaṃ, dvāraṃ panassa
analyzed: samuccheda ppahāna kārīnam viratīnam vasena kāya vacī kammam pi hoti tad itara maggaṅga vasena  manaḥ kammam pi iti eka kkhaṇe tīṇi pi kammāni honti tat ca bhāvanā mayam dvāram panassa
translated: But the profitable of the supramundane plane, though it does not occur in the doors of body and speech, is nevertheless bodily and verbal action in the sense of the kinds of non-action consisting in the abstentions from wrong speech, action and livelihood that are abandonment by cutting off.🔽And it is mental action in the sense of the other path factors.🔽So in a single moment there are three kinds of action. And that is of the kind consisting in development. Its door is the mind door only.

original: manodvārameva. Yathā ca pāṇātipātāveramaṇiyādīnaṃ vasena kusalassa dvārattaye pavatti
analyzed: manaḥ dvāram eva yathā ca vasena kusalassa
translated: And just as the occurrence of profitable action in the three doors is stated in terms of the abstentions from killing living things, etc.,

original: vuttā, evaṃ dasapuññakiriyavatthūnampi vasena vattabbā. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana na vicāritā,
analyzed: vuttāḥ evam dasa puñña kiriya vatthūnam pi vasena vattabbāḥ aṭṭhakathāsu pana na vicāritā
translated: so it can be stated in terms of the ten profitable courses of action. But it is not discussed in the commentaries.

original: tathāpi nayato evaṃ veditabbā.
analyzed: tathā api nayataḥ evam veditabbā
translated: Nevertheless it can be understood by the method stated.

original: Tesu dānaṃ kāyakammameva, vacīkammampi vā. Pattānuppadānaṃ, abbhanumodanaṃ, desanā
analyzed: tesu dānam kāya kammam eva vacī kammam pi vā patta anuppadānam abbhanumodanam desanā
translated: Herein, giving is bodily action or it is verbal action or it is both. The making of an abode available, the welcoming, and the teaching are

original: vacīkammameva. Sīlaṃ apacitisahagataṃ, veyyāvaccasahagatañca kāyakammampi atthi,
analyzed: vacī kammam eva sīlam apaciti sahagatam veyyāvacca sahagatam ca kāya kammam pi atthi
translated: Virtue is bodily action when it is accompanied by respect and by refraining from killing breathing things, etc.,🔽and it is verbal action when it is accompanied by refraining from false speech, etc.

original: vacīkammampi atthi. Tattha sīlassa kāyavacīkammabhāvo siddho eva. Apacitiyā pana
analyzed: vacī kammam pi atthi tattha sīlassa kāya vacī kamma bhāvo siddhaḥ eva apacitiyā pana
translated: Herein, virtue is established as bodily and verbal action.🔽But respect is bodily action when it occurs as the paying of homage with flowers, etc., and as the doing of service, etc.,🔽and it is verbal action when it occurs as the paying of homage with expressions of respect, etc.

original: pupphapūjādinā, vandanādinā vā pavattikāle kāyakammabhāvo, thutimayapūjādinā pavattikāle
analyzed: puppha pūjā ādinā vandanā ādinā vā pavatti kāle kāya kamma bhāvo thuti maya pūjā ādinā pavatti kāle
translated: And refraining from killing breathing things, etc., is bodily action when it is done by one’s own hand,🔽and it is verbal action when it is done by sending someone else or by gesture or by acquiescence, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Deva, or by the mere intention to do it, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, and so on.

original: vacīkammabhāvo ca veditabbo. Veyyāvaccassāpi sahatthā karaṇakāle kāyakammabhāvo,🔽gilānādīnaṃ catupaccayasamādāpanādivasena, garūhi āṇattasaddena ārocanapakkosanādivasena
analyzed: vacī kamma bhāvaḥ ca veditabbaḥ veyyāvaccassa api sahatthā karaṇa kāle kāya kamma bhāvaḥ  gilāna ādīnam catu paccaya samādāpana ādi vasena garūhi āṇatta saddena ārocana pakkosana ādi vasena
translated: And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.🔽And refraining from killing breathing things, etc., is bodily action when it is done by one’s own hand,🔽and it is verbal action when it is done by sending someone else or by gesture or by acquiescence, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Deva, and so on.🔽And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.

original: vacīkammabhāvo ca veditabbo. Bhāvanā, savanaṃ, diṭṭhijukammañca manokammameva, abbhanumodanampīti
analyzed: vacī kamma bhāvaḥ ca veditabbaḥ bhāvanā savanam diṭṭhi ju kammam ca manaḥ kammam eva abbhanumodanam pi iti
translated: And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.🔽And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.🔽And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.🔽And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.

original: keci. Savanampi hi sotadvārānusārena manodvāre eva dhammatthasallakkhaṇavasena pavattikāle manokammameva.
analyzed: keci savanam pi hi sota dvāra anusārena manaḥ dvāre eva dhamma attha sallakkhaṇa vasena pavatti kāle mano kammam eva
translated: And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa, and so on.🔽And it is verbal action when it is done by the mere utterance of words, as in the case of the Elder

original: Tattha dānaṃ apaciti veyyāvaccaṃ pattānuppadānaṃ desanāti imāni pañca kāyavacīdvāresu🔽eva pavattanti, na manodvāre. Ettha ca pattānuppadānadesanānaṃ kāyavikārena pattiṃ
analyzed: tattha dānam apaciti veyyāvaccam pattānuppadānam desanā ati imāni pañca kāyavacī dvāresu  eva pavattanti na manaḥ dvāre ettha ca patta anuppadāna desanānam kāya vikārena pattim
translated: Herein, giving, honouring, service, offering of requisites, and teaching are only found in the three doors of body and speech, not in the mind door. And here the offering of requisites and the teaching should be understood to occur in the body door too when one gives the requisites and teaches by bodily action.

original: dentassa, dhammaṃ desentassa ca kāyadvārepi pavatti veditabbā. Sīlaṃ bhāvanā abbhanumodanaṃ
analyzed: dentassa dhammam desentassa ca kāya dvāre pi pavatti veditabbā sīlam bhāvanā abbhanumodanam
translated: Virtue, development, rejoicing,🔽hearing, and right action of view:

original: savanaṃ diṭṭhijukammanti imāni pana pañca tīsupi dvāresu pavattanti, “na punevaṃ
analyzed: savanam diṭṭhi ju kammanti imāni pana pañca tīsu pi dvāresu pavattanti na puna evam
translated: These five occur in three doors.🔽“I shall not do so again” is virtue and rejoicing

original: karissāmī”ti cettha manasāva duccaritato viramantassa, abbhanumodantassa ca vasena🔽sīlabbhanumodanānaṃ manodvārepi pavatti veditabbā. Yaṃ pana aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ “dānamayaṃ🔽kāyavacīmanokammavasena tividhaṃ hotī”tiādi vuttaṃ, taṃ pubbacetanāvasena manodvāre
analyzed: karissāmi iti ca itthā manasā ava duccaritataḥ viramantassa ca vasena  manaḥ dvāre pi pavatti veditabbā yam pana aṭṭhasāliniyam dāna mayam  kāya vacī manaḥ kamma vasena tividham hoti itiādi vuttam tam pubba cetanā vasena manaḥ dvāre
translated: By the mind door too.

original: pavattaṃ gahetvā pariyāyato vuttaṃ, nippariyāyato kāyavacīdvārappavattā sanniṭṭhānacetanāva.
analyzed: pavattam gahetvā pariyāyataḥ vuttam nippariyāyataḥ kāya vacī dvāra ppavattā sanniṭṭhāna cetanā va
translated: But what is said in the Paṭisambhidā in the section dealing with giving in the “eight questions” way, namely, “Giving is threefold, being of giving of material things, of giving fearlessness, and of giving the Dhamma” , is said figuratively by taking the intention that occurs in the mind door as the giving. For the intention that occurs in the mind door is the only one that is actual giving, etc., in the ultimate sense.

original: Teneva hi tattheva vuttaṃ “vinayapariyāyaṃ patvā hi ‘dassāmi karissāmī’ti vācā bhinnā
analyzed: tena iva hi tattha eva vuttam vinaya pariyāyam patvā hi dassāmi karissāmi iti vācā bhinnā
translated: That is why it is said there: “When the Vinaya method is being used, the word ‘I give’ or ‘I will do’ is broken.

original: hotīti. Iminā lakkhaṇena dānaṃ nāma hoti, abhidhammapariyāyaṃ patvā pana vijjamānakavatthuṃ🔽ārabbha manasā cintitakālato paṭṭhāya kusalaṃ hoti. Aparabhāge kāyena vā vācāya vā
analyzed: hoti iti iminā lakkhaṇena dānam nāma hoti abhidhamma pariyāyam patvā pana vijjamānaka vatthum  ārabbha manasā cintita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya kusalam hoti aparabhāge kāyena vā vācāya vā
translated: This is the characteristic of giving. But when the Abhidhamma method is being used, it is profitable from the time of the mere thinking of the object that exists.

original: kattabbaṃ karissatī”ti. Itarathā “dassāmī”ti cintitamattenāpi dānaṃ nāma bhaveyya,
analyzed: kattabbam karissati iti itarathā dassāmi iti cintita mattena api dānam nāma bhaveyya
translated: Later he will do what has to be done by body or speech. ” Otherwise giving would be giving even when it is merely thought of as “I will give.”

original: tathā ca tādisaṃ vatthuṃ yathācintitaniyāmena adentassa dhuranikkhepe adinnādānampi
analyzed: tathā ca tādisam vatthum yathā cintita niyāmena adentassa dhura nikkhepe adinna ādānam pi
translated: And so too, if one who does not give in the way he has thought of a suitable object, there would be stealing by his giving up the effort.

original: siyā. Evaṃ manasā pāṇātipātādayopi siyuṃ, tañca na yuttaṃ, tasmā vuttanayeneva gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: siyā evam manasā pāṇātipāta ādayaḥ api siyum tat ca na yuttam tasmā vutta nayena iva gahetabbam
translated: And so too, killing breathing things, etc., would be done by mere thinking. But that is not right. So it should be taken as stated.

original: Atha vā “sabbaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dinnaññeva haratū”ti pariccajanasambhavato dānassa manodvārepi pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: atha vā sabbam sāpateyyam haratu uti pariccajana sambhavataḥ dānassa manaḥ dvāre pi pavatti veditabbā
translated: Or alternatively, giving should be understood as occurring in the mind door too, because of the possibility of the act of giving being accomplished by the mere act of resolving thus: “Let all my property be given.”

original: Ettha ca dānasīlādikāyakammānaṃ kāyadvāre pavattiyaṃ kammaṃ kāyakammameva, dvārampi
analyzed: ettha ca dāna sīla ādi kāya kammānam kāya dvāre pavattiyam kammam kāya kammam eva dvāram pi
translated: And here, in the case of the bodily action consisting of giving, virtue, etc., the action occurs in the body door, and the door is the body door.

original: kāyadvārameva. Vacīdvāre pavattiyaṃ kammaṃ kāyakammameva, dvāraṃ pana vacīdvāraṃ.🔽Manodvāre pavattiyampi kammaṃ kāyakammaṃ, dvāraṃ pana manodvāraṃ. Desanābbhanumodanādīnaṃ
analyzed: kāya dvāram eva vacī dvāre pavattiyam kammam kāya kammam eva dvāram pana vacī dvāram  manaḥ dvāre kammam kāya kammam dvāram pana manaḥ dvāram desanā abbhanumodanā ādīnam
translated: In the case of the action consisting of the bodily expression of appreciation, the action is bodily action, but the door is the speech door.🔽In the case of the action consisting of the bodily expression of assent, the action is bodily action, but the door is the mind door.

original: vacīkammānaṃ vacīdvāre pavattiyaṃ kammampi vacīkammaṃ, dvārampi vacīdvārameva. Kāyadvāre🔽pavattiyampi kammaṃ vacīkammameva, dvāraṃ pana kāyadvāraṃ. Manodvāre pavattiyampi🔽kammaṃ vacīkammaṃ, dvāraṃ pana manodvāraṃ. Bhāvanādimanokammānaṃ manodvāre pavattiyaṃ🔽kammampi manokammaṃ, dvārampi manodvārameva. Kāyadvāre pavattiyampi kammaṃ manokammameva,
analyzed: vacī kammānam vacī dvāre pavattiyam kammam pi vacī kammam dvāram pi vacī dvāram eva kāya dvāre  pavattiyam pi kammam vacī kammam eva dvāram pana kāya dvāram manaḥ dvāre pavattiyam pi  kammam vacī kammam dvāram pana manaḥ dvāram bhāvanā ādi manaḥ kammānam manaḥ dvāre pavattiyam  kammam pi manaḥ kammam dvāram pi manaḥ dvāram eva kāya dvāre pavattiyam pi kammam manaḥ kammam eva
translated: In the case of the verbal action consisting of teaching, appreciation, etc., the action and the door are both the speech door. In the case of the action consisting of the verbal expression of assent, the action is verbal action, but the door is the body door.🔽In the case of the action consisting of the verbal expression of appreciation, the action is verbal action, but the door is the mind door.🔽In the case of the mental action consisting of development, etc., the action and the door are both the mind door. In the case of the action consisting of the mental expression of assent, the action is mental action, but the door is the body door.

original: dvāraṃ pana kāyadvāraṃ. Vacīdvāre pavattiyampi kammaṃ manokammameva, dvāraṃ pana
analyzed: dvāram pana kāya dvāram vacī dvāre pavattiyam pi kammam manaḥ kammam eva dvāram pana
translated: In the case of the action consisting of the mental expression of appreciation, the action is mental action, but the door is the speech door.

original: vacīdvāraṃ. Evaṃ pāṇātipātādīnaṃ, pāṇātipātāveramaṇiādīnañca vuttānusārena kammavavatthānaṃ,
analyzed: vacī dvāram evam pāṇātipāta ādīnam vutta anusārena kamma vavatthānam
translated: and the verbal door.🔽The exposition of the kinds of kamma should be understood in the way stated here for killing breathing things, etc., and for the abstention from killing breathing things, etc.

original: dvāravavatthānañca yathānurūpaṃ yojetvā asaṅkarato ñātabbaṃ.
analyzed: dvāra vavatthānam ca yathānurūpam yojetvā asaṅkarataḥ ñātabbam
translated: So the exposition of action and of the doors should be understood without confusion by applying the method stated under killing living beings, etc., and the abstention from killing living beings, etc., as appropriate.

original: Dvārakammavavatthānakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dvāra kamma vavatthāna kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the exposition of doors and of action is ended.

original: Idāni yasmā dasavidhāni cetāni puññakiriyavatthūni tīsu evaṃ saṅgayhanti dānamaye🔽sīlamaye bhāvanāmayeti. Pattānuppadānaṃ hi dānamaye saṅgayhati, “abbhanumodanampī”ti
analyzed: idāni yasmai dasavidhāni cetāni puñña kiriya vatthūni tīsu evam saṅgayhanti dāna maye  sīla maye bhāvanā maye iti patta an uppadānam hi dāna maye saṅgayhati abbhanumodanam pi iti
translated: Now, these ten bases of meritorious deeds are included in three: in the basis of merit consisting in giving,

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Apacitiveyyāvaccāni sīlamaye. Desanāsavanadiṭṭhijukammāni bhāvanāmaye,
analyzed: apaciti veyyāvaccāni sīla maye desanā savana diṭṭhi ju kammāni bhāvanā maye
translated: and in the basis of merit consisting in virtue, and in the basis of merit consisting in development. The act of receiving is included in the basis of merit consisting in giving, and “rejoicing” is included in the basis of merit consisting in giving, according to the commentary. The act of paying homage and the act of rendering service are included in the basis of merit consisting in virtue. The act of listening to Dhamma, the act of professing the Dhamma, and the act of setting beings free from bondage are included in the basis of merit consisting in development.

original: tasmā rūpārammaṇassa kusalassa dānasīlabhāvanāvasena dvārattayappavattiṃ yojetvā🔽dassessāma. Tadanusāreneva itaresaṃ vasenāpi sakkā ñātunti. Kusalaṃ hi vaṇṇārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tasmā rūpa ārammaṇassa kusalassa dāna sīla bhāvanā vasena dvāra ttaya ppavattim yojetvā  dassessāma tad anusārena iva itaresam vasena api sakkā ñātum ti kusalam hi vaṇṇa ārammaṇam
translated: Therefore, after showing the occurrence of the profitable in the three doors by way of giving, virtue, and development, with reference to the profitable having visible form as its object,🔽we shall show the rest by way of the same method. For it can be understood by the same method. For the profitable having visible form as its object occurs in the three doors by way of giving, virtue, and development. How?

original: hutvā uppajjamānaṃ dānasīlabhāvanāvaseneva tīsu dvāresu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Yadā hi
analyzed: hutvā uppajjamānam dāna sīla bhāvanā vasena iva tīsu dvāresu pavattati katham yadā hi
translated: When, after making a gift of a visible form, such as a flower, etc.,

original: nīlapītādivaṇṇavicittaṃ pupphavatthādideyyadhammaṃ labhitvā “vaṇṇadānaṃ me bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: nīla pīta ādi vaṇṇa vicittam puppha vattha ādi deyya dhammam labhitvā vaṇṇa dānam me bhavissati iti
translated: Having obtained a gift of flowers, cloth, etc., of various colours such as blue, yellow, etc., thinking “This will be a gift of colour,”

original: vaṇṇavasena ābhujitvā cetiyādīsu sahatthena pūjeti, tadā rūpārammaṇaṃ dānamayaṃ kāyadvāre
analyzed: vaṇṇa vasena ābhujitvā cetiya ādīsu sahatthena pūjā iti tadā rūpa ārammaṇam dāna mayam kāyadvāre
translated: and having rolled it up in the form of a colour, if he worships with his own hand in a shrine-room, etc., then the giving of material form as a gift occurs in the body door with material form as its object.

original: pavattati, tañca pubbacetanā sanniṭṭhānacetanā aparacetanāti tividhaṃ hoti. Evaṃ
analyzed: pavattati tat ca pubba cetanā sanniṭṭhāna cetanā apara cetanā ati tividham hoti evam
translated: And that is threefold as the prior volition, the decisive-support volition, and the subsequent volition. In the same way,

original: uparipi sabbavāresu tividhatā veditabbā. Yadā pana tadeva yathāvuttavatthuṃ vācāya
analyzed: upari pi sabba vāresu tividha tā veditabbā yadā pana tat eva yathā vutta vatthum vācāya
translated: in all the following cases the threefold nature should be understood.

original: āṇāpetvā puttadārādīhi dāpeti, tadārūpārammaṇaṃ dānamayaṃ vacīdvāre pavattati. Yadā
analyzed: āṇāpetvā putta dāra ādīhi dāpeti tadārūpa ārammaṇam dāna mayam vacī dvāre pavattati yadā
translated: But when he has that same object mentioned above announced by word of mouth and gives it through his children, wife, etc., then the giving of immaterial form occurs in the speech door.

original: pana tadeva vijjamānakavatthuṃ “dassāmī”ti cinteti, paccāsīsati, yathādhippāyaṃ nipphādessati,
analyzed: pana tat eva vijjamānaka vatthum dassāmi iti cinteti paccāsīsati yathā adhippāyam nipphādessati
translated: But when he thinks “I will give” that same object which exists, and he resolves and will produce it according to his wish,

original: tadā pubbacetanāvasena pariyāyato dānamayaṃ manodvāre pavattati nāma. Evaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tadā pubba cetanā vasena pariyāyataḥ dāna mayam manaḥ dvāre pavattati nāma evam rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: then the giving of material form occurs figuratively by way of the prior volition in the mind door. So the giving of material form

original: dānamayaṃ dvāravasena tividhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: dāna mayam dvāra vasena tividham
translated: is threefold by way of the doors.

original: Yadā pana vuttappakāravaṇṇaṃ deyyadhammaṃ labhitvā “evaṃ manāpavaṇṇānaṃ pariccajanaṃ
analyzed: yadā pana vutta pakāra vaṇṇam deyya dhammam labhitvā evam manāpa vaṇṇānam pariccajanam
translated: But when he has obtained a gift of the kind described, he should give it away, thinking, “I will give to those who are dear to me,🔽

original: nāma mayhaṃ kulavaṃsāgatavattameta”nti sahatthā pūjeti, tādisavaṇṇavantaṃ vā parapariggahitādibhogasampattiṃ🔽pariccajitvā sīlaṃ rakkhati, tadā rūpārammaṇaṃ sīlaṃ kāyadvāre ca pavattati. Yadā🔽pana vuttappakāravaṇṇaṃ deyyadhammaṃ kulavaṃsādivasena vācāya āṇāpetvā parehi dāpeti,
analyzed: nāma mayham sahatthā pūjā iti tādi savaṇṇavantam vā para pariggahita ādi bhoga sampattim  pariccajitvā sīlam rakkhati tadā rūpa ārammaṇam sīlam kāya dvāre ca pavattati yadā  pana vutta ppakāra vaṇṇam deyya dhammam kula vaṃsa ādi vasena vācāya āṇāpetvā parehi dāpeti
translated: But when he has obtained a gift of the kind described and gives it himself, thinking, “To give to those who are so lovely to look upon is a family custom in our house,” or when he keeps the precepts after giving away such a possession as a lovely field or house, etc., that is owned by others, then the virtue is in the body door.

original: tādisaṃ vā parapariggahitādiṃ vācāya apanetvā sīlaṃ rakkhati, tadā rūpārammaṇaṃ sīlaṃ🔽vacīdvāre pavattati. Yadā pana tādisaṃ vijjamānakavatthuṃ kulavaṃsādivasena “dassāmī”ti,
analyzed: tādisam vā para pariggahita ādim vācāya apanetvā sīlam rakkhati tadā rūpa ārammaṇam sīlam  vacī dvāre pavattati yadā pana tādisam vijjamānaka vatthum kula vaṃsa ādi vasena dassāmi iti
translated: But when he has a gift of the kind described given by others on his verbal command, thinking, “Give it,” or when he keeps the precepts after having given away such a possession as a lovely field or house, etc., that is owned by others, then the virtue is in the speech door.

original: tādisaṃ parapariggahitādikaṃ anāmasitvā “sīlaṃ rakkhissāmī”ti vā cinteti, tadā rūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tādisam para pariggahita ādikam an āmasitvā sīlam rakkhissāmi iti vā cinteti tadā rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: But when he thinks, “I shall give such and such a thing,” or “I shall keep the precepts,” with regard to a possession of the kind described that exists in his house, or when he thinks, “I shall keep the precepts,” without specifying any particular possession, then the virtue is in the mind door.

original: sīlaṃ manodvāre pavattati. Evaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ sīlamayaṃ dvāravasena tividhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sīlam manaḥ dvāre pavattati evam rūpa ārammaṇam sīla mayam dvāra vasena tividham hoti
translated: Virtue occurs in the mind door. So virtue with materiality as its object is of three kinds according to door.

original: Yadā pana vuttappakāraṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ datvā tadeva vaṇṇaṃ, sabbaṃ vā rūpāyatanaṃ caṅkamanto
analyzed: yadā pana vutta ppakāram vaṇṇavantam da tvā tat eva vaṇṇam sabbam vā rūpa āyatanam caṅkamantaḥ
translated: But when he gives the kind of colour already mentioned and contemplates the colour of the whole material body as he walks up and down,

original: aniccādito vipassati, tadā rūpārammaṇaṃ bhāvanāmayaṃ kāyadvāre pavattati. Tadeva
