analyzed: paṭhama kappikānam pavatte samuṭṭhāti tatas apara bhāge paṭisandhiyam eva sabbesam
translated: not in the other four kinds of becoming.

original: pana pavatte eva parivattati. Imesu ca purisaliṅgaṃ uttamaṃ, itthiliṅgaṃ hīnaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: pana pavatte eva parivattati imesu ca purisa liṅgam uttamam itthi liṅgam hīnam tasmāt
translated: but it is only the mode of appearance that changes. And of these, the male organ is the superior, the female organ the inferior.

original: purisaliṅgaṃ balavaakusalena antaradhāyati, itthiliṅgaṃ dubbalakusalena patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: purisa liṅgam balava akusalena antaradhāyati itthi liṅgam dubbala kusalena patiṭṭhāti
translated: Therefore the male organ disappears through strong unprofitable action, and the female organ appears through weak profitable action.

original: Itthiliṅgaṃ pana antaradhāyantaṃ dubbalākusalena antaradhāyati, itaraṃ balavakusalena
analyzed: itthi liṅgam pana antaradhāyantam dubbala akusalena antaradhāyati itaram
translated: But the female organ disappears through weak unprofitable action, and the other appears through strong profitable action.

original: patiṭṭhāti. Evaṃ ubhayampi sugatiyaṃ akusaleneva antaradhāyati, kusaleneva patiṭṭhāti.🔽Kāyappasādo viya ca sakalasarīrabyāpakameva, na ca kāyappasādādīnaṃ ṭhitokāse tiṭṭhati.🔽Yadi evaṃ na sabbattha kāyabhāvindriyānīti? Nevaṃ paramatthato sabbattha, vinibbhujitvā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti evam ubhayam pi sugatiyam akusalena iva antaradhāyati kusalena iva patiṭṭhāti  kāya ppasādaḥ ca sakala sarīra byāpakam eva na ca kāya ppasāda ādīnam ṭhitokāse tiṭṭhati  yadi evam na sabbattha kāya bhāva indriyāni iti na ivam paramatthataḥ sabbattha vinibbhujitvā
translated: So in both cases it is only through unprofitable action that it disappears in the happy destinies, and through profitable action that it appears.🔽It pervades the whole body like the sensitivity of the body, and it does not occur in the place occupied by the sensitivity of the body, and so on.

original: panesaṃ okāsabhedaṃ paññāpetuṃ na sakkā rūparasādīnaṃ viya. Na hi paramatthato rūpe
analyzed: pana isam okāsa bhedam paññāpetum na sakkā rūpa rasa ādīnam viya na hi paramatthato rūpe
translated: If that is so, then the body faculty and the sex faculty are not found everywhere? They are not found everywhere in the ultimate sense, but it cannot be demonstrated that they have a location divisible from that of the sensitivity of the body, and so on, as taste, etc., have. For there is no taste in the ultimate sense in visible data, etc.,

original: raso atthi. Yadi siyā, rūpaggahaṇeneva gahaṇaṃ gaccheyya. Evaṃ kāyabhāvindriyāni
analyzed: rasaḥ atthi yadi siyā rūpa ggahaṇena iva gahaṇam gaccheyya evam kāya bhāva indriyāni
translated: if there were, it would be apprehended as such by the apprehension of visible data, and so too the body faculty and the sex faculty

original: paramatthato na sabbattha, na ca sabbattha natthi vivecetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya heṭṭhā
analyzed: paramatthataḥ na sabbattha na ca sabbattha natthi vivecetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya heṭṭhā
translated: not in the ultimate sense, because they cannot be discerned as such.

original: vuttalakkhaṇādivavatthānatopi cesaṃ asammissatā desato na vivekābhāvepi. Na kevalañca🔽imāneva, sabbānipi rūpāni asammissāneva honti. Yathā hi pañcavaṇṇena kappāsena vaṭṭiṃ🔽katvā dīpe jalite kiñcāpi jālā ekābaddhā viya honti, tassa tassa pana aṃsuno pāṭiyekkaṃ
analyzed: vutta lakkhaṇa ādi vavatthānataḥ api ca īsam asammissa tā desataḥ na viveka abhāve pi na kevalam ca  imāni eva sabbāni api rūpāni a sammissāna iva honti yathā hi pañca vaṇṇena kappāsena vaṭṭim  katvā dīpe jalite kiñca api jālāḥ ekābaddhāḥ viya honti tassa tassa pana aṃsuno pāṭiyekkam
translated: But they are not non-existent in the ultimate sense either, because they can be discerned as having the characteristics, etc., already stated.🔽And not only these, but all material instances are unmixed.🔽For just as when a wick is made from cotton of five colours and a lamp is lit, although the flame is a unity, still the flame is unmixed with each of the five colours,

original: jālā aññamaññaṃ asammissāva. Evaṃ kāyabhāvindriyādīni ekasmiṃ ṭhāne samosaṭānipi
analyzed: evam kāya bhāvindriya ādīni ekasmin ṭhāne
translated: and each of the five colours is unmixed with the flame, so too, although the body faculty, the five life faculties, etc., are collected together in one place,

original: bhinnaṭṭhānesu heṭṭhupariyādivasena natthi, tānipi asammissāneva honti.🔽Sahajarūpānaṃ anupālanalakkhaṇaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ, tesaṃ pavattanarasaṃ, tesaṃyeva ṭhapanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: bhinna ṭhānesu heṭṭhu pariyā ādi vasena na atthi tāni pi honti  sahaja rūpānam anupālana lakkhaṇam jīvitindriyam tesam pavattana rasam tesam yeva ṭhapana paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: they are not in different places, as the upper and lower parts, etc., are, and they are unmixed with each other.🔽The life faculty has the characteristic of maintaining the conascent material instances. Its function is to cause them to occur. It is manifested as their steadiness.

original: yāpayitabbadhammapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Atthikkhaṇe eva cetaṃ sahajarūpāni anupāleti udakaṃ
analyzed: yāpayitabba dhamma padaṭṭhānam atthi kkhaṇe eva ca itam sahaja rūpāni anupāleti udakam
translated: Its proximate cause is the state of being maintained. It maintains the conascent material instances only at the moment of their presence, like water a bubble in water.

original: viya uppalādīni, na bhaṅgakkhaṇe sayaṃ bhijjamānattā, yathāsakaṃ paccayuppannepi
analyzed: viya uppala ādīni na bhaṅga kkhaṇe sayam bhijjamāna ttā yathāsakam paccaya uppanne pi
translated: like the lotus, etc., do not break up by themselves at the moment of their presence,

original: ca dhamme pāleti dhātī viya kumāraṃ, sayaṃpavattitadhammasambandheneva ca pavattati
analyzed: ca dhamme pāleti dhātī viya kumāram sayaṃpavattita dhamma sambandhena iva ca pavattati
translated: but they are protected by the conditions that produce them, like a child by its nurse. And it occurs only by the connection with the states that occur with it,

original: niyāmako viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: niyāmakaḥ viya āti daṭṭhabbam
translated: like a controller.

original: Manodhātumanoviññāṇadhātūnaṃ nissayalakkhaṇaṃ hadayavatthu, tāsaññeva dhātūnaṃ dhāraṇarasaṃ,🔽ubbahanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Idaṃ pana hadayavatthu yadetaṃ antosarīre dvinnaṃ thanānaṃ🔽majjhe bāhirapattāni apanetvā adhomukhaṭṭhapitarattapadumamakulasaṇṭhānaṃ bahi maṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātūnam nissaya lakkhaṇam hadaya vatthu tāsaññeva dhātūnam dhāraṇa rasam  ubbahana paccupaṭṭhānam idam pana hadaya vatthu yat etam antosarīre dvinnam  majjhe bāhira pattāni apanetvā bahi maṭṭham
translated: The heart-basis has the characteristic of being the support of the mind-element and the mind-consciousness element. Its function is to hold those same two elements.🔽It is manifested as the receiving of their impact.

original: anto kosātakīphalassa abbhantarasadisaṃ, paññavantānaṃ thokaṃ vikasitaṃ, mandapaññānaṃ🔽makuḷitaṃ, hadayamaṃsayamakaṃ parikkhipitvā vakkayakanakilomakapihakādayo tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: antar kosātakī phalassa abbhantara sadisam paññavantānam thokam vikasitam manda paññānam 🔽makuḷitam hadayam aṃsa yamakam parikkhipitvā vakkayaka nakilomaka pihaka ādayo tiṭṭhanti
translated: This heart-basis is to be found in the middle of the body between the nipples. It is the size of a myrobalan plum. It is the colour of pressed turmeric. It is the shape of a lotus root. It is on the outside of the flesh and on the inside of the heart. It is like the inside of a kosātakī seed. It is slightly expanded in the wise,🔽but in the witless it is like a shrivelled kosātakī seed. It is surrounded by heart-flesh. The liver, midriff, heart, kidneys, lungs, spleen, and intestines are all within it. The gullet, mouth, nostrils, eyes, and ears are connected to it. The bile, phlegm, pus, blood, urine, and excrement are all within it. The sinews, nerves, and veins are connected to it. The head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, and the rest are all rooted in it. It is the basis for the mind-element and the mind-consciousness element.

original: Tassa sasambhārahadayamaṃsassa anto punnāgaṭṭhipatiṭṭhānamatte āvāṭake saṇṭhitaṃ
analyzed: tassa sa sambhāra hadaya maṃsassa antar punnāga aṭṭhi patiṭṭhāna matte āvāṭake saṇṭhitam
translated: The blood, which is the measure of half a pasata, is contained in the heart together with its sheaths, in the form of a pool the size of a jujube leaf.

original: addhapasatamattalohitaṃ saṇṭhāti. Tañca rāgacaritassa rattaṃ, dosacaritassa kāḷakaṃ,
analyzed: addha pasata matta lohitam saṇṭhāti tat ca rāga caritassa rattam dosa caritassa kāḷakam
translated: In a person of lustful temperament it is red; in one of hating temperament, black;

original: mohacaritassa maṃsadhovanaudakasadisaṃ, vitakkacaritassa kulatthayūsavaṇṇaṃ, saddhācaritassa
analyzed: moha caritassa maṃsa dhovana audaka sadisam vitakka caritassa kulattha yūsa vaṇṇam saddhā caritassa
translated: in one of deluded temperament, like water used for washing meat; in one of speculative temperament, the colour of pumpkin juice; in one of faithful temperament,

original: kaṇikārapupphavaṇṇaṃ, buddhicaritassa acchaṃ vippasannaṃ anāvilaṃ paṇḍaraṃ parisuddhaṃ
analyzed: kaṇikāra puppha vaṇṇam buddhi caritassa accham vippasannam anāvilam paṇḍaram parisuddham
translated: the colour of kaṇikāra flowers; in one of intelligent temperament, clear, bright, limpid, and pure, radiant like a well-cut gem.

original: niddhotajātimaṇi viya jutimantaṃ hoti, byāpetvā sandhāraṇādikiccehi bhūtehi katūpakāraṃ🔽āyunā anupāliyamānaṃ vaṇṇādiparivutaṃ utucittāhārehi upatthambhiyamānaṃ manodhātumanoviññāṇadhātūnañceva🔽taṃsampayuttānañca vatthubhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: viya jutimantam hoti byāpetvā sandhāraṇa ādi kiccehi bhūtehi katu upakāram  āyunā anupāliyamānam vaṇṇa ādi parivutam utu citta āhārehi upatthambhiyamānam manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātūnam ca iva  tad sampayuttānam ca vatthu bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati
translated: It is a service rendered to the primary elements by the blood, which is a condition for the maintenance of the body, etc.,🔽and it is a support for the life faculty, which is not subject to exhaustion as long as life lasts. It is surrounded by the colours, etc., and it is maintained by the temperature, mental volition, and nutriment.🔽It is the basis for the mind element and the mind-consciousness element and for the states associated with them.

original: Abhikkamādippavattakacittasamuṭṭhānavāyodhātuyā sahajarūpakāyasanthambhanasandhāraṇacalanassa
analyzed: abhikkama ādi ppavattaka citta samuṭṭhāna vāyodhātuyā sahaja rūpa kāya santhambhana sandhāraṇa calanassa
translated: It is the condition for the maintenance, support, and movement of the body, which is born together with the air element that originates with the mind that occurs in the act of going forward and back.

original: paccayākāravikāralakkhaṇā kāyaviññatti, adhippāyappakāsanarasā, kāyavipphandanahetubhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā,🔽cittasamuṭṭhānavāyodhātupadaṭṭhānā. Vacībhedappavattakacittasamuṭṭhānapathavīdhātuyā
analyzed: paccaya ākāra vikāra lakkhaṇā kāya viññatti adhippāya ppakāsana rasā kāya vipphandana hetu bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā  citta samuṭṭhāna vāyodhātu padaṭṭhānā vacībheda ppavattaka citta samuṭṭhāna pathavī dhātuyā
translated: bodily intimation has the characteristic of being a modification of the mode of appearance of a condition. Its function is to manifest an intention. It is manifested as the cause of bodily movement.🔽Its proximate cause is the air element generated by consciousness.

original: upādinnaghaṭṭanassa paccayākāravikāralakkhaṇā vacīviññatti, adhippāyappakāsanarasā,🔽vacīghosassa hetubhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, cittasamuṭṭhānapathavīdhātupadaṭṭhānā. Ubhopetā
analyzed: upādinna ghaṭṭanassa paccaya ākāra vikāra lakkhaṇā vacī viññatti adhippāya ppakāsana rasā  vacī ghosassa hetu bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā citta samuṭṭhāna pathavī dhātu padaṭṭhānā ubha upetā
translated: Verbal intimation has the characteristic of being a modification of the mode of appearance of a condition. Its function is to manifest an intention.🔽It is manifested as the cause of the sound of speech. Its proximate cause is the earth element generated by consciousness.🔽Both have the characteristic of being intimation by body and speech. Their function is to intimate an intention.🔽They are manifested as the cause of the intimation of an intention. Their proximate cause is the earth element generated by consciousness.

original: kāyavipphandanavacīghosehi sayaṃ viññeyyattā, adhippāyaviññāpanato ca “kāyavacīviññattiyo”ti
analyzed: kāya vipphandana vacī ghosehi sayam viññeyya ttā adhippāya viññāpanato ca kāya vacī viññattiyo ti
translated: They are called “intimations by body and speech” because they are to be known respectively by body and by speech, and because they intimate an intention.

original: vuccanti. Cakkhusotapathasmiṃ hi ṭhatvā kenaci hatthavikārasīsukkhipanādikāyavikāre,
analyzed: vuccanti cakkhu sota pathasmim hi ṭhatvā kenacid hattha vikāra sīsukkhipana ādi kāya vikāre
translated: For when someone stands within the range of the eye and ear and makes bodily movements such as waving the hand, raising the eyebrows, etc.,

original: sadde vā kate tathāpavattarūpasaddāyatanāni cakkhusotaviññeyyāni, na tāni viññattiyo,
analyzed: sadde vā kate tathā apavatta rūpa sadda āyatanāni cakkhu sota viññeyyāni na tāni viññattiyaḥ
translated: or makes sounds, then the visible-form and sound bases that occur in such cases are cognizable by the eye and ear respectively, but they are not intimations.

original: cittasamuṭṭhitakalāpagatāya pana vāyodhātuyā sahajātarūpakāyasandhāraṇacalanādīnaṃ🔽paccayabhūto vikāro kāyaviññatti, tathā cittasamuṭṭhitapathavīdhātuyā upādinnaghaṭṭanassa🔽paccayabhūto ākāravikāro vacīviññatti. Na ca tā cakkhusotaviññeyyā, tā pana manodvārikajavanehi🔽tālapaṇṇādisaññāya udapānādīni viya yathāgahitakāyavikāravacīghosānusārena tiracchānānampi
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhita kalāpa gatāya pana vāyodhātuyā sahajāta rūpa kāya sandhāraṇa calana ādīnam  paccaya bhūtaḥ vikāraḥ kāya viññatti tathā citta samuṭṭhita pathavī dhātuyā upādinna ghaṭṭanassa  paccaya bhūtaḥ ākāra vikāraḥ vacī viññatti na ca tā cakkhu sota viññeyyā tā pana manaḥ dvārika javanehi  tāla paṇṇa ādi saññāya udapāna ādīni
translated: But the modification of the air element derived from the mind, which is a condition for the support, movement, etc., of the body consisting of the derived materiality that is conascent with it, is bodily intimation. Likewise the modification of the visible-data element derived from the mind, which is a condition for the striking of what is clung to, is verbal intimation. And they are not to be known by the eye and ear respectively, but by the mind-door process that occurs in conformity with the bodily and verbal expression as apprehended, as water-sipping, etc., are by the mind-door process that occurs in conformity with the expression “water-sipping,” etc. They are also known by animals, etc.,

original: viññeyyā, tadanusāreneva “idañcidañca esa kāreti, vadati cā”ti adhippāyo ca viññeyyo
analyzed: viññeyyā tad anusārena iva vadati ca ati adhippāyo ca viññeyyo
translated: But the modification of the air element derived from the mind that is a condition for the support, shaking, etc., of the body consisting of the derived materiality is bodily intimation. Likewise the modification of the visible-data element derived from the mind that is a condition for the striking of what is clung to is verbal intimation. And they are not to be known by the eye and ear respectively, but they are to be known by animals too by the mode of the bodily change and the sound of speech in accordance with the way they have been apprehended, as water-drawing, etc., are by the idea of the palm-leaf fan, and so on. And the intention is to be known by the mode itself in accordance with the way it has been apprehended thus, “This one does this and that, and he speaks thus and thus.”

original: hoti, tasmā sayaṃ viññeyyato, adhippāyaviññāpanato ca “viññattiyo”ti vuccanti.🔽Tattha ca manodvārikajavanavīthiyaṃ sattasu kāmāvacarajavanesu kāyaviññattijanakesu
analyzed: hoti tasmā sayam viññeyyataḥ adhippāya viññāpanataḥ ca viññattiyaḥ ti vuccanti  tattha ca manodvārika javana vīthiyam sattasu kāmāvacara javanesu kāya viññatti janakesu
translated: So they are called “intimations” because they are to be known by oneself and because they intimate an intention.🔽And here, in the course of the cognitive series of the mind-door, in the first six impulsions of the six kinds of sense-desire consciousness that originate bodily intimation,

original: purimehi chahi javanehi samuṭṭhitavāyodhātuyo upatthambhanasandhāraṇakiccameva kātuṃ
analyzed: purimehi chahi javanehi samuṭṭhita vāyodhātuyaḥ upatthambhana sandhāraṇa kiccam eva kātum
translated: the air elements derived from the mind that have arisen with the first six impulsions only perform the function of supporting and steadying.

original: sakkonti, abhikkamādiṃ pana nipphādetuṃ na sakkonti. Sattamajavanasamuṭṭhitā pana🔽heṭṭhā chahi javanehi samuṭṭhitavāyodhātuyopatthambhaṃ labhitvā sattahi yugehi ākaḍḍhitabbabhāraṃ🔽sakaṭaṃ sattamayugayuttagoṇo viya itarachayugayuttagoṇopatthambhaṃ labhitvā rūpakāyassa
analyzed: sakkonti abhikkama ādim pana nipphādetum na sakkonti sattama javana samuṭṭhitā pana  heṭṭhā chahi javanehi samuṭṭhita vāyodhātuyā upatthambham labhitvā sattahi yugehi ākaḍḍhitabba bhāram  sakaṭam sattama yuga yutta goṇaḥ viya itara cha yuga yutta goṇa upatthambham labhitvā rūpa kāyassa
translated: but they cannot produce the actual going. But the air element that arises with the seventh impulsion🔽obtains support from the air element that has arisen with the first six impulsions, and it can do the work of drawing along a load that has to be drawn by seven pairs of oxen, like an ox that is the seventh in a team of seven pairs. So too, with the air element that arises with the seventh impulsion, which produces the intimation of communication,

original: abhikkamapaṭikkamādiṃ kāretuṃ sakkoti, evaṃ vacīviññattijanakepi sattamajavanehi🔽samuṭṭhitāya pathavīdhātuyāpi upādinnaghaṭṭanassa paccayabhāvo veditabbo. Idha pana
analyzed: abhikkama paṭikkama ādim kāretum sakkoti evam vacī viññatti janake pi sattama javanehi  samuṭṭhitāya pathavī dhātuyā api upādinna ghaṭṭanassa paccaya bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ idha pana
translated: the earth element that has support from the earth element that has arisen with the first six impulsions can do the work of causing the going forward, coming back, etc., of the material body, like an ox that is the seventh in a team of seven pairs and has support from the other oxen in the team. So too, with the air element that arises with the seventh impulsion, which produces the intimation of communication,🔽the earth element that has support from the earth element that has arisen with the first six impulsions can do the work of causing the going forward, coming back, etc., of the material body, like an ox that is the seventh in a team of seven pairs and has support from the other oxen in the team.

original: purimajavanasamuṭṭhitāya upatthambhakattaṃ, sattamajavanasamuṭṭhitāya calanapaccayattañca
analyzed: purima javana samuṭṭhitāya upatthambhaka ttam sattama javana samuṭṭhitāya calana paccaya ttam ca
translated: Herein, the function of the earth element that has arisen with the first impulsion is to support; that of the earth element that has arisen with the seventh impulsion is to cause movement as a condition.

original: natthi tesaṃ vāyodhātukiccattā, purimasahagatā pana pacchimā pathavīdhātu upādinnaghaṭṭanasamatthā
analyzed: natthi tesam vāyo dhātu kiccattā purima sahagatā pana pacchimā pathavī dhātu upādinna ghaṭṭana samatthā
translated: But there is no function of the air element as support, nor of the earth element as a condition for movement, because the air element is the function of impulsion and the earth element is the function of cohesion.🔽But the earth element that is associated with the first impulsion is capable of causing the impact on what is impacted.

original: hoti, sesaṃ tādisameva. Cittasamuṭṭhitakāye pana vāyodhātuyā calante tadupatthambhitatesamuṭṭhānikānampi
analyzed: hoti sesam tādisam eva citta samuṭṭhita kāye pana vāyodhātuyā calante tad upatthambhita tesamuṭṭhānikānam pi
translated: and the rest is the same as the other. But when the air element in the body, which is derived from temperature, moves, then the body’s going forwards, etc., occur through the moving of that derived from the temperature of consciousness,

original: calanato sakalakāyassa abhikkamādayo honti udake gacchante tattha patitatiṇapaṇṇāni viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: calanataḥ sakala kāyassa abhikkama ādayaḥ honti udake gacchante tattha patita tiṇa paṇṇāni viya iti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: just as when one walks on water in a boat, the grass and sticks on the water move too.

original: Rūpaparicchedalakkhaṇā ākāsadhātu, rūpapariyantappakāsanarasā, rūpamariyādapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: rūpa pariccheda lakkhaṇā ākāsadhātu rūpa pariyanta pakāsana rasā rūpa mariyāda paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: The space element has the characteristic of defining matter. Its function is to make room for matter. It is manifested as the non-obstruction of matter,

original: asamphuṭṭhabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, chiddavivarabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā vā, paricchinnarūpapadaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: a samphuṭṭha bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā chidda vivara bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā vā paricchinna rūpa padaṭṭhānā
translated: or it is manifested as the defining of matter’s location. Its proximate cause is matter.

original: yāya paricchinnesu rūpesu “idamito uddhaṃ, adho, tiriya”nti ca hoti.🔽Adandhatālakkhaṇā rūpassalahutā, rūpānaṃ garubhāvavinodanarasā, lahuparivattitāpaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: paricchinnesu rūpesu idam itas uddham adhas tiriyanti ca hoti  adandha tā lakkhaṇā rūpassa lahu tā rūpānam garu bhāva vinodana rasā lahu parivatti tā paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It is by means of it that matter is defined as “above,” “below,” “in front,” “behind,” and so on.🔽Lightness of matter has the characteristic of non-stiffness. Its function is to dispel heaviness of matter. It is manifested as readiness for movement.

original: lahurūpapadaṭṭhānā. Athaddhatālakkhaṇā rūpassamudutā, rūpānaṃ thaddhabhāvavinodanarasā,
analyzed: lahu rūpa padaṭṭhānā athaddha tā lakkhaṇā rūpassa mudu tā rūpānam thaddha bhāva vinodana rasā
translated: Its proximate cause is matter. Fluidity of matter has the characteristic of non-hardness. Its function is to dispel hardness of matter.

original: sabbakiriyāsu avirodhitāpaccupaṭṭhānā, mudurūpapadaṭṭhānā. Sarīrakiriyānukūlakammaññabhāvalakkhaṇā
analyzed: sabba kiriyāsu avirodhi tā paccupaṭṭhānā mudu rūpa padaṭṭhānā sarīra kiriyā anukūla kammañña bhāva lakkhaṇā
translated: Its function is to be present as non-opposition to all kinds of action. Its proximate cause is the flexible kind of materiality.🔽The characteristic of flexibility of matter is malleability.

original: rūpassakammaññatā, akammaññatāvinodanarasā, adubbalabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, kammaññatārūpapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: rūpassa akammañña tā akammañña tā vinodana rasā adubbala bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā kammañña tā rūpa padaṭṭhānā
translated: Its function is to remove inflexibility. Its manifestation is as non-weakness. Its proximate cause is the flexible kind of materiality.

original: Etā pana tissopi aññamaññaṃ na vijahanti, garuthaddhaakammaññarūpapaṭipakkhabhāvena
analyzed: etāḥ pana tissaḥ api aññam aññam na vijahanti garu thaddha akammañña rūpa paṭipakkha bhāvena
translated: But these three do not occur separately. They are called respectively “heavy,” “slow,” and “flexible” because they are respectively opposed to the kinds of matter that are light, quick, and malleable.

original: ca samuṭṭhitānaṃ utucittāhārajānaṃ lahumudukammaññabhūtānaṃ rūpānaṃ vikāratāya ca
analyzed: ca samuṭṭhitānam utu citta āhāra jānam lahu mudu kammañña bhūtānam rūpānam vikāra tāya ca
translated: And they are said to have respectively the function of removing the kinds of matter that arise through temperature, consciousness, and nutriment, which are respectively light, quick, and malleable, and of distorting them.

original: pariyāyato garuthaddhākammaññabhāvavinodanakiccā vuttā, na pana sabhāvato sayaṃ avijjamānattā.🔽Ācayalakkhaṇo rūpassaupacayo, pubbantato rūpānaṃ ummujjāpanaraso, niyyātanapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: pariyāyataḥ garu thaddhā kammañña bhāva vinodana kiccāḥ vuttāḥ na pana sabhāvataḥ sayam a vijjamāna ttā  ācaya lakkhaṇaḥ rūpassa upacayaḥ pubbantataḥ rūpānam ummujja āpana rasaḥ niyyātana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: But they are not so in reality, for they do not exist separately.🔽The characteristic of cohesion of matter is sticking together.🔽Its function is to make matter appear as if it were rising up from the past. Its manifestation is as sending out.🔽Or its manifestation is as the state of being complete. Its proximate cause is the matter that is accumulated.

original: paripuṇṇabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno vā, upacitarūpapadaṭṭhāno. Pavattilakkhaṇā rūpassasantati,
analyzed: paripuṇṇa bhāva paccupaṭṭhānaḥ vā upacita rūpa padaṭṭhāno pavatti lakkhaṇā rūpassa santati
translated: The characteristic of continuity of matter is occurrence.

original: anuppabandhanarasā, anupacchedapaccupaṭṭhānā, anuppabandhakarūpapadaṭṭhānā. Ubhayampetaṃ🔽jātirūpassevādhivacanaṃ. Sampiṇḍitānaṃ hi catusamuṭṭhānikarūpānaṃ paṭhamuppatti upacayo
analyzed: an uppabandhana rasāḥ an upaccheda paccupaṭṭhānāḥ an uppabandhaka rūpa padaṭṭhānāḥ  jāti rūpassa iva adhivacanam sampiṇḍitānam hi catu samuṭṭhānika rūpānam paṭhama uppatti upacayaḥ
translated: its savour is non-interruption, its manifestation is non-disruption, and its proximate cause is the materiality that causes non-interruption. Both these terms,🔽“growth” and “continuity,” are terms for the first arising of the four-originated material instances in a mass. Growth is the first arising of the material instances in a mass.🔽

original: nāma, uparūparuppatti santati nāma. Teneva tāsaṃ padabhājanīye “yo rūpassa upacayo,🔽sā rūpassa santatī”ti vuttaṃ, ākāranānattato pana visuṃ uddiṭṭhā.
analyzed: nāma santati nāma tena iva tāsam pada bhājanīye yaḥ rūpassa upacayaḥ  sā rūpassa santati iti vuttam ākāra nānattato pana visum uddiṭṭhā
translated: Its characteristic is the non-continuity of material instances. Its function is to cause non-continuity. It is manifested as the cutting off of continuity. Its proximate cause is material instances that cause non-continuity. Both these terms, “continuity” and “discontinuity,” are terms for materiality. For the first arising of the four-originated material instances is called “continuity” and the subsequent arising of them is called “discontinuity.”🔽That is why in the Padabhājaniya it is said: “The growth of materiality is the continuity of materiality” . But they are separately listed because of the difference in their mode.

original: Rūpaparipākalakkhaṇā rūpassajaratā, upanayanarasā, sabhāvānapagamepi navabhāvāpagamapaccupaṭṭhānā🔽vīhipurāṇabhāvo viya, paripaccamānarūpapadaṭṭhānā. Khaṇe khaṇe bhijjamānāpi cesā
analyzed: rūpa paripāka lakkhaṇā upanayana rasā sabhāva anapagame pi nava bhāva apagama paccupaṭṭhānā  vīhi purāṇa bhāvaḥ viya paripaccamāna rūpa padaṭṭhānā khaṇe khaṇe bhijjamānā api ca isā
translated: Its characteristic is the maturing of materiality. Its function is to bring about the state of being old. It is manifested as the disappearance of the fresh state even when the individual essence remains.🔽Its proximate cause is materiality that is maturing. It is like the state of being old in a peacock. Although it breaks up every moment,

original: upādinnesu khaṇḍadantādito, anupādinnesu rukkhalatādīsu vaṇṇavikārādito ca antarantarā
analyzed: upādinnesu khaṇḍa danta āditaḥ an upādinnesu rukkha latā ādīsu vaṇṇa vikāra āditaḥ ca antar antarā
translated: it is nevertheless quite evident in what is clung to, such as teeth, etc., by the change in colour, etc., and in what is not clung to, such as trees, etc., by the change in colour, etc., and by the falling of leaves, etc.

original: ca suviññeyyavikārattā “pākaṭajarā, savīcijarā”ti ca vuccati, maṇikanakacandasūriyādīsu
analyzed: ca su viññeyya vikāra ttā pākaṭa jarā sa vīci jarā ati ca vuccati maṇi kanaka canda sūriya ādīsu
translated: That is why it is called “manifest aging” and “aging with pain.”

original: duviññeyyattā, nirantarattā ca “apākaṭajarā, avīcijarā”ti vuccati. Īdisesu hi kappavināsādikāle
analyzed: duviññeyya ttā nirantara ttā ca apākaṭa jarā avīcijarā ti vuccati īdisesu hi kappa vināsa ādi kāle
translated: and because it is cognizable by two kinds of knowledge and because it is uninterrupted, it is called “unapparent ageing” and “uninterrupted ageing” . For in such cases as the destruction of an aeon,

original: vikārato jarā paññāyeyya. Sabbadāpi pana apaññāyamānavikārattā arūpadhammesu jarā
analyzed: vikārataḥ jarā paññāyeyya sabbadā api pana a paññāyamāna vikāra ttā arūpa dhammesu jarā
translated: ageing would be evident as a change. But because it is not evident as a change at all times, ageing in immaterial states

original: paṭicchannajarā nāma. Na ca tattha vaṇṇavikārādayo jarā tesaṃ cakkhuviññeyyato. Na🔽hi jarā cakkhuviññeyyā, manoviññeyyā pana hoti. Yathā oghena paribhinnabhūmiādidassanena
analyzed: paṭicchanna jarā nāma na ca tattha vaṇṇa vikāra ādayaḥ jarā tesam cakkhu viññeyyataḥ na  hi jarā cakkhu viññeyyā manaḥ viññeyyā pana hoti yathā oghena paribhinna bhūmi ādi dassanena
translated: is called “concealed ageing.” And there is no change of colour, etc., in them, because they are cognizable by the eye,🔽for ageing is not cognizable by the eye, but it is cognizable by the mind. Just as a flood, though not seen when the ground, etc., is broken up by a current, is nevertheless quite evident when it is seen by the appearance of the ground, etc., being inundated,
