original: cittaṃ viya tividhā hontīti ayaṃ viseso, sesaṃ cittasamaṃ, idañca nippadesattikanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: cittam viya tividhāḥ honti iti ayam visesaḥ sesam citta samam idam ca nippadesa ttikan ti veditabbam
translated: So they are threefold like consciousness. This is the difference. The rest is the same as that for consciousness. And this should be understood as the triad of the unspecified kinds of consciousness.

original: Vipākattikaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: vipāka ttikam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on the resultant kinds of consciousness is concluded.

original: Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena taṇhādiṭṭhīhi upetena kammunā ādinnā phalabhāvena gahitāti upādinnā,🔽ārammaṇabhāvaṃ upagantvā upādānasambandhena upādānānaṃ hitāti upādāniyā, upādānassa
analyzed: ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena taṇhā diṭṭhīhi upetena kammunā ādinnā phala bhāvena gahitā ati upādinnā  ārammaṇa bhāvam upagantvā upādāna sambandhena upādānānam hitā ati upādāniyā upādānassa
translated: They are called clung-to because they are taken up by kamma accompanied by craving and view that has taken an object.🔽They are called states that are a condition for the kinds of clinging because they are favourable to the kinds of clinging by becoming objects of clinging.

original: ārammaṇapaccayabhūtānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Upādinnā ca te upādāniyā cāti upādinnupādāniyā,
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtānam etam adhivacanam upādinnā ca te upādāniyā ca ati upādinnupādāniyā

original: sāsavakammanibbattānaṃ rūpārūpadhammānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Iminā nayena sesapadadvayepi
analyzed: sa āsava kamma nibbattānam rūpa arūpa dhammānam etam adhivacanam iminā nayena sesa pada dvaye pi

original: paṭisedhasahito attho veditabbo.
analyzed: paṭisedha sahitaḥ atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance.

original: Tattha dvattiṃsa lokiyavipākacittāni, nava kammajakalāpā ca upādinnupādāniyā nāma.
analyzed: tattha dvattiṃsa lokiya vipāka cittāni nava kamma ja kalāpā ca upādinnupādāniyāḥ nāma

analyzed: avasesa lokiya cittāni ca iva akamma ja rūpa kalāpā ca anupādinnupādāniyāḥ nāma lokuttara citta nibbānāni
translated: Supramundane consciousness and Nibbāna are called

original: anupādinnaanupādāniyā nāma. Kiñcāpi khīṇāsavānaṃ upādānakkhandhā “amhākaṃ mātulatthero”tiādinā
analyzed: anupādinnaanupādāniyāḥ nāma kiñcā api khīṇa āsavānam upādāna kkhandhāḥ amhākam mātulatthera iti ādinā

analyzed: vadantānam paresam upādānassa ārammaṇa paccayāḥ honti magga phala nibbānāni pana divasam  viya makkhikāhi tejussadattāḥ upādānehi an upādinna an eva asaṃkiliṭṭha asaṃkilesikesu pi

original: eseva nayo. Cetasikesu pana kusalā anupādinnupādāniyā eva, karuṇāmuditā siyā upādinnupādāniyā,

translated: But among the mental factors, the profitable are only “with object and with clinging.” Compassion and gladness may be “with object and with clinging” or “with object and without clinging.”

original: siyā anupādinnupādāniyā viratiyo pana siyā anupādinnupādāniyā, siyā anupādinnaanupādāniyā,
analyzed: siyā anupādinnupādāniyā viratiyā pana siyā anupādinnupādāniyā siyā anupādinna anupādāniyā
translated: The abstinences may be “with object and without clinging” or “without object and without clinging.”

analyzed: nāma cetasikesu pana akusalā saṃkiliṭṭha saṃkilesikā ava karuṇā muditā a saṃkiliṭṭha a saṃkilesikā ava  sesa kusala abyākatā siyā saṃkiliṭṭha saṃkilesikā siyā asaṃkiliṭṭha saṃkilesikā siyā
translated: But among the fine-material ones, the unprofitable and the defiled-neutral are defiled-accompanied-by-defilement, and compassion and gladness are undefiled-unaccompanied-by-defilement.🔽The rest of the profitable and the indeterminate are of three kinds, that is to say, they are either defiled-accompanied-by-defilement or undefiled-unaccompanied-by-defilement or undefiled-accompanied-by-undefilement.

original: asaṃkiliṭṭhaasaṃkilesikāti tidhāpi honti, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Saṃkiliṭṭhasaṃkilesikattikaṃ.
analyzed: asaṃkiliṭṭha asaṃkilesikā ti tidhā api honti idam ca nippadesa ttikam saṃkiliṭṭha saṃkilesika ttikam
translated: This is the threefold division. The twofold division is that of defiled-accompanied-by-defilement and undefiled-unaccompanied-by-defilement.

original: Sampayogavasena vattamānena saha vitakkena savitakkā, tathā saha vicārena savicārā,
analyzed: sampayoga vasena vattamānena saha vitakkena sa vitakkā tathā saha vicārena sa vicārā
translated: They are accompanied by applied thought when they occur together with applied thought. So too, they are accompanied by sustained thought when they occur together with sustained thought.

original: savitakkā ca te savicārā cāti savitakkasavicārā. Ubhayarahitā avitakkaavicārā. Vitakkavicāresu🔽vicārova mattā pamāṇametesanti vicāramattā, vicārato uttariṃ vitakkena saddhiṃ sampayogaṃ
analyzed: sa vitakkā ca te sa vicārā ca ati sa vitakka sa vicārāḥ ubhaya rahitāḥ avitakka avicārāḥ vitakka vicāresu  vicāra uva mattā vicārataḥ uttarim vitakkena saddhim sampayogam
translated: They are accompanied by both applied and sustained thought when they are accompanied by both. They are without applied thought and sustained thought when they are without both applied thought and sustained thought.🔽In the case of applied thought and sustained thought,🔽the measure is just sustained thought. The meaning is that they do not occur together with applied thought in excess of sustained thought.

original: na gacchantīti attho. Avitakkā ca te vicāramattā cāti avitakkavicāramattā.
analyzed: na gacchanti iti attho a vitakkā ca te vicāra mattā ca ati a vitakka vicāra mattā
translated: They are without applied thought and have just sustained thought.

original: Tattha dvipañcaviññāṇavajjitakāmāvacaracittāni ceva ekādasa mahaggatalokuttarapaṭhamajjhānikacittāni
analyzed: tattha dvi pañca viññāṇa vajjita kāmāvacara cittāni ca iva ekādasa mahaggata lokuttara paṭhamajjhānika cittāni
translated: Herein, the kinds of consciousness of the sense sphere except for the two sets of five consciousnesses, and the eleven kinds of exalted consciousness and the supramundane of the first jhāna,

original: ca taṃsampayuttesu vitakkavicāre ṭhapetvā sesā ca savitakkasavicārā nāma. Tesu vitakko
analyzed: ca tad sampayuttesu vitakka vicāre ṭhapetvā sesā ca sa vitakka sa vicārā nāma tesu vitakko
translated: and the rest except for applied thought and sustained thought associated with them, are called with-applied-thought-and-sustained-thought. Herein, applied thought

original: ekādasa dutiyajjhānikamahaggatalokuttarāni ca taṃsampayuttesu vicāraṃ ṭhapetvā sesā🔽ca avitakkavicāramattā nāma. Dutiyajjhānikesu vicāro, sesā pañcacattālīsa mahaggatalokuttaracittāni,
analyzed: ekādasa dutiya jhānika mahaggata lokuttarāni ca tad sampayuttesu vicāram ṭhapetvā sesā  ca avitakka vicāra mattāḥ nāma dutiya jhānikesu vicāro mahaggata lokuttara cittāni
translated: is in the eleven kinds of consciousness of the second jhāna and the exalted and supramundane kinds, and the rest except for sustained thought associated with them,🔽and it is also in the forty-five kinds of consciousness called without-applied-thought-and-sustained-thought. Sustained thought is in the second-jhāna kinds. The rest,

original: dvipañcaviññāṇāni, taṃsampayuttā ca sabbañca rūpaṃ, nibbānañca avitakkaavicārā nāma.
analyzed: dvi pañca viññāṇāni tad sampayuttā ca sabbam ca rūpam nibbānam ca avitakka avicārāḥ nāma
translated: namely, the forty-five kinds of exalted and supramundane consciousness, the two sets of five consciousnesses, and all materiality and Nibbāna associated with them, are called without-applied-thought-and-sustained-thought.

original: Apica kusalacetasikā savitakkasavicārāva, vitakko avitakkavicāramattova, vicāro pana
analyzed: apica kusala cetasikā vitakkaḥ a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ uva vicāraḥ pana
translated: Moreover, the profitable consciousnesses are with-applied-thought-and-sustained-thought. Applied thought is without-applied-thought-and-with-sustained-thought. Sustained thought

original: dutiyajjhānikesu siyā avitakkaavicāro, savitakkacittesu siyā na vattabbo, avasesā
analyzed: dutiya jhānikesu siyā avitakka avicāro sa vitakka cittesu siyā na vattabbo avasesā
translated: is either without-applied-thought-and-without-sustained-thought in the second-jhāna kinds, or it is not to be spoken of as such in the kinds of consciousness with applied thought. The rest🔽are either with-applied-thought-and-without-sustained-thought or without-applied-thought-and-without-sustained-thought.

original: pana sabbe cetasikā dhammā tidhāpi honti. Imasmiṃ pana tike vitakkasahajāto vicārova
analyzed: pana sabbe cetasikāḥ dhammā tidhā api honti imasmim pana tike vitakka sahajātaḥ vicāraḥ uva
translated: But all mental states are of three kinds in all three instances. But in this triad applied thought is associated with the first jhāna, and sustained thought with the second.

original: na vattabbo. Vitakkattikaṃ.
analyzed: na vattabbaḥ vitakka ttikam
translated: But all mental states are of three kinds in all three instances. But in this triad, applied thought is not to be spoken of as associated with the kind of happiness called happiness of pleasure.🔽The triad is made up of the three terms beginning with “associated with happiness.”

original: Pītiyā saha ekuppādādibhāvaṃ gatāti pītisahagatā, pītisampayuttāti attho. Sesapadadvayepi🔽eseva nayo. Upekkhāti cettha adukkhamasukhā vedanā vuttā. Sā hi sukhadukkhākārappavattiṃ🔽upekkhati majjhattākārasaṇṭhitattā tenākārena pavattatīti upekkhā. Iti vedanāttikato
analyzed: pītiyā saha eka uppāda ādi bhāvam gatā ati pīti sahagatā pīti sampayuttā ati attho sesa pada dvaye pi  esa iva nayaḥ upekkhā ati ca ittha adukkham asukhā vedanā vuttā sā hi sukha dukkha ākāra ppavattim  upekkhati majjhattā ākāra saṇṭhita ttā tena ākārena pavattati iti upekkhā iti vedanā attikato
translated: “ Associated with happiness” : arisen together with happiness; the meaning is, associated with happiness. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other two terms.

original: padadvayameva gahetvā nippītikasukhassa sappītikasukhato visesadassanavasena ayaṃ tiko vutto.
analyzed: pada dvayam eva gahetvā nippītika sukhassa sa pītika sukhataḥ visesa dassana vasena ayam tikaḥ vutto
translated: “ Equanimity” : here, equanimity is the feeling that is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant . For that is called “equanimity” because it looks on , that is, occurs, in the mode of neutrality, since it occurs in a mode that is neutral between the pleasant and the unpleasant. Thus, taking the two terms beginning with “associated with equanimity” from the triad of feeling, this triad is stated in order to show the difference between the happiness of pleasure and the happiness of equanimity.

original: Tattha pīti pañcavidhā khuddikā khaṇikā okkantikā ubbegā pharaṇāti. Tattha khuddikā
analyzed: tattha pi iti pañcavidhā khuddikā khaṇikā okkantikā ubbegā pharaṇā ti tattha khuddikā
translated: Herein, happiness is of five kinds: tremulous, fleeting, thrilling, transporting, and uplifting .

original: pīti sarīre lomahaṃsanamattameva kātuṃ sakkoti. Khaṇikā pīti khaṇe khaṇe vijjuppādasadisā
analyzed: pi iti sarīre lomahaṃsana mattam eva kātum sakkoti khaṇikā pi iti khaṇe khaṇe vijjuppāda sadisā
translated: Herein, tremulous happiness is only able to make the hairs of the body bristle. Fleeting happiness is like the flash of lightning.

original: hoti. Okkantikā pīti samuddatīraṃ vīci viya kāyaṃ okkamitvā okkamitvā bhijjati. Ubbegā🔽pīti balavatī hoti kāyaṃ uddhaggaṃ katvā ākāse laṅghāpanappamāṇappattā. Pharaṇāya🔽pītiyā pana uppannāya sakalasarīraṃ dhamitvā pūritavatthi viya, mahatā udakoghena
analyzed: hoti okkantikā samudda tīram kāyam okkamitvā okkamitvā bhijjati ubbegā  pīti balavatī hoti kāyam uddhaggam katvā ākāse laṅghāpana pamāṇa ppattā pharaṇāya  pītiyā pana uppannāya sakala sarīram dhamitvā pūrita vatthi viya mahatā udaka oghena
translated: The impact rapture is like the waves on the seashore that break and subside as soon as they reach the shore. The uplifting rapture is strong. It is capable of lifting up the body and causing it to levitate. The diffusive rapture, when it arises, pervades the whole body and fills it, as if the whole body of skin were full of water balloons.

original: pakkhandapabbatakucchi viya ca anuparipphuṭaṃ hoti. Tattha pharaṇā rūpāvacaralokuttarāva, sesā kāmāvacarāva.
analyzed: pakkhanda pabbata kucchi viya ca anuparipphuṭam hoti tattha pharaṇā rūpāvacara lokuttarā ava sesā kāmāvacarā ava
translated: It is like the waves on the ocean shore that break and subside as soon as they reach the shore. Exuberant happiness is strong. It is capable of making the body rise up into the air by making the supernormal power of elevation its object. But when the happiness of uplifting occurs, the whole body is as if covered and filled with the current of happiness, like a sack full of beans. It is as if the inside of the body were being washed out with a flood of oil. Herein, the uplifting is found in the fine-material sphere and in the supramundane, while the rest are found in the sense sphere.

original: Sukhaṃ pana kāyikaṃ, cetasikañceti duvidhaṃ hoti. Satipi ca nesaṃ katthaci avippayoge🔽iṭṭhārammaṇapaṭilābhatuṭṭhi pīti, paṭiladdharasānubhavanaṃ sukhaṃ. Yattha pīti, tattha
analyzed: sukham pana kāyikam cetasikam ca iti duvidham hoti sati pi ca na īsam katthaci a vippayoge  iṭṭha ārammaṇa paṭilābha tuṭṭhi pīti paṭiladdha rasa anubhavanam sukham yattha pīti tattha
translated: Happiness is twofold, namely, bodily and mental. And although it is not dissociated from either of these,

original: sukhaṃ. Yattha sukhaṃ, tattha na niyamato pīti. Saṅkhārakkhandhasaṅgahitā pīti, vedanākkhandhasaṅgahitaṃ
analyzed: sukham yattha sukham tattha na niyamataḥ pi iti saṅkhāra kkhandha saṅgahitā pi iti vedanā kkhandha saṅgahitam
translated: happiness is satisfaction due to obtaining a desirable object, while happiness is the experiencing of that which has been obtained. Where there is happiness there is bodily pleasure. Where there is bodily pleasure there is not necessarily happiness. Happiness is included in the formations aggregate. Pleasure is included in the

original: sukhaṃ. Kantārakhinnassa vanantodakadassanasavanesu viya pīti, vanacchāyāpavesanaudakaparibhogesu
analyzed: sukham kantāra khinnassa vananta udaka dassana savanesu viya pīti vana chāyā apavesana odaka paribhogesu
translated: and the happiness is like the entering of the shade of the forest and the using of the water.

original: viya sukhaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ samaye pākaṭabhāvato cetaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: viya sukham tasmin tasmin samaye pākaṭa bhāvato ca itam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: But it should be understood that this is said according to the prominence of each in the several cases.

original: Tattha sukhasahagatā, upekkhāsahagatā ca vedanāttike vuttāva, sukhasahagataṃ pana
analyzed: tattha sukha sahagatā upekkhā sahagatā ca vedanā attike vuttā ava sukha sahagatam pana
translated: Herein, the feeling that is associated with happiness and that which is associated with equanimity are dealt with in the Three Kinds of Feeling. But the bodily- pleasure that is associated with happiness

original: kāyaviññāṇaṃ, mahaggatalokuttaracatutthajjhānikacitte ca vajjetvā sesā pītisahagatā
analyzed: kāya viññāṇam mahaggata lokuttara catuttha jjhānika citte ca vajjetvā sesā pīti sahagatā
translated: and the consciousnesses of the four immaterial states and of the fourth jhāna in the supramundane planes are called “accompanied by rapture.”

original: nāma, tattha pīti na pītisahagatā, sukhasahagatāva hoti, sukhaṃ pana pītisahagataṃ🔽nāma siyā na pītisukhasahagatā. Imasmiṃ tike dve domanassasahagatacittuppādā, dukkhasahagataṃ
analyzed: nāma tattha pīti na pīti sahagatā sukha sahagatā ava hoti sukham pana pīti sahagatam  nāma siyā na pīti sukha sahagatāḥ imasmin tike dve domanassa sahagata cittuppādāḥ dukkha sahagatam
translated: Herein, the rapture is not accompanied by rapture, being accompanied by happiness only. But the happiness is called “accompanied by rapture”🔽and it may be accompanied by rapture and happiness. In this triad the two types of consciousness accompanied by grief and the bodily pain, matter, and Nibbāna are not to be admitted.

original: kāyaviññāṇaṃ, rūpaṃ, nibbānañca navattabbā. Cetasikesu pana pīti sukhasahagatāva,
analyzed: kāya viññāṇam rūpam nibbānam ca na vattabbā cetasikesu pana pīti sukha sahagatā ava
translated: But among the mental states the rapture is accompanied by happiness only,

original: vicikicchā upekkhāsahagatāva, lobhadiṭṭhimānā, pañcavīsati kusalābyākatā ca tidhāpi
analyzed: vicikicchā upekkhā sahagatā ava lobha diṭṭhi mānā pañcavīsati kusala abyākatā ca tidhā api
translated: and the doubt is accompanied by equanimity only, while greed, false view, and conceit, and the twenty-five profitable and indeterminate types are of all three kinds.

original: honti, cetasikasukhaṃ siyā pītisahagataṃ, paṭhamadutiyatatiyajjhānikesu catutthajjhānikesu
analyzed: honti cetasika sukham siyā pīti sahagatam paṭhama dutiya tatiya jhānikesu catuttha jhānikesu
translated: and mental pleasure may be accompanied by happiness. In the first, second and third jhānas it is in the fourth jhāna it is indeterminate.

original: siyā navattabbaṃ, kāyikaṃ pana sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ sabbā ca upekkhā doso issā
analyzed: siyā na vattabbam kāyikam pana sukham dukkham domanassam sabbā ca upekkhā dosaḥ issā
translated: But bodily pleasure and pain, grief, and all equanimity, hate, envy,

original: macchariyaṃ kukkuccañca navattabbāva, sesā sattarasa dhammā siyā tidhāpi honti navattabbāpi.
analyzed: macchariyam kukkuccam ca sesā sattarasa dhammā siyā tidhā api honti navattabbā api
translated: avarice, and worry are only indeterminate. The remaining seventeen states may be of three kinds or indeterminate.

original: Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Pītittikaṃ.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva pītittikam
translated: The rest is easy to understand.

original: Dassanenāti sotāpattimaggena. So hi paṭhamaṃ nibbānadassanato “dassana”nti vutto.
analyzed: dassanena āti sotāpatti maggena so hi paṭhamam nibbāna dassanataḥ dassananti vutto
translated: By seeing: by the path of stream-entry. For that is called “seeing” because it is the first seeing of Nibbāna.

original: Gotrabhu pana kiñcāpi paṭhamataraṃ passati, yathā pana rañño santikaṃ kenacideva🔽karaṇīyena āgato puriso dūratova rathikāya carantaṃ hatthikkhandhagataṃ rājānaṃ disvāpi
analyzed: gotrabhu pana kiñcā api paṭhamataram passati yathā pana rañño santikam kenacid eva  karaṇīyena āgataḥ purisaḥ dūratas va rathikāya carantam hatthi kkhandha gatam rājānam disvā api
translated: But although the state of change-of-lineage sees first, nevertheless, just as when a man has gone into the king’s presence on some business

original: “diṭṭho te rājā”ti puṭṭho disvāpi kātabbakiccassa akatattā “na passāmī”ti vadati,
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ te rājā ati puṭṭhaḥ disvā api kātabba kiccassa a kata ttā na passāmi iti vadati
translated: and another asks, “Have you seen the king?,” he replies, “I have not seen him,” because he has not done what has to be done, though he has seen the king,

original: evameva nibbānaṃ disvā kattabbassa kilesappahānassa abhāvā “dassana”nti na vuccati.
analyzed: evam eva nibbānam disvā kattabbassa kilesa ppahānassa abhāvā dassananti na vuccati
translated: Likewise, Nibbāna is not called “seen” because there is no defilement to be abandoned by seeing it.

original: Taṃ hi ñāṇaṃ maggassa āvajjanaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati. Bhāvanāyāti sesamaggattayena. Sesamaggattayaṃ
analyzed: tat hi ñāṇam maggassa āvajjana ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati bhāvanāya ati sesa magga ttayena sesa magga ttayam
translated: For that knowledge stands in the place of adverting to the path. By development: by the three supramundane paths.

original: hi paṭhamamaggena diṭṭhasmiṃyeva dhamme bhāvanāvasena uppajjati, adiṭṭhapubbaṃ kañci
analyzed: hi paṭhama maggena diṭṭhasmin yeva dhamme bhāvanā vasena uppajjati adiṭṭha pubbam kañci
translated: For the third path arises by development in the same way as the first path in the case of one who has seen only the first two paths,

original: na passati, tasmā “bhāvanā”ti vuccati. Tatiyapadaṃ ubhayapaṭikkhepavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na passati tasmā bhāvanā iti vuccati tatiya padam ubhaya paṭikkhepa vasena vuttam
translated: but it does not see anything not seen before. That is why it is called “development.” The third phrase is stated to deny both.

original: Tattha cattāro diṭṭhigatasampayuttacittuppādā, vicikicchāsahagato cāti pañca dassanena🔽pahātabbāva, uddhaccasahagato bhāvanāya eva pahātabbo, avasesā cha akusalacittuppādā
analyzed: tattha cattāro diṭṭhigata sampayutta cittuppādāḥ vicikicchā sahagataḥ ca ati pañca dassanena  uddhacca sahagataḥ bhāvanāya eva pahātabbaḥ avasesā cha akusala cittuppādā
translated: Herein, five kinds of consciousness associated with the four kinds of views and with uncertainty are to be abandoned by seeing;🔽that associated with agitation is to be abandoned by development only;

original: apāyahetubhāvena pavattito, appavattito ca siyā dassanenapahātabbā, siyā bhāvanāyapahātabbā,
analyzed: apāya hetu bhāvena pavattitaḥ appavattitaḥ ca siyā dassanena apahātabbā siyā bhāvanāya apahātabbā
translated: the remaining six kinds of unprofitable consciousness are to be abandoned by seeing or by development according to whether they occur or not as causes for the unhappy destiny.

original: akusalavajjitā pana sabbe cittuppādā, rūpaṃ, nibbānañca nevadassanenanabhāvanāyapahātabbā.
analyzed: akusala vajjitāḥ pana sabbe cittuppādāḥ rūpam nibbānam ca
translated: But all kinds of consciousness except the unprofitable ones, and also materiality and Nibbāna, are not to be abandoned by either seeing or development.

original: Cetasikesu pana diṭṭhi vicikicchā issā macchariyaṃ kukkuccaṃ dassanenapahātabbāva,
analyzed: cetasikesu pana diṭṭhi vicikicchā issā macchariyam kukkuccam
translated: But as regards the unprofitable, wrong view, doubt, avarice, concealment, deceit, hypocrisy, and obstinacy are to be abandoned by seeing only.

original: sesā akusalā siyā dassanenapahātabbā, siyā bhāvanāyapahātabbāti tijātikā terasavidhā
analyzed: sesā akusalā siyā dassanena apahātabbā siyā bhāvanāya apahātabbā ati ti jātikā terasavidhā
translated: The rest are either to be abandoned by seeing or by development.🔽So they are of three kinds and thirteen in number.

original: honti, vuttāvasesā nevadassanenanabhāvanāyapahātabbāva. Yaṃ pana “sotāpattimaggañāṇena🔽abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa nirodhena satta bhave ṭhapetvā anamatagge saṃsāre ye uppajjeyyuṃ
analyzed: honti vutta avasesāḥ yam pana sotāpatti magga ñāṇena  abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇassa nirodhena satta bhave ṭhapetvā anamatagge saṃsāre ye uppajjeyyuṃ
translated: The rest, which have already been mentioned, are not to be abandoned by either seeing or development.

original: nāmañca rūpañca, etthete nirujjhantī”tiādinā nayena kusalābyākatānampi pahānaṃ anuññātaṃ,🔽taṃ tesaṃ maggānaṃ abhāvitattā ye uppajjeyyuṃ, te upanissayapaccayānaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: nāman ca rūpam ca ettha ite nirujjhanti iti ādinā nayena kusala abyākatānam pi pahānam anuññātam  tam tesam maggānam abhāvita ttā ye uppajjeyyum te upanissaya paccayānam kilesānam
translated: But although the abandoning of profitable and indeterminate states is allowed in the way beginning, “With the cessation of resultant consciousness due to the path of stream-entry, seven kinds of becoming cease, and the name-and-form in the beginningless round of rebirths that might arise ceases” ,🔽it is said with reference to the following roundabout that “those that might arise are abandoned because the defilements that are their support condition are abandoned since those paths have not been developed” .

original: pahīnattā pahīnāti imaṃ pariyāyaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Dassanenapahātabbattikaṃ.🔽Dassanena pahātabbo hetu etesanti dassanenapahātabbahetukā. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pahīna ttā pahīnā ti imam pariyāyam sandhāya vuttam idam ca nippadesa ttikam dassanena pahātabba ttikam 🔽dassanena pahātabbaḥ hetu etesanti dassanena pahātabba hetukā dutiya pade pi esā iva nayo
translated: And this is a roundabout way of stating the matter.

original: Tatiyapade pana nevadassanenanabhāvanāyapahātabbo hetu etesanti evamatthaṃ aggahetvā
analyzed: tatiya pade pana hetu etesan ti evam attham aggahetvā
translated: But in the third case, without taking the meaning in the way beginning “because they have a cause that is not to be abandoned by seeing and by development,”

original: nevadassanenanabhāvanāya pahātabbo hetu etesaṃ atthīti evamattho gahetabbo. Itarathā
analyzed: na iva dassanena na bhāvanāya pahātabbaḥ hetu etesam atthi iti evam atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ itarathā
translated: the meaning should be taken as follows: “They have a cause that is not to be abandoned by seeing and by development.” For otherwise🔽there would be no inclusion of those without root-cause. For they have no

original: hi ahetukānaṃ aggahaṇaṃ bhaveyya. Hetu eva hi tesaṃ natthi, yo dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbo
analyzed: hi ahetukānam aggahaṇam bhaveyya hetu eva hi tesam na atthi yaḥ dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbaḥ
translated: cause that might be abandoned by seeing or by development.

original: siyā. Sahetukesupi hetuvajjānaṃ pahānaṃ āpajjati, na hetūnaṃ. Hetuyeva hi etesaṃ
analyzed: siyā sa hetukesu pi hetu vajjānam pahānam āpajjati na hetūnam hetuyā iva hi etesam
translated: And in the case of those with root-cause, it is the root-cause itself that is

original: nevadassanenanabhāvanāyapahātabboti vutto, na te dhammā. Ubhayampi cetaṃ anadhippetaṃ,
analyzed: vutto na te dhammāḥ ubhayam pi ca itam anadhippetam
translated: said to be “not to be abandoned by seeing and by development,” not the states themselves. And both these meanings are unintended here.

original: tasmā vuttanayena attho gahetabbo. Ito paraṃ sabbo vinicchayo anantarattikasadisova.🔽Kevalaṃ cetasikesu vicikicchuddhaccasampayutto moho dassanabhāvanāhi pahātabbahetukesu
analyzed: tasmā vutta nayena atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ itas param sabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ anantara ttika sadisaḥ uva  kevalam cetasikesu vicikicchu ddhacca sampayuttaḥ mohaḥ dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabba hetukesu
translated: So the meaning should be taken in the way stated. The rest of the exposition is the same as that of the third jhāna in the fourth chapter.🔽In the case of the immaterial states, delusion associated with doubt and

original: na pavisati sahajātassa aññassa hetuno abhāvā, nevadassanenanabhāvanāyapahātabbahetukesu
analyzed: na pavisati sahajātassa aññassa hetuno abhāvā
translated: stiffness is not included among those with a cause to be abandoned by seeing and by development because there is no other cause of it that is conascent with it. It is included among those with a cause not to be abandoned by seeing or by development.

original: pana pavisati. Lobhadosamūlacittesu pana hetūsu moho lobhena ceva dosena ca sahetuko,🔽lobhadosā ca mohenevāti ime pahātabbahetukapade paviṭṭhāti ayaṃ viseso, sesaṃ tādisamevāti.
analyzed: pana pavisati lobha dosa mūla cittesu pana hetūsu mohaḥ lobhena ca iva dosena ca sa hetukaḥ  lobha dosā ca mohena iva ati ime pahātabba hetuka pade paviṭṭhā ati ayam viseso sesam tādisam eva ati
translated: But in the case of the causes that are rooted in greed and hate, delusion is accompanied by greed and by hate,🔽and greed and hate are accompanied by delusion. So there is this difference here. The rest is the same.

original: Dassanenapahātabbahetukattikaṃ.
analyzed: dassanena apahātabba hetuka ttikam
translated: This is the section of the exposition dealing with the states that are to be abandoned by seeing and that have a cause.

original: Kammakilesehi ācīyatīti ācayo, paṭisandhicutigatipavattisaṅkhātānaṃ upādinnakkhandhānametaṃ
analyzed: kamma kilesehi ācīyati iti ācayaḥ paṭisandhi cuti gati pavatti saṅkhātānam upādinna kkhandhānam etam
translated: “It is accumulated by defilements of action”: “accumulation” is a term for the aggregates that are clung to, which are included in rebirth-linking and death.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Tassa kāraṇaṃ hutvā nipphādanabhāvena taṃ ācayaṃ gacchanti, yassa vā
analyzed: adhivacanam tassa kāraṇam hutvā nipphādana bhāvena tam ācayam gacchanti yassa vā
translated: They go to that accumulation as its cause by generating it, or🔽they go to the person in whom they occur as the accumulation in the way already stated.

original: pavattanti, taṃ puggalaṃ yathāvuttameva ācayaṃ gamentīti ācayagāmino. Tato eva ācayasaṅkhātā
analyzed: pavattanti tam puggalam yathā vuttam eva ācayam gamenti iti ācaya gāminaḥ tatas eva ācaya saṅkhātā
translated: That is why they are called “going to an accumulation.”🔽Nibbāna is called “accumulation” because it is the opposite of accumulation,

original: cayā apetattā nibbānaṃ apetaṃ cayāti apacayo, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattanato apacayaṃ
analyzed: cayāḥ apeta ttā nibbānam apetam cayā ti apacayaḥ tam ārammaṇam katvā pavattanataḥ apacayam
translated: since it is the opposite of the accumulation of aggregates. They go to that nibbāna as their object,🔽thus they are called “going to the opposite of accumulation.”

original: gacchantīti apacayagāmino. Apica pākāraṃ iṭṭhakavaḍḍhakī viya pavattaṃ ācinantā gacchantīti
analyzed: gacchanti iti apacaya gāminaḥ api ca pākāram iṭṭhaka vaḍḍhakī viya pavattam ācinantāḥ gacchanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, they go accumulating, as it were, by building up, like a wall of bricks,

original: ācayagāmino. Teneva vaḍḍhakinā citaṃ citaṃ viddhaṃsayamāno puriso viya tadeva pavattaṃ
analyzed: ācaya gāminaḥ tena iva vaḍḍhakinā citam citam viddhaṃsayamānaḥ purisaḥ viya tat eva pavattam
translated: They are called “conducive to taking on” .🔽Just as a man who is burning a heap of grass and sticks goes on adding to it whatever dry grass and sticks he can get hold of, so too, these states go on “taking on” by adding to themselves whatever profitable kamma, unprofitable kamma, or functional kamma there may be in the three planes.🔽They are called “conducive to diminution” .🔽Just as a man who is burning a heap of grass and sticks goes on burning it by adding to it whatever dry grass and sticks he can get hold of, so too, these states go on “diminishing” by adding to themselves whatever profitable kamma, unprofitable kamma, or functional kamma there may be in the three planes.

original: apacinantā gacchantīti apacayagāmino. Tatiyapadaṃ ubhayapaṭikkhepena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apacinantā gacchanti iti apacaya gāminaḥ tatiya padam ubhaya paṭikkhepena vuttam
translated: The third kind is stated by the exclusion of both the other kinds.

original: Tattha lokiyakusalākusalāni ācayagāmino nāma, cattāri maggāni apacayagāmino nāma,
analyzed: tattha lokiya kusala akusalāni ācaya gāminaḥ nāma cattāri maggāni apacaya gāminaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the profitable and unprofitable in the worlds are called “conducive to taking on,” the four paths are called “conducive to diminution,”

original: sabbāni vipākaphalakiriyāni, rūpaṃ, nibbānañca nevaācayagāmino na apacayagāmino nāma.
analyzed: sabbāni vipāka phala kiriyāni rūpam nibbānam ca na iva ācaya gāminaḥ na apacaya gāminaḥ nāma
translated: all the resultants and inoperatives, materiality, and Nibbāna are called “neither conducive to taking on nor to diminution.”

original: Cetasikesu pana akusalā ācayagāmino eva, karuṇā muditā siyā ācayagāmino, siyā nevācayagāmino
analyzed: cetasikesu pana akusalāḥ ācaya gāminaḥ eva karuṇā muditā siyā ācaya gāminaḥ siyā na iva ācaya gāminaḥ
translated: But as regards the mental factors, the unprofitable ones are only “conducive to taking on,” compassion and gladness may be “conducive to taking on” or “neither conducive to taking on nor to diminution,”

original: na apacayagāmino nāma, sesā tidhāpi honti, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Ācayagāmittikaṃ.
analyzed: na apacaya gāminaḥ nāma sesā tidhā api honti idam ca nippadesa ttikam ācaya gāmi ttikam
translated: the rest are of three kinds. This is the exposition “Conducive to taking on” is without specification.

original: Tīsu sikkhāsu jātā, sattannaṃ vā sekhānaṃ etetipi sekhā, apariyositasikkhattā sayameva
analyzed: tīsu sikkhāsu jātā sattannam vā sekhānam sekhāḥ a pariyosita sikkhattā sayam eva
translated: They are “learners” because they have arisen in the three trainings, or because they are still training themselves since their training is not yet finished.

original: sikkhantītipi sekhā. Upari sikkhitabbābhāvato na sekhāti asekhā, vuddhippattā vā
analyzed: sikkhanti iti pi sekhā upari sikkhitabba abhāvataḥ na sekhā ati asekhā vuddhi pattā vā
translated: They are “non-learners” because there is nothing more for them to learn since there is no higher training.

original: sekhātipi asekhā. Tatiyapadaṃ ubhayapaṭikkhepena vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha cattāri lokuttarakusalāni, heṭṭhimāni ca tīṇi sāmaññaphalānīti satta sekhā
analyzed: sekhā atipi asekhā tatiya padam ubhaya paṭikkhepena vuttam  tattha cattāri lokuttara kusalāni heṭṭhimāni ca tīṇi sāmañña phalāni iti satta sekhā
translated: and neither-trainer-nor-non-trainer. The third term is stated by way of a denial of both.

original: nāma, arahattaphalaṃ asekhā nāma, lokiyacittāni, rūpaṃ, nibbānañca nevasekhā nāsekhā
analyzed: nāma arahatta phalam asekhā nāma lokiya cittāni rūpam nibbānam ca na iva sekhā na asekhā
translated: Herein, the four kinds of noble-idea-accompanied profitable cognizance and the three lower kinds of fruition are called “trainers” . The fruition of Arahantship is called “non-trainer” . The mundane kinds of consciousness, and materiality, and extinction, are called “neither-trainer-nor-non-trainer” .

original: nāma. Cetasikesu pana akusalā ca appamaññā ca nevasekhā nāsekhā eva, sesā tidhāpi
analyzed: nāma cetasikesu pana akusalā ca appamaññā ca na ivasekhā na asekhā eva sesā tidhā api
translated: But as regards the miscellaneous kinds, the unprofitable and the measureless are only “neither-trainer-nor-non-trainer” ; the rest are of all three kinds.

original: honti, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Sekhattikaṃ.
analyzed: honti idam ca nippadesattikam sekhattikam
translated: This is the exposition of “trainer” and so on.

original: Samantato khaṇḍitattā appamattakaṃ parittanti vuccati “parittaṃ gomayapiṇḍa”nti ādīsu🔽viya. Kāmāvacaradhammā hi appānubhāvatāya parittā viyāti parittā. Kilesavikkhambhanasamatthatāya,
analyzed: samantataḥ khaṇḍita ttā appamattakam parittanti vuccati parittam gomaya piṇḍam ti ādīsu  viya kāmāvacara dhammā hi appa anubhāva tāya parittā viyāti parittā kilesa vikkhambhana samattha tāya
translated: “Small” is said because it is broken all round. It is called “small” because it is of little power, as in such passages as “a small lump of cow-dung” .

original: mahantavipulaphalatāya, dīghasantānatāya ca mahantabhāvaṃ gatā, mahantehi vā uḷāracchandavīriyacittapaññehi
analyzed: mahanta vipula phala tāya dīgha santāna tāya ca mahanta bhāvam gatāḥ mahantehi vā uḷāra chanda vīriya citta paññehi
translated: For mundane ideas are “small” because they are of little power. They are “great” because they have reached the state of greatness by being able to suppress defilements, by having a great and wide fruit, and by having a long continuity. Or alternatively, they are “great” because they are undertaken by great, lofty, superior zeal, energy, cognizance, and understanding.

original: gatā paṭipannātipi mahaggatā. Pamāṇakarā dhammā rāgādayo pamāṇaṃ nāma, ārammaṇato
analyzed: mahaggatā pamāṇa karāḥ dhammāḥ rāga ādayaḥ pamāṇam nāma ārammaṇato
translated: and the path and the fruition of the path that have gone to and entered upon that are called exalted.

original: vā sampayogato vā natthi etesaṃ pamāṇaṃ, pamāṇassa ca paṭipakkhāti appamāṇā.
analyzed: vā sampayogataḥ vā na atthi etesam pamāṇam pamāṇassa ca paṭipakkhā ati appamāṇā
translated: The states of greed, etc., are called “limited” because they have a limited object or because there is no limit to them in the way of proliferation.🔽The supramundane states and Nibbāna are called “unlimited.”

original: Tattha catupaññāsa kāmāvacaracittāni, rūpañca parittā nāma, sattavīsati rūpārūpāvacaracittāni
analyzed: tattha catupaññāsa kāmāvacara cittāni rūpañca parittā nāma sattavīsati rūpa arūpāvacara cittāni
translated: Herein, the fifty-four kinds of mundane consciousness belonging to the sense sphere and material form are called “limited.”

original: mahaggatā nāma, lokuttaracittāni, nibbānañca appamāṇā nāma. Cetasikesu pana akusalā
analyzed: mahaggatāḥ nāma lokuttara cittāni nibbānam ca appamāṇāḥ nāma cetasikesu pana akusalāḥ
translated: The twenty-seven kinds of mundane consciousness belonging to the fine-material sphere and immaterial sphere are called “exalted.”

original: parittā eva, appamaññā parittamahaggatā eva, viratiyo parittaappamāṇā eva, sesā tidhāpi
analyzed: parittā eva appamaññā paritta mahaggatāḥ eva viratiyaḥ paritta appamāṇā eva sesā tidhā api
translated: The unprofitable consciousnesses are limited only. The equalities are limited and exalted only. The abstinences are limited and unlimited only. The rest are of all three kinds.

original: honti, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Parittattikaṃ.
analyzed: honti idam ca nippadesa ttikam paritta ttikam
translated: This is the section of the text without commentary.

original: Parittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ etesanti parittārammaṇā. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Sayaṃ parittā vā hontu mahaggatā vā, parittādidhamme ārabbha pavattā tadārammaṇāti vuccanti.
analyzed: parittam ārammaṇam etesanti paritta ārammaṇā sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayaḥ sayam parittāḥ vā hontu mahaggatāḥ vā paritta ādi dhamme ārabbha pavattā tad ārammaṇā ti vuccanti
translated: They have a limited object, thus they are “having a limited object.” The same method applies in the other two cases. Whether they are themselves limited or exalted, they occur in dependence on limited, etc., states, and so they are called “having that as object.”

original: Tattha tevīsati kāmāvacaravipākā, kiriyāmanodhātuahetukajavanañca parittārammaṇāva,🔽viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanakusalavipākakiriyāni mahaggatārammaṇāva, aṭṭha
analyzed: tattha tevīsati kāmāvacara vipākā kiriyā manaḥ dhātu ahetuka javanam ca paritta ārammaṇā va  viññāṇañcāyatana nevasaññā na asaññāyatana kusala vipāka kiriyāni mahaggata ārammaṇā ca aṭṭha
translated: Herein, twenty-three kinds of sense-sphere resultant and the functional mind-element and mind-consciousness-element with root-cause have only limited objects.🔽The profitable, resultant, and functional consciousnesses of the base consisting of boundless space and of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception have only exalted objects.

original: lokuttaracittāni appamāṇārammaṇāva, akusalacittāni ca aṭṭha ñāṇavippayuttajavanāni🔽ca siyā parittārammaṇā, siyā mahaggatārammaṇā, siyā navattabbārammaṇatāya na vattabbā,
analyzed: lokuttara cittāni appamāṇa ārammaṇā na akusala cittāni ca aṭṭha ñāṇa vippayutta javanāni  ca siyā paritta ārammaṇā siyā mahaggata ārammaṇā siyā navattabba ārammaṇa tāya na vattabbā
translated: The eight unprofitable consciousnesses and the eight functional consciousnesses without knowledge have either limited or exalted objects, but they are not classifiable as having immeasurable objects.🔽The eleven kinds of sense-sphere functional consciousnesses with knowledge, the kinds of direct-knowledge consciousness, and the adverting at the mind door have all three kinds of objects.

original: na kadāci appamāṇārammaṇā, aṭṭha ñāṇasampayuttakāmāvacarajavanāni, abhiññā, manodvārāvajjanañcāti🔽ekādasa tidhāpi honti navattabbāpi. Tesu ca kusalāni pañca arahattamaggaphalavajjitasabbārammaṇāni.
analyzed: na kadāci appamāṇa ārammaṇāḥ aṭṭha ñāṇa sampayutta kāmāvacara javanāni abhiññā manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam ca ati  ekādasa tidhā api honti tesu ca kusalāni pañca arahatta magga phala vajjita sabba ārammaṇāni
translated: They are also not classifiable as having immeasurable objects.🔽Herein, the five kinds of profitable consciousness have all objects except for the path and fruition of Arahantship.

original: Tatthāpi taṃtaṃsekhānameva yathāsakaṃ maggaphalāni ārammaṇāni honti, kiriyāni cha
analyzed: tattha api yathāsakam magga phalāni ārammaṇāni honti kiriyāni cha
translated: Herein, too, the path and fruition of the respective Initiate are the objects of the respective kinds of profitable consciousness. The six kinds of functional consciousness have all objects except for the supramundane states.

original: sabbathāpi sabbārammaṇāni, abhiññāvajjitarūpāvacarāni ceva cha ākāsānañcāyatanaākiñcaññāyatanacittāni
analyzed: sabbathā api sabba ārammaṇāni abhiññā vajjita rūpāvacarāni ca iva cha ākāsa anañcāyatana ākiñcaññāyatana cittāni
translated: All objects of the remaining kinds of knowledge are of all kinds, namely, the visible-data base, the fine-material-world element, and the four immaterial bases, and also the four kinds of formless-world consciousness that are to be directly known by the kinds of direct-knowledge, namely, the four consciousnesses belonging to the base consisting of boundless space, the base consisting of boundless consciousness, the base consisting of nothingness, and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: ca niyamena paññattārammaṇatāya, rūpanibbānānañca anārammaṇatāya sabbathā navattabbāti.
analyzed: ca niyamena paññatta ārammaṇa tāya rūpa nibbānānam ca anārammaṇa tāya sabbathā na vattabbā ti
translated: And also the visible-data base and the Nibbāna element are not to be taken as objects in any way.

original: Cetasikesu pana akusalā akusalacittasadisāva, viratiyo siyā parittārammaṇā, siyā
analyzed: cetasikesu pana akusalāḥ akusala citta sadisāḥ va viratiyaḥ siyā paritta ārammaṇā siyā
translated: As regards the associated states, the unprofitable ones are like the unprofitable consciousness. The abstinences may have limited or

original: appamāṇārammaṇā, karuṇāmuditā navattabbāva, sesā tidhāpi honti siyā navattabbāti.
analyzed: appamāṇa ārammaṇā karuṇā muditā sesā tidhā api honti siyā navattabbā ati
translated: immeasurable objects. Compassion and gladness are not to be taken as objects. The remaining ones are of all three kinds, that is to say, they may be not to be taken as objects.

original: Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Parittārammaṇattikaṃ.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva paritta ārammaṇa ttikam
translated: The rest is easily understood. The limited-object triad is finished.

original: Hīnāti lāmakā, akusalā dhammā. Hīnapaṇītānaṃ majjhe bhavāti majjhimā, avasesā tebhūmakā
analyzed: hīnā ati lāmakā akusalā dhammā hīna paṇītānam majjhe majjhimā avasesā tebhūmakā
translated: Inferior: inferior states are unprofitable. Medium: states that are neither inferior nor superior are medium. The remaining states belonging to the three planes

original: rūpārūpadhammāva. Uttamaṭṭhena, atappakaṭṭhena ca paṇītā, lokuttaracittanibbānāni.
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhammau uttama ṭṭhena atappaka ṭṭhena ca paṇītā lokuttara citta nibbānāni
translated: are superior. The states of the supramundane consciousness and Nibbāna are excellent.

original: Cetasikesu pana akusalā hīnāva, karuṇāmuditā majjhimāva, sesakusalābyākatā majjhimapaṇītāva,
analyzed: cetasikesu pana akusalāḥ karuṇā muditāḥ majjhimāḥ ava sesa kusalāḥ abyākatāḥ majjhima paṇītāḥ ava
translated: As regards the associated states, the unprofitable ones are inferior. Compassion and gladness are medium. The remaining profitable and indeterminate states are medium and excellent.

original: sesā tidhāpi honti, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Hīnattikaṃ.
analyzed: tidhā api honti idam ca nippadesa ttikam sesam su viññeyyam eva hīna ttikam
translated: The rest are threefold, and this is the section on the indeterminate. The rest is easy to understand.

original: “Hitasukhāvahā me bhavissantī”ti evaṃ āsīsitāpi tathā abhāvato, asubhādīsuyeva subhantiādiviparītappavattito
analyzed: hita sukha āvahāḥ me bhavissanti iti evam tathā abhāvataḥ subha nti ādi viparīta ppavattito
translated: The indeterminate is so called because it is not stated in the way beginning, “May they be happy and secure” , and because it occurs in the opposite way to the way stated in the case of the foul, etc.,

original: ca micchā sabhāvāti micchattā, vipākadāne sati khandhabhedānantarameva vipākadānato
analyzed: ca micchā micchat tā vipāka dāne sati khandha bheda anantaram eva vipāka dānataḥ
translated: which is why it is called “wrong” . It is “fixed” because it gives its fruit in the next becoming immediately next to the kamma that produces its fruit,

original: niyatā, micchattā ca te niyatā cāti micchattaniyatā. Vuttaviparītena atthena sammā🔽sabhāvāti sammattā, sammattā ca te niyatā cāti sammattaniyatā. Ubhayathāpi na niyatāti aniyatā.
analyzed: niyatā micchattā ca te niyatā ca ati micchatta niyatā vutta viparītena atthena sammā  sabhāvā ati sammattā sammattā ca te niyatā ca ati sammatta niyatā ubhayathā api na niyatā ati aniyatā
translated: and because it is wrong and fixed, it is called “wrong and fixed.” The opposite in meaning to that is “right and fixed.” It is “indeterminate” because it is not fixed in either way.

original: Ānantarikabhāvena pavattiyaṃ siyā micchattaniyatā, aññathā pavattiyaṃ siyā aniyatā.
analyzed: ānantarika bhāvena pavattiyam siyā micchatta niyatā aññathā pavattiyam siyā aniyatā
translated: It may be “wrong and fixed” in occurrence by way of the immediate continuity, and it may be “indeterminate” in occurrence by way of other than the immediate continuity.

original: Ahetukaakiriyanatthikadiṭṭhīsu hi aññatarā diṭṭhi yassa niyatā, taṃ buddhasatampi
analyzed: ahetuka akiriya natthika diṭṭhīsu hi aññatarā diṭṭhi yassa niyatā tam buddha satam pi
translated: For when one of the two kinds of view, namely, the view that there is no cause or the view that denies the fruit, is fixed in anyone, then even if the Buddha himself were to arise for the sake of that person, he would be unable to make him give up that view.

original: vibodhetuṃ na sakkoti. Yena ca anantare eva attabhāve phaladānato ānantarikesu mātughātakapitughātakaarahantaghātakasaṅghabhedakalohituppādakasaṅkhātesu
analyzed: vibodhetum na sakkoti yena ca anantare eva atta bhāve phala dānataḥ ānantarikesu mātu ghātaka pitu ghātaka arahanta ghātaka saṅgha bhedaka lohituppādaka saṅkhātesu
translated: and he cannot prevent the result.

original: pañcasu kammesu ekampi kammaṃ paṭighacittena kataṃ hoti, so sineruppamāṇepi suvaṇṇathūpe🔽katvā sakalacakkavāḷaṃ pūretvā nisinnasambuddhappamukhaṃ saṅghaṃ yāvajīvaṃ catūhi
analyzed: pañcasu kammesu ekam pi kammam paṭigha cittena katam hoti so sineru pamāṇe pi suvaṇṇa thūpe  katvā sakala cakkavāḷam pūretvā nisinna sambuddha ppamukham saṅgham yāvajīvam catūhi
translated: And if he has done any one of the five kinds of deeds that are immediately fruitful, namely, killing one’s mother, killing one’s father, killing an arahat, causing a schism in the Community, and maliciously drawing blood from a Perfect One, and that deed has been done with a thought of hate, then even if he were to build a golden spire the size of Sineru,

original: paccayehi upaṭṭhahitvāpi tena kusalena ānantarikassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhituṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: paccayehi upaṭṭhahitvā api tena kusalena ānantarikassa vipākam paṭibāhitum na sakkoti
translated: and were he to honour with the four all-requisites a Community of monks headed by the Enlightened One filling the whole world together with the gods, he could not prevent the result of that profitable deed that is immediately fruitful.

original: ānantarikena pana adhikena ānantarikaṃ paṭibāhati, tasmā niyatamicchādiṭṭhi ānantarikā🔽ca maggaphalānaṃ, mahaggatānañca paṭibāhakatāya anantarameva niraye vipākadānato
analyzed: ānantarikena pana adhikena ānantarikam paṭibāhati tasmā niyatam icchādiṭṭhi ānantarikā  ca magga phalānam mahaggatānam ca paṭibāhaka tāya anantaram eva niraye vipāka dānataḥ
translated: But if he has done a deed that is immediately fruitful in addition to one that is not immediately fruitful, then the immediately fruitful one prevents the other,🔽and so the wrong view that is fixed is immediately fruitful.🔽And the four paths are called fixed as rightness because they prevent the immediately fruitful and the fixed as wrongness, and because they give their own results immediately in the next becoming,

original: micchattaniyatā ca jātā, cattāro pana maggā sammattaniyatā nāma, sesacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: micchatta niyatā ca jātā cattāro pana maggā sammatta niyatā nāma sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: and the rest of the states consisting of the other kinds of consciousness, and of the kinds of materiality, and Nibbāna, are called unfixed.

original: aniyatā nāma. Cetasikesu pana moho ahirikaṃ anottappaṃ uddhaccaṃ lobho diṭṭhi doso🔽thinaṃ middhanti ime nava siyā micchattaniyatā, siyā aniyatā, sesaakusalā, karuṇā,
analyzed: aniyatāḥ nāma cetasikesu pana mohaḥ ahirikam anottappam uddhaccam lobho diṭṭhi doso  thinam ime nava siyā micchatta niyatā siyā aniyatā sesa akusalā karuṇā
translated: called indeterminate. But in the case of the associated states, delusion, shamelessness, fearlessness of wrongdoing, agitation, greed, false view,🔽hate, lethargy, and drowsiness are either wrongness-determined or indeterminate. The rest of the unprofitable, and compassion

original: muditā ca aniyatā eva, sesakusalābyākatā siyā sammattaniyatā, siyā aniyatā, tijātikā
analyzed: muditā ca aniyatā eva sesa kusala abyākatā siyā sammatta niyatā siyā aniyatā ti jātikā
translated: and gladness, are indeterminate only. The rest of the profitable and indeterminate are either rightness-determined or indeterminate. But the three universals

original: pana tidhāpi honti, idañca nippadesattikanti. Micchattattikaṃ.🔽Nibbānaṃ maggati, kilese vā mārento gacchatīti maggo, ariyamaggo, so ārammaṇametesanti🔽maggārammaṇā. Lokiyo aṭṭhaṅgikopi maggo paccayaṭṭhena etesaṃ hetūti maggahetukā,🔽maggasampayuttā dhammā. Magge vā hetūti maggahetū, alobhādayo. Te etesaṃ hetūti maggahetukā.
analyzed: pana tidhā api honti idam ca nippadesattikam ti micchattattikam  nibbānam maggati kilese vā mārentaḥ gacchati iti maggaḥ ariya maggo so ārammaṇam etesan ti  magga ārammaṇā lokiyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ api maggo paccaya ṭṭhena etesam hetu uti magga hetukā  magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ magge vā hetū iti magga hetū alobha ādayo te etesam hetū iti magga hetukā
translated: are of three kinds. And this is the explanation of the triad. The Wrongness Triad.🔽The path is that by which one goes to extinction or by which one goes killing defilements. The path is the noble path. It is the object of these, thus they are “having path as object.”

original: Sammādiṭṭhi sayaṃ maggo ceva hetu ca, iti maggabhūto hetu etesanti maggahetukā, lokuttarāva.
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi sayam maggo ca iva hetu ca iti magga bhūtaḥ hetu etesanti magga hetukāḥ lokuttarāḥ ava
translated: The mundane eight-factored path is a condition for these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these, thus it is a cause of these,

original: Abhibhavitvā pavattanaṭṭhena maggo adhipati ārammaṇabhūto, sahajāto vā etesanti maggādhipatino, tadubhayaṃ.
analyzed: abhibhavitvā pavattana ṭṭhena maggaḥ adhipati ārammaṇa bhūto sahajātaḥ vā etesanti tat ubhayam
translated: The path is the dominant, either as object or as conascent, of these two, and so they are called “with the path as the dominant.”

original: Tattha rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānakusalakiriyā ca abhiññābhūtā, manodvārāvajjanañca🔽siyā maggārammaṇā, siyā navattabbā, ariyānaṃ hi cetopariyaanāgataṃsañāṇāni paresaññeva
analyzed: rūpāvacara catuttha jhāna kusala kiriyā ca abhiññā bhūtā  siyā magga ārammaṇā siyā na vattabbā ariyānam hi cetas upariya anāgataṃsa ñāṇāni paresañca eva
translated: Herein, the profitable and functional consciousnesses of the fine-material sphere belonging to the fourth jhāna, and the kinds of direct- knowledge,🔽may be either with the path as object or not. For the kinds of knowledge of penetration of others’ minds and of recollection of past births of Noble Ones,

original: maggacittassa jānanakāle maggārammaṇāni, pubbenivāsañāṇamanodvārāvajjanāni pana attano,
analyzed: magga cittassa jānana kāle magga ārammaṇāni pubbenivāsa ñāṇa manaḥ dvāra āvajjanāni pana attano
translated: when they are knowing another’s path consciousness, are with the path as object, but when they are of their own,

Noble Ones cannot take their own path as object with that. And because the kind of knowledge of recollection of past births

analyzed: yathāsakam heṭṭhimam ca magga phalam jānitum sakkonti na uparimam tāni pana abhiññā javanāni
translated: But these impulsions of direct-knowledge

original: Na hi tāni kiñci ārammaṇaṃ adhipatiṃ karonti, antamaso lokuttaramapi. Kasmā? Attano🔽mahaggatatāya rājānaṃ disvā tassa mātāpitaro viya, manodvārāvajjanaṃ pana attano
analyzed: na hi tāni kiñci ārammaṇam adhipatim karonti antamasaḥ lokuttaram api kasmai  mahaggata tāya rājānam disvā tassa mātā pitaraḥ viya manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam pana
translated: For they do not make any object their predominant, not even a supramundane one. Why?🔽Because they are great. They are like the parents of a king when he is seen.🔽But the adverting of the mind-door process is like the hunchback and the eunuch when he is seen.

translated: The four consciousnesses of the path-moment are always

analyzed: magga hetukāḥ eva tān eva ca adhipati bhāvena siyā magga adhipatino
translated: causes of the path. And they may be predominances of the path when they occur with the predominance of the investigation and energy faculties.

original: itaresaṃ chandacittānaṃ adhipatibhāvena pavattiyaṃ siyā navattabbā, aṭṭha ñāṇasampayuttakāmāvacarajavanāni
analyzed: itaresam chanda cittānam adhipati bhāvena pavattiyam siyā aṭṭha ñāṇa sampayutta kāmāvacara javanāni
translated: But they may not be when they occur with the predominance of the desire and other faculties. The eight kinds of sense-sphere impulsion associated with the eight kinds of knowledge

original: siyā maggārammaṇā, siyā maggādhipatino, siyā navattabbā. Tāni hi attanā, parehi ca
analyzed: siyā magga ārammaṇā siyā magga adhipatino siyā tāni hi attanā parehi ca
translated: They may be objects of the path, or they may be governed by the path, or they may not be made to occur. For they are

original: paṭividdhamaggapaccavekkhaṇakāle maggārammaṇā, attano maggaṃ garuṃkatvā paccavekkhaṇakāle🔽maggādhipatino ca tathāappavattiyaṃ navattabbā ca honti. Ariyā hi paresaṃ maggaphalāni
analyzed: paṭividdha magga paccavekkhaṇa kāle magga ārammaṇā attanaḥ maggam garuṃkatvā paccavekkhaṇa kāle  magga adhipatino ca ca honti ariyāḥ hi paresam magga phalāni
translated: at the time of reviewing the path that has been penetrated by oneself and by others, objects of the path. At the time of reviewing🔽one’s own path with the idea of its being important, they are governed by the path. And they are not made to occur in the future.

original: paccavekkhantā garuṃ karontāpi attano maggaphalāni viya garuṃ na karonti, api sammāsambuddhānaṃ.
analyzed: paccavekkhantāḥ garum karontā api attanaḥ magga phalāni viya garum na karonti api sammāsambuddhānam
translated: For when Noble Ones review the path and fruition of others and treat them with respect, they do not treat them with respect as they do their own path and fruition, not even the paths and fruitions of Perfectly Enlightened Ones.

original: Tesu sotāpanno sotāpannānameva maggaphalāni jānituṃ sakkoti, nāññesaṃ, sakadāgāmī
analyzed: tesu sotāpanno sotāpannānam eva magga phalāni jānitum sakkoti na aññesam sakadāgāmī
translated: Among them, one who is a stream-enterer can know only the paths and fruitions of stream-enterers, not those of the others. But a once-returner🔽can know those of once-returners too, not those of non-returners and Arahants.

original: pana sakadāgāmīnampi, na anāgāmiarahantānaṃ, anāgāmī pana anāgāmīnampi, na arahantānaṃ,
analyzed: pana sakadāgāmīnam pi na anāgāmi arahantānam anāgāmī pana anāgāmīnam pi na arahantānam
translated: And a non-returner can know those of non-returners too, not those of Arahants.

original: arahā pana sabbesampi maggaphalāni jānāti, sobhanalokiyacittarūpanibbānāni navattabbāneva.
analyzed: arahā pana sabbesam pi magga phalāni jānāti sobhana lokiya citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: But an Arahant can know those of all, and he does not make the beautiful mundane consciousnesses, materiality, and Nibbāna not to occur.

original: Cetasikesu pana viratiyo lokuttarakusale maggasadisāva, aññattha navattabbā, karuṇā,
analyzed: cetasikesu pana viratiyaḥ lokuttara kusale magga sadisā va aññattha na vattabbā karuṇā

original: Uppannāti ettha vattamānabhūtāpagataokāsakatabhūmiladdhavasena uppannā anekappabhedā

original: honti. Tattha sabbampi uppādajarābhaṅgasamaṅgīsaṅkhātaṃ saṅkhataṃ vattamānuppannaṃ🔽nāma, ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavitvā niruddhaṃ anubhūtāpagatasaṅkhātaṃ kusalākusalañca

translated: Herein, all the formed that is called “endowed with arising, ageing, and dissolution” is what has come to be arisen.🔽What has passed away is what has ceased after experiencing the flavour of the object. What is called “what has passed away” is profitable and unprofitable.

original: uppādādittayaṃ anuppatvā niruddhaṃ bhūtāpagatasaṅkhātaṃ, sesasaṅkhatañca bhūtāpagatuppannaṃ
analyzed: uppāda ādi ttayam an uppatvā niruddham bhūta apagata saṅkhātam sesa saṅkhatam ca bhūta apagata uppannam
translated: What has passed away arisen is what has ceased without reaching the triad of arising, etc., and what is called “what has passed away” is the rest of the formed.

original: nāma, “yānissa tāni pubbekatāni kammānī”ti evamādinā nayena vuttaṃ kammaṃ atītampi
analyzed: nāma yāni issa tāni pubbekatāni kammāni iti evamādinā nayena vuttam kammam atītam pi
translated: What has passed away is what is called “any action that he has previously done” .

analyzed: asamūhatam akusalam bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma ettha ca vipassanāya ārammaṇa bhūtā tebhūmakā  pañca kkhandhā bhūmi nāma tesu khandhesu uppatta āraha kilesa jātā bhūmiladdham nāma
translated: and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,🔽and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,🔽and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,🔽and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,🔽and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,

analyzed: tehi kilesehi sā bhūmi laddhā hoti iti evam etesu uppannesu idha vattamā anuppannā adhippetā  tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ pubbantataḥ uppādataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva bhaṅgā pannā gatā pavattā ati

translated: and because it is present in the sense of having made a place for itself by causing its result to arise without fail,🔽and because it is present in the sense
