analyzed: addhānam vasena pūretvā dassitaḥ laddha ukāsassa hi kammassa vipākaḥ uppādī nāma yadi
translated: and it is shown as fulfilled by the time of the life span. For the result of kamma that has had opportunity is called “arisen.”

original: pana āyūhitakusalākusalaṃ kammaṃ sabbaṃ vipākaṃ dadeyya, assa okāso na bhaveyya.
analyzed: pana āyūhita kusala akusalam kammam sabbam vipākam dadeyya assa okāsaḥ na bhaveyya
translated: But if all profitable and unprofitable kamma that has been stored up were to give its result, there would be no opportunity for it.

original: Taṃ pana duvidhaṃ hoti dhuvavipākaṃ, addhuvavipākañca. Tattha pañcānantarikaaṭṭhasamāpatticatutthamaggādi🔽dhuvavipākaṃ nāma. Taṃ pana kammaṃ khaṇappattampi atthi appattampi. Tattha khaṇappattaṃ
analyzed: tam pana duvidham hoti dhuva vipākam addhuva vipākam ca tattha pañca ānantarika aṭṭha samāpatti catuttha magga ādi  dhuva vipākam nāma tam pana kammam khaṇa ppattam pi atthi appattam pi tattha khaṇa ppattam
translated: That kamma is of two kinds, namely, that with inevitable result and that with non-inevitable result. Herein, the five crimes with immediate result, the eight attainments, the fourth path, and so on,🔽are called that with inevitable result. But that kamma is kamma that has had its opportunity and that which has not. Herein, that which has had its opportunity is called “arisen.” That which has not had its opportunity is called “unrisen.”

original: uppannaṃ nāma, appattaṃ anuppannaṃ nāma. Tassa duvidhassa ca vipāko duvidho hoti🔽khaṇappatto ca appatto ca. Tattha khaṇappatto uppanno nāma, appatto cittānantare
analyzed: uppannam nāma appattam anuppannam nāma tassa duvidhassa ca vipākaḥ duvidhaḥ hoti  khaṇappatto ca appatto ca tattha khaṇappatto uppanno nāma appatto citta anantare
translated: And the result of that kamma of the two kinds is of two kinds too,

original: vā uppajjatu, kappasatasahassātikkame vā dhuvapaccayaṭṭhena uppādī nāma hoti. Metteyyassa
analyzed: vā uppajjatu kappa sata sahassa atikkame vā dhuva paccaya ṭṭhena uppādī nāma hoti metteyyassa
translated: namely, that which has had its opportunity and that which has not. Herein, that which has had its opportunity is called “arisen.” That which has not had its opportunity is called “unrisen” whether it arises in the next consciousness or after an interval of a hundred thousand or a million aeons,

original: bodhisattassa maggo anuppanno nāma hoti, phalaṃ uppādī nāma. Tattha catūsu bhūmīsu
analyzed: bodhisattassa maggaḥ anuppannaḥ nāma hoti phalam uppādī nāma tattha catūsu bhūmīsu
translated: because it is a condition for the result by way of what is called “distant proximity.” The path of the Bodhisatta Metteyya is called “unrisen.” The fruit of the path is called “unrisen” too. Herein, in the case of the four paths

original: vipāko, kammajarūpañca vattamānuppannā nāma, uppajjanārahā uppādino nāma, na pana
analyzed: vipāko kamma ja rūpam ca vattamānuppannāḥ nāma uppajjana arahāḥ uppādinaḥ nāma na pana
translated: Resultant and kamma-born materiality are called “present and arisen.” That which is due to arise is called “arisen and due to arise.” But it is not

original: vattabbā “anuppannā”ti. Kusalākusalakiriyā, kammajarūpañca siyā uppannā, siyā anuppannā,
analyzed: vattabbā anuppannā ti kusala akusala kiriyā kamma ja rūpam ca siyā uppannā siyā anuppannā
translated: Resultant and the materiality originated by kamma are called “present” when they have arisen and are still persisting. They are called “due to arise” when they are in the threshold of arising and are about to arise. But it should not be said of them that they are “non-existent.” The profitable and unprofitable in- formation and the materiality originated by kamma may be either “arisen” or “non-existent.”

original: na pana vattabbā “uppādino”ti. Cetasikesu pana akusalā akusalacittasadisāva, sesā
analyzed: na pana vattabbāḥ uppādinaḥ ti cetasikesu pana akusalāḥ akusala citta sadisā ava sesā
translated: But it should not be said of them that they are “due to arise.” But as regards the associated states, the unprofitable are like the unprofitable consciousness. The rest are

original: duvidhāpi honti, atītā, panettha nibbānañca navattabbā. Sesaṃ suviññeyyamevāti. Uppannattikaṃ.
analyzed: duvidhā api honti atītā pana ittha nibbānam ca sesam su viññeyyam eva ati uppanna ttikam
translated: of both kinds. But here Nibbāna should not be taken. The rest are easily understood. This is the section on “arisen.”

original: Attano sabhāvaṃ, uppādādikkhaṇaṃ vā patvā taṃ atikkamitvā itā gatā pattāti atītā.
analyzed: attanaḥ sabhāvam uppāda ādi kkhaṇam vā patvā tam atikkamitvā itā gatā pattā ati atītā
translated: Having gone past, having reached, their own individual essence or the moment of arising, etc., they are “departed” , thus they are “past” .

original: Tadubhayampi na āgatāti anāgatā. Taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicca uppannāti paccuppannā, sabbe
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi na āgatā ati anāgatā tam tam kāraṇam paṭicca uppannā ati paccuppannā sabbe
translated: Neither of these two is “come” , thus they are “future” . They are “present” because they have arisen in dependence on this and that condition. All

original: saṅkhatā nāmarūpadhammā. Na saṅkhatadhammesu tekālikabhāvaṃ appatto nāma atthi, sabbepi
analyzed: saṅkhatāḥ nāma rūpa dhammāḥ na saṅkhata dhammesu tekālika bhāvam appatto nāma atthi sabbe pi
translated: formed states consisting of mentality and materiality are so. There is no formed state that has not reached the state of being one of the three

original: te tidhā honti. Nibbānaṃ panettha navattabbanti. Atītattikaṃ.
analyzed: te tidhā honti nibbānam pana ittha atīta ttikam
translated: times. All of them are of the three times. But here Nibbāna should not be taken. This is the section on “past.”

original: Atītaṃ ārammaṇaṃ etesanti atītārammaṇā. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: atītam ārammaṇam etesanti atīta ārammaṇā sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo
translated: Those that have past objects are the bases of past consciousness. The rest are as stated.

original: Tattha kusalavipākakiriyāvasena chabbidhāni viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanāni
analyzed: tattha kusala vipāka kiriyā vasena chabbidhāni
translated: Herein, the bases of the six kinds of consciousness, namely, profitable, resultant, and functional, in the base consisting of boundless consciousness and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception,

original: heṭṭhā atītasamāpattiṃ ārabbha pavattito atītārammaṇāni, dvipañcaviññāṇamanodhātuyo
analyzed: heṭṭhā atīta samāpattim ārabbha pavattitaḥ atīta ārammaṇāni dvi pañca viññāṇa manaḥ dhātuyo
translated: are past when they occur in dependence on a past attainment, and they are present when they have present objects. The two kinds of five consciousnesses and the mind element

original: paccuppannārammaṇāva, sesā ekādasa kāmāvacaravipākā, ahetukahasanacittañca tidhāpi
analyzed: paccuppanna ārammaṇāḥ ava sesāḥ ekādasa kāmāvacara vipākāḥ ahetuka hasana cittam ca tidhā api
translated: are only present. The remaining eleven kinds of sense-sphere resultant and the functional consciousness without root-cause are of three kinds,

original: honti, sesakāmāvacarakiriyakusalākusalā ca abhiññābhūtarūpāvacaracatutthajjhānakusalakiriyā🔽ca tidhāpi honti navattabbā ca. Tesu kāmāvacarānaṃ atītādīsu chasu ārammaṇesu pavattivibhāgo🔽heṭṭhā vuttova. Navattabbatā pana tesu ñāṇavippayuttajavanakusalānaṃ paññattārammaṇavaseneva,
analyzed: honti sesa kāmāvacara kiriya kusala akusalā ca abhiññā bhūta rūpāvacara catuttha jjhāna kusala kiriyā  ca tidhā api honti ca tesu kāmāvacarānam atīta ādīsu chasu ārammaṇesu pavatti vibhāgaḥ  heṭṭhā vuttaḥ uva navattabba tā pana tesu ñāṇa vippayutta javana kusalānam paññatta ārammaṇa vasena iva
translated: that is, past, future, and present. The remaining sense-sphere functional, profitable, and unprofitable, and the profitable and functional of the fine-material sphere in the fourth jhāna,🔽are of three kinds, and they are also not to be taken as objects.🔽The way in which they occur with past, etc., objects among these is stated in the case of the sense-sphere kinds. But the fact that they are not to be taken as objects is stated only in the case of the profitable consciousnesses accompanied by knowledge with their object as a concept,

original: na nibbānārammaṇavasena, tesupi tihetukajavanāvajjanānaṃ maggaphalarūpārūpajjhānānaṃ,
analyzed: na nibbāna ārammaṇa vasena tesu pi ti hetuka javana avajjanānam magga phala rūpa arūpa jjhānānam
translated: not in the case of those with Nibbāna as their object. And in the case of the profitable and functional consciousnesses accompanied by knowledge, it is stated only in the case of the profitable and functional consciousnesses of the fine-material sphere in the fourth jhāna,

original: purecārikabhāvenāpi nibbānacatukkajjhānavisayānañca paccavekkhaṇabhāvenāpi navattabbatā🔽veditabbā, abhiññānaṃ pana iddhividhañāṇassa tāva kāyavasena cittaṃ pariṇāmetvā kāyasannissitaṃ
analyzed: purecārika bhāvena api nibbāna catukka jjhāna visayānam ca paccavekkhaṇa bhāvena api na vattabba tā  veditabbā abhiññānam pana iddhividha ñāṇassa tāva kāya vasena cittam pariṇāmetvā kāya sannissitam
translated: and by the way of the preliminary work, and by the way of reviewing the four jhānas and Nibbāna as their object, they are not to be undertaken.

original: katvā dissamānena kāyena gacchantassa atītaṃ pādakajjhānacittaṃ ārabbha pavattanato
analyzed: katvā dissamānena kāyena gacchantassa atītam pādaka jhāna cittam ārabbha pavattanato
translated: But firstly, as regards the kinds of direct-knowledge, the knowledge of the mind-made body, which is one of the kinds of supernormal power, has a past object when it occurs contingent upon a consciousness of the basic jhāna that has already arisen and passed away,

original: atītārammaṇaṃ, “anāgatesu rūpāni evaṃ hontū”ti adhiṭṭhahantassa anāgatārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: atīta ārammaṇam anāgatesu rūpāni evam hontu uti adhiṭṭhahantassa anāgata ārammaṇam
translated: and it has a future object when one resolves thus, “Let there be visible data,” etc.,

original: kāyaṃ pana cittasannissitaṃ katvā adissamānena kāyena gamanakāle, ajjhattaṃ kumāravaṇṇādīnaṃ,
analyzed: kāyam pana citta sannissitam katvā a dissamānena kāyena gamana kāle ajjhattam kumāra vaṇṇa ādīnam
translated: But when the body is made dependent on the mind and one goes with an invisible body, then at the time of creating the visible-data base consisting of the boy’s body, etc., inside oneself,

original: bahiddhāpāsādakūṭāgārādīnañca paccuppannānaṃ nimmānakāle ca paccuppannārammaṇañca
analyzed: bahiddhā pāsāda kūṭāgāra ādīnam ca paccuppannānam nimmāna kāle ca paccuppanna ārammaṇañca
translated: and at the time of creating palaces, kūṭāgāras, etc., outside, the object is a present one.

original: tāva hotīti evaṃ iddhividhassa chabbidhampi ajjhattikaṃ, bāhirañca tekālikaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tāva hoti iti evam iddhi vidhassa chabbidham pi ajjhattikam bāhiram ca tekālikam ārammaṇam hoti iti veditabbam
translated: So it should be understood that the mind-made body has six kinds of objects, namely, past, future, present, internal, external, and both internal and external.

original: Dibbasotassa kucchigataṃ ajjhattikaṃ, bāhirañca paccuppannaṃ saddāyatanamevārammaṇaṃ.🔽Cetopariyañāṇassa atīte sattadivasabbhantare, anāgate sattadivasabbhantare ca paresaññeva🔽cittaṃ atītañca anāgatañcārammaṇaṃ hoti. Sattadivasātikkame panetaṃ paracittaṃ jānituṃ
analyzed: dibba sotassa kucchi gatam ajjhattikam bāhiram ca paccuppannam sadda āyatanam eva ārammaṇam  cetas upariya ñāṇassa atīte satta divasa bbhantare anāgate satta divasa bbhantare ca paresañca eva  cittam atītam ca anāgatam ca ārammaṇam hoti satta divasa atikkame pana itam para cittam jānitum
translated: The base of the divine ear is the present internal and external sound-element.🔽The base of the knowledge of penetration of minds is the mind of others in the past and future within the seven days.🔽But when the seven days have elapsed, it cannot know the other’s mind. For this is the province of the knowledge of past lives and of the knowledge of the future, not of this.

original: na sakkoti. Atītaṃsaanāgataṃsañāṇānaṃ hi esa visayo, na etassa. Paccuppannacittajānanakāle
analyzed: na sakkoti atīta aṃsa anāgata aṃsa ñāṇānam hi esa visayaḥ na etassa paccuppanna citta jānana kāle
translated: But at the time of knowing the present mind,

original: panassa paccuppannamārammaṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: panassa paccuppannam ārammaṇam hoti
translated: its object is present.

original: Paccuppannañca nāmetaṃ tividhaṃ khaṇapaccuppannaṃ santatipaccuppannaṃ addhāpaccuppannañcāti.
analyzed: paccuppannam ca nāma etam tividham khaṇa paccuppannam santati paccuppannam addhā paccuppannam ca ati
translated: And the present is threefold as momentary present, continuous present, and distant present.

original: Tattha uppādaṭṭhitibhaṅgappattaṃ khaṇapaccuppannaṃ nāma. Santatipaccuppannaṃ pana
analyzed: tattha uppāda ṭṭhiti bhaṅga ppattam khaṇa paccuppannam nāma santati paccuppannam pana
translated: Herein, what has reached occurrence, continuance, and dissolution is called momentary present. But the continuous present

original: duvidhaṃ rūpārūpavasena. Tattha ātapaṭṭhānā āgantvā gabbhaṃ paviṭṭhassa yāva andhakārabhāvo
analyzed: duvidham rūpa arūpa vasena tattha ātapa ṭṭhānā āgantvā gabbham paviṭṭhassa yāva andhakāra bhāvo
translated: is twofold as material and immaterial. Herein, the material is that which has come into the womb after passing through the various stages of the embryo.

original: na vigacchati, antogabbhe vā vasitvā divā ātapaṭṭhānaṃ olokentassa yāva akkhīnaṃ🔽phandanabhāvo na vūpasammati, ayaṃ rūpasantati nāma. Dve tayo javanavārā arūpasantati🔽nāma, tadubhayaṃ santatipaccuppannanti veditabbaṃ. Ekabhavaparicchinnaṃ addhāpaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: na vigacchati antogabbhe vā vasitvā divā ātapa ṭṭhānam olokentassa yāva akkhīnam  phandana bhāvaḥ ayam rūpasantati nāma dve tayaḥ javana vārāḥ a rūpasantati  nāma tat ubhayam santati paccuppannam ti veditabbam eka bhava paricchinnam addhā paccuppannam
translated: and does not depart, or when one who has lived in the womb looks at the light of day after emerging, so long as the winking of the eyes does not cease, this is called the continuity of materiality. Two or three impulsions are called the continuity of the immaterial. Both should be understood as the present continuity. The present moment limited to a single becoming is called the present moment of time.

original: nāma. Imasmiṃ pana cetopariyañāṇavisaye katipayajavanavārā addhāpaccuppannaṃ nāma.🔽Tattha khaṇapaccuppannaṃ cittaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa ārammaṇaṃ na hoti āvajjanena saddhiṃ🔽nirujjhanato. Na hi āvajjanajavanānaṃ ettha bhinnārammaṇatā yuttā. Rūpasantatipaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: nāma imasmin pana cetas upariya ñāṇa visaye katipaya javana vārāḥ addhāpaccuppannam nāma  tattha khaṇa paccuppannam cittam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa ārammaṇam na hoti āvajjanena saddhiṃ  nirujjhanataḥ na hi āvajjana javanānam ettha bhinna ārammaṇa tā yuttā rūpa santati paccuppannam
translated: and does not depart, and when he has dwelt inside and looks out at the sun’s heat, so long as the winking of the eyes does not cease, this is called the continuity of materiality. Two or three impulsions are called the continuity of the immaterial. Both should be understood as present in continuity. That limited to a single becoming is called present in time. But in the case of the knowledge of penetration of minds, several impulsions are called present in time.

original: pana katipayajavanavāraparicchinnaṃ addhāpaccuppannaṃ assa ārammaṇaṃ hoti. Iddhimā
analyzed: pana katipaya javana vāra paricchinnam addhā paccuppannam assa ārammaṇam hoti iddhimā
translated: Herein, the consciousness present in a moment is not the object of the knowledge of penetration of minds because it has ceased together with the adverting. For it is not proper that the adverting and the impulsion should have different objects. But the continuity of materiality, which is limited to several impulsions, is its object.

original: hi parassa cittaṃ jānitukāmo āvajjeti, taṃ āvajjitakkhaṇe paccuppannacittamārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: hi parassa cittam jānitu kāmaḥ āvajjeti tam āvajjita kkhaṇe paccuppanna cittam ārammaṇam
translated: For a possessor of supernormal power who wants to know another’s mind adverts. At the moment of his adverting the consciousness present in the other is his object.

original: katvā teneva saha nirujjhati. Tato tadeva niruddhaṃ cittamālambitvā cattāri, pañca
analyzed: katvā tena iva saha nirujjhati tatas tat eva niruddham cittam ālambitvā cattāri pañca
translated: and it ceases together with that. Then, having taken that same ceased consciousness as object, four or five impulsions impel.

original: vā javanāni uppajjanti, tesaṃ pacchimaṃ iddhicittaṃ, sesāni kāmāvacarajavanāni. Tesañca
analyzed: vā javanāni uppajjanti tesam pacchimam iddhi cittam sesāni kāmāvacara javanāni tesam ca
translated: and it ceases together with that. Then, taking that same consciousness that has ceased as its object, four or five impulsions impel. The last of these is the consciousness of supernormal power; the rest are impulsions of the fine-material sphere.

original: ekārammaṇattepi iddhicittameva parassa cittaṃ jānāti, na itarāni. Yathā cakkhudvāravīthiyaṃ
analyzed: eka ārammaṇa tte pi iddhi cittam eva parassa cittam jānāti na itarāni yathā cakkhu dvāra vīthiyam
translated: And though they have the same object, it is only the consciousness of supernormal power that knows another’s consciousness, not the others. Just as, in the eye’s field of vision,

original: cakkhuviññāṇameva rūpaṃ passati, na itarāni, tesu ca āvajjanameva nippariyāyato paccuppannārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam eva rūpam passati na itarāni tesu ca āvajjanam eva nippariyāyato paccuppanna ārammaṇam
translated: it is only eye-consciousness that sees visible objects, not the others, and of them the adverting is actually next to the present object,

original: itarāni pana addhāsantativasena pariyāyatoti gahetabbaṃ, evametassa atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: itarāni pana addhā santati vasena pariyāyato ti gahetabbam evam etassa atīta anāgata paccuppannam
translated: but the others are next to it by continuity, so too, this consciousness has only the consciousness of another as its object, whether past, future or present,

original: cittamevārammaṇaṃ hoti, tañca kho parasseva, na attano.
analyzed: cittam eva ārammaṇam hoti tat ca kho parassa iva na attanaḥ
translated: but that is of another, not of himself.

original: Pubbenivāsañāṇaṃ pana nāmagottakasiṇapaññattādianussaraṇe, nibbānānussaraṇe ca navattabbārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇam pana nāma gotta kasiṇa paññatta ādi anussaraṇe nibbāna anussaraṇe ca navattabba ārammaṇam
translated: But knowledge of past lives has as its object the recollection of names, clans, signs, etc., and the recollection of Nibbāna, which is not classifiable.

original: saṅkhatadhammānussaraṇe atītārammaṇameva. Tassa hi atītesu sāsavānāsavesu, ajjhattikabāhiresu
analyzed: saṅkhata dhamma anussaraṇe atīta ārammaṇam eva tassa hi atītesu sa āsava anāsavesu ajjhattika bāhiresu
translated: The recollection of ideas that are formed has only past objects, for it is only in past ideas that are subject to cankers and have cankers that it occurs, whether internal or external,

original: ca dhammesu anārammaṇaṃ nāma natthi, buddhānaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇasamagatikaṃ hoti. Yathākammūpagañāṇassa
analyzed: ca dhammesu anārammaṇam nāma natthi buddhānam sabbaññuta ññāṇa sama gatikam hoti yathā kamma upaga ñāṇassa
translated: The recollection of ideas that are formed has only past objects. For there is no object that is not included in the past among ideas that are subject to cankers and have cankers in the case of past internal and external ideas.

original: ajjhattikaṃ, bāhirañca atītaṃ kusalākusalacetanāmattameva. “Cetopariyañāṇassa cittamevārammaṇaṃ🔽hoti, na taṃsampayuttadhammā”ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ, paṭṭhāne pana “kusalā khandhā🔽iddhividhañāṇassa cetopariyañāṇassa pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇassa yathākammūpagañāṇassa
analyzed: ajjhattikam bāhiram ca atītam kusala akusala cetanā mattam eva cetaḥ pariyañāṇassa cittam eva ārammaṇam  hoti na tad sampayutta dhammā ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam paṭṭhāne pana kusalāḥ khandhāḥ  iddhividha ñāṇassa cetas upariya ñāṇassa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇassa yathākammūpaga ñāṇassa
translated: The knowledge of faring according to deeds has only past wholesome and unwholesome volition as its object, whether internal or external.🔽It is said in the Commentaries that the knowledge of penetration of minds has only consciousness as its object, not the states associated with that consciousness.

original: anāgataṃsañāṇassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo”ti vuttattā cetopariyañāṇayathākammūpagañāṇānaṃ
analyzed: anāgataṃsa ñāṇassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ti vutta ttā cetas pariya ñāṇa yathākammūpaga ñāṇānam
translated: But since it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The wholesome aggregates are a condition, as object condition, for the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power, for the knowledge of penetration of minds, for the knowledge of recollection of past lives, for the knowledge of faring according to deeds,

original: cittasampayuttāpi cetanāsampayuttāpi cattāro khandhā ārammaṇaṃ honti evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: citta sampayuttā api cetanā sampayuttā api cattāro khandhāḥ ārammaṇam honti eva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: for the knowledge of the future, ” it must be understood that the knowledge of penetration of minds and the knowledge of faring according to deeds have as their object the four aggregates associated with consciousness and the volition associated with consciousness.

original: Dibbacakkhuñāṇassa pana ajjhattikaṃ, bāhirañca paccuppannaṃ vaṇṇāyatanamevārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa pana ajjhattikam bāhiram ca paccuppannam vaṇṇa āyatanam eva ārammaṇam
translated: But the object of the knowledge of the divine eye is only the visible-data base that is internal and external and present.

original: Anāgataṃsañāṇassa chabbidhampi anāgatameva ajjhattañca bāhirañcārammaṇaṃ, idampi
analyzed: anāgataṃsañāṇassa chabbidham pi anāgatam eva ajjhattam ca bāhiram ca ārammaṇaṃ idam pi
translated: The object of the knowledge of the future is the six bases that are internal and external and future, which are of six kinds. This too

original: pubbenivāsañāṇaṃ viya anāgate sabbaññutaññāṇasadisanti. Evaṃ abhiññānaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannesu,
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇam viya anāgate sabbaññuta ññāṇa sadisanti evam abhiññānam atīta anāgata paccuppannesu
translated: is like the knowledge of the past and like the knowledge of omniscience in the future. This is how the occurrence of the kinds of direct- knowledge should be understood as to the past, future, and present,

original: navattabbesu ca ajjhattikabāhiresu chasu ārammaṇesu yathāyogaṃ pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: navattabbesu ca ajjhattika bāhiresu chasu ārammaṇesu yathāyogam pavatti veditabbā
translated: and as to the nine bases that are internal and external and not to be directly known.

original: Sesāni pannarasa rūpāvacaracittāni, ākāsānañcāyatanaākiñcaññāyatanakusalavipākakiriyāni,
analyzed: sesāni pannarasa rūpāvacara cittāni ākāsa anañcāyatana ākiñcaññāyatana kusala vipāka kiriyāni
translated: The remaining fifteen kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness, namely, the profitable, resultant and functional consciousness associated with the four jhānas in the base consisting of boundless space and in the base consisting of nothingness,

original: aṭṭha lokuttaracittāni, rūpanibbānāni ca navattabbāni. Cetasikesu pana appamaññā
analyzed: aṭṭha lokuttara cittāni rūpa nibbānāni ca navattabbāni cetasikesu pana appamaññā
translated: and the eight kinds of supramundane consciousness, and the materiality of the immaterial becoming, are not to be directly known. But among the associated states, the four divine abidings

original: navattabbāva. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Atītārammaṇattikaṃ.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva atīta ārammaṇa ttikam
translated: are not to be directly known. The rest is easy to understand. As to the past, etc., as object:

original: “Evaṃ pavattamānā mayaṃ attāti gahaṇaṃ gamissāmā”ti iminā viya adhippāyena attānaṃ
analyzed: evam pavattamānāḥ mayam attā ati gahaṇam gamissāma ati iminā viya adhippāyena attānam
translated: “We shall come to be apprehended as self by occurring thus” — it is with this intention that they occur.

original: adhikāraṃ katvā pavattāti ajjhattā. Ajjhatta-saddo panāyaṃ gocarajjhatte niyakajjhatte
analyzed: adhikāram katvā pavattā ati ajjhattā ajjhatta saddo pana ayam gocara jjhatte niyaka jjhatte
translated: and it occurs after the function has been performed, it is internal. The word internal is found in four senses: as the internal of the domain, as the internal of one’s own,

original: ajjhattajjhatte visayajjhatteti catūsu atthesu dissati. “Ajjhattarato samāhito”tiādīsu
analyzed: ajjhatta ajjhatte visaya jjhatta iti catūsu atthesu dissati ajjhattarataḥ samāhita uti ādīsu
translated: as the internal of the internal, and as the internal of the object. In such passages as “Delighting in the internal, being composed” ,

original: hi ayaṃ gocarajjhatte dissati. “Ajjhattaṃ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: hi ayam gocara jjhatte dissati ajjhattam vā dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati itiādīsu
translated: it is found in the sense of the internal of the domain. In such passages as “One abides contemplating mental objects internally in the mental objects of the ideas” ,🔽it is found in the sense of the internal of one’s own. In such passages as “The six internal bases” ,

original: niyakajjhatte. “Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanānī”tiādīsu ajjhattajjhatte. “Ajjhattaṃ suññataṃ🔽upasampajja viharatī”tiādīsu visayajjhatte, issariyaṭṭhāneti attho. Phalasamāpatti🔽hi buddhānaṃ issariyaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Idha panāyaṃ niyakajjhatte vattati, tasmā attano🔽santāne pavattā pāṭipuggalikā rūpārūpadhammā idha ajjhattāti veditabbā. Tato bahibhūtā
analyzed: niyaka jjhatte cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni iti ādīsu ajjhatta jjhatte ajjhattam suññatam  upasampajja viharati itiādīsu visaya jjhatte issariya ṭṭhāne ti attho phala samāpatti  hi buddhānam issariya ṭṭhānam nāma idha pana ayam niya kajjhatte vattati tasmai attanaḥ  santāne pavattā pāṭipuggalikāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ idha ajjhattā ati veditabbā tatas bahibhūtā
translated: it is found in the sense of the internal of the internal. In such passages as “Having entered upon the internal emptiness” ,

original: indriyabaddhā vā anindriyabaddhā vā rūpārūpapaññattiyo bahiddhā nāma, tatiyapadaṃ
analyzed: indriya baddhāḥ vā anindriya baddhāḥ vā rūpa arūpa paññattiyaḥ bahiddhā nāma tatiya padam
translated: it is found in the sense of the internal of the object, the meaning being “the state of sovereignty.” For the attainment of fruition is called the state of sovereignty of Buddhas. But here it is in the sense of the internal of one’s own, and so the ideas of materiality and the immaterial, which occur in one’s own continuity, should be understood here as internal. Those that are external to that, whether or not they are bound up with faculties, are called external. The third term

original: tadubhayavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tad ubhaya vasena vuttam
translated: So it is said in both ways.

original: Tattha sabbāni cittacetasikāni indriyabaddharūpaṃ tidhā honti, anindriyabaddharūpaṃ,
analyzed: tattha sabbāni citta cetasikāni indriya baddha rūpam tidhā honti an indriya baddha rūpam
translated: Herein, all consciousness and its concomitants are internal as materiality conjoined with faculties,

original: nibbānapaññattiyo ca bahiddhāva. Imasmiṃ hi tike kusalattike alabbhamānā paññattiyopi🔽labbhanti ṭhapetvā ākiñcaññāyatanārammaṇaṃ, tadeva idha navattabbaṃ. Teneva hi bhagavatā
analyzed: nibbāna paññattiyaḥ ca bahiddhā vā imasmin hi tike kusala ttike a labbhamānā paññattiyaḥ api  labbhanti ṭhapetvā ākiñcaññāyatana ārammaṇam tat eva idha tena iva hi bhagavatā
translated: and as the three immaterial bases, and also as the description of Nibbāna. For in this triad of profitable consciousnesses, descriptions that are not found in the first triad are found,

original: anantarattike “kasiṇādipaññattārammaṇāni kāmarūpāvacarādicittāni bahiddhārammaṇāni,
analyzed: anantara ttike kasiṇa ādi paññatta ārammaṇāni kāma rūpāvacara ādi cittāni bahiddha ārammaṇāni
translated: except for the base consisting of nothingness. That is not to be taken here. That is why the Blessed One said in the next triad: “The kinds of consciousness belonging to the fine-material and immaterial spheres, which have as their object the descriptions of the kasiṇa and so on, have an external object,

original: ākiñcaññāyatanañca navattabba”nti vuttaṃ, idañca nippadesattikaṃ. Ajjhattattikaṃ.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatanañca vuttam idam ca nippadesa ttikam ajjhatta ttikam
translated: and the base consisting of nothingness is not to be taken” . And this triad is a non-specific triad.🔽The internal triad is

original: Yathāvutte ajjhattādike ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattānaṃ vasena ayaṃ tiko vutto. Tattha
analyzed: yathā vutte ajjhatta ādike ārammaṇam katvā pavattānam vasena ayam tikaḥ vutto tattha
translated: This triad is stated according to the kinds of consciousness that occur having as their object the internal and so on stated in the way already described. Herein,

original: chabbidhāni viññāṇañcāyatananevasaññānāsaññāyatanacittāni ajjhattārammaṇāneva, ākāsānañcāyatanattayaṃ,
analyzed: chabbidhāni viññāṇañcāyatana nevasaññā nāsaññāyatana cittāni ajjhatta ārammaṇāni na eva ākāsa anañcāyatana ttayam
translated: the three kinds of consciousness of the base consisting of boundless space,

original: rūpāvacaralokuttaracittāni ca bahiddhārammaṇāneva, voṭṭhabbanavajjitā ahetukamahāvipākā
analyzed: rūpāvacara lokuttara cittāni ca bahiddhā ārammaṇāni eva voṭṭhabbana vajjitā ahetuka mahā vipākā
translated: The great resultants without root-cause, excluding the determining, are of three kinds.

original: tidhāpi honti, avasesā pana ākiñcaññāyatanavajjitāni āvajjanajavanāni, abhiññā ca
analyzed: tidhā api honti avasesā pana ākiñcaññāyatana vajjitāni āvajjana javanāni abhiññā ca
translated: The rest, excluding the base consisting of nothingness, are of three kinds, and the kinds of direct-knowledge are of three kinds.

original: siyā tidhāpi honti, ākiñcaññāyatanārammaṇassa āvajjanaparikammapaccavekkhaṇādibhāvappavattiyaṃ🔽siyā navattabbāti. Tesaṃ ajjhattādiārammaṇatā anantarattike, heṭṭhā ca vuttanayānusārena
analyzed: siyā tidhā api honti ākiñcaññāyatana ārammaṇassa āvajjana parikamma paccavekkhaṇa ādi bhāva ppavattiyam  siyā na vattabbā ti tesam ajjhatta ādi ārammaṇa tā anantara ttike heṭṭhā ca vutta naya anusārena
translated: But the determining, the reviewing, and so on, of the base consisting of nothingness as object are not to be found.🔽They should be understood according to the method stated above in the immediately preceding triad.🔽But the three bases consisting of nothingness and materiality and Nibbāna are not to be found.

original: ñātabbā, ākiñcaññāyatanattayaṃ, pana rūpanibbānāni ca navattabbāva. Cetasikesu pana🔽appamaññāviratī bahiddhārammaṇāva, sesā tidhāpi honti navattabbā ca. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: ñātabbā ākiñcaññāyatana ttayam pana rūpa nibbānāni ca cetasikesu pana  appamaññā viratī bahiddhā ārammaṇā ava sesā tidhā api honti na vattabbā ca sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: But the divine abidings, the liberations, the applications of mindfulness, the kinds of direct-knowledge, the analytical insights, the fruits, and the paths are of three kinds, and they are not to be found.

original: Ajjhattārammaṇattikaṃ.
analyzed: ajjhatta ārammaṇa ttikam
translated: The rest is easy to understand.🔽The triad of internal objects, etc.

original: Daṭṭhabbabhāvasaṅkhātena saha nidassanenāti sanidassanā, paṭihananabhāvasaṅkhātena
analyzed: daṭṭhabba bhāva saṅkhātena saha nidassanena ati sa nidassanā paṭihanana bhāva saṅkhātena
translated: With appearance: with the appearance called “visibility.”

original: saha paṭighenāti sappaṭighā, sanidassanā ca te sappaṭighā cāti sanidassanasappaṭighā,
analyzed: saha paṭighena ati sa paṭighā sa nidassanā ca te sa paṭighā ca ati sa nidassana sa paṭighā
translated: With impingement: impinging, and they are visible too, thus they are visible and impinging.

original: rūpāyatanameva. Nīlādibhedamupādāya pana bahuvacananiddeso. Natthi etesaṃ daṭṭhabbabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: rūpa āyatanam eva nīla ādi bhedam upādāya pana bahuvacana niddesaḥ natthi etesam daṭṭhabba bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: Only the visible-data base. But the plural is used because of the division into blue, etc.

original: nidassananti anidassanā, anidassanā ca te vuttanayena sappaṭighā cāti anidassanasappaṭighā,
analyzed: nidassananti anidassanā anidassanā ca te vutta nayena sa ppaṭighā ca ati anidassana sa ppaṭighā
translated: They have no sign consisting in visibility, thus they are signless. And they are impinging in the way already stated, thus they are impinging and signless.

original: sesāni oḷārikarūpāni. Tatiyapadaṃ ubhayapaṭikkhepena vuttaṃ, sukhumarūpacittacetasikanibbānāni
analyzed: sesāni oḷārika rūpāni tatiya padam ubhaya paṭikkhepena vuttam sukhuma rūpa citta cetasika nibbānāni
translated: The remaining gross physical forms. The third term is stated by the exclusion of both. Subtle physical form, consciousness, and Nibbāna

original: anidassanaappaṭighā nāma, idañca nippadesattikanti veditabbaṃ. Sanidassanattikaṃ.
analyzed: anidassana appaṭighā nāma idam ca nippadesa ttikan ti veditabbam sa nidassana ttikam
translated: are called signless and impinging. And this is to be understood as the explanation of the triad with “visible.” The visible triad is ended.

original: Tikamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tikamātika ttha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section of the threefold matrix is ended.

original: Abhidhammadukamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The Abhidhamma Duka Matrix🔽Now, in the case of the duka matrix, we shall only give the explanation of the terms not already dealt with below.

original: Dukamātikāya pana heṭṭhā anāgatapadatthavaṇṇanaṃyeva karissāma. Hetugocchake tāva
analyzed: duka mātikāya pana heṭṭhā anāgata padattha vaṇṇanaṃya iva karissāma hetu gocchake tāva
translated: In the case of the “root-cause” duka,

original: hetū dhammāti ettha hetuhetu paccayahetu uttamahetu sādhāraṇahetūti catubbidhā hetū.
analyzed: hetū dhammā ti ettha hetu hetu paccaya hetu uttama hetu sādhāraṇa hetū iti catubbidhāḥ hetū
translated: herein, as regards the clause “Root-causes are ideas,” there are four kinds of root-cause, that is to say, root-cause as cause, root-cause as condition, root-cause as highest , and root-cause as shared in common .

original: Tattha alobhādayo cha dhammā hetuhetū nāma, upādārūpādīnaṃ mahābhūtādayo paccayahetū🔽nāma, vipākuppattiyaṃ kusalākusalaṃ, iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇañca uttamahetū nāma, saṅkhārādīnaṃ🔽avijjādayo sādhāraṇahetū nāma. Idha pana hetuhetu adhippeto. Hetū dhammāti mūlaṭṭhena
analyzed: tattha alobha ādayaḥ cha dhammā hetu hetū nāma upādā rūpa ādīnam mahābhūta ādayo paccaya hetū  nāma vipāka uppattiyam kusala akusalam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇam ca uttama hetū nāma saṅkhāra ādīnam  avijjā ādayo sādhāraṇa hetū nāma idha pana hetu hetu adhippetaḥ hetū dhammā ti mūla ṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the six dhammas beginning with non-greed are called root-causes. The great primaries, etc., are the causes as conditions for the derived matter, etc.🔽The profitable and unprofitable are the supreme causes for the production of the result. The desirable and undesirable objects are the causes as object. The ignorance, etc., are the general causes for formations, etc.

original: hetusaṅkhātā dhammā, “hetudhammā”tipi pāṭho, soyevattho. Na hetūti tesaññeva paṭikkhepavacanaṃ.
analyzed: hetu saṅkhātāḥ dhammāḥ hetu dhammā ti pi pāṭhaḥ saḥ yeva atthaḥ na hetu iti tesaññeva paṭikkhepa vacanam
translated: But here the root-cause is intended. Dhammas that are causes are dhammas that are roots. The reading is also “hetudhammā” , which has the same meaning. Not causes: this is a term that excludes those same six dhammas.

original: Tattha alobho adoso amohoti kusalābyākatā tayo, lobho doso mohoti akusalā tayo cāti
analyzed: tattha a lobho a doso a moho ti kusalā abyākatā lobho doso moho ti akusalā ca ati
translated: Herein, non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion are the three profitable ones, and greed, hate, and delusion are the three unprofitable ones.

original: ime cha dhammā hetū nāma. Ime ṭhapetvā avasesā cetasikā, sabbāni ca cittāni, rūpanibbānāni
analyzed: ime cha dhammā hetū nāma ime ṭhapetvā avasesā cetasikā sabbāni ca cittāni rūpa nibbānāni
translated: These six dhammas are called root-causes. Apart from these, all the other mental states, all the kinds of consciousness, and materiality and Nibbāna

original: cāti ime dhammā na hetū nāma, idañca nippadesadukanti veditabbaṃ. Hetudukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: ca ati ime dhammā na hetū nāma idam ca nippadesa dukam ti veditabbam hetu dukam paṭhamam
translated: are called dhammas that are not causes. And this should be understood as the dyad without definition. The dyad of causes comes first.

original: Sampayogato pavattena saha hetunāti sahetukā. Tatheva pavatto natthi etesaṃ hetūti ahetukā.🔽Tattha ahetukacittavajjitāni ekasattati cittāni sahetukā nāma. Tesu dve mohamūlāni
analyzed: sampayogataḥ pavattena saha hetunā ati sa hetukā tathā iva pavattaḥ natthi etesam hetu uti ahetukā  tattha ahetuka citta vajjitāni ekasattati cittāni sahetukāḥ nāma tesu dve moha mūlāni
translated: With root-cause means with root-cause-originated. Without root-cause means they have no root-cause at all.

original: moheneva sahetukāni, aṭṭha lobhamūlāni lobhamohehi dvīhi, dve dosamūlāni dosamohehi,
analyzed: mohena iva sa hetukāni aṭṭha lobha mūlāni lobha mohehi dvīhi dve dosa mūlāni dosa mohehi
translated: Herein, the seventy-one kinds of consciousness excluding the root-causeless kinds are called “with root-cause.” Of these, the two kinds with delusion as their root-cause are with root-cause only by delusion. The eight with greed as their root-cause are with root-cause by greed and delusion. The two with hate as their root-cause are with root-cause by hate and delusion.

original: dvādasa ñāṇavippayuttakusalābyākatāni alobhādosehi, sesāni sattacattālīsa alobhādīhi🔽tīhipi sahetukānīti, mohamūlesu pana moho, dvipañcaviññāṇaṃ, manodhātu, santīraṇattayaṃ,
analyzed: dvādasa ñāṇa vippayutta kusala abyākatāni alobha a dosehi sesāni sattacattālīsa alobha ādīhi  sa hetukāni iti moha mūlesu pana mohaḥ dvi pañca viññāṇam manaḥ dhātu
translated: The twelve profitable and indeterminate kinds not associated with knowledge are with root-cause by non-greed and non-hate. The remaining forty-seven are with root-cause by all three, non-greed, etc.

original: voṭṭhabbanaṃ, hasituppādakāni aṭṭhārasa cittāni, rūpanibbānāni cāti ime dhammā ahetukā🔽nāma. Cetasikesu pana lobhadosā, vicikicchā ca moheneva sahetukā, diṭṭhimāno lobhamohehi
analyzed: voṭṭhabbanam hasita uppādakāni aṭṭhārasa cittāni rūpa nibbānāni ca ati ime dhammāḥ ahetukā  nāma cetasikesu pana lobha dosāḥ vicikicchā ca mohena iva sa hetukā diṭṭhi mānaḥ lobha mohehi
translated: But in the case of the kinds with delusion as their root-cause, delusion, the two kinds of five-door adverting, mind element, the three kinds of receiving, the two kinds of investigating, the four kinds of determining, the eighteen kinds of consciousness producing laughter, and materiality and Nibbāna—these states are called “without root-cause.”

original: dvīhi, issāmacchariyakukkuccāni dosamohehi, moho pana siyā lobhena, siyā dosenāti
analyzed: dvīhi issā macchariya kukkuccāni dosa mohehi mohaḥ pana siyā lobhena siyā dosena ati
translated: But as regards the associated states, greed and hate and uncertainty are with root-cause only by delusion. False view and conceit are with root-cause by greed and delusion. Envy, avarice, and worry are with root-cause by hate and delusion. But delusion may be with root-cause by greed or by hate.

original: dvīhi sahetukopi mohamūlesu ahetukopi, thinamiddhāni siyā lobhamohehi, siyā dosamohehīti
analyzed: dvīhi sa hetukaḥ api moha mūlesu ahetukaḥ api thinam iddhāni siyā lobha mohehi siyā dosa mohehi iti
translated: Two are associated with root-causes in the case of the roots of delusion, and one is not associated with root-causes. Sloth-and-torpor may be with greed and delusion, or with hate and delusion.

original: tīhipi sahetukāni, ahirikānottappauddhaccāni tathā ca kevalamohena ca, amoho pana
analyzed: sa hetukāni ahirika no uttappa auddhaccāni tathā ca kevala mohena ca amohaḥ pana
translated: Three are associated with root-causes. Shamelessness, lack of abashment, and agitation are with delusion only. But non-delusion

original: alobhādoseheva dvīhi, alobho siyā adosāmohehi, siyā adosenāti dvīhi, adoso siyā alobhāmohehi,
analyzed: alobha a dosehi iva dvīhi alobhaḥ siyā a dosa a mohehi siyā a dosena ati dvīhi adosaḥ siyā a lobha a mohehi
translated: is with two, with non-greed and non-hate. Non-greed may be with non-hate and non-delusion, or with non-hate. So it is with two. Non-hate may be with non-greed and non-delusion,

original: siyā alobhenāti dvīhi, sesā pana dvāvīsati kusalābyākatā siyā tīhi, siyā dvīhipi
analyzed: siyā alobhena ati dvīhi sesā pana dvāvīsati kusalā abyākatā siyā tīhi siyā dvīhi pi
translated: or with non-greed. So it is with two. But the remaining twenty-two profitable and indeterminate are associated with two or three root-causes.🔽Zeal may be associated with two or three, with joy, gladness, and avoidance of the three roots. The remaining eleven of the third type are associated with six root-causes or not. As regards feeling,

original: hetūhi sahetukā, chando pana yathāyogaṃ tīhi, pītidosavajjitehi pañcahi siyā sahetukāpi
analyzed: hetūhi sa hetukā chandaḥ pana yathāyogam tīhi pīti dosa vajjitehi pañcahi siyā sa hetukā api
translated: sorrow is associated with two only. Happiness and equanimity are associated with five, with avoidance of the three roots and hate and delusion, respectively.

original: ahetukāpi, sesā ekādasa tijātikā chahi hetūhi sahetukāpi ahetukāpi, vedanā cettha
analyzed: ahetukā api sesā ekādasa ti jātikā chahi hetūhi sa hetukā api ahetukā api vedanā ca ittha
translated: They are also not associated. The remaining eleven of the third type are associated with six root-causes or not. As regards feeling,

original: domanassabhūtā dvihetukāva, somanassaupekkhā yathāyogaṃ dosavajjitehi pañcahi sahetukāpi
analyzed: domanassa bhūtā dvi hetukā ava somanassa aupekkhā yathāyogam dosa vajjitehi pañcahi sa hetukā api
translated: sorrow is associated with two only. Happiness and equanimity are associated with five, with avoidance of the three roots and hate and delusion, respectively.

original: ahetukāpi, sukhadukkhabhūtā ahetukāva, idañca nippadesadukanti. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: ahetukā api sukha dukkha bhūtā ahetukā vā idam ca nippadesa dukan ti dutiyam
translated: They are also not associated. Pleasure and pain are not associated. This is the explanation in brief.

original: Ekuppādāditāya hetunā sampayuttāti hetusampayuttā. Hetunā vippayuttāti hetuvippayuttā.
analyzed: ekuppāda āditāya hetunā sampayuttā ati hetu sampayuttā hetunā vippayuttā ati hetu vippayuttā
translated: They are associated with a cause in the sense of having a cause in common, that is, in the sense of having a single prenascence, etc., They are dissociated from a cause in the sense of having no cause in common.

original: Ayaṃ hetusampayuttaduko anantare vuttasahetukadukena atthato ninnānākaraṇo. Sahetukaduko
analyzed: ayam hetu sampayutta dukaḥ anantare vutta sa hetuka dukena atthataḥ ninnānākaraṇaḥ sa hetuka dukaḥ
translated: This dyad of associated with a cause and dissociated from a cause is not differentiated in meaning from the dyad of having a cause and being without cause stated immediately above.

original: eva hi bhagavatā desanāvilāsena, tathā bujjhanakapuggalānaṃ vā ajjhāsayavasena hetusampayuttadukabhāvenāpi
analyzed: eva hi bhagavatā desanā vilāsena tathā bujjhanaka puggalānam vā ajjhāsaya vasena
translated: For that dyad of having a cause and being without cause was stated by the Blessed One as a mere elaboration of the teaching, or else it was stated with reference to the inclination of those susceptible of teaching.🔽So too in the case of the other dyads of the same meaning stated above.

original: vutto. Evaṃ uparipi samānatthadukānaṃ vacane kāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tatiyaṃ.🔽Catutthādayo pana yasmā paṭhamadukadutiyatatiyadukesu paṭhamapadena yojetvā dve dukā,
analyzed: vuttaḥ evam upari pi samāna attha dukānam vacane kāraṇam veditabbam tatiyam  catuttha ādayaḥ pana yasmā paṭhama duka dutiya tatiya dukesu paṭhama padena yojetvā dve dukā
translated: But the third dyad, etc., are taught by combining the first term of the first dyad, the second term of the second dyad, and the first term of the third dyad, to make one dyad;🔽and by combining the second term of the first dyad with the second dyad, to make a second dyad;

original: paṭhamaduke ca pacchimapadaṃ dutiyadukena yojetvā ekaṃ dukanti tayo dukā desitā,
analyzed: paṭhama duke ca pacchima padam dutiya dukena yojetvā ekam tayaḥ dukāḥ desitā
translated: and by combining the second term of the third dyad with the third dyad, to make a third dyad.

original: tasmā tesaṃ padattho vuttanayova.
analyzed: tasmā tesam padatthaḥ vutta nayaḥ va
translated: So the meaning of the terms here is the same as the meaning stated above.

original: Tattha ca yatheva “hetū ceva dhammā sahetukā ca, sahetukā ceva dhammā na ca hetū”ti
analyzed: tattha ca yathā iva hetū ca iva dhammā sa hetukā ca sa hetukā ca iva dhammā na ca hetu uti
translated: Herein, “states that are causes and are also related to causes” are states that have a cause in common, that is, that have a single prenascence, etc.; “states that are related to causes but are not causes” are states that are associated with a cause.

original: ayaṃ duko sambhavati, tathā “hetū ceva dhammā ahetukā ca, ahetukā ceva dhammā na
analyzed: ayam sambhavati tathā hetū ca iva dhammā ahetukā ca ahetukā ca iva dhammā na
translated: This dyad is possible, so too: “States that are causes and states that are not causes, states that are not causes and states that are causes, states that are causes and states that are not causes and states that are neither causes nor not causes.”🔽

original: ca hetū”ti ayampi sambhavati. Iminā nayena hetusampayuttadukena yojanāyapi eko labbhati.
analyzed: ca ayam pi sambhavati iminā nayena ekaḥ labbhati
translated: This dyad is possible. So too this is possible: “Ideas that are causes and those that are not causes, and those that are not causes and those that are not causes” . By this method one is possible in the case of the dyad “concomitant with a cause” .

original: Yathā ca “na hetū kho pana dhammā sahetukāpi, ahetukāpī”ti ayaṃ labbhati, tathā “hetū🔽kho pana dhammā sahetukāpi, ahetukāpī”ti ayampi. Yathā cettha sahetukaduke dve dukā,🔽evaṃ hetusampayuttadukepi “na hetū kho pana dhammā hetusampayuttāpi, hetuvippayuttāpī”ti
analyzed: yathā ca na hetū kho pana dhammā sa hetukā api ahetukā api iti ayam labbhati tathā hetū  kho pana dhammā sa hetukā api ahetukā api iti ayam pi yathā ca ittha sa hetuka duke dve dukā  evam hetu sampayutta duke pi na hetū kho pana dhammā hetu sampayuttā api hetu vippayuttā api iti
translated: And just as this is possible: “Ideas that are not causes are nevertheless associated with a cause and dissociated from a cause” , so too this is possible: “Ideas that are causes are nevertheless associated with a cause and dissociated from a cause” .🔽And just as there are two dyads in the dyad “associated with a cause” ,

original: ca “hetū kho pana dhammā hetusampayuttāpi, hetuvippayuttāpī”ti ca dve dukā labbhantīti
analyzed: ca hetū kho pana dhammā hetu sampayuttā api hetu vippayuttā api iti ca dve dukā labbhanti iti
translated: so too in the case of the dyad “concomitant with a cause” there are two dyads, namely “Ideas that are not causes are nevertheless concomitant with a cause and not concomitant with a cause” and “Ideas that are causes are nevertheless concomitant with a cause and not concomitant with a cause” .

original: aparepi pañca dukā hetugocchake yojetuṃ sakkā. Te pana bhagavatā vuttānusāreneva
analyzed: apare pi pañca dukāḥ hetu gocchake yojetum sakkā te pana bhagavatā vutta anusārena iva
translated: Others say that five more dyads can be yoked to the “with cause” group. But they can be known only by one who follows the Blessed One’s word,

original: sakkā ñātunti chasu eva saṅgahitāti veditabbā. Tattha ye tāva ekasmiṃ citte dve tayo
analyzed: sakkā ñātunti chasu eva saṅgahitā iti veditabbā tattha ye tāva ekasmim citte dve tayo
translated: so they should be understood to be included in the six only. Herein, firstly, as regards the dyads “with a condition” and “with nutriment” , there are two dyads in each case, namely “Ideas that are conditions and those that are not conditions, and those that are not conditions and those that are not conditions” and “Ideas that are nutriment and those that are not nutriment, and those that are not nutriment and those that are not nutriment” .

original: hetū ekato uppajjanti, te hetū ceva aññoññāpekkhāya sahetukā ca nāma. Sahetukacittesu
analyzed: hetū ekatas uppajjanti te hetū ca iva aññoññāpekkhāya sa hetukā ca nāma sa hetuka cittesu
translated: Arisen together with causes are called causes and also related to causes, since those causes are mutually dependent.

original: pana hetuṃ ṭhapetvā sesā cittacetasikā dhammā sahetukā ceva na ca hetū nāma. Imasmiṃ🔽duke sabbe ahetukadhammā na vattabbā. Cetasikesu pana hetuvajjitā akusalā ceva kusalābyākatā🔽ca, chando ca sahetuko ceva na hetu eva, sesā tijātikā, tathā navattabbā ca, moho
analyzed: pana hetum ṭhapetvā sesā citta cetasikā dhammā sa hetukā ca iva na ca hetū nāma imasmin  duke sabbe ahetuka dhammā na vattabbā cetasikesu pana hetu vajjitā akusalā ca iva kusalā abyākatā  ca chando ca sa hetukaḥ ca iva na hetu eva sesā ti jātikā tathā na vattabbā ca moho
translated: But in the case of consciousness accompanied by cause, the states of consciousness and its concomitants, leaving out the cause, are called related to causes but not causes.

original: pana hetu ceva sahetuko ca navattabbo ca. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: pana hetu ca iva sa hetuko ca na vattabbo ca catuttham
translated: In this dyad all states without cause are not to be spoken of. But among the concomitants, the unprofitable and the profitable and indeterminate, leaving out the cause, are related to causes but not causes. And will is related to causes but not a cause. The rest are of three kinds. So too, they are not to be spoken of. But delusion is a cause and related to causes and not to be spoken of. Fourth dyad.

original: Anantaradukopi iminā dukena sabbathāpi sadisovāti. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: anantara dukā upi iminā dukena sabbathā api sadisā uvāti pañcamam
translated: The next dyad is similar in every way to this one. Fifth dyad.

original: Sahetukacittesu hetuvajjitā cittacetasikā dhammā nahetū sahetū nāma, ahetukacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: sa hetuka cittesu hetu vajjitāḥ citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ na hetū sa hetū nāma ahetuka citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: In the case of consciousness accompanied by cause, the states of consciousness and its concomitants, leaving out the cause, are called not causes but related to causes. And the immaterial aggregates, materiality, and Nibbāna,

original: nahetū ahetukā nāma. Imasmiṃ pana duke cha hetū na vattabbā. Sesaṃ suviññeyyamevāti. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: na hetū ahetukāḥ nāma imasmim pana duke cha hetū na vattabbā sesam su viññeyyam eva ati chaṭṭham
translated: leaving out the causes, are not causes and not related to causes. But in this dyad the six causes are not to be spoken of. The rest is quite clear. Sixth dyad.

original: Hetugocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: hetu gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The set of dyads based on cause is finished.

original: Sattasu cūḷantaradukesu attano nipphādakena saha paccayenāti sappaccayā, cittacetasikarūpāni.
analyzed: sattasu cūḷantara dukesu attanaḥ nipphādakena saha paccayena ati sappaccayā citta cetasika rūpāni
translated: In the seven dyads beginning with “with object” there are those with objects, namely, the kinds of materiality originated by kamma and temperature, and the states of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: Natthi etesaṃ uppāde vā ṭhitiyaṃ vā paccayo ahutvā bhavanassevābhāvāti appaccayā,
analyzed: natthi etesam uppāde vā ṭhitiyam vā paccayaḥ a hutvā bhavanassa iva abhāvā ati appaccayā
translated: There are those without objects, namely, the kinds of materiality not originated by kamma or temperature, and Nibbāna.

original: nibbānameva. Desanāya panettha paramatāya sotapatitavasena bahuvacananiddeso kato.
analyzed: nibbānam eva desanāya pana ittha parama tāya sota patita vasena bahuvacana niddeso kato
translated: But in the teaching here the plural is used because of the plurality of the objects of the states of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: Evaṃ sanidassanādīsupi. Idañca ito parāni cha ca nippadesadukānīti veditabbāni. Tato
analyzed: evam sani dassana ādīsu pi idam ca i taḥ parāni cha ca nippadesa dukāni iti veditabbāni tatas
translated: So too with the “visible” dyad, and so on. And the next six dyads should be understood in the same way as the “with object” dyad.

original: parañca yattha “ime na vattabbā”ti na vakkhāma, taṃ nippadesanti gahetabbaṃ. Sappaccayadukaṃ.
analyzed: param ca yattha ime na vattabbā ati na vakkhāma tam nippadesam ti gahetabbam sa paccaya dukam
translated: And what is not mentioned as “these” in the following dyads should be taken as “that” . The “with object” dyad.

original: Paccayehi samāgantvā katāti saṅkhatā. Na saṅkhatāti asaṅkhatā. Idañca sabbathā sappaccayadukasadisameva. Sappaccayasaṅkhataubhayadukaṃ sabbathā sadisameva. Saṅkhatadukaṃ.
analyzed: paccayehi samāgantvā katā ati saṅkhatā na saṅkhatā ati asaṅkhatā idam ca sabbathā sappaccaya duka sadisam eva sappaccaya saṅkhata ubhaya dukam sabbathā sadisam eva saṅkhata dukam
translated: “Conditioned” is that which is made by conditions coming together. “Unconditioned” is that which is not so. And this dyad is entirely similar to the “with object” dyad. The “conditioned” dyad is entirely similar to the “with object” and “conditioned” dyads.

original: Rūpāyatanaṃ sanidassanaṃ nāma. Sesarūpacittacetasikanibbānāni anidassanā nāma. Sanidassanadukaṃ.🔽Pasādavisayarūpāni dvādasa sappaṭighā nāma. Sesarūpacittacetasikanibbānāni appaṭighā nāma. Sappaṭighadukaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa āyatanam sa nidassanam nāma sesa rūpa citta cetasika nibbānāni anidassanāḥ nāma sa nidassana dukam  pasāda visaya rūpāni dvādasa sappaṭighāḥ nāma sesa rūpa citta cetasika nibbānāni appaṭighāḥ nāma sa paṭigha dukam
translated: The visible-data base is called “with-object.” The rest of the materiality, consciousness, and Nibbāna are called “without-object.” This is the dyad “with-object, without-object.”🔽The twelve kinds of sensitive materiality are called “with impingement.” The rest of the materiality, consciousness, and Nibbāna are called “without impingement.” This is the dyad “with impingement, without impingement.”

original: Avinibbhogavasena rūpaṃ etesaṃ atthīti rūpino, ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ vā rūpaṃ, taṃ etesaṃ atthīti rūpino, bhūtopādāyarūpameva. Na rūpino arūpino, cittacetasikanibbānāni. Rūpidukaṃ.
analyzed: avinibbhoga vasena rūpam etesam atthi iti rūpino ruppana lakkhaṇam vā rūpam tam etesam atthi iti rūpinaḥ bhūta upādāya rūpam eva na rūpinaḥ arūpinaḥ citta cetasika nibbānāni rūpi dukam
translated: Materiality exists in the sense of not being separable from them, or materiality has the characteristic of being molested , and that exists in them, thus they are “material” . The immaterial is consciousness, the mental factors, and Nibbāna. This is the dyad “material, immaterial.”

original: Loko vuccati lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena vaṭṭaṃ, tasmiṃ pariyāpannabhāvena loke niyuttāti
analyzed: lokaḥ vuccati lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena vaṭṭam tasmin pariyāpanna bhāvena loke niyuttā ati
translated: The world is called “that which is broken up” in the sense of being broken up and scattered. They are “in the world” in the sense of being included in the world.

original: lokiyā, pañcupādānakkhandhā. Tato lokato tattha apariyāpannabhāvena uttiṇṇāti lokuttarā,
analyzed: lokiyā pañca upādānakkhandhā tatas lokataḥ tattha a pariyāpanna bhāvena uttiṇṇā ati lokuttarā
translated: They are “worldly” . They are “not in the world” in the sense of not being included there.

original: ariyamaggaphalanibbānāni. Cetasikesu panettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ asekhattike vuttanayena
analyzed: ariya magga phala nibbānāni cetasikesu pana ittha yat vattabbam tat asekhattike vutta nayena
translated: They are “supermundane” . But here, in the case of the mental factors, what is to be said has been said in the case of the “in training” , etc.,

original: veditabbaṃ. Lokiyadukaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam lokiya dukam
translated: This is the dyad “worldly, supermundane.”

original: Kenaci viññeyyāti cakkhuviññāṇādīsu kenaci ekena cakkhuviññāṇena vā sotaviññāṇādinā
analyzed: kenaci viññeyyā ti cakkhu viññāṇa ādīsu kenaci ekena cakkhu viññāṇena vā sota viññāṇa ādinā
translated: ‘By some as cognizable’: cognizable by some one of the six consciousnesses beginning with eye-consciousness.

original: vā vijānitabbā. Kenaci na viññeyyāti teneva cakkhuviññāṇena vā sotaviññāṇādinā vā
analyzed: vā vijānitabbā kenacid na viññeyyā ati tena iva cakkhu viññāṇena vā sota viññāṇa ādinā vā
translated: ‘By some as not cognizable’: not cognizable by that same eye-consciousness, etc.

original: na kenaci vijānitabbāni. Evaṃ hi sati dvinnampi padānaṃ atthanānattato duko hoti.
analyzed: na kenacid vijānitabbāni evam hi sati dvinnam pi padānam attha nānattataḥ dukaḥ hoti
translated: When this is so, then the two terms have a difference of meaning, and so they make a dyad.🔽In the analysis of the terms too, the following is given as the first dyad:

original: Padabhājanīyasmimpi “ye te dhammā cakkhuviññeyyā, na te dhammā sotaviññeyyā”ti ettakaṃ🔽ekadukanti aggahetvā “ye te dhammā cakkhuviññeyyā, na te dhammā sotaviññeyyā, ye
analyzed: pada bhājanīyasmim pi ye te dhammā cakkhu viññeyyā na te dhammā sota viññeyyā ati ettakam  eka dukanti aggahetvā ye te dhammā cakkhu viññeyyāḥ na te dhammā sota viññeyyāḥ ye
translated: ‘Ideas cognizable by the eye are not ideas cognizable by the ear’🔽without taking the first term ‘Ideas cognizable by the eye’ and the second term ‘Ideas cognizable by the ear’ separately.

original: vā pana te dhammā sotaviññeyyā, na te dhammā cakkhuviññeyyā”ti ayameko dukoti veditabbo.🔽Tassa pana rūpaṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ, saddo na cakkhuviññeyyoti ayamattho. Evaṃ sesesupi
analyzed: vā pana te dhammā sota viññeyyā na te dhammā cakkhu viññeyyā ti ayam ekaḥ duko ti veditabbo  tassa pana rūpam cakkhu viññeyyam saddo na cakkhu viññeyyaḥ ti ayam attho evam sesesu pi
translated: But it should be understood that the dyad is this: ‘Ideas cognizable by the eye are not ideas cognizable by the ear, or ideas cognizable by the ear are not ideas cognizable by the eye.’

original: dukaparicchedo ñātabbo. Tattha rūpāyatanaṃ cakkhunā vā cakkhuviññāṇena vā viññeyyaṃ
analyzed: duka paricchedaḥ ñātabbo tattha rūpa āyatanam cakkhunā vā cakkhu viññāṇena vā viññeyyam
translated: And the meaning of that is this: visible data are cognizable by the eye or by eye-consciousness,🔽but sound is not cognizable by the eye.

original: nāma. Sesarūpārūpadhammā teneva cakkhunā vā cakkhuviññāṇena vā kenaci naviññeyyā.
analyzed: nāma sesa rūpa arūpa dhammā tena iva cakkhunā vā cakkhu viññāṇena vā kenacid na viññeyyā
translated: The rest of the material and immaterial dhammas are not to be known by that eye or by that eye-consciousness.

original: Evaṃ sotaghānajivhākāyatabbiññāṇamūlikāsupi catūsu yojanāsu vibhāgo yathānurūpaṃ
analyzed: evam sota ghāna jivhā kāya tap biññāṇa mūlikāsu pi catūsu yojanāsu vibhāgaḥ yathānurūpam
translated: So too with the ear, nose, tongue, body, and the three kinds of direct-knowledge as the starting point. The analysis should be understood according to the appropriate differences in each case.

original: ñātabbo. Rūpādayo pana pañcavisayā manodhātuttayena kenaci viññeyyā. Sesarūpārūpadhammā🔽teneva manodhātuttayena kenaci naviññeyyā. Kiñcāpi sāmaññato manoviññāṇena aviññeyyassa
analyzed: ñātabbaḥ rūpa ādayaḥ pana pañca visayāḥ manaḥ dhātu ttayena kenaci viññeyyā sesa rūpa arūpa dhammā  tena iva manaḥ dhātu ttayena kenaci na viññeyyā kiñca api sāmaññataḥ manaḥ viññāṇena a viññeyyassa
translated: But the five objects beginning with visible forms are to be known by the three kinds of mind element. The rest of the material and immaterial dhammas🔽are not to be known by that same triad of mind elements. And although there is no such thing as something that is not to be known by mind-consciousness in the sense of the general kind,

original: abhāvato pāḷiyaṃ manoviññāṇaviññeyyavasena duko na vutto, tathāpi visesato vattabbova.🔽Tathā hi chabbidhāpi kāmāvacaradhammā kāmāvacaravipākādinā manoviññāṇena kenaci viññeyyā,
analyzed: abhāvataḥ pāḷiyam manaḥ viññāṇa viññeyya vasena dukaḥ na vutto tathā api visesataḥ vattabbaḥ eva  tathā hi chabbidhā api kāmāvacara dhammā kāmāvacara vipāka ādinā manaḥ viññāṇena kenaci viññeyyā
translated: nevertheless the dyad is stated in the text as “cognizable by mind-consciousness” in order to show the particular kinds.🔽For thus: the six kinds of sense-desire element are to be known by the sense-desire-element resultant mind-consciousness, etc.;

original: rūpārūpāvacaralokuttarapaññattiyo teneva kenaci naviññeyyā. Tathā kāmarūpārūpāvacarapaññattiyo
analyzed: rūpa arūpāvacara lokuttara paññattiyo tena iva kenacid na viññeyyā tathā kāmarūpa arūpāvacara paññattiyo
translated: the description of the fine-material, immaterial, and supramundane dhammas is not to be known by that same mind-consciousness. So too: the description of the sense-desire and fine-material dhammas🔽is

original: akusalādinā kenaci viññeyyā, lokuttarā teneva kenaci naviññeyyā. Tathā nibbānaṃ lokuttarena🔽kenaci viññeyyaṃ, sesalokiyalokuttarā teneva kenaci naviññeyyāti iminā nayena rūpārūpāvacarādibhedena🔽manoviññāṇena kenaci viññeyyāviññeyyadhammā yathāyogaṃ yojetabbā. Evaṃ sabbe dhammā🔽kenaci viññeyyā, kenaci na viññeyyā nāma. Imasmiñca duke paññattiyopi labbhantīti
analyzed: akusala ādinā kenaci viññeyyā lokuttarā tena iva kenaci na viññeyyā tathā nibbānam lokuttarena  kenaci viññeyyam sesa lokiya lokuttarā tena iva kenaci na viññeyyā ati iminā nayena rūpa arūpa avacara ādi bhedena  manaḥ viññāṇena kenacid viññeyya aviññeyya dhammāḥ yathāyogam yojetabbāḥ evam sabbe dhammāḥ  kenacid viññeyyā kenacid na viññeyyā nāma imasmin ca duke paññattiyaḥ api labbhanti iti
translated: and the supramundane is cognizable by that same kind of consciousness but not by any other kind. So too, Nibbāna is cognizable by the supramundane kind of consciousness but not by any other kind. The rest, which are mundane, are cognizable by that same kind of consciousness but not by any other kind. So too, the kinds of consciousness and its concomitants belonging to the fine-material and immaterial spheres are cognizable by the corresponding kinds of consciousness but not by any other kinds. Thus the states cognizable and not cognizable by the mind-consciousness element should be construed in the appropriate way. So all states are cognizable by some kind of consciousness or other, and not cognizable by some kind of consciousness or other. And in this dyad the terms are applicable by definition.🔽🔽

original: veditabbāti. Kenaciviññeyyadukaṃ.🔽Cūḷantaradukā niṭṭhitā.🔽Āsavagocchake āsamantato savantīti āsavā, cakkhutopi…pe… manatopi savanti, pavattantīti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Dhammato yāvagotrabhuṃ, okāsato yāvabhavaggā savantīti vā āsavā, ete
analyzed: veditabbā iti  cūḷantaradukā niṭṭhitā  āsava gocchake manataḥ pi savanti pavattanti iti  vuttam hoti dhammataḥ okāsataḥ savanti iti vai āsavāḥ ete
translated: They are cognizable by the unprofitable, etc., but not by the supramundane. The supramundane is cognizable by the supramundane, but not by the mundane. So too, Nibbāna is cognizable by the supramundane, but not by the mundane. The rest are cognizable by the mundane and supramundane. In this way, the states classed as “cognizable by the mind” and “not cognizable by the mind” should be construed according to the kinds of consciousness classed as “cognizable by the mind” and “not cognizable by the mind” respectively. So all states are cognizable by some kind of consciousness or other, and not cognizable by some kind of consciousness or other. And in this dyad the terms are applicable by individual characteristic too. This is how the exposition should be known here. This is the dyad on what is cognizable by some kind of consciousness or other. The short dyads are completed.

original: dhamme, etañca okāsaṃ antokaritvā pavattantīti attho. Antokaraṇattho hi ayaṃ ā-kāro.
analyzed: dhamme etañca okāsam antokaritvā pavattanti iti atthaḥ antokaraṇa atthaḥ hi ayam ākāro
translated: In the dyads on the effluents, the effluents flow all round , thus they are effluents . They flow from the eye, from the ear, from the nose, from the tongue, from the body, and from the mind, thus they are called effluents. The meaning is that they flow from the eye, etc., and from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and they flow from the mind and from the states belonging to the mind. Or alternatively, they flow all round the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, thus they are effluents. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, and they flow from the eye, etc., and from the mind. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, and they flow from the eye, etc., and from the mind. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, and they flow from the eye, etc., and from the mind. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, and they flow from the eye, etc., and from the mind. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc., and to the mind, and they flow from the eye, etc., and from the mind. The meaning is that they flow from the states belonging to the eye, etc.,

original: Cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena madirādiāsavā viyātipi āsavā. Yadi ca cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena āsavā,
analyzed: cira pārivāsiya ṭṭhena madirā ādi āsavāḥ āsavāḥ yadi ca cira pārivāsiya ṭṭhena āsavā
translated: And if they are corruptions in the sense of being long in taking effect,🔽then only these can be so.

original: ete eva bhavituṃ arahanti. Anādittā āyataṃ vā saṃsāradukkhaṃ savanti pasavantītipi
analyzed: ete eva bhavitum arahanti an ādittāḥ āyatam vā saṃsāra dukkham savanti pasavanti iti pi
translated: And they are “corruptions” in the sense of flowing out and trickling out the suffering of the round of rebirths that has not been burnt up.

original: āsavā. Tato aññe no āsavā nāma.
analyzed: āsavā tatas aññe no āsavā nāma
translated: Apart from these there are none called “corruptions.”

original: Tattha kāmāsavo bhavāsavo diṭṭhāsavo avijjāsavoti ime cattāro āsavā nāma. Tattha
analyzed: tattha kāma āsavaḥ bhava āsavaḥ diṭṭha āsavaḥ avijja āsavaḥ ti ime cattāro āsavāḥ nāma tattha
translated: Herein, the four corruptions are the corruption of sensual desire, the corruption of being, the corruption of view, and the corruption of ignorance.

original: aṭṭhasu lobhasahagatacittesu uppanno sabbopi lobho kāmāsavo nāma. Aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhasu lobha sahagata cittesu uppannaḥ sabbaḥ api lobho kāmāsavaḥ nāma aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: Herein, all greed occurring in the eight kinds of consciousness associated with greed is called the corruption of sensual desire.🔽But in the Eight-Factored Discourse it is said thus: “Lust for the five strands of sensual desire is the corruption of sensual desire” ,

original: pana “pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgo kāmāsavo”ti ca, “diṭṭhisahajāto rāgo kāmāsavo na hoti,🔽diṭṭhirāgo nāma hotī”ti ca, “yo brahmānaṃ vimānakapparukkhābharaṇesu chandarāgo uppajjati,
analyzed: pana pañca kāmaguṇiko rāgo kāma āsavo ti ca diṭṭhi sahajātaḥ rāgo kāma āsavo na hoti  diṭṭhi rāgaḥ nāma hoti iti ca yaḥ brahmānam vimāna kappa rukkha ābharaṇesu chanda rāgaḥ uppajjati
translated: and thus: “Lust associated with false view is not the corruption of sensual desire;🔽it is called lust of view” ,

original: so kāmāsavo na hoti pañcakāmaguṇikassa rāgassa idheva pahīnattā”ti ca vuttaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: so kāma āsavaḥ na hoti pañca kāmaguṇikassa rāgassa idha iva pahīna ttā ti ca vuttam pāḷiyam
translated: and thus: “The lust that arises in regard to the divine mansions, the wish-fulfilling tree, and the adornments of the Brahmās is not the corruption of sensual desire, because lust for the five strands of sensual desire has already been abandoned here” .🔽In the texts it is said thus:

original: pana “kāmāsavo aṭṭhasu lobhasahagatesu cittuppādesu uppajjatī”ti ca, “kāmāsavaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: pana kāma āsavaḥ aṭṭhasu lobha sahagatesu cittuppādesu uppajjati iti ca kāma āsavam paṭicca
translated: but “the taint of sensual desire arises in the eight types of consciousness accompanied by joy” and “the taint of sensual desire is a condition, as condition consisting in decisive support, for the five aggregates affected by clinging” .

original: diṭṭhāsavo avijjāsavo”ti ca vuttattā bhavāsavaṃ ṭhapetvā avaseso sabbopi lobho kāmāsavoti
analyzed: diṭṭha āsavaḥ avijja āsavaḥ ti ca vutta ttā bhava āsavam ṭhapetvā avasesaḥ sabbaḥ api lobho kāma āsavaḥ ti
translated: But since it is said, “The taint of sensual desire arises in the eight types of consciousness accompanied by joy,” and “With the taint of sensual desire as condition there arise the taint of views and the taint of ignorance,” it is evident that all greed except the taint of existence is the taint of sensual desire.🔽For the lust associated with views and the lust for the divine abodes, etc., are not the taint of existence.

original: paññāyati diṭṭhisampayuttarāgassa, brahmānaṃ vatthābharaṇādīsu rāgassa ca bhavāsavattābhāvā.
analyzed: paññāyati diṭṭhi sampayutta rāgassa brahmānam vattha ābharaṇa ādīsu rāgassa ca bhava āsava tā abhāvā
translated: For lust associated with views is the taint of views, and the lust for the divine abodes, etc., is the taint of existence.

original: Diṭṭhivippayuttarāgo eva hi rūpārūpabhavapatthanāvasena pavattiyaṃ bhavāsavo hoti
analyzed: diṭṭhi vippayutta rāgaḥ eva hi rūpa arūpa bhava patthanā vasena pavattiyam bhava āsavaḥ hoti
translated: Lust unassociated with views is the taint of existence in the occurrence of the aspiration for the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming.🔽For it is said: “In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas there underlies the underlying tendency to lust for existence” .

original: “rūpadhātuyā arūpadhātuyā ettha bhavarāgānusayo anusetī”tiādivacanato, na ca kāmāsavabhavāsavavinimutto
analyzed: rūpa dhātuyāḥ a rūpa dhātuyāḥ ettha bhava rāga anusayaḥ anuseti iti ādi vacanataḥ na ca kāma āsava bhava āsava vinimuttaḥ
translated: And there is no greed that is not included in the taints of sensual desire and of existence.

original: lobho atthi. Yadi siyā, “lobho siyā āsavo, siyā no āsavo”ti pāḷiyaṃ vattabbo bhaveyya,
analyzed: lobhaḥ atthi yadi siyā lobho siyā āsavaḥ siyā no āsavaḥ ti pāḷiyam vattabbo bhaveyya
translated: If there were, it would have to be mentioned in the texts in the way beginning, “Greed is a taint, or it is not a taint” .

original: “diṭṭhivippayuttalobhena sampayutto avijjāsavo siyā āsavasampayutto, siyā āsavavippayutto”ti
analyzed: diṭṭhi vippayutta lobhena sampayuttaḥ avijjā āsavaḥ siyā āsava sampayutto siyā āsava vippayutto ti
translated: And it is said: “Lust unassociated with views is associated with the taint of ignorance, or it is not associated with the taint of ignorance” .

original: ca vattabbo siyā. Padabhājanīye ca kāmāsavaniddese āgatassa “kāmesu kāmacchando”ti
analyzed: ca vattabbaḥ siyā pada bhājanīye ca kāma āsava niddese āgatassa kāmesu kāmacchandaḥ ti
translated: and it could be said of it. And in the exposition of the taint of sensual desire in the “Explanation of the Terms” in the Paṭṭhāna, the meaning of the term “desire for sensual desires” is given in the Aṭṭhasālinī as “desire for the five strands of sensual desire.”

original: imassa padassa aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ “pañcakāmaguṇesu kāmacchando”ti attho vutto, tassa🔽pana padassa vatthukāmesu kilesakāmotipi atthayojanā sakkā kātuṃ tebhumakassa dhammassa
analyzed: imassa padassa aṭṭhasāliniyam pañca kāmaguṇesu kāmacchando ti attho vutto tassa  pana padassa vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmaḥ ti pi attha yojanā sakkā kātum tebhumakassa dhammassa
translated: But it is possible to interpret the meaning of that term as “the defilement of sensual desire in the objects of sensual desire,”
