translated: Any pride that arises in the three modes already described is called the fetter of conceit. Herein, pride occurs in three modes in a person who is superior thus: “I am superior,” “I am equal,” “I am inferior.” And so it is with one who is equal and one who is inferior. Herein, the pride in one who is superior that he is superior is pride in one who is as he should be.

original: Tathā sadisassa sadisamāno, hīnassa hīnamāno ca. Tiṇṇampi itare dve dve mānā ayāthāvamānāti ñātabbā.🔽Satthudhammasaṅghasikkhāsu, pubbantāparantatadubhayapaṭiccasamuppannesu ca kaṅkhatāvasena pavattā sabbāpi vicikicchā vicikicchāsaṃyojanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: tathā sadisassa sadisa mānaḥ hīnassa hīna mānaḥ ca tiṇṇam pi itare dve dve mānā ñātabbā  satthu dhamma saṅgha sikkhāsu pubbanta aparanta tad ubhaya paṭicca samuppannesu ca kaṅkha tā vasena pavattā sabbā api vicikicchā vicikicchā saṃyojanam nāma
translated: So too, the pride in one who is equal that he is equal is pride in one who is as he should be. And the pride in one who is inferior that he is inferior is pride in one who is as he should be. But the other two kinds of pride in each of the three should be understood as improper pride.🔽Any doubt that occurs in the way already stated is called the fetter of doubt.

original: Gosīlagovatādīhi suddhīti gahaṇākārappavattā diṭṭhi eva sīlabbataparāmāsasaṃyojanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: gosīla govata ādīhi suddhi iti gahaṇa ākāra ppavattā diṭṭhi eva sīlabbata parāmāsa saṃyojanam nāma
translated: The view that there is purification in such things as the cow, the bull, the python, etc., and the way of entry into a womb, is called the fetter of adherence to rules and vows.

original: Tadavasesā diṭṭhi diṭṭhisaṃyojananti gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tad avasesā diṭṭhi diṭṭhi saṃyojanan ti gahetabbam
translated: The rest of the views should be taken as the fetter of views.

original: Paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanādīsu asahanākārena pavattā issā issāsaṃyojanaṃ
analyzed: para lābha sakkāra garukāra mānana vandana pūjana ādīsu asahanā ākārena pavattā issā issā saṃyojanam
translated: The resentment that occurs in the mode of not being able to bear the gain, honour, respect, reverence, salutations, and worship given to another is called the fetter of resentment.

original: nāma. Āvāsamacchariyaṃ kulalābhavaṇṇadhammamacchariyanti pañcavidhaṃ macchariyaṃ🔽macchariyasaṃyojanaṃ nāma. Sakalārāmepi hi pariveṇovarakādīsu vā vasanto tattha aññassa🔽vattasampannassa pesalassa bhikkhuno āgamanaṃ na icchati, āgatassāpi khippaṃ gamanaññeva
analyzed: nāma āvāsa macchariyam kula lābha vaṇṇa dhamma macchariyanti pañcavidham macchariyam  macchariya saṃyojanam nāma sakala ārāme pi hi pariveṇa uvaraka ādīsu vā vasanto tattha aññassa  vatta sampannassa pesalassa bhikkhuno āgamanam na icchati āgatassa api khippam
translated: The five kinds of stinginess, namely, stinginess regarding dwellings, stinginess regarding families, stinginess regarding gains, stinginess regarding Dhamma, and stinginess regarding honours,🔽are called the fetter of stinginess. For one who lives in a monastery, a pavilion, a hut, etc., does not want another virtuous and competent bhikkhu to come there;

original: icchati, idaṃ āvāsamacchariyaṃ nāma. Bhaṇḍanakārakādīnaṃ pana tattha vāsaṃ anicchato🔽āvāsamacchariyaṃ nāma na hoti.🔽Attano pana upaṭṭhākakule vā ñātikule vā aññassa pesalassa upasaṅkamanaṃ anicchato
analyzed: icchati idam āvāsamacchariyam nāma bhaṇḍana kāraka ādīnam pana tattha vāsam an icchato  nāma na hoti  attanaḥ pana upaṭṭhāka kule vā ñāti kule vā aññassa pesalassa upasaṅkamanam an icchato
translated: and when the other comes, he wants him to go away quickly. This is called stinginess regarding dwellings. But one who does not want quarrelsome bhikkhus, etc., to live there does not have stinginess regarding dwellings.

original: kulamacchariyaṃ hoti, pāpapuggalassa anicchato pana na hoti. So hi tesaṃ pasādabhedāya paṭipajjatīti.
analyzed: kula macchariyam hoti pāpa puggalassa an icchataḥ pana na hoti saḥ hi tesam pasāda bhedāya paṭipajjati iti
translated: But one who does not want another virtuous bhikkhu to visit the family that supports him or a relation’s family has stinginess regarding families. But one who does not want a wicked person to visit them does not have stinginess regarding families. For the latter tries to create confidence in them in order to break their confidence in the former.

original: Attanā labhanaṭṭhāne catupaccayaṃ labhante sīlavante disvā “mā labhantū”ti cintentassa
analyzed: attanā labhana ṭṭhāne catu paccayam labhante sīlavante disvā mā labhantu uti cintentassa
translated: When one who is himself in a position to get the four requisites thinks, “Let them not get them” when he sees virtuous bhikkhus getting them,

original: lābhamacchariyaṃ hoti. Yo pana saddhādeyyaṃ vinipāteti, pūtibhāvampi gacchantaṃ aññassa
analyzed: lābha macchariyam hoti yaḥ pana saddhā deyyam vinipāteti pūti bhāvam pi gacchantam aññassa
translated: this is called stinginess about requisites. But when one who misappropriates requisites given in faith does not give to another what has become rotten and spoiled,

original: na deti, taṃ labhantaṃ disvā “sace imaṃ añño sīlavā labheyya, paribhogaṃ gaccheyyā”ti
analyzed: na deti tam labhantam disvā sace imam añño sīlavā labheyya paribhogam gaccheyya ati
translated: and when he thinks, “If another virtuous man were to get this, it would be used,”

original: cintentassa macchariyaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: cintentassa mad śariyam nāma natthi
translated: there is no stinginess in him.

original: Vaṇṇo nāma attanā sadiso sarīravaṇṇopi guṇavaṇṇopi. Tattha “rūpavā pāsādiko”ti parassa🔽sarīravaṇṇaṃ, “sīlavā, dhutavā”tiādinā guṇavaṇṇañca attano vaṇṇabhaṇanaṭṭhāne vuccamānaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ nāma attanā sadisaḥ sarīra vaṇṇaḥ api guṇa vaṇṇaḥ api tattha rūpavā pāsādikaḥ ti parassa  sarīra vaṇṇam sīlavā dhuta vāti ādinā guṇa vaṇṇam ca attanaḥ vaṇṇa bhaṇana ṭhāne vuccamānam
translated: “Beauty” is either bodily beauty or the beauty of good qualities. Herein, when someone says, “He is handsome and good-looking,” he is referring to bodily beauty.

original: asahantassa duvidhaṃ vaṇṇamacchariyaṃ nāma hoti, apesalaṃ pana vipannaṃ pasaṃsitvā
analyzed: asahantassa duvidham vaṇṇam acchariyam nāma hoti apesalam pana vipannam pasaṃsitvā
translated: When he says, “He is virtuous, he has good qualities,” he is referring to the beauty of good qualities. When someone cannot bear to hear himself spoken of in terms of either of these two kinds of beauty,

original: parisāsu upatthambhentaṃ disvā pāpagarahitāya asahantassa na hoti.
analyzed: parisāsu upatthambhentam disvā a sahantassa na hoti
translated: this is called stinginess about beauty. But when someone cannot bear to hear another praised in these terms, this is not stinginess about beauty.

original: Dhammoti pariyattiyeva, na paṭivedho ariyānaṃ tattha macchariyābhāvā. Pariyattiṃ
analyzed: dhammaḥ ti pariyattiyā iva na paṭivedhaḥ ariyānam tattha mad śariyā bhāvā pariyattim
translated: “Dhamma” is the scriptures, not penetration, because there is no stinginess about the latter on the part of Noble Ones. But there is what may be called “stinginess about the Dhamma” in one who is secretive about the scriptures and does not want to teach others.

original: pana guḷhaganthaṃ aññesaṃ akathetukāmassa dhammamacchariyaṃ nāma hoti, dhammānuggahena🔽pana lolassa, kālena samaṇo, kālena nigaṇṭhādi ca hutvā vicarantassa paveṇiāgataṃ🔽tantiṃ “saṇhasukhumaṃ dhammantaraṃ bhinditvā āluḷissati, amhākaṃ samayaṃ bhindissatī”ti🔽ca na dentassa, puggalānuggahena vā pakatiyā saṭhassa māyāvino “saṇhasukhumadhammaṃ
analyzed: pana guḷha gantham aññesam a kathetu kāmassa dhammamacchariyam nāma hoti dhamma anuggahena  pana lolassa kālena samaṇaḥ kālena nigaṇṭha ādi ca hutvā vicarantassa paveṇi āgatam  tantim saṇha su khumam dhammantaram bhinditvā āluḷissati amhākam samayam bhindissati iti  ca na dentassa puggala anuggahena vā pakatiyā saṭhassa māyāvino saṇha sukhuma dhammaṃ
translated: But there is no stinginess about the Dhamma in one who is stingy about the Dhamma because he is greedy for gain and honour,🔽or in one who goes about in the guise of an ascetic or a Jain, etc., and does not give the scriptures to one who has come to his fold, thinking “He will break up the unity of the order by splitting it with his subtle and fine doctrines and by sowing dissension.”

original: uggaṇhitvā aññaṃ byākaritvā nassissatī”ti na dentassa ca dhammamacchariyaṃ na hoti.
analyzed: uggaṇhitvā aññam byākaritvā nassissati iti na dentassa ca dhammamacchariyam na hoti
translated: Or in one who is stingy about the Dhamma because he is naturally deceitful and cunning and does not give the scriptures to one who is devoted to the Dhamma, thinking “He will learn the subtle and fine doctrines and will betray me by teaching them to others.”

original: Yathā ca bhikkhūnaṃ, evaṃ gahaṭṭhānampi pañcavidhaṃ macchariyaṃ yathānurūpaṃ ñātabbaṃ.
analyzed: yathā ca bhikkhūnam evam gahaṭṭhānam pi pañcavidham macchariyam yathā anurūpam ñātabbam
translated: And as in the case of bhikkhus, so in the case of householders, the five kinds of stinginess should be understood according to the method stated.

original: Saṅkhepato pana gahaṭṭhapabbajitānaṃ attasampattinigūhanalakkhaṇaṃ macchariyaṃ nāmāti gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ pana gaha ṭṭha pabbajitānam atta sampatti nigūhana lakkhaṇam macchariyam nāma ati gahetabbam
translated: But in brief, the characteristic of stinginess in householders and bhikkhus is the concealing of one’s own excellence.

original: Imesu ca saṃyojanesu diṭṭhivicikicchāsīlabbataparāmāsaissāmacchariyāni sotāpattimaggena🔽pahīyanti, paṭigho anāgāmimaggena, kāmarāgo catūhipīti vattabbaṃ, “tatiyenā”ti pana
analyzed: imesu ca saṃyojanesu diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsa issāmacchariyāni sa utāpatti maggena  pahīyanti paṭighaḥ anāgāmi maggena kāma rāgaḥ catūhi pi iti vattabbam tatiyena ati pana
translated: And in these fetters, the false view, uncertainty, virtue-and-duty, and grasping of a rule and ritual as supreme, covetousness, and stinginess are abandoned by the path of stream-entry,🔽and resentment by the path of non-return. It should be said that lust for existence is abandoned by all four paths. But it is said

original: vuttaṃ. Mānabhavarāgaavijjā arahattamaggena. Tattha ca ayāthāvamāno paṭhamamaggena
analyzed: vuttam māna bhava rāga avijjāḥ arahatta maggena tattha ca ayāthāvamāno paṭhama maggena
translated: that it is abandoned by the third. Conceit, lust for existence, and ignorance are abandoned by the path of Arahantship. Herein, the wrong conceit should be regarded as abandoned by the first path,

original: pahīyatīti daṭṭhabbo, imesaṃ kāmarāgabhavarāgānaṃ lobhasabhāvattā diṭṭhisīlabbataparāmāsānaṃ
analyzed: pahīyati iti daṭṭhabbaḥ imesam kāma rāga bhava rāgānam lobha sabhāva ttā diṭṭhi sīla bbata parāmāsānam
translated: because these lust for sensual desires and lust for existence are of the nature of greed, and these false view, virtue-and-duty, and grasping of a rule and ritual as supreme

original: micchādiṭṭhisabhāvattā sabhāvato aṭṭheva dhammā dasa saṃyojanā nāma jātā. Ime dasa
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi sabhāvattā sabhāvataḥ aṭṭha iva dhammā dasa saṃyojanāḥ nāma jātāḥ ime dasa
translated: are of the nature of wrong view. So in reality there are only eight states called the ten fetters. These ten

original: ṭhapetvā sesā lokiyalokuttaradhammā no saṃyojanā nāma. Sesaṃ āsavadukasadisaṃ. Saṃyojanadukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā sesā lokiya lokuttara dhammā no saṃyojanāḥ nāma sesam āsava duka sadisam saṃyojana dukam paṭhamam
translated: are called fetters because they fetter beings to suffering by means of the three kinds of suffering, namely, suffering due to suffering, suffering due to formations, and suffering due to change . The rest of the states, that is, the mundane and supramundane states other than these, are not called fetters. The rest of the explanation is similar to that of the Greed chapter. The chapter on the fetters is the first.

original: Ārammaṇabhāvaṃ upagantvā saṃyojanasaṃvaḍḍhanena saṃyojanānaṃ hitāti saṃyojaniyā,
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhāvam upagantvā saṃyojana saṃvaḍḍhanena saṃyoja nānam hitā ati saṃyojaniyā
translated: They are called “related to the fetters” because they increase the fetters by becoming their object.

original: sāsavadhammā eva. Tathā nīvaraṇiyāti etthāpi. Na saṃyojaniyā asaṃyojaniyā, anāsavā.
analyzed: sa āsava dhammā eva tathā nīvaraṇiyā ati ettha api na saṃyojaniyāḥ asaṃyojaniyāḥ anāsavā
translated: They are only states with taints. So too with the hindrances. “Not related to the fetters” are the taints-free states.

original: Sesaṃ sāsavadukasadisameva. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: sesam dutiyam
translated: The rest is the same as in the case of the unprofitable. (2)

original: Tatiyādayopi āsavagocchake tatiyādisadisā eva, visesamattamevettha vakkhāma. Tattha
analyzed: tatiya ādayaḥ api āsavagocchake tatiya ādi sadisāḥ eva visesa mattam evā ittha vakkhāma tattha
translated: In the third and the rest, the third and the rest are similar to those in the case of the taints. Only the difference will be stated here.🔽Herein, twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness are called “associated with fetters,”

original: hi dvādasākusalacittāni saṃyojanasampayuttā nāma, uddhaccasahagato moho, sesacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: hi dvādasa akusala cittāni saṃyojana sampayuttāḥ nāma uddhacca sahagataḥ moho sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: and delusion accompanied by agitation, and the rest of the kinds of consciousness and the kinds of materiality and Nibbāna,

original: saṃyojanavippayuttā nāma. Sesaṃ samameva. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyojana vippayuttāḥ nāma sesam samam eva tatiyam
translated: are called “unassociated with fetters.” The rest is the same in each case. (3)

original: Dasa saṃyojanāni saṃyojanā ceva saṃyojaniyā ca nāma. Tadavasesalokiyadhammā saṃyojaniyā ceva no ca saṃyojanā nāma. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: dasa saṃyojanāni saṃyojanā ca iva saṃyojaniyā ca nāma tad avasesa lokiya dhammā saṃyojaniyā ca iva no ca saṃyojanā nāma sesam su viññeyyam eva catuttham
translated: The ten fetters are called “fetters” and also “subject to the fetters.” The rest of the mundane states are called “subject to the fetters” but not “fetters.” The rest is quite clear. (4)

original: Ye pana uddhaccavirahitesu ekādasasu akusalacittesu vicikicchāmohā dosamohā dosaissāmohā
analyzed: ye pana uddhacca virahitesu ekādasasu akusala cittesu vicikicchā mohāḥ dosa mohāḥ dosa issā mohāḥ
translated: But in the eleven kinds of unprofitable consciousness free from agitation, doubt and delusion, hate and delusion, hate, delusion, and obstinacy,🔽hate, delusion, and vanity, greed, conceit, and delusion, greed, views, and delusion, arise together in pairs,

original: dosamacchariyamohā lobhamānamohā lobhadiṭṭhimohā cāti dve tayo ekato uppajjanti,
analyzed: dosa macchariya mohāḥ lobha māna mohāḥ lobha diṭṭhi mohāḥ ca ati dve tayo ekatas uppajjanti
translated: in threes,

original: te saṃyojanā ceva saṃyojanasampayuttā ca nāma. Dvādasākusalacittāni ceva saṃyojanavajjitataṃsampayuttā
analyzed: te saṃyojanā ca iva saṃyojana sampayuttā ca nāma dvādasa akusala cittāni ca iva
translated: and they are called “fetters” and also “associated with fetters.” The twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness, excluding the fetters, are called “associated with fetters” but not “fetters.”

original: ca saṃyojanasampayuttā ceva no ca saṃyojanā nāma. Sesamidha anantaradukañca āsavagocchake
analyzed: ca saṃyojana sampayuttā ca iva no ca saṃyojanā nāma āsava gocchake
translated: and the rest are called “not fetters and not associated with fetters.”

original: pañcamachaṭṭhadukasadisameva. Kevalaṃ āsavapadaṭṭhāne saṃyojanapadameva viseso. Pañcamachaṭṭhadukāni.
analyzed: pañcama chaṭṭha duka sadisam eva kevalam āsava pada ṭṭhāne saṃyojana padam eva visesaḥ pañcama chaṭṭha dukāni
translated: The remaining dyads here are like the fifth and sixth dyads in the section on cankers. The only difference is that the word “fetter” replaces the word “canker.”

original: Saṃyojanagocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyojana gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on fetters is finished.

original: Ganthagocchake yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ cutipaṭisandhivasena vaṭṭasmiṃ ganthenti ghaṭentīti ganthā. Tato aññe no ganthā.🔽Tattha abhijjhākāyagantho, byāpādo, sīlabbataparāmāso, idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyaganthoti
analyzed: gantha gocchake yassa saṃvijjanti tam cuti paṭisandhi vasena vaṭṭasmim ganthenti ghaṭenti iti ganthā tatas aññe no ganthā  tattha abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ byāpādaḥ sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ kāya ganthaḥ iti
translated: In the section on bonds, those that exist in a person bind him in the round of rebirths by way of death and rebirth-linking. They are called “bonds” because they bind, because they tie a person to the round of rebirths. The rest are not bonds.🔽Herein, the bodily tie of covetousness, the bodily tie of ill will, the bodily tie of adherence to rules and observances, and the bodily tie of insisting that “This only is the truth” are called “bonds.”

original: ime cattāro dhammā ganthā nāma. Tattha abhijjhā eva nāmakāyaṃ vuttanayena ganthetīti
analyzed: ime cattāro dhammā ganthāḥ nāma tattha abhijjhāḥ eva nāmakāyam vutta nayena
translated: Herein, covetousness itself binds the body, and for that reason it is called the bodily tie of covetousness. So too with the rest.

original: abhijjhākāyagantho. Evaṃ sesesupi. Sabbaññubhāsitampi paṭikkhipitvā “sassato loko,
analyzed: evam sesesu pi sabbaññu bhāsitam pi paṭikkhipitvā sassataḥ loko
translated: Having rejected the omniscient one’s teaching, one insists: “The world is eternal,

original: idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti iminā ākārena abhinivisanato sīlabbataparāmāsavirahitā
analyzed: idam eva saccam mogham aññanti iminā ākārena abhinivisanataḥ sīlabbata parāmāsa virahitā
translated: this alone is the truth, the opposite is false.” Because of this mode of insisting, the bodily tie of adherence to rules and observances is devoid of the bodily tie of insisting that “This only is the truth.”

original: sabbāpi diṭṭhi idaṃsaccābhiniveso nāma. Sesā vuttatthāva. Imesu ca pacchimā dve ganthā
analyzed: sabbā api diṭṭhi idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ nāma sesā imesu ca pacchimā dve ganthā
translated: All views are called ‘adherence to the idea of self and what pertains to a self. ’ The rest are as already explained. And of these last two fetters,

original: paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti, byāpādo tatiyena, abhijjhā catūhipi. Ime ca sabhāvato
analyzed: paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti byāpādaḥ tatiyena abhijjhā ime ca sabhāvato
translated: the first is abandoned by the first path, and ill will by the third, while greed is abandoned by all four. And these three ideas,

original: tayo dhammā cattāro ganthā nāma jātā. Ime pana ṭhapetvā sesā sabbe dhammā no ganthā
analyzed: tayo dhammā cattāraḥ ganthāḥ nāma jātāḥ ime pana ṭhapetvā sesā sabbe dhammā no ganthā
translated: which are in fact states of greed, are called the four fetters. But all the other ideas are not fetters.

original: nāma. Ganthadukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: nāma ganthadukam paṭhamam
translated: The first dyad is ended.

original: Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena ganthehi ganthitabbāti ganthaniyā. Na ganthaniyā aganthaniyā. Sesaṃ sāsavadukasadisameva. Dutiyaṃ.🔽Mohamūlavajjitāni dasa akusalacittāni, diṭṭhivippayuttacittesu lobhaṃ, dosamūlesu🔽ca dosaṃ ṭhapetvā taṃsampayuttā ca ganthasampayuttā nāma. Yathāvutto lobho, doso,
analyzed: ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena ganthehi ganthitabbā ati ganthaniyā na ganthaniyā a ganthaniyā sesam sāsava duka sadisam eva dutiyam  moha mūla vajjitāni dasa akusala cittāni diṭṭhi vippayutta cittesu lobham dosa mūlesu  ca dosam ṭhapetvā tad sampayuttā ca gantha sampayuttā nāma yathā vuttaḥ lobhaḥ doso
translated: They are ‘to be given up through vision’ because they are to be given up by the path of seeing. They are ‘not to be given up through vision’ because they are not to be given up by that path. The rest is as already stated. The second dyad is ended.🔽The ten unprofitable consciousnesses excluding those rooted in delusion are called ‘associated with the fetters’ since they are associated with greed, and since they are associated with hate in the case of those rooted in hate.

original: mohamūlāni, kusalābyākatāni cittāni, rūpanibbānāni ca ganthavippayuttā nāma. Cetasikesu
analyzed: moha mūlāni kusala abyākatāni cittāni rūpa nibbānāni ca gantha vippayuttāḥ nāma cetasikesu
translated: The rest are called ‘unassociated with the fetters’ since they are not associated with greed, hate and delusion as stated. And also the profitable and indeterminate kinds of consciousness and materiality and Nibbāna are called ‘unassociated with the fetters.’

original: pana diṭṭhimānaissāmacchariyakukkuccathinamiddhāni ganthasampayuttā eva. Dosavicikicchā,
analyzed: pana gantha sampayuttā eva dosa vicikicchā
translated: But views, conceit, envy, stinginess, worry, and lethargy are only connected with fetters. Anger and uncertainty

original: kusalābyākatā ca ganthavippayuttā eva, sesā dvidhāpi honti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: ca gantha vippayuttā eva sesā dvidhā api honti tatiyam
translated: are not connected with fetters, and are only wholesome and indeterminate. The rest are of both kinds. The third method.

original: Cattāro ganthā ganthā ceva ganthaniyā ca nāma. Tadavasesā lokiyā ganthaniyā ceva
analyzed: cattāro ganthāḥ ganthā ca iva ganthaniyā ca nāma tad avasesā lokiyā ganthaniyā ca iva
translated: The four fetters are both fetters and connected with fetters. The rest of the mundane are only connected with fetters,

original: no ca ganthā nāma. Tathā cetasikesu ganthavajjitā akusalā, appamaññā ca, sesā cetasikā
analyzed: no ca ganthā nāma tathā cetasikesu gantha vajjitā akusalā appamaññā ca sesā cetasikā
translated: but are not fetters. So too, among the mental states, the unwholesome except for the fetters, and the measureless states, are only connected with fetters,

original: pana tathā ca na vattabbā ca, idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: pana tathā ca na vattabbā ca idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā catuttham
translated: but are not fetters. But the rest are not to be spoken of in this way. But here the supramundane are not to be spoken of. The fourth method.

original: Diṭṭhi ganthāceva ganthasampayuttā ca nāma. Lobho tathā ca na vattabbo ca, ganthasampayuttesu
analyzed: diṭṭhi ganthā ca iva gantha sampayuttā ca nāma lobho tathā ca na vattabbo ca gantha sampayuttesu
translated: Views are both fetters and connected with fetters. Greed is not to be spoken of in this way. Among those connected with fetters,

original: ganthe ṭhapetvā sesā ganthasampayuttā ceva no ca ganthā nāma. Idha pana ganthavippayuttā
analyzed: ganthe ṭhapetvā sesā gantha sampayuttā ca iva no ca ganthā nāma idha pana gantha vippayuttā
translated: the rest are only connected with fetters, but are not fetters. But here those not connected with fetters

original: na vattabbā. Cetasikesu pana mānaissāmacchariyakukkuccathinamiddhāni ganthasampayuttā
analyzed: na vattabbā cetasikesu pana gantha sampayuttā
translated: are not to be spoken of. But among the mental states, conceit, envy, stinginess, worry, and lethargy are connected with fetters,🔽but are not fetters.

original: ceva no ca ganthā eva, mohāhirikānottappauddhaccāni tijātikā ca siyā, tathā navattabbā
analyzed: ca iva no ca ganthāḥ eva moha ahirika anottappa auddhaccāni ti jātikā ca siyā tathā na vattabbā
translated: and not bonds. Delusion, shamelessness, fearlessness of wrongdoing, agitation, and greed are of three kinds, and so are the Undesired,

original: ca, sesā na vattabbā. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: ca sesā na vattabbā sesam su viññeyyam eva pañcamam
translated: and the rest are not to be spoken of. The rest is quite clear. The fifth section.

original: Lokuttaravajjitā ganthavippayuttā ganthaniyā nāma. Lokuttarā pana ganthavippayuttā
analyzed: lokuttara vajjitā gantha vippayuttā ganthaniyā nāma lokuttarā pana gantha vippayuttā
translated: Those dissociated from the bonds but subject to the bonds are called “not-in-bonds” except for the supramundane. But the supramundane, being dissociated from the bonds,

original: aganthaniyā nāma. Idha pana ganthasampayuttā na vattabbā. Cetasikesu pana doso vicikicchā
analyzed: aganthaniyā nāma idha pana gantha sampayuttā na vattabbā cetasikesu pana dosaḥ vicikicchā
translated: are called “not-in-bonds and not subject to the bonds.” Herein, those associated with the bonds are not to be spoken of. But as regards the associated states, hate, doubt,

original: karuṇā muditā ganthavippayuttā ganthaniyā eva, mohāhirikānottappauddhaccalobhā tathā
analyzed: karuṇā muditā gantha vippayuttā ganthaniyā eva moha ahirika anottappa auddhacca lobhā tathā
translated: pity, and gladness are dissociated from the bonds but subject to the bonds. Delusion, shamelessness, fearlessness of wrongdoing, agitation, greed, and the Undesired

original: na vattabbā ca, sesā kusalābyākatā dvidhāpi honti, tijātikā pana dvidhāpi na vattabbā
analyzed: na vattabbā ca sesā kusala abyākatā dvidhā api honti ti jātikā pana dvidhā api na vattabbā
translated: are not to be spoken of. The rest of the profitable and indeterminate are of both kinds. But those of three kinds are not to be spoken of as either.

original: ca, sesā akusalāpi na vattabbā ca. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: ca sesā akusalā api na vattabbā ca chaṭṭham
translated: And the rest of the unprofitable are not to be spoken of. The sixth section.

original: Ganthagocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: gantha gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The “bonds” chapter is finished.

original: Oghayogagocchakāni sabbathā āsavagocchakasadisāni. Padatthamattameva, hettha nāmamattañca
analyzed: ogha yoga gocchakāni sabbathā āsava gocchaka sadisāni padattha mattam eva ha ittha nāma mattam ca
translated: The “floods,” “bonds,” and “clingings” are all like the “cankers.” Herein, the words and the mere terms

original: viseso. Tattha yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ vaṭṭasmiṃ ohananti osīdāpentīti oghā. Ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: visesaḥ tattha yassa saṃvijjanti tam vaṭṭasmim ohananti osīdāpenti iti oghāḥ ārammaṇam
translated: The difference between them is this. Those that exist in him are “floods” in the sense of flowing on (og-hana) or of making him flow on in the round of rebirths (vaṭṭe). The object of craving is the “shore” (āraṃmaṇa).

original: katvā atikkamanīyato oghehi atikkamitabbāti oghaniyā. Tathā yoganiyāti etthāpi. Vaṭṭasmiṃ🔽yojentīti yogā. Sesaṃ tādisameva.🔽Oghayogagocchakāni niṭṭhitāni.
analyzed: katvā atikkamanīyataḥ oghehi atikkamitabbā ati ogha niyā tathā yoga niyā ati ettha api vaṭṭasmiṃ  yojenti iti sesam tādisam eva  ogha yoga gocchakāni niṭṭhitāni
translated: The difference is this. Those that exist in the three planes are called floods because they flood the round of rebirths by flooding it with the suffering of the round. Those that exist in the three planes are called bonds because they bind the round of rebirths by binding it with the suffering of the round. Those that exist in the three planes are called hindrances because they hinder the round of rebirths by hindering it with the suffering of the round. Those that exist in the three planes are called ties because they tie the round of rebirths by tying it with the suffering of the round. Those that exist in the three planes are called bonds because they bond the round of rebirths by bonding it with the suffering of the round. The rest is as already stated. The exposition of the floods, bonds, hindrances, and ties is ended.

original: Nīvaraṇagocchake cittaṃ nīvaranti pariyonandhantīti nīvaraṇā. Tattha kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: nīvaraṇa gocchake cittam nīvaranti pariyonandhanti iti nīvaraṇā kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam
translated: The hindrances are so called because they hinder the mind by oppressing it. Herein, the hindrance of sensual desire,

original: byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇaṃ vicikicchānīvaraṇaṃ🔽avijjānīvaraṇanti ime cha nīvaraṇā nāma. Tattha thinanti sappipiṇḍo viya avipphārikatāya🔽cittassa ghanabhāvo, thaddhatāti attho. Medhatīti middhaṃ, akammaññabhāvo, pacalāyikabhāvakaroti
analyzed: byāpāda nīvaraṇam thinamiddha nīvaraṇam uddhacca kukkucca nīvaraṇam vicikicchā nīvaraṇam  avijjānīvaraṇanti ime cha nīvaraṇāḥ nāma tattha thinanti sappi piṇḍaḥ viya a vipphārika tāya  cittassa ghana bhāvaḥ atthaḥ medhati iti middham a kammañña bhāvo
translated: the hindrance of ill will, the hindrance of sloth and torpor, the hindrance of worry and flustering, the hindrance of doubt,

original: attho. Idañca sekhaputhujjanānaṃ niddāya pubbabhāge, aparabhāge ca pacalāyanahetukaṃ
analyzed: attho idam ca sekha puthujjanānam niddāya pubba bhāge apara bhāge ca pacalāyana hetukam
translated: the hindrance of ignorance. These are called the six hindrances. Herein, sloth is the state of one’s own mind’s being closed up, like a lump of froth, because of lack of spread; the meaning is, it is stiffness. Torpor is sleepiness; the meaning is, it is unserviceability, the cause of the state of rolling from side to side. This is a cause of rolling from side to side in the earlier and later stages of sleep in the case of those still subject to lapse, that is, in trainers and ordinary men.

original: uppajjati, na niddokkamanakāle. Khīṇāsavānampi hi karajakāyassa dubbalabhāvena asammissabhavaṅgasantativasena
analyzed: uppajjati na niddokkamana kāle khīṇāsavānam pi hi karaja kāyassa dubbala bhāvena a sammissa bhavaṅga santati vasena
translated: and it does not arise at the time of waking up. For even in those whose cankers are destroyed, there is waking up because of the weakness of the material body, and the life-continuum is not mixed with the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: niddokkamanaṃ hoti, taṃ pana tesaṃ thinamiddhahetukaṃ na hoti, itaresameva hoti.
analyzed: niddokkamanam hoti tam pana tesam thinamiddha hetukam na hoti itaresam eva hoti
translated: But that is not due to sluggishness and drowsiness, it is only due to other causes.

original: Keci pana rūpameva “middha”nti vadanti, taṃ na yuttaṃ, “thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ avijjānīvaraṇena
analyzed: keci pana rūpam eva middhanti vadanti tam na yuttam thina middha nīvaraṇam avijjā nīvaraṇena
translated: But some say that “sluggishness” is materiality. That is incorrect, because it is said that sluggishness and drowsiness are associated with the immaterial states,

original: nīvaraṇañceva nīvaraṇasampayuttañcā”ti arūpadhammehi sampayogavacanato arūpameva.
analyzed: nīvaraṇam ca iva nīvaraṇa sampayuttam ca ati arūpa dhammehi sampayoga vacanataḥ arūpam eva
translated: in the passage: “The hindrance of sluggishness and drowsiness is a hindrance and is associated with the hindrance of ignorance” .

original: Akusalañca “thinamiddhanīvaraṇassa pahīnattā”tiādipahānavacanato. Akusalā eva hi
analyzed: akusalam ca thinam iddha nīvaraṇassa pahīna ttā ati ādi pahāna vacanataḥ akusalāḥ eva hi
translated: And because it is said that they are abandoned in the passage: “Because the hindrance of sluggishness and drowsiness has been abandoned” .

original: pahātabbā, tasmā āruppepi cetaṃ uppajjati. “Nīvaraṇaṃ dhammaṃ paṭicca nīvaraṇo dhammo
analyzed: pahātabbā tasmai āruppe pi ca itam uppajjati nīvaraṇam dhammam paṭicca nīvaraṇaḥ dhammo
translated: For only unprofitable states are to be abandoned. Therefore this arises in the immaterial states too.🔽In the Vibhaṅga, under the heading beginning, “Dependent on a state that is a hindrance there arises a state that is a hindrance,” it is said:

original: uppajjati na purejātapaccayā”ti etassa vibhaṅge “āruppe kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: uppajjati na purejāta paccayā ati etassa vibhaṅge āruppe kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam paṭicca
translated: “Dependent on the hindrance of lust for sense desires in the immaterial states …

original: thinamiddhauddhaccaavijjānīvaraṇa”nti sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ. “Soppaṃ pacalāyikā”ti
analyzed: thinam iddha auddhacca avijjā nīvaraṇanti sabbam vitthāretabbam soppam pacalāyikā ati
translated: and torpor, drowsiness, agitation, and worry are hindrances.” All this should be quoted in detail. “The one who is slow to act is a procrastinator”

original: padabhājanīye panassa phalūpacārena vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Thinaṃ middhañcāti idaṃ
analyzed: pada bhājanīye pana assa phala upacārena vuttanti veditabbam thinam middham ca ati idam
translated: should be understood to be stated in the Padaṭṭhāna by way of the proximate cause of its fruit. “Torpor and drowsiness”

original: dvayaṃ nīvaraṇaṭṭhāne ekanīvaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, tathā uddhaccakukkuccañcāti idaṃ dvayaṃ.
analyzed: dvayam nīvaraṇa ṭṭhāne eka nīvaraṇam vuttam tathā uddhacca kukkuccam ca ati idam dvayam
translated: are stated as a single hindrance in the place of the hindrances as a pair. So too “agitation and worry” are a pair.

original: Tattha kukkuccanti “akataṃ vata me kalyāṇaṃ, kataṃ pāpa”ntiādinā uppajjamāno vippaṭisāro.
analyzed: tattha kukkuccanti akatam vata me kalyāṇam katam pāpam ti ādinā uppajjamānaḥ vippaṭisāraḥ
translated: Herein, worry is the dissimulation that arises thus, “I have not done what is good, I have done what is bad.”

original: Tenevassa padabhājanīye “cetaso vippaṭisāro manovilekho”ti ca vuttaṃ. “Akappiye kappiyasaññitā”tiādi🔽pana kukkuccamūladassanatthaṃ. Evaṃsaññitāya hi kate vītikkame pacchā “duṭṭhu mayā
analyzed: tena iva assa pada bhājanīye cetasaḥ vippaṭisāraḥ manaḥ vilekhaḥ ti ca vuttam akappiye kappiya saññitā tiādi  pana kukkucca mūla dassana attham evaṃsaññitāya hi kate vītikkame pacchā duṭṭhu mayā
translated: Hence it is said in the Padaṭṭhāna: “It is mental dissimulation, mental affliction” . But the statement beginning, “The perception that what is not allowable is allowable”

original: kata”nti sudinnādīnaṃ viya vippaṭisāro uppajjati. Yaṃ pana vinaye “atha kho āyasmā
analyzed: sudinna ādīnam viya vippaṭisāraḥ uppajjati yam pana vinaye atha kho āyasmā
translated: is for the purpose of showing the root of worry. For when one acts after perceiving in this way, then afterwards, when one sees that one has transgressed, one becomes dissimulate thus, “I have done badly,” like Sudinna, and so on.

original: sāriputto…pe… kukkuccāyanto na paṭiggahesī”ti kukkuccaṃ āgataṃ, taṃ nīvaraṇakukkuccaṃ.
analyzed: sāriputta upe kukkuccāyantaḥ na paṭiggahesi iti kukkuccam āgatam tam nīvaraṇa kukkuccam
translated: But the worry that occurs in the Vinaya as “Then the venerable Sāriputta … being scrupulous, did not accept” is the worry that is a hindrance.

original: Na hi arahato nīvaraṇaṃ atthi, nīvaraṇavatirūpakaṃ pana “kappati, na kappatī”ti vīmaṃsanasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: na hi arahataḥ nīvaraṇam atthi nīvaraṇavati rūpakam pana kappati na kappati iti vīmaṃsana saṅkhātam
translated: For an Arahant has no hindrance, but it should be understood that the perplexity called “doubt” is the investigation called “Is it allowable or not?”

original: vinayakukkuccaṃ nāmetanti veditabbaṃ. Sesanīvaraṇāni vuttatthāni eva. Imesu ca kukkuccavicikicchā
analyzed: vinaya kukkuccam nāma etat ti veditabbam sesa nīvaraṇāni vutta tthāni eva imesu ca kukkucca vicikicchā
translated: The rest of the hindrances are in the same way as stated. And in these, perplexity and worry

original: paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti, byāpādo tatiyena, thinamiddhuddhaccāvijjā catutthena,
analyzed: paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti byāpādaḥ tatiyena thinam iddha uddhacca avijjā catutthena
translated: are abandoned by the first path, ill will by the third, and stiffness-and-torpor, agitation, and ignorance by the fourth.🔽But it should be said that lust is abandoned by all four. But it is said “by the third” .

original: kāmacchando catūhipīti vattabbaṃ, “tatiyenā”ti pana vuttaṃ. Ime ca sabhāvato aṭṭha
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ catūhi pi iti vattabbam tatiyena ati pana vuttam ime ca sabhāvataḥ aṭṭha
translated: These eight states, which are in themselves

original: dhammā cha nīvaraṇā nāma jātā, ime pana ṭhapetvā sesā no nīvaraṇā nāma. Nīvaraṇadukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: dhammā cha nīvaraṇāḥ nāma jātāḥ ime pana ṭhapetvā sesāḥ no nīvaraṇāḥ nāma nīvaraṇa dukam paṭhamam
translated: are called “hindrances.” But the rest are not called “hindrances.”

original: Dutiyaṃ sāsavadukasadisameva. Dvādasa akusalacittāni nīvaraṇasampayuttā nāma. Sesacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: dutiyam sāsava duka sadisam eva dvādasa akusala cittāni nīvaraṇa sampayuttāḥ nāma sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: The second dyad is similar to the first dyad of the unprofitable. The twelve unprofitable consciousnesses are called “associated with hindrances.” The rest of consciousness and all materiality and Nibbāna

original: nīvaraṇavippayuttā nāma. Cetasikesu akusalā nīvaraṇasampayuttāva, kusalābyākatā nīvaraṇavippayuttāva,
analyzed: nīvaraṇa vippayuttāḥ nāma cetasikesu akusalāḥ nīvaraṇa sampayuttāḥ kusala abyākatāḥ nīvaraṇa vippayuttāḥ
translated: are called “unassociated with hindrances.” As regards the associated states, the unprofitable are only associated with hindrances, the profitable and indeterminate are only unassociated with hindrances,

original: sesā dvidhāpi honti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: sesāḥ dvidhā api honti tatiyam
translated: while the rest are of both kinds. The third dyad.

original: Cha nīvaraṇā nīvaraṇā ceva nīvaraṇiyā ca nāma. Sesā lokiyā nīvaraṇiyā ceva no ca nīvaraṇā nāma. Lokuttarā na vattabbā. Sesaṃ āsavagocchake catutthasadisameva. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: cha nīvaraṇāḥ nīvaraṇā ca iva nīvaraṇiyā ca nāma sesā lokiyā nīvaraṇiyā ca iva no ca nīvaraṇā nāma lokuttarā na vattabbā sesam āsava gocchake catuttha sadisam eva catuttham
translated: The six Hindrances are Hindrances and also called Hindrances-to-be-abandoned-by-Development. The rest are Hindrances-to-be-abandoned-by-Development only and not Hindrances. The supramundane are not to be spoken of. The rest is like the fourth in the case of the taints. Fourth question.

original: Cha nīvaraṇā nīvaraṇā ceva nīvaraṇasampayuttā ca nāma. Tadaññe nīvaraṇasampayuttā
analyzed: cha nīvaraṇā nīvaraṇā ca iva nīvaraṇa sampayuttā ca nāma tad aññe nīvaraṇa sampayuttā
translated: The six Hindrances are Hindrances and also associated with Hindrances. The others are associated with Hindrances

original: pana nīvaraṇasampayuttā ceva no ca nīvaraṇā nāma. Tathā cetasikesu nīvaraṇavirahitā
analyzed: pana nīvaraṇa sampayuttā ca iva no ca nīvaraṇā nāma tathā cetasikesu nīvaraṇa virahitā
translated: but not Hindrances. So too, in the case of the mental factors, the unprofitable dissociated from the Hindrances

original: akusalā, tijātikā pana tathā ca na vattabbā ca, kusalābyākatā na vattabbāva. Idha
analyzed: akusalā ti jātikā pana tathā ca na vattabbā ca kusalā abyākatā na vattabbā āva idha
translated: are associated with Hindrances but not Hindrances. The three kinds are not to be spoken of as such. The profitable and indeterminate are not to be spoken of. Herein,

original: pana nīvaraṇavippayuttā sabbe na vattabbā. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: pana nīvaraṇa vippayuttā sabbe na vattabbā pañcamam
translated: all dissociated from the Hindrances are not to be spoken of. Fifth question.

original: Lokuttaravajjitā nīvaraṇavippayuttā nīvaraṇiyā nāma. Lokuttarā nīvaraṇavippayuttā
analyzed: lokuttara vajjitā nīvaraṇa vippayuttā nīvaraṇiyā nāma lokuttarā nīvaraṇa vippayuttā
translated: Except the supramundane, those dissociated from the Hindrances are Hindrances-to-be-abandoned-by-Development. The supramundane dissociated from the Hindrances

original: anīvaraṇiyā nāma. Idha pana nīvaraṇasampayuttā na vattabbā. Cetasikesu pana karuṇāmuditā
analyzed: anīvaraṇiyā nāma idha pana nīvaraṇa sampayuttā na vattabbā cetasikesu pana karuṇā muditā
translated: are not Hindrances-to-be-abandoned-by-Development. Herein, those associated with the Hindrances are not to be spoken of. But in the case of the mental factors, compassion and gladness

original: nīvaraṇavippayuttā nīvaraṇiyāva, kusalābyākatā dvidhāpi honti, tijātikā tathā ca
analyzed: nīvaraṇa vippayuttāḥ kusala abyākatāḥ dvidhā api honti tathā ca
translated: The profitable and indeterminate are both dissociated from the hindrances and related to the hindrances. They are of three kinds.

original: na vattabbā ca, akusalā pana na vattabbāva. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: na vattabbā ca akusalā pana na vattabbā ava chaṭṭham
translated: And they are not to be spoken of as either of the other two kinds. But the unprofitable are not to be spoken of. Sixth.

original: Nīvaraṇagocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The Hindrance Group is completed.🔽In the case of the perversions, the perversion of perception and the perversion of view are wrong view.🔽The perversion of consciousness is the consciousness associated with wrong view. The perversion of cognition is the cognition associated with wrong view.🔽The rest are not perversions.

original: Parāmāsagocchake dhammānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ aniccādiākāraṃ atikkamitvā “nicca”ntiādivasena🔽pavattamānā parato āmasantīti parāmāsā. Micchādiṭṭhi. Bahuvacananiddese kāraṇaṃ vuttameva.
analyzed: parāmāsa gocchake dhammānam yathābhūtam anicca ādi ākāram atikkamitvā nicca nti ādi vasena  pavattamānā paratas āmasanti iti parāmāsāḥ micchādiṭṭhi bahuvacana niddese kāraṇam vuttam eva
translated: The perversions are perversions of what is impermanent, etc., because they occur in the opposite way to the way it is with what is impermanent, etc., that is to say, as “permanent,” etc.

original: ceva cittajarūpakalāpā ca. Cittaṃ, pana acittajarūpakalāpā, nibbānañca no cittasamuṭṭhānā🔽nāma. Cittasamuṭṭhānadukaṃ.

original: Mahantaradukā niṭṭhitā.

analyzed: diṭṭha upādānam sīla bbata upādānam atta vāda upādānam ime upādānāḥ nāma tattha vatthu kāmesu
translated: Herein, the kinds of clinging are called clinging to sense pleasures, clinging to views, clinging to rules and vows, and clinging to a doctrine of self.

original: uppanno kilesakāmova vuttanayena upādānanti kāmupādānaṃ. Evaṃ sesesupi. Tattha vīsativatthukā
analyzed: uppannaḥ kilesa kāmaḥ va vutta nayena upādānam ti kāma upādānam evam sesesu pi tattha vīsati vatthukā
translated: Herein, sense desire as defilement that arises in respect of the kinds of sense pleasures as object is clinging to sense pleasures in the way already stated. So too with the rest.🔽Herein, the embodiment view with its twenty modes is called clinging to a doctrine of self. The rest are as already stated.

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhi attavādupādānaṃ nāma. Sesāni pubbe vuttāneva. Pacchimāni panettha tīṇi
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi attavādupādānam nāma sesāni pubbe vuttāni eva pacchimāni pana ittha tīṇi
translated: But the last three kinds of clinging are only the embodiment view occurring in these four ways.

original: upādānāni tathāpavattadiṭṭhi eva. Tāni ca paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti, kāmupādānaṃ
analyzed: upādānāni eva tāni ca paṭhamena maggena pahīyanti kāma upādānam
translated: And they are abandoned by the first path only, while clinging to sense pleasures is abandoned by the four.

original: catūhipi. Ime ca sabhāvato dve dhammā vibhāgato caturupādānā nāma jātā. Ime pana
analyzed: ime ca sabhāvataḥ dve dhammā vibhāgato catur upādānāḥ nāma jātāḥ ime pana
translated: And these two dhammas, which are twofold in the ultimate sense, are called fourfold in the conventional sense.

original: ṭhapetvā sesā sabbe dhammā no upādānā nāma. Upādānadukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā sesā sabbe dhammā no upādānāḥ nāma upādāna dukam paṭhamam
translated: But all dhammas other than these are called not-clinging.🔽This is the first dyad.

original: Upādāniyaduko saṃyojaniyadukasadisova. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam
translated: The section on objects of clinging is similar to that on sources of dispute. (2)

original: Aṭṭhalobhasahagatacittāni, taṃsampayuttesu diṭṭhivippayuttalobhaṃ ṭhapetvā sesā ca
analyzed: aṭṭha lobha sahagata cittāni tad sampayuttesu diṭṭhi vippayutta lobham ṭhapetvā sesā ca
translated: The eight consciousnesses accompanied by greed, and the rest of the states associated with them except for the greed unaccompanied by views,

original: upādānasampayuttā nāma. Diṭṭhivippayuttalobhadosamohamūlāni, kusalābyākatāni ca cittāni,
analyzed: upādāna sampayuttāḥ nāma diṭṭhi vippayutta lobha dosa moha mūlāni kusala abyākatāni ca cittāni
translated: are called “accompanied by clinging.” The roots of greed, delusion, and the unwholesome and indeterminate consciousnesses,

original: rūpanibbānāni ca upādānavippayuttā nāma. Cetasikesu pana diṭṭhimānā upādānasampayuttāva,
analyzed: rūpa nibbānāni ca upādāna vippayuttāḥ nāma cetasikesu pana diṭṭhi mānāḥ upādāna sampayuttāḥ ava
translated: and materiality and Nibbāna, are called “unaccompanied by clinging.” As regards the mental factors, the conceit “I am” and the false view of self are accompanied by clinging,🔽while hate, envy, avarice, worry, and doubt, and the wholesome and indeterminate consciousnesses,

original: dosaissāmacchariyakukkuccavicikicchā, kusalābyākatā ca upādānavippayuttā eva. Sesā
analyzed: kusala abyākatā ca upādāna vippayuttā eva sesā
translated: are unaccompanied by clinging. The rest

original: duvidhāpi honti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: duvidhā api honti tatiyam
translated: are of both kinds. (3)

original: Cattāri upādānāni upādānā ceva upādāniyā ca nāma. Tadavasesā lokiyā upādāniyā ceva no ca upādānā nāma. Idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: cattāri upādānāni upādānā ca iva upādāniyā ca nāma tad avasesā lokiyā upādāniyā ca iva no ca upādānā nāma idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā sesam vutta nayam eva catuttham
translated: The four kinds of clinging are both clinging and objects of clinging. The rest of the mundane states are objects of clinging but not clinging. But here the supramundane states should not be mentioned. The rest is as already stated. (4)

original: Pañcamachaṭṭhadukā pāṭhato ganthagocchake pañcamachaṭṭhadukasadisāva, kevalaṃ pañcamaduke
analyzed: pañcama chaṭṭha dukā pāṭhataḥ gantha gocchake kevalam pañcama duke
translated: The fifth and sixth sections are similar to the fifth and sixth sections of the exposition of the categories in the Paṭṭhāna. Only the fifth section

original: “cetasikesu māno upādānasampayutto ceva no ca upādāno eva, mohāhirikānottappauddhaccathinamiddhāni🔽tijātikāni tathā ca na vattabbā cā”ti idañca, chaṭṭhaduke “cetasikesu dosaissāmacchariyakukkuccavicikicchā🔽appamaññā upādānavippayuttā upādāniyā eva, mohāhirikānottappauddhaccalobhathinamiddhāni
analyzed: cetasikesu māno upādāna sampayutto ca iva no ca upādāno eva moha ahirika no uttappa auddhacca thinamiddhāni  ti jātikāni tathā ca na vattabbā ca ati idam ca chaṭṭha duke cetasikesu  appamaññāḥ upādāna vippayuttāḥ upādāniyāḥ eva moha ahirika no uttappa auddhacca lobha thinamiddhāni
translated: “The rest of the mental factors are associated with the underlying tendency to conceit, but are not themselves underlying tendencies. Delusion, shamelessness, lack of abashment, restlessness, torpor, and drowsiness

original: tathā ca na vattabbāni cā”ti ettakameva pāṭhato viseso, atthato pana nāmamattakova
analyzed: tathā ca na vattabbāni ca ati ettakam eva pāṭhataḥ visesaḥ atthataḥ pana nāma mattakaḥ eva
translated: are of three kinds. They are not to be spoken of in the same way.” This is the only difference in the text of the sixth dyad. The difference in meaning is merely a matter of names.

original: viseso. Seso suviññeyyova. Pañcamachaṭṭhāni.
analyzed: visesaḥ sesaḥ su viññeyyaḥ va pañcama chaṭṭhāni
translated: The rest is easy to understand. The fifth and sixth dyads.

original: Upādānagocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: upādāna gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on the underlying tendencies is finished.

original: Kilesagocchake saṃkiliṭṭhattike vuttanayena padattho veditabbo. Lobho doso moho māno
analyzed: kilesa gocchake vutta nayena padatthaḥ veditabbaḥ lobhaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ mānaḥ
translated: In the section on defilements, the meaning of the terms in the triad on what is defiled should be understood in the way already stated. Greed, hatred, delusion, conceit,

original: diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinaṃ uddhaccaṃ ahirikaṃ anottappanti ime dasa dhammā kilesā nāma.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinam uddhaccam ahirikam anottappanti ime dasa dhammā kilesāḥ nāma
translated: views, uncertainty, torpor, restlessness, shamelessness, and lack of abashment—these ten states are called defilements.

original: Ime ca vuttatthā eva, idha pana lobho, hetuganthanīvaraṇaupādānagocchakesu lobho
analyzed: ime ca vuttatthāḥ eva idha pana lobhaḥ hetu gantha nīvaraṇa aupādāna gocchakesu lobho
translated: These are their meanings as already stated. But here greed is in the root-causeless, the hindrances, the kinds of clinging, and the kinds of existence.

original: ca nippadesato catumaggavajjhopi ekeneva koṭṭhāsena ṭhito, sesagocchakesu so sabbopi
analyzed: ca nippadesataḥ catu magga vajjhaḥ api ekena iva koṭṭhāsena ṭhito sesa gocchakesu so sabbaḥ api
translated: And in the root-causeless it is without specification and is included in one section that is eschewal by the four paths. In the other kinds of existence it is all that greed

original: lobho “kāmāsavo bhavāsavo”tiādinā dve dve koṭṭhāsā hutvā ṭhito, iminā pana aṭṭhakathāvacanenāpi
analyzed: lobho kāma āsavaḥ bhava āsavaḥ ti ādinā dve dve koṭṭhāsāḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ iminā pana aṭṭhakathā vacanena api
translated: which is included in two sections, namely, “the taint of sensual desire” and “the taint of being,” etc.,

original: bhavāsavādibyatiritto sabbo catumaggavajjhopi rāgo kāmāsavādīsu saṅgahito. Kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhava āsava ādi byatirittaḥ sabbaḥ catu magga vajjhaḥ api rāgaḥ kāma āsava ādīsu saṅgahitaḥ kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam
translated: But by this commentarial statement too all greed that is eschewal by the four paths is included in the “taint of sensual desire,” etc.,🔽And the hindrance of lust is not only lust for the five strands of sensual desire. It should be regarded as the hindrance of lust in the immaterial sphere too,🔽because of the text, “Dependent on the hindrance of lust there is the hindrance of stiffness and torpor” ,

original: pana bhavarāgopi na pañcakāmaguṇikarāgamattovāti paññāyati, “āruppe kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ🔽paṭicca thinamiddhanīvaraṇa”ntiādipāḷito cetaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ pañcakāmaguṇikarāgassa🔽rūpārūpabhūmīsu anuppajjanato. Imesu ca kilesesu diṭṭhivicikicchā paṭhamena maggena
analyzed: pana bhava rāgaḥ api na pañca kāmaguṇika rāga mattaḥ vā ati paññāyati āruppe kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam  paṭicca thinam iddha nīvaraṇa nti ādi pāḷito ca itam daṭṭhabbam pañca kāmaguṇika rāgassa  rūpa arūpa bhūmīsu anuppajjanataḥ imesu ca kilesesu diṭṭhi vicikicchā paṭhamena maggena
translated: since lust for the five strands of sensual desire does not arise in the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: pahīyanti, doso tatiyena, lobhādayo catūhipi. Ime pana dasa dhamme ṭhapetvā sesā
analyzed: pahīyanti doso tatiyena lobha ādayo ime pana dasa dhamme ṭhapetvā sesā
translated: And of these defilements, wrong view and uncertainty are abandoned by the first path, hate by the third, and greed, etc., by all four. But apart from these ten states,

original: no kilesā nāma. Kilesadukaṃ paṭhamaṃ.🔽Saṃkilesikaduko sāsavadukasadisova. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: no kilesā nāma kilesadukam paṭhamam  saṃkilesika dukaḥ dutiyam
translated: not defilements. The first dyad is finished.🔽The second dyad is the same as the “with taints” dyad.

original: Saṃkiliṭṭhaduko, kilesasampayuttaduko cāti dvepi samānatthāva. Te ca nīvaraṇagocchake tatiyadukasadisāva. Tatiyacatutthāni.
analyzed: ca ati dve pi te ca nīvaraṇa gocchake tatiya duka sadisāva tatiya catutthāni
translated: The third and fourth dyads are the same as the third dyad in the Hindrances chapter.

original: Dasa kilesā kilesā ceva saṃkilesikā ca nāma. Sesā lokiyadhammā saṃkilesikā ceva no
analyzed: dasa kilesā kilesā ca iva saṃkilesikā ca nāma sesā lokiya dhammā saṃkilesikā ca iva no
translated: Ten defilements are both defilements and things that defile. The rest of the mundane states are only things that defile.

original: ca kilesā nāma. Idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā. Sesaṃ nīvaraṇagocchake catutthadukasadisameva. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: ca kilesāḥ nāma idha pana lokuttarā na vattabbā sesam nīvaraṇa gocchake catuttha duka sadisam eva pañcamam
translated: Herein, however, the supramundane states should not be mentioned. The rest is the same as the fourth dyad in the Hindrances chapter. The fifth dyad is finished.

original: Chaṭṭhasattamadukānipi aññamaññaṃ samānatthāneva. Tāni chaṭṭhasattamāni nīvaraṇagocchake
analyzed: chaṭṭha sattama dukāni pi aññam aññam samāna tthānā iva tāni chaṭṭha sattamāni nīvaraṇa gocchake
translated: The sixth and seventh dyads are the same in meaning. The sixth and seventh are the same as the fifth and sixth dyads in the Hindrances chapter,

original: yathākkamaṃ pāṭhato pañcamachaṭṭhadukasadisāni, atthato pana nāmamattakova viseso.
analyzed: yathākkamam pāṭhato pañcama chaṭṭha duka sadisāni atthato pana nāma mattakaḥ va viseso
translated: but the difference in meaning is only a matter of names.

original: Seso suviññeyyo. Chaṭṭhasattamaaṭṭhamāni.
analyzed: seso su viññeyyaḥ chaṭṭha sattama aṭṭhamāni
translated: The rest is easily understood. The sixth, seventh, and eighth dyads are finished.

original: Kilesagocchakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: kilesa gocchakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The chapter on defilements is finished.

original: Piṭṭhidukesu ādito cattāro dukā dassanenapahātabbattike, dassanenapahātabbahetuke🔽ca vuttanayena veditabbā. Kevalaṃ pana tattha paṭhamattike vuttesu dassanenapahātabbe
analyzed: piṭṭhi dukesu āditaḥ cattāro dukāḥ dassanena apahātabba ttike dassanena apahātabba hetuke  ca vutta nayena veditabbā kevalam pana tattha paṭhama ttike vuttesu dassanena apahātabbe
translated: In the case of the pairs in the back triad, the first two pairs are to be understood in the way already stated, that is, as the three ideas and the cause of the three ideas abandonable by seeing.

original: dhamme ṭhapetvā sesā idha paṭhamadukassa dutiyapade dassanenapahātabbesu pavisanti,🔽bhāvanāyapahātabbe ṭhapetvā sesā idha dutiyaduke nabhāvanāyapahātabbesu pavisanti.
analyzed: dhamme ṭhapetvā sesāḥ idha paṭhama dukassa dutiya pade dassanena apahātabbesu pavisanti  bhāvanāya apahātabbe ṭhapetvā sesāḥ idha dutiya duke na bhāvanāya apahātabbesu pavisanti
translated: But in the first pair here, all except the ideas abandonable by seeing that were mentioned in the first triad there enter here in the second place in the first pair.🔽And in the second pair here, all except the ideas abandonable by development that were mentioned in the first triad there enter here in the first place in the second pair.

original: Tattha ca dutiyattike vuttesu dassanenapahātabbahetuke ṭhapetvā sesā idha tatiyaduke🔽nadassanenapahātabbahetuke, bhāvanāyapahātabbahetuke ca ṭhapetvā sesā idha catutthaduke
analyzed: tattha ca dutiya ttike vuttesu dassanena apahātabba hetuke ṭhapetvā sesāḥ idha tatiya duke  na dassanena apahātabba hetuke bhāvanāya apahātabba hetuke ca ṭhapetvā sesāḥ idha catuttha duke
translated: And in the third pair here, all except the causes abandonable by seeing that were mentioned in the second triad there enter here in the second place in the third pair.

original: nabhāvanāyapahātabbahetukesu pavisanti.
analyzed: na bhāvanāya pahātabba hetukesu pavisanti
translated: And in the fourth pair here, all except the causes abandonable by development that were mentioned in the second triad there enter here in the first place in the fourth pair.

original: Padattho ca dassanena pahātabbo hetu etesaṃ atthīti dassanenapahātabbahetukā. Evaṃ
analyzed: padatthaḥ ca dassanena pahātabbaḥ hetu etesam atthi iti dassanena pahātabba hetukāḥ evam
translated: The meaning of the terms is this. They have a cause abandonable by seeing, thus they are with cause abandonable by seeing .

original: bhāvanāyapahātabbahetukāti etthāpi attho veditabbo. Evaṃ hi sati ahetukānaṃ aggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanāya apahātabba hetukā ti ettha api atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam hi sati ahetukānam aggahaṇam
translated: the omission of the non-root-causeless would be inexplicable.

original: siyāti ettakameva viseso. Tikadvayameva hi bhagavā desanāvilāsena cattāro duke katvā
analyzed: siyā ti ettakam eva visesaḥ tika dvayam eva hi bhagavā desanā vilāsena cattāraḥ duke katvā
translated: This is the only difference. For the Blessed One, in his skill in teaching, made four dyads by combining two dyads.

original: desesi. Sesaṃ tādisameva. Cattāro dukā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: desesi sesam tādisam eva cattāro dukā niṭṭhitā
translated: The rest is the same. The four dyads are ended.

original: Pañcapaññāsasavitakkacittesu vitakkavirahitā cittacetasikā dhammā savitakkā nāma. Vitakko, pana sesacittarūpanibbānāni ca avitakkā nāma. Pañcamaṃ.🔽Chasaṭṭhiyā savicāracittesu vicāravirahitā dhammā savicārā nāma. Vicāro, pana sesacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: pañca paññāsasa vitakka cittesu vitakka virahitā citta cetasikāḥ dhammā sa vitakkāḥ nāma vitakko pana sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni ca avitakkāḥ nāma pañcamaṃ  cha saṭṭhiyā sa vicāra cittesu vicāra virahitā dhammā sa vicārāḥ nāma vicāro pana sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: In the fifty-five kinds of consciousness accompanied by applied thought, the states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants devoid of applied thought are called “accompanied by applied thought.” But applied thought itself, and the rest of the states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants, and also the kinds of materiality and the supramundane states, are called “unaccompanied by applied thought.” The fifth dyad is ended.

original: ca avicārā nāma. Sesaṃ idha, anantare vuttaduke ca vitakkattike vuttānusārena ñātabbaṃ. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: ca avicārā nāma sesam idha anantare vutta duke ca vitakka ttike vutta anusārena ñātabbam chaṭṭham
translated: In the sixty-six kinds of consciousness accompanied by sustained thought, the states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants devoid of sustained thought are called “accompanied by sustained thought.” But sustained thought itself, and the rest of the states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants, and also the kinds of materiality and the supramundane states, are called “unaccompanied by sustained thought.” The rest should be understood here in the same way as in the case of the dyad of applied thought. The sixth dyad is ended.

original: Ito paresu sappītikaduko, pītisahagataduko ca samānatthāva, te ca sukhasahagataupekkhāsahagatadukā
analyzed: itas paresu sappītika duko pīti sahagata duko ca samāna thā ava te ca sukha sahagata aupekkhā sahagata dukā
translated: The dyads of “with happiness” and “with joy” are the same in meaning. And they are the same as the dyads of “with pleasure” and “with equanimity.”

original: cāti cattāropi dukā pītittike vuttanayāva. Kevalaṃ panetesaṃ dukānaṃ paṭhamaṃ padaṃ🔽tattha pavisati, pītittike itarītarapadadvayasaṅgahitā, asaṅgahitā ca sabbe atthā
analyzed: ca ati cattāraḥ api dukā kevalam pana itesam dukānam paṭhamam padam  tattha pavisati itarītara pada dvaya saṅgahitā asaṅgahitā ca sabbe atthā
translated: The four dyads are like the way the triad of joy is stated. But the first term of these dyads🔽enters into the first term of the triad of joy. The second and third terms of the dyads are included and not included in the second and third terms of the triad of joy.

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayenettha dukānaṃ dutiyapadesu atthato saṅgahitā, ime ca nippadesadukāti
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayena ittha dukānam dutiya padesu atthataḥ saṅgahitāḥ ime ca nippadesa dukā ti
translated: All the meanings are stated below. Here the second terms of the dyads are included in the second terms of the triad of joy. And these dyads are dyads without a demonstrative pronoun.

original: ayameva viseso. Sattamaaṭṭhamanavamadasamā.🔽Tadanantaresu kāmāvacarāti ettha “heṭṭhato avīcinirayaṃ pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito
analyzed: ayam eva visesaḥ sattama aṭṭhama navama dasamā  tad anantaresu ettha ha iṭṭhatas avīcinirayam pariyantam karitvā uparitas
translated: This is the only difference. The seventh, eighth, and ninth months are the same.

original: paranimmitavasavattī deve anto karitvā yaṃ tasmiṃ antare etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā”ti🔽evaṃ pāḷiyaṃ paricchinnānaṃ catunnaṃ apāyānaṃ, manussānaṃ, channaṃ devalokānañca
analyzed: deve antar karitvā yam tasmin antare etthāvacarāḥ ettha pariyāpannā ati  evam pāḷiyam paricchinnānam catunnam apāyānam manussānam channam deva lokānam ca
translated: In the next three dyads, “sense-desire realm” is the elevenfold sense-desire existence, which is defined in the text thus: “Below, with the Avīci hell as the limit; above, with the gods who control others’ sense-desires as the limit; what is in between, what is included here, is called the sense-desire realm” .

original: vasena okāsato ekādasavidho kāmabhavo “kāmo”ti vuccati uttarapadalopena yathā “rūpūpapattiyā”tiādīsu
analyzed: vasena okāsataḥ ekādasavidho kāma bhavo kāmo ti vuccati uttara pada lopena yathā
translated: It is so called by the elision of the middle term, as in such passages as “for rebirth in the form realm” .

original: rūpabhavo “rūpa”nti. Tasmiṃ kāme avacaranti pavattantīti kāmāvacarā. Yebhuyyato cetaṃ
analyzed: rūpa bhavaḥ tasmin kāme avacaranti pavattanti iti kāma avacarāḥ
translated: “The becoming of the form” is “form.” They “have their resort in” or “occur in” those sensual desires, thus they are “sensual-desire-world-sphere.”🔽This is said of the majority.

original: vuttaṃ rūpārūpesu cetesañca idha pavattito “thalacarā”tiādīsu viya. Kāmabhavasaṅkhāte
analyzed: vuttam rūpa arūpesu idha pavattitaḥ thala carāti ādīsu viya kāma bhava saṅkhāte
translated: But in the case of the immaterial, they “have their resort in” the sensual desires called “becoming,” thus they are “sensual-desire-world-sphere” too, like the “land-walkers” , etc.,

original: vā kāme paṭisandhiṃ avacārentītipi kāmāvacarā, kusalākusalāni. Uddhaccasahagatacittaṃ🔽pana abyākatacittasadisaṃ. Tadāyattatāya, ārammaṇakaraṇavasena vā kilesakāmo ettha
analyzed: vā kāme paṭisandhim kāma avacarā kusala akusalāni uddhacca sahagata cittam  pana abyākata citta sadisam tad āyatta tāya ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena vā kilesa kāmaḥ ettha
translated: or they “have their resort in” rebirth-linking in the sensual desires called “sensual-desire becoming,” thus they are “sensual-desire-world-sphere,” namely, the profitable and unprofitable.🔽But the consciousness associated with agitation is like the indeterminate consciousness.🔽Or the sensual desire that is a defilement has its resort here in that, either because it is dependent on that or because it makes that its object, thus it is “sensual-desire-world-sphere.”

original: avacaratītipi kāmāvacaraṃ. Kāmañcesa rūpārūpāvacaradhammesupi avacarati, ruḷhito
analyzed: avacarati itipi kāma avacaram rūpa arūpa avacara dhammesu pi avacarati
translated: Though in fact it has its resort in the states of the fine-material and immaterial kinds too,

original: pana “vadatīti vaccho”tiādīsu viya ime eva “kāmāvacarā”ti vuccanti. Apica kāmataṇhā
analyzed: pana vadati iti vacchā iti ādīsu ime eva vuccanti apica kāma taṇhā
translated: it is only these that are called “sensual-desire-world-sphere” in the way already stated, just as in the passage, “A calf has its resort in the cow” , etc.,🔽or in the passage, “A calf is called a ‘walker’ because it has its resort in walking” , etc.

original: rūpataṇhā arūpataṇhāti ettha vuttakāmataṇhāsaṅkhāto kāmo ettha avacaratītipi kāmāvacarā.
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā arūpa taṇhā ti ettha vutta kāma taṇhā saṅkhāto kāmaḥ ettha avacarati iti pi kāmāvacarā
translated: Besides, sensual desire has its resort here, thus it is “sensual-desire-world-sphere,” where “sensual desire” is craving as stated in the passage, “Craving has what is wished for as its specific nature” .

original: Evaṃ brahmānaṃ vimānābharaṇādīsu chandarāgassāpi kāmataṇhābhāvo siddho, rūpataṇhāvisayānampi
analyzed: evam brahmānam vimāna ābharaṇa ādīsu chanda rāgassa api kāma taṇhā bhāvo siddhaḥ
translated: So it is established that the desire and lust for divine mansions, ornaments, etc., is craving for sensual desires, and that the desire and lust for the objects of the craving for fine-material existence is craving for fine-material existence.

original: ca brahmānaṃ kammajarūpādīnaṃ kāmataṇhāyapi visayatāya kāmāvacaratā siddhā hoti.🔽Na rūpārūpāvacarānaṃ tadabhāvato tadaññe na kāmāvacarā. Iminā nayena rūpāvacarādidukānampi🔽padattho yathārahaṃ ñātabbo. Tattha catupaññāsa kāmāvacaracittāni, sabbañca rūpaṃ
analyzed: ca brahmānam visaya tāya kāmāvacara tā siddhā hoti  na tad abhāvato tad aññe na kāmāvacarāḥ iminā nayena  padatthaḥ yathāraham ñātabbo tattha catupaññāsa kāmāvacara cittāni sabbañca rūpam
translated: And since they are objects of craving for sensual desires in the case of the kamma-born materiality, etc., of the Brahmās, it is established that they belong to the sensual-desire element.🔽They are not of the fine-material and immaterial elements because they are not of those two kinds. The meaning of the terms in the other dyads should be understood according to the method stated in each case.

original: kāmāvacarā nāma. Sesacittanibbānāni na kāmāvacarā nāma. Cetasikesu vattabbaṃ pariyāpannaduke🔽eva āvi bhavissati. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: kāmāvacarāḥ nāma sesa citta nibbānāni na kāmāvacarāḥ nāma cetasikesu vattabbam pariyāpanna duke  eva āvi bhavissati ekādasamam
translated: Herein, the fifty-four kinds of consciousness belonging to the sense sphere and all materiality are called “of the sense sphere.” The remaining kinds of consciousness and Nibbāna are not of the sense sphere. What should be said under the heading of “associated” will be made clear in the dyads that follow.

original: Pannarasa rūpāvacaracittāni rūpāvacarā nāma. Sesacittarūpanibbānāni na rūpāvacarā nāma. Dvādasamaṃ.
analyzed: rūpāvacara cittāni rūpāvacarāḥ nāma sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni na rūpāvacarāḥ nāma dvādasamam
translated: Eleven kinds of consciousness belonging to the fine-material sphere are called “of the fine-material sphere.” The remaining kinds of consciousness and materiality and Nibbāna are not of the fine-material sphere.

original: Dvādasa arūpāvacaracittāni arūpāvacarā nāma. Sesacittarūpanibbānāni na arūpāvacarā nāma. Terasamaṃ.
analyzed: dvādasa arūpāvacara cittāni arūpāvacarāḥ nāma sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni na arūpāvacarāḥ nāma terasamam
translated: Twelve kinds of consciousness belonging to the immaterial sphere are called “of the immaterial sphere.” The remaining kinds of consciousness and materiality and Nibbāna are not of the immaterial sphere.

original: Tebhūmakavaṭṭe pariyāpannā antogadhāti pariyāpannā, lokiyadhammāva. Tattha na pariyāpannāti
analyzed: tebhūmakavaṭṭe pariyāpannā antogadhā ati pariyāpannā lokiya dhammā va tattha na pariyāpannā ati
translated: In the dyads of the three planes, those that are included in the three planes are “included,” that is, they are mundane states. Those that are not included there are not included.

original: apariyāpannā, lokuttarā. Cetasikesu pana kāmāvacarādidukānaṃ catunnampi sādhāraṇo
analyzed: a pariyāpannā lokuttarā cetasikesu pana kāmāvacara ādi dukānam catunnam pi sādhāraṇaḥ
translated: and the supramundane are not included.

original: vinicchayo evaṃ veditabbo – akusalacetasikā kāmāvacarāva, appamaññā kāmarūpāvacarā,
analyzed: vinicchayaḥ evam veditabbo akusala cetasikā kāmāvacarā ava appamaññā kāmarūpāvacarā
translated: But the exposition of the four kinds of consciousnesses belonging to the sense sphere, etc., should be understood thus. The unprofitable consciousnesses are included in the sense sphere only. The four measureless states are included in the sense-sphere and fine-material-sphere.

original: viratiyo pana kāmāvacarapariyāpannā, vitakkavicārapītiyo pana kāmarūpāvacarapariyāpannā,
analyzed: viratiyaḥ pana kāmāvacara pariyāpannā vitakka vicāra pītiyaḥ pana kāma rūpāvacara pariyāpannā
translated: The abstinences are included in the sense sphere only. Applied thought, sustained thought, and happiness are included in the sense sphere and the fine-material sphere.

original: sesā catubhūmakāti. Cuddasamaṃ.🔽Vaṭṭamūlaṃ chindantā nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vaṭṭato nīyantīti niyyānikā, cattāri
analyzed: sesā  vaṭṭa mūlam chindantā nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā vaṭṭataḥ nīyanti iti niyyānikā cattāri
translated: The rest are in all four planes.

original: lokuttaramaggacittāni. Iminā lakkhaṇena na niyyantīti aniyyānikā, sesacittarūpanibbānāni.🔽Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Pañcadasamaṃ.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva pañcadasamam
translated: 14. The supramundane are called “leading out” because they lead out from the round of rebirths by cutting its root, making nibbana their object. The rest are not leading out because they do not have that characteristic.

original: Cutiyā vā attano vā pavattiyā anantaraṃ phaladāne niyatattā niyatā, micchattaniyatā, sammattaniyatā ca. Tathā aniyatattā aniyatā, sesadhammā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Soḷasamaṃ.
analyzed: cutiyāḥ vā attanaḥ vā pavattiyāḥ anantaram phala dāne niyata ttā niyatā micchatta niyatā sammatta niyatā ca tathā aniyata ttā aniyatā sesa dhammā sesam vutta nayam eva soḷasamam
translated: 15. The profitable and indeterminate are “determinate” because they are certain to give their fruit immediately after their occurrence, either through death or through rebirth-linking. The unprofitable are “indeterminate” because they are not certain to give their fruit immediately after their occurrence. The rest are indeterminate because they are not fruits. The rest are as already stated.🔽16. The profitable and indeterminate are “with root cause” because they have root cause. The unprofitable are “without root cause” because they have no root cause. The rest are as already stated.

original: Aññe dhamme uttaranti atikkamantīti uttarā, attānaṃ uttarituṃ samatthehi saha uttarehīti sauttarā, lokiyāva. Natthi etesaṃ uttarāti anuttarā, lokuttarā. Sattarasamaṃ.
analyzed: aññe dhamme uttaranti atikkamanti iti uttarāḥ attānam uttaritum samatthehi saha uttarehi iti sa uttarā lokiyā ava natthi etesam uttarā ati anuttarā lokuttarā sattarasamam
translated: They are “higher” because they go beyond other ideas, and they are “with what is higher” because they are able to make oneself higher. They are “not higher” because there is nothing higher than them.

original: Raṇanti kandanti etehīti raṇā, yehi abhibhūtā sattā nānappakārato paridevanti, tesaṃ
analyzed: raṇanti kandanti etehi iti raṇā yehi abhibhūtā sattā nānā pakārato paridevanti tesam
translated: They are “with conflict” because beings wail and lament through being overwhelmed by them.

original: akusalamūlānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ, tehi sampayogavasena, pahānekaṭṭhatāvasena ca saha
analyzed: adhivacanam tehi sampayoga vasena ca saha
translated: This is a term for the three roots of the unprofitable. They are “with conflict” because they are associated with that and because they are not yet abandoned.

original: raṇehīti saraṇā. Etenākārena natthi etesaṃ raṇāti araṇā.🔽Tattha dvādasa akusalacittāni saraṇā nāma. Saraṇadhammesu cettha lobhadosamohā raṇā🔽ceva saraṇā ca, tesu lobhadosā moheneva sampayogato saraṇā, tathā vicikicchuddhaccasahagatacittaṃ,
analyzed: raṇehi iti saraṇā etena akārena na atthi etesam raṇāti araṇā  tattha dvādasa akusala cittāni saraṇā nāma saraṇa dhammesu ca ittha lobha dosa mohāḥ  ca iva saraṇā ca tesu lobha dosāḥ mohena iva sampayogataḥ saraṇā tathā vicikicchu dhacca sahagata cittam
translated: They are “without conflict” because there is no conflict in them in this way.🔽Herein, the twelve unprofitable consciousnesses are called “with conflict.” And here greed, hate, and delusion are both “conflict” and “with conflict.” They are “with conflict” because they are associated with that, and because they are not yet abandoned. So too the consciousness associated with uncertainty and agitation, and that associated with them.

original: taṃsampayuttā ca. Moho pana tesu sampayogato saraṇo, diṭṭhisampayuttarāgena, pana
analyzed: tad sampayuttā ca moho pana tesu sampayogato saraṇaḥ diṭṭhi sampayutta rāgena pana
translated: But delusion is “with conflict” because it is associated with that. But with the associated greed of views, etc.,

original: bhavarāgena ca raṇabhūtena pahānekaṭṭhatāvaseneva saraṇo. Lobhadosamohamūlasampayuttesu
analyzed: bhava rāgena ca raṇa bhūtena saraṇaḥ lobha dosa moha mūla sampayuttesu
translated: and with the passion for becoming, it is a battleground because of the state of being a battleground for the abandoning of the passion for becoming.

original: pana moho lobhena ceva dosena ca, sesā lobhamohena ceva dosamohena ca sampayogato
analyzed: pana mohaḥ lobhena ca iva dosena ca sesāḥ lobha mohena ca iva dosa mohena ca sampayogato
translated: But in the case of those associated with the roots of greed, hate, and delusion, delusion is associated with greed and with hate, and the rest are associated with greed and delusion and with hate and delusion.🔽So it should be understood that they are battlegrounds through association. All profitable and indeterminate consciousness, and materiality and Nibbāna, are called “not a battleground.”

original: saraṇāti veditabbā. Sabbāni kusalābyākatacittāni, rūpanibbānāni ca araṇā nāma. Cetasikesu
analyzed: saraṇā ati veditabbā sabbāni kusala abyākata cittāni rūpa nibbānāni ca araṇā nāma cetasikesu
translated: But among the mental factors,

analyzed: pana akusalā pana akusalā pana dvidhā api honti iti aṭṭhārasamam
translated: the unprofitable are battlegrounds, the profitable and indeterminate are not battlegrounds, and those of the third type are of both kinds. The eighteenth

analyzed: suttantika duka mātika attha vaṇṇanā  sutta antika dukesu vedeti vividhena vā ākārena jānāti iti vijjā vipassanā ñāṇa manaḥ maya iddhi cha abhiññā vasa ppavattā
translated: The “Questions on the Schedule in Triads” in the Suttanta

analyzed: vijjā tam vā vijjam sampayoga vasena vijjā bhāginaḥ aṭṭhavidha vijjā sampayutta dhammā  tāsu yā kāci ekā vijjā vijjā sesāḥ vijjā bhāgino ti evam vijjā api vijjā sampayutta dhammā api
translated: Or alternatively, they are called “associated with knowledge” because they associate with that knowledge by way of association.🔽And of these, any one of the eight kinds of knowledge is knowledge, while the rest are associated with knowledge.

original: vijjābhāginotveva veditabbā, idha pana vijjāsampayuttā dhammāva adhippetā. Na vijānātīti
analyzed: vijjā bhāgino tu eva veditabbāḥ idha pana vijjā sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ ava adhippetāḥ na vijānāti iti
translated: So knowledge and the states associated with knowledge should be understood as “associated with knowledge.” But here only the states associated with knowledge are intended.

analyzed: avijjā catur acca chādaka vasena catubbidhaḥ moho tasmin avijjā bhāge avijjā koṭṭhāse  avijjā sabhāve vattanti iti avijjā bhāginaḥ tāḥ eva avijjā tam vā avijjam sampayoga vasena  bhajanti iti pi avijjā bhāginaḥ avijjā sampayutta dhammā evam avijjā api avijjā sampayutta dhammā api
translated: Ignorance is non-cognizance. It is delusion in the fourfold aspect of concealing the four truths.🔽It is called “associated with ignorance” because it occurs in the portion of ignorance, in the category of ignorance, in the nature of ignorance.🔽Or alternatively, it is called “associated with ignorance” because it associates with that ignorance by way of association.

original: avijjābhāginotveva veditabbā, idha pana avijjāsampayuttadhammāva adhippetā.
analyzed: avijjā bhāginaḥ tu eva veditabbāḥ idha pana avijjā sampayutta dhammā ava adhippetā
translated: So ignorance and the states associated with ignorance should be understood as “associated with ignorance.” But here only the states associated with ignorance are intended.

analyzed: dvādasa akusala cittāni ca avijjā bhāginaḥ uva idha  pana avijjā sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni ca na vattabbā ava cetasikesu pana moha appamaññā

analyzed: puna an ajjhottharaṇa vasena kilesa andhakāram a samattha tāya upamā
translated: Again, because of their inability to dispel the darkness of defilement without leaving any remainder, the three kinds of knowledge in the three paths are like lightning flashes.

original: etesanti vijjūpamā, ādito tīsu maggesu ñāṇaṃva. Nissesaṃ viddhaṃsanasamatthatāya
analyzed: etesanti vijju upamāḥ āditas tīsu maggesu ñāṇam va nissesam viddhaṃsana samattha tāya
