analyzed: yathāsakam sacca chādaka kilesa andhakāram vidhamitvā tīsu maggesu yathākkamam uppannesu
translated: when the darkness of defilement that conceals the four truths is dispelled by the three paths in due succession,

original: cattāri saccāni pākaṭāni honti, tesu niruddhesu puna avasiṭṭhakilesandhakāro catusaccaṃ
analyzed: cattāri saccāni pākaṭāni honti tesu niruddhesu puna catu saccam
translated: the four truths become evident to the man of insight,

original: paṭicchādeti, tasmā tīsu maggesu paññā vijjūpamā vuttā. Yathā pana vajirassa abhejjo
analyzed: paṭicchādeti tasmā tīsu maggesu paññā vijju upamā vuttā yathā pana vajirassa abhejjaḥ
translated: but when the three paths cease, the remaining darkness of defilement conceals the four truths again. That is why the three kinds of knowledge in the three paths are called like lightning flashes.🔽But the knowledge in the path of arahatship is like a thunderbolt, because it is unhindered in its penetration of the four truths.

original: pāsāṇo nāma natthi, tañca nissesato vajiraṃ khepeti, vajirena ca gatamagge pāsāṇassa🔽puna pākatikabhāvo natthi, evaṃ arahattamaggañāṇassa avajjhakileso nāma natthi, tañca
analyzed: pāsāṇaḥ nāma natthi tat ca nissesataḥ vajiram khepeti vajirena ca gata magge pāsāṇassa  puna pākatika bhāvaḥ natthi evam arahatta magga ñāṇassa avajjha kileso nāma natthi tat ca
translated: There is no stone that is not split by the diamond, and when the diamond has gone there is no re-forming of the stone,

original: nissesato arahattamaggañāṇaṃ khepeti, tena ca khepite kilese avasiṭṭhakilesābhāvato
analyzed: nissesataḥ arahatta magga ñāṇam khepeti tena ca khepite kilese avasiṭṭha kilesa abhāvataḥ
translated: so too there is no defilement that is not cut off by the knowledge of the path of arahatship, and when that has cut it off there is no remaining of the defilements to be cut off again,

original: tassa puna paccudāvattanaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā catutthamagge paññā vajirūpamā vuttā.
analyzed: tassa puna paccudāvattanam nāma natthi tasmā catuttha magge paññā vaji rūpamā vuttā
translated: so the wisdom of the fourth path is said to be like a diamond.

original: Paññā eva hettha siyā vijjūpamā, siyā na vattabbā ca hoti. Sesacetasikacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: paññā eva ha ittha siyā vijju upamā siyā na vattabbā ca hoti sesa cetasika citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: Wisdom here may be like lightning or it may not be so described. The rest of the mental factors, consciousness, and materiality, and Nibbāna

original: pana sabbāni na vattabbāneva. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: pana sabbāni na vattabbāni iva dutiyam
translated: are not so described.

original: Bālesu ṭhitattā, yattha ṭhitā tadupacārena bālā, bālakarattā vā bālā, dvādasākusalacittāni.
analyzed: bālesu yattha ṭhitā tad upacārena bālā bālaka rattā vā bālā dvādasa akusala cittāni
translated: Because of being in fools, because of being in what is called after them, or because of being the colour of fools, the twelve unprofitable consciousnesses are fools.

original: Idha pana ahirikañca anottappañca bālā nāma. Paṇḍitesu ṭhitattā paṇḍitā, paṇḍitakarattā
analyzed: idha pana ahirikañca anottappañca bālāḥ nāma paṇḍitesu ṭhita ttā paṇḍitā paṇḍitakara ttā
translated: But here shamelessness and lack of abashment are called “fools,” and because of being in the wise, because of being the colour of the wise,

original: vā paṇḍitā, ekavīsati kusalacittāni. Idha pana hirī ca ottappañca paṇḍitā nāma. Sesacittarūpanibbānāni
analyzed: vā paṇḍitāḥ ekavīsati kusala cittāni idha pana hirī ca ottappañca paṇḍitāḥ nāma sesa citta rūpa nibbānāni
translated: and the wise are the twenty-one kinds of profitable cognizance. But here the wise are conscience and shame. The remaining kinds of cognizance, materiality, and Nibbāna

original: na vattabbāni. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: na vattabbāni sesam su viññeyyam eva tatiyam
translated: are not to be called either. The rest is quite clear. Third Grouping.

original: Kaṇhāti kāḷakā, cittassa apabhassarabhāvakaraṇā. Sukkāti odātā, pabhassarabhāvakaraṇā. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ bāladukasadisameva. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: kaṇhā ati kāḷakā cittassa a pabhassara bhāva karaṇā sukkā ati odātā pabhassara bhāva karaṇā sesam sabbam bāla duka sadisam eva catuttham
translated: Black is dark, causing the appearance of the mind to be dark. White is bright, causing the appearance of the mind to be bright. The rest is all like the fool’s talk. Fourth Grouping.

original: Idha ceva samparāye ca tapentīti tapanīyā. Na tapanīyā atapanīyā. Sesaṃ bāladukasadisameva. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: idha ca iva samparāye ca tapenti iti tapanīyāḥ na tapanīyā a tapanīyā sesam bāladuka sadisam eva pañcamam
translated: They scorch here and now and in the other world, thus they are scorchers . Not scorchers are non-scorchers . The rest is all like the fool’s talk. Fifth Grouping.

original: “Sirivaḍḍhako dhanavaḍḍhako”tiādayo viya vacanamattameva adhikāraṃ katvā pavattā
analyzed: sirivaḍḍhakaḥ dhanavaḍḍhaka uti ādayaḥ vacana mattam eva adhikāram katvā pavattā
translated: The words ‘wealth-increasing’ and ‘prosperity-increasing’ are used in the sense of mere words,

original: adhivacanā nāma. Nāmadheyyanti tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ nāmāni. Tāni catubbidhāni sāmaññanāmaṃ🔽guṇanāmaṃ kittimanāmaṃ opapātikanāmanti. Tattha paṭhamakappikesu mahājanena sammannitvā
analyzed: adhivacanā nāma nāmadheyyanti tesam tesam dhammānam nāmāni tāni catubbidhāni sāmañña nāmam 🔽guṇa nāmam kittima nāmam opapātika nāmanti tattha paṭhama kappikesu mahājanena sammannitvā
translated: and they are called ‘designations’ . ‘Name’ is the names of the various ideas. They are of four kinds, namely, common-characteristic names,🔽special-characteristic names, fame names, and apparition names. Herein, in the first group of five, ‘wealth-increasing’ and ‘prosperity-increasing’ are common-characteristic names since they are common to many ideas. ‘

original: ṭhapitattā “mahāsammato”ti rañño nāmanti evarūpaṃ sāmaññanāmaṃ nāma. “Dhammakathiko🔽paṃsukūliko kāḷo rasso”ti evarūpaṃ guṇato āgataṃ, “bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”tiādīnipi
analyzed: ṭhapita ttā mahā sammataḥ ti raññaḥ nāman ti evarūpam sāmañña nāmam nāma dhamma kathiko  paṃsukūlikaḥ kāḷaḥ rasso ti evarūpam guṇataḥ āgatam bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ iti ādīni pi
translated: The name of the king Mahāsammata is a name of common usage. The name of a monk who is a preacher of the Dhamma,

original: tathāgatassa anekāni nāmasatāni guṇanāmaṃ nāma. Yaṃ pana jātassa kumārassa ñātakā
analyzed: tathāgatassa anekāni nāma satāni guṇa nāmam nāma yam pana jātassa kumārassa ñātakā
translated: a refuse-rag wearer, a dark-skinned man, a short man, is a name that has come about through a special quality. The names of the Tathāgata such as “The Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One” are names that have come about through special qualities.

original: kappetvā pakappetvā “ayaṃ asuko nāmā”ti nāmaṃ karonti, idaṃ kittimanāmaṃ nāma. Yā
analyzed: kappetvā pakappetvā ayam asukaḥ nāma ati nāmam karonti idam kittima nāmam nāma yā
translated: But the name that relatives give to a boy at his birth, after they have cut his umbilical cord and washed him, is a name of fame.

original: pana purimapaññatti aparapaññattiyaṃ nipatati, seyyathidaṃ – purimakappepi cando🔽cando eva, etarahipi anāgatepi cando eva. Tathā “sūriyo samuddo pathavī rūpaṃ vedanā
analyzed: pana purima paññatti apara paññattiyam nipatati seyyathidam purima kappe pi cando  cando eva anāgate pi cando eva tathā sūriyo samuddo pathavī rūpam vedanā
translated: But the name that is included in a previous designation and is included in a subsequent designation is a name that has come down through a succession of teachers. For example, in the past the moon was called Canda,

original: saññā saṅkhārā viññāṇaṃ nibbāna”ntievamādi opapātikanāmaṃ nāma. Tāni puna vijjamānapaññatti
analyzed: saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam nibbānam ti evamādi opapātika nāmam nāma tāni puna vijjamāna paññatti
translated: and in the future it will be called Canda. And so too the sun, the ocean, the earth, material form, feeling, perception, formations, consciousness, and Nibbāna. Such names are names that have come down through a succession of teachers.

original: avijjamānapaññatti vijjamānenaavijjamānapaññatti avijjamānenavijjamānapaññatti vijjamānenavijjamānapaññatti
analyzed: a vijjamāna paññatti vijjamānena a vijjamāna paññatti avijjamānena vijjamāna paññatti vijjamānena vijjamāna paññatti
translated: Description of what is not found is threefold as description of what is not found by what is found, description of what is not found by what is not found, and description of what is not found by what is both found and not found.🔽Description of what is found is threefold as description of what is found by what is found, description of what is found by what is not found, and description of what is found by what is both found and not found.

original: avijjamānenaavijjamānapaññattīti evaṃ nāmapaññattivasena chabbidhāni honti.🔽Tattha paramatthato upalabbhamānā yathāvuttadvāsattatividhā nāmarūpadhammā vijjamānā
analyzed: avijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti iti evam nāma paññatti vasena chabbidhāni honti  tattha paramatthataḥ upalabbhamānāḥ yathāvutta dvāsattatividhāḥ nāma rūpa dhammāḥ vijjamānā
translated: So they are of six kinds as description of name.🔽Herein, the seventy-two kinds of states consisting of mentality-materiality that are found in the ultimate sense are called “what is found.”

original: nāma, tesaṃ pakārehi ñāpanato paññatti vijjamānapaññatti nāma, “cittaṃ phasso pathavī🔽rūpaṃ nibbāna”ntiādayo paramatthavācakā saddā. Upādinnanāmarūpadhamme pana upādāya
analyzed: nāma tesam pakārehi ñāpanato paññatti vijjamānapaññatti nāma cittam phassaḥ pathavī  rūpam nibbāna nti ādayo saddāḥ upādinna nāma rūpa dhamme pana upādāya
translated: The description of them by means of their synonyms is called “description of what is found.” Such terms as “mind,” “contact,” “earth,” “materiality,” “Nibbāna,” are terms that express ultimate realities.

original: paññattā sattapuggalaitthipurisadevamanussatiracchānādibhedā, anupādinnarūpadhamme
analyzed: paññattā satta puggala aitthi purisa deva manussa tiracchāna ādi bhedāḥ an upādinna rūpa dhamme
translated: But the seven kinds of persons, namely, the four fruitions, the sekha, and the puthujjana, are described by means of the aggregates that are clung to .

original: upādāya paññattā bhūmipabbatarukkhasakaṭacandasūriyanakkhattadisākālakasiṇādibhedā🔽ca paramatthato anupalabbhamānā avijjamānā nāma, tesaṃ paññatti avijjamānapaññatti
analyzed: upādāya paññattā bhūmi pabbata rukkha sakaṭa canda sūriya nakkhatta disā kāla kasiṇa ādi bhedā 🔽ca paramatthataḥ anupalabbhamānāḥ avijjamānāḥ nāma tesam paññatti avijjamāna paññatti
translated: The various kinds of materiality that are not clung to, namely, the earth kasiṇa, the wall kasiṇa, the charcoal kasiṇa, the blue kasiṇa, and so on, are described by means of the materiality that is clung to.🔽The various kinds of materiality that are not clung to, namely, the earth kasiṇa, the wall kasiṇa, the charcoal kasiṇa, the blue kasiṇa, and so on, are described by means of the materiality that is clung to.🔽The various kinds of materiality that are not clung to, namely, the earth kasiṇa, the wall kasiṇa, the charcoal kasiṇa, the blue kasiṇa, and so on, are described by means of the materiality that is clung to.🔽The various kinds of materiality that are not clung to, namely, the earth kasiṇa, the wall kasiṇa, the charcoal kasiṇa, the blue kasiṇa, and so on, are described by means of the materiality that is clung to.

analyzed: nāma tathā attā bhūmi iti ādayaḥ attha paññatti vācakā saddā ca  vijjamāna attha vācakā saddāḥ nāma purisassa cittam
translated: So too, such terms as “the self is the earth” and so on are terms that express a designation of an existent meaning. Terms that express a designation of a non-existent meaning are such terms as “the man’s mind,”

Evaṃ chabbidhāpi cetā adhippāyaṃ viññāpetukāmatācittasamuṭṭhāpitasaviññattisaddānusārena🔽ñātasaṅketassa sotaviññāṇavīthianantaraṃ uppannehi manodvārikaviññāṇehi “imassedaṃ
analyzed: megha vaṇṇaḥ ti ādīsu nāma citta lahu tā pathavī gandhaḥ iti ādi  vijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti nāma manussa sarīram rukkha sākhāti ādi avijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti  nāma evam chabbidhā api cetāḥ adhippāyam viññā petu kāma tā citta samuṭṭhāpita sa viññatti sadda anusārena  ñāta saṅketassa sota viññāṇa vīthi anantaram uppannehi manodvārika viññāṇehi imassa idam

Terms that express a designation of a non-existent and an existent are such terms as “the human body,” “the branch of a tree” and so on.

original: atthassa ñāpanato “nāmapaññattī”ti vuccanti, tesaṃ adhivacanānaṃ pathā atthā adhivacanapathā,
analyzed: atthassa ñāpanataḥ nāma paññattī iti vuccanti tesam adhivacanānam pathā atthāḥ adhivacana pathā
translated: They are called “verbal expressions” because they express the meaning. The “paths of verbal expression” are the meanings of those expressions.

original: sammutiparamatthabhedā sabbe dhammā saddavacanīyasabhāvā. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: sammuti paramattha bhedā sabbe dhammā sadda vacanīya sabhāvā chaṭṭham
translated: All ideas are expressible by terms, being divided into conventional and ultimate. The sixth

original: Ito paraṃ dve dukā adhivacanadukasadisāva, kevalaṃ padatthamattameva viseso. Tattha🔽abhisaṅkharontīti saṅkhārāti evaṃ niddhāretvā sahetukaṃ katvā vuccamānā nirutti nāma,
analyzed: itas param dve dukā kevalam padattha mattam eva visesaḥ tattha  abhisaṅkharonti iti saṅkhārāḥ ati evam niddhāretvā sa hetukam katvā vuccamānā nāma
translated: The next two dyads are similar to the dyad on verbal expression. Only the word-meaning is different. Herein,🔽“They form , thus they are formations” : when this is stated with cause, it is called “verbal description” .

original: “takko vitakko saṅkappo”ti evaṃ tena tena pakārena ñāpanato paññatti nāma, yathāvuttanāmapaññattiyova.🔽Na hi adhivacananiruttipaññattīsu atthato kocipi bhedo atthi, nibbattinimittabhedadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: takkaḥ vitakkaḥ saṅkappo ti evam tena tena pakārena ñāpanato paññatti nāma yathā vutta nāma paññattiyaḥ uva  na hi adhivacana nirutti paññattīsu atthataḥ koci pi bhedaḥ atthi nibbatti nimitta bheda dassana ttham
translated: “Thinking, pondering, planning” : because of the expression of this or that, it is called “verbal designation” . The verbal expression and the verbal designation are just the verbal expression and the verbal designation stated above.🔽For there is no difference in meaning between verbal expression, verbal description, and verbal designation.

original: pana nesaṃ vibhāgena padattho dassito. Imesu ca tīsu dukesu paññattisahitā sabbe
analyzed: pana nesam vibhāgena padattho dassitaḥ imesu ca tīsu dukesu paññatti sahitā sabbe
translated: But the word-meaning is shown by the analysis in order to show the difference in the reason for the derivation. And in these three dyads all ideas are included together with the verbal designation.

original: dhammā labbhanti, anantare nāmarūpaduke paññattirahitāti ime cattāro dukā imesu suttantikadukesu🔽nippadesā, sesā pana aṭṭhatiṃsāpi sappadesāti veditabbā. Sattamaṭṭhamāni.
analyzed: dhammā labbhanti anantare nāma rūpa duke paññatti rahitā ati ime cattāro dukā imesu suttantika dukesu  nippadesā sesā pana aṭṭhatiṃsā api sa ppadesā ti veditabbā sattama aṭṭhamāni
translated: and ideas are not found, and in the next two, the two on mentality-materiality, there is no description. These four dyads are without description in these Thread-dyads.🔽The remaining thirty-eight are with description. The seventh section is finished.🔽

original: Nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena, namanaṭṭhena, nāmanaṭṭhena ca nāmaṃ, arūpakkhandhanibbānāni. Tāni🔽hi sabbadāpi vedanā saññā saṅkhārā viññāṇaṃ nibbānanti opapātikanāmavasena attano🔽nāmaṃ karontāva pavattanti candasūriyādayo viya. Na hi tesaṃ sāmaññaguṇakittimavasena
analyzed: nāma karaṇa ṭhena namana ṭṭhena nāmana ṭṭhena ca nāmam arūpa khandha nibbānāni tāni  hi sabbadā api vedanā saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam nibbānam ti opapātika nāma vasena attanaḥ  nāmam karontā ava pavattanti canda sūriya ādayaḥ viya na hi tesam sāmañña guṇa kittima vasena
translated: The immaterial aggregates and Nibbāna are called “name” in the sense of naming, in the sense of bowing down, and in the sense of bending.

original: nāmakaraṇakiccaṃ atthīti. Evaṃ nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena nāmaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: nāmakaraṇa kiccam atthi iti evam nāmakaraṇa ṭṭhena nāmam veditabbam ārammaṇa abhimukham
translated: For these are always occurring, giving themselves their own names as “feeling,” “perception,” “formations,” “consciousness,” and “Nibbāna,” just as the moon, sun, and so on, are called by their own names. For they do not have the function of naming by way of the quality of being common to all. This is how “name” should be understood in the sense of naming.

original: pana namanaṭṭhena, aññamaññaṃ tattha nāmanaṭṭhena ca cattāro arūpakkhandhāva nāmaṃ.
analyzed: pana namana ṭṭhena aññamaññam tattha nāmana ṭṭhena ca cattāro arūpa kkhandhāḥ va nāmam
translated: But only the four immaterial aggregates are “name” in the sense of bowing down to an object and in the sense of bending to each other.

original: Nibbānaṃ pana ārammaṇādhipatipaccayatāya attani anavajjadhammānaṃ nāmanaṭṭheneva
analyzed: nibbānam pana ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya tāya attani anavajja dhammānam nāmana ṭṭhena eva
translated: Nibbāna is “name” only in the sense of bending to itself as the faultless state that is the object condition.

original: nāmaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ruppanaṭṭhena rūpaṃ, rūpakkhandho. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: nāmam veditabbam ruppana ṭṭhena rūpam rūpa kkhandhaḥ navamam
translated: Materiality is to be known as the formed. The materiality aggregate is the formed. The ninth.

original: Avijjāti dukkhādipaṭicchādako sabbo moho. Bhavataṇhāti bhavapatthanāvasena pavatto
analyzed: avijjā ti dukkha ādi paṭicchādako sabbaḥ mohaḥ bhava taṇhā ti bhava patthanā vasena pavatto
translated: Ignorance is all delusion that conceals the three kinds of suffering. Craving for being is greed that occurs as desire for being.

original: lobho. Tathā appavatto panettha lobho, sesacetasikacittarūpanibbānāni ca na vattabbāni.
analyzed: lobho tathā appavattaḥ pana ittha lobho sesa cetasika citta rūpa nibbānāni ca na vattabbāni
translated: And the greed that does not occur here, and the remaining consciousness, mentality, and immaterial things, and Nibbāna, are not to be stated.

original: Ito paraṃ pana evaṃ navattabbavibhāgaṃ adassetvā padatthasarūpamattameva dassayissāma,
analyzed: itas param pana evam nava ttabba vibhāgam a dassetvā padattha sarūpam attam eva dassayissāma
translated: But from here on we shall show only the mere individual essence of the word meaning without pointing out the division of what is not to be stated in each instance as we have done here.

original: dassitāvasesā na vattabbāti gahetabbā. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: dassita avasesā na vattabbā ati gahetabbā dasamam
translated: And what has been shown should be understood as not to be stated. The tenth.

original: Bhavo vuccati sassataṃ. “Bhavissati attā ca loko cā”ti sassatavasena uppajjanakadiṭṭhi
analyzed: bhavaḥ vuccati sassatam bhavissati attā ca loko ca ati sassata vasena uppajjanaka diṭṭhi
translated: Eternalism is called “being.” The view that arises in the mode of eternity, thus: “The self and the world are eternal,”

original: bhavadiṭṭhi nāma. Vibhavo vuccati ucchedo. “Na bhavissati attā ca loko cā”ti ucchedavasena🔽uppajjanakadiṭṭhi vibhavadiṭṭhi nāma. Ubhayenāpi micchādiṭṭhi gahitā. Tathā anantaresupi
analyzed: bhavadiṭṭhi nāma vibhavaḥ vuccati ucchedaḥ na bhavissati attā ca loko ca ati uccheda vasena  uppajjanaka diṭṭhi vibhava diṭṭhi nāma ubhayena api micchādiṭṭhi gahitā tathā anantaresu pi
translated: is called the view of being. Annihilationism is called “non-being.” The view that arises in the mode of annihilation, thus: “The self and the world are not eternal,”

original: tīsu dukesu. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: tīsu dukesu ekādasamam
translated: is called the view of non-being. Both are included in wrong view. So too in the next three dyads. The eleventh.

original: Khandhapañcakaṃ “attā ca loko cā”ti gahetvā “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti pavattā diṭṭhi🔽sassatadiṭṭhi nāma. Tathā “ucchijjissatī”ti pavattā diṭṭhi ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma. “Antavā”ti
analyzed: khandha pañcakam attā ca loko ca ati gahetvā sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati pavattā diṭṭhi  sassatadiṭṭhi nāma tathā ucchijjissati iti pavattā diṭṭhi ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma antavāti
translated: Taking the five aggregates as the self and the world, the view that occurs thus, “The self and the world are eternal,”🔽is called the eternalist view . Likewise, the view that occurs thus, “They will be annihilated” is called the annihilationist view . The view that occurs thus, “The world is finite”

original: pavattā antavādiṭṭhi nāma. “Anantavā”ti pavattā anantavādiṭṭhi nāma. Pubbantaṃ anugatā🔽brahmajāle vuttanayena atītakoṭṭhāsaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattā aṭṭhārasavidhā pubbantānudiṭṭhi
analyzed: pavattā antavādiṭṭhi nāma anantavā ati pavattā anantavādiṭṭhi nāma pubbantam anugatā  brahmajāle vutta nayena atīta koṭṭhāsam ārammaṇam katvā pavattā aṭṭhārasavidhā pubbanta anudiṭṭhi
translated: is called the finite view . The view that occurs thus, “The world is infinite” is called the infinite view . The view that occurs in the past is called the view of past eternity.

original: nāma. Aparantaṃ anugatā tattheva āgatanayena anāgatakoṭṭhāsaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattā🔽catucattālīsavidhā aparantānudiṭṭhi nāma. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana brahmajāle,
analyzed: nāma aparantam anugatā tattha iva āgata nayena anāgata koṭṭhāsam ārammaṇam katvā pavattā  catucattālīsavidhā nāma ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāro pana brahmajāle
translated: In the way stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta, it occurs with reference to the past section of the round of rebirths and is of eighteen kinds. The view that occurs in the future is called the view of future eternity.

original: tadaṭṭhakathāya ca veditabbo. Dvādasamaterasamacuddasamāni.
analyzed: tad aṭṭhakathāya ca veditabbaḥ dvādasa materasama cuddasamāni
translated: In the way stated there, it occurs with reference to the future section of the round of rebirths and is of forty-four kinds. This is the brief treatment here. The detailed treatment, however, should be understood from the Brahmajāla Sutta

original: Ahirikadukaṃ, hiridukañca suviññeyyameva. Pañcadasamasoḷasamāni.
analyzed: ahirika dukam hiri dukañca su viññeyyam eva pañcadasama soḷasamāni
translated: and its commentary. The twelfth, thirteenth, and fourteenth are easy to understand. The fifteenth and sixteenth are:

original: Dukkhaṃ vaco etasmiṃ vippaṭikūlagāhimhi vipaccanīkasāte anādare puggaleti dubbaco,🔽sahadhammikaṃ dassetvā ovadiyamāne anādarakārako puggalo, tassa kammaṃ dovacassaṃ,
analyzed: dukkham vacaḥ etasmim vippaṭikūla gāhimhi vipaccanīka sāte anādare puggala iti dubbacaḥ  sahadhammikam dassetvā ovadiyamāne anādara kārako puggalo tassa kammam dovacassam
translated: Speech is painful in one who is hard to admonish, who is hard to speak to, who is uncooperative, who is hostile, who is not respectful, who is not deferential, who is not amenable to advice.🔽The state of being hard to admonish is the state of being hard to speak to, the state of being uncooperative, the state of being hostile, the state of being disrespectful, the state of being undeferential, the state of being unamenable to advice.

original: tassa bhāvo dovacassatā, anādaravasena pavattā dve paṭighacittā, taṃsampayuttā ca.
analyzed: tassa bhāvaḥ dovacassatā anādara vasena pavattā dve paṭigha cittā tad sampayuttā ca
translated: The two kinds of consciousness accompanied by agitation and accompanied by equanimity that occur in one who, when being shown what is proper, is disrespectful, and the states associated with them, are called “the state of being hard to admonish.”

original: Pāpā assaddhādayo puggalā etassa mittāti pāpamitto, tassa bhāvo pāpamittatā, pāpapuggalesu
analyzed: pāpāḥ assaddha ādayaḥ puggalāḥ etassa mittā ati pāpa mittaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ pāpa mitta tā pāpa puggalesu
translated: One who has evil friends is a person who has bad faith, etc., as friends. The state of having evil friends is the state of having bad faith, etc., as friends.

original: daḷhabhattivasena, kāyacittehi taṃsevanātanninnatāvasena ca pavattāni aṭṭha lobhacittāni. Sattarasamaṃ.
analyzed: daḷha bhatti vasena kāya cittehi ca pavattāni aṭṭha lobha cittāni sattarasamam
translated: The eight kinds of consciousness accompanied by greed that occur in one who associates with bad people and imitates their bodily and verbal behavior out of strong affection for them.

original: Sovacassatā, kalyāṇamittatā ca vuttapaṭipakkhavasena veditabbā. Atthato pana tathāpavattāni sahetukakāmāvacarakusalakiriyacittāni. Aṭṭhārasamaṃ.
analyzed: sovacassatā kalyāṇa mitta tā ca vutta paṭipakkha vasena veditabbā atthataḥ pana tathā pavattāni sa hetuka kāmāvacara kusala kiriya cittāni aṭṭhārasamam
translated: The opposite of the above is good friendship. As to meaning, however, it is the profitable and functional consciousnesses accompanied by non-greed that occur in one who associates with good people and imitates their bodily and verbal behavior out of strong affection for them.

original: Pañcasu, sattasu vā āpattīsu kusalabhāvo āpattikusalatā, saha vatthunā tāsaṃ āpattīnaṃ
analyzed: pañcasu sattasu vā āpattīsu kusala bhāvaḥ āpatti kusala tā saha vatthunā tāsam āpattīnam
translated: The state of being skilled in offenses is the state of being skilled in the five or seven classes of offenses, together with the bases for them.

original: āpajjanaparicchedajānanavasena pavattā kāmāvacarajavanapaññā. Āpattīhi vuṭṭhāne kusalabhāvo
analyzed: āpajjana pariccheda jānana vasena pavattā kāmāvacara javana paññā āpattīhi vuṭṭhāne kusala bhāvaḥ
translated: Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the five kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in the clearing up of offenses🔽is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in attainment is the skill in attainment. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.

Ekūnavīsatimaṃ.🔽Samāpajjitabbato samāpatti, tāsu lokiyalokuttarāsu savitakkasavicārādīsu samāpattīsu🔽kusalatā samāpattikusalatā, saha parikammena appanāparicchedajānanavasena pavattā
analyzed: āpatti vuṭṭhāna kusala tā vuṭṭhāna vidhānena saddhim āpatti vuṭṭhāna pariccheda jānana vasena  pavattā yathāvutta citta sampayutta paññāvaḥ ekūnavīsatimam  samāpajjitabbataḥ tāsu lokiya lokuttarāsu sa vitakka sa vicāra ādīsu samāpattīsu  kusala tā samāpatti kusala tā saha parikammena appanā pariccheda jānana vasena pavattā
translated: Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.

original: paññā. Samāpattīhi vuṭṭhāne kusalabhāvo samāpattivuṭṭhānakusalatā, yathāparicchinnakāleyeva🔽tāhi vuṭṭhānakapaññā kāmāvacarajavanapaññāva. Vīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: paññā samāpattīhi vuṭṭhāne kusala bhāvaḥ samāpatti vuṭṭhāna kusala tā yathā paricchinna kāleya iva  tāhi vuṭṭhānaka paññā kāmāvacara javana paññā ava vīsatimam
translated: Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.

original: Aṭṭhārasasu dhātūsu kusalabhāvo dhātukusalatā, savanadhāraṇapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇapaññā.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasasu dhātūsu kusala bhāvaḥ dhātu kusala tā savana dhāraṇa paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa paññā
translated: Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of direct-knowledge is the understanding associated with the kinds of direct-knowledge in the sense sphere.🔽Skill in the clearing up of offenses is the skill in the clearing up of offenses. Understanding consisting in the kinds of

original: Tāsaññeva dhātūnaṃ manasikāre kusalabhāvo manasikārakusalatā, tāsaṃ sammasanapaṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇapaññā.
analyzed: tāsam eva dhātūnam manasikāre kusala bhāvaḥ manasikāra kusala tā tāsam sammasana paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa paññā
translated: Skill in the elements is skill in the profitable states consisting in the attention given to the elements. The understanding that penetrates by comprehending them is the understanding of reviewing.

original: Esa nayo āyatanakusalatāyapi. Tattha hi savanadhāraṇapaccavekkhaṇā kāmāvacarāva,
analyzed: esa nayo tattha hi savana dhāraṇa paccavekkhaṇā
translated: So too with skill in the bases. Herein, the hearing, bearing in mind, and reviewing are of the sense sphere only.

original: paṭivedho lokuttarova, sammasanaṃ kāmāvacaralokuttaraṃ. Aññamaññaṃ paṭicca sahitaṃ
analyzed: paṭivedhaḥ lokuttaraḥ uva sammasanam kāmāvacara lokuttaram aññam aññam paṭicca sahitam
translated: The penetration is supramundane. The comprehending is of the sense sphere and supramundane.

original: phalaṃ uppādetīti paṭiccasamuppādo, avijjādīhi niddiṭṭho paccayasamūho, tasmiṃ dvādasaṅge🔽anulomapaṭiccasamuppāde kusalabhāvo paṭiccasamuppādakusalatā, “iminā paccayena idaṃ
analyzed: phalam uppādeti iti paṭiccasamuppādaḥ avijjā ādīhi niddiṭṭhaḥ paccaya samūhaḥ tasmin dvādasaṅge  anuloma paṭiccasamuppāde kusala bhāvaḥ paṭiccasamuppāda kusala tā iminā paccayena idam
translated: The fruit that arises in combination with the other is dependent origination. The aggregate of conditions demonstrated by ignorance, etc., is the twelve-limbed direct-order dependent origination.

original: hotī”ti jānanavasena pavattā lokiyajavanapaññāva. Ekavīsatimadvāvīsatimāni.
analyzed: hoti iti jānana vasena pavattā lokiya javana paññāve ekavīsatima dvāvīsatimāni
translated: Skill in dependent origination is skill in the profitable states consisting in the understanding of that. The mundane impulsions that occur with the knowledge “This comes to be through that condition” are the understanding of direct-order dependent origination.🔽The twenty-first and twenty-second.

original: Tiṭṭhati ettha phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti ṭhānaṃ, kāraṇaṃ, tasmiṃ ṭhāne kusalatā ṭhānakusalatā. Na ṭhāne kusalatā aṭṭhānakusalatā. Tevīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha phalam tad āyatta vutti tāyā ati ṭhānam kāraṇam tasmin ṭhāne kusala tā ṭhāna kusala tā na ṭhāne kusala tā a ṭhāna kusala tā tevīsatimam
translated: The fruit abides there, thus it is a place , a reason. Skill in that is skill in the place. Skill in what is not a place is skill in what is not a place. The twenty-third.

original: Ujubhāvo ajjavo. Mudubhāvo maddavo. Kāyacittujukatāmudukatādvayaṃ. Catuvīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: uju bhāvaḥ ajjavaḥ mudu bhāvaḥ maddavaḥ kāya citta ujuka tā muduka tā dvayam catuvīsatimam
translated: Straightness is uprightness. Softness is malleability. The two, bodily and mentally, are the twenty-fifth.

original: Adhivāsanasaṅkhātā khamanaṃ khanti, tathāpavattakāmāvacarajavanāni. Pāpato suṭṭhu
analyzed: adhivāsana saṅkhātā khamanam khanti tathā apavatta kāmāvacara javanāni pāpataḥ suṭṭhu
translated: Patience is forbearance in the sense of enduring; and also the impulsions of the fine-material sphere that occur in that way. The twenty-eighth is🔽the state of being free from avarice, which is the absence of avarice. The twenty-ninth is🔽the state of being uncovetous, which is the absence of covetousness. analyzed: orataḥ virataḥ ti sorataḥ tassa bhāvaḥ soraccam kāya vacī manaḥ saṃvara sīla saṅkhātāni lokiya lokuttara javanāni pañcavīsatimam  sammoda kapiya vādi tā saṅkhātaḥ sa khila bhāvaḥ sākhalyam yathā parehi saddhim attanaḥ chiddam
translated: the state of being free from vanity, which is the absence of vanity. The thirty-seventh is🔽the state of being free from intoxication, which is the absence of intoxication. The thirty-eighth is🔽the state of being free from conceit, which is the absence of conceit. The thirty-ninth is

analyzed: vivaram na hoti evam dhamma āmisehi paṭisantharaṇam paṭicchādanam paṭisanthāraḥ āgantukassa
translated: the state of being free from presumption, which is the absence of presumption. The fortieth is🔽the state of being free from negligence, which is the absence of negligence. The forty-first is🔽the state of being free from obstinacy, which is the absence of obstinacy. The forty-second is🔽the state of being free from domineering, which is the absence of domineering. The forty-third is🔽the state of being free from contempt, which is the absence of contempt. The forty-fourth is🔽the state of being free from insolence, which is the absence of insolence. The forty-seventh is

original: hi paccuggamanapattacīvarapaṭiggahaṇaāsanadānabījanapādadhovanamakkhanādinā, pānīyena🔽āpucchanena, kāle āgatassa yāguādīnaṃ, vikāle pānakādīnañca dānena, punadivase piṇḍāya
analyzed: hi paccuggamana patta cīvara paṭiggahaṇa āsana dāna bījana pāda dhovana makkhana ādinā pānīyena 🔽āpucchanena kāle āgatassa yāgu ādīnam vikāle pānaka ādīnam ca dānena puna divase piṇḍāya
translated: the

original: caraṇaṭṭhānadassanapavesananikkhamanakālārocanādinā ca pabbajitā, gahaṭṭhānañca vinaye
analyzed: caraṇa ṭṭhāna dassana pavesana nikkhamana kāla ārocana ādinā ca pabbajitāḥ gaha ṭṭhānam ca vinaye
translated: And he should give the going-forth, the acceptance, the bowl and robes, and so on, to those who ask for them, and he should show them the place for walking and the place for meditating, and he should announce the time for going to the village for alms, the time for entering, the time for coming out, and so on.

original: āgatanayena yathānurūpaṃ āmisapaṭisanthāro kātabbo. Āgantukaṃ pana upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: āgata nayena yathānurūpam āmisa paṭisanthāro kātabbo āgantukam pana upasaṅkamitvā
translated: And he should give material assistance to householders in accordance with their deserts in the way stated in the Vinaya.

original: “tumhe katarabhāṇakā”ti apucchitvā “ācariyupajjhāyā vo kataraṃ ganthaṃ vaḷañjentī”ti🔽pucchitvā tassa visaye pañhapucchanena sace na sakkoti, sayaṃ kathetvā dānena, dhammakathanapañhavissajjanakammaṭṭhānakathanakukkuccadiṭṭhivinodanādinā,
analyzed: tumhe a pucchitvā ācariya upajjhāyāḥ vo kataram gantham vaḷañjenti iti  pucchitvā tassa visaye pañha pucchanena sace na sakkoti sayam kathetvā dānena dhamma kathana pañha vissajjana kammaṭṭhāna kathana kukkucca diṭṭhi vinodana ādinā
translated: But when a visitor comes, he should not ask him, “What reciter of the Dhamma are you?,” or “What text do your teacher and preceptor recite?”

original: parivāsādivinayakammakaraṇena, pabbājanaupasampadādinā ca dhammapaṭisanthāro kātabbo.
analyzed: parivāsa ādi vinaya kamma karaṇena pabbājana upasampad ādinā ca dhamma paṭisanthāraḥ kātabbaḥ
translated: But he should question him on the text he is studying. If he cannot answer, the other should give him a talk on generosity, virtue, and the heavens, and he should cheer him by telling him stories about the Buddha, and he should give him material assistance by providing food, and so on, and he should give him the Dhamma assistance of performing the duties of the Pātimokkha, and so on, and of giving advice, and he should give him the Dhamma assistance of the training by giving him the going forth, the full admission, and so on.

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato panāyaṃ saddhiṃ ānisaṃsadīpakavatthūhi aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana ayam saddhim ānisaṃsa dīpaka vatthūhi aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: This is the brief account. But the detailed account should be understood as given in the Book of Elevens together with the stories illustrating the benefits .

original: ñātabbo. Etasmiṃ duvidhe paṭisanthāre kusalabhāvo paṭisanthārakusalatā, tathāpavattakāmāvacarajavanāni eva. Chabbīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: ñātabbaḥ etasmin duvidhe paṭisanthāre kusala bhāvaḥ paṭisanthāra kusala tā tathā apavatta kāmāvacara javanāni eva chabbīsatimam
translated: The state of being skilled in the two kinds of assistance is assistance-skill. So too with the next two terms. The kinds of impulsions that occur in the sense sphere are the kinds of impulsions that occur in the sense sphere. The twenty-sixth.

original: Indriyesu manacchaṭṭhesu āpāthagatarūpādīsu ārammaṇesu nimittagahaṇādinā indriyasaṃvarabhedasaṅkhāto
analyzed: indriyesu manat śaṭṭhesu āpāthagata rūpa ādīsu ārammaṇesu nimitta gahaṇa ādinā indriya saṃvara bheda saṅkhāto
translated: The restraint of the faculties is the restraint of the six faculties beginning with the eye, in regard to the objects such as visible forms that have come into their range.

original: aguttadvārabhāvo indriyesu aguttadvāratā. Paṭiggahaṇaparibhogavasena bhojane mattaṃ
analyzed: agutta dvāra bhāvaḥ indriyesu agutta dvāra tā paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga vasena bhojane mattam
translated: The lack of guardedness of the doors of the sense faculties is the unguardedness of the doors of the sense faculties. It is the lack of restraint of the six faculties with mind as sixth, in regard to the objects such as visible forms that have come into focus, by way of apprehending the sign, etc.

original: ajānanabhāvo bhojane amattaññutā, tathāpavattaakusalacittāni. Sattavīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: a jānana bhāvaḥ bhojane amattaññu tā tathā apavatta akusala cittāni sattavīsatimam
translated: The lack of moderation in food is the unawareness of moderation in eating. It is the unwholesome states of consciousness that occur in that way. The twenty-seventh.

original: Anantaradukepi vuttapaṭipakkhavasena kāmāvacarasahetukakusalakiriyacittāni veditabbāni. Aṭṭhavīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: anantara duke pi vutta paṭipakkha vasena kāmāvacara sa hetuka kusala kiriya cittāni veditabbāni aṭṭhavīsatimam
translated: In the next dyad, the wholesome and functional consciousness of the sense sphere with cause should be understood by way of the opposite of what was said above. The twenty-eighth.

original: Sativippavāsasaṅkhāto muṭṭhasatibhāvo muṭṭhassaccaṃ, sabbe akusalā dhammā, asampajānanabhāvo asampajaññaṃ, moho. Ekūnatiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: sati vippavāsa saṅkhātaḥ muṭṭha sati bhāvaḥ muṭṭhassaccam sabbe akusalāḥ dhammāḥ asampajānana bhāvaḥ asampajaññam mohaḥ ekūnatiṃsatimam
translated: The confusedness of consciousness is the confusedness of mindfulness. It is all the unwholesome states of consciousness. The lack of full awareness is the lack of full awareness. It is delusion. The twenty-ninth.

original: Anantaraduke catubhūmikā satipaññāva vuttā. Tiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: anantara duke catu bhūmikā vuttā tiṃsatimam
translated: In the next dyad, mindfulness and full awareness belonging to the four planes have been mentioned. The thirtieth.

original: Appaṭisaṅkhāne appaṭivānasaṅkhāte akampiyaṭṭhena yonisodassanasaṅkhātaṃ paṭisaṅkhānameva
analyzed: a paṭisaṅkhāne a paṭivāna saṅkhāte a kampiya ṭṭhena yoniso dassana saṅkhātam paṭisaṅkhānam eva
translated: The lack of reflection is the lack of reflection in the sense of lack of resolution, which is called reflection.

original: balanti paṭisaṅkhānabalaṃ, kāmāvacarapaññāva. Sattabojjhaṅgādibhāvanāvasena pavattā
analyzed: balanti paṭisaṅkhāna balam satta bojjhaṅga ādi bhāvanā vasena pavattā
translated: The power of reviewing is understanding of the sense sphere.

original: catubhūmakadhammā bhāvanābalaṃ. Ekatiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: catu bhūmaka dhammāḥ bhāvanā balam ekatiṃsatimam
translated: The power of development is the states of the four paths.

original: Paccanīkadhamme sametīti samatho, so tividho cittasamatho adhikaraṇasamatho sabbasaṅkhārasamathoti.
analyzed: paccanīka dhamme sameti iti samatho so tividho citta samatho adhikaraṇa samatho sabba saṅkhāra samatho ti
translated: The “stilling” is serenity, which is threefold as the stilling of the cognizance, the stilling of the grounds for conceiving, and the stilling of all formations.

original: Tattha ca pubbabhāgāsu aṭṭhasamāpattīsu ekaggatā cittasamatho nāma, sammukhāvinayādi
analyzed: tattha ca pubba bhāgāsu aṭṭha samāpattīsu ekagga tā citta samathaḥ nāma sammukhā vinaya ādi
translated: Herein, unification of cognizance in the eight attainments is called the stilling of the cognizance.🔽The seven kinds of settlement of litigation are called the stilling of the grounds for conceiving.

original: sattavidho adhikaraṇasamatho nāma, nibbānaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho nāma. Idha pana
analyzed: sattavidhaḥ adhikaraṇa samathaḥ nāma nibbānam sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ nāma idha pana
translated: And extinction is called the stilling of all formations. But here

original: catubhūmako samādhi adhippeto. Aniccādivasena vividhenākārena passatīti vipassanā,
analyzed: catu bhūmako samādhi adhippeto anicca ādi vasena vividhena ākārena passati iti vipassanā
translated: concentration of the four paths is intended.

original: lokiyalokuttarā vipassanāpaññāva. Bāttiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: lokiya lokuttarā vipassanā paññā ava bāttiṃsatimam
translated: Insight is understanding consisting in insight, which is mundane or supramundane.

original: Samathova taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā puna pavattetabbassa samathassa nimittanti samathanimittaṃ. Paggāhanimittepi eseva nayo. Catubhūmakasamādhivīriyāni eva. Tettiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: samathaḥ uva tam ākāram gahetvā puna pavattetabbassa samathassa nimittan ti samatha nimittam paggāha nimitte pi esa iva nayaḥ catu bhūmaka samādhi vīriyāni eva tettiṃsatimam
translated: The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of serenity is the sign of the concentration of the four paths. The sign of change is the sign of the understanding consisting in insight of the four paths. The sign of

original: Anantaradukepi vīriyasamādhī eva vuttā. Catuttiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: vīriya samādhī eva vuttā catuttiṃsatimam
translated: In the next tetrad too energy and concentration are mentioned. The fortieth.

original: Sīlavināsikā asaṃvarasaṅkhātā sīlassa vipattīti sīlavipatti, tathāpavattā akusaladhammā. Sammādiṭṭhiyā vipatti diṭṭhivipatti, micchādiṭṭhi eva. Pañcatiṃsatimaṃ.🔽Soraccameva sīlassa sampādanato sīlaparipūraṇato sīlassa sampadāti sīlasampadā. Diṭṭhipāripūribhūtaṃ
analyzed: sīla vināsikā asaṃvara saṅkhātā sīlassa vipatti iti sīla vipatti tathā pavattā akusala dhammā sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ vipatti diṭṭhi vipatti micchādiṭṭhi eva pañcatiṃsatimam  soraccam eva sīlassa sampādanato sīla paripūraṇato sīlassa sampadā ati sīla sampadā diṭṭhi pāripūri bhūtam
translated: The failure of virtue is the failure of virtue called “non- restraint” . The unprofitable thoughts that occur in such a way are the failure of virtue. The failure of view is the failure of right view, that is, wrong view. The fiftieth.

original: ñāṇameva diṭṭhiyā sampadāti diṭṭhisampadā. Catubhūmakā sīlapaññāva. Tathā anantaradukepi. Chattiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇam eva diṭṭhiyā sampadā ti diṭṭhi sampadā catu bhūmakā sīla paññā ava tathā
translated: The virtue that is fulfilled by gentleness is the fulfilment of virtue because it accomplishes virtue, because it completes virtue. The knowledge that is the fulfilment of view is the fulfilment of view because it is the fulfilment of right view. The virtue and the understanding in four planes are the fulfilment of virtue and the fulfilment of view. In the next tetrad too it is the same. The sixtieth.

original: Visuddhibhāvaṃ sampattā sīlasaṅkhātā sīlassa visuddhi sīlavisuddhi. Nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ visuddhiṃ pāpetuṃ samatthā dassanasaṅkhātā diṭṭhiyā visuddhi diṭṭhivisuddhi. Sattattiṃsatimaṃ.
analyzed: visuddhi bhāvam sampattā sīla saṅkhātā sīlassa visuddhi sīla visuddhi nibbāna saṅkhātam visuddhim pāpetum samatthā dassana saṅkhātā diṭṭhiyā visuddhi diṭṭhi visuddhi sattattiṃsatimam
translated: The purification of virtue is the purification of virtue called “purification” . The purification of view is the purification of view called “purification” , which is capable of bringing about the purification called “Nibbāna” . The seventieth.

original: Kammassakatāsaccānulomikamaggaphalasampayuttapaññā diṭṭhi visuddhi nāma. Yathādiṭṭhissa tadanurūpaṃ padhānaṃ yathādiṭṭhissa ca padhānaṃ nāma. Aṭṭhatiṃsatimaṃ.🔽Saṃvegajanakāni jātijarābyādhimaraṇasaṅkhātāni kāraṇāni saṃvejanīyaṭṭhānāni nāma,
analyzed: kammassaka tā asacca ānulomika magga phala sampayutta paññā diṭṭhi visuddhi nāma yathā diṭṭhissa tad anurūpam padhānam yathā diṭṭhissa ca padhānam nāma aṭṭhatiṃsatimam  saṃvega janakāni jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa saṅkhātāni kāraṇāni saṃvejanīya ṭṭhānāni nāma
translated: Understanding associated with the path and fruition, which is in conformity with the truth of kamma’s ownership, is called purification by knowledge and vision. The effort that is in conformity with the view is called the effort of one who has seen the state .🔽The causes called birth, ageing, sickness, and death, which arouse a sense of spiritual urgency, are called grounds for a sense of spiritual urgency.

original: tesu jātiādipaṭiccasamuppannabhayasaṅkhātaṃ saṃvijanaṃ saṃvego nāma, tathāpavattakusalādi
analyzed: tesu jāti ādi paṭicca samuppanna bhaya saṅkhātam saṃvijanam saṃvegaḥ nāma tathā pavatta kusala ādi
translated: The sense of spiritual urgency, which is a fear of birth, etc., that arises in dependence on those grounds, is called a sense of spiritual urgency.🔽The virtue, etc., that occur in such a one are called the virtue, etc., of one who has a sense of spiritual urgency.

original: eva. Evaṃ saṃvegajātassa yoniso upāyena padhānaṃ saṃviggassa yoniso padhānaṃ, lokiyalokuttaravīriyameva.🔽Ekūnacattālīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: eva evam saṃvega jātassa yonisas upāyena padhānam saṃviggassa yonisas padhānam lokiya lokuttara vīriyam eva  ekūnacattālīsatimam
translated: The effort of one who has a sense of spiritual urgency by a suitable means in order to fulfil the true ideal is called the effort of one who has a sense of spiritual urgency. It is simply the mundane and supramundane energy.🔽The dissatisfaction with what is obtained of profitable ideas is called dissatisfaction.

original: Kusaladhammapūraṇe asantuṭṭhibhāvo asantuṭṭhitā. Yo pana dānaṃ datvā tato tena asantuṭṭho
analyzed: kusala dhamma pūraṇe asantuṭṭhi bhāvaḥ asantuṭṭhi tā yaḥ pana dānam da tvā tena asantuṭṭhaḥ
translated: But one who, after giving a gift, is not satisfied with that and🔽after sacrificing, taking the Refuges, and desiring the five precepts, etc.,

original: hutvā saraṇagamanaṃ ākaṅkhati, tato pañcasīlādiṃ, pabbajjaṃ, buddhavacanānaṃ uggaṇhanaṃ,
analyzed: hutvā saraṇa gamanam ākaṅkhati tatas pañca sīla ādim pabbajjam buddha vacanānam uggaṇhanam
translated: after going forth, learning the Buddha’s word,

original: samathavipassanaṃ, tato tenāpi asantuṭṭho anukkamena arahattaṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ asantuṭṭhitā
analyzed: samatha vipassanam tena api asantuṭṭhaḥ anukkamena arahattam gaṇhāti ayam asantuṭṭhitā
translated: and then, dissatisfied even with that, he eventually reaches Arahantship. This is dissatisfaction with what is unwholesome.

original: kusalesu dhammesu. Adhikusaladhammānaṃ bhāvanāya ukkaṇṭhamāno padhānaṃ paṭivāpeti
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu adhi kusala dhammānam bhāvanāya ukkaṇṭhamānaḥ padhānam paṭivāpeti
translated: He is dissatisfied with the development of the more excellent wholesome states and turns away from the effort.

original: nivattāpetīti paṭivāni, na paṭivāni appaṭivāni, tassa bhavo appaṭivānitā. Arahattaṃ🔽appatvā padhānasmiṃ anivattanatā anosakkanatā, tathāpavattalokiyalokuttarakusalā
analyzed: nivattā apeti iti paṭivāni na paṭivāni appaṭivāni tassa bhavaḥ appaṭivāni tā arahattam  a patvā padhānasmiṃ a nivattana tā anosakkana tā tathā apavatta lokiya lokuttara kusalā
translated: He turns away from the effort, thus he is a turn-awayer; not a turn-awayer is a non-turn-awayer. His is the state of a non-turn-awayer.

original: dhammā. Cattālīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: cattālīsatimaṃ
translated: He does not turn away from the effort until he reaches Arahantship. He does not turn away, does not turn back, from the effort. So too with the more excellent mundane and supramundane wholesome states. The fortieth.

original: Vijānanato vijjā, pubbenivāsacutūpapātaāsavakkhayañāṇāni. Vimuccanato vimutti, aṭṭha🔽samāpattiyo, nibbānañca. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo hi ārammaṇe adhimuccanato, sayaṃ vikkhambhitakilesehi
analyzed: vijānanataḥ vijjā pubbenivāsa cutūpapāta āsava kkhaya ñāṇāni vimuccanataḥ vimutti aṭṭha  samāpattiyaḥ nibbānañca aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ hi ārammaṇe adhimuccanato sayam vikkhambhita kilesehi
translated: Knowledge is the knowing of past lives, of the appearance and disappearance of beings, and of the destruction of cankers.

original: vimuccanaṭṭhena ca vimuttīti vuttā, nibbānaṃ pana sabbakilesehi accantavimuccanaṭṭhena. Ekacattālīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: vimuccana ṭhena ca vimutti iti vuttā nibbānam pana sabba kilesehi accanta vimuccana ṭṭhena ekacattālīsatimam
translated: Liberation is the eight attainments and Nibbāna. For the eight attainments are called “liberations” because of their liberation from the object by directing the mind to it, and because of their liberation from the defilements by the abandoning of the defilements in the process of attaining them. But Nibbāna is called “liberation” because of its absolute liberation from all defilements. The forty-first.

original: Kilesakkhayakaresu catūsu ariyamaggesu ñāṇaṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ nāma. Paṭisandhivasena anuppādabhūte
analyzed: kilesa khaya karesu catūsu ariya maggesu ñāṇam khaye ñāṇam nāma paṭisandhi vasena anuppāda bhūte
translated: Knowledge in the four noble paths that are the doers of the destruction of defilements is called knowledge of destruction.

original: taṃtaṃmaggavajjhakilesānaṃ anuppādapariyosāne uppannaariyaphale ñāṇaṃ anuppāde ñāṇaṃ🔽nāma. Sesaṃ sabbattha suviññeyyameva. Dvācattālīsatimaṃ.
analyzed: tad tad magga vajjha kilesānam anuppāda pariyosāne uppanna ariya phale ñāṇam anuppāde ñāṇam  nāma sesam sabbattha su viññeyyam eva dvācattālīsatimam
translated: Knowledge arisen in the noble fruit that has arisen at the end of the non-arising of the defilements to be abandoned by each path respectively, which is the non-arising of the defilements abandoned by each path, is called knowledge of non-arising.🔽The rest is quite clear in all instances. The thirty-second.

original: Suttantikadukamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantika duka mātika ttha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the prose-exposition of the Dvācattālīsaka is ended.

original: Mohavicchedaniyā abhidhammamātikatthavaṇṇanāya
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the Abhidhamma-mātikā in the Mohavicchedani

original: Dhammasaṅgaṇīmātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the Dhammasanganī-mātikā is ended.

original: 2. Vibhaṅgamātikā
translated: The Vibhaṅga-mātikā

original: Idāni dhammasaṅgaṇīmātikānantaraṃ vibhaṅgamātikāya atthavaṇṇanā anuppattā. Tassā pana –
analyzed: idāni dhammasaṅgaṇī mātikā anantaram vibhaṅga mātikāya attha vaṇṇanā anuppattā tassā pana
translated: Now comes the turn for the commentary on the exposition of the Vibhaṅga-mātikā, which follows next after the Dhammasanganī-mātikā. But this is the method of exposition:

original: Atthato dhammabhedena, vibhaṅganayadassanā;
analyzed: atthataḥ dhamma bhedena vibhaṅga naya dassanā
translated: By way of meaning and by way of the analysis of ideas,🔽And by way of the method of the text as well,

original: Pāḷimuttanayā cāpi, hoti saṃvaṇṇanānayo.
analyzed: ca api hoti
translated: This exposition is made.

original: Sā panesā aṭṭhārasannaṃ vibhaṅgānaṃ ādimhi ṭhapitā aṭṭhārasavidhā hoti –
analyzed: sā pana esā aṭṭhārasannam vibhaṅgānaṃ ādimhi ṭhapitā aṭṭhārasavidhā hoti
translated: And this is of eighteen kinds, being placed at the beginning of the eighteen Vibhaṅgas, as follows:

original: khandhavibhaṅgamātikā-āyatana-dhātu-sacca-indriya-paccayākāra-satipaṭṭhāna-sammappadhāna-iddhipādabojjhaṅga-maggaṅgajhāna-appamaññā-sikkhāpada-paṭisambhidā-ñāṇa-khuddakavatthu-dhammahadayavibhaṅgamāti
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅga mātikā āyatana dhātu sacca indriya paccaya ākāra sati paṭṭhāna sammappadhāna eddhipāda bojjhaṅga maggaṅga jhāna appamaññā sikkhāpada paṭisambhidā ñāṇa khuddaka vatthu dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga mātikā
translated: The Schedule of the Analysis of the Aggregates, the Bases and Elements, the Truths, the Faculties, the Causal Relationships, the Ways of Mindfulness, the Right Strivings, the Bases of Psychic Power, the Factors of Enlightenment, the Factors of the Path, the Meditations, the Unlimited States, the Recollections, the Analytical Insights, the Knowledges, the Minor Trances, the Heartwood of the True Idea, the Analysis of the Heartwood of the True Idea.

original: Khandhavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The Schedule of the Analysis of the Aggregates

original: Tattha ādibhūtāya khandhavibhaṅgamātikāya atthato tāva – pañcakkhandhāti ettha pañcāti
analyzed: tattha ādi bhūtāya khandha vibhaṅga mātikāya atthato tāva pañca khandhā ti ettha pañca ati
translated: Herein, as to the Schedule of the Analysis of the Aggregates, which is the beginning, firstly as to meaning: in the passage ‘ Five aggregates ’ , the word ‘ five ’ is

original: gaṇanaparicchedo, tena na tato heṭṭhā, na uddhanti dasseti. Khandhāti paricchinnadhammanidassanaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇana paricchedaḥ tena na tatas heṭṭhā na uddhanti dasseti khandhā ti paricchinna dhamma nidassanam
translated: a delimitation of number, which shows that there is nothing less than that but there is more, and the word ‘ aggregates ’ is a showing of the limitedness of the ideas.

original: Tatrāyaṃ khandha-saddo sambahulesu ṭhānesu nipatati rāsimhi guṇe paṇṇattiyaṃ ruḷhiyanti.
analyzed: tatra ayam khandha saddaḥ sambahulesu ṭhānesu nipatati rāsimhi guṇe paṇṇattiyam
translated: Herein, this word ‘ aggregate ’ is used in several senses, namely, in the sense of a heap, in the sense of a quality, in the sense of a description, and in the sense of a continuity.

original: Tattha “mahāudakakkhandho”tiādīsu hi rāsito khandho nāma. “Sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandho”tiādīsu
analyzed: tattha mahā udaka khandhaḥ ti ādīsu hi rāsitaḥ khandhaḥ nāma sīla kkhandho samādhi kkhandho ti ādīsu
translated: Herein, in such passages as ‘ A great mass of water ’ , it is used in the sense of a heap. In such passages as ‘ The aggregate of virtue, the aggregate of concentration ’ ,🔽it is used in the sense of a quality. In such passages as ‘ The Blessed One saw a great log ’ ,

original: guṇato. “Addasā kho bhagavā mahantaṃ dārukkhandha”ntiādīsu paṇṇattito. “Viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: guṇataḥ addasā kho bhagavā mahantam dārukkhandhanti ādīsu paṇṇattitaḥ viññāṇam
translated: it is used in the sense of a description. In such passages as ‘ Consciousness is impermanent ’ ,🔽it is used in the sense of a continuity.

original: viññāṇakkhandho”tiādīsu ekampi cittaṃ ruḷhito khandho nāma, svāyamidha rāsito adhippeto.
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ ti ādīsu ekam pi cittam ruḷhitaḥ khandho nāma svāyam idha rāsitaḥ adhippeto
translated: In the passage, “The material form aggregate, the feeling aggregate, the perception aggregate, the formations aggregate, the consciousness aggregate” , even a single consciousness is called an “aggregate” in the sense of “that which is rolled together” .🔽But here the sense of “heap” is intended.

original: Rāsaṭṭho hi khandha-saddo, koṭṭhāsaṭṭhotipi vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Lokasmiṃ hi iṇaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: rāsaṭṭhaḥ hi khandha saddo koṭṭhāsaṭṭhaḥ ti pi vattum vaṭṭati lokasmim hi iṇam gahetvā
translated: For the word “aggregate” has the meaning of “heap” . It is also proper to say “compendium” .🔽For in the world they say, “We will pay the debt with two or three installments” .

original: codiyamānā “dvīhi khandhehi dassāma, tīhi khandhehi dassāmā”ti vadanti, tasmā khandhoti🔽koṭṭhāsoti vuttaṃ hoti. Rūpakkhandhoti ettha ruppatīti rūpaṃ, sītuṇhādīhi pasiddhākārena
analyzed: codiyamānāḥ dvīhi khandhehi dassāma tīhi khandhehi dassāma ati vadanti tasmā khandhoti  koṭṭhāsaḥ ti vuttam hoti rūpa kkhandho ti ettha ruppati iti rūpam sītuṇha ādīhi pasiddha ākārena
translated: Therefore “aggregate” is said to be🔽a compendium .🔽In the passage, “The material form aggregate” , it is material form because it is deformed .🔽The meaning is that it is deformed , is struck, is afflicted, by cold, heat, etc., which are well known as having the nature of deforming .

original: ruppati ghaṭṭīyati, pīḷiyatīti attho. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: ruppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷiyati iti atthaḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā rūpanti vuccati. Kena ruppati? Sītenapi ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppati, jighacchāyapi ruppati, pipāsāyapi ruppatī”tiādi.
analyzed: ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati kena ruppati sītena api ruppati uṇhena api ruppati jighacchāya api ruppati pipāsāya api ruppati itiādi
translated: “Bhikkhus, it is deformed , thus it is material form (rūpa) . By what is it deformed ? It is deformed by cold, it is deformed by heat, it is deformed by hunger, it is deformed by thirst” .

original: Rūpañca taṃ khandho cāti rūpakkhandho, rūparāsi rūpakoṭṭhāsoti attho. Vedanākkhandhādīsupi eseva nayoti ayaṃ tāvettha atthato saṃvaṇṇanānayo.
analyzed: rūpam ca tam khandho ca ati rūpa kkhandho rūpa rāsi rūpa koṭṭhāsaḥ ti atthaḥ vedanā khandha ādīsu pi esā iva nayo ti ayam tāva ettha atthataḥ saṃvaṇṇanā nayo
translated: Materiality is a category, thus it is the materiality category. The meaning is a heap of materiality, a section of materiality. The same method applies to the feeling category, etc. This, firstly, is the commentary on the meaning of the terms.

original: Dhammabhedato panettha heṭṭhā kusalattike vibhattā atītādibhedabhinnā sabbe rūpadhammā
analyzed: dhamma bhedato pana ittha heṭṭhā kusala ttike vibhattā atīta ādi bheda bhinnā sabbe rūpa dhammā
translated: As to the analysis of states, all material states classed in the past, future, and present, which were dealt with in the profitable triad of faculties in the first chapter ,

original: rūpakkhandho nāma. Tathā catubhūmakā vedanāsaññāyo vedanākkhandho nāma, saññākkhandho
analyzed: rūpakkhandhaḥ nāma tathā catu bhūmakāḥ vedanā saññāyaḥ vedanā kkhandho nāma saññā kkhandho
translated: are called the materiality category. Likewise the feeling aggregate, classed in the four planes, is called the feeling category, and the perception aggregate is called the perception category.

original: nāma. Vedanāsaññā pana ṭhapetvā sesā phassādayo paññāsa cetasikā saṅkhārakkhandho
analyzed: nāma vedanā saññā pana ṭhapetvā sesā phassa ādayo paññāsa cetasikā saṅkhāra kkhandho
translated: But the fifty mental factors beginning with contact, leaving out feeling and perception, are called the formations category.

original: nāma. Pañcasu khandhesu nibbānameva asaṅgahitaṃ, upādānakkhandhesu pana sabbe lokuttaradhammā.🔽Ayameva hi khandhehi upādānakkhandhānaṃ viseso. Khandhā avisesato vuttā, upādānakkhandhā
analyzed: nāma pañcasu khandhesu nibbānam eva asaṅgahitam upādānakkhandhesu pana sabbe lokuttara dhammā  ayam eva hi khandhehi upādānakkhandhānam visesaḥ khandhāḥ avisesataḥ vuttāḥ upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: In the five categories Nibbāna is not included. But in the categories of clinging all supramundane states are excluded.

original: sāsavopādāniyabhāvena visesetvā. Idha pana avisesena vuttattā nibbānaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesā
analyzed: sa āsava upādāniya bhāvena visesetvā idha pana avisesena vutta ttā nibbānam ṭhapetvā avasesā
translated: For this is the difference between the categories and the categories of clinging. The categories are stated without distinction; the categories of clinging are stated with distinction by way of what is subject to cankers and what is liable to clinging. But here they are stated without distinction, so Nibbāna is excluded and the rest are included.

original: sabbe dhammā saṅgahaṃ gacchantīti ayaṃ dhammabhedato saṃvaṇṇanānayo.🔽Vibhaṅganayadassanāti vibhaṅgapāḷiyā āgataatthanayadassanato. Vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ hi
analyzed: sabbe dhammā saṅgaham gacchanti iti ayam dhamma bhedato saṃvaṇṇanā anayaḥ  vibhaṅga naya dassanā ati vibhaṅga pāḷiyā āgata attha naya dassanataḥ vibhaṅga pāḷiyam hi
translated: All ideas are included in the ideas of the aggregates, bases, and elements. This is the method of exposition by analysis of ideas.🔽As to the method of exposition by analysis: as shown by the method of exposition in the Vibhanga.

original: suttantabhājanīyaṃ abhidhammabhājanīyaṃ pañhāpucchakanti tīhi nayehi khandhavibhaṅgo🔽vibhatto. Tathā āyatanavibhaṅgādayo. Kevalaṃ hi indriyavibhaṅge, sikkhāpadavibhaṅge
analyzed: suttanta bhājanīyam abhidhamma bhājanīyam pañhāpucchakan ti tīhi nayehi khandha vibhaṅgaḥ  vibhatto tathā āyatana vibhaṅga ādayo kevalam hi indriya vibhaṅge sikkhāpada vibhaṅge
translated: For in the Vibhanga the analysis of the aggregates is made in three ways, namely, by the method of exposition in terms of Threads, in terms of Abhidhamma, and in terms of Questions and Answers.🔽And so too with the analysis of the bases, etc.🔽But in the analysis of the faculties and in the analysis of the training precepts only the method of exposition in terms of Threads is not included.🔽And in the analysis of the conditions only the method of exposition in terms of Questions and Answers is not included.

original: ca suttantabhājanīyaṃ natthi. Paccayākāravibhaṅge pañhāpucchakaṃ natthi. Ñāṇavibhaṅgādīsu
analyzed: ca suttanta bhājanīyam natthi paccaya ākāra vibhaṅge pañhāpucchakam natthi ñāṇa vibhaṅga ādīsu
translated: But in the analysis of knowledge, etc.,

original: pana tīsu tayopi nayā na santi. Tesu hi ñāṇavibhaṅgo ekavidhato paṭṭhāya yāva dasavidhā
analyzed: pana tīsu tayaḥ api nayāḥ na santi tesu hi ñāṇa vibhaṅgo ekavidhato paṭṭhāya yāva dasavidhā
translated: all three methods are not included. For in the analysis of knowledge the analysis is made by the single method of exposition in terms of the kinds of knowledge, from the one kind up to the ten kinds.

original: vibhatto, khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgo ekavidhato paṭṭhāya yāva dvāsaṭṭhipabhedā vibhatto,
analyzed: vibhattaḥ khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅgo ekavidhataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva dvāsaṭṭhi pabhedā vibhatto
translated: In the analysis of the minor khandhakas the analysis is made by the single method of exposition in terms of the kinds of khandhakas, from the one kind up to the sixty-two kinds.

original: dhammahadayavibhaṅgo pana sabbasaṅgahādīhi dasahi vārehi vibhatto, tasmā tesaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: dhamma hadaya vibhaṅgaḥ pana sabba saṅgaha ādīhi dasahi vārehi vibhatto tasmā tesam tesam
translated: But in the analysis of the heartwood of the Dhamma the analysis is made by the ten methods of exposition beginning with the all-inclusive method.

original: nayānaṃ mukhamattadassanavasena tattha tattha saṃvaṇṇanā bhavissanti. Tatridaṃ khandhavibhaṅge
analyzed: nayānam mukha matta dassana vasena tattha tattha saṃvaṇṇanāḥ bhavissanti tatra idam khandha vibhaṅge
translated: The expositions will be given here and there according to the three methods of exposition, namely, by the method of the Threads, by the method of the Categories, and by the method of the Faculties. Herein,

original: tiṇṇaṃ nayānaṃ mukhamattadassanaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – suttantabhājanīye tāva rūpakkhandho –🔽“Tattha katamo rūpakkhandho? Yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā
analyzed: tiṇṇam nayānam mukha matta dassanam seyyathidam suttanta bhājanīye tāva rūpa kkhandho  tattha katamaḥ rūpa kkhandho yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā
translated: the method of the Threads is as follows. In the case of the materiality aggregate, for instance, in the Thread-basket the materiality aggregate is shown by the method of the Threads in the following way:

original: bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, tadekajjhaṃ
analyzed: bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā tad ekajjham
translated: “Herein, what is the materiality aggregate? Whatever materiality there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having thus defined it in brief, he defines it in detail thus: ‘Whatever materiality there is that is past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, all that is reckoned as one aggregate, that is to say, the materiality aggregate’ .

original: abhisaññūhitvā abhisaṅkhipitvā ayaṃ vuccati rūpakkhandho”ti –🔽Evaṃ uddisitvā vitthārato vibhatto, tathā vedanākkhandhādayopi. Tattha niyakajjhattaṃ
analyzed: abhisaññūhitvā abhisaṅkhipitvā ayam vuccati rūpa kkhandho ti  evam uddisitvā vitthārataḥ vibhatto tathā vedanā khandha ādayaḥ api tattha
translated: Having defined it thus in detail, he defines it again in brief thus: ‘This is called the materiality aggregate’ .

original: nāma ajjhattarūpaṃ ajjhattaṃ nāma, tato aññaṃ parapuggalagataṃ, aviññāṇañca bahiddhā
analyzed: nāma ajjhatta rūpam ajjhattam nāma tatas aññam para puggala gatam aviññāṇam ca bahiddhā
translated: Herein, ‘one’s own’ internal materiality is called ‘one’s own’ ; that of another person, and also what is not consciousness, are called ‘external’ .

original: nāma, tathā vedanādayopi. Pasādavisayarūpaṃ pana oḷārikaṃ nāma, sesaṃ sukhumaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nāma tathā vedanā ādayaḥ api pasāda visaya rūpam pana oḷārikam nāma sesam sukhumam nāma
translated: So too with the feeling aggregate, and so on. But gross materiality is that consisting of the eight kinds of earth element, and so on. The rest is subtle.

original: Aniṭṭharūpaṃ hīnaṃ nāma, iṭṭharūpaṃ paṇītaṃ nāma.
analyzed: aniṭṭha rūpam hīnam nāma iṭṭha rūpam paṇītam nāma
translated: What is unpleasing is called “inferior.” What is pleasing is called “superior.”

original: Nanu iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ nāma pāṭekkaṃ paṭivibhattaṃ nāma natthi, ekaṃ ekaccassa iṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: nanu iṭṭha aniṭṭham nāma pāṭekkam paṭivibhattam nāma natthi ekam ekaccassa iṭṭham
translated: But is not what is pleasing and what is unpleasing not classed separately? For what is pleasing and agreeable to one person

original: hoti manāpaṃ, tadeva aññassa ca aniṭṭhaṃ hoti. Vatthādīni hi sūkarādīnaṃ nappiyāni🔽honti, na manussādīnaṃ, tesañca vatthābharaṇādīni piyāni, na sūkarādīnanti, tasmā🔽rucivaseneva iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā gahetabbā? Na, iṭṭhāniṭṭhānaṃ pāṭekkaṃ vibhattattā. Kusalakammajaṃ🔽hi kusalavipākavisayova iṭṭhaṃ nāma, akusalakammajaṃ akusalavipākavisayova aniṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: hoti manāpam tat eva aññassa ca aniṭṭham hoti vattha ādīni hi sūkara ādīnam na piyāni  honti na manussa ādīnam tesam ca vattha ābharaṇa ādīni piyāni na sūkara ādīnanti tasmā  ruci vasena iva iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā gahetabbā na iṭṭha aniṭṭhānam pāṭekkam vibhatta ttā kusala kamma jam  hi kusala vipāka visayo uva iṭṭham nāma akusala kamma jam akusala vipāka visayo uva aniṭṭham
translated: is unpleasing and disagreeable to another. For what is unpalatable to pigs, etc., is palatable to human beings, etc.,🔽and what is palatable to human beings, etc., is unpalatable to pigs, etc. So should the state of being pleasing and unpleasing be taken as due to preference?

original: nāma, saññāvipallāsena pana koci iṭṭhameva buddharūpādiṃ javanakkhaṇe aniṭṭhato manasi
analyzed: nāma saññā vipallāsena pana koci iṭṭham eva buddha rūpa ādim javana khaṇe an iṭṭhataḥ manasi
translated: No, because what is pleasing and unpleasing is classed separately. For what is produced by profitable action is called “pleasing” only as the domain of the result of profitable action, and what is produced by unprofitable action is called “unpleasing” only as the domain of the result of unprofitable action. But by perverting perception some person at the javana stage of a consciousness thinks what is pleasing, such as the form of the Enlightened One, etc., unpleasing,

original: karoti, aniṭṭhañca nirayaggisatthavisādiṃ iṭṭhato manasi karoti. Javanehi eva vipallāsabhāvo,
analyzed: karoti aniṭṭham ca niraya aggi sattha visādim iṭṭhataḥ manasi karoti javanehi eva vipallāsa bhāvaḥ
translated: and what is unpleasing, such as the flames and swords in hell, etc., pleasing. The state of perversion is due to the javanas.

original: na vipākehīti vipākavasena iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ niyataṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: na vipākehi iti vipāka vasena iṭṭha aniṭṭham niyatam veditabbam
translated: Nor is it to be understood as desirable or undesirable by way of kamma-result.

original: Sammohavinodaniyā pana vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya –
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā pana vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya
translated: But in the Sammohavinodani Commentary on the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Sukhasamphassaṃ hi gūthakalalaṃ cakkhudvāraghānadvāresu aniṭṭhaṃ, kāyadvāre iṭṭhaṃ🔽hoti. Cakkavattino maṇiratanena pothiyamānassa, suvaṇṇasūle uttāsiyamānassa ca maṇiratanasuvaṇṇasūlāni
analyzed: sukha samphassam hi gūtha kalalam cakkhu dvāra ghāna dvāresu aniṭṭham kāya dvāre iṭṭham  hoti cakkavattinaḥ maṇi ratanena pothiyamānassa suvaṇṇa sūle uttāsiyamānassa ca maṇi ratana suvaṇṇa sūlāni
translated: “For the pleasant contact of the infant in the womb is undesirable at the eye and ear doors, but it is desirable at the body door.

original: cakkhudvāre iṭṭhāni honti, kāyadvāre aniṭṭhānī”ti –
analyzed: cakkhu dvāre iṭṭhāni honti kāya dvāre aniṭṭhāni iti
translated: And the jewel and the golden needle of the universal monarch when they are being polished are desirable at the body door, but they are undesirable at the eye door.”

original: Evaṃ dvāravasena ekasseva vatthuno iṭṭhatā, aniṭṭhatā ca vuttā. Sā ca ekakkhaṇe na🔽yuttā ekakalāpagatabhūtopādāyarūpānaṃ ekasāmaggiyamuppattito. Na hi bhūtesu akusalavasena🔽aniṭṭhesu uppajjantesu tadupādāyarūpādikusalena iṭṭhāni uppajjanti, bhinnakkhaṇe
analyzed: evam dvāra vasena ekassa iva vatthuno iṭṭha tā aniṭṭha tā ca vuttā sā ca eka khaṇe na  yuttāḥ eka kalā apagata bhūta upādāya rūpānam eka sāmaggiyam uppattitaḥ na hi bhūtesu akusala vasena  aniṭṭhesu uppajjantesu tad upādāya rūpa ādi kusalena iṭṭhāni uppajjanti bhinna kkhaṇe
translated: So it is said that the desirability and undesirability of the same object are due to the doors. But that is not right,

original: pana iṭṭhāni maṇiratanādīni tehi pothiyamānassa akusalapaccayena utunā aniṭṭhāni
analyzed: pana iṭṭhāni maṇi ratana ādīni tehi pothiyamānassa akusala paccayena utunā aniṭṭhāni
translated: because the simultaneous arising of the four primary elements that occur in a single group of matter is impossible. For when the primary elements arise as undesirable by way of unprofitableness, the matter derived from them, etc., do not arise as desirable by way of profitableness. But when the desirable jewel, etc., are being polished, the undesirable heat that arises from them by way of the condition of temperature does not arise as undesirable by way of unprofitableness.

original: vipariṇamanti, kusalapaccayena aniṭṭhāni gūthakalalādīni iṭṭhānīti, ayaṃ no attanomati.
analyzed: vipariṇamanti kusala paccayena aniṭṭhāni gūtha kalala ādīni iṭṭhāni iti ayam no attanomati
translated: They change, and what is unlovely becomes lovely and what is lovely becomes unlovely through the condition of the profitable. This is our own opinion.

original: Evaṃ vibhattesu ca iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu taṃ taṃ rūpaṃ upādāyupādāya hīnaṃ, paṇītañca daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam vibhattesu ca iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu tam tam rūpam upādāya upādāya hīnam paṇītam ca daṭṭhabbam
translated: And when the lovely and the unlovely have been defined in this way, the materiality that is clung to should be regarded as inferior and superior in each case according to the kind of materiality clung to.

original: Sukhumaṃ pana rūpaṃ dūrerūpaṃ nāma, oḷārikaṃ santikerūpaṃ nāma. Taṃ taṃ vā pana rūpaṃ
analyzed: sukhumam pana rūpam dūrerūpam nāma oḷārikam santikerūpam nāma tam tam vā pana rūpam
translated: But subtle materiality is called “distant” and gross materiality “near.” Or any materiality can be regarded as distant or near

original: upādāyupādāya rūpaṃ dūre santike daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Vedanādīsu pana akusalā vedanā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā. Kusalākusalā oḷārikā, abyākatā🔽sukhumā. Dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā. Sukhadukkhā vā oḷārikā, itarā sukhumā.🔽Asamāpannassa vā vedanā oḷārikā, samāpannassa sukhumā. Sāsavā oḷārikā, anāsavā sukhumā.
analyzed: upādāya upādāya rūpam dūre santike daṭṭhabbam sesam vutta nayam eva  vedanā ādīsu pana akusalā vedanā oḷārikā itarā sukhumā kusala akusalā oḷārikā abyākatā  sukhumā dukkhā vedanā oḷārikā itarā sukhumā sukha dukkhā vai oḷārikā itarā sukhumā  asamāpannassa vā vedanā oḷārikā samāpannassa sukhumā sa āsavā oḷārikā anāsavā sukhumā
translated: according as it is clung to as such and such. The rest is as already stated.🔽But as regards feeling, etc., unprofitable feeling is gross, and the other kinds are subtle. Profitable and unprofitable feeling is gross, and the indeterminate is subtle. Painful feeling is gross, and the other kinds are subtle. Or pleasant and painful feeling is gross, and the neither-painful-nor-pleasant is subtle.

original: Taṃ taṃ vā pana vedanaṃ upādāyupādāya oḷārikasukhumatā daṭṭhabbā. Akusalā vedanā
analyzed: tam tam vā pana vedanam upādāya upādāya oḷārika sukhuma tā daṭṭhabbā akusalā vedanā
translated: Or the feeling of one who has not attained is gross, and that of one who has attained is subtle. That with cankers is gross, and that without cankers is subtle.🔽Or any feeling can be regarded as gross or subtle according to the kind of feeling. Unprofitable feeling is gross,

original: kusalābyākatāhi dūre, tā ca tāya dūreti evaṃ jātisabhāvapuggalabhūmibhedato vuttanayena
analyzed: dūre ca dūra iti evam jāti sabhāva puggala bhūmi bhedataḥ vutta nayena
translated: and the profitable and indeterminate are far from the unprofitable. And they are far from that because of the difference of kind, of individual essence, of person, and of plane.

original: dūrevedanā daṭṭhabbā, kusalā vedanā kusalāya santiketi evaṃ jātiādisāmaññato santikevedanā
analyzed: dūre vedanā daṭṭhabbā kusalā vedanā kusalāya santikā iti evam jāti ādi sāmaññato santikevedanā
translated: So feeling should be regarded as far in the way already stated. But feeling that is profitable should be regarded as near to profitable feeling, and so on.🔽Or any feeling can be regarded as far or near according to the way in which it is apprehended.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Taṃ taṃ vā pana vedanaṃ upādāyupādāya vedanā dūresantike daṭṭhabbā. Evaṃ🔽saññākkhandhādīsupi yathānurūpaṃ oḷārikasukhumatādayo veditabbāti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā tam tam vā pana vedanam upādāya upādāya vedanā dūre santike daṭṭhabbā evam  saññā kkhandha ādīsu pi yathānurūpam oḷārika sukhuma tā ādayaḥ veditabbā ti ayam ettha saṅkhepo
translated: So too with the perception aggregate, and so on.🔽This is the brief account here.

original: vitthāro pana vibhaṅgapāḷiaṭṭhakathāsu gahetabboti ayaṃ suttantabhājanīyanayo.🔽Abhidhammabhājanīyanaye rūpakkhandhassa tāva ekavidhādito yāva ekādasavidhā rūpakaṇḍe
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana vibhaṅga pāḷi aṭṭhakathāsu gahetabbo ti ayam suttanta bhājanīya nayo  abhidhamma bhājanīya naye rūpakkhandhassa tāva ekavidha āditas yāva ekādasavidhā rūpa kaṇḍe
translated: The detailed account should be understood according to the texts and commentaries. This is the method according to the Suttanta.🔽As regards the method according to the Abhidhamma, the form aggregate should be understood according to the “Description of Form” in the Vibhaṅga, that is to say, as to kinds, and so on.

original: vuttanayena veditabbā. Vedanākkhandho pana ekavidho phassasampayutto, duvidho sahetukadukavasena,
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbā vedanā khandho pana ekavidhaḥ phassa sampayuttaḥ duvidhaḥ sa hetuka duka vasena
translated: But the feeling aggregate is of one kind as associated with contact; of two kinds as with cause and without cause;

original: tividho kusalattikavasena, catubbidho catubhūmakavasena, pañcavidho sabhāvabhedena,
analyzed: tividhaḥ kusala ttika vasena catubbidhaḥ catu bhūmaka vasena pañcavidhaḥ sa bhāva bhedena
translated: of three kinds as the triple group of profitable, etc.; of four kinds as the four planes; of five kinds by classification of individual essence;

original: chabbidho chadvārikavasena, sattavidho sattaviññāṇasampayogavasena, aṭṭhavidho tesu
analyzed: chabbidho cha dvārika vasena sattavidho satta viññāṇa sampayoga vasena aṭṭhavidho tesu
translated: sixfold, by way of the six bases of contact; sevenfold, by way of the seven kinds of consciousness that are associated with the six bases of contact; eightfold, by way of the eight kinds of consciousness that are associated with the six bases of contact;

original: kāyaviññāṇasampayuttaṃ sukhadukkhavasena dvidhā bhinditvā, navavidho tesu manoviññāṇasampayuttaṃ🔽kusalattikavasena tidhā bhinditvā, dasavidho tesu kāyaviññāṇasampayuttaṃ duvidhā,
analyzed: kāya viññāṇa sampayuttam sukha dukkha vasena dvidhā bhinditvā navavidhaḥ tesu manaḥ viññāṇa sampayuttam  kusala ttika vasena tidhā bhinditvā dasavidhaḥ tesu kāya viññāṇa sampayuttam duvidhā
translated: ninefold, by way of the nine kinds of consciousness that are associated with the six bases of contact;🔽tenfold, by way of the ten kinds of consciousness that are associated with the six bases of contact.

original: manoviññāṇasampayuttañca tidhā bhinditvāti evaṃ sahetukadukamūlaṃ paṭhamavāraṃ vatvā
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa sampayuttam ca tidhā bhinditvā ati evam sa hetuka duka mūlam paṭhama vāram vatvā
