Or alternatively, knowledge of suffering is the wrong practice in regard to the fruit, which is the perception of permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self in the aggregates that are impermanent, ugly, painful, and not self. Knowledge of origination is the wrong practice in regard to the cause, which is the belief in a cause that is not a cause, such as the belief that the world is created by Īśvara, by Brahmā, by time, by nature, and so on. Knowledge of cessation is the wrong practice in regard to cessation, which is the grasping of the unconditioned as a separate entity, such as the world of non-form, and so on.

original: maggañāṇaṃ kāmasukhallikaattakilamathānuyogappabhede avisuddhimagge visuddhimaggaggāhavasena🔽pavattaṃ upāye vippaṭipattiṃ nivatteti. Idamettha ñāṇakiccaṃ.
analyzed: magga ñāṇam avisuddhi magge visuddhi magga ggāha vasena  pavattam upāye vippaṭipattim nivatteti idam ettha ñāṇa kiccam
translated: Path knowledge does the same for the view of eternalism and the view of inaction. Or else, knowledge of suffering does so for the perversion consisting in perceiving permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self in the aggregates, which are impermanent, foul, painful, and not self. Knowledge of origination does so for the perversion consisting in perceiving a cause in what is not a cause, namely, the view that the world is created by an Overlord, by Time, by Primordial Essence, and so on. Knowledge of cessation does so for the perversion consisting in perceiving cessation in the non-cessation of the world consisting in the non-cessation of the aggregates, which is the object of the perversion of perception. Knowledge of the path does so for the perversion consisting in perceiving the path in what is not the path, namely, the practice of the moralities and the practice of striving that are mixed with the view of self and are included in the plane of the world. This is the function of knowledge here.

original: Upamāto panettha bhāro viya hi dukkhasaccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, bhārādānamiva samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: upamātaḥ pana ittha bhāraḥ viya hi dukkha saccam daṭṭhabbam bhāra ādānam iva samudaya saccam
translated: By way of similes: Suffering should be seen as a burden, the origin as the taking up of the burden,

original: bhāranikkhepanamiva nirodhasaccaṃ, bhāranikkhepanupāyo viya maggasaccaṃ. Apica rogatannidānatadupasamabhesajjehi,
analyzed: bhāra nikkhepanam iva nirodha saccam bhāra nikkhepana upāyaḥ viya magga saccam api ca roga tad nidāna tad upasama bhesajjehi
translated: The truth of cessation is like the laying down of the load, and the truth of the path is like the means to the laying down of the load. Furthermore, they can be respectively associated with disease, its cause, its cure, and medicine,

original: orimatīramahoghapārimatīrataṃsampāpakopāyehi cāti evamādīhi yathākkamaṃ yojetvāpi
analyzed: ca ati evamādīhi yathākkamam
translated: or with this shore, the far shore, the great flood, the means to cross over the great flood, and so on.

original: etāni upamāto veditabbāni. Ayamettha upamā. Evaṃ ñeyyo pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: etāni upamātaḥ veditabbāni ayam ettha upamā evam ñeyyaḥ pāḷi mutta vinicchayo
translated: This is the simile here. This is how the exegesis of the text should be known.

original: Saccavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Schedule of the Truths Section is ended.

original: Indriyavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The Schedule of the Faculties

original: Indriyavibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – dvāvīsati indriyānīti ettha indriyaṭṭhasambhavato
analyzed: indriya vibhaṅga mātikāya pana atthato tāva dvāvīsati indriyāni iti ettha indriya aṭṭha sambhavato
translated: As to the meaning, firstly, in the twenty-two faculties, here the faculties are so called because of the presence of the meaning of faculty.

original: indriyāni. Ko panesa indriyaṭṭho nāmāti? Indaliṅgaṭṭho, indadesitaṭṭho, indadiṭṭhaṭṭho,
analyzed: indriyāni kaḥ pana esa indriya ṭṭhaḥ nāma ati inda liṅga ṭṭhaḥ inda desita ṭṭhaḥ inda diṭṭha ṭṭho
translated: But what is this meaning of faculty? It is the meaning of a mark of a lord, the meaning of what is taught by a lord, the meaning of what is seen by a lord,

original: indasiṭṭhaṭṭho, indajuṭṭhaṭṭho ca, so sabbopi idha yathāyogaṃ yujjati. Kusalākusalaṃ
analyzed: ca so sabbaḥ api idha yathāyogam yujjati kusala akusalam
translated: the meaning of what is directed by a lord, the meaning of what is chosen by a lord. All these are appropriate here as occasion arises. Good and bad

original: kammaṃ indo nāma kammesu kassaci issariyābhāvato, tenevettha kammasañjanitāni tāva
analyzed: kammam indo nāma kammesu kassaci issariya abhāvato tena iva ittha kamma sañjanitāni tāva
translated: kamma is called a “lord” because of the absence of lordship in anyone over kamma in the doing. So firstly, those that are generated by kamma

original: indriyāni attano janakakammaṃ ulliṅgenti, tena ca siṭṭhānīti indaliṅgaṭṭhena, indasiṭṭhaṭṭhena🔽ca indriyāni. Sammāsambuddho pana paramissariyabhāvato indo, tato sabbānipetāni indriyāni🔽bhagavatā yathābhūtato pakāsitāni, abhisambuddhāni cāti indadesitaṭṭhena, indadiṭṭhaṭṭhena
analyzed: indriyāni attanaḥ janaka kammam ulliṅgenti tena ca siṭṭhāni iti inda liṅga ṭṭhena inda siṭṭha ṭṭhena  ca indriyāni sammāsambuddhaḥ pana paramissariya bhāvataḥ indo tatas sabbānipetāni indriyāni  bhagavatā yathābhūtatas pakāsitāni abhisambuddhāni ca ati inda desita ṭṭhena inda diṭṭha ṭṭhena
translated: The faculties announce their own generating kamma, and they are trained by that kamma, thus they are faculties in the sense of “announcing” kamma and in the sense of “being trained” by kamma.

original: ca indriyāni. Teneva bhagavatā kānici gocarāsevanāya, kānici bhāvanāsevanāya sevitānīti
analyzed: ca indriyāni tena iva bhagavatā kānici gocara āsevanāya kānici bhāvanā āsevanāya sevitāni iti
translated: But the Fully Enlightened One is a lord in the sense of supreme ownership, and these faculties are announced by him, are discovered by him, thus they are faculties in the sense of “announced” by a lord and in the sense of “seen” by a lord.🔽And because some of them are cultivated by him through the cultivation of the resort and some through the cultivation of development,

original: indajuṭṭhaṭṭhenapi indriyāni. Apica ādhipaccasaṅkhātena issariyaṭṭhenāpi etāni indriyāni.
analyzed: indriyāni api ca ādhipacca saṅkhātena issariya ṭṭhena api etāni indriyāni
translated: they are faculties in the sense of “used” by a lord. Furthermore, they are faculties in the sense of ownership in the sense of sovereignty.

original: Cakkhundriyantiādīsu cakkhādīnaṃ padattho heṭṭhā pakāsito. Pacchimesu pana tīsu pubbabhāge
analyzed: cakkhu indriya nti ādīsu cakkha ādīnam padatthaḥ heṭṭhā pakāsitaḥ pacchimesu pana tīsu pubba bhāge
translated: As regards the words “eye faculty,” etc., the meaning of the words has been given above . But in the case of the last three,

original: anaññātaṃ amataṃ padaṃ, catusaccadhammaṃ vā jānissāmīti evaṃ paṭipannassa uppajjanato,
analyzed: anaññātam amatam padam catusacca dhammam vā jānissāmi iti evam paṭipannassa uppajjanataḥ
translated: they are faculties in the sense of “knowing” because they arise in one who is practising thus: “I shall know the supramundane state that has not been known before,” or “I shall know the Dhamma of the four noble truths that has not been known before.”

original: indriyaṭṭhasambhavato ca anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ. Ājānanato aññā eva indriyanti
analyzed: indriya ṭṭha sambhavato ca ājānanataḥ aññā eva indriyanti
translated: Because of the knowing, the faculty is “not-I,”🔽so there is the faculty of “not-I.”

original: aññindriyaṃ. Aññātāvino catūsu saccesu niṭṭhitañāṇakiccassa khīṇāsavassa indriyanti🔽aññātāvindriyaṃ. Tattha ca pasādindriyānantaraṃ cakkhuviññāṇādivīthicittappavattiyaṃ
analyzed: aññindriyam aññātāvino catūsu saccesu niṭṭhita ñāṇa kiccassa khīṇa āsavassa indriyanti  aññātau indriyam tattha ca pasād indriya anantaram cakkhu viññāṇa ādi vīthi citta ppavattiyam
translated: In one who has known there is the faculty of final knowledge, in one whose knowledge of the four truths is finished, in one whose cankers are destroyed, so there is the faculty of final knowledge.

original: rūpādīnaṃ niyatabhāvassa, attano tikkhamandatānuvidhānassa ca āpādanato ādhipaccaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam niyata bhāvassa attanaḥ tikkha manda tā anuvidhānassa ca āpādanataḥ ādhipaccam
translated: Herein, the predominance of the eye-consciousness process, etc., should be understood in the way beginning “Because of the definite presence of visible data, etc., and because of the condition of one’s own keenness or dullness” .

original: veditabbaṃ. Manindriyādīnaṃ pana attano attano vijānanādilakkhaṇe ādhipaccaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam man indriya ādīnam pana attanaḥ attanaḥ vijānana ādi lakkhaṇe ādhipaccam veditabbam
translated: And the predominance of the mind faculty, etc., should be understood in the way beginning “Because of the condition of one’s own knowing, etc.”

original: Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.🔽Dhammabhedato panettha jīvitindriyaṃ rūpārūpavasena dvidhā. Sukhindriyādīni pañca
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam tāva ettha padattho  dhamma bhedato pana ittha jīvitindriyam rūpa arūpa vasena dvidhā sukhindriya ādīni pañca
translated: The rest is easily intelligible. This, in the first place, is the word meaning.🔽As to division: the life faculty is twofold as material and immaterial.🔽The five beginning with the pleasure faculty are one thing, namely, feeling. So too the four beginning with the understanding faculty are one thing, namely, non-delusion. But the rest

original: vedanābhāvato ekadhammo, tathā paññindriyādīni cattāri amohabhāvato. Sesāni pana
analyzed: vedanā bhāvato eka dhammo tathā paññindriya ādīni cattāri amoha bhāvato sesāni pana
translated: are

original: indriyāni ekekadhammā evāti evaṃ paramatthato soḷasa dhammāva dvāvīsatindriyabhāvena
analyzed: indriyāni ekeka dhammāḥ eva ati evam paramatthato soḷasa dvāvīsati indriya bhāvena
translated: The faculties are each single dhammas. So in the ultimate sense there are only sixteen dhammas taught as the twenty-two faculties.

original: desitāni. Sesāni panettha cetasikarūpanibbānāni asaṅgahitānīti ayaṃ dhammabhedo.
analyzed: desitāni sesāni pana ittha cetasika rūpa nibbānāni asaṅgahitāni iti ayam dhamma bhedaḥ
translated: The rest here, namely, the mental factors, materiality, and nibbana, are not included. This is the analysis of the teaching.

original: Vibhaṅganayato panettha suttantabhājanīyaṃ nāma na gahitaṃ. Kasmā? Suttante imāya
analyzed: vibhaṅga nayataḥ pana ittha suttantabhājanīyam nāma na gahitam kasmā suttante imāya
translated: But in the method of exposition by way of the Vibhanga, the “portion of text” is not taken. Why? Because in the sutta

original: paṭipāṭiyā dvāvīsatiyā indriyānaṃ anāgatattā. Suttantasmiṃ hi katthaci dve indriyāni
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyāḥ dvāvīsatiyāḥ indriyānaṃ anāgata ttā suttantasmim hi katthaci dve indriyāni
translated: the twenty-two faculties are not given in this order. For in the sutta, sometimes two faculties are mentioned,

original: kathitāni, katthaci tīṇi, katthaci pañca, evaṃ pana nirantaraṃ dvāvīsati āgatāni
analyzed: kathitāni katthaci tīṇi katthaci pañca evam pana nirantaram dvāvīsati āgatāni
translated: sometimes three, sometimes five. But there is no continuous occurrence of all twenty-two.

original: nāma natthi. Abhidhammabhājanīyepi viseso natthi.
analyzed: nāma natthi abhidhamma bhājanīye pi visesaḥ natthi
translated: And there is no difference in the “portion of the Abhidhamma.”

original: Pañhāpucchakanaye pana dvāvīsatiyā indriyānaṃ kati kusalā…pe… kati araṇāti? Anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ
analyzed: pañhāpucchaka naye pana dvāvīsatiyāḥ indriyānam kati kati
translated: But in the method of exposition by way of the questions and answers, how many of the twenty-two faculties are profitable, etc.? The faculty of final knowledge is profitable.

original: kusalaṃ, domanassindriyaṃ akusalaṃ, saddhāsatipaññāaññindriyāni cattāri kusalābyākatāni,
analyzed: kusalam domanassindriyam akusalam saddhā sati paññā aññindriyāni cattāri kusala abyākatāni
translated: The faculty of grief is unprofitable. The four faculties of faith, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding are profitable and indeterminate.

original: manajīvitasomanassaupekkhāvīriyasamādhindriyāni cha tidhāpi, sesāni dasa abyākatāni.
analyzed: mana jīvita so manassa aupekkhā vīriya samādhi indriyāni cha tidhā api sesāni dasa abyākatāni
translated: The life faculty, the happiness faculty, the joy faculty, the energy faculty, the concentration faculty, and the faith faculty are threefold. The remaining ten faculties are indeterminate.

original: Cha indriyāni siyā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā, siyā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya sampayuttāti,
analyzed: cha indriyāni siyā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā siyā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā ati
translated: Six faculties may be connected with the pleasant feeling, or they may be connected with the neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: tīṇi tidhāpi, jīvitaṃ tidhā ca na vattabbañca, dvādasindriyāni na vattabbāni eva.
analyzed: tīṇi tidhā api jīvitam tidhā ca na vattabbam ca dvādasa indriyāni na vattabbāni eva
translated: Three are threefold. The life faculty is not to be spoken of as threefold. Twelve faculties are not to be spoken of.

original: Tīṇi vipākāni, dve vipākadhammadhammāni, rūpindriyāni satta nevavipākanavipākadhammadhammāni,
analyzed: tīṇi vipākāni dve vipāka dhamma dhammāni rūpa indriyāni satta neva vipāka na vipāka dhamma dhammāni
translated: Three faculties are resultants. Two faculties are resultants and have results. Seven faculties consisting of matter are neither resultants nor have results.

original: aññindriyaṃ siyā vipākaṃ, siyā vipākadhammadhammaṃ, navindriyāni tidhāpi. Navindriyāni🔽upādinnupādāniyāni, domanassindriyaṃ anupādinnupādāniyaṃ, tīṇi anupādinnaanupādāniyāni,
analyzed: aññindriyam siyā vipākam siyā vipāka dhamma dhammam nava indriyāni tidhā api nava indriyāni  upādinnupādāniyāni domanassindriyam anupādinnupādāniyam tīṇi anupādinna anupādāniyāni
translated: The mind faculty may be a resultant, or it may be a state having a resultant nature. Nine faculties are threefold.🔽Nine faculties are clung-to and related to the world of form. The grief faculty is not clung-to and related to the world of form. Three faculties are not clung-to and not related to the world of form.

original: nava tidhāpi. Domanassindriyaṃ savitakkasavicāraṃ, upekkhindriyaṃ tathā ca avitakkaavicārañca,
analyzed: nava tidhā api domanassindriyam sa vitakka sa vicāram upekkhindriyam tathā ca avitakka avicāram ca
translated: Nine are threefold. The grief faculty is accompanied by applied and sustained thought. The equanimity faculty is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, or it is not accompanied by applied thought but is accompanied by sustained thought, or it is not accompanied by applied thought and is not accompanied by sustained thought.

original: nava avitakkaavicārāni, ekādasa tidhāpi. Satta rūpindriyāni ceva sukhadukkhadomanassindriyāni
analyzed: nava avitakka avicārāni ekādasa tidhā api satta rūpa indriyāni ca iva sukha dukkha domanassa indriyāni
translated: Nine are without thinking and without exploring. Eleven are of two kinds. Seven are of three kinds.🔽The five beginning with the eye are limited. The last three are immeasurable. The remaining nine are of three kinds.

original: cāti dasa parittāni, pacchimāni tīṇi appamāṇāni, sesāni nava tidhāva. Tattha ca somanassindriyaṃ🔽rūpāvacaravaseneva mahaggataṃ, tadavasesāni arūpāvacaravasenāpīti veditabbaṃ. Pañcindriyāni
analyzed: dasa parittāni pacchimāni tīṇi appamāṇāni sesāni nava tattha ca somanassindriyaṃ  rūpāvacara vasena iva mahaggatam tad avasesāni arūpāvacara vasena api iti veditabbam pañcindriyāni
translated: And here the joy faculty is🔽great only in the fine-material sphere; the rest are also so in the immaterial sphere.

original: anidassanasappaṭighāni, sattarasa anidassanaappaṭighāneva.🔽Paññindriyādīni cattāri hetū, sesā na hetū…pe… domanassindriyaṃ saraṇaṃ, manajīvitasomanassaupekkhāvīriyasamādhindriyāni
analyzed: anidassana sappaṭighāni sattarasa anidassana appaṭighāni eva  paññindriya ādīni cattāri hetū sesāḥ na hetu upe domanassindriyam saraṇam mana jīvita somanassa aupekkhā vīriya samādhi indriyāni
translated: Five faculties are visible and have physical resistance. Seventeen are invisible and have no physical resistance.

original: dvidhāpi, sesāni pannarasa araṇānevāti ayaṃ pañhāpucchakanayo.
analyzed: dvidhā api ayam pañhāpucchaka nayaḥ
translated: The five beginning with the understanding faculty are causes. The rest are not causes. … The grief faculty is a shelter. The faculties of mind, life, joy, equanimity, and energy are of two kinds. The remaining fifteen are not shelters. This is the method of asking questions.

original: Indriyesu panetesu, pāḷimuttavinicchayo;
analyzed: indriyesu pana etesu
translated: But in these faculties, the method of the texts is ended.

original: Kamato dāni viññeyyo, tattha kosallamicchatā.
analyzed: kamataḥ dāni viññeyyaḥ tattha kosallam icchatā
translated: Now, the skill in the faculties should be known according to the method.

original: Kamatoti ayampi desanākkamova. Tattha ajjhattadhamme pariññāya ariyabhūmipaṭilābho
analyzed: kamataḥ ti ayam pi desanā kkamaḥ u va tattha ajjhatta dhamme pariññāya ariya bhūmi paṭilābho
translated: According to the method: this is the order of teaching. Herein, the attainment of the noble plane is by means of the full understanding of internal ideas.

original: hotīti attabhāvapariyāpannāni cakkhundriyādīni paṭhamaṃ desitāni. So manussattabhāvo
analyzed: hoti iti atta bhāva pariyāpannāni cakkhu indriya ādīni paṭhamam desitāni saḥ manussatta bhāvaḥ
translated: “It is” : the eye faculty, etc., which are included in the individual essence, are taught first. That human individual essence

original: yaṃ dhammaṃ upādāya “itthī”ti vā “puriso”ti vā saṅkhaṃ gacchati, “ayaṃ so”ti nidassanatthaṃ
analyzed: yam dhammam upādāya itthī iti vā purisaḥ iti vā saṅkham gacchati ayam saḥ ti nidassana ttham
translated: is the basis for the designation “woman” or “man.” In order to point out “this is that,”

original: tato itthindriyaṃ, purisindriyañca. So duvidhopi jīvitindriyapaṭibaddhavuttīti ñāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: tatas itthi indriyam purisa indriyam ca saḥ duvidhaḥ api jīvitindriya paṭibaddha vutti iti ñāpana ttham
translated: after that, the female and male faculties. Since both of these occur bound up with the life faculty, in order to show that,

original: tato jīvitindriyaṃ. Yāva tassa pavatti, tāva etesaṃ vedayitānaṃ anivatti. Yañca kiñci🔽vedayitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ sukhaṃ dukkhanti ñāpanatthaṃ tato sukhindriyādīni. Tannirodhatthaṃ
analyzed: tatas jīvitindriyam yāva tassa pavatti tāva etesam vedayitānam yat ca kiñci  vedayitam sabbam tam sukham dukkhanti ñāpana ttham tatas sukha indriya ādīni tad nirodha ttham
translated: after that, the life faculty. As long as there is the occurrence of that, there is no cessation of these feelings. And whatever is felt,🔽all that is either pleasant or painful. In order to show that, after that, the pleasure faculty, etc. But these states are to be developed in order to bring about the cessation of that. In order to show the practice,

original: pana ete dhammā bhāvetabbāti paṭipattidassanatthaṃ tato saddhādīni. “Imāya paṭipattiyā
analyzed: pana ete dhammā bhāvetabbā ti paṭipatti dassana tham tatas saddhā ādīni imāya paṭipattiyā
translated: after that, faith, etc. “By this practice

original: esa dhammo paṭhamaṃ attani pātubhavatī”ti paṭipattiyā amoghabhāvadassanatthaṃ tato
analyzed: esa dhammo paṭhamam attani pātubhavati iti paṭipattiyā amogha bhāva dassana attham tatas
translated: this state becomes manifest first in oneself” . In order to show that the practice is not fruitless, after that,

original: anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ. Tasseva phalattā, tato anantaraṃ bhāvetabbattā ca tato
analyzed: anaññātaññassāmi iti indriyam tassa iva phala ttā tatas anantaram bhāvetabba ttā ca tatas
translated: the “I-shall-come-to-know-the-unknown” faculty. Because it is the fruit of that and because it is to be developed immediately after that, after that,🔽the knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path. Because it is the fruit of that and because it is to be developed immediately after that, after that,🔽the knowledge and vision of the way. Because it is the fruit of that and because it is to be developed immediately after that, after that,🔽the final-knowledge faculty.

original: aññindriyaṃ. Ito paraṃ bhāvanāya imassa adhigamo, adhigate ca pana imasmiṃ natthi
analyzed: aññindriyam itas param bhāvanāya imassa adhigamaḥ adhigate ca pana imasmin natthi
translated: the faculty of final knowledge. From now on, this is attained by development. And when this is attained, there is no more🔽

original: kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti ñāpanatthaṃ ante paramassāsabhūtaṃ aññātāvindriyaṃ desitanti
analyzed: kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti ñāpana attham ante parama ssāsa bhūtam aññātāvindriyam desitanti
translated: The faculty of final knowledge. The faculty of final knowledge is taught as the supreme comfort at the end, in order to show that this is attained by development from here on, and that when it is attained there is nothing more to be done.

original: evaṃ kamato pāḷimuttavinicchayanayo viññeyyo.
analyzed: evam kamataḥ pāḷi mutta vinicchaya nayaḥ viññeyyaḥ
translated: So it should be understood how the method of exposition of the text of the Abhidhamma is according to the method of the triplets.

original: Indriyavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Paccayākāravibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā🔽Paccayākāravibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – avijjāpaccayātiādīsu avindiyaṃ kāyaduccaritādiṃ🔽vindati paṭilabhati, vindiyaṃ vā kāyasucaritādiṃ na vindati, dhammānaṃ vā yathāsabhāvaṃ🔽aviditaṃ karoti, antavirahite vā saṃsāre satte javāpeti, avijjamānesu vā javati,
analyzed: indriya vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  paccaya ākāra vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā  paccaya ākāra vibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva avijjā paccaya ati ādīsu kāya duccarita ādim  vindati paṭilabhati vā kāya su carita ādim na vindati dhammānam vā yathā sabhāvam  a viditam karoti anta virahite vā saṃsāre satte a vijjamānesu vā
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Schedule of the Analysis of the Faculties is ended.

original: vijjamānesu vā na javatīti avijjā. Paṭicca phalameti etasmāti paccayo, dhammānaṃ
analyzed: vijjamānesu vā na javati iti avijjā paṭicca phalam eti etasma ati paccayaḥ dhammānam
translated: As to the Schedule of the Analysis of the Causal Relations, however, the meaning is as follows. In the passage beginning “With ignorance as condition” , etc., it is not found , or it finds , or it is found , or it makes the true nature of things unknown , or it hurls beings into the beginningless round of rebirths , or it hurries on in what is not , or it does not hurry on in what is , thus it is ignorance . It is a condition in the sense of “reaching a fruit by depending on this” .

original: uppattiyā, ṭhitiyā ca upakārako dhammo. Avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo,
analyzed: uppattiyā ṭhitiyā ca upakārakaḥ dhammaḥ avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayo
translated: and it is a state that is helpful for the arising and steadying of the formations. It is ignorance and it is a condition, thus it is the condition ignorance.

original: tasmā avijjāpaccayā. Saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharontīti saṅkhārā.
analyzed: tasmai avijjā paccayā saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti saṅkhārā
translated: Therefore, with the condition ignorance, they form the formed. Thus they are formations.

original: Ito paraṃ saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇantiādīsu vuttaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Avuttesu
analyzed: itas param saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam ti ādīsu vuttam vutta nayena iva veditabbam avuttesu
translated: From here on, with the condition formations, consciousness, etc., what has been said should be understood in the same way as before.🔽But in the case of what has not been said,

original: pana vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ. Namatīti nāmaṃ, ruppatīti rūpaṃ, nāmañca rūpañca nāmarūpañca
analyzed: pana vijānāti iti viññāṇam namati iti nāmam ruppati iti rūpam nāmañca rūpañca nāma rūpañca
translated: it cognizes, thus it is consciousness. It bends, thus it is mind. It is molested, thus it is matter. Mind and matter are mentality-materiality.

original: nāmarūpanti ekadesasarūpekasesanayena veditabbaṃ. Āye tanoti, āyatañca nayatīti āyatanaṃ,🔽chaṭṭhāyatanañca saḷāyatanañca saḷāyatananti ekasesanayena veditabbaṃ. Phusatīti
analyzed: nāma rūpam ti eka desa sarūpa ikasesa nayena veditabbam āye tanoti āyatan ca nayati iti āyatanam  chaṭṭha āyatanam ca saḷāyatanam ca saḷāyatanam ti eka sesa nayena veditabbam phusati iti
translated: Mentality-materiality should be understood in the way beginning “matter in the sense of one part and matter in the sense of a remainder.” It extends, it leads out, thus it is a base.

original: phasso. Vedayatīti vedanā. Paritassatīti taṇhā. Upādiyatīti upādānaṃ. Bhavati, bhāvayati
analyzed: phassaḥ vedayati iti vedanā paritassati iti taṇhā upādiyati iti upādānam bhavati bhāvayati
translated: The sixth base and the sixfold base are the sixfold base in the sense of a remainder. It contacts, thus it is contact. It feels, thus it is feeling. It longs, thus it is craving. It grasps, thus it is assuming. It becomes, it causes to become, thus it is becoming.

original: cāti bhavo. Jananaṃ jāti. Jīraṇaṃ jarā. Maranti etenāti maraṇaṃ. Socanaṃ soko. Paridevanaṃ
analyzed: ca ati bhavaḥ jananam jāti jīraṇam jarā maranti etena ati maraṇam socanam paridevanam
translated: The birth is birth. The aging is aging. It dies, thus it is death. It grieves, thus it is sorrow. It laments, thus it is lamentation.

original: paridevo. Dukkhayati, uppādaṭṭhitivasena dvidhā khaṇatītipi dukkhaṃ. Dummanassa bhāvo
analyzed: paridevaḥ dukkhayati uppāda ṭṭhiti vasena dvidhā dukkham dummanassa bhāvo
translated: and sorrow. It is suffering because it torments by the two kinds of pain classed as pain of change and pain of suffering.🔽Gloominess is the state of being downcast.🔽Agitation is great affliction.

original: domanassaṃ. Bhuso āyāso upāyāso. Sambhavantīti nibbattanti. Na kevalañca sokādīheva,
analyzed: domanassam bhusaḥ āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ sambhavanti iti nibbattanti na kevalam ca soka ādi iha iva
translated: “Come to be” : are generated. And not only by sorrow, etc.,

original: atha kho avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā sambhavantītiādinā sabbapadehipi sambhavanti-saddassa
analyzed: atha kho avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā sambhavanti iti ādinā sabba padehi pi sambhavanti saddassa
translated: but also by all the terms beginning with “With ignorance as condition there are formations” should be construed with the word “come to be.”

original: yojanā kātabbā. Evaṃ hi paccayapaccayuppannavavatthānaṃ kataṃ hoti.🔽Evanti niddiṭṭhanayanidassanaṃ, tena avijjādīheva kāraṇehi, na issaranimmānādīhīti
analyzed: yojanā kātabbā evam hi paccaya paccaya uppanna vavatthānam katam hoti  evam ti niddiṭṭha naya nidassanam tena avijjā ādīhi iva kāraṇehi na issara nimmāna ādīhi iti
translated: For in this way the distinction of condition and conditionally-arisen is made.🔽“Thus”: this shows the method stated above. By that he shows that it is only by such causes as ignorance, etc., and not by a Supreme God, etc.,

original: dasseti. Etassāti yathāvuttassa. Kevalassāti asammissassa, sakalassa vā, dukkhakkhandhassāti
analyzed: dassa iti etassa ati yathā vuttassa kevalassa ati asammissassa sakalassa vā dukkha kkhandhassa ati
translated: “This entire”: this entire, unmixed, or complete.🔽“Mass of suffering”: mass of suffering, not a being, not pleasure, beauty, etc.

original: dukkhasamūhassa, na sattassa, na sukhasubhādīnaṃ. Samudayoti nibbatti, hotīti sambhavati.🔽Ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.
analyzed: dukkha samūhassa na sattassa na sukha subha ādīnam samudayo ti nibbatti hoti iti sambhavati 🔽ayam tā vettha padatthaḥ
translated: “Origination”: generation. “Comes to be”: is generated.

original: Dhammabhedato panettha avijjāti suttantapariyāyena dukkhādīsu catūsu, abhidhammapariyāyena
analyzed: dhamma bhedato pana ittha avijjā ti suttanta pariyāyena dukkha ādīsu catūsu abhidhamma pariyāyena
translated: But as to the analysis of the Dhamma, ignorance is, according to the Suttanta method, in the four things beginning with suffering, and according to the Abhidhamma method

original: pubbantādīhi saddhiṃ aṭṭhasu vā ṭhānesu aññāṇaṃ. Saṅkhārā pana puññāpuññāneñjābhisaṅkhārā
analyzed: pubbanta ādīhi saddhim aṭṭhasu vā ṭhānesu aññāṇam saṅkhārā pana puññāpuñña aneñja abhisaṅkhārā
translated: it is non-penetration in the eight things beginning with the past. But the determinations are the three determinations of merit, of demerit, and of the imperturbable,

original: tayo, kāyavacīcittasaṅkhārā tayo cāti chabbidhā. Tattha aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalacetanā,
analyzed: tayo kāya vacī citta saṅkhārā tayo ca ati chabbidhā tattha aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā
translated: and they are of six kinds as the three determinations of body, speech, and mind. Herein, thirteen kinds of volition, namely

original: pañca rūpāvacarakusalacetanā ceti terasa cetanā puññābhisaṅkhāro nāma. Dvādasa akusalacetanā
analyzed: pañca rūpāvacara kusala cetanā ca iti terasa cetanā puññābhisaṅkhāraḥ nāma dvādasa akusala cetanā
translated: eight kinds of profitable volition in the sense-world sphere and five kinds of profitable volition in the fine-material world sphere, are called the determination of merit. Twelve kinds of unprofitable volition

original: apuññābhisaṅkhāro nāma. Catasso arūpāvacarakusalacetanā āneñjābhisaṅkhāro nāma. Imesaṃ
analyzed: apuñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ nāma catasso arūpāvacara kusala cetanāḥ āneñja abhisaṅkhāraḥ nāma imesam
translated: are called the determination of demerit. Four kinds of profitable volition in the immaterial world sphere are called the determination of the imperturbable.

original: pana tiṇṇaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ eva dvārato pavattidassanatthaṃ ayaṃ saṅkhārādittiko vutto.
analyzed: pana tiṇṇam saṅkhārānam eva dvārataḥ pavatti dassana tham ayam vutto
translated: But this exposition of determinations, etc., is given in order to show the way in which these three kinds of determinations occur by means of the doors.

original: Aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalacetanā ceva dvādasākusalacetanā ca kāyadvāre pavattiyaṃ kāyasaṅkhāro,
analyzed: aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā ca iva dvādasa akusala cetanā ca kāya dvāre pavattiyam kāya saṅkhāro
translated: Eight kinds of profitable volition in the sense-world sphere and twelve kinds of unprofitable volition are determinations of body in the occurrence of the body door,

original: vacīdvāre pavattiyaṃ vacīsaṅkhāro, etā ceva manodvāre pavattiyaṃ, manodvāre eva pavattanakā
analyzed: vacī dvāre pavattiyam vacī saṅkhāraḥ etā ca iva manaḥ dvāre pavattiyam manaḥ dvāre eva pavattanakā
translated: The formation of a volition in the verbal door is verbal formation. The same in the mental door is mental formation.

original: rūpārūpakusalacetanā ca cittasaṅkhāroti vuccanti. Abhiññācetanā, panettha uddhaccacetanā
analyzed: rūpa arūpa kusala cetanā ca citta saṅkhāro ti vuccanti abhiññā cetanā pana ittha uddhacca cetanā
translated: And the wholesome volition of the fine-material and immaterial aggregates is called mental formation. But the volition of direct-knowledge and the volition of agitation,

original: ca parato paṭisandhiviññāṇapaccayabhāve apanetabbāpi avijjāpaccayā sambhavato idha
analyzed: ca paratas paṭisandhi viññāṇa paccaya bhāve apanetabbā api avijjā paccayā sambhavataḥ idha
translated: though they should be excluded from the condition-state of rebirth-linking consciousness, are nevertheless to be included here as they are possible as conditions for ignorance.

original: gahetabbāvāti ayaṃ tiko purimattikameva pavisatīti atthato lokiyakusalākusalacetanāva
analyzed: gahetabbā avā ti ayam tiko purima tikam eva pavisati iti atthataḥ lokiya kusala akusala cetanā ava
translated: So this triad falls within the first triad. As to meaning, however, only the wholesome and unwholesome volition of the worlds is to be understood as formations with ignorance as condition.

original: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti veditabbaṃ. Idañca suttantabhājanīyanayena, abhidhammabhājanīyanayena
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti veditabbam idam ca suttanta bhājanīya nayena abhidhamma bhājanīya nayena
translated: And this is according to the method of the Suttanta Basket. But according to the method of the Abhidhamma Basket,

original: pana lokiyalokuttare ekekacittakkhaṇe dvādasaṅgassa paṭiccasamuppādassa gahaṇato🔽sabbāpi cetanā saṅkhārāti veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ viññāṇanāmarūpādīsupi sabbacittasampayuttavasena
analyzed: pana lokiya lokuttare eka eka citta kkhaṇe dvādasaṅgassa paṭiccasamuppādassa gahaṇato  sabbā api cetanā saṅkhārā ti veditabbam evam viññāṇa nāma rūpa ādīsu pi sabba citta sampayutta vasena
translated: all volition should be understood as formations because the twelve-factored dependent origination is discerned in each conscious moment of the worlds and of the higher than the worlds.

original: ca dhammabhedo veditabbo. Suttantabhājanīyanayeneva pana dassayissāma.
analyzed: ca dhamma bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ suttanta bhājanīya nayena iva pana dassayissāma
translated: So the analysis of states should be understood in this way as associated with all consciousness. But we shall illustrate it according to the method of the Suttanta Basket only.

original: Saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇañca cakkhuviññāṇādichabbidhaṃ bāttiṃsalokiyavipākaviññāṇameva🔽hoti, lokuttarāni pana vaṭṭakathāya na yujjantīti na gahitāni. Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayāḥ viññāṇam ca cakkhu viññāṇa ādi chabbidham bāttiṃsa lokiya vipāka viññāṇam eva  hoti lokuttarāni pana vaṭṭa kathāya na yujjanti iti na gahitāni viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpam
translated: And with formations as condition, consciousness is the six kinds of resultant consciousness classed as eye-consciousness, etc., and amounting to thirty-two kinds of mundane resultant consciousness. But the supramundane kinds are not included because they do not belong to the round of rebirths. With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality.

original: pana sabbalokiyaviññāṇasampayuttā tayo arūpino khandhā. Rūpaṃ sabbāni bhūtupādāyarūpāni.
analyzed: pana sabba lokiya viññāṇa sampayuttā tayo arūpino khandhāḥ rūpam sabbāni bhūta upādāyarūpāni
translated: “With formations as condition, consciousness”: the six kinds of resultant consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness and the thirty-two kinds of mundane resultant consciousness. But the supramundane kinds are not included because they are not relevant to the exposition of the round. “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality”: the three immaterial aggregates associated with all mundane consciousness. The materiality is all the primary and secondary matter.

original: Saḷāyatanaṃ manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni. Phasso cakkhusamphassādiko chavipākaphasso,🔽tathā vedanāpi. Taṇhā rūpataṇhādibhedato chabbidho lobho. Upādānaṃ kāmupādānādito
analyzed: indriyāni phasso cakkhu samphassa ādiko cha vipāka phasso  tathā vedanā api taṇhā rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedataḥ chabbidhaḥ lobhaḥ upādānam kāma upādāna āditaḥ
translated: “With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base”: the six bases consisting of the mind and the five physical sense faculties. “With the sixfold base as condition, contact”: the six kinds of resultant contact beginning with eye-contact.

original: catubbidhā lobhadiṭṭhiyova. Bhavo pana duvidho kammabhavo, upapattibhavoti. Tattha🔽kammabhavo tebhūmakakusalākusalacetanā ca taṃsampayuttā abhijjhādayo ca. Upapattibhavo
analyzed: catubbidhā bhavaḥ pana duvidho kamma bhavo upapatti bhavo ti tattha  kamma bhavo tebhūmaka kusala akusala cetanā ca tad sampayuttāḥ abhijjhā ādayo ca upapatti bhavo
translated: So too with feeling. “With feeling as condition, craving”: craving is of six kinds classed as craving for visible forms, etc., and it is greed. “With craving as condition, clinging”: clinging is of four kinds classed as sense-desire clinging, etc., and it is greed. “With clinging as condition, existence”: existence is of two kinds, kamma-existence and rebirth-process existence.

original: pana kammābhinibbattā pañcapi khandhā. So pabhedato kāmarūpārūpabhavā tayo, saññā
analyzed: pana kamma abhinibbattā pañca api khandhā so pabhedato kāmarūpa arūpa bhavā tayo saññā
translated: Herein, kamma-existence is profitable and unprofitable volition in the three planes, and the greed, etc., associated with it. Rebirth-process existence is the five aggregates generated by kamma. It is threefold classed as sense-desire existence, fine-material existence, and immaterial existence.

original: asaññā nevasaññānāsaññā bhavā tayo, ekacatupañcavokārabhavā tayoti navavidho niddiṭṭho.🔽Jātiādīni pubbe vuttāni. Tesu jātiggahaṇena viññāṇanāmarūpasaḷāyatanaphassavedanāva
analyzed: asaññā nevasaññānāsaññā bhavā tayo eka catu pañca vokāra bhavā tayo ti navavidhaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ  jāti ādīni pubbe vuttāni tesu jāti ggahaṇena viññāṇa nāma rūpa saṅgāyatana phassa vedanā va
translated: The three kinds of becoming are the non-percipient, the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient, and the five-constituent kinds.

original: gahitā tadavinābhāvato. Tathā jarāmaraṇaggahaṇenāpi tesaññeva pākabhedattā. Sokādayo
analyzed: tad avinābhāvato tathā jarā maraṇa ggahaṇena api tesaññā eva soka ādayaḥ
translated: Birth, etc., are as already mentioned. Herein, by the mention of birth, consciousness, mentality-materiality, the sixfold base, contact, and feeling are included too, because they are inseparable from it. Likewise by the mention of ageing-and-death, they are included too, because they are its ripening.

original: pana jarāmaraṇena dvādasamena aṅgena ekasaṅkhepaṃ katvā vuttā, na visuṃ aṅgabhāvena.
analyzed: pana jarā maraṇena dvādasamena aṅgena eka saṅkhepam katvā vuttā na visum aṅga bhāvena
translated: Sorrow, etc., are mentioned by the twelfth factor, ageing-and-death, in brief, not as a separate factor.

original: Kimatthanti ce? Bhavacakkassa avicchedadassanatthaṃ. Sokādito hi avijjā siddhā hoti
analyzed: kimattham ti ce bhava cakkassa a viccheda dassana attham soka āditaḥ hi avijjā siddhā hoti
translated: What is the point of that? It is to show that the round is unbroken. For sorrow, etc., are established as ignorance

original: avijjāvippayogato, avijjāsamuppattito ca. Jarāmaraṇabbhāhatassa hi bālasseva te sambhavanti,
analyzed: avijjā vippayogataḥ avijjā samuppattitaḥ ca jarā maraṇa abbhā hatassa hi bālassa iva te sambhavanti
translated: because of the absence of ignorance, and because of the arising of ignorance. For these occur only in a fool who is struck down by ageing-and-death,

original: tehi ca avijjāya siddhāya puna avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti evaṃ hetuphalaparamparāya
analyzed: tehi ca avijjāya siddhāya puna avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati evam hetu phala paramparāya
translated: and when sorrow, etc., are established by that, then ignorance has a condition again in the form of sorrow, etc., and so the round of the conditions of cause and fruit

original: bhavacakkaṃ avicchinnaṃ, anādikaṃ, apariyantaṃ, apariyosānañca hoti.
analyzed: bhava cakkam a vicchinnam anādikam a pariyantam a pariyosānam ca hoti
translated: is unbroken, beginningless, endless, and without any being who traverses it.

original: Yadi evaṃ, kasmā avijjā ādito vuttāti? Padhānadassanatthaṃ pana ādito vuttā. Tiṇṇaṃ🔽hi vaṭṭānaṃ avijjā padhāno hetu tassā bhāve bhāvato, nirodhena ca nirujjhanato. Evaṃ
analyzed: yadi evam kasmai avijjā āditas vuttā ati padhāna dassana attham pana āditas vuttā  hi vaṭṭānam avijjā padhānaḥ hetu tassāḥ bhāve bhāvataḥ nirodhena ca nirujjhanataḥ evam
translated: If that is so, why is ignorance stated first? It is stated first in order to show the root. For ignorance is the root of the three rounds of existence. When it exists, they exist; when it does not exist, they do not exist. And they cease with the cessation of ignorance.

original: avijjādīhi dvādasahi aṅgehi suttantabhājanīyanayena sabbe lokiyadhammāva paccayapaccayuppannabhāvena🔽vuttāti veditabbā. Abhidhammapariyāyena pana lokuttarāpīti ayamettha dhammabhedo.
analyzed: avijjā ādīhi dvādasahi aṅgehi suttanta bhājanīya nayena sabbe lokiya dhammā paccaya paccaya uppanna bhāvena  vuttā ati veditabbā abhidhamma pariyāyena pana lokuttarā api iti ayam ettha dhamma bhedaḥ
translated: But if that is so, why is ignorance stated first? It is stated first as the principal cause. For ignorance is the principal cause of the three rounds. It is because of its presence that they come to be, and it is through its cessation that they cease. So all mundane states should be understood as stated by way of the conditionality of the states beginning with ignorance and ending with aging-and-death. But in the Abhidhamma they are stated by way of the supramundane states as well. This is the exposition of the states.

original: Vibhaṅganayato panettha pañhāpucchakanayo natthi, suttantabhājanīyanayāpi dhammabhede vuttanayeneva vitthārato vibhattāti veditabbo. Abhidhammabhājanīye pana –🔽“Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmaṃ, nāmapaccayā
analyzed: vibhaṅga nayataḥ pana ittha pañhāpucchaka nayaḥ natthi suttanta bhājanīya nayā api dhamma bhede vutta nayena iva vitthārataḥ vibhattā ti veditabbaḥ abhidhamma bhājanīye pana  avijjā paccayā saṅkhāraḥ saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāmam nāma paccayā
translated: As regards the method of questioning, there is none here as in the case of the Suttanta method. But it should be understood that the exposition in detail is in the way already stated in the case of the exposition of the states by the Suttanta method. In the Abhidhamma method, however, it is as follows:

original: chaṭṭhāyatanaṃ, chaṭṭhāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā
analyzed: chaṭṭha āyatanam chaṭṭha āyatana paccayā phassaḥ phassa paccayā vedanā vedanā paccayā
translated: “With ignorance as condition there are formations; with formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality; with mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base; with the sixfold base as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving;🔽with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, becoming; with becoming as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging-and-death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.”

original: taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā
analyzed: taṇhā taṇhā paccayā upādānam upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ bhava paccayā jāti jāti paccayā
translated: craving, craving is a condition for attachment, attachment is a condition for continuation, continuation is a condition for birth, birth is a condition for

original: jarāmaraṇaṃ, evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.🔽“Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro…pe… viññāṇapaccayā nāmaṃ, nāmapaccayā phasso…pe… samudayo hoti.
analyzed: jarā maraṇam evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti  avijjā paccayā saṅkhāra upe viññāṇa paccayā nāmam nāma paccayā phassa upe samudayaḥ hoti
translated: old age and death. Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.🔽“With ignorance as condition there are (volitional) processes, … with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form. With mind and bodily form as condition: the sixth sense sphere. With the sixth sense sphere as condition: contact … Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.

original: “Avijjāpaccayā…pe… viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā chaṭṭhāyatanaṃ, chaṭṭhāyatanapaccayā phasso…pe… samudayo hoti.
analyzed: avijjā paccaya āpe viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam nāma rūpa paccayā chaṭṭha āyatanam chaṭṭha āyatana paccayā phassa upe samudayaḥ hoti
translated: “With ignorance as condition … with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form. With mind and bodily form as condition: the six sense spheres. With the sixth sense sphere as condition: contact … Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.

original: “Avijjāpaccayā …pe… viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, chaṭṭhāyatanapaccayā phasso…pe… samudayo hotī”ti –🔽Evaṃ paccayacatukkaṃ, puna “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro avijjāhetuko”tiādinā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: avijjā paccayā pe viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanam chaṭṭha āyatana paccayā samudayaḥ hoti iti  evam paccaya catukkam puna avijjā paccayā saṅkhāraḥ avijjā hetukaḥ ti ādinā vutta nayena iva
translated: “With ignorance as condition … with consciousness as condition: mind and bodily form. With mind and bodily form as condition: the six sense spheres. With the sixth sense sphere as condition: contact … Thus there is an origination of this whole mass of suffering.”🔽Thus the four conditions. Again, “With ignorance as condition there are (volitional) processes, which are rooted in ignorance,” and so on,🔽is the four conditions by way of root. Again, “With ignorance as condition there are (volitional) processes, which are associated with ignorance,” and so on,

original: hetucatukkaṃ, puna “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro avijjāsampayutto”tiādinā sampayuttacatukkaṃ,
analyzed: hetu catukkam puna avijjā paccayā saṅkhāro avijjā sampayuttaḥ ti ādinā sampayutta catukkam
translated: is the four conditions by way of association.

original: puna “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro, saṅkhārapaccayāpi avijjā”tiādinā aññamaññapaccayacatukkanti
analyzed: puna avijjā paccayā saṅkhāro saṅkhāra paccayā api avijjā āti ādinā aññamañña paccaya catukkanti
translated: and again with the four sections beginning, “With ignorance as condition there are formations, and with formations as condition, ignorance” ,

original: evaṃ avijjāmūlakāni cattāri catukkāni vuttāni. Evaṃ “saṅkhārapaccayā avijjā”tiādinā
analyzed: evam avijjā mūlakāni cattāri catukkāni vuttāni evam saṅkhāra paccayā avijjā āti ādinā
translated: thus making four sections rooted in ignorance. Similarly with the four sections beginning, “With formations as condition, ignorance” ,

original: saṅkhārādimūlakādiupādānamūlakapariyosānāni aṭṭhasu padesu cattāri cattāri catukkānīti🔽bāttiṃsa catukkāni mātikaṃ katvā nikkhipitvā puna akusalakusalavipākakiriyacittesu🔽lokiyalokuttaresu ekekasmiṃ citte yathānikkhittehi chattiṃsabāttiṃsamātikācatukkehi
analyzed: saṅkhāra ādi mūlaka ādi upādāna mūlaka pariyosānāni aṭṭhasu padesu cattāri cattāri catukkāni iti  bāttiṃsa catukkāni mātikam katvā nikkhipitvā puna akusala kusala vipāka kiriya cittesu  lokiya lokuttaresu ekekasmin citte yathā nikkhittehi chattiṃsa bāttiṃsa mātikā catukkehi
translated: and so on, there are four sections in each of the remaining eight places, that is, with craving as root, and so on, up to with clinging as root,🔽thus making thirty-two sets of four sections. This is the matrix. When this has been set forth, then the method of conditionality should be expounded in detail according to the appropriate states among the thirty-two and thirty-six sets of four sections in the various kinds of consciousness, that is to say,

original: vitthārato yathānurūpaṃ paccayākāro vibhatto. Idañca yasmā na kevalaṃ ayaṃ paccayākāro
analyzed: vitthārataḥ yathānurūpam paccaya ākāraḥ vibhattaḥ idam ca yasmai na kevalam ayam paccaya ākāro
translated: in the unprofitable, profitable, resultant and functional kinds, and in the mundane and supramundane kinds.

original: nānācittesu eva hoti, ekacittepi hotiyeva. Nāpi vaṭṭacitte eva hoti, taṇhābhāvato
analyzed: nānā cittesu eva hoti eka citte api na api vaṭṭa citte eva hoti taṇhā bhāvato
translated: And this method of conditionality is not only in the various kinds of consciousness; it is also in a single kind of consciousness. And it is not only in the kinds of consciousness in the round of rebirths; it is also in the kinds of consciousness in the cessation of the round.

original: vivaṭṭacittepi, tasmā taṃ nippadesato ekacittakkhaṇikaṃ paccayākāraṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vivaṭṭa citte api tasmā tam nippadesataḥ eka citta kkhaṇikam paccaya ākāram dassetum vuttam
translated: So it is said in order to show the method of conditionality in a single conscious moment without specifying the kinds of consciousness.

original: Teneva hettha “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti avatvā “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro”ti ekavacanena
analyzed: tena iva ha ittha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati avatvā avijjā paccayā saṅkhāro ti ekavacanena
translated: And so, instead of saying “With ignorance as condition there are formations,” it says “With ignorance as condition, a formation” in the singular number,

original: vuttaṃ ekacittakkhaṇe bahucetanābhāvā. Tattha yadetaṃ paṭhamacatukkaṃ, tattha paṭhamavāro🔽nāmarūpaṭṭhāne nāmaṃ, saḷāyatanaṭṭhāne chaṭṭhāyatanañca gahetvā rūpārūpādisabbabhavasādhāraṇavasena,🔽ekacittakkhaṇapariyāpannadhammaggahaṇavasena ca rūpaṃ chaḍḍetvā vutto rūpassa sabbabhavāsādhāraṇattā,
analyzed: vuttam eka cittakkhaṇe bahu cetanā abhāvā tattha yat etam paṭhama catukkam tattha paṭhama vāraḥ  nāma rūpa ṭṭhāne nāmam saḷāyatana ṭṭhāne chaṭṭhāyatanañca gahetvā rūpa arūpa ādi sabba bhava sādhāraṇa vasena  eka citta kkhaṇa pariyāpanna dhamma ggahaṇa vasena ca rūpam chaḍḍetvā vuttaḥ rūpassa sabba bhava a sādhāraṇa ttā
translated: because there is no plurality of intentions in a single conscious moment. Herein, in the first tetrad the first section🔽is stated by excluding materiality in the first two instances, namely, in the case of mentality and in the case of the sixth base,

original: bahucittakkhaṇikattā ca. Dutiyo nāmarūpaṭṭhāne nāmaṃ, “nāmapaccayā phasso”ti saḷāyatanaṭṭhāne🔽phassameva gahetvā phassassa saḷāyatanaṃ vināpi paccayavisesasambhavadassanavasena
analyzed: bahu citta khaṇika ttā ca dutiyaḥ nāma rūpa ṭṭhāne nāmam nāma paccayā phasso ti saḷāyatana ṭṭhāne  phassam eva gahetvā phassassa saṅgāyatanam vinā api paccaya visesa sambhava dassana vasena
translated: because materiality is not common to all kinds of becoming and because it is included in the states of a single conscious moment. The second section🔽is stated by taking only contact in the case of the sixth base,

original: ceva mahānidānasuttanayadassanavasena ca vutto. Tatiyo saḷāyatanaṭṭhāne chaṭṭhāyatanameva
analyzed: ca iva mahānidāna sutta naya dassana vasena ca vutto tatiyo saḷāyatana ṭṭhāne chaṭṭha āyatanam eva
translated: because it is shown that contact is a condition for mentality even without the sixth base, and because it is shown by the method of the Mahānidāna Sutta . The third section🔽is stated by taking only the sixth base in the case of the sixth base,

original: gahetvā gabbhaseyyakānaṃ aparipuṇṇāyatanānaṃ, rūpabhavikādīnañca vasena vutto. Catuttho
analyzed: gahetvā gabbhaseyyakānam a paripuṇṇa āyatanānam rūpa bhavika ādīnam ca vasena vutto catutthaḥ
translated: and the four kinds of generation, namely, womb-born, egg-born, moisture-born, and spontaneously born.

original: “nāmapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso”ti evaṃ itarāyatanehipi saḷāyatanassa
analyzed: nāma paccayā saḷāyatanam saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti evam itara āyatanehi pi saḷāyatanassa
translated: “With mentality as condition, the six sense bases; with the six sense bases as condition, contact” , and so on, shows the specific conditionality of the six sense bases by the other links.

original: visesato phassapaccayataṃva dassetvā opapātikānaṃ, paripuṇṇāyatanānaṃ kāmabhavikānañca
analyzed: visesataḥ phassa paccaya tam va dassetvā opapātikānam paripuṇṇa āyatanānam kāmabhavikānam ca
translated: It is stated with reference to the four kinds of generation, namely, womb-born, egg-born, moisture-born, and spontaneously born.

original: vasena vutto. Evaṃ dutiyacatukkādīsupi.🔽Sabbatthāpi cettha yasmā sokādayo sabbe ekacittakkhaṇe na sambhavanti, sabbasmiñca🔽citte, bhave ca nappavattanti, tasmā na gahitā. Jātijarāmaraṇāni panettha arūpadhammānaṃ🔽lakkhaṇamattāni, tāni ca acittakkhaṇamattānipi samānāni cittakkhaṇe antogadhattā
analyzed: vasena vuttaḥ evam dutiya catukka ādīsu pi  sabbattha api ca ittha yasmā soka ādayaḥ sabbe eka cittakkhaṇe na sambhavanti sabbasmin ca  citte bhave ca na pavattanti tasmā na gahitā jāti jarā maraṇāni pana ittha arūpa dhammānam  lakkhaṇa mattāni tāni ca acitta khaṇa mattāni pi samānāni citta kkhaṇe
translated: So too with the second triad, and so on.🔽But here grief, etc., are not included because they do not all occur in a single conscious moment and because they do not occur in all kinds of consciousness and in all kinds of becoming.

original: pariyāyato paccayuppanne katvā aṅgaparipūraṇatthaṃ gahitāni. Bhavoti cettha upādānādipaccayavirahitā
analyzed: pariyāyataḥ paccaya uppanne katvā aṅga paripūraṇa attham gahitāni ca ittha upādāna ādi paccaya virahitā
translated: Birth, ageing, and death are merely the characteristics of immaterial dhammas. And although they occur only in a single conscious moment, they are included as conditions in the sense of being included in the round of existence, in order to complete the enumeration of the factors.🔽As to “becoming,” it is stated

original: cattāro arūpino khandhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānanti ettha kāmupādānaṃ vajjetvā tīṇi
analyzed: cattāro arūpino khandhāḥ taṇhā paccayā upādānan ti ettha kāma upādānam vajjetvā tīṇi
translated: The four immaterial aggregates, with craving as condition: with the exception of sense-desire clinging, the other three kinds of clinging.

original: upādānāni eva gahetabbāni. Dvinnampi ekalakkhaṇānaṃ dhammānaṃ ekakkhaṇe asambhavā🔽lobhamūlavirahitesu dosamohamūlesu ceva kusalābyākatesu ca cittesu vedanāpaccayā
analyzed: upādānāni eva gahetabbāni dvinnam pi eka lakkhaṇānam dhammānam eka kkhaṇe asambhavā  lobha mūla virahitesu dosa moha mūlesu ca iva kusala abyākatesu ca cittesu vedanā paccayā
translated: The four immaterial aggregates are due to craving, and due to craving there is clinging. Herein, the clinging to sense pleasures should be omitted and only the three kinds of clinging should be taken. For it is impossible for two things having the same characteristic to be present together in a single cognitive series.

original: paṭighaṃ vicikicchā uddhaccanti evaṃ taṇhāṭhāne yathāyogaṃ paṭighādayo tayo. Tesu🔽vicikicchāvajjitesu ceva diṭṭhivippayuttesu ca upādānaṭṭhāne adhimokkho gahito. Vicikicchāya
analyzed: paṭigham vicikicchā uddhaccanti evam taṇhā ṭhāne yathāyogam paṭigha ādayaḥ tayaḥ tesu  vicikicchā vajjitesu ca iva diṭṭhi vippayuttesu ca upādānaṭṭhāne adhimokkhaḥ gahitaḥ vicikicchāya
translated: In the kinds of consciousness rooted in hate and in the kinds rooted in delusion, and in the kinds that are indeterminate, feeling is a condition for repugnance, perplexity, and agitation. So in place of craving, repugnance, etc., should be construed as appropriate.🔽In the kinds of consciousness free from perplexity and associated with wrong view, the condition by way of decisive support is taken as applied thought.🔽But since applied thought is impossible together with perplexity, the condition by way of decisive support is taken as the state of being a condition for becoming.

original: pana saddhiṃ adhimokkhassāpi asambhavā vicikicchāpaccayā bhavoti ca gahito. Upādānaṭṭhāne🔽ca adhimokkho ca gahito. Lokiyānañcettha kusalābyākatānaṃ upanissayavasena avijjāpaccayatā
analyzed: pana saddhim adhimokkhassa api asambhavā vicikicchā paccayā bhavaḥ ti ca gahitaḥ upādānaṭṭhāne  ca adhimokkhaḥ ca gahitaḥ lokiyānam ca ittha kusala abyākatānam upanissaya vasena avijjā paccaya tā
translated: And in the kinds of consciousness free from applied thought, the condition by way of decisive support is taken as the condition by way of decisive support.🔽Herein, the condition by way of decisive support for the mundane kinds of profitable and indeterminate consciousness is stated by way of ignorance.

original: vuttā. Lokuttarānaṃ pana yasmā appahīnāvijjo avijjāya pahānatthaṃ, paṭippassambhanatthañca
analyzed: vuttā lokuttarānam pana yasmai appahīna avijjaḥ avijjāya pahāna attham paṭippassambhana attham ca
translated: But for the supramundane kinds of consciousness, it is stated by way of the condition by way of decisive support for the supramundane kinds of consciousness, since one who has not abandoned ignorance, for the purpose of abandoning ignorance, and for the purpose of suppressing the defilements,

original: lokuttaraṃ bhāveti, tasmā samatikkamanavasena avijjāpaccayatā vuttā, na sahajātavasena.
analyzed: lokuttaram bhāveti tasmā samatikkamana vasena avijjā paccaya tā vuttā na sahajāta vasena
translated: He develops the supramundane, therefore the conditionality through surmounting is stated, not conditionality through conascence.

original: Teneva tesaṃ niddesavāresu “tattha katamā avijjā”ti avibhajitvā “tattha katamo avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: tena iva tesam niddesa vāresu tattha katamā avijjā ti a vibhajitvā tattha katamaḥ avijjā paccayā
translated: That is why in the Description of this Dependent Origination, after not analysing “What is ignorance here?” it is analysed “What is formations with ignorance as condition? ”

original: saṅkhāro”ti vibhattaṃ. Kiriyadhammānaṃ pana kenaci pariyāyena avijjāmūlakattaṃ natthīti
analyzed: saṅkhāro ti vibhattam kiriya dhammānam pana kenacid pariyāyena avijjā mūlaka ttam natthi iti
translated: But there is no root-cause conditionality in any way for the functional dhammas,

original: “saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇa”ntiādinā saṅkhāramūlakādiko nayo vutto, na avijjāmūlako.🔽Apica lokiyakusalādīsu tesaṃ dhammānaṃ dukkhasaccapariyāpannattā “evametassa kevalassa🔽dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hotī”ti evaṃ appanā katā, lokuttarakusalādīsu “evametesaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇan ti ādinā saṅkhāra mūlaka ādikaḥ nayaḥ vuttaḥ na avijjā mūlakaḥ  apica lokiya kusala ādīsu tesam dhammānam dukkha sacca pariyāpanna ttā evam etassa kevalassa  dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti iti evam appanā katā lokuttara kusala ādīsu evam etesam
translated: so the method stated in the way beginning “With formations as condition, consciousness” is root-cause method, not ignorance-root method.

original: dhammāna”nti. Ayaṃ lokiyato lokuttarānaṃ desanāya visesoti ayaṃ abhidhammabhājanīye nayo.🔽Idāni paccayanayā, kārakādīhi suññato;
analyzed: dhammānan ti ayam lokiyataḥ lokuttarānam desanāya viseso ti ayam abhidhammabhājanīye nayo  idāni paccayanayā kāraka ādīhi suññataḥ
translated: Besides, in the case of the mundane profitable, etc., the four noble truths are included in the truth of suffering, and so the definition is given in the way beginning, “So there is an origin to this whole mass of suffering” . In the case of the supramundane profitable, etc., it is given in the way beginning, “So there is an origin to these states” . This is the difference in the teaching of the supramundane as against the mundane. This is the method in the Abhidhamma.🔽Now, by the method of conditions, by the voidness of doer, etc.,

original: Mūladdhasandhisaṅkhepākāravaṭṭavibhāgato.
analyzed: mūladdha sandhi saṅkhepa ākāra vaṭṭa vibhāgataḥ
translated: By root, by having a root, by brief and detailed, by mode, and by round.

original: Vāraṇopamatopettha, gambhīranayabhedato;
analyzed: gambhīra naya bhedataḥ
translated: The method of condition is here to be understood as to profundity and as to classification,

original: Yathārahaṃ vijānīyo, pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: yathāraham vijānīyaḥ
translated: As to the text and the exegesis, according to the case.

original: Tattha paccayanayo sāmaññato, visesato cāti duvidho hoti. Tattha tabbhāvabhāvimattatāpakāsako🔽sāmaññato paccayanayo. Visesato pana paṭṭhāne āgatesu hetupaccayādicatuvīsatiyā paccayesu🔽yathānurūpaṃ paccayavisesuppannamattatāpakāsako. Sā ca nesaṃ catuvīsatiyā paccayānaṃ
analyzed: tattha paccaya nayo sāmaññataḥ visesataḥ ca ati duvidhaḥ hoti tattha  sāmaññato paccaya nayaḥ visesato pana paṭṭhāne āgatesu hetu paccaya ādi catuvīsatiyā paccayesu  yathānurūpam paccaya visesa uppanna matta tā pakāsako sā ca na īsam catuvīsatiyā paccayānam
translated: Herein, the condition method is twofold as to general and as to particular. Herein, the condition method as to general is that which reveals mere presence and absence in the case of the conditions.🔽But that as to particular is that which reveals the mere presence of a particular condition in the case of the twenty-two conditions beginning with root-cause condition that are stated in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽And the particularization of these twenty-two conditions will become known from the exegesis of the Paṭṭhāna in the Abhidhamma Pitaka.

original: vibhāgatā paṭṭhānamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanāya āvi bhavissati. Tattha sāmaññato saṅkhārādayo
analyzed: vibhāga tā paṭṭhānam ātika ttha saṃvaṇṇanāya āvi bhavissati tattha sāmaññato saṅkhāra ādayo
translated: Herein, the general condition method should be understood as follows. Formations, etc.,

original: avijjādipaccayabhāve eva bhāvinoti veditabbā. Yassa hi catūsu saccesu, pubbantādīsu
analyzed: avijjā ādi paccaya bhāve eva bhāvinaḥ ti veditabbā yassa hi catūsu saccesu pubbanta ādīsu
translated: are present only when ignorance, etc., are present. For when ignorance, etc., are not abandoned in the four truths and in the past, future, and present,

original: ca avijjā appahīnā hoti, so dukkhe tāva pubbantādīsu ca aññāṇena tīsu bhavesu jātijarārogamaraṇādianekādīnavavokiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: ca avijjā appahīnā hoti so dukkhe tāva pubbanta ādīsu ca aññāṇena tīsu bhavesu jāti jarā roga maraṇa ādi aneka ādīnava vokiṇṇam
translated: then, owing to the unknowing of the three periods of time in regard to suffering, etc., the round of rebirths, which is beset with manifold calamities such as birth, ageing, disease, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair,

original: puññaphalasaṅkhātaṃ saṅkhāravipariṇāmadukkhaṃ dukkhato ajānanto sukhasaññāya patthetvā🔽tīhi dvārehi puññāneñjābhisaṅkhāre ārabhati. Samudaye aññāṇena dukkhahetubhūtesupi🔽taṇhāparikkhāresu dukkhahetukaṃ āpāyikādidukkhaṃ, dukkhahetubhūtesu kāmūpasevanādīsu
analyzed: puñña phala saṅkhātam saṅkhāra vipariṇāma dukkham dukkhataḥ a jānantaḥ sukha saññāya patthetvā  tīhi dvārehi puñña aneñja abhisaṅkhāre ārabhati samudaye aññāṇena dukkha hetu bhūtesu pi  taṇhā parikkhāresu dukkha hetukam āpāyika ādi dukkham dukkha hetu bhūtesu kāma upasevana ādīsu
translated: Not knowing the suffering due to change in formations called the fruit of merit as suffering, he seeks it, conceiving it as pleasure.🔽Through the three doors he instigates formations of merit and of the imperturbable. Through ignorance of origination he does not see as suffering the suffering due to formations that is rooted in craving and is included in the suffering of the mental body and the suffering of consciousness.

original: ca ādīnavaṃ apassanto sukhahetusaññāya ceva kilesābhibhūtatāya ca tividhepi saṅkhāre🔽ārabhati. Nirodhe, pana magge ca aññāṇena anirodhabhūte gativisese nirodhasaññī,
analyzed: ca ādīnavam a passanto sukha hetu saññāya ca iva kilesa abhibhūta tāya ca tividhe pi saṅkhāre  ārabhati nirodhe pana magge ca aññāṇena anirodha bhūte gati visese nirodha saññī
translated: And he does not see the danger in the craving for sense desires, etc., which are the cause of that suffering. He instigates the three kinds of formations through conceiving them as the cause of pleasure and through being overwhelmed by defilements.🔽Through ignorance of cessation he conceives cessation as pleasure in the various kinds of becoming that are not cessation.

original: nirodhassa ca vā amaggabhūtesupi yaññāmaratapādīsupi nirodhamaggasaññī hutvā tividhepi
analyzed: nirodhassa ca vā amagga bhūtesu pi nirodha magga saññī hutvā tividhe pi
translated: Or he conceives cessation as pleasure in sacrifices, the worship of deities, etc., which are not the path to cessation. He instigates the three kinds of formations.

original: saṅkhāre ārabhati. Idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇena “ahetū appaccayā🔽sattā uppajjanti, na honti paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā “attāva jānāti vā na jānāti vā, sova
analyzed: saṅkhāre ārabhati idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇena ahetū appaccayā 🔽sattāḥ uppajjanti na honti param vā attā ava jānāti vā na jānāti vā saḥ uva
translated: Through ignorance of the path he conceives as the path to cessation what is not the path to cessation, namely, the observance of the fire ceremony, the observance of the new and full moon days, the observance of the vow of silence, the observance of the vow of dumbness, the observance of the vow of the tortoise, the observance of the vow of the ox, the observance of the vow of the dog, the observance of the vow of the deer, the observance of the vow of the elephant, the observance of the vow of the ram, the observance of the vow of the partridge, the observance of the vow of the peacock, the observance of the vow of the cuckoo, the observance of the vow of the owl, the observance of the vow of the stork, the observance of the vow of the crow, the observance of the vow of the hawk, the observance of the vow of the vulture, the observance of the vow of the kite, the observance of the vow of the bee, the observance of the vow of the ant, the observance of the vow of the fish, the observance of the vow of the tortoise, the observance of the vow of the water, the observance of the vow of the earth, the observance of the vow of the air, the observance of the vow of the tree, the observance of the vow of the cross-roads, the observance of the vow of the river, the observance of the vow of the ocean, the observance of the vow of the cow, the observance of the vow of the brahmin, the observance of the vow of the ascetic,

original: saṅkhāre saṅkharoti, sova paṭisandhiyaṃ uppajjati, tassa aṇuissarādayo kalalādibhāvena
analyzed: saṅkhāre saṅkharoti saḥ uva paṭisandhiyam uppajjati tassa kalala ādi bhāvena
translated: He generates determinations, and he reappears in rebirth-linking. Then his in-drives, out-drives, etc.,

original: sarīraṃ saṇṭhāpentā indriyāni sampādenti, sova indriyasampanno phusati, vedayati,
analyzed: sarīram saṇṭhāpentaḥ indriyāni sampādenti saḥ u vai indriya sampannaḥ phusati vedayati
translated: arranging the body in the form of an embryo, etc., develop the faculties. He, having faculties, contacts, feels,

original: taṇhiyati, upādānādīni ca karotī”ti vā “sabbe sattā niyatisaṅgatibhavapariṇatā”ti
analyzed: upādāna ādīni ca karoti iti vā sabbe sattā niyati saṅgati bhava pariṇatā ati
translated: craves, clings, and generates the rest. Or else he misconstrues thus: “All beings are subject to destiny, chance, fate, natural law” .

original: vā vikappeti. So evaṃ avijjāya andhīkato –
analyzed: vā vikappeti saḥ evam avijjāya andhīkataḥ
translated: Thus blinded by ignorance,

original: “Yathāpi nāma jaccandho, naro apariṇāyako;
analyzed: yathā api nāma naraḥ apariṇāyakaḥ
translated: “As a man blind from birth, Who cannot see the path,

original: Ekadā yāti maggena, ummaggenāpi ekadā.
analyzed: ekadā yāti maggena ummaggena api ekadā
translated: Sometimes goes by a path, And sometimes by a wrong path,

original: “Saṃsāre saṃsaraṃ bālo, tathā apariṇāyako;
analyzed: saṃsāre saṃsaram bālaḥ tathā apariṇāyakaḥ
translated: So the fool, wandering on, Cannot see the path;

original: Karoti ekadā puññaṃ, apuññamapi ekadā”ti. –
analyzed: karoti ekadā puññam apuññam api ekadā iti
translated: Sometimes he makes merit, And sometimes demerit” .

original: Vuttanayena tividhe saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharotīti. Kiṃ panettha ekāva avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena tividhe saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharoti iti kim pana ittha ekā ava avijjā
translated: He generates the three kinds of determinations in the way already described. But here, is ignorance the condition for the determinations only in one way,

original: paccayo hoti, nanu ekasmā kāraṇā ekaṃva kāriyaṃ uppajjati, anekaṃ kāriyaṃ na uppajjati,
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti nanu ekasmā kāraṇā ekam va kāriyam uppajjati anekam kāriyam na uppajjati
translated: or is it so in several ways? For it is said: “Only one effect arises from one cause, not several effects” ,🔽and “The condition being one, how could there be several effects?”

original: anekasmā vā ekanti, anekasmā kāraṇā anekaṃ kāriyaṃ uppajjatīti? Saccaṃ, padhānattapākaṭattaasādhāraṇattadīpanatthaṃ🔽panettha anekesu kāraṇesupi ekā avijjā eva paccayabhāvena niddiṭṭhā “phassapaccayā
analyzed: anekasmai vā ekanti anekasmā kāraṇā anekam kāriyam uppajjati iti saccam padhāna tta pākaṭa tta asādhāraṇa tta dīpana ttham  pana ittha anekesu kāraṇesu pi ekā avijjā eva paccaya bhāvena niddiṭṭhā phassa paccayā
translated: The answer is: from many causes many effects arise. But in order to show the pre-eminent, obvious, and specific cause,

original: vedanā, semhasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā”tiādīsu viya. Avijjā hi padhāno hetu, saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: vedanā semha samuṭṭhānā ābādha ati ādīsu viya avijjā hi padhānaḥ hetu saṅkhārānaṃ
translated: only ignorance is stated as a condition for formations, just as “with feeling as condition there is craving,” “with bile as condition there is fever,” etc.🔽For ignorance is the pre-eminent cause of formations, it is obvious, and it is specific. It is a cause of formations, not of consciousness, etc.,

original: pākaṭo, asādhāraṇo ca taṇhādihetūnampi hetuttā, na vatthārammaṇādīni khīṇāsavassa🔽tesaṃ sambhavepi saṅkhārānaṃ abhāvāti. Evaṃ tāvettha vaṭṭasaṅkhārānaṃ avijjāya eva🔽bhāve bhāvo veditabbo. Tathā viññāṇassāpi upacitakammābhāve abhāvato, sabbattha sabbesañca
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ asādhāraṇaḥ ca taṇhā ādi hetūnam pi hetuttā na vattha ārammaṇa ādīni khīṇa āsavassa  tesam evam tāva ettha vaṭṭa saṅkhārāṇam avijjāya eva  bhāve bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ tathā viññāṇassa api upacita kamma abhāve abhāvato sabbattha sabbesam ca
translated: because even though the latter also have ignorance as their condition, they are not said to have ignorance as their condition in the way that formations are, because formations are absent in one free from the taints,🔽while consciousness, etc., are not absent. Thus the presence and absence of formations should be understood to occur with the presence and absence of ignorance in the case of the round of formations.

original: sabbavipākaviññāṇuppattippasaṅgato ca saṅkhārānaṃ eva bhāve bhāvo veditabbo. Yathā
analyzed: sabba vipāka viññāṇa uppatti ppasaṅgataḥ ca saṅkhārānam eva bhāve bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ yathā
translated: And the presence and absence of formations should be understood to occur with the presence and absence of kamma-formations in the case of consciousness, because consciousness does not occur when kamma-formations are absent, and because all consciousnesses of all kinds would arise everywhere if kamma-formations were the only cause of consciousness.

original: cettha, evaṃ uparipi nāmarūpādīnaṃ viññāṇādibhāve bhāvo yathānurūpaṃ anubhavayuttīhi
analyzed: ca ittha evam upari pi nāma rūpa ādīnam viññāṇa ādi bhāve bhāvaḥ yathā anurūpam anubhava yuttīhi
translated: Herein, the presence of mentality-materiality, etc., in consciousness, etc., should be understood according to the method stated in the case of the presence of consciousness, etc., in ignorance, etc., in each instance as appropriate.

original: ñātabboti ayaṃ sāmaññato paccayanayo.🔽Visesato pana avijjā puññābhisaṅkhārānaṃ tāva ārammaṇapaccayena, upanissayapaccayena
analyzed: ñātabbaḥ ti ayam sāmaññataḥ paccaya nayaḥ  visesato pana avijjā puñña abhisaṅkhārānam tāva ārammaṇa paccayena upanissaya paccayena
translated: This is the general method of conditionality.🔽But ignorance is a condition in two ways, as object condition and decisive-support condition, for the formations that are kamma-result.

original: cāti dvidhā paccayo hoti. Sā hi avijjaṃ ārabbha sammasanādivasena uppattiyaṃ kāmāvacarānaṃ,
analyzed: ca ati dvidhā paccayaḥ hoti sā hi avijjam ārabbha sammasana ādi vasena uppattiyam
translated: For it is a condition, as object condition, for the sense-desire-world formations that arise with the modes of receiving, etc., taking ignorance as object;

original: abhiññācittena samohacittassa jānanakāle rūpāvacarānañca puññābhisaṅkhārānaṃ tāva🔽ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo hoti, avijjāsamatikkamanatthāya pana avijjāsammūḷhatāya🔽kāmarūpabhavasampattiyo patthetvāva kāmarūpāvacarapuññāni karontassa upanissayapaccayena
analyzed: abhiññā cittena sa moha cittassa jānana kāle rūpāvacarānam ca puñña abhisaṅkhārānam tāva  ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ hoti avijjā samatikkamana atthāya pana avijjā sammūḷha tāya  kāmarūpa bhava sampattiyo kāmarūpāvacara puññāni karontassa upanissaya paccayena
translated: and it is a condition, as object condition, for the fine-material-world formations that arise with the mode of receiving taking the consciousness associated with the direct-knowledge mind-object as object.🔽But it is a condition, as decisive-support condition, for the sense-desire-world and fine-material-world formations that arise in one who, being deluded by ignorance and not understanding the surmounting of ignorance,🔽seeks sense desires and the fine-material and immaterial existence that are the means to surmounting ignorance and performs kamma that will result in these.

original: paccayo hoti. Apuññābhisaṅkhārānaṃ panesā avijjaṃ ārabbha rāgādīnaṃ uppajjanakāle
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti apuñña abhisaṅkhārānam pana esā avijjam ārabbha rāga ādīnam uppajjana kāle
translated: But it is a condition, as object condition, for the unprofitable formations that arise with the arising of greed, etc., taking ignorance as object.

original: ārammaṇādipaccayena avijjāsammūḷhatāya pāṇātipātādīni karontassa nissayapaccayena,
analyzed: ārammaṇa ādi paccayena avijjā sammūḷha tāya pāṇa atipāta ādīni karontassa nissaya paccayena
translated: For one who does so deluded by ignorance through the condition of object, etc., it is a condition by way of support condition.

original: dutiyajavanādīnaṃ anantarūpanissayāsevananatthivigatapaccayehi yaṃ kiñci akusalaṃ
analyzed: dutiya javana ādīnam ananta rūpa nissaya āsevana natthi vigata paccayehi yam kiñci akusalam
translated: For one who does so by way of any unwholesome action through the condition of proximity, prenascence, decisive support, repetition, absence, and disappearance of the second impulsion, etc.,

original: karontassa hetusahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttaatthiavigatapaccayehīti evaṃ anekadhā
analyzed: karontassa hetu sahajāta aññamañña nissaya sampayutta atthi avigata paccayehi iti evam anekadhā
translated: it is a condition in many ways through the conditions of root, conascence, mutuality, support, association, presence, and non-disappearance.

original: paccayo hoti, āneñjābhisaṅkhārānaṃ pana ekena upanissayapaccayeneva paccayo hoti.🔽Saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇapade pana tayopi saṅkhārā viññāṇassa yathārahaṃ tīsu bhavesu
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti āneñja abhisaṅkhārānam pana ekena upanissaya paccayena iva paccayaḥ hoti  saṅkhāra paccayāḥ viññāṇa pade pana tayo api saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇassa yathāraham tīsu bhavesu
translated: But for the formations of the imperturbable it is a condition only by way of decisive support condition.

original: paṭisandhipavattīsu kammapaccayena ceva upanissayapaccayena cāti dvidhā paccayā honti.
analyzed: paṭisandhi pavattīsu kamma paccayena ca iva upanissaya paccayena ca ati dvidhā paccayāḥ honti
translated: As for the clause “With formations as condition, consciousness”: in the three kinds of becoming, in rebirth-linking and in the course of an existence, the three kinds of formations are a condition in two ways, namely, as kamma condition and as decisive support condition, for the kinds of consciousness appropriate to them.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyanayena sahajātassa viññāṇassa sahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttakammatthiavigatādipaccayehi paccayā honti.
analyzed: abhidhamma bhājanīya nayena sahajātassa viññāṇassa sahajāta aññamañña nissaya sampayutta kamma atthi avigata ādi paccayehi paccayāḥ honti
translated: By the method of the Abhidhamma, they are a condition for the conascent consciousness through the conditions of conascence, mutuality, support, association, presence, and non-disappearance.

original: Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpapade pana viññāṇaṃ vipākabhūtaṃ, avipākabhūtañca nāmassa kevalassa🔽vā rūpamissakassa vā paṭisandhipavattīsu sahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttavipākaāhāraindriyaatthiavigatapaccayehi
analyzed: viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpa pade pana viññāṇam vipāka bhūtam avipāka bhūtam ca nāmassa kevalassa  vā rūpa missakassa vā paṭisandhi pavattīsu sahajāta aññamañña nissaya sampayutta vipāka āhāra aindriya atthi avigata paccayehi
translated: As regards the clause “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality,” consciousness is both kamma- originated and resultant.

original: yathārahaṃ navadhā, aṭṭhadhā vā paccayo hoti. Paṭisandhiyaṃ vipākaviññāṇaṃ vatthurūpassa
analyzed: yathāraham navadhā aṭṭhadhā vā paccayaḥ hoti paṭisandhiyam vipāka viññāṇam vatthu rūpassa
translated: In rebirth-linking and in the course of an existence it is a condition, as appropriate, in nine or eight ways, by conascence, mutuality, support, association, kamma-result, nutriment, faculty, presence, non-disappearance conditions, for the mere mentality that is without materiality or for that which is accompanied by materiality.

original: sahajātaaññamaññanissayavipākaāhāraindriyavippayuttaatthi avigatapaccayehi navadhā🔽paccayo hoti. Ṭhapetvā pana vatthurūpaṃ sesarūpassa teheva aññamaññapaccayarahitehi
analyzed: sahajāta aññamañña nissaya vipāka āhāra aindriya vippayutta atthi avigata paccayehi navadhā  paccayaḥ hoti ṭhapetvā pana vatthu rūpam sesa rūpassa tehi iva aññamañña paccaya rahitehi
translated: In rebirth-linking, kamma-born consciousness is a condition, in nine ways, by conascence, mutuality, support, kamma-result, nutriment, faculty, dissociation, presence, non-disappearance conditions, for the materiality of the physical heart- basis.🔽But, leaving aside the materiality of the physical heart-basis, it is a condition, in eight ways, by those same conditions except the condition being condition by mutuality, for the rest of materiality.

original: aṭṭhahi paccayo hoti. Abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṃ pana ekavokārapañcavokārabhavesu kammajarūpassa
analyzed: aṭṭhahi paccayaḥ hoti abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam pana ekavokāra pañcavokāra bhavesu kamma ja rūpassa
translated: And the consciousness that is a formation is a condition, as proximity condition, etc., for kamma-born materiality in an existence consisting of one or five aggregates.

original: suttantikapariyāyena upanissayavasena paccayo hoti. Pavattiyaṃ pana sabbampi viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: suttantika pariyāyena upanissaya vasena paccayaḥ hoti pavattiyam pana sabbam pi viññāṇam
translated: But in the course of an existence all consciousness is a condition, as proximity, etc., for the associated aggregates and for the kinds of materiality originated by consciousness.

original: tassa tassa nāmarūpassa yathārahaṃ paccayo hoti. Tattha arūpabhave viññāṇaṃ nāmasseva,
analyzed: tassa tassa nāma rūpassa yathāraham paccayaḥ hoti tattha arūpa bhave viññāṇam nāmassa eva
translated: It is a condition in the various ways for the corresponding mentality-materiality. Herein, in the immaterial becoming it is a condition for mentality only,

original: asaññibhave rūpasseva, pañcavokārabhave nāmarūpassa paccayo hotīti veditabbaṃ. Teneva🔽nāmañca rūpañca nāmarūpañca nāmarūpanti nibbacanaṃ katanti.🔽Nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanapade pana nāmaṃ vipākabhūtaṃ, avipākabhūtañca arūpabhave🔽chaṭṭhāyatanassa avakaṃsato sahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttavipākaatthiavigatavasena
