translated: But as to meaning, in the passages beginning “unarisen unprofitable” , the non-arising of defilements should be understood as non-occurrence or as non-experience of an object, otherwise unprofitable states would never not arise in the beginningless round of rebirths.

original: nāma natthi. Kusaladhammesu pana ratanattayappasādavipassanādivivaṭṭūpanissayakusalādivasena
analyzed: nāma natthi kusala dhammesu pana
translated: But in profitable things there is, in the sense of the three jewels, confidence, insight, etc., and the profitable, etc., that are their proximate causes,

original: anuppannāpi atthi. Tesampi uppannapubbatte sati sabbasattānaṃ ito pubbe ca āsavakkhayappasaṅgato.
analyzed: anuppannā api atthi tesam pi uppanna pubbatte sati sabba sattānam itas pubbe ca āsava kkhaya ppasaṅgato
translated: even though they have not arisen. And when they have arisen before, then all beings are bound to have had defilements exhausted,🔽because they have been constantly occupied with the profitable, etc., that are the means to that end.

original: Ekantappavattasādhakā tesaṃ. Tattha ekaccassa vattaganthadhutaṅgasamādhivipassanānavakammesu
analyzed: ekanta ppavatta sādhakā tesam tattha ekaccassa vatta gantha dhutaṅga samādhi vipassanā nava kammesu
translated: Herein, for one who is constantly occupied with any one of the following: the duties, the duties of purity, the jhānas, insight, and the right endeavors,

original: aññatarasmiṃ niccappayuttassa, ghaṭato, vāyamato ca brahmalokā āgatattā bhavavasena🔽kilesesu aladdhāsevanassa sattassa kilesā na samudācaranti, aparabhāge panassa vattādīni🔽vissajjetvā kusītassa carato ceva akalyāṇamittādito kilesesu laddhāsevanassa ca ayonisomanasikāraṃ,
analyzed: aññatarasmim nicca ppayuttassa ghaṭataḥ vā āyamataḥ ca brahma lokāḥ āgata ttāḥ bhava vasena  kilesesu aladdha āsevanassa sattassa kilesāḥ na samudācaranti apara bhāge panassa vatta ādīni  vissajjetvā kusītassa carataḥ ca iva akalyāṇa mitta āditaḥ kilesesu laddha āsevanassa ca a yoniso manasikāram
translated: because he has come from the Brahmā-world, where he was occupied with the profitable, and because he has not yet acquired the habit of defilements in this existence,🔽his defilements do not occur. But later, when he has given up the duties, etc., and is living indolently,🔽and when he has acquired the habit of defilements through bad friends, etc., and through wrong reflection,

original: sativossaggañca āgamma uppajjanti. Evaṃ tāva asamudācāravasena kilesānaṃ anuppatti veditabbā.
analyzed: sati vossaggam ca āgamma uppajjanti evam tāva asamudācāra vasena kilesānam anuppatti veditabbā
translated: and when he has failed to obtain the support of mindfulness, then his defilements arise. This, in the first place, is how the non-occurrence of defilements should be understood as due to non-arising.

original: Ekaccassa pana tasmiṃ attabhāve ananubhūtapubbaṃ dibbādibhedaṃ manāpiyaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: ekaccassa pana tasmin atta bhāve an anubhūta pubbam dibba ādi bhedam manāpiyam ārammaṇam
translated: But in some beings defilements arise through the occurrence of wrong reflection on a desirable object of the kind beginning “divine” that has not been experienced in that existence,

original: labhitvā tattha ayonisomanasikārasativossagge āgamma kilesā uppajjanti, alabhitvā
analyzed: labhitvā tattha ayoniso manasikāra sati vossagge āgamma kilesāḥ uppajjanti a labhitvā
translated: and in some they do not arise even when such an object is obtained.

original: evaṃ ananubhūtārammaṇavasena kilesānaṃ anuppatti veditabbā.
analyzed: evam ananubhūta ārammaṇa vasena kilesānam anuppatti veditabbā
translated: This is how it should be understood that defilements arise through an object that has not been experienced.

original: “Uppannānaṃ pāpakāna”nti ettha pana catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ vattamānabhūtāpagataokāsakatabhūmiladdhavasena,
analyzed: uppannānam pāpakānam ti ettha pana catubbidham uppannam vattamāna bhūta apagata okāsa kata bhūmi laddha vasena
translated: As regards the words “ arisen evil states” , there are four kinds of arising: as occurrence, as generation, as opportunity, and as acquisition.🔽The exposition of these should be understood according to the method given under the four kinds of arising in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: tesaṃ vibhāgo uppannattike vuttova. Aparampi catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ samudācāraārammaṇādhiggahitaavikkhambhitaasamugghātitavasena.
analyzed: tesam vibhāgaḥ uppanna ttike vuttaḥ iva aparam pi catubbidham uppannam samudācāra ārammaṇa adhiggahita a vikkhambhita a samugghātita vasena
translated: There are also four kinds of arising as manifestation, as object, as apprehension, and as non-suppression.

original: Tattha sampati vattamānaṃyeva samudācāruppannaṃ nāma. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva. Yasmā panettha
analyzed: tattha sampati vattamānam yeva samudācāruppannam nāma sesam pākaṭam eva yasmā pana ittha
translated: Herein, what arises as manifestation is simply what is occurring at the moment. The rest is evident.

original: imesu uppannesu vattamānabhūtāpagataokāsakatasamudācārasaṅkhātaṃ catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ
analyzed: imesu uppannesu vattamāna bhūta apagata okāsa kata samudācāra saṅkhātam catubbidham uppannam
translated: But although in this context these four kinds of arising, namely, as occurrence, as generation, as opportunity, and as manifestation, are included in the four kinds of arising,

original: na maggādivajjhaṃ, tasmā bhūmiladdhaārammaṇādhiggahitaasamugghātitasaṅkhātaṃ catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: na magga ādi vajjham bhūmi laddha ārammaṇa adhiggahita a samugghātita saṅkhātam catubbidham
translated: not as path, etc., and therefore it is of four kinds as “consisting in what is obtained by the plane,” “as object,” “as apprehension,” and “as abandoning.”🔽

original: uppannaṃ sandhāyettha “uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ pahānāyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: uppannam sandhāya ittha uppannānam pāpakānam pahānāya iti vuttam
translated: and not for the path, etc., therefore the four kinds of profitable cognizance that have arisen are referred to here by the words “for the abandoning of arisen evil unprofitable ideas” .🔽But how is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas at the moment of the path, and how is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?

original: Kathaṃ pana maggakkhaṇe anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ uppādāya vāyāmo hoti, kathañca uppannānaṃ
analyzed: katham pana magga kkhaṇe anuppannānam kusalānam uppādāya vāyāmaḥ hoti katham ca uppannānam
translated: How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?

original: ṭhitiyāti? Maggappavattiyā eva. Maggo hi pavattamāno pubbe anuppannapubbattā anuppanno
analyzed: ṭhitiyā ti magga ppavattiyā eva maggaḥ hi pavattamānaḥ pubbe anuppanna pubbattā anuppannaḥ
translated: How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?

original: nāma vuccati. Yā cassa pavatti, ayameva ṭhiti nāmāti ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.🔽Dhammabhedo panetthāpi ekasseva vīriyassa kiccabhedato catudhā vuttāti ayamettha pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: nāma vuccati yā ca assa pavatti ayam eva ṭhiti nāma ati ayam tāva ettha padattho  dhamma bhedaḥ pana itthā api ekassa iva vīriyassa kicca bhedato catudhā vuttā ati ayam ettha pāḷimutta vinicchayo
translated: How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?

original: Vibhaṅganayato pana suttantabhājanīye tāva cattāro sammappadhānā lokiyalokuttarakusalacittasampayuttavīriyavasena
analyzed: vibhaṅga nayataḥ pana suttanta bhājanīye tāva cattāro sammappadhānāḥ lokiya lokuttara kusala citta sampayutta vīriya vasena
translated: How is there endeavour for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the abandoning of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the arising of unarisen profitable ideas?🔽How is there endeavour for the maintenance of those that have arisen?🔽How is there endeavour for the non-arising of

original: akusalādipadehi saddhiṃ vitthārato vibhattā. Abhidhammabhājanīyapañhāpucchakesu panete
analyzed: akusala ādi padehi saddhim vitthārataḥ vibhattā abhidhamma bhājanīya pañhāpucchakesu pana ite
translated: and they are analyzed in detail with the unprofitable, etc., in the Vibhanga.

original: lokuttarakusalacittasampayuttavaseneva vibhattā, phalacittasampayuttā pana na gahitā.
analyzed: lokuttara kusala citta sampayutta vasena iva vibhattā phala citta sampayuttā pana na gahitā
translated: But in the Questions of Milinda they are analyzed only as associated with supramundane profitable consciousness, and those associated with fruition consciousness are not included.

original: Teneva pañhāpucchake “kusalā eva, vipākadhammadhammā eva, apacayagāminova, sekhāvā”tiādinā
analyzed: tena iva pañhāpucchake kusalāḥ eva vipāka dhamma dhammāḥ eva apacaya gāminaḥ uva sekhā vāti ādinā
translated: That is why in the Questions of Milinda it is said, “They are profitable only, they are states that are results of profitable only, they are states that are a basis for what is partaking of penetration only, they are states that are kept in being only by those still learning” ,

original: vuttā. Seso panettha vinicchayo satipaṭṭhāne vuttanayānusārena veditabbo.
analyzed: vuttā sesaḥ pana ittha vinicchayaḥ sati paṭṭhāne vutta naya anusārena veditabbo
translated: and so on. The rest of the exposition should be understood according to the method stated in the Satipaṭṭhāna.

original: Sammappadhānavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sammappadhāna vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Description of the Requisites of Enlightenment” is ended.

original: Iddhipādavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā🔽Iddhipādavibhaṅgamātikāya pana cattāro iddhipādāti ettha ijjhatīti iddhi, samijjhati🔽nipphajjatīti attho, iddhi eva pādo iddhipādo, iddhikoṭṭhāsoti attho. Ijjhanti vā
analyzed: iddhipāda vibhaṅga mātikāya pana cattāro iddhipādā ti ettha ijjhati iti iddhi samijjhati  nipphajjati iti attho iddhi eva pādaḥ iddhipādaḥ iddhi koṭṭhāsaḥ ti attho ijjhanti vā
translated: The “Description of the Bases for Spiritual Power”

original: etāya sattā iddhā vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā hontītipi iddhi, pajjanti etenāti pādo, patiṭṭhā
analyzed: etāya sattāḥ iddhāḥ vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti pi iddhi pajjanti etena ati pādaḥ patiṭṭhā
translated: As to the “Description of the Bases for Spiritual Power” , there are four bases for spiritual power: here it is success that is spiritual power, the meaning is, it is what comes about, it is what comes to be. Spiritual power itself is a base, thus it is a base for spiritual power; the meaning is, it is a footing for spiritual power. Or alternatively, beings succeed by means of this, thus it is spiritual power; it is a base, thus it is a base for spiritual power; it is a footing.

original: adhigamūpāyoti attho, iddhiyā pādo iddhipādo. Chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgatanti
analyzed: adhigama upāyo ti attho iddhiyā pādaḥ iddhi pādo chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatanti
translated: The meaning is that it is a footing for success.🔽Concentration due to zeal: concentration is concentration of cognizance; it is of that that there is concentration, thus it is concentration; or alternatively, it is concentration in the sense of concentrating, in the sense of bringing together, thus it is concentration;🔽or alternatively, it is concentration in the sense of con-centration, in the sense of collecting, thus it is concentration.

original: ettha chandahetuko, chandādhiko vā samādhi chandasamādhi, kattukamyatāchandaṃ adhipatiṃ🔽karitvā paṭiladdhasamādhissetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā padhānasaṅkhārā,
analyzed: ettha chanda hetukaḥ chanda adhikaḥ vā samādhi chanda samādhi adhipatim  karitvā adhivacanam padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā padhāna saṅkhārā
translated: It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.

original: catukiccasādhakassa sammappadhānavīriyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Samannāgatanti tena chandasamādhinā,
analyzed: catu kicca sādhakassa sammappadhāna vīriyassa etam adhivacanam samannāgatanti tena chanda samādhinā
translated: It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,

original: padhānasaṅkhārena ca upetaṃ. Iddhipādanti yathāvuttatthena “iddhī”ti saṅkhyaṃ gatānaṃ
analyzed: padhāna saṅkhārena ca upetam iddhi pādanti yathāvuttatthena iddhi iti saṅkhyam
translated: which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,

original: upacārajjhānādikusalacittasampayuttānaṃ chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: upacāra jhāna ādi kusala citta sampayuttānam chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhārānam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.

original: pādabhūtasesacittacetasikarāsiṃ. Bhāvetīti vaḍḍheti, attano santāne punappunaṃ janetīti
analyzed: bhāveti iti vaḍḍheti attano santāne punappunam janeti iti
translated: Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because it is rooted in zeal, or it is concentration that is due to zeal,🔽which is the expression for concentration obtained by making zeal to act the dominant condition.🔽Zeal to act is the desire to act.🔽It is concentration due to zeal because

original: attho. Iminā nayena sesesupi attho veditabbo. Tattha vīmaṃsāti paññā. Sesaṃ padato suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: atthaḥ iminā nayena sesesu pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha vīmaṃsā ati paññā sesam padataḥ su viññeyyam eva
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in the case of the rest too. Herein, investigation is understanding. The rest is self-evident in the text.

original: Atthato panettha tena kiṃ kathitaṃ? Catunnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ matthakappattaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: atthataḥ pana ittha tena kim kathitam catunnam bhikkhūnam matthaka ppattam kammaṭṭhānam
translated: But what is stated by this? The meditation subject that has reached the peak with four bhikkhus is stated.

original: kathitaṃ. Yathā hi catūsu amaccaputtesu ṭhānantaraṃ patthetvā vicarantesu eko upaṭṭhānena,
analyzed: kathitam yathā hi catūsu amacca puttesu ṭhāna antaram patthetvā vicarantesu ekaḥ upaṭṭhānena
translated: For just as when four princes, sons of a king, are seeking a position, one pleases the king with attendance,

original: eko sūrabhāvena, eko jātisampattiyā, eko mantabalenāti evaṃ te paccekakāraṇena rājānaṃ🔽ārādhetvā ṭhānantaraṃ pāpuṇanti, evaṃ bhikkhūpi chandavīriyacittavīmaṃsāsu ekekaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ sūra bhāvena ekaḥ jāti sampattiyā ekaḥ manta balena ati evam te pacceka kāraṇena rājānam  ārādhetvā pāpuṇanti evam bhikkhū api chanda vīriya citta vīmaṃsāsu ekekam
translated: one with a good scent, one with good birth, and one with the strength of his counsel, and so they obtain the position by their several individual reasons,

original: jeṭṭhaṃ dhuraṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā lokuttaradhammanibbattakā honti. Ettha ca chando🔽samādhi padhānasaṅkhāroti tayo dhammā iddhīpi honti iddhipādāpi, sesā pana sampayuttā
analyzed: jeṭṭham dhuram pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhamma nibbattakāḥ honti ettha ca chando  samādhi padhāna saṅkhāro ti tayo dhammā iddhī pi honti iddhipādā api sesā pana sampayuttā
translated: so too, with zeal, energy, cognizance, and investigation as their several individual reasons, these bhikkhus are the producers of the supramundane profit. And here zeal,🔽concentration, and equanimity are both success and bases of success, but the remaining associated aggregates are only bases of success.

original: cattāro khandhā iddhipādā eva. Evaṃ sesādhipatiyuttacittesupi iddhipādāti veditabbā.
analyzed: cattāro khandhāḥ iddhipādāḥ eva evam sesa adhipati yutta cittesu pi iddhipādā ti veditabbā
translated: So too in the case of the rest of the profitable consciousnesses associated with the bases of success.

original: Apica jhānavipassanāsu pubbabhāgo iddhipādo. Yo paṭilābho, sā iddhi. Paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ🔽hi pubbabhāgaparikammāni iddhipādo nāma, paṭhamajjhānādayo iddhi nāma. Paṭhamamaggādīnaṃ
analyzed: apica jhāna vipassanāsu pubba bhāgaḥ iddhipādaḥ yaḥ paṭilābhaḥ sā iddhi paṭhamajjhāna ādīnam  hi pubba bhāga parikammāni iddhipādaḥ nāma paṭhama jhāna ādayaḥ iddhi nāma paṭhama magga ādīnam
translated: Furthermore, the preliminary-work concentration is the road to power, and the obtainment is the success.🔽For the preliminary-work meditation is called the road to power, and the first jhana, etc., is called the success.

original: pubbabhāgavipassanā iddhipādo nāma, paṭhamamaggādayo iddhi nāma. Paṭilābhavasenāpi🔽dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati. Paṭhamajjhānādayo hi paṭhamamaggādayo ca iddhipādo nāma, dutiyajjhānādayo,
analyzed: dīpetum vaṭṭati paṭhama jhāna ādayaḥ hi paṭhama magga ādayaḥ ca iddhipādaḥ nāma dutiya jhāna ādayaḥ
translated: The insight preliminary to the first path, etc., is called the road to power, and the first path, etc., is called the success.🔽It is also allowable to illustrate it by the obtainment.

original: dutiyamaggādayo ca iddhi nāmāti ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.🔽Dhammabhedo panettha vibhaṅganayeneva pākaṭo bhavissati. Tattha hi suttantabhājanīye🔽tāva chandādīnaṃ padānaṃ vibhaṅgaṃ vatvā ante “iddhipādoti tathābhūtassa vedanākkhandho…pe…
analyzed: dutiya magga ādayaḥ ca id hi nāma ati ayam tāva ettha padattho  dhamma bhedaḥ pana ittha vibhaṅga nayena iva pākaṭaḥ bhavissati tattha hi suttanta bhājanīye  tāva chanda ādīnam padānam vibhaṅgam vatvā ante iddhipādo ti tathābhūtassa
translated: For the first jhana, etc., and the first path, etc., are called the road to power, and the second jhana, etc., and the second path, etc., are called the success. This, in the first place, is the word meaning.

original: viññāṇakkhandho. Iddhipādaṃ bhāvetīti te dhamme āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti, tena
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ iddhipādam bhāveti iti te dhamme āsevati bhāveti bahulīkaroti tena
translated: The analysis of the states will become evident in the way in which it is given in the Vibhanga. For after giving the analysis of the terms zeal, etc., there at the end, in the case of each, it is said: “The feeling aggregate … the perception aggregate … the volitional-activities aggregate … the consciousness aggregate that has arisen in such-and-such a way is the road to power. He develops the road to power: he frequents, he cultivates, he makes much of those states,

original: vuccati iddhipādaṃ bhāvetī”ti evaṃ sabbe lokiyalokuttaradhammā iddhipādoti vuttā.
analyzed: vuccati iddhipādam bhāveti iti evam sabbe lokiya lokuttara dhammā iddhipādaḥ ti vuttā
translated: “he is said to develop the road to power” .

original: Abhidhammabhājanīye pana chandādīni padāni vibhajitvā ante “iddhipādoti tathābhūtassa
analyzed: abhidhamma bhājanīye pana chanda ādīni padāni vibhajitvā ante iddhipādaḥ ti tathābhūtassa
translated: In the Abhidhamma Collection, however, the words “desire,” etc., are analysed, and at the end it is said: “The contact … the resolve … the attention … the knowledge … the deliverance that has arisen in one who is thus is the road to power” .

original: phasso…pe… paggāho avikkhepo”ti evaṃ sabbe lokuttarakusaladhammā iddhipādāti vatvā
analyzed: paggāhaḥ avikkhepaḥ ti evam sabbe lokuttara kusala dhammā iddhipādā ti vatvā
translated: So all the supramundane profitable states are called the road to power.

original: puna “chandiddhipādo vīriyiddhipādo cittiddhipādo vīmaṃsiddhipādo”ti mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: punar chandiddhipādaḥ vīriyiddhipādaḥ cittiddhipādaḥ vīmaṃsiddhipādaḥ iti mātikam ṭhapetvā
translated: Then, after setting up the mātikā thus, “Desire as the road to power, resolve as the road to power, endeavour as the road to power, concentration as the road to power, and understanding as the road to power” ,

original: “tattha katamo chandiddhipādo? Idha bhikkhu yasmiṃ samaye lokuttaraṃ jhānaṃ bhāveti…pe…
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ chanda iddhipādaḥ idha bhikkhu yasmin samaye lokuttaram jhānam
translated: it is said: “Here, what is desire as the road to power? On an occasion when he develops the supramundane jhāna …

original: yo tasmiṃ samaye chando chandikatā…pe… ayaṃ vuccati chandiddhipādo”tiādinā lokuttarakusalacittasampayuttachandavīriyacittavīmaṃsā
analyzed: tasmin samaye ayam vuccati chanda iddhipāda uti ādinā lokuttara kusala citta sampayutta chanda vīriya citta vīmaṃsā
translated: the desire, the state of wanting, the being eager, the eagerness, the keenness, the keen desire, the keen state of wanting, the being greatly eager, the being greatly wanting, the great eagerness, the great state of wanting, the desire, the wanting, the eagerness, the searching, the seeking, the great desire, the great eagerness, the great zeal, the great fervour, the great keenness, the great thrust of the mind, the great exertion of the mind, the great striving of the mind, the great exertion of will, the great effort of will, the great endeavour of will, the great onrush of will, the great urge of will, the great urge of the mind, the great urge of consciousness, the great urge of mental absorption, the great urge of concentration, the great urge of unification, the great urge of the road to power, the great urge of the road to power that has arisen in one who is thus is called desire as the road to power” .

original: eva iddhipādāti vuttā. Tathā pañhāpucchakepi kusalā eva, anidassanaappaṭighā eva,
analyzed: eva iddhipādā ati vuttā tathā pañhāpucchake pi kusalāḥ eva anidassana appaṭighāḥ eva
translated: So only desire, only energy, only consciousness, only investigation that are associated with supramundane profitable consciousness are called the road to power. So too, in the Questions of Milinda, only the profitable, only the non-percipient-non-non-percipient,

original: vīmaṃsiddhipādo hetu, sesā na hetū…pe… cittiddhipādo na vattabbo, sesā cittasampayuttā…pe…
analyzed: vīmaṃsiddhipādaḥ hetu sesāḥ na hetu upe cittiddhipādaḥ na vattabbo sesā citta sampayutta āpe
translated: The basis of success consisting in investigation is a cause, the rest are not causes. … The basis of success consisting in will is not to be spoken of, the rest are associated with cognizance. …

original: anuttarāva, araṇāvāti. Sesamettha satipaṭṭhāne vuttasadisameva. Pāḷimuttakanayo panetthāpi na uddhaṭoti.
analyzed: sesam ettha sati paṭṭhāne vutta sadisam eva pāḷi muttaka nayo pana itthā api na uddhaṭaḥ ti
translated: The rest here are like those dealt with in the Foundations of Mindfulness. But the Thread-order has not been extracted here.

original: Iddhipādavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iddhipāda vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Matrix of the Bases of Success is ended.

original: Bojjhaṅgavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bojjhaṅga vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā
translated: Matrix of the Factors of Enlightenment

original: Bojjhaṅgavibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – satta bojjhaṅgāti ettha bodhiyā, bodhissa
analyzed: bojjhaṅga vibhaṅga mātikāya pana atthato tāva satta bojjhaṅgā ti ettha bodhiyā bodhissa
translated: As to meaning, firstly as to “Seven factors of enlightenment”: here enlightenment is either the state of one who is enlightened or the state of enlightenment.

original: vā aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yāya eva dhammasāmaggiyā maggakkhaṇe uppajjamānāya🔽līnuddhaccādianekesaṃ upaddavānaṃ paṭipakkhabhūtāya satidhammavicayādisattavidhāya
analyzed: vā aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgā idam vuttam hoti yāya eva dhamma sāmaggiyāḥ magga kkhaṇe uppajjamānāya  upaddavānam paṭipakkha bhūtāya sati dhammavicaya ādi sattavidhāya
translated: A factor of that is a factor of enlightenment. This is what is said: by whatever combination of states there is enlightenment, i.e. the Noble Disciple arises from the sleep of defilement when it arises at the moment of the path,

original: dhammasāmaggiyā ariyasāvako bujjhati, kilesaniddāya uṭṭhahati, saccāni vā paṭivijjhati,
analyzed: dhamma sāmaggiyā ariya sāvakaḥ bujjhati kilesa niddāya uṭṭhahati saccāni vā paṭivijjhati
translated: or he penetrates the Truths, by that combination of states consisting of the seven enlightenment factors of mindfulness, investigation of (mental) states, etc., which is the opposite of the many kinds of hindrance such as depression, agitation, etc.,

original: tassā dhammasāmaggisaṅkhātāya bodhiyā aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā jhānaṅgamaggaṅgāni viya. Yo🔽panesa yathāvuttappakārāya etāya dhammasāmaggiyā bujjhatīti katvā ariyasāvako “bodhī”ti🔽vuccati, tassa bodhissa aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā senaṅgarathaṅgādayo viya. Apica “bodhāya
analyzed: tassā dhamma sāmaggi saṅkhātāya bodhiyā aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgāḥ jhāna aṅga maggaṅgāni viya yo  pana esa yathā vutta ppakārāya etāya dhamma sāmaggiyā bujjhati iti katvā ariya sāvakaḥ bodhi iti  vuccati tassa bodhissa aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgā senaṅga rathaṅga ādayaḥ api ca bodhāya
translated: They are factors of the enlightenment consisting in the unities of the ideas, like the factors of jhana and factors of the path.🔽But the noble disciple who is called “enlightenment” because he is enlightened by means of that unity of ideas of the kind stated is the enlightenment’s factor, thus they are enlightenment factors, like the factors of the chariot and factors of the army.

original: saṃvattantīti bojjhaṅgā”tiādinā paṭisambhidānayenāpi bojjhaṅgattho veditabbo. Pasattho,
analyzed: saṃvattanti iti bojjhaṅgā ti ādinā paṭisambhidā nayena api bojjhaṅga tthaḥ veditabbaḥ pasattho
translated: Besides, the meaning of enlightenment factor can be understood by the method of the Paṭisambhidā, according as it is said: “They lead on to enlightenment, thus they are enlightenment factors” , and so on.

original: sundaro vā bojjhaṅgo sambojjhaṅgo, satiyeva sambojjhaṅgo satisambojjhaṅgo. Evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: sundaraḥ vā bojjhaṅgaḥ sambojjhaṅgaḥ satiyā iva sambojjhaṅgaḥ sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ evam sesesu pi
translated: A good enlightenment factor is a good enlightenment factor, or a beautiful enlightenment factor is a good enlightenment factor. The enlightenment factor of mindfulness itself is the mindfulness enlightenment factor. So too with the rest.

original: Tattha dhamme vicināti aniccādito parivīmaṃsati jānāti, dhamme vā etena sattā vicinantīti
analyzed: tattha dhamme vicināti anicca āditas parivīmaṃsati jānāti dhamme vai etena sattāḥ vicinanti iti
translated: Herein, he investigates ideas, he examines them by way of impermanence, etc., he knows them, or beings investigate, examine, and know ideas by means of this, thus it is investigation of ideas ; it is understanding.

original: dhammavicayo, paññā. Upekkhati samarasānaṃ dhammānaṃ hāpanavaḍḍhane avāvaṭatāya paṭisaṅkhānākārena
analyzed: dhamma vicayaḥ paññāḥ upekkhati sama rasānam dhammānam hāpana vaḍḍhane a vāvaṭa tāya paṭisaṅkhāna ākārena
translated: He looks on with equanimity at ideas that are in a state of resolution of the compact , because he is uninterested in their diminution and increase by way of reviewing, thus it is equanimity.

original: majjhattā hotīti upekkhā, tatramajjhattatā. Paṭisaṅkhānalakkhaṇo hi upekkhāsambojjhaṅgoti.🔽Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ tāvettha padattho. Dhammabhedopettha suviññeyyova.
analyzed: majjhattā hoti iti upekkhā tatra majjhatta tā paṭisaṅkhāna lakkhaṇaḥ hi upekkhā sambojjhaṅgo ti  sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam tāva ettha padatthaḥ dhamma bheda upettha su viññeyyaḥ eva
translated: Equanimity is the middle, the state of neutrality. For equanimity as a factor of complete purification has the characteristic of non-attention .🔽The rest is easy to understand. This, firstly, is the word commentary.

original: Vibhaṅganayato panettha suttantabhājanīye tāva lokiyalokuttaravasena sesesu lokuttarakusalavipākavasena🔽vibhattā. Pañhāpucchake pana siyā kusalā, siyā abyākatā, pītisambojjhaṅgo sukhāya
analyzed: vibhaṅga nayataḥ pana ittha suttanta bhājanīye tāva lokiya lokuttara vasena sesesu lokuttara kusala vipāka vasena  vibhattā pañhāpucchake pana siyā kusalā siyā abyākatā pīti sambojjhaṅgaḥ sukhāya
translated: The exposition of the meaning of the text should be understood as follows. Herein, in the first place, in the Suttanta section it is divided according to the mundane and supramundane, and in the rest according to the profitable and resultant of the supramundane.

original: vedanāya sampayuttova, sesā dvīhi…pe… pītisambojjhaṅgo sukhasahagatova, sesā tidhāpi,
analyzed: vedanāya sampayuttaḥ uva sesā dvīhipe pīti sambojjhaṅgo sukha sahagataḥ uva sesā tidhā api
translated: But in the Questions section it may be either profitable or indeterminate. The enlightenment factor of rapture is associated only with pleasant feeling. The rest are threefold. … The enlightenment factor of rapture is accompanied by pleasure only. The rest are threefold.

original: anidassanaappaṭighā, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo hetu, sesā na hetū…pe… rūpāvacarāva,
analyzed: anidassana appaṭighā dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgaḥ hetu sesāḥ na rūpāvacarā
translated: They are non-illumining, non-reactive. The enlightenment factor of discrimination of the properties is a cause. The rest are not causes. … They belong to the fine-material sphere only.

original: araṇāvāti. Sesaṃ satipaṭṭhāne vuttanayameva. Ayamettha vibhaṅganayo.
analyzed: sesam sati paṭṭhāne vutta nayam eva ayam ettha vibhaṅga nayo
translated: They are without dispute. The rest are as stated in the Foundations of Mindfulness. This is the exposition of the meaning of the text.🔽Now,

original: Idāni pana –🔽Kamato tāvattato ca, hetubhūmivibhāgato;
analyzed: idāni pana  kamataḥ tāvat tatas ca hetu bhūmi vibhāgataḥ
translated: The method of exposition should be understood as follows:🔽By way of function, and by way of plane,🔽By way of cause, and by way of classification,

original: Vivekato ca viññeyyo, pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: vivekato ca viññeyyaḥ pāḷi mutta vinicchayo
translated: And by way of distinction, the exposition🔽Of the text should be understood as complete.

original: Tattha kamato tāva ayampi desanākkamova. Sabbesaṃ hi bojjhaṅgānaṃ upakārattā satisambojjhaṅgo
analyzed: tattha kamataḥ tāva ayam pi desanā kkamaḥ uva sabbesam hi bojjhaṅgānam upakāra attā sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ
translated: Herein, firstly, as to order: the factor of Perfect Wisdom is stated first because it assists all the other factors of Perfect Wisdom.

original: paṭhamaṃ vutto, tato yasmā upaṭṭhitasatiko dhamme paññāya pavicināti, pavicitadhammo🔽vīriyaṃ ārabhati, āraddhavīriyassa pīti uppajjati, pītimanassa kāyopi cittampi passambhati,
analyzed: paṭhamam vuttaḥ tatas yasmai upaṭṭhita satikaḥ dhamme paññāya pavicināti pavicita dhammo  vīriyam ārabhati āraddha vīriyassa pīti uppajjati pīti manassa kāyaḥ api cittam pi passambhati
translated: Then, when he has established mindfulness, he investigates the states with understanding. When he has investigated states,🔽he arouses energy. When he has aroused energy, happiness arises in one who has aroused energy. When he is happy, his body and mind are tranquil.

original: passaddhakāyassa sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati, samāhitacitto taṃ cittaṃ sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā
analyzed: passaddha kāyassa sukhino cittam samādhiyati samāhita cittaḥ tam cittam sādhukam ajjhupekkhitā
translated: When his body is tranquil, the contented one’s mind becomes concentrated. When his mind is concentrated, he looks on at the mind with proper insight.

original: hoti, tasmā dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādayo yathākkamaṃ vuttāti ayaṃ tāvettha kamo.
analyzed: hoti tasmā dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādayaḥ yathākkamam vuttā ati ayam tāva ettha kamaḥ
translated: So they are stated in this way according to their order of arising. This, firstly, is the order here.

original: Tāvattato pana kasmā te satteva vuttā, anūnā anadhikāti? Līnuddhaccapaṭipakkhato,🔽sabbattikato ca. Ettha hi tayo bojjhaṅgā līnassa paṭipakkhā. Yathāha – “yasmiṃ ca
analyzed: tāvat tatas pana kasmā te sattā iva vuttā anūnā anadhikā ati līn uddhacca paṭipakkhato  sabba ttikataḥ ca ettha hi tayaḥ bojjhaṅgāḥ līnassa paṭipakkhāḥ yathā āha yasmin ca
translated: But why are they stated in this number, neither more nor less? Because of the opposite of depression and agitation,

original: kho, bhikkhave, samaye līnaṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: kho bhikkhave samaye līnam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye dhamma vicaya sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: and because of totality. For three factors of Perfect Wisdom are the opposite of depression, according as it is said: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is depressed, the time has come for developing the enlightenment factor of investigation of mental objects, the enlightenment factor of energy, the enlightenment factor of rapture” .🔽“Bhikkhus, when the mind is agitated, the time has come for developing the enlightenment factor of tranquillity, the enlightenment factor of concentration, the enlightenment factor of equanimity” .

original: bhāvanāya, kālo vīriya…pe… pītisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāyā”ti. Tayo uddhaccassa paṭipakkhā.🔽Yathāha – “yasmiṃ ca kho, bhikkhave, samaye uddhataṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: bhāvanāya kālaḥ vīriya pe pīti sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya ati tayo uddhaccassa paṭipakkhā  yathā āha yasmin ca kho bhikkhave samaye uddhatam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye
translated: and the time for energy … and the time for the enlightenment factor of rapture” .

original: passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya, kālo samādhi…pe… upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāyā”ti.
analyzed: passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya kālaḥ samādhi pe upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is excited, that is the time for the development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor … the concentration enlightenment factor … the equanimity enlightenment factor” .

original: Eko panettha loṇadhūpanaṃ viya sabbabyañjanesu sabbabojjhaṅgesu icchitabbo. Yathāha
analyzed: ekaḥ pana ittha loṇa dhūpanam viya sabba byañjanesu sabba bojjhaṅgesu icchitabbaḥ yathā āha
translated: But one of them is to be desired in all the enlightenment factors like salt in all curries.

original: – “satiñca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbatthikaṃ vadāmī”ti. Evaṃ līnuddhaccapaṭipakkhato
analyzed: satim ca khvā aham bhikkhave sabbatthikam vadāmi iti evam līn uddhacca paṭipakkhato
translated: For it is said: “Bhikkhus, I say that mindfulness is to be developed all the time” .🔽So they are stated as seven since they are the opposites of the seven kinds of slackness and of the seven kinds of restlessness,

original: ca sabbatthikato ca satteva vuttāti ayaṃ tāvattato.
analyzed: ca sabbatthikato ca sattā iva vuttā iti ayam tāvat tatas
translated: and since they are all-purpose.

original: Hetubhūmivibhāgatoti ettha hetuvibhāgato tāva – cattāro satisambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya
analyzed: hetu bhūmi vibhāgato ti ettha hetu vibhāgato tāva cattāro sati sambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya
translated: As to the analysis of the grounds for their appearance: the four things that lead to the arising of the mindfulness enlightenment factor are

original: saṃvattanti satisampajaññaṃ muṭṭhassatipuggalaparivajjanatā upaṭṭhitassatipuggalasevanatā
analyzed: saṃvattanti sati sampajaññam muṭṭhaḥ sati puggala parivajjana tā upaṭṭhitaḥ sati puggala sevana tā
translated: mindfulness, awareness, avoidance of people who are difficult to admonish, and cultivation of people who are easy to admonish.

original: tadadhimuttatāti. Tathā satta dhammā dutiyassa paripucchakatā vatthuvisadakiriyā
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ati tathā satta dhammā dutiyassa paripucchaka tā vatthu visada kiriyā
translated: There are seven ideas for the second questioning:🔽making the basis clean,🔽making the faculties steady, avoiding the foolish,

original: indriyasamattapaṭipādanā duppaññapuggalaparivajjanā paññavantapuggalasevanā gambhīrañāṇacariyapaccavekkhaṇatā
analyzed: indriya samatta paṭipādanā duppañña puggala parivajjanā paññavanta puggala sevanā gambhīra ñāṇa cariya paccavekkhaṇa tā
translated: associating with the wise, reviewing the profound knowledge and seeing,🔽and the inclination to that.

original: tadadhimuttatāti. Tattha ajjhattikabāhirānaṃ sarīraparikkhārabhūtānaṃ vatthūnaṃ visadabhāvakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ti tattha ajjhattika bāhirānam sarīra parikkhāra bhūtānam vatthūnam visada bhāva karaṇam
translated: Herein, making the basis clean is the making clean of the internal and external bodily and requisite bases.🔽There are eleven ideas for the third questioning:

original: vatthuvisadakiriyā nāma. Tathā ekādasa dhammā tatiyassa apāyabhayagamanavīthidāyajjamahattasatthumahattajātimahattasabrahmacārimahattānaṃ
analyzed: vatthuvisadakiriyā nāma tathā ekādasa dhammā tatiyassa
translated: reviewing the great profit of the chance of going to the plane of no-rebirth, the great profit of the Master, the great profit of the True Idea, the great profit of the Community, the great profit of the True Ideal person,

original: paccavekkhaṇatā ānisaṃsadassāvitā piṇḍapātāpacāyanatā kusītapuggalaparivajjanatā🔽āraddhavīriyapuggalasevanatā tadadhimuttatāti. Tattha “buddhādīhi gatamaggo mayā
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa tā ānisaṃsa dassāvi tā piṇḍapāta apacāyana tā kusīta puggala parivajjana tā  āraddha vīriya puggala sevana tā tad adhimutta tā ti tattha buddha ādīhi gata maggaḥ mayā
translated: seeing the advantages, not being mean with the alms food, avoiding the lazy,🔽associating with the energetic, and the inclination to that.

original: gantabbo”ti paccavekkhaṇā vīthipaccavekkhaṇā nāma. “Dāyakehi dinnapiṇḍapātassa mahapphalataṃ
analyzed: gantabbo ti paccavekkhaṇā vīthi paccavekkhaṇā nāma dāyakehi dinna piṇḍapātassa mahapphala taṃ
translated: Herein, reviewing the path gone by the Enlightened One, etc., as the path to be gone by oneself, is called reviewing the path. Reviewing the great profit of the alms food given by donors,

original: sampādessāmī”ti attānaṃ damanaṃ piṇḍapātāpacāyanaṃ nāma. Tathā ekādasa dhammā catutthassa
analyzed: sampādessāmi iti attānam damanam piṇḍapāta apacāyanam nāma tathā ekādasa dhammā catutthassa
translated: So too, eleven ideas belong with the fourth jhana:

original: buddhadhammasaṅghasīlacāgadevatopasamānussatiyo satta, lūkhapuggalaparivajjanatā
analyzed: buddha dhamma saṅgha sīla cāga devatā upasama anussatiyaḥ satta lūkha puggala parivajjana tā
translated: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha, virtue, generosity, the heavenly worlds, the recollection of peace, avoidance of rough people,

original: siniddhapuggalasevanatā pasādanīyasuttantapaccavekkhaṇatā tadadhimuttatāti. Tathā
analyzed: siniddha puggala sevana tā pasādanīya suttanta paccavekkhaṇa tā tad adhimutta tā ati tathā
translated: cultivation of refined people, reviewing of inspiring discourses, and resoluteness upon that.🔽So too, seven ideas belong with the fifth jhana:

original: satta dhammā pañcamassa paṇītabhojanasevanatā, utusukhairiyāpathasukhasevanatā dve
analyzed: satta dhammā pañcamassa paṇīta bhojana sevana tā utu sukha eriyāpatha sukha sevana tā dve
translated: the use of refined food, the use of the pleasure of weather and of postures, the two,

original: majjhattappayogatā sāraddhakāyapuggalaparivajjanatā santakāyapuggalasevanatā tadadhimuttatāti.
analyzed: majjhatta payoga tā sāraddha kāya puggala parivajjana tā santa kāya puggala sevana tā tad adhimutta tā ati
translated: the use of the middle, avoidance of people who are ill-tempered, cultivation of people who are placid, and resoluteness upon that.🔽Eleven ideas belong with the sixth jhana:

original: Ekādasa dhammā chaṭṭhassa vatthuvisadakiriyā indriyasamattapaṭipādanā nimittakusalatā
analyzed: ekādasa dhammā chaṭṭhassa vatthu visada kiriyā indriya samatta paṭipādanā nimitta kusala tā
translated: making the physical basis quite clear, balancing the faculties, skill in the sign,

original: samaye cittassa paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanajjhupekkhanā catasso, asamāhitasamāhitapuggalānaṃ
analyzed: samaye cittassa paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsana ajjhupekkhanā catasso asamāhita samāhita puggalānaṃ
translated: stimulating, restraining, encouraging, and equanimity in the case of the mind, and avoidance of people who are not fully absorbed in meditation and cultivation of people who are.

original: parivajjanasevanatā dve, jhānavimokkhapaccavekkhaṇatā tadadhimuttatāti. Tattha kasiṇādinimittānaṃ🔽uggahaṇakusalatā nimittakusalatā nāma. Pañca dhammā sattamassa sattasaṅkhārakelāyanamajjhattapuggalānaṃ🔽parivajjanasevanatā dve dve, tadadhimuttatāti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana
analyzed: parivajjana sevana tā dve jhāna vimokkha paccavekkhaṇa tā tad adhimutta tā ti tattha kasiṇa ādi nimittānam  uggahaṇa kusala tā nimitta kusala tā nāma pañca dhammā sattamassa satta saṅkhāra kelāyanam ajjhatta puggalānam  parivajjana sevana tā dve dve tad adhimutta tā ati ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ pana

appearance.🔽The skill in the state of turning away is the skill in apprehending the sign of the four kinds of turning away.🔽The

original: sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāya gahetabboti ayamettha hetuvibhāgo.🔽Bhūmivibhāgato panete kāmāvacarā, lokuttarā vā honti, kāmāvacaresu balavavipassanādīsu🔽eva bojjhaṅgā labbhanti, na itaresu. Lokuttaresu pana sabbattha labbhanti, rūpāvacarārūpāvacaracittesu
analyzed: sammoha vinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāya gahetabbo ti ayam ettha hetu vibhāgo  bhūmi vibhāgataḥ pana ete kāmāvacarāḥ lokuttarāḥ vā honti kāmāvacaresu balava vipassanā ādīsu  eva bojjhaṅgāḥ labbhanti na itaresu lokuttaresu pana sabbattha labbhanti rūpāvacara arūpāvacara cittesu
translated: The two kinds of avoidance and undertaking, and the reviewing of jhāna and of deliverance, and the devotion to that are the cause. Herein, skill in the sign of the kasiṇa, etc., is skill in the sign. The five dhammas are the two kinds of avoidance and undertaking, and the reviewing of jhāna and of deliverance, and the devotion to that. Herein, the brief treatment is this. The detailed treatment should be understood according to the method given in the Vibhaṅga commentary, the Sammohavinodani. This is the investigation of the cause.

original: sabbathā na labbhanti abodhipakkhikattā. Keci pana therā vipassanāpādakesu kasiṇāsubhabrahmavihārajjhānesupi
analyzed: sabbathā na labbhanti a bodhi pakkhika ttā keci pana therāḥ vipassanā pādakesu kasiṇa asubha brahmavihāra jhānesu pi
translated: As to the investigation of the plane, these factors of enlightenment belong to the sense sphere or the supramundane. In the sense sphere they are found only in those of strong insight, not in others. But in the supramundane they are found in all. They are not found in any consciousness of the fine-material sphere or immaterial sphere, because these are not associated with the enlightenment factors. But some elders say that they are also found in the jhānas of the fine-material sphere that are the basis for insight.

original: bojjhaṅge uddharanti, na ca te paṭisiddhā aṭṭhakathācariyehi, tasmā tesaṃ matena
analyzed: bojjhaṅge uddharanti na ca te paṭisiddhāḥ aṭṭhakathā cariyehi tasmā tesam matena
translated: They are not refuted by the teachers of the commentaries. Therefore, according to their opinion,

original: rūpāvacarāpi honti, na kenaci pariyāyena arūpāvacarāti ayamettha bhūmivibhāgo.
analyzed: rūpa avacarā api honti na kenacid pariyāyena a rūpa avacarā ati ayam ettha bhūmi vibhāgaḥ
translated: they are of the fine-material sphere and not of the immaterial sphere in any way. This is the exposition of the planes.

original: Vivekatoti ettha vivekoti vivittatā, svāyaṃ pañcavidho tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavivekavasena.
analyzed: vivekāt ti ettha vivekaḥ ti vivitta tā tad ayam pañcavidhaḥ tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda paṭipassaddhi nissaraṇa viveka vasena
translated: As to seclusion: here seclusion is solitude. This is fivefold as seclusion of the primary elements, as suppression, as change-of-lineage, as surmounting, and as renunciation.

original: Tadaṅgavivekoti vipassanā, vikkhambhanavivekoti aṭṭha samāpattiyo, samucchedavivekoti
analyzed: tad aṅga vivekā ti vipassanā vikkhambhana vivekā ti aṭṭha samāpattiyo samuccheda vivekā ti
translated: Seclusion of the primary elements is insight. Seclusion by suppression is the eight attainments. Seclusion by change-of-lineage is

original: maggo, paṭipassaddhivivekoti phalaṃ, nissaraṇavivekoti sabbanimittanissaṭaṃ nibbānaṃ.🔽Tatrime tadaṅgasamucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavivekanissitā honti. Tathā hete vipassanākkhaṇe
analyzed: maggo paṭipassaddhi viveko ti phalam nissaraṇa viveko ti sabba nimitta nissaṭam nibbānam  tatra ime tad aṅga samuccheda paṭipassaddhi nissaraṇa viveka nissitāḥ honti tathā ha ete vipassanā kkhaṇe
translated: the path. Seclusion by surmounting is the fruition. Seclusion by renunciation is Nibbāna, which is the escape from all signs.🔽These are dependent on the last three kinds of seclusion, namely, that by change-of-lineage, that by surmounting, and that by renunciation. For at the moment of insight

original: kiccato tadaṅgavivekanissitā, ajjhāsayato nissaraṇavivekanissitā. Maggakāle pana
analyzed: kiccataḥ tad aṅga viveka nissitā ajjhāsayataḥ nissaraṇa viveka nissitā magga kāle pana
translated: they are dependent on seclusion by change-of-lineage as to function, and on seclusion by renunciation as to proximate cause. But at the moment of the path

original: kiccato samucchedavivekanissitā, ārammaṇato nissaraṇavivekanissitā, phalakkhaṇe kiccato
analyzed: kiccataḥ samuccheda viveka nissitā ārammaṇataḥ nissaraṇa viveka nissitā phala kkhaṇe kiccataḥ
translated: By way of function, it is supported by the seclusion of cutting off; by way of object, it is supported by the seclusion of surmounting. At the moment of fruition, it is supported by the seclusion of tranquillization of function.

original: paṭipassaddhivivekanissitā. Ārammaṇato nissaraṇavivekanissitā ca honti. Kesañci therānaṃ
analyzed: paṭipassaddhi viveka nissitāḥ ārammaṇataḥ nissaraṇa viveka nissitā ca honti kesañci therānam
translated: And it is supported by the seclusion of surmounting by way of object. In the view of some elders,

original: mate vipassanāpādakarūpāvacarajjhānakkhaṇe vikkhambhanavivekanissitāvāti pañcavivekanissitāpi
analyzed: mate vipassanā pādaka rūpāvacara jhāna kkhaṇe vikkhambhana viveka nissitā avāti pañca viveka nissitā api
translated: at the moment of insight-producing material-sphere jhāna, it is supported by the seclusion of suppression. Thus it is supported by five kinds of seclusion.

original: hontīti ayamettha viveko. Evaṃ viññeyyo pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: honti iti ayam ettha vivekaḥ evam viññeyyaḥ pāḷi mutta vinicchayo
translated: This is the distinction here. This is how the exegesis of the text should be understood.

original: Bojjhaṅgavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bojjhaṅga vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the exposition of the factors of enlightenment is finished.

original: Maggaṅgavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: maggaṅga vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the Path Factors

original: Maggaṅgavibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – ariyoti taṃtaṃmaggavajjhakilesehi ārakattā,
analyzed: pana atthataḥ tāva ariyaḥ ti taṃ taṃ magga vajjha kilesehi āraka ttā
translated: As to meaning, firstly, noble is that which is far from the defilements to be abandoned by that path,

original: ariyabhāvakarattā ca ariyo, aṭṭha aṅgāni assāti aṭṭhaṅgiko, nibbānatthikehi maggīyati,
analyzed: ariya bhāva karattā ca ariyaḥ aṭṭha aṅgāni assa ati aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ nibbāna atthikehi maggīyati
translated: and which causes the attainment of noble status. It has eight factors, thus it is the eight-factored one. It is a path because those who seek Nibbāna are caused to enter it,

original: nibbānaṃ vā maggati, kilese vā mārento gacchatīti maggo. Seyyathidanti so katamoti
analyzed: nibbānam vā maggati kilese vā mārentaḥ gacchati iti maggaḥ so katamaḥ iti
translated: or because it causes Nibbāna to be reached, or because it goes along overcoming the defilements. What is that?

original: ce, idāni svāyaṃ maggo caturaṅginī viya senā aṅgamattameva hoti, aṅgavinimutto natthīti
analyzed: ce idāni svāyam maggo caturaṅginī senā aṅga mattam eva hoti aṅga vinimuttaḥ natthi iti
translated: Now, this path is just a mere factor like an army with four factors, and it is devoid of a factor called “person.”

original: dassento “sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhī”ti āha. Tattha sammā passatīti sammādiṭṭhi,
analyzed: dassentaḥ sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi iti āha tattha sammā passati iti sammādiṭṭhi
translated: Showing this, he said, “Right view … right concentration.” Herein, one who sees rightly is one of right view .

original: paññā. Sammā saṅkappeti takketīti sammāsaṅkappo, vitakko. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Tato
analyzed: paññā sammā saṅkappeti takketi iti sammāsaṅkappaḥ vitakko sesam su viññeyyam eva tatas
translated: Wisdom is meant. One who resolves rightly, who directs his mind rightly, is one of right intention . Thought is meant. The rest is easy to understand.

original: dhammabhedopi vibhaṅganayopi bojjhaṅgesu vuttasadiso.🔽Abhidhammabhājanīye pana viratittayavajjito pañcaṅgikopi maggo vibhatto, tañca pañcannaṃ
analyzed: dhamma bhedaḥ api vibhaṅga nayaḥ api bojjhaṅgesu vutta sadiso  abhidhamma bhājanīye pana virati ttaya vajjito pañcaṅgikaḥ api maggo vibhatto tat ca
translated: The analysis and the method of exposition should be understood as in the case of the enlightenment factors.

original: aṅgānaṃ kiccādhikataṃ, viratīnañca avuttasiddhataṃ sandhāya, virativajjitassa pana
analyzed: aṅgānam kicca adhika tam viratīnam ca a vutta siddha tam sandhāya virati vajjitassa pana
translated: But in the Abhidhamma the path is analyzed into five factors, omitting the three abstinences. And that is done with the intention of showing the predominance of the five factors and the established nature of the abstinences,

original: lokuttaramaggassa abhāvā sopi aṭṭhaṅgikovāti veditabbo.
analyzed: lokuttara maggassa abhāvā saḥ api aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ vā iti veditabbo
translated: for there is no supramundane path without the abstinences.

original: Pañhāpucchakepi sammāsaṅkappo sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttova, sesā dvīhi. Sammāsaṅkappo
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pi sammāsaṅkappo sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttaḥ uva sesāḥ dvīhi sammāsaṅkappo
translated: In the Questions of Milinda, right intention is associated only with pleasant feeling, the rest with two.

original: avitakkavicāramatto, pītisahagato sukhasahagatova, na upekkhāsahagato, sesā tidhāpi.
analyzed: a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ pīti sahagataḥ sukha sahagataḥ va na upekkhā sahagataḥ sesā tidhā api
translated: The first has no thinking and only has reflection, and it is accompanied by happiness and by bliss, but not by equanimity. The rest are of three kinds.

original: Sammādiṭṭhi hetu, sesā nahetūti ayaṃ viseso. Sesaṃ samameva. Idāni pana –
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi hetu sesāḥ na hetu uti ayam visesaḥ sesam samam eva idāni pana
translated: Right view is a cause, but the rest are not causes. This is the difference. The rest is the same.🔽Now, in the case of the path factors, the method of exposition should be understood as follows:🔽By way of function, by way of difference of function,

original: Kamato kiccabhedato, bhūmibhedavivekato;
analyzed: kamataḥ bhūmi bheda vivekataḥ
translated: By way of difference of plane,

original: Maggaṅgesu vijānīyo, pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: maggaṅgesu vijānīyo pāḷi mutta vinicchayo
translated: The method of exposition should be understood in the texts by way of function, etc.

original: Tattha kamato tāva ayampi desanākkamova. Bhagavatā hi nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa
analyzed: tattha kamataḥ tāva ayam pi desanā kkamaḥ uva bhagavatā hi nibbāna adhigamāya paṭipannassa
translated: Herein, by way of function: this is the order of exposition itself. For the Blessed One, when he was practising the way to the destruction of suffering,

original: paññāpajjotapaññāsatthatāya avijjandhakāravidhamanato bahūpakārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi🔽desitā. Tato heraññikassa kahāpaṇaparivattakahattho viya yathāsabhāvadassanassa sammādiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: paññāpajja utapaññāsattha tāya avijja andhakāra vidhamanataḥ bahu upakāra ttā paṭhamam sammādiṭṭhi  desitā tatas heraññikassa kahāpaṇa parivattaka hatthaḥ viya yathā sabhāva dassanassa sammādiṭṭhiyā
translated: first taught right view, which is helpful for the attainment of Nibbāna, since it is the light of understanding and the means for the dispelling of the darkness of ignorance.🔽Then he taught right thought, which is helpful for the seeing of the way of behaviour that is the specific duty of one who has entered on the way, like the hand, which is the organ for handling things, in the case of one who has obtained a handful of coins.

original: bahūpakārattā sammāsaṅkappo. Svāyaṃ yathā sammādiṭṭhiyā, evaṃ sammāvācāyapi upakārako.
analyzed: bahu upakāra ttā sammāsaṅkappo yathā sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ evam upakārako
translated: And this is helpful for right speech in the same way as right view is.

original: Yathāha “pubbe kho, gahapati, takketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindatī”ti, tasmā
analyzed: yathā āha pubbe kho gahapati takketvā vicāretvā pacchā vācam bhindati iti tasmā
translated: As it is said: “First, householder, one should examine and then speak” .

original: tadanantaraṃ sammāvācā. Yasmā pana vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante payojenti, tasmā
analyzed: tad anantaram sammāvācā yasmai vācāya saṃvidahitvā loke kammante tasmai
translated: Then right speech. But since they engage in work in the world after making plans with speech,

original: tadanantaraṃ sammākammanto. Kāyavacīduccaritaṃ pahāya ubhayasucaritaṃ pūrentasseva
analyzed: tad anantaram sammā kammantaḥ kāyavacī duccaritam pahāya ubhaya su caritam pūrentassa iva
translated: then right action follows it. And when he has given up bodily and verbal misconduct and is fulfilling the two kinds of good conduct,

original: yasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakaṃ sīlaṃ pūrati, na itarassa, tasmā tadubhayānantaraṃ sammāājīvo🔽vutto. Evaṃ “visuddhadiṭṭhisīlenāpi ettāvatā paritosaṃ akatvā idaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhitabba”nti
analyzed: yasmai ājīva ṭṭhamakam sīlam pūrati na itarassa tasmai tad ubhaya anantaram sammāājīvaḥ  vuttaḥ evam visuddha diṭṭhi sīlena api ettāvatā paritosam a katvā idam vīriyam ārabhitabbanti
translated: since he fulfils the virtue consisting in the eighth factor of the noble path, namely, right livelihood, and not the other kind,🔽then right livelihood is stated next to the two. In order to show that “one who is not satisfied with this much, namely, purified view and purified virtue, should begin effort”

original: dassetuṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāvāyāmo. Āraddhavīriyenāpi kāyādīsu sati sūpaṭṭhitā kātabbāti
analyzed: dassetum tad anantaram sammāvāyāmaḥ āraddha vīriyena api kāya ādīsu sati su upaṭṭhitā kātabbā ti
translated: then right effort is stated next. And in order to show that “one who has begun effort should establish mindfulness well in the body, etc.,”

original: dassanatthaṃ tadanantaraṃ sammāsati. Sūpaṭṭhitāya satiyā ekattārammaṇe cittaṃ samādhātuṃ
analyzed: dassana ttham tad anantaram sammā sati su upaṭṭhitāya satiyāḥ ekatta ārammaṇe cittam samādhātum
translated: then right mindfulness is stated next. And since it is possible to concentrate the mind on a single object when mindfulness is well established,

original: sakkāti tadanantaraṃ sammāsamādhi vuttoti ayaṃ tāvettha kamo.
analyzed: sakkā ati tad anantaram sammāsamādhi vutto ti ayam tāva ettha kamaḥ
translated: then right concentration is stated next. This, firstly, is the order here.

original: Kiccato panesaṃ ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni, seyyathidaṃ – sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehipi
analyzed: kiccataḥ pana esam ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni seyyathīdam sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehi pi
translated: As to function: each has three functions. Right view, firstly, has the function of giving direction, of preventing, and of establishing.

original: attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhiṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ pajahati, ārammaṇato nirodhasaccaṃ🔽sacchikaroti, asammohato sesasaccāni paṭivijjhati. Evaṃ sammāsaṅkappādīnaṃ micchāsaṅkappapajahanādivasena
analyzed: attanaḥ paccanīka kilesehi saddhim micchādiṭṭhim pajahati ārammaṇataḥ nirodha saccam  sacchikaroti a sammohataḥ sesa saccāni paṭivijjhati evam sammāsaṅkappa ādīnam micchāsaṅkappa pajahana ādi vasena
translated: He realizes the truth of cessation as object.🔽He penetrates the other truths by non-delusion. This is how their functions should be understood according to the abandoning of wrong thought, etc.,

original: yathānurūpanti kiccatā veditabbā. Visesato panettha sammāsaṅkappo sahajātadhamme
analyzed: yathā anurūpam ti kicca tā veditabbā visesataḥ pana ittha sammāsaṅkappo sahajāta dhamme
translated: and as appropriate. But in particular, right thought impels the states associated with it;

original: abhiniropeti, sammāvācā pariggaṇhāti, sammākammanto samuṭṭhāpeti, sammāājīvo vodāpeti,
analyzed: abhiniropeti sammā vācā pariggaṇhāti sammā kammanto samuṭṭhāpeti sammā ājīvaḥ vodāpeti
translated: right speech defines them; right action originates them; right livelihood purifies them;

original: sammāvāyāmo paggaṇhāti, sammāsati upaṭṭhāpeti, sammāsamādhi samādahatīti idamettha kiccaṃ.
analyzed: sammāvāyāmaḥ paggaṇhāti sammā sati upaṭṭhāpeti sammā samādhi samādahati iti idam ettha kiccam
translated: right effort exerts them; right mindfulness looks on at them; right concentration focuses them. This is their function.

original: Bhedato pana pubbabhāge sammādiṭṭhi “dukkhe ñāṇa”ntiādinā catūsu saccesu ñāṇavasena
analyzed: bhedato pana pubba bhāge sammādiṭṭhi dukkhe ñāṇa nti ādinā catūsu saccesu ñāṇa vasena
translated: But in detail, in the earlier stage right view is knowledge in the four truths in the way beginning, “Knowledge of suffering” .

original: nānakkhaṇā nānārammaṇā nānānāmā hoti, dutiyo pana nekkhammaabyāpādaavihiṃsāsaṅkappavasena,
analyzed: nāna khaṇā nānā ārammaṇā nānā nāmā hoti dutiyaḥ pana nekkhamma abyāpāda avihiṃsā saṅkappa vasena
translated: It is of various moments, of various objects, and has various names. But the second, which is right thought, is of three kinds as the thoughts of renunciation, of non-ill will, and of non-cruelty.

original: viratiyo catubbidhavacīduccaritatividhakāyaduccaritamicchājīvaviramaṇasaṅkhātacetanāvasenapi🔽virativasenapi, chaṭṭhasattamā catubbidhasammappadhānasatipaṭṭhānavasena nānakkhaṇā
analyzed: viratiyāḥ catur bidha vacī duccarita tividha kāya duccaritam icchā jīva viramaṇa saṅkhāta cetanā vasena api  virati vasena api chaṭṭha sattamā catubbidha sammappadhāna sati paṭṭhāna vasena nānā kkhaṇā
translated: The abstinences are fourfold as volition consisting in abstinence from the four verbal kinds of misconduct and from the three kinds of bodily misconduct and from wrong livelihood,

original: nānārammaṇā nānānāmā honti. Maggakāle panete sammādiṭṭhiādayo ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā.🔽Kiccato pana tāni pubbabhāge nānānāmāni labhanti, sammāsamādhi pana pubbabhāgepi
analyzed: nānā ārammaṇāḥ nānā nāmāḥ honti magga kāle pana ete sammādiṭṭhi ādayaḥ eka kkhaṇāḥ eka ārammaṇā  kiccataḥ pana tāni pubba bhāge nānā nāmāni labhanti sammāsamādhi pana pubba bhāge pi
translated: and as abstinence. The sixth and seventh are threefold as right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration. They are of different moments and different objects and have different names. But at the time of the path they are of one moment and of one object.

original: maggakkhaṇepi catukkapañcakajjhānavasena nānakkhaṇo nānānāmo, maggakkhaṇe pana ekārammaṇo🔽hoti. Ekassa hi paṭhamamaggo pādakajjhānādiniyamato paṭhamajjhānādiko vā dutiyajjhānādīsu
analyzed: magga kkhaṇe pi catukka pañcaka jhāna vasena nānā kkhaṇaḥ nānā nāmaḥ magga kkhaṇe pana eka ārammaṇaḥ  hoti ekassa hi paṭhama maggaḥ pādaka jjhāna ādi niyamato paṭhama jjhāna ādikaḥ vā dutiya jhāna ādīsu
translated: But as to function, they get their different names in the earlier stage. Right concentration, however, is of different moments and different names as the four and five jhānas, both in the earlier stage and at the time of the path. But at the time of the path it is of one object.

original: aññatarajjhāniko vā, dutiyamaggādayopissa paṭhamamaggasadisajjhānikā vā visadisajjhānikā
analyzed: aññatara jjhānikaḥ vā dutiya magga ādayaḥ pissa paṭhama magga sadisa jjhānikā vā visadisa jjhānikā
translated: For one man’s path is of different moments and different names, being either the first jhāna, etc., or one of the other jhānas beginning with the second, according as his basic jhāna is determined as the proximate cause, etc., and the second path, etc., are similar to the first path in having that same jhāna as their proximate cause or are dissimilar to it in having a different jhāna as their proximate cause.

original: vāti so maggakālepi nānakkhaṇo nānānāmo vāti ayamettha bhedo.
analyzed: vāti saḥ magga kāle pi nāna kkhaṇaḥ nānā nāmaḥ vāti ayam ettha bhedaḥ
translated: So they are of different moments and different names even at the time of the path. This is the difference here.

original: Bhūmito ca vivekato ca vinicchayo bojjhaṅgesu vuttānusārena veditabboti evaṃ vijānīyo pāḷimuttavinicchayo.
analyzed: bhūmito ca vivekato ca vinicchayaḥ bojjhaṅgesu vutta anusārena veditabbaḥ ti evam vijānīyo pāḷimutta vinicchayo
translated: And the exposition of the words “from the earth” and “from the separation” should be understood in the same way as that of the words “from the earth” and “from the separation” in the case of the enlightenment factors. This is how the exposition should be known as to the words “from the scriptures.”

original: Maggaṅgavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Jhānavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā🔽Jhānavibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutotiādīsu pātimokkhanti
analyzed: maggaṅga vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā          pana atthato tāva
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Maggaṅgapaññatti is ended.

original: sikkhāpadasīlaṃ. Taṃ hi yo naṃ pāti rakkhati, taṃ mokkheti moceti āpāyikādīhi dukkhehi,
analyzed: sikkhāpada sīlam tam hi yaḥ nam pāti rakkhati tam mokkheti moceti āpāyika ādīhi dukkhehi
translated: As regards the Jhānapaññatti, firstly as to meaning: in the passage beginning “Restrained with the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha” , the Pāṭimokkha is the virtue consisting in the training precepts. For one who observes that, who guards it, is released from, is freed from, the bad destinations and so on, from suffering,

original: tasmā “pātimokkha”nti vuccati. Saṃvaraṇaṃ, saṃvaranti vā tenāti saṃvaro, pātimokkhameva🔽saṃvaro pātimokkhasaṃvaro, kammavācāpariyosāne ijjhanakassa atthato cetanādirūpassa
analyzed: tasmā pātimokkham ti vuccati saṃvaraṇam saṃvaranti vā tena ati saṃvaraḥ pātimokkham eva  saṃvaro pātimokkha saṃvaro kamma vācā pariyosāne ijjhanakassa atthataḥ cetanā ādi rūpassa
translated: and so it is called “Pāṭimokkha” . It restrains , or it is itself restrained by, the one who is observing it, thus it is restraint ; the Pāṭimokkha itself is restraint,

original: pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlassevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tena saṃvuto pihitakāyavacīpayogoti pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto.
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara sīlassa iva etat adhivacanam tena saṃvutaḥ pihita kāya vacī payogaḥ ti pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ
translated: or the restraint is in the Pāṭimokkha, thus it is the Pāṭimokkha restraint. This is a term for the volition, etc., that succeed at the end of the announcement of the Monastic Rule,🔽in the sense of the virtue consisting in the Pāṭimokkha restraint. Restrained by that, with bodily and verbal conduct restrained, is what is meant.

original: Viharatīti iriyati pavatteti. Ācāragocarasampannoti ettha ācaritabbato ācāro, gāvo
analyzed: viharati iti pavattā iti ācāra gocara sampannaḥ ti ettha ācaritabbataḥ ācāraḥ gāvaḥ
translated: “He lives”: he moves, he occurs. “Endowed with virtue and resort”: here, what is to be practiced is the resort.🔽Cows

original: caranti etthāti gocaro, gunnaṃ caraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. Taṃsadisatāya pana sabbopi pavattivisayo
analyzed: caranti ettha ati gocaraḥ caraṇa ṭhānam tad sadisa tāya pana sabbaḥ api pavatti visayo
translated: go there, thus it is a resort. But the place where cattle go is a pasture. However, all the sphere of occurrence should be understood as a resort by the similarity of that.

original: gocaroti veditabbo. Tesaṃ vibhāgo niddese vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: gocaro ti veditabbo tesam vibhāgaḥ niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbo
translated: The distinction of these should be understood in the way stated in the Niddesa.

original: Niddese hi –
analyzed: niddese hi
translated: For in the Niddesa,

original: “Ācāragocarasampannoti atthi ācāro, atthi anācāro. Tattha katamo anācāro? Kāyiko
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampanno ti atthi ācāraḥ atthi anācāro tattha katamaḥ anācāraḥ kāyiko
translated: “Endowed with virtue and resort”: there is virtue, there is non-virtue. Herein, what is non-virtue? Bodily

original: vītikkamo, vācasiko vītikkamo, kāyikavācasiko vītikkamo, ayaṃ vuccati anācāro, sabbampi
analyzed: vītikkamaḥ vācasikaḥ vītikkamaḥ kāyika vācasikaḥ vītikkamaḥ ayam vuccati anācāraḥ sabbam pi
translated: misconduct, verbal misconduct, bodily and verbal misconduct, this is called non-virtue. All

original: dussīlyaṃ anācāro, idhekacco veḷudānena vā patta…pe… pupphaphalasinānadantakaṭṭhadānena🔽vā cāṭukamyatāya vā muggasupyatāya vā pāribhaṭutāya vā jaṅghapesanikena vā aññataraññatarena
analyzed: dussīlyam anācāraḥ idha ekaccaḥ veḷu dānena vā pattape puppha phala sināna danta kaṭṭha dānena  vā cāṭu kamyatāya vā mugga supyatāya vā pāribhaṭutāya vā jaṅgha pesanikena vā aññatara aññatarena
translated: immorality is non-virtue. Here, some person makes a living by the gift of bamboo, by the gift of a bowl… by the gift of flowers, fruits, bathing powder and tooth sticks,

original: vā buddhapatikuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti, ayaṃ vuccati anācāro.
analyzed: vā buddha pati kuṭṭhena micchāājīvena jīvikam kappeti ayam vuccati anācāro
translated: by flattery, by sleeping in the same place , by being a servant, by being a messenger, by being a go-between, by one of the wrong kinds of livelihood condemned by the Noble Ones, this is called non-virtue.

original: “Tattha katamo ācāro? Kāyiko avītikkamo”tiādinā –
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ ācāraḥ kāyikaḥ avītikkamaḥ ti ādinā
translated: “Herein, what is conduct? It is non-transgression in bodily action” ,

original: Vuttavipariyāyena ācāro niddiṭṭho.
analyzed: vutta vipariyāyena ācāraḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ
translated: and so on. Conduct is demonstrated in the opposite way to that stated.

original: “Gocaroti atthi gocaro, atthi agocaro. Tattha katamo agocaro? Idhekacco vesiyāgocaro🔽vā hoti, vidhavā…pe… thullakumārīpaṇḍakabhikkhunīpānāgāragocaro vā, saṃsaṭṭho viharati
analyzed: gocaro ti atthi gocaraḥ atthi agocaro tattha katamaḥ agocaraḥ idha ekacco vesiyā agocaro  vā hoti vidhavā pe thulla kumārī paṇḍaka bhikkhunī pānāgāra gocaraḥ vā saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati
translated: “As to resort: there is a resort and there is no resort. Herein, what is no resort? Here someone resorts to and associates with and attends to courtesans,🔽widows,

original: rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi ananulomikena saṃsaggena, yāni
analyzed: rājūhi rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi ananulomikena saṃsaggena yāni
translated: and so on as far as male and female wanderers outside the Buddhist order, and he associates with kings and royal ministers and sectarians and their disciples in a way that is not proper for a recluse.

original: vā pana tāni kulāni assaddhāni appasannāni…pe… tathārūpāni kulāni sevati bhajati
analyzed: vā pana tāni kulāni assaddhāni appasannāni pe tathārūpāni kulāni sevati bhajati
translated: Or he resorts to and associates with and attends to families that are without faith, without confidence, and so on as far as families that are contemptuous of spiritual teachers.

original: payirupāsati, ayaṃ vuccati agocaro.
analyzed: payirupāsati ayam vuccati agocaraḥ
translated: This is called no resort.

original: “Tattha katamo gocaro? Idhekacco na vesiyāgocaro hotī”tiādinā –
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ gocaraḥ idha ekacco na vā isiyā gocaraḥ hoti itiādinā
translated: “Herein, what is a resort? Here someone does not resort to courtesans” ,

original: Vuttavipariyāyena gocaro niddiṭṭho.
analyzed: vutta vipariyāyena gocaraḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ
translated: and so on. A resort is demonstrated in the opposite way to that stated.

original: Apicettha therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ purato gamananisīdanacaṅkamanaghaṭṭanābhibhavanādikāyikācittīkārakiriyānañceva
analyzed: apica ittha therānam bhikkhūnam puratas gamana nisīdana caṅkamana ghaṭṭana abhibhavana ādi kāyikā cittīkāra kiriyānam ca eva
translated: Moreover, here the paying of attention by bodily action in the presence of elder bhikkhus to rising up to greet them, to refraining from sitting in their seats, to refraining from spreading out a seat for them, to not sitting on a seat when told to do so, to not eating in front of them, to not eating when told to do so, to not going when told to go, to not sitting when told to sit, to not bending over when told to bend over, to not holding on to a support when told to do so, and to not going when told to go away,

original: there bhikkhū anāpucchā dhammakathanakhuṃsanādivācasikācittīkārakiriyānañca anācārānaṃ
analyzed: there bhikkhū an āpucchāḥ dhamma kathana khuṃsana ādi vācasika cittīkāra kiriyānaṃ ca anācārānaṃ
translated: There are monks who, without asking permission, give a talk on the Monastic Law, give a talk on the Teaching, give a talk on the Teaching and the Monastic Law, give a talk on the Monastic Law and the Teaching,🔽and who do other kinds of mental acts of service.

original: paṭipakkhavasena kāyikavācasiko ācāro veditabbo. Apica bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso
analyzed: paṭipakkha vasena kāyika vācasikaḥ ācāraḥ veditabbaḥ apica bhikkhu sa gāravaḥ sa patissaḥ
translated: Herein, the opposite of the kinds of bodily and verbal action consisting of teaching Dhamma, asking for information, etc., without asking permission, and of the kinds of bodily and verbal action consisting of the misconducts, should be understood as the kinds of bodily and verbal action consisting of conduct.

original: hirottappasampanno sunivattho supāruto pāsādikena abhikkantādinā okkhittacakkhu iriyāpathasampanno
analyzed: hirottappa sampanno sunivattho supāruto pāsādikena abhikkanta ādinā okkhitta cakkhu iriyāpatha sampanno
translated: Moreover, a bhikkhu who is respectful, deferential, full of loving-kindness, with a sense of conscience and moral shame, well clothed and well covered, with eyes cast down, endowed with the proper conduct,

original: ābhisamācārikesu sakkaccakārī garucittīkārabahulo viharati, ayaṃ vuccati ācāro. Gocaro
analyzed: ābhisamācārikesu sakkacca kārī garu cittīkāra bahulaḥ viharati ayam vuccati ācāraḥ gocaraḥ
translated: and who lives with a sense of urgency, with a sense of moral shame and moral dread, and with a strong sense of moral shame, is said to have conduct.🔽The resort is threefold, that is to say: the resort for support, the resort for protection, and the resort for reliance.

original: pana tividho upanissayagocaro ārakkhagocaro upanibandhagocaroti. Tattha dasakathāvatthuguṇasamannāgato🔽kalyāṇamitto upanissayagocaro nāma. Antaragharādīsu okkhittacakkhutādīhi disā vidisā
analyzed: pana tividhaḥ upanissaya gocaraḥ ārakkha gocaraḥ upanibandha gocaraḥ ti tattha dasa kathā vatthu guṇa samannāgato  kalyāṇa mittaḥ upanissaya gocaraḥ nāma antara ghara ādīsu okkhitta cakkhu tā ādīhi disā vidisā
translated: Herein, a good friend possessing the ten qualities of a good friend is called the resort for support.🔽The resort for protection is the going about with eyes cast down, etc., without looking in the directions and quarters, between the houses, and so on.

original: anoloketvā gamanaṃ ārakkhagocaro nāma. Cattāro pana satipaṭṭhānā upanibandhagocaro
analyzed: anoloketvā gamanam ārakkhagocaro nāma cattāro pana sati paṭṭhānā upanibandha gocaro
translated: But the four foundations of mindfulness are called the resort for reliance.

original: nāma. Yattha cittaṃ upanibandhati, ayaṃ tividhopettha gocaroti veditabbo. Imināti
analyzed: nāma yattha cittam upanibandhati ayam tividha upettha gocaraḥ iti veditabbaḥ iminā ati
translated: Herein, the resort is threefold, as the object of the mind’s attachment.

original: iminā ācārena, gocarena ca samannāgato ācāragocarasampanno nāma.🔽Aṇumattesu vajjesūti aṇuppamāṇesu dosesu. Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassanasīlo, aṇumattaṃ
analyzed: iminā ācārena gocarena ca samannāgataḥ ācāra gocara sampannaḥ nāma  aṇumattesu vajjesu iti aṇu ppamāṇesu dosesu bhaya dassāvī iti bhaya dassana sīlaḥ aṇumattam
translated: “By this”: by this conduct and resort. One who possesses it is “endowed with conduct and resort.”🔽“In respect of the slightest faults”: in respect of faults that are as small as a hair’s tip.

original: reṇuṃ sinerusadisaṃ passanto viya sabbalahukampi dukkaṭadubbhāsitamattaṃ pārājikasadisaṃ🔽katvā vajjato bhayato dassanasīloti attho. Samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: reṇum sineru sadisam passantaḥ viya sabba lahukam pi dukkaṭa dubbhāsita mattam pārājika sadisam  katvā vajjataḥ bhayataḥ dassana sīlaḥ ti attho samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu iti yam kiñci
translated: “Seeing fear”: having the habit of seeing fear. Seeing even the slightest fault, such as a minor offense of wrong conduct or wrong speech, as if it were as big as Mount Sineru,🔽he has the habit of seeing fear in faults.

original: sikkhāpadesu sikkhitabbaṃ, taṃ suṭṭhu ādāya gahetvā sikkhati.
analyzed: sikkhāpadesu sikkhitabbam tam suṭṭhu ādāya gahetvā sikkhati
translated: “He trains in the training rules he has undertaken”: whatever should be trained in, he trains in that by undertaking it well.

original: Indriyesu guttadvāroti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu rūpādiārammaṇanimittādīnaṃ aggahaṇasaṅkhātasatisaṃvarena
analyzed: indriyesu mana chaṭṭhesu indriyesu rūpa ādi ārammaṇa nimitta ādīnam aggahaṇa saṅkhāta sati saṃvarena
translated: “Having guarded the doors of the sense faculties”: by means of the restraint of mindfulness called “not grasping the signs, etc., of objects such as visible forms,” he has closed the doors of the six sense faculties beginning with the mind.

original: pihitadvāro. Bhojane mattaññūti piṇḍapāte paṭiggahaṇaparibhogesu paccavekkhaṇañāṇavasena
analyzed: pihita dvāraḥ bhojane mattaññu iti piṇḍapāte paṭiggahaṇa paribhogesu paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇa vasena
translated: “Moderation in eating”: by means of the knowledge of reflection on the acceptance and use of alms food,

original: ceva appicchatādīhi ca mattajānanako, piṇḍapātavasena cettha catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ🔽gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Atha vā bhuñjitabbato bhojananti catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ gahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ca iva appiccha tā ādīhi ca matta jānanakaḥ piṇḍapāta vasena ca ittha catunnam paccayānam  gahaṇam veditabbam atha vā bhuñjitabbataḥ bhojanan ti catunnam paccayānam gahaṇam
translated: and with fewness of wishes, etc., he is one who knows the right amount. Herein, the taking of the four requisites should be understood as the alms-food. Or alternatively, the taking of the four requisites should be understood as the “food” in the sense of what is to be eaten.

original: veditabbaṃ. Pubbarattāpararattanti ettha aḍḍharattisaṅkhātāya rattiyā pubbe pubbarattaṃ,
analyzed: veditabbam pubba ratta apara rattam ti ettha aḍḍha ratti saṅkhātāya rattiyā pubbe pubba rattam
translated: and with fewness of wishes, etc., he is a knower of the right amount. And here the four requisites should be understood as included by the alms food. Or alternatively, the four requisites should be understood as included by the “food” since they are what is eaten. As regards “the first and last watches of the night”: before the middle of the night is the first watch,

original: iminā paṭhamayāmañceva pacchābhattañca gaṇhāti. Rattiyā pacchā apararattaṃ, iminā
analyzed: iminā paṭhama yāmam ca iva pacchābhattam ca gaṇhāti rattiyā pacchā apara rattam iminā
translated: and by that he includes the first and the after-meal watches. After the middle of the night is the last watch,

original: pacchimayāmañceva purebhattañca gaṇhāti. Pacchimayāmo panassa bhikkhuno niddākilamathavinodanokāsoti na gahito.
analyzed: pacchima yāmañca iva purebhattañca gaṇhāti pacchima yāmaḥ panassa bhikkhuno niddā kilamatha vinodana ukāsaḥ ti na gahito
translated: and by that he includes the last and the before-meal watches. But the last watch is the bhikkhu’s time for putting aside the duties of the life of purity and for sleep.

original: Jāgariyānuyogamanuyuttoti asubhabhāvanāsaṅkhātassa bhāvanārāmassa anuyogasaṅkhātaṃ🔽āsevanabhāvanaṃ anuyutto caṅkamananisajjāhi yonisomanasikārena āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi
analyzed: jāgariya anuyogam anuyuttaḥ ti asubha bhāvanā saṅkhātassa bhāvanā ārāmassa anuyoga saṅkhātam  āsevana bhāvanam anuyuttaḥ caṅkamana nisajjāhi yoni soma nasikārena āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi
translated: “Devoted to wakefulness”: he is devoted to the development of the meditation subject called “the contemplation of the unattractive” which is called “the practice of wakefulness”🔽because it is the practice of the state of wakefulness. The meaning is that he is devoted to the purification of the mind of obstructive states by means of the right reflection consisting in the meditation subject and by means of the bodily postures, etc.,
