original: cittaparisodhane yuttappayuttoti attho. Sātaccaṃ nepakkanti satataṃ pavattayitabbato
analyzed: citta parisodhane yutta ppayuttaḥ ti atthaḥ sātaccam nepakkam ti satatam
translated: “And to steady endurance” : because it should be practised continuously,

original: sātaccasaṅkhātaṃ vīriyaṃ, paripākagatattā nepakkasaṅkhātañca paññaṃ anuyuttoti sambandho.
analyzed: sātacca saṅkhātam vīriyam paripāka gata ttā nepakka saṅkhātam ca paññam anuyuttaḥ ti sambandhaḥ
translated: He is devoted to energy called “steadfastness” and to understanding called “non-distraction” because they have reached maturity.

original: Iminā vīriyapaññāhi yuttasseva jāgariyānuyogasiddhīti dasseti.
analyzed: iminā vīriya paññāhi yuttassa iva jāgariya anuyoga siddhi iti dasseti
translated: This shows that only one who is endowed with energy and understanding succeeds in devotion to wakefulness.

original: Idāni taṃ jāgariyānuyogaṃ sarūpato dassento “bodhipakkhikānaṃ dhammāna”ntiādimāha.🔽Bodhipakkhikānaṃ dhammānanti catusaccāvabodhasaṅkhātassa maggañāṇassa pakkhe bhavānaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam jāgariya anuyogam sarūpataḥ dassentaḥ bodhi pakkhikānam dhammānam ti ādim āha  bodhi pakkhikānam dhammānan ti catu sacca avabodha saṅkhātassa magga ñāṇassa pakkhe bhavānam
translated: Now, in order to show that devotion to wakefulness in its individual essence, he said “to the states that are on the side of enlightenment” .

original: catusaccasatipaṭṭhānādisattatiṃsadhammānaṃ. Niddese panassa lokiyabhāvanāya visesabodhipakkhiyadhamme
translated: “To the states that are on the side of enlightenment” : to the seventy-three states beginning with the four foundations of mindfulness that are on the side of the knowledge of the path called “enlightenment” consisting in the penetration of the four truths.

original: ekārammaṇe pavattanasamatthatāya satta bojjhaṅgā eva niddiṭṭhā. Tesaṃ gahaṇena pana
analyzed: eka ārammaṇe pavattana samattha tāya satta bojjhaṅgāḥ eva niddiṭṭhā tesam gahaṇena pana
translated: But in the Niddesa the states on the side of enlightenment that are special to mundane development are shown to be the seven factors of enlightenment because of their ability to occur with a single object.

original: sesānampi tattha gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. So abhikkante paṭikkantetiādīsu abhikkantaṃ
analyzed: sesānam pi tattha gahaṇam veditabbam saḥ abhikkante paṭikkanta iti ādīsu abhikkantam
translated: And by the inclusion of these, the inclusion of the rest should be understood.

original: vuccati purato gamanaṃ, paṭikkantaṃ nivattanaṃ, tadubhayañca ṭhānanisajjāsayanesupi
analyzed: vuccati puratas gamanam paṭikkantam nivattanam tat ubhayam ca ṭhāna nisajja āsayanesu pi
translated: “On going forward and on coming back” : going forward is said to be going in front; coming back is turning back; and both of these are also standing, sitting, and lying down.

original: purato, pacchato ca kāyassa abhigamanaapagamanavasena labbhati. Sampajānakārī hotīti
analyzed: puratas pacchatas ca kāyassa abhigamana apagamana vasena labbhati sampajāna kārī hoti iti
translated: It is found in going forward and back by the body in front and behind. He acts with clear comprehension:

original: sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī, sampajaññasseva vā kārī, sampajañña-ggahaṇena cettha🔽avippayogato satipi gahitāva hoti. Tenevassa niddese “sato sampajāno abhikkamatī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sampajaññena sabba kicca kārī sampajaññassa iva vā kārī sampajañña ggahaṇena ca ittha  a vippayogato sati pi gahitā ava hoti tena iva assa niddese sataḥ sampajānaḥ abhikkamati itiādi vuttam
translated: he does all his actions with clear comprehension, or he is only the doer of clear comprehension. But by the mention of clear comprehension🔽mindfulness is included too because it is inseparable from it. That is why in the description of this jhāna it is said, “In looking straight on and in looking away, in bending and in stretching, the bhikkhu acts with clear comprehension and he looks upon his own abandonment of the hindrances as a treasure gained” .

original: Ālokitetiādīsu ālokitaṃ nāma purato pekkhanaṃ. Vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhanaṃ. Imesaṃ
analyzed: ālokita iti ādīsu ālokitam nāma puratas pekkhanam vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhanam imesam
translated: In looking straight on, etc., looking straight on is looking in front. Looking away is looking in the other directions.🔽But by the mention of these two🔽looking up, looking down, looking across and so on are also included.🔽In flexing and extending: in flexing and extending the limbs. In bearing:

original: pana dvinnaṃ gahaṇena heṭṭhā upari pacchato pekkhanasaṅkhātāni olokitullokitāpalokitānipi🔽gahitānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: pana dvinnam gahaṇena heṭṭhā upari pacchatas pekkhana saṅkhātāni olokita ullokita apalokitāni pi  gahitāni iti veditabbāni
translated: in carrying the bowl and robes. In looking:

original: Samiñjite pasāriteti pabbānaṃ samiñjane, pasāraṇe ca. Saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇeti
analyzed: samiñjite pasāritā iti pabbānam samiñjane pasāraṇe ca saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇā iti
translated: in looking in front and at the sides. In the use of the requisites: in using the four requisites. In going forward and back: in going forward and back by the body. In looking straight on and in looking away: in looking straight on and in looking away by the eye. In bending and in stretching: in bending and stretching the body. In wearing the patched cloak and in carrying the bowl:

original: ettha saṅghāṭicīvarānaṃ nivāsanapārupanavasena, pattassa bhikkhāpaṭiggahaṇādivasena
analyzed: ettha saṅghāṭi cīvarānam nivāsana pārupana vasena pattassa bhikkhā paṭiggahaṇa ādi vasena
translated: herein, in wearing the patched cloak is in wearing the outer cloak and the upper robe by way of wearing them as an inner garment and an upper garment; in carrying the bowl is in carrying the bowl by way of taking it in the hand and so on.

original: ca paribhogo dhāraṇaṃ nāma. Asiteti piṇḍapātādibhojane. Pīteti yāguādipāne. Khāyiteti
analyzed: ca paribhogaḥ dhāraṇam nāma asita iti piṇḍapāta ādi bhojane pīta iti yāgu ādi pāne khāyita iti
translated: and using is called bearing. As to what is eaten: as to what is eaten by way of the staple food of cooked rice, etc.,🔽As to what is drunk: as to what is drunk by way of beverages, etc.,🔽As to what is chewed: as to what is chewed by way of hard food, etc.,

original: piṭṭhakhajjādikhādane. Sāyiteti madhuphāṇitādisāyite. Uccārapassāvakammeti uccārassa
analyzed: piṭṭha khajja ādi khādane sāyita iti madhu phāṇita ādi sāyite uccāra passāva kammā iti uccārassa
translated: As to what is tasted: as to what is tasted by way of honey, molasses, etc.,🔽As to evacuation of urine and faeces: as to the passing of urine and faeces,🔽As to going: as to going,🔽As to standing: as to standing,🔽As to sitting: as to sitting,

original: ca passāvassa ca karaṇe. Gateti gamane. Ṭhiteti ṭhāne. Nisinneti nisajjāya. Sutteti
analyzed: ca passāvassa ca karaṇe gatā iti gamane ṭhitā iti ṭhāne nisinnā iti nisajjāya suttā iti
translated: As to sleeping: as to sleeping,

original: sayane. Jāgariteti jāgaraṇe. Ettha ca bhikkhācāragamanādivasena “abhikkante”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sayane jāgaritā iti jāgaraṇe ettha ca bhikkhā ācāra gamana ādi vasena abhikkantā iti vuttam
translated: As to waking: as to waking. And here “on going out” is said by way of going out for alms, etc.,🔽but “on going” and the rest should be understood by way of the postures of standing, etc., in the monastery. As to speaking:

original: Vihāre pana caṅkamanādiiriyāpathavaseneva “gate”tiādi vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Bhāsiteti
analyzed: vihāre pana caṅkamana ādi iriyāpatha vasena iva gata iti ādi vuttan ti veditabbam bhāsita iti
translated: as to speaking,

original: kathane. Tuṇhībhāveti akathane.🔽Sabbesu pana tesu abhikkantādīsu paccekaṃ sātthakasampajaññaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ
analyzed: kathane tuṇhībhāva iti a kathane  sabbesu pana tesu abhikkanta ādīsu paccekam sa atthaka sampajaññam sa ppāya sampajaññam
translated: As to keeping silent: as to keeping silent.🔽And in all these cases, on going out, etc., the clear comprehension should be understood as fourfold, namely, clear comprehension of purpose, clear comprehension of the proper time, clear comprehension of measure, and clear comprehension of priority and posteriority.

original: gocarasampajaññaṃ asammohasampajaññanti catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: gocara sampajaññam asammoha sampajaññanti catubbidham sampajaññam veditabbam tattha
translated: Herein,

original: abhikkamitukāmatādicitte uppanne cittavaseneva gamanādiṃ akatvā “kiṃ nu me tattha🔽gatena attho”ti pariggaṇhitvā cetiyadassanādino tassa tassa atthassa pariggaṇhanaṃ
analyzed: abhikkamitu kāma tā ādi citte uppanne citta vasena iva gamana ādim a katvā kim nu me tattha  gatena attho ti pariggaṇhitvā cetiya dassana ādino tassa tassa atthassa pariggaṇhanam
translated: When there is a wish to go forward, etc., and the mind is inclined to go forward, etc., then, instead of going forward, etc., just as the mind is inclined, he should first review the purpose thus: “What is the purpose of my going forward?

original: sātthakasampajaññaṃ nāma. Sātthakesu panetesu gamanādīsu jīvitabrahmacariyantarāyānañceva🔽sallekhapaṭipattivighātakarānaṃ kāyikacetasikaparikkilesānañca sabbesānaṃ sabbhāvābhāvaṃ
analyzed: sātthakasampajaññam nāma sātthakesu pana etesu gamana ādīsu jīvita brahmacariya antarāyānam ca iva  sallekha paṭipatti vighāta karānam kāyika cetasika parikkilesānam ca sabbesānam sabbhāva abhāvam
translated: ” or “What is the purpose of my looking in this direction?” or “What is the purpose of my looking at this?” or “What is the purpose of my going thus?” or “What is the purpose of my staying thus?” or “What is the purpose of my sitting thus?” or “What is the purpose of my lying down thus?” or “What is the purpose of my speaking?” or “What is the purpose of my keeping silent?” or “What is the purpose of my arousing this kind of thought?” or “What is the purpose of my not arousing this kind of thought?”🔽This reviewing of the purpose is called “clear comprehension of purpose.”

original: pariggahetvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ nāma. Evaṃ pariggahitasātthakasappāyassa
analyzed: pariggahetvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam nāma evam pariggahita sātthaka sappāyassa
translated: But when he goes forward, etc., in such purposeful ways, then he should review the suitability of the action thus: “Is it suitable to go forward, etc., in this way?🔽” or “Is it suitable to look in this direction, etc., in this way?” or “Is it suitable to think in this way?”🔽This reviewing of the suitability of the action is called “clear comprehension of suitability.”🔽But when he goes forward, etc., in such suitable ways, then he should review the field thus: “Is it a suitable field, this mother, this father, this monk, this … this noble disciple?”🔽This reviewing of the field is called “clear comprehension of the field.”🔽But when he goes forward, etc., in such suitable fields, then he should review the action thus: “Is this action of mine blameless or blameworthy?

original: pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu, vipassanāya vā attano abhirucitaṃ kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu vipassanāya vā attanaḥ abhirucitam kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhātam
translated: ” or “Is it profitable or unprofitable?”🔽This reviewing of the action is called “clear comprehension of action.”

original: gocaraṃ avissajjetvāva abhikkamādīnaṃ karaṇaṃ gocarasampajaññaṃ nāma. Abhikkamādīsu
analyzed: gocaram a vissajjetvā ava abhikkama ādīnam karaṇam gocarasampajaññam nāma abhikkama ādīsu
translated: But when he goes forward, etc., in such blameless, etc., actions, then he should review the time thus: “Is it timely for me to go forward, etc., in this way?

original: pana andhabālaputhujjanā “attā abhikkamādīni karoti, ahaṃ karomī”ti vā sammuyhanti,
analyzed: pana andha bāla puthujjanāḥ attā abhikkama ādīni karoti aham karomi iti vā sammuyhanti
translated: ” or “Is it timely for me to look in this direction, etc., in this way?” or “Is it timely for me to think in this way?”🔽This reviewing of the time is called “clear comprehension of time.”🔽But when he goes forward, etc., in such timely ways, then he should review the manner of doing it

original: tathā asammuyhitvā “abhikkamitukāmatādicittakiriyavāyodhātu vipphārādikāraṇasāmaggiyā🔽ayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāto aṭṭhisaṅghāṭo abhikkamādīni karoti, tato añño abbhantare attā vā
analyzed: tathā a sammuyhitvā abhikkamitu kāma tā ādi citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra ādi kāraṇa sāmaggiyā  ayam kāya saṅkhātaḥ aṭṭhi saṅghāṭaḥ abhikkama ādīni karoti tatas aññaḥ abbhantare attā vā
translated: And when he has thus understood without bewilderment, then the occurrence of the consciousness that desires to go forward, etc., is a condition for the meeting together of the conascent material states consisting of the earth element, etc., and for the arising of the conascent kinds of consciousness and their concomitants.

original: satto vā abhikkamanto vā paṭikkamanto vā…pe… tuṇhī bhavanto vā natthī”ti evamādinā
analyzed: sattaḥ vā abhikkamantaḥ vā paṭikkamantaḥ vā āpe tuṇhī bhavantaḥ vā natthi iti evamādinā
translated: So it is the body, consisting of the collection of bones, that goes forward and comes back, stands and sits and lies down. There is no other self or living being or soul that does these things.🔽This is how he brings about the occurrence of clear comprehension that is non-delusion.

original: yāthāvato jānanavasena paññāya pavattanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ nāma. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,
analyzed: yāthāvataḥ jānana vasena paññāya pavattanam asammohasampajaññam nāma ayam ettha saṅkhepo
translated: This is the brief treatment of it.

original: vitthāro pana sammohavinodaniyaṃ gahetabbo.
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana sammoha vinodaniyam gahetabbo
translated: The detailed treatment should be understood according to the Dispensation of the Ariyans, which is the Dispensation of the True Idea, and according to the Commentaries and the Subcommentaries.

original: Idāni yasmā yassa abbhantare yathāvuttā ettakā guṇā natthi, tassa araññavāso pana
analyzed: idāni yasmai yassa abbhantare yathā vuttāḥ ettakāḥ guṇāḥ na atthi tassa arañña vāso pana
translated: Now, when someone has not got these aforesaid good qualities inside himself, then dwelling in the forest is not suitable for him,

original: makkaṭādīnaṃ viya anucchaviko na hoti, upacāramattampissa jhānaṃ na uppajjati. Yassa
analyzed: makkaṭa ādīnam viya anucchavikaḥ na hoti upacāra mattam pissa jhānam na uppajjati yassa
translated: and even the mere access jhāna does not arise in him, just as it did not arise in the Elder Cūḷa-Sīva.

original: pana santi, tassa araññavāso anucchaviko hoti. So hi tattha sabbappakārajjhānaṃ nibbattetuṃ
analyzed: pana santi tassa arañña vāsaḥ anucchavikaḥ hoti so hi tattha sabba ppakāra jjhānam nibbattetum
translated: But when someone has got them, then dwelling in the forest is suitable for him, and he can produce the jhāna of all kinds in such a place.

original: sakkoti, araññavāsañceva āraññake ca upasobheti, sakalañca sāsanaṃ pasādeti, tasmā
analyzed: sakkoti arañña vāsam ca iva āraññake ca upasobheti sakalam ca sāsanam pasādeti tasmā
translated: He adorns both the forest life and the forest-dweller, and he gladdens the entire Dispensation.

original: evarūpassa bhikkhuno upāsanaṭṭhānayogapathaṃ sappāyasenāsanaṃ dassento “so vivittaṃ🔽senāsanaṃ bhajatī”tiādimāha. Tattha vivittanti suññaṃ. Seti ceva āsati ca etthāti🔽senāsanaṃ, mañcādi, vihārādi ca. Tenevassa niddese “mañco pīṭha”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evarūpassa bhikkhuno upāsana ṭṭhāna yogapatham sa pāyasena āsanam dassento so vivittam  senāsanam bhajati itiādim āha tattha vivittanti suññam seti ca iva āsati ca ettha ati  senāsanam mañca ādi vihāra ādi ca tena iva assa niddese mañcaḥ pīṭha ntiādi vuttam
translated: Therefore, showing the kind of bhikkhu who should be given a lodging suitable for the practice of devotion, the Exalted One says, “He frequents a solitary bed.”🔽Herein, solitary means empty. A bed is a place for lying down, a couch, etc., and a place for sitting, a chair, etc.🔽That is why in the description of it, the couch and chair, etc., are mentioned.

original: Idāni aññampissa pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ “arañña”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha araññanti vinayapariyāyena🔽tāva ṭhapetvā gāmañca gāmūpacārañca avasesaṃ, suttantapariyāyena ca āraññakaṃ bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: idāni pabhedam dassetum araññanti ādi vuttam tattha araññanti vinaya pariyāyena  tāva ṭhapetvā gāmañca gāmūpacārañca avasesam suttanta pariyāyena ca āraññakam bhikkhum
translated: Now, in order to point out its other divisions, the Exalted One says, “The forest,” etc. Herein, the forest is, according to the Vinaya method,

original: sandhāya pañcadhanusatikaṃ pacchimaṃ araññanti vuttaṃ, abhidhammapariyāyena pana
analyzed: sandhāya pañca dhanusatikam pacchimam araññan ti vuttam abhidhamma pariyāyena pana
translated: everything except the village and the vicinity of the village. According to the Suttanta method, it is the five hundred bow-lengths beyond the village. According to the Abhidhamma method,

original: gāmadvārassa indakhīlato bahi sabbaṃ “arañña”nti gahetabbaṃ. “Nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā”ti
analyzed: gāma dvārassa indakhīlato bahi sabbam araññanti gahetabbam nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā ti
translated: everything outside the village-boundary is the forest. “Having gone outside the village-boundary” is said in the Abhidhamma method.

original: hi vuttaṃ. Kandaranti kaṃ vuccati udakaṃ, tena daritaṃ udakena bhinnaṃ pabbatapadesaṃ,
analyzed: hi vuttam kandaram ti kam vuccati udakam tena daritam udakena bhinnam pabbata padesam
translated: for this is said: “A mountain cleft is a place in a mountain that is split open by water, that is to say, by water that has cut through the rock.

original: yaṃ “nitumba”ntipi “nadīkuñja”ntipi vadanti. Tattha hi rajatapaṭṭasadisavālikāpuline
analyzed: yam vadanti hi rajata paṭṭa sadisa vālikā puline
translated: It is what is called a ‘nitumba’ and a ‘river hollow.’ For there, on a bank of sand like a silver sheet,

original: maṇivitānasadise sandacchāye vanagahane nisīditvā maṇikkhandhasadise udake sandamāne
analyzed: maṇi vitāna sadise sanda chāye vana gahane nisīditvā maṇi kkhandha sadise udake sandamāne
translated: in a wood with a canopy of creepers like a jewelled awning, sitting in a place where water trickles down like a stream of jewels,

original: sītena vātena bījiyamānassa samaṇadhammaṃ karoto cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Giriguhanti
analyzed: sītena vātena bījiyamānassa samaṇa dhammam karotaḥ cittam ekaggam hoti giri guhanti
translated: and fanned by a cool breeze, the mind of one who is practising the spiritual life becomes unified. A mountain cave is

original: dvinnaṃ pabbatānamantaraṃ, ekasmiññeva vā umaṅgasadisaṃ mahāvivaraṃ. Vanapatthanti
analyzed: dvinnam pabbatānam antaram ekasmin ñeva vā umaṅga sadisam mahā vivaram
translated: the space between two rocks or a large opening in one rock like a cave. A forest grove is

original: gāmantaṃ atikkamitvā manussānaṃ anupacāraṭṭhānaṃ, yattha na kasanti na vapanti. Tenevassa
analyzed: gāmantam atikkamitvā manussānam an upacāra ṭhānam yattha na kasanti na vapanti tena iva assa
translated: a place where people do not go for the purpose of recreation, beyond the village boundary, where they do not plough or sow. Accordingly,

original: niddese “vanapatthanti dūrānametaṃ senāsanānaṃ adhivacana”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: niddese vana patthanti dūrānam etam senāsanānam adhivacana ntiādi vuttam
translated: in the description it is said, ‘A forest grove: this is a designation for a remote lodging’ .

original: Abbhokāsanti acchannaṃ. Ākaṅkhamāno panettha cīvarakuṭiṃ katvā vasati. Palālapuñjanti
analyzed: a channam ākaṅkhamānaḥ pana ittha cīvara kuṭim katvā vasati palāla puñjanti
translated: The open air is an uncovered place. But one who wishes to can make a leaf hut and live in that. A heap of grass is

original: palālarāsiṃ. Mahāpalālapuñjato hi palālaṃ nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye karonti,
analyzed: palāla rāsim mahā palāla puñjataḥ hi palālam nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇa sadise ālaye karonti
translated: and a heap of straw. For they make their dwelling in a place like a mountain cave by taking away the straw from a big heap of straw.

original: gacchagumbādīnampi upari palālaṃ pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisīdanti, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Appasaddantiādīsu vacanasaddena virahitattā appasaddaṃ. Nagaranigghosasaddena ceva🔽migapakkhinigghosena ca rahitattā appanigghosaṃ. Vijanavātanti anusañcarakajanassa
analyzed: gaccha gumba ādīnam pi upari palālam pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisīdanti tam sandhāya itam vuttam  appasadda nti ādīsu vacana saddena virahita ttā appasaddam nagara nigghosa saddena ca iva  miga pakkhi nigghosena ca rahita ttā appa nigghosam vijana vātam ti anusañcaraka janassa
translated: They sit down below, having thrown the straw over the top of the trees, creepers, etc., that are there. That is what is meant.🔽It is “secluded” because it is devoid of the sound of speech.🔽It is “undisturbed” because it is devoid of the sound of the noise of a town and the cries of beasts and birds.

original: sarīravātena virahitattā vijanavātaṃ, “vijanavāda”ntipi pāṭho. Senāsanassa anto janavādasaddena🔽rahitanti attho. Manussānaṃ rahassa kiriyārahattā manussarāhasseyyakaṃ, tato tato🔽paṭinivattitvā sammadeva kammaṭṭhāne cittassa līyanato paṭisallānasaṅkhātassa vivekassa
analyzed: sarīra vātena virahita ttā vijana vātam pāṭhaḥ senāsanassa antaḥ janavāda saddena  rahitanti atthaḥ manussānam rahassa kiriyā rahattā manussa rāhasseyyakam tatas tatas  paṭinivattitvā sammat eva kammaṭṭhāne cittassa līyanataḥ paṭisallāna saṅkhātassa vivekassa
translated: It is “remote” because it is devoid of the sound of the wind’s passage when the bodies of people moving about brush against the trees.🔽It is “fit for seclusion” because it is fit for the development of the seclusion called “seclusion of resort” since the mind tends to concentration there, having turned away from here and there.

original: bhāvanārāmassa anurūpattā paṭisallānasāruppaṃ. Bhajatīti sambandho. Araññagatotiādīsu
analyzed: bhāvanā ārāmassa anurūpa ttā paṭisallāna sāruppam bhajati iti sambandhaḥ arañña gataḥ ti ādīsu
translated: The meaning is that it is fit for the development of the seclusion of resort because it is suitable for one who delights in the development of seclusion.🔽In the passages beginning, “Gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty place” ,

original: araññaṃ, rukkhamūlañca ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ sabbampi senāsanaṃ suññāgārena saṅgahitaṃ.🔽Pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvāti samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti
analyzed: araññam rukkha mūlañca ṭhapetvā avasesam sabbam pi senāsanam suññāgārena saṅgahitam  pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ati samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam bandhitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati
translated: Apart from the forest and the foot of a tree, all the rest is called a “vacant dwelling.”🔽“Having folded his legs crosswise”: having bound his legs in the position known as “bound by Nāgas.”

original: uparimakāyaṃ ujuṃ ṭhapetvā, aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā. Evaṃ
analyzed: uparima kāyam ujum ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādetvā evam
translated: “Set his body erect”: having placed the upper body erect.

original: nisinnassa hi cammamaṃsanahārūni na paṇamanti, athassa tesaṃ apaṇamanapaccayā khaṇe
analyzed: nisinnassa hi camma maṃsana hārūni na paṇamanti athassa tesam a paṇamana paccayā khaṇe
translated: For when he sits thus, his skin, flesh and sinews are not bent, and as a result of their not being bent,

original: khaṇe vedanā na uppajjanti, tato cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vuddhiṃ upagacchati.
analyzed: khaṇe vedanāḥ na uppajjanti tatas cittam ekaggam hoti kammaṭṭhānam vuddhim upagacchati
translated: pain does not arise in his body moment after moment, and his mind becomes concentrated and his meditation subject reaches growth.

original: Parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ paṭṭhapetvā, mukhasamīpe🔽vā katvā. Tenevassa niddese “ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā, nāsikagge vā mukhanimitte
analyzed: parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham satim paṭṭhapetvā mukha samīpe  vā katvā tena iva assa niddese ayam sati upaṭṭhitā hoti su upaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukha nimitte
translated: “Having established mindfulness in front of him”: having set up mindfulness facing the meditation subject,🔽or having placed it in front of him.🔽That is why it is said in the description of the meditation subject, “This mindfulness is established , well established, near, one might say, or in front” .

original: vā”ti vuttaṃ. Mukhanimittanti cettha uttaroṭṭhassa vemajjhapadeso, yattha nāsikāvāto
analyzed: vā ti vuttam mukha nimittam ti ca ittha uttara uṭṭhassa vemajjha padesaḥ yattha nāsikā vāto
translated: And here the “sign of the mouth” is the middle of the upper lip, where the nostril-wind

original: paṭihaññati. Atha vā “parīti pariggahaṭṭho, mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho, satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho,
analyzed: paṭihaññati atha vā pari iti pariggaha aṭṭhaḥ mukhanti niyyāna ṭṭhaḥ satī iti upaṭṭhāna ṭṭhaḥ
translated: and it is opposed to that. Or else the meaning here should be regarded as stated in the Paṭisambhidā: “Pari is the meaning of ‘encompassing’; mukha is the meaning of ‘outlet’; sati is the meaning of ‘establishment.’

original: tena vuccati parimukhaṃ sati”nti vaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tena vuccati parimukham satinti vaṃ paṭisambhidā ayam vutta nayena pa ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So it is said: ‘Mindfulness is in the forefront’ ” .

original: Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho “pariggahitaniyyānaṃ satiṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ pariggahita niyyānam satim katvā iti
translated: The meaning in brief here is: “having made mindfulness the outlet that encompasses.”

original: Abhijjhaṃ loketiādīsu abhimukhaṃ jhāyati cintetīti abhijjhā, rāgo. Lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena
analyzed: abhijjham loka iti ādīsu abhimukham jhāyati cinteti iti abhijjhā rāgaḥ lujjana palujjana aṭṭhena
translated: In the case of the passage beginning, “With a mind free from covetousness … he dwells … having removed covetousness from the mind” , covetousness is lust.

original: loko, pañcupādānakkhandhā. Tesu kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambhetvāti attho. Vikkhambhanavaseneva
analyzed: pañca upādānakkhandhā tesu kāmacchandam vikkhambhetvā ti atthaḥ vikkhambhana vasena iva
translated: The world is so called because of the breaking up and falling away of what is born, etc., that is, the five aggregates as objects of clinging. The meaning is: “having suppressed sensual desire for them.”

original: vigatābhijjhena, na cakkhuviññāṇādisadisenāti attho. Cetasāti cittena, itthambhūto🔽viharatīti attho. Abhijjhāyāti abhijjhāto. Cittaṃ parisodhetīti yathā naṃ sā muñcitvā
analyzed: vigata abhijjhena na cakkhu viññāṇa ādi sadisena ati attho cetasā ati cittena ittham bhūtaḥ  viharati iti atthaḥ abhijjhāyāti abhijjhātaḥ cittam parisodheti iti yathā nam sā muñcitvā
translated: He dwells with a mind free from covetousness, not with a mind resembling eye-consciousness, etc.🔽With a mind: with consciousness. The meaning is: “he dwells having become such.”🔽He purifies his mind of covetousness: the meaning is, he liberates his mind from it so that it does not seize it again.

original: na puna gaṇhāti, evaṃ parimocetīti attho. Byāpajjati iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo
analyzed: na puna gaṇhāti evam parimoceti iti atthaḥ byāpajjati iminā cittam pūti kummāsa ādayaḥ
translated: He does not oppress the mind with the mind: he does not afflict the mind with the mind.

original: viya pakatiṃ jahātīti byāpādo. Vikārappattiyā padussati, paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti
analyzed: viya pakatim jahāti iti byāpādaḥ vikāra pattiyā padussati param vā padūseti vināseti iti
translated: and it is as if it has lost its normal condition, thus it is ill will. It is corrupted by the occurrence of corruption, or it corrupts another, it destroys another, thus it is corruption.🔽Both these words are simply synonyms for anger.

original: padoso, ubhayampetaṃ kodhassevādhivacanaṃ. Yasmā cetaṃ sabbakammaṭṭhānasādhāraṇavasena
analyzed: padosaḥ kodhassa iva adhivacanam yasmā ca itam sabba kammaṭṭhāna sādhāraṇa vasena
translated: And since this is taught as common to all meditation subjects,

original: desīyati, tasmā “sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī”ti evaṃ mettāvasena avatvā “abyāpannacitto”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: desīyati tasmā sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī ti evam mettā vasena a vatvā abyāpanna cittaḥ ti ettakam eva vuttam
translated: therefore, instead of saying “abounding in loving-kindness” as in the case of the earth kasiṇa, it is said simply “with a mind unaffected by sensual desire” .🔽Dullness is sluggishness of mind, and drowsiness is sluggishness of consciousness.

original: Thinaṃ cittassa gelaññaṃ, middhaṃ cetasikānaṃ. Ālokasaññīti rattiyampi divāpi diṭṭhaālokasañjānanasaññāya🔽samannāgato, tāya pana ālokasaññāya thinamiddhavinodanassa visesato satisampajaññaṃ
analyzed: thinam cittassa gelaññam middham cetasikānam āloka saññī iti rattiyam pi divā api diṭṭha āloka sañjānana saññāya  samannāgataḥ tāya pana āloka saññāya thinam iddha vinodanassa visesato sati sampajaññam
translated: Perceiving light: he is provided with the perception of light that is seen both by day and by night.

original: icchitabbanti āha “sato sampajāno”ti.🔽Anuddhatoti avikkhitto tathā eva ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto. Tiṇṇavicikicchoti vicikicchaṃ
analyzed: icchitabban ti āha sataḥ sampajānoti  anuddhataḥ ti a vikkhitto tathā eva ajjhattam vūpasanta citto tiṇṇavicikiccho ti vicikiccham
translated: But since mindfulness and full awareness are needed in particular for the dispelling of dullness and drowsiness, he said “mindful and fully aware” .🔽Not floating: not distracted. And in the same way, with consciousness settled inwardly, he is “calm.”🔽Having crossed over doubt: he is established by surmounting doubt.

original: atikkamitvā ṭhito. Akathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjadhammesu “kathaṃ ime,
analyzed: atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ a kathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesu iti anavajja dhammesu katham ime
translated: Not talking idly: he is not talking about what is irrelevant, about “this sort of thing or that sort of thing” .

original: kathaṃ ime”ti evaṃ pavattanato kathaṃkathīsaṅkhātāya vicikicchāya virahito. Evaṃ
analyzed: katham ime iti evam pavattanataḥ kathaṃkathī saṅkhātāya vicikicchāya virahitaḥ evam
translated: “How are they?” — thus he is free from doubt called “perplexity” which occurs in this way.

original: pañcanīvaraṇappahānaṃ dassetvā idāni yasmā appahīnanīvaraṇassa jhānaṃ na uppajjati,
analyzed: pañca nīvaraṇa pahānam dassetvā idāni yasmai appahīna nīvaraṇassa jhānam na uppajjati
translated: Having thus shown the abandoning of the five hindrances, now, since the jhāna does not arise in one who has not abandoned the hindrances,

original: na hi kāmacchandādīhi nānāvisayavikkhittacittaṃ ekattārammaṇe samādhiyati, na kāmadhātusamatikkamanāya🔽vā paṭipajjati, tasmā “so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha soti yo🔽yathāvuttasīlādiguṇe patiṭṭhāya araññādianurūpasenāsanagato attano cariyānukulakammaṭṭhāne
analyzed: na hi kāma chanda ādīhi nānā visaya vikkhitta cittam ekatta ārammaṇe samādhiyati na kāmadhātu samatikkamanāya  vā paṭipajjati tasmā saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya atiādi vuttam tattha saḥ ti yo  yathā vutta sīla ādi guṇe patiṭṭhāya arañña ādi anurūpa senāsana gataḥ cariyā anukula kammaṭṭhāne
translated: for the mind that is distracted to various objects by sensual desire, etc., is not concentrated upon a single object, and it does not enter upon the way to surmounting the sense-sphere existence,

original: līnuddhaccarahitāya sātaccakiriyāya uppāditupacārajjhānena pahīnapañcanīvaraṇo paṭhamajjhānādhigamāya
analyzed: līn uddhacca rahitāya sātacca kiriyāya uppādita upacāra jjhānena pahīna pañca nīvaraṇaḥ paṭhama jhāna adhigamāya
translated: therefore it is said: “Having thus abandoned these five hindrances, which are defilements of the mind and weaken wisdom” . Herein, having thus abandoned: he who, having thus established himself in virtue, etc., and gone to the forest, etc., as a suitable dwelling, and aroused access concentration by means of the way of development that suits his own temperament, and abandoned the five hindrances,

original: vāyamati, soti attho.
analyzed: vāyamati saḥ ti attho
translated: strives for the attainment of the first jhāna, is what is meant.

original: Cetaso upakkileseti cittassa appabhassarabhāvakaraṇe. Paññāya dubbalīkaraṇeti yasmā
analyzed: cetasaḥ upakkilese ti cittassa appabhassara bhāva karaṇe paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe iti yasmā
translated: Defilements of the mind: causes of lack of lucidity in consciousness. Weaken wisdom:

original: ime nīvaraṇā uppajjamānā anuppannāya lokiyalokuttarāya paññāya uppajjituṃ na denti,
analyzed: ime nīvaraṇāḥ uppajjamānāḥ anuppannāya lokiya lokuttarāya paññāya uppajjitum na denti
translated: These hindrances, when they arise, do not allow mundane and supramundane understanding that has not arisen to arise.

original: uppannāya pana lokiyaaṭṭhasamāpattiyā, abhiññābhūtāya vā mūlaṃ upacchinditvā pātenti,
analyzed: uppannāya pana lokiya aṭṭha samāpattiyā abhiññā bhūtāya vā mūlam upacchinditvā pātenti
translated: But when mundane understanding consisting in the eight meditative attainments has arisen, or when direct-knowledge has arisen, they destroy the root of it and make it fall away.🔽That is why they are called “weaknesses of understanding.”

original: tasmā “paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā”ti vuccanti. Vivicceva kāmehītiādīsu kāmehīti vatthukāmakilesakāmehi.
analyzed: tasmā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ti vuccanti vivicca iva kāmehi itiādīsu kāmehi iti vatthu kāma kilesa kāmehi
translated: In the passage beginning, “Quite secluded from sense desires” , sense desires are sense-desire objects and the defilements of sense desire.🔽Quite secluded from : having secluded oneself, having become secluded, having gone away from, is the meaning.

original: Viviccevāti viviccitvā vinā hutvā, apakkamitvāti attho. Niyamatthena panettha eva-kārena
analyzed: vivicca iva ati viviccitvā vinā hutvā apakkamitvā iti atthaḥ niyama atthena pana ittha evakārena
translated: But the word eva here has the meaning of a negative particle.

original: jhānapaṭipakkhabhūtānaṃ kāmānaṃ pariccāgeneva paṭhamajjhānādhigamo, andhakārapariccāgeneva
analyzed: jhāna paṭipakkha bhūtānam kāmānam pariccāgena iva paṭhamajjhāna adhigamaḥ andhakāra pariccāgena iva
translated: It shows that the first jhāna is reached only by giving up sense desires, which are opposed to it, just as the light of a lamp appears only when the darkness has been given up.

original: dīpappavatti viyāti dasseti. Uttarapadepi cesa eva-kāro ānetvā “vivicceva akusalehi
analyzed: dīpa ppavatti viyā ti dasseti uttara pade pi ca isaḥ eva kāraḥ ānetvā vivicca iva akusalehi
translated: And the word eva should be brought over from the first part of the compound and construed with the second part thus: “Quite secluded from unprofitable things” .

original: dhammehī”ti sambandhitabbo. Na hi sakkā kāmato aññehi nīvaraṇasaṅkhātehi akusaladhammehi
analyzed: dhammehi iti sambandhitabbaḥ na hi sakkā kāmataḥ aññehi nīvaraṇa saṅkhātehi akusala dhammehi
translated: For it is not possible to give up sense desires and then to give up the unprofitable things consisting in the hindrances, which are different from sense desires, and then to reach the first jhāna.

original: aviviccāpi jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ. Padadvayepi pana “viviccā”ti iminā kāyavivekādīsu,
analyzed: a vivicca api jhānam upasampajja viharitum pada dvaye pi pana vivicca ati iminā kāya viveka ādīsu
translated: and to enter upon and abide in jhāna without seclusion.🔽But in both phrases ‘secluded’ is intended here in the sense of all kinds of seclusion, that is to say,

original: tadaṅgavivekādīsu ca tadaṅganissaraṇavivekavajjitā sabbepi vivekā idha adhippetā.
analyzed: tad aṅga viveka ādīsu ca tad aṅga nissaraṇa viveka vajjitā sabbe api vivekā idha adhippetā
translated: seclusion of body, etc., and seclusion of the kinds beginning with that due to destruction of lust, except for seclusion of the kinds beginning with that due to surmounting of perceptions.

original: Vatthukāmavivekavacanato hi kāyaviveko vutto, kilesakāmehi pana sesākusalehi ca vivekavacanato
analyzed: vatthu kāma viveka vacanataḥ hi kāya vivekaḥ vutto kilesa kāmehi pana sesa akusalehi ca viveka vacanato
translated: For seclusion of body is stated as seclusion from sense desires, which are things consisting in gross physical matter.🔽But seclusion of cognizance and seclusion of cognizance’s support are stated as seclusion from the remaining kinds of unprofitable things beginning with lust, and as seclusion from the kinds of seclusion beginning with that due to surmounting of perceptions.

original: cittaupadhivivekā, vikkhambhanādivivekā ca vuttā. Lokuttarajjhānampi saṅgahitattā
analyzed: citta aupadhi vivekā vikkhambhana ādi vivekā ca vuttā lokuttara jhānam pi saṅgahita ttā
translated: And the supramundane jhāna is also included.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evametena padadvayena yathākkamaṃ kāmacchandanīvaraṇasesanīvaraṇavikkhambhanādiko
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam evam etena pada dvayena yathākkamam kāmacchanda nīvaraṇa sesa nīvaraṇa vikkhambhana ādikaḥ
translated: So in the first place the two phrases refer respectively to the kinds of seclusion beginning with that due to surmounting of perceptions and that due to surmounting of lust.

original: vutto. Evaṃ oghādīsupi yathārahaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttaḥ evam ogha ādīsu pi yathāraham yojetabbam
translated: And so too in the case of the floods, etc., the two phrases should be construed as appropriate.

original: Ettāvatā ca paṭhamassa jhānassa pahānaṅgaṃ dassetvā idāni sampayogaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca paṭhamassa jhānassa pahāna aṅgam dassetvā idāni sampayoga aṅgam dassetuṃ
translated: So far, having shown the first jhāna’s renunciation-factor, he now shows its association-factor,

original: “savitakkaṃ savicāra”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha vitakkena ca vicārena ca saha vattati
analyzed: sa vitakkam sa vicāra ntiādi vuttam tattha vitakkena ca vicārena ca saha vattati
translated: saying ‘accompanied by thought and by exploration’ . Herein, it occurs together with thought and with exploration,

original: rukkho viya pupphena, phalena cāti idaṃ jhānaṃ “savitakkaṃ savicāra”nti vuccati.
analyzed: rukkhaḥ viya pupphena phalena ca ati idam jhānam sa vitakkam sa vicāran ti vuccati
translated: Like a tree with flowers and fruits, this jhāna is called “accompanied by thought and examination” .

original: Vivekajanti ettha vivitti viveko, nīvaraṇavigamoti attho. Vivittoti vā viveko, nīvaraṇavivitto
analyzed: viveka janti ettha vivitti vivekaḥ nīvaraṇa vigamo ti attho vivitto ti vā vivekaḥ nīvaraṇa vivitto
translated: “Born of seclusion”: here seclusion is absence of hindrances; the meaning is, disappearance of hindrances. Or alternatively, seclusion is secluded; the meaning is, secluded from hindrances.

original: jhānasampayuttadhammarāsīti attho, tasmā vivekato, tasmiṃ vā viveke jātanti vivekajaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna sampayutta dhamma rāsi iti attho tasmā vivekato tasmin vā viveke viveka jam
translated: The meaning is, a mass of jhāna factors. Therefore born of seclusion, or born in that seclusion.

original: Pītisukhanti ettha pītīti appanāppattā pharaṇāpīti, sukhañca taṃsampayuttaṃ, iti🔽ayañca pīti idañca sukhaṃ assa jhānassa, asmiṃ vā atthīti idaṃ jhānaṃ “pītisukha”nti
analyzed: pīti sukham ti ettha pīti iti appanā appattā pharaṇā api iti sukham ca tad sampayuttam iti  ayam ca pīti idam ca sukham assa jhānassa asmim vā atthi iti idam jhānam pīti sukhanti
translated: “Rapture and pleasure”: here the rapture is the pervading rapture that has reached absorption; the pleasure is associated with that.🔽So this rapture and this pleasure are in this jhāna, or it has these, thus it is called “accompanied by rapture and pleasure” .

original: vuccati. Atha vā pīti ca sukhañca pītisukhaṃ, vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ assa, asmiṃ vāti🔽vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ, evaṃ ekapadavasena “vivekajapītisukha”nti vattabbe niggahītāgamaṃ
analyzed: vuccati atha vā pīti ca sukham ca pīti sukham viveka jam pīti sukham assa asmin vāti  viveka jam pīti sukham evam eka pada vasena viveka ja pīti sukhanti vattabbe niggahīta āgamam
translated: Or alternatively, the rapture and the pleasure are rapture and pleasure; the meaning is, they are born of seclusion. They are in this , thus it is called “born of seclusion and accompanied by rapture and pleasure” .🔽Although it should be said “born of seclusion, rapture, and pleasure” as a compound of three terms, still, by construing the word “seclusion” with the compound “rapture and pleasure,” it is proper to say “born of seclusion, rapture, and pleasure” as a compound of two terms only.

original: katvā “vivekajaṃ pītisukha”ntipi vattuṃ yujjati. Yatheva hi jhānaṃ, evaṃ pītisukhampi
analyzed: katvā viveka jam pīti sukham ti api vattum yujjati yathā iva hi jhānam evam pīti sukham pi
translated: For just as the jhāna is called “accompanied by rapture and pleasure” as a compound of two terms although it is accompanied by thought, etc.,

original: vivekajameva hotīti. Paṭhamaṃ jhānanti gaṇanānupubbato paṭhamaṃ, paṭhamaṃ uppattitopi
analyzed: viveka jam eva hoti iti paṭhamam jhānanti gaṇanā anupubbato paṭhamam paṭhamam uppattitaḥ pi
translated: it is only the kind of happiness that is born of seclusion. The first jhana: it is the first in the numerical sense, and also it is the first for one who gives attention to the signs of elements in the way beginning “The earth element has the characteristic of hardness” .

original: paṭhamaṃ. Ārammaṇūpanijjhānato, paccanīkajhāpanato vā jhānaṃ, iminā nayena upari
analyzed: paṭhamam ārammaṇa upanijjhānataḥ paccanīka jhāpanataḥ vā jhānam iminā nayena upari
translated: It is jhana in the sense of the usual meaning of the word, and also in the sense of driving away the hindrances, and so on.

original: “dutiyaṃ jhāna”ntiādīsu attho veditabbo. Upasampajja viharatīti evaṃ pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam jhānan ti ādīsu attho veditabbo upasampajja viharati iti evam pañcaṅga vippahīnam
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in each instance in the text beginning “The second jhana … ” .

original: pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ tividhakalyāṇaṃ dasalakkhaṇasampannaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ adhigantvā
analyzed: pañcaṅga samannāgatam tividha kalyāṇam dasa lakkhaṇa sampannam paṭhamam jhānam adhigantvā
translated: He enters upon and dwells in: having thus reached the first jhana, which surmounts the hindrances and possesses the five factors, which is of the level of the first jhana, and is good in the three ways, he enters upon and dwells in it by means of the progress and the abiding described under the first jhana .

original: tadanurūpena iriyāpathavihārena pavattatīti attho. Ettha ca cittekaggatā kiñcāpi🔽“savitakkasavicāra”nti imasmiṃ pāṭhe na niddiṭṭhā, tathāpi vibhaṅge “jhānanti vitakko🔽vicāro pīti sukhaṃ cittassekaggatā”ti vuttattā aṅgameva.
analyzed: tad anurūpena iriyāpatha vihārena pavattati iti attho ettha ca citta ekagga tā kiñcā api  imasmin pāṭhe na niddiṭṭhā tathā api vibhaṅge vitakko  vicāraḥ pi iti sukham cittassa ekagga tā ti vutta ttā aṅgam eva
translated: And here, although unification of mind is not mentioned in the description of the second jhana, etc., nevertheless it is present there too,🔽and so the jhanas should be understood as possessing the five factors in each case.

original: Evaṃ paṭhamajjhānādhigamaṃ dassetvā idāni tadanantaraṃ adhigatapaṭhamajjhānassa taṃ
analyzed: evam paṭhama jhāna adhigamam dassetvā idāni tad anantaram adhigata paṭhama jhānassa tam
translated: Having thus shown the attainment of the first jhana, he now shows the development of the first jhana next to which the second is described, and the way in which it is next to it.

original: āvajjanasamāpajjanavuṭṭhānādhiṭṭhānapaccavekkhaṇasaṅkhātāhi pañcahi vasīhi vasībhūtaṃ🔽katvā tato vuṭṭhāya tattha āsannanīvaraṇapaccatthikatāya ceva oḷārikavitakkavicārakkhobhasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: āvajjana samāpajjana vuṭṭhāna adhiṭṭhāna paccavekkhaṇa saṅkhātāhi pañcahi vasīhi vasībhūtam  katvā tatas vuṭṭhāya tattha āsanna nīvaraṇa paccatthika tāya ca iva oḷārika vitakka vicāra khobha samaṅgi tāya
translated: and he has mastered it by means of the five ways of exercising mastery, that is to say, by exercising mastery in entering upon it, in resolving , in emerging from it, in attending to it, and in transforming it.🔽Then, after emerging from it, he sees the danger in it because of the nearness of the hindrances and because of the grossness of applied thought and sustained thought,

original: ca dosaṃ disvā nikantiṃ pariyādāya vitakkādibhedoḷārikaṅgappahānāya, pītiādisantaṅgapaṭilābhāya
analyzed: ca dosam disvā nikantim pariyādāya vitakka ādi bheda uḷārika aṅga pahānāya pīti ādi santaṅga paṭilābhāya
translated: and he abandons liking for it and he gives his attention again and again to that same meditation subject in order to abandon the gross factors beginning with applied thought and in order to obtain the peaceful factors beginning with happiness.

original: ca tadeva kammaṭṭhānaṃ punappunaṃ manasikaroto dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ uppajjati, tappādakañca
analyzed: ca tat eva kammaṭṭhānam punappunam manasikarotaḥ dutiyam jhānam uppajjati tad pādakam ca
translated: So the second jhāna arises in him in the same way as the first.

original: lokuttarajjhānaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānena dassetuṃ “vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha vūpasamāti samatikkamā, dutiyajjhānakkhaṇe apātubhāvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Ajjhattanti
analyzed: lokuttara jhānam puggala adhiṭṭhānena dassetum vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ti ādim āha  tattha vūpasamā ti samatikkamā dutiya jjhāna kkhaṇe apātubhāvā ti vuttam hoti ajjhattam
translated: And in order to show the supramundane second jhāna that is formed with that as its counterpart, he said “With the stilling of applied and sustained thought” .🔽Herein, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought: with the surmounting of applied and sustained thought; at the moment of the second jhāna these are stilled, ceased, sur­mounted. Inwardly: internally.

original: attani jātaṃ, attasantāne nibbattanti attho. Sampasādananti saddhāsaṅkhātasampasādanayogato
analyzed: attani jātam atta santāne nibbattanti attho sampasādananti saddhā saṅkhāta sampasādana yogato
translated: Quite secluded from sense desires and secluded from unprofitable things: this is said in order to show the condition for the arising of the second jhāna. For this jhāna arises quite secluded from sense desires and quite secluded from the hindrances that are unprofitable. Tranquil: peaceful, in virtue of the stilling of the disturbance of applied and sustained thought.

original: jhānampi sampasādanaṃ nīlavaṇṇayogato nīlavatthaṃ viya. Ekodibhāvanti ettha vitakkavicārehi
analyzed: jhānam pi sampasādanam nīla vaṇṇa yogataḥ nīlavattham viya eka udi bhāvanti ettha vitakka vicārehi
translated: and the jhāna is the confidence in that, as cloth is the confidence in the colour of blue.🔽“Unification of mind” : here it is the unification by means of applied and sustained thought that is called “unification of mind” .

original: anajjhāruḷhattā eko aggo seṭṭho udetīti ekodi, samādhi. Taṃ bhāveti vaḍḍhetīti dutiyajjhānaṃ🔽ekodibhāvaṃ. So panāyaṃ ekodi yasmā cetaso, na sattassa, na jīvassa, tasmā etaṃ “cetaso
analyzed: an ajjhāruḷha ttā ekaḥ aggo seṭṭhaḥ udeti iti ekodi tam bhāveti vaḍḍheti iti dutiya jhānam  ekodi bhāvam saḥ pana ayam ekodi yasmai cetasaḥ na sattassa na jīvassa tasmai etam cetasaḥ
translated: That he develops, makes much of, is the second jhāna.🔽“Unification of mind” : this unification of mind is the best, the foremost, the highest, the chief, the most excellent, the sublime, the unsurpassed, the hard to equal, the matchless, the incomparable, the unique, the unequalled, the one that is not shared by ordinary people.

original: ekodibhāva”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: eka udi bhāvan ti vuttam
translated: But this unification of mind is not of a being or a living being or a person, and so it is said that it is “unification of mind.”

original: Nanu cāyaṃ saddhā paṭhamajjhānepi atthi, ayañca ekodināmako samādhi, atha kasmā idameva
analyzed: nanu ca ayam paṭhama jhāne pi atthi ayam ca ekodi nāmakaḥ atha kasmai idam eva
translated: But is not faith also present in the first jhāna, and is not this concentration called unification of mind there too? If so, why is it said only of the second jhāna that it possesses faith and unification of mind?

original: evaṃ vuttanti? Vuccate – imasmiñhi jhāne vitakkavicārakkhobhābhāvena balavatī saddhā,🔽samādhi ca, tasmā idameva evaṃ vuttanti. Avitakkaṃ avicāranti bhāvanāya pahīnattā
analyzed: evam vuttam ti vuccate imasmin hi jhāne vitakka vicāra khobha abhāvena balavatī saddhā  ca tasmai idam eva evam vuttam iti a vitakkam a vicāranti bhāvanāya pahīna ttā
translated: It is said in order to show the particular and specific conditions for the arising of the jhāna. For this jhāna arises with the faith and the unification of mind that are stronger than those in the first jhāna.🔽That is why it is said only of the second jhāna that it possesses faith and unification of mind.🔽“Without applied thought, without sustained thought” : applied thought and sustained thought are absent in this jhāna;

original: natthi etasmiṃ, etassa vā vitakko vicāro, na tatiyajjhānādi viya, cakkhuviññāṇādi
analyzed: na atthi etasmin etassa vā vitakkaḥ vicāraḥ na tatiya jhāna ādi viya cakkhu viññāṇa ādi
translated: or it is free from applied thought and sustained thought, unlike the first jhāna, etc., and eye-consciousness, etc.

original: viya ca abhāvappattito, tasmā imassa “vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti idaṃ kāraṇavacananti🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Samādhijanti paṭhamajjhānasamādhito, sampayuttasamādhito vā jātaṃ, vitakkādikkhobhābhāvena
analyzed: ca abhāva ppattitaḥ tasmai imassa vitakka vicārānam idam kāraṇa vacanan ti  daṭṭhabbam samādhi janti paṭhama jhāna samādhitaḥ sampayutta samādhitaḥ vā jātam vitakka ādi khobha abhāvena
translated: So this phrase “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” should be regarded as a statement of the cause.🔽Born of concentration: born of the first-jhāna concentration or associated with the first-jhāna concentration.🔽It is said to be “born of concentration” in order to show that it is the state of consciousness that is called “concentration” and that the state of consciousness born of that and associated with it is “born of concentration.”

original: cetassa vaṇṇabhaṇanatthaṃ idameva “samādhija”nti vuttaṃ. Upasampajja viharatīti evaṃ
analyzed: cetassa vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham idam eva samādhi janti vuttam upasampajja viharati iti evam
translated: Enters upon and dwells in: here it is the attainment that is called “entering upon” and the actual dwelling in that attainment that is called “dwelling in it.”

original: duvaṅgavippahīnaṃ tivaṅgasamannāgataṃ tividhakalyāṇādiyuttaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ adhigantvā
analyzed: duvaṅga vippahīnam tivaṅga samannāgatam tividha kalyāṇa ādi yuttam dutiyam jhānam adhigantvā
translated: Having reached the second jhāna, which is of the same kind as the first jhāna but distinguished by the abandoning of two factors, possession of two factors, and the rest,

original: vuttanayena vattatīti attho.🔽Evaṃ dutiyajjhānādhigamaṃ dassetvā idāni tadanantaraṃ adhigatadutiyajjhānassa taṃ🔽vuttanayeneva vasībhūtaṃ katvā tattha āsannavitakkavicārapaccatthikatāya ceva oḷārikapītaṅgasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: vutta nayena vattati iti atthaḥ  evam dutiya jhāna adhigamam dassetvā idāni tad anantaram adhigata dutiya jhānassa tam  vutta nayena iva vasībhūtam katvā tattha āsanna vitakka vicāra paccatthika tāya ca iva oḷārika pītaṅga samaṅgi tāya
translated: he enters upon and dwells in it, is the meaning.🔽Having thus shown the attaining of the second jhāna, he now shows the surmounting of it in the way already described, saying, “When he … surmounts … applied thought and sustained thought” .🔽Having thus become surmounter of the second jhāna in the way already described, seeing its grossness in the way already described, and perceiving its stilling, he attains the third jhāna … in the way already described.

original: ca dosaṃ disvā nikantiṃ pariyādāya tadoḷārikaṅgappahānāya sesasantaṅgapaṭilābhāya
analyzed: ca dosam disvā nikantim pariyādāya tad oḷārika aṅga pahānāya sesa santaṅga paṭilābhāya
translated: Having thus become surmounter of the third jhāna in the way already described, seeing its grossness in the way already described, and perceiving the stilling of the gross factor in the third jhāna, that is to say, the factor of happiness, and perceiving the absence of affliction in the remaining factor, that is to say, the remaining factor of equanimity, he attains the fourth jhāna … in the way already described.

original: tadevārammaṇaṃ punappunaṃ manasikaroto tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ uppajjati, tappādakañca lokuttaraṃ,
analyzed: tat eva ārammaṇam punappunam manasikarotaḥ tatiyam jhānam uppajjati tad pādakam ca lokuttaram
translated: When he again and again brings that same object to mind, the third jhāna arises in him in the way already described, and also the supramundane jhāna that has that as its proximate cause.🔽In order to point out that jhāna he says: “With the fading away of happiness as well he dwells in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, he experiences pleasure with the body; he enters upon and dwells in the third jhāna, …” Herein, fading away of happiness is viraga;

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “pītiyā ca virāgā”tiādimāha. Tattha virajjanaṃ virāgo, samatikkamo,🔽tasmā virāgā. Ca-kārena vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamaṃ sampiṇḍeti “pītiyā ca virāgā,
analyzed: tam dassetum pītiyā ca virāga ati ādim āha tattha virajjanam virāgaḥ samatikkamaḥ  cakārena
translated: it is the fading away, the abandoning, the casting out, the expunging, the state of no longer doing, of that happiness.🔽So with the fading away of happiness as well he dwells in equanimity: he dwells in equanimity about the abandoning of that happiness.🔽The word “as well” includes the stilling of applied and sustained thought.🔽This is said in order to point out the path to the third jhāna and to recommend it.

original: vitakkavicārānañca vūpasamā”ti. Idañcetassa āgamanamaggaparidīpanatthaṃ, vaṇṇabhaṇanatthañca
analyzed: vitakka vicārā anañca vūpasamā ti idam cetassa āgamana magga paridīpana attham vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham ca
translated: He experiences pleasure with the body: here “pleasure” is the pleasure called “of the third jhāna” .🔽He experiences that by making it his object, he makes it the province of his consciousness, is what is meant.

original: vuttaṃ. Upekkhako viharatīti ettha upapattito ikkhati apakkhapatitā hutvā passatīti🔽upekkhā, tatramajjhattatā. Tāya visadāya pītivirāgapadaṭṭhānāya thāmagatāya samannāgatattā
analyzed: vuttam upekkhakaḥ viharati iti ettha upapattitaḥ ikkhati apakkha pati tā hutvā passati iti  upekkhā tatram ajjhatta tā tāya visadāya pīti virāga padaṭṭhānāya thāma gatāya samannāgata ttā
translated: He dwells in equanimity: here “equanimity” is non-partisan impartiality.🔽He is said to “dwell in equanimity” because he possesses that equanimity which is purified by the surmounting of happiness and which is the footing for the third jhāna.

original: tatiyajjhānasamaṅgī “upekkhako”ti vuccati, vitakkādikkhobhābhāvena panesā ettheva🔽paribyattakiccā jātā, na paṭhamajjhānādīsūti. Sato ca sampajānoti puggalādhiṭṭhānena
analyzed: tatiya jhāna samaṅgī upekkhako ti vuccati vitakka ādi khobha abhāvena pana esā ettha eva 🔽paribyatta kiccāḥ jātāḥ na paṭhama jhāna ādīsu iti sataḥ ca sampajānoti puggala adhiṭṭhānena
translated: But it is only in this third jhāna that equanimity is found in its specifically technical sense of “onlooking” , since that is where it is first effective in causing the onlooking by surmounting the pleasure.

original: sati ca sampajaññañca vuttaṃ, idañca satisampajaññabaleneva ṭhitaṃ taṃpītisahacaritaṃ🔽sukhaṃ, tato apanītaṃ vaccho viya bandhanabalena dhenuṃ pītiṃ na upagacchati, imasmiñca🔽sati atimadhure sukhe yogino na sārajjanti, no aññathāti imampi atthavisesaṃ dassetuṃ🔽idheva vuttanti veditabbaṃ. translated: and the supramundane fourth jhāna, which is the footing for the reviewing knowledge, arises in him. Herein, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain is with the abandoning of bodily pleasure and pain. Previously: before the arising of the fourth jhāna. This is the meaning. With the disappearance of former gladness and sadness: with the previous abandoning of mental pleasure and pain.

original: hi yathākkamaṃ paṭhamādicatunnaṃ jhānānaṃ upacārakkhaṇe eva pahīyanti. Yadi evaṃ,
analyzed: hi yathākkamam paṭhama ādi catunnam jhānānam upacāra kkhaṇe eva pahīyanti yadi evam
translated: But when is their abandoning? At the moment of access of the four jhānas. translated: But why is cessation stated only in the jhānas in the way beginning, “With the abandoning of pleasure and pain” and “With the abandoning of happiness and sadness” , and so on? —Because it is a special cessation.

original: Upacārakkhaṇesu hi yo nirodho, so nirodho eva, nātisayanirodho, so pana jhānakkhaṇesu

analyzed: eva tatas eva hi tattha tattha aparisesa ggahaṇam tattha tattha pana pahīnā api  etāḥ vedanāḥ ettha du viññeyya lakkhaṇāya adukkham asukhāya vedanāya dukkha ādi byatirekena
translated: That is why the words “without remainder” are used in each case.

original: sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ, vaṇṇabhaṇanatthañcassa jhānassa samāhaṭā, paccayadassanatthañcassa.

analyzed: yathā āha cattāro kho āvuso paccayāḥ adukkhamasukhāya cetas vimuttiyā samāpattiyā

translated: The meaning is that he abides in the posture appropriate to it.🔽Having thus shown the fourth jhana of the fine-material sphere that transcends the world, he now began the explanation of the immaterial jhanas, saying “He directs it to the base consisting of boundless space” .

original: yaṃ tattha paṭhamaṃ, evaṃ adhigatarūpāvacaracatutthajjhānassa karajarūpe daṇḍādānādīnañceva
analyzed: yam tattha paṭhamam evam adhigata rūpāvacara catuttha jhānassa kara ja rūpe
