Of perceptions of matter: of the fifteen perceptions of the fine-material sphere, namely, the five profitable, the five unprofitable, and the five functional, which are called “perceptions” because they are arrived at by perceiving,

original: rūpanti saññā nāmamassāti “rūpasañña”nti vuccati. Samatikkamāti virāgā, nirodhā ca.
analyzed: rūpam ti saññā nāmam assa ati rūpa saññanti vuccati samatikkamā ati virāgā nirodhā ca
translated: and also of the fine-material jhānas themselves, for the fine-material jhāna too is called “perception of matter” in the sense of “perception arrived at by perceiving matter.” And also the kasiṇa as object of the jhāna is called “perception of matter” in the sense of “name for matter” .🔽Surmounting: by dispassion, by surmounting, and also by substitution of opposite states.

original: Vibhaṅge pana saññāsu samatikkantāsu ārammaṇaṃ samatikkantameva hotīti “samāpannassa
analyzed: vibhaṅge pana saññāsu samatikkantāsu ārammaṇam samatikkantam eva hoti iti samāpannassa
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga the surmounting of perception is stated thus: “When perception is surmounted, the object is surmounted too” .

original: vā upapannassa vā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārissa vā”tiādinā saññānameva samatikkamo vutto,
analyzed: vā upapannassa vā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārissa vā iti ādinā saññānam eva samatikkamaḥ vutto
translated: And it is said: “in one who has entered upon the jhāna, or in one who has been reborn in the fine-material sphere and is experiencing the happiness of rebirth-linking” .

original: ārammaṇe avirattassa saññāsamatikkamo natthevāti taṃ samatikkamavasenāpi atthavaṇṇanā kātabbāva.
analyzed: ārammaṇe avirattassa saññā samatikkamo nattha iva ati tam samatikkama vasena api attha vaṇṇanā kātabbā ava
translated: But there is no surmounting of perception in one who is not surmounting the object. So the commentary should be understood to be given according to the surmounting of the object.

original: Paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamāti cakkhādīnaṃ vatthūnaṃ, rūpādīnañca ārammaṇānaṃ paṭighātena🔽samuppannā dvipañcaviññāṇasaññā paṭighasaññā, tāsaṃ atthaṅgamā. Kiñcāpi tā rūpāvacarajjhānasamāpannassāpi
analyzed: paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā ti cakkha ādīnam vatthūnam rūpa ādīnam ca ārammaṇānam paṭighātena  samuppannā dvi pañca viññāṇa saññā paṭigha saññā tāsam atthaṅgamā kiñcā api tāḥ rūpāvacara jhāna samāpannassa api
translated: With the cessation of perceptions of impingement: the perceptions of the five-door and mind-door adverting, which arise with impingement on the physical basis consisting of the eye, etc., and on the objects consisting of visible data, etc., are called “perceptions of impingement.”

original: na santi, atha kho na pahīnattā na santi. Na hi rūpavirāgāya rūpāvacarabhāvanā saṃvattati,
analyzed: na santi atha kho na pahīna ttāḥ na santi na hi rūpa virāgāya rūpāvacara bhāvanā saṃvattati
translated: Though these are absent in one who has entered upon the fine-material jhāna, still they are not “surmounted” by him, because they have not been abandoned. For the development of the fine-material jhāna does not lead to the abandoning of the perceptions of the kinds of sense-desire,🔽but rather to the abandoning of the perceptions of visible data, etc., which are the cause of the former.

original: rūpāyattāva etāsaṃ pavatti, ayaṃ pana bhāvanā rūpavirāgāya saṃvattati, tasmā tā ettha
analyzed: etāsam pavatti ayam pana bhāvanā rūpa virāgāya saṃvattati tasmāt tāḥ ettha
translated: But this development of the immaterial jhāna does lead to the abandoning of the perceptions of visible data, etc.,

original: pahīnāti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārāti nānatte gocare pavattānaṃ,
analyzed: pahīnā iti vattum vaṭṭati nānatta saññānam amanasikārā ati nānatte gocare pavattānam
translated: Disregard of perceptions of variety: of perceptions occurring in a varied field,

original: nānattānaṃ vā manoviññāṇadhātuvasena pavattānañca catucattālīsakāmāvacarasaññānaṃ🔽amanasikārā anāvajjanā. Ettha ca rūpapaṭighasaññānaṃ iminā jhānena nibbattabhavepi
analyzed: nānattānam vā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu vasena pavattānam ca catucattālīsa kāmāvacara saññānam  amanasikārāḥ anāvajjanāḥ ettha ca rūpa paṭigha saññānam iminā jhānena nibbatta bhave pi
translated: or of the forty-four kinds of sense-desire perceptions occurring as the mind-consciousness element,

original: anuppattito “samatikkamā atthaṅgamā”ti evaṃ abhāvo eva vutto. “Nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā”ti🔽aṭṭhakāmāvacarakusalānaṃ navakiriyānaṃ dasākusalānaṃ vasena sattavīsatisaññānaṃ arūpabhavepi
analyzed: anuppattitaḥ samatikkamā atthaṅgamā ati evam abhāvaḥ eva vuttaḥ nānatta saññānam a manasikārā ti  aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusalānam nava kiriyānam dasa akusalānam vasena sattavīsati saññānam arūpa bhave pi
translated: because they do not occur in the existence produced by this jhāna, their non-existence is stated thus “with the surmounting of perceptions of variety” .

original: manasikārena uppattisambhavato tāsaṃ amanasikārā icceva vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: manasikārena uppatti sambhavato tāsam amanasikārāḥ icca eva vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: And here “disregard” should be understood as non-attention, since it is impossible for perceptions to be disregarded by being given attention.

original: Ananto ākāsoti ettha nāssa uppādanto vā vayanto vā paññāyatīti ananto. Ākāsoti kasiṇugghāṭimākāso
analyzed: anantaḥ ākāso ti ettha na assa uppādantaḥ vā vayantaḥ vā paññāyati iti anantaḥ ākāso ti kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsaḥ
translated: “Endless space”: there is no end to it, thus it is endless . What is meant is that it has no end or boundary. “Space” is what is called the “sign of space” .🔽Herein, the endlessness should be understood as the object of jhāna;

original: vuccati, manasikāravasenapettha anantatā veditabbā. Teneva vibhaṅge vuttaṃ “tasmiṃ
analyzed: vuccati manasikāra vasena pa ittha ananta tā veditabbā tena iva vibhaṅge vuttam tasmin
translated: for that is said in the Vibhaṅga: “It is endless, thus it is infinite ;

original: ākāse cittaṃ ṭhapeti…pe… anantaṃ pharati, tena vuccati ananto ākāso”ti. Idaṃ panassa
analyzed: ākāse cittam ṭhapeti pe anantam pharati tena vuccati ananto ākāso ti idam panassa
translated: he places his cognizance on space … he pervades it, hence ‘infinite space’ is said.🔽

original: bhāvanākāradassanaṃ. Ākāsānañcāyatananti ettha nāssa antoti anantaṃ ākāsameva anantaṃ🔽ākāsānantaṃ, ākāsānantameva ākāsānañcaṃ, tadeva ākāsānañcaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena, sañjātisamosaraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhāvanā ākāra dassanam ākāsa anañcāyatananti ettha na assa antaḥ iti anantam ākāsam eva anantam  ākāsa anantam ākāsa anantam eva ākāsa ānañcam tat eva ākāsa ānañcam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sañjāti samosaraṇa ṭṭhena
translated: He places his cognizance on space, he pervades the extent of space, he sees the extent of space as infinite. Hence ‘ infinite space ’ is said. This is the way he sees the development of the jhana. As to the words the base consisting of infinite space, there is no end to it thus it is infinite . Space itself is infinite ,🔽and that is the base consisting of infinite space . That is the jhana’s object in the sense of physical basis and in the sense of proximate cause ,

original: ca āyatanaṃ, taṃ ārammaṇamassa sasampayuttadhammassa jhānassāti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: ca āyatanam tam ārammaṇam assa sa sampayutta dhammassa jhānassa ati ākāsānañcāyatanam
translated: and it is the jhana itself since it is what jhans or meditates on that object, thus it is the base consisting of infinite space.

original: Taṃ upasampajja vuttanayena viharatīti attho.🔽Evaṃ ākāsānañcāyatanādhigamaṃ dassetvā idāni yaṃ tadanantaraṃ adhigatapaṭhamāruppassa🔽taṃ vasībhūtaṃ katvā tattha āsannarūpajjhānapaccatthikatāya, rūpapaṭibhāgākāsārammaṇatāya
analyzed: tam upasampajja vutta nayena viharati iti attho  evam ākāsa anañcāyatana adhigamam dassetvā idāni yam tad anantaram adhigata paṭhama āruppassa  tam vasībhūtam katvā tattha āsanna rūpa jjhāna paccatthika tāya rūpa paṭibhāga ākāsa ārammaṇa tāya
translated: The meaning is that he enters upon and dwells in that jhana.🔽Having thus shown the attainment of the base consisting of infinite space, he now shows the attainment of the base consisting of infinite consciousness, which comes next after that, by the words He directs his cognizance beyond the cognizance associated with the base consisting of infinite space and he cognizes ‘ There is nothing ’.

original: ca dosaṃ disvā nikantiṃ pariyādāya taṃ samatikkamāya ākāsaṃ pharitvā pavattaṃ viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: ca dosam disvā nikantim pariyādāya tam samatikkamāya ākāsam pharitvā pavattam viññāṇam
translated: Having made that jhana familiar to him in this way, seeing danger in the base consisting of infinite space because it is the proximate cause for the occurrence of the material-form element, and perceiving the base consisting of infinite consciousness as a refuge, he surmounts the base consisting of infinite space. Then, in order to do so, he extends consciousness,

original: “anantaṃ viññāṇa”nti punappunaṃ manasikaroto viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ uppajjati, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: anantam viññāṇanti punappunam manasikarotaḥ viññāṇaṃ ca āyatanam uppajjati tam dassetuṃ
translated: When he brings to mind “consciousness is infinite” again and again, the base consisting of infinite consciousness arises. In order to point out that he said,

original: “sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha pubbe vuttanayena jhānampi
analyzed: sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma atiādi vuttam tattha pubbe vutta nayena jhānam pi
translated: “By completely surmounting the base consisting of boundless space,” etc. Herein, the jhāna too is the base consisting of boundless space, and the object too is the base consisting of boundless space.

original: ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ ārammaṇampi. Ārammaṇampi hi purimanayena ākāsānañcañca taṃ paṭhamāruppassa🔽ārammaṇattā vuttanayena āyatanañcāti “ākāsānañcāyatana”nti vuccati. Iti ubhayassāpi🔽appavattikaraṇena, amanasikaraṇena ca ekajjhaṃ katvā “ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammā”ti
analyzed: ākāsānañcāyatanam ārammaṇam pi ārammaṇam pi hi purima nayena tam paṭhama āruppassa  ārammaṇattā vutta nayena āyatanam ca ati ākāsānam ca āyatananti vuccati iti ubhayassa api  appavatti karaṇena a manasikaraṇena ca ekajjham katvā ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma ati
translated: For the object is called the base consisting of boundless space in the way already stated, since it is the object of the first jhāna in this birth, and it is boundless space since it is boundless and is space.

original: idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Anantaṃ viññāṇanti taññeva paṭhamāruppaviññāṇaṃ ākāsaṃ anantato pharitvā pavattaṃ
analyzed: idam vuttan ti veditabbam  anantam viññāṇanti tat na eva paṭhama āruppa viññāṇam ākāsam anantataḥ pharitvā pavattam
translated: So it should be understood that the words “By completely surmounting the base consisting of boundless space” are said of both of them taken together by way of their making the two disappear and by way of giving attention to them in combination.🔽Consciousness is infinite: it is the same first-jhāna consciousness that is called “consciousness is infinite” because it occurs making the space appear infinite.

original: “anantaṃ viññāṇa”nti evaṃ manasikarototi vuttaṃ hoti, manasikāravasena vā anantaṃ.
analyzed: anantam viññāṇam ti evam manasikaroto ti vuttam hoti manasikāra vasena vā anantam
translated: Or it is infinite by way of the attention given to it.

original: Vibhaṅgepi hi “anantaṃ pharatī”ti vuttaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatananti ettha vuttanayena anantameva🔽ānañcaṃ, viññāṇañca taṃ ānañcañcāti viññāṇānantanti vattabbe ruḷhito “viññāṇañca”nti
analyzed: vibhaṅge api hi anantam pharati iti vuttam viññāṇam ca āyatanam ti ettha vutta nayena anantam eva  ānañcam viññāṇam ca tam ānañcam ca ati viññāṇa anantam ti vattabbe ruḷhitaḥ viññāṇañcanti
translated: The base consisting of boundless consciousness: it is boundless ,

original: vuttaṃ, tadeva āyatanamārammaṇamassāti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Evaṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ dassetvā idāni yaṃ tadanantaraṃ adhigatadutiyāruppassa taṃ
analyzed: vuttam tat eva āyatanam ārammaṇam assa ati viññāṇam ca āyatanam sesam vutta nayam eva  evam viññāṇañcāyatanam dassetvā idāni yam tad anantaram adhigata dutiya āruppassa tam
translated: and it is consciousness , thus it is boundless consciousness . What should be said is that it is the boundlessness of consciousness , but it is said to be the boundless of consciousness by the contraction of the middle thus .🔽That is the base , the object, of this jhāna, thus it is the base consisting of boundless consciousness . The rest is as already described .

original: vasībhūtaṃ katvā tattha āsannākāsānañcāyatanapaccatthikatāya, tadārammaṇatāya ca
analyzed: vasībhūtam katvā tattha āsanna ākāsa anañca āyatana paccatthika tāya tad ārammaṇa tāya ca
translated: Having thus shown the base consisting of boundless consciousness, the Master now said, “With the stilling of applied and sustained thought” in order to show the base consisting of nothingness, which comes next after that,

original: dosaṃ disvā nikantiṃ pariyādāya taṃ samatikkamāya paṭhamāruppaviññāṇābhāvaṃ “natthi
analyzed: dosam disvā nikantim pariyādāya tam samatikkamāya paṭhama āruppa viññāṇa abhāvam natthi
translated: after he had attained the second jhāna in the base consisting of boundless consciousness and had mastered it, and after he had seen the danger in the base consisting of boundless space by regarding it thus, “That has the sign of the boundlessness of space as its object and so is gross,” and had sur- mounted it by abandoning desire for it,🔽and after he had seen the advantage in the base consisting of boundless consciousness by regarding it thus, “The base consisting of boundless consciousness is a peaceful and sublime jhāna,” and had entered upon that and had mastered it, and after he had seen the danger in that too by regarding it thus, “That has the sign of the boundlessness of consciousness as its object and so is gross,” and had sur- mounted it by abandoning desire for it,

original: natthī”ti vā “suññaṃ suñña”nti vā “vivittaṃ vivitta”nti vā punappunaṃ manasikaroto🔽ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ uppajjati, taṃ dassetuṃ “sabbaso”tiādimāha. Idhāpi vuttanayena jhānassa,
analyzed: natthi iti vā suññam suññanti vā vivittam vivittam vā punappunam manasikaroto 🔽ākiñcaññāyatanam uppajjati tam dassetum sabbaso tiādim āha idha api vutta nayena jhānassa
translated: and after he had done this and had again and again brought to mind “non-existence, non-existence” or “void, void” or “secluded, secluded” in order to surmount the first jhāna in the base consisting of boundless consciousness,🔽and after he had done this and had again and again brought to mind “non-existence, non-existence” or “void, void” or “secluded, secluded” in order to surmount the second jhāna in the base consisting of boundless consciousness,🔽and after he had done this and had again and again brought to mind “non-existence, non-existence” or “void, void” or “secluded, secluded” in order to surmount the third jhāna in the base consisting of boundless consciousness,🔽and after he had done this and had again and again brought to mind “non-existence, non-existence” or “void, void” or “secluded,

original: tadārammaṇassa ca viññāṇañcāyatanassa samatikkamova veditabbo. Natthi kiñcīti “natthi
analyzed: tad ārammaṇassa ca viññāṇañca āyatanassa samatikkamaḥ uva veditabbo natthi kiñci iti natthi
translated: and the surmounting of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, which is its object, should be understood.

original: natthi, suññaṃ suññaṃ, vivittaṃ vivitta”nti evaṃ manasikarototi attho.🔽Ākiñcaññāyatananti ettha nāssa kiñcananti akiñcanaṃ, antamaso bhaṅgamattampissa avasiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: natthi suññam suññam vivittam vivittanti evam manasikaroto ti attho  ākiñcaññāyatananti ettha na assa kiñcananti akiñcanam antamasaḥ avasiṭṭham
translated: There is nothing: the meaning is that he gives his attention to it as “nothing, nothing, void, void, secluded, secluded.”

original: natthīti vuttaṃ hoti, akiñcanassa bhāvo ākiñcaññaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanaviññāṇāpagamassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ, ākiñcaññaṃ āyatanamārammaṇamassāti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: na atthi iti vuttam hoti akiñcanassa bhāvaḥ ākiñcaññam ākāsa ānañca āyatana viññāṇa apagamassa etam  adhivacanam ākiñcaññam āyatanam ārammaṇam assa ati ākiñcaññāyatanam sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The base consisting of nothingness: there is no “something” here, thus it is nothingness ; what is meant is that not even a mere remnant is left. The state of being nothingness is the “nothingness base” ; this is a term for the absence of the consciousness of the base consisting of boundless space. The base consisting of nothingness is that which has nothingness as its object. The rest is as already stated.

original: Evaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanādhigamaṃ dassetvā idāni yaṃ tadanantaraṃ adhigatatatiyāruppassa
analyzed: evam ākiñcaññāyatana adhigamam dassetvā idāni yam tad anantaram adhigata tatiya āruppassa
translated: Having thus shown the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness, he now shows the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, which is next to that, by way of surmounting the base consisting of nothingness, and so on.

original: taṃ vasībhūtaṃ katvā tattha āsannaviññāṇañcāyatanapaccatthikatāya dosaṃ disvā nikantiṃ
analyzed: tam vasībhūtam katvā tattha āsanna viññāṇaṃ ca āyatana paccatthika tāya dosam disvā nikantim
translated: Having mastered that third jhāna of the base consisting of nothingness, and having given attention again and again to the danger in the base consisting of boundless consciousness, which is proximate to it, and having abandoned his attachment to it, he surmounts that jhāna.

original: pariyādāya taṃ samatikkamāya tadeva ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ “santaṃ santa”nti punappunaṃ
analyzed: pariyādāya tam samatikkamāya tat eva ākiñcaññāyatanam santam santanti punappunam
translated: To surmount that jhāna means to surmount the jhāna of the base consisting of nothingness.🔽For when a bhikkhu who has attained mastery in the jhāna of the base consisting of nothingness finds it a convenient means for entering upon the jhāna of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, then, in order to enter upon that jhāna, he gives attention to the coarseness of the jhāna of the base consisting of nothingness by comparing it with the subtler jhāna of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: manasikaroto nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ uppajjati, taṃ dassetuṃ “sabbaso”tiādimāha.
analyzed: manasikarotaḥ na ivasaññānāsaññāyatanam uppajjati tam dassetum sabbaso tiādim āha
translated: When he brings that to mind, the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception arises in him. In order to show that, he said “All” .

original: Tattha nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti oḷārikāya saññāya abhāvato, sukhumāya ca bhāvato
analyzed: tattha nevasaññā nāsañña āyatananti oḷārikāya saññāya abhāvato sukhumāya ca bhāvato
translated: Herein, neither perception nor non-perception : because of the absence of gross perception and because of the presence of subtle perception,

original: nevassa sasampayuttadhammassa jhānassa saññā nāsaññāti nevasaññānāsaññaṃ, tadeva🔽dhammāyatanamanāyatanapariyāpannattā āyatananti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: na eva assa sa sampayutta dhammassa jhānassa saññā na asaññā ati nevasaññānāsaññam tat eva  dhammāyatanam anāyatana pariyāpanna ttā āyatanam ti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam
translated: the jhāna, together with its associated states, has neither perception nor non-perception, thus it is neither perception nor non-perception.🔽That is a base, since it is included in the mental-data base and the immaterial-sphere base, thus it is the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: Atha vā yāyamettha saññā, sā paṭusaññākiccaṃ kātuṃ asamatthatāya nevasaññā, saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvena🔽vijjamānattā nāsaññāti nevasaññānāsaññā, nevasaññānāsaññā ca sā sampayuttadhammānaṃ🔽adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena āyatanañcāti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ. Na kevalañcettha saññāva edisī,
analyzed: atha vā yā ayam ettha saññā sā paṭu saññā kiccam kātum asamattha tāya na iva saññā saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāvena  vijjamāna ttā na asaññā ati nevasaññā anāsaññā nevasaññā anāsaññā ca sā sampayutta dhammānam  adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatanam ca ati nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam na kevalam ca ittha edisī
translated: Or alternatively, since the perception here is incapable of performing the decisive function of perception, it is “neither perception” ;🔽since it exists in a subtle form as a residual formation, it is “non-non-perception” , thus it is neither perception nor non-perception. And that is a base in the sense of foundation for the associated states,🔽thus it is the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception. And not only is the perception here of this kind,

original: api tu phassopi nevaphasso nāphasso, cittampi nevacittaṃ nācittaṃ, evaṃ sesasampayuttadhammāpi,
analyzed: api tu phassaḥ api na iva phassaḥ na aphassaḥ cittam pi na iva cittam na acittam evam sesa sampayutta dhammā api
translated: but also the contact is “neither contact nor non-contact” , the consciousness is “neither consciousness nor non-consciousness” , and so too the associated states.

original: saññāsīsena panāyaṃ desanā katāti veditabbā. Tattha saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvenāti
analyzed: saññā sīsena pana ayam desanā katā ati veditabbā tattha saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāvena ati
translated: But this teaching should be understood as being given in terms of perception.

original: accantasukhumabhāvappattasaṅkhārabhāvena. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: accanta sukhuma bhāva ppatta saṅkhāra bhāvena sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: Herein, by the state of subtle formations that remain is the state of formations that have reached extreme subtlety. The rest is as already stated.

original: Ayaṃ panettha ādito paṭṭhāya piṇḍatthappakāsanā – “idha bhikkhu pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto”tiādinā
analyzed: ayam pana ittha āditas paṭṭhāya piṇḍattha pakāsanā idha bhikkhu pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvuto tiādinā
translated: But the exposition of the meaning of the text in brief is as follows: “Herein, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, possessed of virtue, restrained by the restraint of the Patimokkha” ,

original: sāsane lokiyalokuttarajjhānanibbattakapuggalassa patiṭṭhābhūtasīlesu pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlavisuddhiṃ
analyzed: sāsane lokiya lokuttara jjhāna nibbattaka puggalassa patiṭṭhā bhūta sīlesu pātimokkha saṃvara sīla visuddhim
translated: he teaches purification of virtue consisting in restraint by the Patimokkha, which is the foundation for those in the Dispensation who are producing jhāna, whether they be worldlings or beings of the noble type.🔽“He lives” : by this he teaches that he possesses the kind of life that is in conformity with that virtue.

original: upadisati. “Viharatī”ti iminā tadanurūpavihārasamaṅgibhāvaṃ. “Ācāragocarasampanno”ti🔽iminā ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ, tadupakārake ca dhamme. “Aṇumattesū”tiādinā yathāvuttasīlehi
analyzed: upadisati viharati iti tad anurūpa vihāra samaṅgi bhāvam ācāra gocara sampannoti  iminā ājīva pārisuddhi sīlam tad upakārake ca dhamme aṇumattesu iti ādinā yathā vutta sīlehi
translated: “Possessed of conduct and resort” :🔽by this he teaches purification of livelihood, and also the states that are helpful to it.🔽“In regard to the minor rules of training” , etc.: by this he teaches non-transgression of the aforesaid virtues and the undertaking of them without remainder.

original: acavanaṃ, tesañca anavasesato samādānaṃ. “Indriyesu guttadvāro”ti iminā indriyasaṃvarasīlaṃ.
analyzed: tesaṃ ca anavasesato samādānam indriyesu iminā indriya saṃvara sīlam
translated: “Guarded by the guard of the sense-doors” : by this he teaches purification of virtue consisting in restraint of the sense faculties.

original: “Bhojane mattaññū”ti iminā paccayasannissitasīlaṃ, santosādiguṇañca. “Pubbarattāpararatta”ntiādinā🔽sīladhutaṅgesu patiṭṭhitassa bhāvanārāmassa tadupakārake dhamme. “Bodhipakkhikāna”ntiādinā🔽paṭipattiyā nibbedhabhāgiyataṃ. “So abhikkante”tiādinā yathāvuttaguṇānaṃ aparihānāya,🔽vakkhamānānañca paṭilābhāya satisampayogaṃ. “So vivitta”ntiādinā bhāvanānurūpasenāsanapariggahaṃ.
analyzed: bhojane iminā paccaya sannissita sīlam santosa ādi guṇam ca pubba ratta apara ratta nti ādinā  sīla dhutaṅgesu patiṭṭhitassa bhāvanā ārāmassa tad upakārake dhamme bodhi pakkhika ananti ādinā  paṭipattiyā so abhikkanta iti ādinā yathā vutta guṇānaṃ a parihānāya  paṭilābhāya sati sampayogam saḥ vivitta nti ādinā bhāvanā anurūpa senāsana pariggaham
translated: “Moderation in food” shows the virtue consisting in the right use of requisites and the qualities of contentment, etc. “The first and last watches of the night” shows the qualities that assist the development of concentration. “The factors of enlightenment” shows the path as a factor of penetration. “When he walks” shows the association with mindfulness for the non-abandonment of the qualities already acquired and for the acquisition of those not yet acquired. “He dwells in a secluded state” shows the choice of a suitable lodging in accordance with the development of concentration.

original: “So araññagato”tiādinā jhānabhāvanārambhappakāraṃ. “So abhijjha”ntiādinā jhānabhāvanābhiyogena🔽pahīnapañcanīvaraṇassa upacārajjhānuppattiṃ. “So ime pañca nīvaraṇe”tiādinā tassa🔽uparūpari vāyamato rūpārūpajjhānuppattikkamaṃ upadisati. Ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.
analyzed: so arañña gataḥ tiādinā jhāna bhāvanā ārambha ppakāram so abhijjhanti ādinā jhāna bhāvanā abhiyogena 🔽pahīna pañca nīvaraṇassa upacāra jhāna uppattim so ime pañca nīvaraṇa iti ādinā tassa 🔽upari upari vā ayam atas rūpa arūpa jjhāna uppatti kkamam upadisati ayam tāva ettha padattho

original: Dhammabhedo panettha vibhaṅganaye pākaṭo bhavissati. Tīsu hi nayesu mahaggatalokuttarā
analyzed: dhamma bhedaḥ pana ittha vibhaṅga naye pākaṭaḥ bhavissati tīsu hi nayesu mahaggata lokuttarā
translated: For in the three methods the profitable, resultant, and functional consciousnesses of the fine-material sphere,

original: kusalavipākakiriyacittasampayuttā vitakkavicārapītisukhaupekkhāekaggatāsaṅkhātā jhānadhammā
analyzed: kusala vipāka kiriya citta sampayuttāḥ vitakka vicāra pīti sukha upekkhā ekagga tā saṅkhātāḥ jhāna dhammāḥ
translated: which are associated with the jhāna factors called applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and unification of mind,

original: nānānayehi vibhattā, jhānasampayuttā pana sesakāmāvacaradhammāva idha saṅgahitā.
analyzed: nānā nayehi vibhattā jhāna sampayuttā pana idha saṅgahitā
translated: are analysed by various methods, but the remaining fine-material-sphere states associated with jhāna are included here.

original: Kiñcāpi panettha pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlādayopi vuttā, tathāpi te jhānānaṃ pubbabhāgappaṭipattidassanavasena
analyzed: kiñcā api pana ittha pātimokkha saṃvara sīla ādayaḥ api vuttā tathā api te jhānānam pubbabhāga paṭipatti dassana vasena
translated: And although the virtue consisting in the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha, etc., is mentioned,

original: ceva jhānasampayuttadhammavasena ca vuttā, idha pana na saṅgahitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ca iva jhāna sampayutta dhamma vasena ca vuttā idha pana na saṅgahitā ati veditabbā
translated: it should be understood that it is not included here, since it is mentioned only as the preliminary practice for jhāna and as a state associated with jhāna factors.

original: Pañhāpucchake pana siyā kusalā, siyā abyākatā, tīṇi jhānāni sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā,
analyzed: pañhāpucchake pana siyā kusalā siyā abyākatā tīṇi jhānāni sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā
translated: But in the case of the question and answer, it may be profitable or indeterminate. Three jhānas are associated with the pleasant feeling,

original: catutthaṃ adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya sampayuttaṃ, upekkhā panettha vedanā na vattabbā,
analyzed: catuttham adukkham asukhāya vedanāya sampayuttam upekkhā pana ittha vedanā na vattabbā
translated: the fourth is associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. Equanimity as a jhāna factor is not to be spoken of as a feeling,

original: siyā vipākā, siyā vipākadhammadhammā, paṭhamajjhānaṃ vitakkavicāravajjitaṃ savitakkasavicāraṃ,
analyzed: siyā vipākā siyā vipāka dhamma dhammā paṭhama jhānam vitakka vicāra vajjitam sa vitakka sa vicāram
translated: It may be result, it may be subject to resultant, the first meditation is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, it is accompanied by joy and happiness born of seclusion.

original: vitakko panettha avitakkavicāramatto, vicāro na vattabbo, tīṇi jhānāni avitakkaavicārā,
analyzed: vitakkaḥ pana ittha avitakka vicāra mattaḥ vicāraḥ na vattabbo tīṇi jhānāni avitakka avicārā
translated: But the applied thought here is not accompanied by sustained thought, the sustained thought is not to be spoken of. The three meditations are not accompanied by applied and sustained thought,🔽the two meditations are accompanied by joy, but not by happiness. The three are accompanied by happiness, but not by joy. The fourth is accompanied by neither.

original: dve jhānāni pītivajjitāni pītisahagatāni, tīṇi sukhavajjitāni sukhasahagatāni, catutthaṃ
analyzed: dve jhānāni pīti vajjitāni pīti sahagatāni tīṇi sukha vajjitāni sukha sahagatāni catuttham
translated: The third meditation is accompanied by happiness and by equanimity. The fourth is accompanied by equanimity, but not by happiness. In the third meditation the happiness is not accompanied by equanimity.🔽It may be exalted, it may be immeasurable, three may be objects of measureless states, or they may not be so described. The fourth is not described in any of these three ways.🔽Three may be causes of paths, they may be associated with a path, or they may not be so described.

original: upekkhāvajjitaṃ upekkhāsahagataṃ, tatiyajjhāne sukhaṃ, upekkhā ca idha na vattabbaṃ…pe…
analyzed: upekkhā vajjitam upekkhā sahagatam tatiya jhāne sukham upekkhā ca idha na vattabbam pe
translated: The fourth is not described in any of these three ways. The third meditation is accompanied by happiness and by equanimity. The fourth is accompanied by equanimity, but not by happiness. In the third meditation the happiness is not accompanied by equanimity.🔽It may be exalted, it may be immeasurable, three may be objects of measureless states, or they may not be so described. The fourth is not described in any of these three ways.

original: siyā mahaggatā, siyā appamāṇā, tīṇi siyā appamāṇārammaṇā, siyā na vattabbā, catutthaṃ
analyzed: siyā mahaggatā siyā appamāṇā tīṇi siyā appamāṇa ārammaṇā siyā na vattabbā catuttham
translated: Three may be causes of paths, they may be associated with a path, or they may not be so described.🔽The fourth is not described in any of these three ways. The third meditation is accompanied by happiness and by equanimity. The fourth is accompanied by equanimity, but not by happiness. In the third meditation the happiness is not accompanied by equanimity.🔽It may be exalted, it may be immeasurable, three may be objects of measureless states, or they may not be so described. The fourth is not described in any of these three ways.

original: tidhāpi na vattabbañca, tīṇi siyā maggahetukā, siyā maggādhipatino, siyā na vattabbā,
analyzed: tidhā api na vattabbam ca tīṇi siyā magga hetukā siyā magga adhipatino siyā na vattabbā
translated: Three may be causes of paths, they may be associated with a path, or they may not be so described.🔽The fourth is not described in any of these three ways. The third meditation is accompanied by happiness and by equanimity. The fourth is accompanied by equanimity, but not by happiness. In the third meditation the happiness is not accompanied by equanimity.

original: catutthaṃ tidhāpi na vattabbañca…pe… pīti bahiddhārammaṇāni, catutthaṃ tidhāpi na
analyzed: catuttham tidhā api na vattabbam cape pi iti bahiddhā ārammaṇāni catuttham tidhā api na
translated: It may be exalted, it may be immeasurable, three may be objects of measureless states, or they may not be so

original: vattabbañca…pe… anidassanaappaṭighā na hetū…pe… nocittacetasikā araṇāti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: anidassana appaṭighāḥ na hetu upe no cittacetasikāḥ sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: and so on.🔽The rest is easy to understand.

original: Pāḷimuttanayo panettha natthi, ito paraṃ pana ettakampi avatvā vijjamānaṭṭhāne eva vakkhāma.
analyzed: pāḷimuttanayo pana ittha natthi itas param pana ettakam pi a vatvā vijjamāna ṭhāne eva vakkhāma
translated: There is no mnemonic verse here. But from now on we shall not quote the text of the Vibhaṅga in full, but only in part, and we shall comment only on the words that are not clear.

original: Jhānavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the word by word meaning of the Jhānavagga is ended.

original: Appamaññāvibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appamaññā vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā
translated: The word by word meaning of the Appamāṇavagga

original: Appamaññāvibhaṅgamātikāya pana atthato tāva – catasso appamaññāyotiādīsu pharaṇaappamāṇavasena
analyzed: pana atthato tāva catasso appamaññāyo ti ādīsu pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena
translated: As to the meaning, in the first place, in the passage “Four measureless states” and so on, they are measureless because of the measurelessness of their radiation and of their object.

original: appamaññāyo. Etā hi ārammaṇavasena appamāṇe vā satte pharanti, ekasattamhi vā anavasesapharaṇavasena
analyzed: appamaññāyaḥ etāḥ hi ārammaṇa vasena appamāṇe vā satte pharanti eka sattamhi vā anavasesa pharaṇa vasena
translated: For they radiate to measureless beings or they radiate to a measureless one being, since they radiate to a single being without reserve.

original: appamāṇato pharantīti evaṃ pharaṇaappamāṇavasena “appamaññāyo”ti vuccanti, satta
analyzed: appamāṇataḥ pharanti iti evam pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena appamaññāyaḥ ti vuccanti satta
translated: So they are called “measureless” because of the measurelessness of their radiation and of their object.🔽They can also be called measureless because of the measurelessness of the beings they aim at.

original: appamāṇavasenāpi vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Mettāsahagatenāti mettāya samannāgatena. Ekaṃ disanti
analyzed: appamāṇa vasena api vattum vaṭṭati mettā sahagatena ati mettāya samannāgatena ekam disanti
translated: Endowed with loving-kindness: associated with loving-kindness. One direction:

original: puratthimādīsu catūsu disāsu yaṃ kiñci ekaṃ disaṃ, taṃdisāpariyāpannasattapharaṇavasena
analyzed: puratthima ādīsu catūsu disāsu yam kiñci ekam disam taṃdisā pariyāpanna satta pharaṇa vasena
translated: The meaning is that he pervades with loving-kindness the beings in one direction, east, etc., without excepting anyone.

original: cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Pharitvāti phusitvā ārammaṇaṃ katvā. Viharatīti pavatteti. Tathā dutiyantiādīsu.
analyzed: ca itam vuttam pharitvā ti phusitvā ārammaṇam katvā viharati iti pavatta iti tathā dutiya ntiādīsu
translated: He abides pervading: he touches, makes his object.

original: Yathā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā, tatheva tadanantaraṃ dutiyaṃ, tatiyaṃ, catutthañcāti attho.
analyzed: yathā ekam disam pharitvā tathā iva tad anantaram dutiyam tatiyam catuttham ca ati
translated: And likewise the second, etc.: the meaning is that he does likewise with the second direction, the third, and the fourth.

original: Iti uddhamadho tiriyanti eteneva nayena uparimaṃ disaṃ, heṭṭhimaṃ disaṃ, anudisañca🔽anukkamena mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharatīti attho. Ettāvatā ekamekaṃ disaṃ
analyzed: iti uddham adhas tiriyanti etena iva nayena uparimam disam heṭṭhimam disam anudisam ca  anukkamena mettā sahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharati iti attho ettāvatā ekam ekam disam
translated: Thus upwards, downwards, and across: in the same way he does likewise with the upper direction, the lower direction, and the direction all around.🔽The meaning is that he pervades with loving-kindness that is accompanied by the fourth jhāna successively.

original: pariggahetvā odhiso mettāpharaṇataṃ dassitaṃ.🔽Sabbadhītiādi pana anodhiso dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha sabbadhīti sabbattha. Sabbattatāyāti
analyzed: pariggahetvā odhisaḥ mettā pharaṇa tam dassitam  sabbadhi itiādi pana anodhisaḥ dassana attham vuttam tattha sabbadhi iti sabbattha sabbattatāya ati
translated: So far the delimitation of the directions by the four primary and four intermediate directions has been demonstrated.🔽But the words “everywhere in the world” are said for the purpose of showing that there is no restriction to directions.🔽Herein, everywhere is in all places.🔽In the world is in the world of beings.

original: sabbesu hīnamajjhimukkaṭṭhamittasapattamajjhattādippabhedesu attatāya, tesu vibhāgaṃ
analyzed: sabbesu hīna majjhi mukkaṭṭha mitta sapatta majjhatta ādi ppabhedesu atta tāya tesu vibhāgam
translated: With a mind: with a consciousness.

original: akatvā attasamatāyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā sabbattatāyāti sabbena cittabhāvena, īsakampi
analyzed: a katvā atta sama tāya iti vuttam hoti atha vā sabbattatāya ati sabbena citta bhāvena īsakampi
translated: “Without making a distinction” means without making a difference. Or else, “in its entirety” means with the whole of the mind; the meaning is, without leaving out even a little,

original: bahi avikkhepamānoti attho. Sabbāvantanti sabbasattavantaṃ, sabbasattayuttanti attho.
analyzed: bahi a vikkhepamānaḥ ti attho sabbāvantam ti sabba sattavantam sabba satta yuttam iti attho
translated: without distraction. “All-embracing” means all-embracing of all beings; the meaning is, all beings are included.

original: Lokanti sattalokaṃ. Puna “mettāsahagatenā”ti idaṃ “vipulenā”tiādīhi visesanehi sambandhadassanavasena
analyzed: lokam ti satta lokam puna mettā sahagatena ati idam vipulena ati ādīhi visesanehi sambandha dassana vasena
translated: “The world” is the world of beings. “With a mind abundant” and so on is said either to show the connection with the qualification “abundant” and so on,

original: vā vuttaṃ, nigamanavasena vā. Tattha pharaṇavasena vipulatā veditabbā. Bhūmivasena
analyzed: vā vuttam nigamana vasena vā tattha pharaṇa vasena vipula tā veditabbā bhūmi vasena
translated: or to sum up. Herein, abundance should be understood as pervading;🔽greatness as the plane;

original: pana mahaggatatā. Paguṇavasena, appamāṇasattārammaṇavasena ca appamāṇatā. Byāpādapaccatthikappahānena
analyzed: pana mahaggata tā paguṇa vasena appamāṇa satta ārammaṇa vasena ca appamāṇa tā byāpāda paccatthika ppahānena
translated: immeasurableness as the measureless object consisting of the immeasurable beings;🔽friendliness as the abandoning of ill will and enmity;

original: averatā. Domanassappahānena niddukkhatā, saṅkhatatā, abyāpajjatā ca daṭṭhabbā. Evaṃ
analyzed: avera tā domanassa ppahānena niddukkha tā saṅkhata tā abyāpajja tā ca daṭṭhabbā evam
translated: absence of suffering as the abandoning of grief; and as the state of being unmixed, unconfined, and unthreatened.

original: karuṇāsahagatenātiādīsupi attho veditabboti ayaṃ tāvettha padattho.
analyzed: karuṇā sahagatena ati ādīsu pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti ayam tāva ettha padattho
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance beginning with “with a mind possessing compassion” . This, in the first place, is the word meaning.

original: Dhammabhedo panettha suviññeyyova. Vibhaṅganayena pana tīsu rūpāvacarakusalavipākakiriyācittesu🔽sampayuttā sattesu mettādibrahmavihārabhūtā adoso karuṇā muditā tatramajjhattatāti
analyzed: dhamma bhedaḥ pana ittha su viññeyyaḥ va vibhaṅga nayena pana tīsu rūpāvacara kusala vipāka kiriyā cittesu  sampayuttā sattesu mettā ādi brahmavihāra bhūtā adosaḥ karuṇā muditā tatram ajjhatta tā ati
translated: But the analysis of the ideas is easy to understand. But in the three kinds of consciousnesses of the fine-material sphere, namely, profitable, resultant, and inoperative,🔽there are seven associated with the four divine abidings, namely, non-hate, compassion, gladness, and equanimity,

original: cattāro dhammā nānānayehi vibhattā, taṃsampayuttā pana kāmāvacarabhūtā ca etā idha
analyzed: cattāro dhammā nānā nayehi vibhattā tad sampayuttā pana kāmāvacara bhūtā ca etāḥ idha
translated: which are the divine abidings of loving-kindness, etc., and these four ideas are analysed in different ways. But those associated with the four divine abidings in the sense sphere and those in the immaterial sphere are not included here.

original: na gahitā. Arūpāvacaralokuttaresu panetā appamaññā natthevāti. Pañhāpucchake panetā
analyzed: na gahitā arūpāvacara lokuttaresu panetā appamaññā nattha iva ati pañhāpucchake panetā
translated: And there are none in the supramundane. But in the case of the questions,🔽they may be profitable or indeterminate. They are associated with the three kinds of feeling,

original: tāva siyā kusalā, siyā abyākatā. Tisso sukhāya, catutthā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya
analyzed: siyā kusalā siyā abyākatā tisso sukhāya catutthāḥ adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya
translated: but the fourth is associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: sampayuttā. Vipākattike tidhāpi, upekkhā avitakkaavicārā, sesā tidhāpi, mahaggatāva,
analyzed: sampayuttā vipāka ttike tidhā api upekkhā avitakka avicārā sesā tidhā api mahaggatā ava
translated: In the “resultant” section they are threefold. Equanimity is without thinking and without exploring. The rest are threefold. They are exalted,

original: parittārammaṇaatītārammaṇattikesu na vattabbāva, bahiddhārammaṇāva, anidassanaappaṭighāva,
analyzed: paritta ārammaṇa atīta ārammaṇa ttikesu na vattabbau bahiddha ārammaṇau anidassana appaṭighau

original: mettā hetu, sesā na hetū, no cittā, cetasikā, rūpāvacarā, sauttarāva. Sesaṃ suviññeyyamevāti.
analyzed: mettā hetu sesā na hetū no cittā cetasikā rūpāvacarā sauttarā ava sesam su viññeyyam eva ati
translated: Loving-kindness is a cause; the rest are not causes. They are not states of consciousness; they are kinds of mental factors. They are of the fine-material sphere. They are only “with root cause.” The rest can be understood.

original: Appamaññāvibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Sikkhāpadavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā

original: pāṇātipāto, pāṇavadhoti attho. Pāṇoti cettha vohārato satto, paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ,🔽tasmiṃ pana pāṇe pāṇasaññino jīvitindriyupacchedakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā kāyavacīdvārānaṃ
analyzed: pāṇa atipāto pāṇa vadho ti attho pāṇo ti ca ittha vohārato satto paramatthataḥ jīvitindriyam  tasmin pana pāṇe pāṇa saññinaḥ jīvitindriya upacchedaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: And here a breathing thing is a being in the sense of common usage, and in the ultimate sense it is the life faculty.

So abstention from killing breathing things is a training rule.

translated: Stealing is the taking of another’s property.

Intoxicants:🔽there are five kinds of intoxicants: intoxicants from flowers, intoxicants from fruits, intoxicants from sugar-cane, intoxicants from honey, and intoxicants mixed with other substances. Both of these:🔽

analyzed: pañhāpucchake pana cetanāya phassa ādīnam ca pariyāya sikkhāpada ttā nippariyāya sikkhāpada bhūtānam

translated: which are training precepts both in the literal sense and by implication. Herein, the five training precepts are only profitable. They may be associated with pleasure,🔽with neither-pain-nor-pleasure, … with limited … with the here and now … with the external …

analyzed: araṇāvā ti ettha ca yāni sikkhāpadāni satta ārammaṇāni vuttāni tāni ca virati sabhāvattā

analyzed: yasmā satto ti saṅkham gate paritta dhamme eva paccuppanne eva dhamme ārammaṇam karonti
translated: And since a living being is a name for a limited thing, they have as their object only a limited thing, that is, a present phenomenon.🔽So they should be understood as “limited” in this way.🔽Now, as regards the abstentions from killing living beings, etc.,🔽The method of the training precepts

analyzed: tasmā paritta ārammaṇā iti ca vuttā ati veditabbā idāni viramitabba pāṇātipāta ādīnam
