original: satta ñāṇāni. Evaṃ sesesupi jātipariyosānesu cāti evaṃ ekādasasu paṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu
analyzed: satta ñāṇāni evam sesesu pi jāti pariyosānesu ca ati evam ekādasasu paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgesu
translated: There are seven kinds of knowledge. So too in the case of the other terms ending with birth. Thus in the case of the eleven factors of dependent origination,

original: paccekaṃ kālattayepi anvayabyatirekañāṇaṃ tesaṃ vayadassanañāṇassa ca vasena satta
analyzed: paccekam anvaya byatireka ñāṇam tesam vaya dassana ñāṇassa ca vasena satta
translated: there are seven kinds of knowledge in each of the three periods of time, making twenty-one kinds of knowledge, by way of the knowledge of the past and the knowledge of the future.

original: satta katvā sattasattati ñāṇāni.
analyzed: satta katvā sattasattati ñāṇāni
translated: So there are seventy-seven kinds of knowledge.

original: Sattakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: sattakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The sevenfold group is finished.

original: Aṭṭhakaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: aṭṭhakam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The eightfold group is easy to understand.

original: Navake navasu anupubbavihārasamāpattīsu paññāti nirodhasamāpattiṃ samāpajjantassa
analyzed: navake navasu anupubba vihāra samāpattīsu paññā ati nirodha samāpattim samāpajjantassa
translated: In the case of the nine kinds of knowledge in the nine successive abidings, there are nine kinds of knowledge in the case of one who attains the attainment of cessation,

original: anupaṭipāṭiyā vihātabbato uppādetabbato anupubbavihārasaṅkhātāsu rūpārūpasamāpattīsu🔽sampayuttā aṭṭha paññā ceva tadanantaraṃ nirodhaṃ phusitvā vuṭṭhitassa nirodhaṃ santato
analyzed: anupaṭipāṭiyā vihātabbataḥ uppādetabbataḥ anupubba vihāra saṅkhātāsu rūpa arūpa samāpattīsu  sampayuttāḥ aṭṭha paññā ca iva tad anantaram nirodham phusitvā vuṭṭhitassa nirodham santataḥ
translated: because of the necessity for the successive arising and entering upon of the fine-material and immaterial attainments called “successive abidings.”

original: paccavekkhaṇañāṇañcāti nava.
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam ca ati nava
translated: There are eight kinds of knowledge associated with the attainment of cessation, and there is the knowledge of reviewing cessation as peace after emerging from it. So there are nine.

original: Navakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: navakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The ninefold group is finished.

original: Dasake tathāgatassāti yathā vipassīādayo pubbakā isayo āgatā, tathā āgatassa sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: dasake tathāgatassa ti yathā vipassī ādayo pubbakāḥ isayaḥ āgatā tathā āgatassa sammāsambuddhassa
translated: In the case of the ten kinds of knowledge in the case of a Tathāgata, a Tathāgata is a Supremely Enlightened One who has come into this world in the same way as the former Buddhas Vipassī, etc.,

original: Tathāgatabalānīti aññehi asādhāraṇāni tathāgatasseva balāni, yathā vā pubbabuddhānaṃ🔽balāni puññussayasampattiyā āgatāni, tathā āgatāni balānītipi attho. Tattha duvidhaṃ
analyzed: tathāgata balāni iti aññehi asādhāraṇāni tathāgatassa iva balāni yathā vā pubbabuddhānam  balāni puññussaya sampattiyā āgatāni tathā āgatāni balāni iti pi atthaḥ tattha duvidham
translated: The powers of the Tathāgata are the powers that are not shared by others, but are possessed only by the Tathāgata. Or the meaning can be taken as the powers that have come to the Tathāgata in the same way as they came to the Buddhas of the past.

original: tathāgatassa balaṃ kāyabalaṃ, ñāṇabalañca. Tesu kāyabalaṃ hatthikulānusārena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathāgatassa balam kāya balam ñāṇa balañca tesu kāya balam hatthi kula anusārena veditabbaṃ
translated: The Tathāgata’s power is twofold: physical power and the power of knowledge. The physical power can be understood by way of the ten clans of elephants.

original: Vuttaṃ hetaṃ porāṇehi –
analyzed: vuttam ha etam porāṇehi
translated: For this is said by the ancients:

original: “Kāḷāvakañca gaṅgeyyaṃ, paṇḍaraṃ tambapiṅgalaṃ;
analyzed: kāḷāvakam ca gaṅgeyyam paṇḍaram tamba piṅgalam
translated: “The black, the Ganges, the white, the copper-red, the tawny,

original: Gandhamaṅgalahemañca, uposathachaddantime dasā”ti. ;🔽Imāni hi dasa hatthikulāni. Tattha kāḷāvakanti pakatihatthikulaṃ, yaṃ dasannaṃ purisānaṃ🔽kāyabalaṃ, taṃ ekassa kāḷāvakahatthino balaṃ, yaṃ tesaṃ dasannaṃ balaṃ, taṃ ekassa
analyzed: gandha maṅgala hemañcaḥ uposatha chaddantime dasāti  imāni hi dasa hatthi kulāni tattha kāḷāvakanti pakati hatthi kulam yam dasannam purisānam  kāya balam tam ekassa kāḷāvaka hatthinaḥ balam yam tesam dasannam balam tam ekassa
translated: The fragrant, the playful, the golden, the Uposatha, and the Chaddanta—these are the ten clans of elephants.”

original: gaṅgeyyassa, tesaṃ dasannaṃ paṇḍarassa, tesaṃ dasannaṃ tambassa, tesaṃ dasannaṃ piṅgalassa,
analyzed: gaṅgeyyassa tesam dasannam paṇḍarassa tesam dasannam tambassa tesam dasannam piṅgalassa
translated: For the physical power of ten men of the black clan of elephants is equal to the power of one elephant of the Ganges clan. The power of ten elephants of the Ganges clan is equal to the power of one elephant of the white clan. The power of ten elephants of the white clan is equal to the power of one elephant of the copper-red clan. The power of ten elephants of the copper-red clan is equal to the power of one elephant of the tawny clan.

original: tesaṃ dasannaṃ gandhahatthino, tesaṃ dasannaṃ maṅgalassa, tesaṃ dasannaṃ hemassa,
analyzed: tesam dasannam gandhahatthinaḥ tesam dasannam maṅgalassa tesam dasannam hemassa
translated: Of these ten scents, ten elephants, ten auspicious things, ten gold coins,

original: tesaṃ dasannaṃ uposathassa, tesaṃ dasannaṃ balaṃ chaddantassa, yaṃ dasannaṃ chaddantānaṃ
analyzed: tesam dasannam uposathassa tesam dasannam balam chaddantassa yam dasannam chaddantānam
translated: ten uposatha days, ten of the strength of the Chaddanta tusker,

original: balaṃ, taṃ tathāgatassa nārāyaṇabalanti vuccati. Tadetaṃ pakatihatthigaṇanāya hatthīnaṃ
analyzed: balam tam tathāgatassa nārāyaṇa balanti vuccati tat etam pakati hatthi gaṇanāya hatthīnam
translated: the strength of ten Chaddantas is said to be the strength of the Tathāgata’s Nārāyaṇa tusker. This, in terms of the number of ordinary elephants,

original: koṭisahassaṃ, purisagaṇanāya dasannaṃ purisakoṭisahassānaṃ balaṃ hoti. Idaṃ tāva
analyzed: koṭi sahassam purisa gaṇanāya dasannam purisa koṭi sahassānam balam hoti idam tāva
translated: is a thousand koṭis of elephants, in terms of the number of men, the strength of ten thousand koṭis of men. This, then,

original: tathāgatassa kāyabalaṃ. Yāni pana dasabalacatuvesārajjādīni anekāni ñāṇasahassāni,
analyzed: tathāgatassa kāya balam yāni pana dasa bala catu vesārajja ādīni anekāni ñāṇa sahassāni
translated: is the strength of the Tathāgata’s body. But the many thousands of kinds of knowledge, such as the ten powers and the four kinds of intrepidity,

original: etaṃ ñāṇabalaṃ nāma. Idhāpi ñāṇabalameva adhippetaṃ. Ñāṇañhi akampiyaṭṭhena, upatthambhanaṭṭhena ca balanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: etam ñāṇa balam nāma idha api ñāṇa balam eva adhippetam ñāṇam hi akampiya ṭṭhena upatthambhana ṭṭhena ca balan ti vuttam
translated: are called the strength of knowledge. Here too it is the strength of knowledge that is intended. For knowledge is called strength in the sense of being unshakable and in the sense of supporting .

original: Yehi balehi samannāgatoti yehi dasahi ñāṇabalehi upeto. Āsabhaṇṭhānanti seṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: yehi balehi samannāgato ti yehi dasahi ñāṇa balehi upetaḥ āsabhaṇṭhānam ti seṭṭha ṭṭhānam
translated: Endowed with the strengths: endowed with the ten strengths of knowledge. The place of honour: the foremost place.

original: Apica gavasatajeṭṭhako usabho, gavasahassajeṭṭhako vasabho. Vajasatajeṭṭhako vā usabho,
analyzed: apica gava sata jeṭṭhakaḥ usabhaḥ gava sahassa jeṭṭhakaḥ vasabhaḥ vaja sata jeṭṭhakaḥ vā usabhaḥ
translated: Moreover, the bull is the chief of a hundred head of cattle, the vasala is the chief of a thousand head, the usabha is the chief of a hundred head of cattle or

original: vajasahassajeṭṭhako vasabho, sabbagavaseṭṭho nisabho, seto pāsādiko mahābhāravaho
analyzed: vaja sahassa jeṭṭhakaḥ vasabhaḥ sabbaga vaseṭṭhaḥ nisabhaḥ setaḥ pāsādikaḥ mahā bhāravahaḥ
translated: the vasala is the chief of a thousand head of cattle, the nisabha is the chief of all cattle, the white one, the lovely one, the one with a great load to carry,

original: sabbaparissayasaho asanisatasaddehipi akampanīyo nisabho, so idha usabhoti adhippeto.
analyzed: sabba parissaya sahaḥ a sani sata saddehi pi a kampanīyaḥ nisabhaḥ saḥ idha usabhaḥ ti adhippeto
translated: the one who can bear all hardships, the one who does not tremble at the sound of a hundred claps of thunder, the nisabha, he is the one intended here as the bull.🔽For this is a synonym for him. The place where the bull is is the bull’s place.

original: Idampi hi tassa pariyāyavacanaṃ. Usabhassa idanti āsabhaṃ. Ṭhānanti tassa nisabhabalasamannāgatassa
analyzed: idam pi hi tassa pariyāya vacanam usabhassa idam ti āsabham ṭhānam ti tassa nisabha bala samannāgatassa
translated: The place where the bull, who is endowed with the strength of a nisabha,

original: catūhi pādehi pathaviṃ uppīḷetvā acalaṭṭhānaṃ, idaṃ pana āsabhaṃ viyāti āsabhaṃ.🔽Yatheva hi nisabhasaṅkhāto usabho usabhabalena samannāgato catūhi pādehi pathaviṃ
analyzed: catūhi pādehi pathavim uppīḍetvā acala ṭṭhānam idam pana āsabham viyāti āsabham  yathā iva hi nisabha saṅkhātaḥ usabhaḥ usabha balena samannāgataḥ catūhi pādehi pathavim
translated: stands unmoving after pressing the earth down with his four feet, but this is the bull’s place as if it were a bull’s place.🔽For just as the bull called the nisabha, who is endowed with the strength of a bull,🔽stands unmoving after pressing the earth down with his four feet,

original: uppīḷetvā acalaṭṭhānena tiṭṭhati, evaṃ tathāgatopi hi dasabalasamannāgato catuvesārajjapādehi
analyzed: uppīḍetvā acala ṭṭhānena tiṭṭhati evam tathāgataḥ api hi dasa bala samannāgato catu vesārajja pādehi
translated: so too the Tathāgata, who is endowed with the ten powers, with the four kinds of perfect confidence,

original: aṭṭhaparisapathaviṃ uppīḷetvā sadevake loke kenaci appadhaṃsiyo acalena ṭhānena tiṭṭhati,🔽tañcesa paṭijānāti upagacchati na paccakkhāti attani āropeti, tena vuttaṃ “āsabhaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha parisa pathavim uppīḍetvā sa devake loke kenaci appadhaṃsiyaḥ acalena ṭhānena tiṭṭhati  tat ca isa paṭijānāti upagacchati na paccakkhāti attani āropeti tena vuttam āsabham
translated: and he stands in an immovable place which is not overcome by anyone in the world with its gods.

original: ṭhānaṃ paṭijānātī”ti.
analyzed: ṭhānam paṭijānāti iti
translated: If he admits that he has done so, and does not deny it, and he makes it known, then it is said that he “admits the bull-place.”

original: Parisāsūti aṭṭhasu parisāsu. Sīhanādaṃ nadatīti seṭṭhanādaṃ abhītanādaṃ, sīhanādasadisaṃ
analyzed: parisāsu iti aṭṭhasu parisāsu sīha nādam nadati iti seṭṭha nādam abhīta nādam sīha nāda sadisam
translated: In the assemblies: in the eight assemblies. He roars the lion’s roar: he roars the best roar, the fearless roar, or a roar similar to the lion’s roar.

original: vā nādaṃ nadati. Ayamattho sīhanādasuttena dīpetabbo. Yathā vā sīho sahanato ca hananato
analyzed: vā nādam nadati ayam atthaḥ sīhanāda suttena dīpetabbaḥ yathā vā sīhaḥ sahanataḥ ca hananataḥ
translated: This meaning should be illustrated by the Lion’s Roar Discourse . Or just as a lion is called a “lion” because he is able to endure and to kill,

original: ca “sīho”ti vuccati, evaṃ tathāgatopi lokadhammānaṃ sahanato, parappavādānañca hananato
analyzed: ca sīhaḥ ti vuccati evam tathāgataḥ api loka dhammānam sahanato para ppavādānam ca hananato
translated: so too the Tathāgata is called a “lion” because he is able to endure the world’s phenomena and to kill opposing doctrines.

original: “sīho”ti vuccati, tassa nādaṃ nadati.🔽Brahmacakkantiādīsu brahmanti uttamaṃ visuddhaṃ. Cakka-saddo panāyaṃ “cattārimāni,
analyzed: sīhaḥ ti vuccati tassa nādam nadati  brahma cakka nti ādīsu brahmanti uttamam visuddham cakka saddo pana ayam cattārimāni
translated: He roars his roar.

original: bhikkhave, cakkāni, yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussāna”ntiādīsu sampattiyaṃ dissati.
analyzed: bhikkhave cakkāni yehi samannāgatānam deva manussānam ti ādīsu sampattiyam dissati
translated: Brahma wheel, etc.: Brahma is the highest, the pure. But the word “wheel” is seen in the expression of excellence in such passages as: “Monks, there are these four wheels, possessed with which gods and humans … “

original: “Pādatalesu cakkāni jātānī”tiādīsu lakkhaṇe. “Cakkaṃva vahato pada”nti ettha rathaṅge.
analyzed: pāda talesu cakkāni jātāni iti ādīsu lakkhaṇe cakkam iva vahataḥ ettha rathaṅge
translated: In such passages as “The wheels appeared on his feet” , it is a mark. In the passage “The wheel follows the one who goes” , it is a part of a chariot.

original: “Catucakkaṃ navadvāra”nti ettha iriyāpathe. “Cakkaṃ pavattaya sabbapāṇina”nti ettha
analyzed: catu cakkam nava dvāram ti ettha iriyāpathe cakkam pavattaya sabba pāṇinam ti ettha
translated: In the passage “The four-spoked wheel, the nine-doors” , it is a posture. In the passage “The wheel is set rolling for the sake of all beings” ,

original: dāne. “Dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti ettha ratanacakke. “Icchāhatassa posassa,🔽cakkaṃ bhamati matthake”ti ettha uracakke. “Khurapariyantena cepi cakkenā”ti ettha
analyzed: dāne dibbam cakka ratanam pātuḥ ahosi iti ettha ratana cakke icchā hatassa posassa  cakkam bhamati matthaka iti ettha ura cakke khura pariyantena cepi cakkena ati ettha
translated: it is giving. In the passage “The divine wheel-gem appeared” , it is a gem-wheel. In the passage “For the man who is struck down by desire,🔽the wheel revolves in his head” , it is a breast-wheel. In the passage “Even with a wheel that has a razor edge” ,

original: paharaṇacakke. “Asanicakka”nti ettha asanimaṇḍale. “Mayā pavattitaṃ cakka”nti ettha
analyzed: paharaṇa cakke ettha asani maṇḍale mayā pavattitam cakkanti ettha
translated: it is a weapon-wheel. In the passage “The wheel of the lightning flash” , it is a circle of lightning. In the passage “The wheel has been set rolling by me” ,

original: dhammacakke. Idha pana dhammacakke pavattati.🔽Dhammacakkañca duvidhaṃ hoti paṭivedhañāṇañca desanāñāṇañca. Tattha paññāpabhāvitaṃ
analyzed: dhammacakke idha pana dhammacakke pavattati  dhamma cakkañca duvidham hoti paṭivedha ñāṇañca desanā ñāṇañca tattha paññā apabhāvitam
translated: it is the Dhamma-wheel. Here it is the Dhamma-wheel that is meant.🔽The Dhamma-wheel is twofold, namely, the knowledge of penetration and the knowledge of teaching. Herein, the supramundane knowledge of penetration, which is developed by understanding and which brings about the noble fruits for oneself,

original: attano ariyaphalāvahaṃ lokuttaraṃ paṭivedhañāṇaṃ, karuṇāpabhāvitaṃ sāvakānaṃ ariyaphalāvahaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ ariya phala āvaham lokuttaram paṭivedha ñāṇam karuṇā pabhāvitam sāvakānam ariya phala āvaham
translated: is the knowledge of penetration. The knowledge of teaching, which is developed by compassion and which brings about the noble fruits for disciples,

original: kāmāvacaraṃ desanāñāṇaṃ, ubhayampi panetaṃ aññehi asādhāraṇaṃ buddhānaññeva orasañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: kāmāvacaram desanā ñāṇam ubhayam pi pana itam aññehi asādhāraṇam buddha anaññā iva orasa ñāṇam
translated: Knowledge of teaching in the sense-desire world. But both these kinds are the special knowledge of Buddhas, not shared by others.

original: taṃ pavatteti uppādeti vibhāveti vitthārikaṃ karotīti attho.🔽Idāni yāni dasa ñāṇāni ādito “tathāgatabalānī”ti nikkhittāni, tāni vitthāretuṃ “katamāni
analyzed: tam uppādeti vibhāveti vitthārikam karoti iti attho  idāni yāni dasa ñāṇāni āditas tathāgata balāni iti nikkhittāni tāni vitthāretum katamāni
translated: He sets it going, he causes it to arise, he makes it manifest, he makes it spread, is the meaning.

original: dasa? Idha tathāgato”tiādimāha. Tattha ṭhānañca ṭhānatoti kāraṇañca kāraṇato. Kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: dasa idha tathāgataḥ ti ādim āha tattha ṭhānam ca ṭhānato iti kāraṇam ca kāraṇato kāraṇam
translated: Now, as to the ten kinds of knowledge that were listed at the beginning as “The Enlightened One’s powers” , he now said “What are the ten? Here the Enlightened One” in order to elaborate them. Herein, the possible as the possible and the impossible as the impossible is the cause as the cause and the non-cause as the non-cause.

original: hi yasmā tattha phalaṃ tiṭṭhati tadāyattavuttitāya uppajjati ceva pavattati ca, tasmā🔽ṭhānanti vuccati. Aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānatoti akāraṇañca akāraṇato. Yampīti yena ñāṇena
analyzed: hi yasmai tattha phalam tiṭṭhati tad āyatta vutti tāya uppajjati ca iva pavattati ca tasmai  ṭhānanti vuccati aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānato ti akāraṇam ca akāraṇataḥ yam pi iti yena ñāṇena
translated: For since the fruit is there, it is called the possible since it is present there, since it arises and occurs owing to that,🔽and the non-cause is the impossible since the fruit is not there,🔽and the knowledge by means of which he understands as it actually is the possible as the possible and the impossible as the impossible,

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi ṭhānāṭhānañāṇaṃ tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ nāma hotīti
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti idam pi ṭhāna aṭhāna ñāṇam tathāgatassa tathāgata balam nāma hoti iti
translated: this knowledge of the possible and the impossible is called the Enlightened One’s power of the possible and the impossible.

original: attho. Evaṃ uparipi sabbattha yojanā veditabbā. Kathaṃ panettha bhagavā ṭhānañca
analyzed: evam upari pi sabbattha yojanā veditabbā katham pana ittha bhagavā ṭhānam ca
translated: The construction should be understood in each instance in this way. But how is it that the Blessed One is the possessor of this power?

original: ṭhānato, aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti? Aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso, yaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti a ṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam
translated: and the impossible as impossible? It is impossible, there is no way, that a person who has right view

original: diṭṭhisampanno puggalo kañci saṅkhāraṃ niccato upagaccheyya…pe… kañci dhammaṃ attato
analyzed: diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalo kañci saṅkhāram niccatas upagaccheyya pe kañci dhammaṃ attataḥ
translated: could regard anything as permanent, as happiness, as self, or as clean;

original: upagaccheyya, mātaraṃ jīvitā voropeyya, pitaraṃ…pe… arahantaṃ jīvitā voropeyya, paduṭṭhacittena
analyzed: upagaccheyya mātaram jīvitā voropeyya pitaraṃpe arahantam jīvitā voropeyya paduṭṭha cittena
translated: that he could deprive his mother of life, could deprive his father of life, could deprive an arahat of life,

original: tathāgatassa lohitaṃ uppādeyya, saṅghaṃ bhindeyya, aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddiseyya, aṭṭhamaṃ
analyzed: tathāgatassa lohitam uppādeyya saṅgham bhindeyya aññam satthāram uddiseyya aṭṭhamam
translated: could with a mind of hatred cause the Tathāgata to bleed, could cause a schism in the Saṅgha, could point out a different teacher,

original: bhavaṃ nibbatteyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati, puthujjano panetaṃ sabbaṃ kareyyāti ṭhānametaṃ🔽vijjatīti pajānāti, tathā yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṃ🔽acarimaṃ uppajjeyyuṃ, tathā dve rājāno cakkavattī uppajjeyyuṃ, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati,
analyzed: bhavam nibbatteyya na itam ṭhānam vijjati puthujjanaḥ pana itam sabbam kareyya ati ṭhānam etam  vijjati iti pajānāti tathā yam ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhāḥ apubbam  acarimam uppajjeyyum tathā dve rājāno cakkavattī uppajjeyyum na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: or could be reborn in hell, in the animal realm, or in the realm of ghosts. There is no such possibility. But it is possible that an ordinary person could do all these things.🔽So he knows this as it really is. And so too with the impossibility of two arahats, or two Universal Monarchs, arising in the same world without one preceding and the other following.

original: eko pana uppajjati, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatīti pajānāti, tathā yaṃ kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ pana uppajjati ṭhānam etam vijjati iti pajānāti tathā yam kāya duccarita ādīnam tiṇṇam
translated: But it is possible that one of them could arise. So he knows this as it really is. And so too with the impossibility of the three kinds of misconduct ever being called “the white path” or “the good way” or “the noble’s way” or “the way to heaven” or “the way to the world of Brahmā” or “the way that leads to what is wished for, desired, and agreeable,”

original: duccaritānaṃ iṭṭho vipāko, sucaritānañca aniṭṭho vipāko nibbatteyyāti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ🔽vijjati, tabbiparīto pana nesaṃ vipāko nibbatteyyāti ṭhānametaṃ vijjatīti, ye ye
analyzed: duccaritānam iṭṭhaḥ vipāko su caritānam ca aniṭṭhaḥ vipāko nibbatteyya ati na etam ṭhānam  vijjati tad biparītaḥ pana nesam vipākaḥ nibbatteyya iti ṭhānam etam vijjati iti ye ye
translated: There is no such room. But there is room for the opposite result.

original: dhammā yesaṃ yesaṃ dhammānaṃ hetū paccayā uppādāya, taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ, itare aṭṭhānanti🔽yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ettha panāyaṃ saṅkhepato aṭṭhakathāvinicchayo. “Sukhato upagaccheyyā”ti
analyzed: dhammāḥ yesam yesam dhammānam hetū paccayāḥ uppādāya tam tam ṭhānam itare aṭṭhānam ti  yathābhūtam pajānāti ettha pana ayam saṅkhepataḥ aṭṭhakathā vinicchayo sukhataḥ upagaccheyya iti
translated: The room for the arising of this or that state that has this or that state as its condition is a “room for that.” The opposite is a “no-room.”🔽He understands how there is room and no room for the arising of this or that state.🔽But here is a brief commentary on the text.

original: idaṃ “ekantasukhī attā”tiādinā diṭṭhivipallāsavasena sukhato gāhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ,🔽saññācittavipallāsavasena pana ariyasāvakopi kilesapariḷāhābhibhūto mattahatthiparitāsito
analyzed: idam ekanta sukhī attā ati ādinā diṭṭhi vipallāsa vasena sukhataḥ gāham sandhāya vuttam  saññā citta vipallāsa vasena pana ariya sāvakaḥ api kilesa pariḷāha abhibhūtaḥ matta hatthi paritāsito
translated: “He would misapprehend it as pleasant”: this is said with reference to the misapprehension of pleasure that occurs through the perversion of perception and view expressed thus: “The self is exclusively happy” .🔽But even a noble disciple, when overwhelmed by defilement and tormented by the fever of lust, misapprehends some formation as pleasant, just as a man scorched by heat misapprehends a flame as cool.

original: viya, sucikāmo gūthakūpaṃ viya kañci saṅkhāraṃ sukhato upagacchati, attato upagamanavāre
analyzed: viya su cikāmaḥ gūtha kūpam viya kañci saṅkhāram sukhataḥ upagacchati attataḥ upagamana vāre
translated: And in the case of the misapprehension of self,

original: kasiṇādipaṇṇattiyā, nibbānassa ca saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ “saṅkhāra”nti avatvā “kañci dhamma”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kasiṇa ādi paṇṇattiyāḥ nibbānassa ca saṅgaṇhana attham saṅkhāran ti avatvā kañci dhamman ti vuttam
translated: and in order to include Nibbāna, he said “any idea” instead of saying “a formation” as he did in the case of the kasiṇa and so on.

original: Mātarantiādīsu kiñcāpi ariyasāvako sīsacchedaṃ pāpuṇantopi kunthakipillikaṃ upādāya
analyzed: mātaranti ādīsu kiñca api ariya sāvakaḥ sīsa chedam pāpuṇantaḥ api kuntha kipillikam upādāya
translated: In the case of “mother” and the rest, although a noble disciple could not even commit killing living beings, beginning with a gnat or an ant,

original: pāṇātipātaṃ, adinnādānādīsu vā yaṃkiñci duccaritaṃ apāyahetubhūtaṃ kātuṃ bhavantarepi🔽na sakkoti, puthujjanabhāvassa pana mahāsāvajjatādassanatthamettha pañcānantariyāneva
analyzed: pāṇa atipātam adinnādāna ādīsu vā yaṃkiñcid duccaritam apāya hetu bhūtam kātum bhavantare pi  na sakkoti puthujjana bhāvassa pana mahā sāvajja tā dassana tham ettha pañca anantariyān eva
translated: or any kind of misconduct, beginning with taking what is not given, that would be a cause for his reappearance in states of loss,

original: uddhaṭāni. Sāvajjo hi puthujjanabhāvo, yatra hi nāma ānantariyānipi karissatīti.🔽Ettha ca manussabhūtasseva manussabhūtaṃ janikaṃ mātaraṃ, pitaraṃ vā api parivattaliṅgaṃ🔽jīvitā voropentassa kammaṃ ānantariyaṃ hoti. Tiracchānabhūtaṃ pana mātaraṃ, pitaraṃ
analyzed: uddhaṭāni sāvajjaḥ hi puthujjana bhāvaḥ yatra hi nāma ānantariyāni pi karissati iti  ettha ca manussa bhūtassa iva manussa bhūtam janikam mātaram pitaram vā api parivatta liṅgam  jīvitā voropentassa kammaṃ ānantariyam hoti tiracchāna bhūtam pana mātaram pitaram
translated: nevertheless the five crimes with a like result have been mentioned here in order to show how reprehensible the ordinary man’s state is, since he might even commit crimes with a like result.🔽For the ordinary man’s state is blameworthy, since he might even commit crimes with a like result.🔽And here, when a human being kills his own mother or father, who are human beings, by cutting off their heads, the action is a crime with a like result.

original: vā sayaṃ vā tiracchānabhūto manussabhūtaṃ, tiracchānabhūtaṃ vā jīvitā voropento ānantariyaṃ
analyzed: vā sayam vā tiracchāna bhūtaḥ manussa bhūtam tiracchāna bhūtam vā jīvitā voropentaḥ ānantariyam
translated: But if the mother or father is an animal, or if he himself is an animal, or if he kills a human being or an animal, the action is not a crime with a like result.

original: na phusati, kammaṃ pana bhāriyaṃ, ānantariyaṃ āhacceva tiṭṭhati. Arahantampi manussabhūtameva
analyzed: na phusati kammam pana bhāriyam ānantariyam āhacca iva tiṭṭhati arahantam pi manussa bhūtam eva
translated: One who kills an Arahant who is a human being crosses the threshold of the ānantariya.

original: ghātento ānantariyaṃ phusati. Tassa ca puthujjanakāle pahāraṃ datvā arahattaṃ patvā🔽tasmiṃ teneva rogena matepi arahantaghātako hoti, na yakkhabhūtaṃ arahantaṃ, sesaariyapuggale
analyzed: ghātentaḥ ānantariyam phusati tassa ca puthujjana kāle pahāram da tvā arahattam patvā  tasmin tena iva rogena mate pi arahanta ghātakaḥ hoti na yakkha bhūtam arahantam sesa ariya puggale
translated: And if he gives a blow to one who becomes an Arahant after he has given it, and he dies of that affliction, he is one who has killed an Arahant.

original: vā manussabhūtepi ghātento, kammaṃ pana ānantariyasadisaṃ hoti. Yaṃ pana puthujjanakāle
analyzed: vā manussa bhūte pi ghātento kammam pana ānantariya sadisam hoti yam pana puthujjana kāle
translated: But if he kills a non-human Arahant or a human Arahant other than the above, the kamma is similar to the ānantariya.

original: dinnaṃ dānaṃ arahattaṃ patvā paribhuñjati, puthujjanasseva taṃ dinnaṃ hoti, sesaariyapuggale
analyzed: dinnam dānam arahattam patvā paribhuñjati puthujjanassa iva tat dinnam hoti sesa ariya puggale
translated: But when one who has given a gift as a worldling enjoys it after he has reached Arahantship, it is given by him as a worldling.

original: mārentassa ānantariyaṃ natthi, kammaṃ pana garukaṃ hoti. Ettha ca eḷakādicatukkaṃ
analyzed: mārentassa ānantariyam natthi kammam pana garukam hoti ettha ca eḷaka ādi catukkam
translated: There is no ānantariya in killing the other Noble Persons, but the kamma is heavy.

original: veditabbaṃ – “eḷakaṃ māremī”ti hi abhisandhinā eḷakaṭṭhāne nipannaṃ mātaraṃ, pitaraṃ,
analyzed: veditabbam eḷakam mā āremi iti hi abhisandhinā eḷaka ṭṭhāne nipannam mātaram pitaram
translated: And here the four cases beginning with the goat should be understood. For if one has the intention, “I shall kill a goat,” and he kills his mother who is lying in the place of a goat, or his father who is lying there, or an Arahant, or a perfected one’s predecessor, or a paccekabuddha, or a fully enlightened Buddha, or a disciple of one of them, or a human being other than these, or even a large animal such as an elephant, he does not commit an ānantariya, but the kamma is similar to the ānantariya.

original: arahantaṃ vā mārento ānantariyaṃ phusati, eḷakābhisandhinā vā mātādiabhisandhinā
analyzed: arahantam vā mārentaḥ ānantariyam phusati eḷaka abhisandhinā vā mātā ādi abhisandhinā
translated: and if he kills an Arahant, he contacts the heinous kamma. But if he kills a bull elephant with the thought of killing his mother, etc.,

original: vā eḷakaṃ mārento ānantariyaṃ na phusati, mātādiabhisandhinā te eva mārento phusateva.
analyzed: vai eḷakam ānantariyam na phusati mātā ādi abhisandhinā te eva phusatā iva
translated: he does not contact the heinous kamma. But if he kills his mother, etc., with the thought of killing his mother, etc., he contacts the heinous kamma.

original: Esa nayo coracatukkādīsupi.🔽Lohituppāde tathāgatassa abhejjakāyatāya kuddhacittassa parassa upakkamena cammacchedo,
analyzed: e sa nayaḥ cora catukka ādī supi  lohituppāde tathāgatassa abhejja kāya tāya kuddha cittassa parassa upakkamena camma chedaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the case of the thief, the murderer, and the adulterer.🔽In the case of causing blood to flow from a Tathāgata, there is no cutting of the skin, no flowing of blood,

original: lohitapaggharaṇaṃ vā natthi, devadattena pana paviddhasilāto bhijjitvā gatasakkhalikappahārena
analyzed: lohita paggharaṇam vā natthi devadattena pana paviddha silātaḥ bhijjitvā gata sakkhalika ppahārena
translated: through the intention of one who is enraged with the Tathāgata’s person. But when Devadatta hurled down a boulder with the intention of killing the Tathāgata,

original: viya sarīrassa antoyeva ekasmiṃ ṭhāne yathā khuddikamakkhikāpivanamattampi lohitaṃ🔽visamaṃ samosarati, tathā karontassa ānantariyaṃ hoti, na pana jīvakasseva muducittena
analyzed: viya sarīrassa ekasmin ṭhāne yathā lohitam  visamam samosarati tathā karontassa ānantariyam hoti na pana jīvakassa iva mudu cittena
translated: a splinter of rock struck the Tathāgata’s foot and drew blood.🔽The heinous kamma is done by one who causes blood to flow in this way, not by one who causes blood to flow by removing with a sharp instrument the blood that has welled up under a boil, as did the Elder Jīvaka with the thought of benefiting .

original: duṭṭhalohitaṃ nīharitvā phāsukaṃ karontassa, puññameva panassa hoti, parinibbute
analyzed: duṭṭha lohitam nīharitvā phāsukam karontassa puññam eva pana assa hoti parinibbute
translated: The latter’s action is a source of merit.

original: bhagavati cetiyaṃ bhindantassa, bodhiṃ chindantassa, dhātūsu upakkamantassa ca ānantariyaṃ
analyzed: bhagavati cetiyam bhindantassa bodhim chindantassa dhātūsu upakkamantassa ca ānantariyam
translated: If one breaks a shrine, cuts down the Bodhi Tree, or attacks the relics, one does not commit a heinous deed,

original: na hoti, kammaṃ pana ānantariyasadisaṃ hoti. Bodhirukkhassa pana thūpaṃ vā sadhātukaṃ
analyzed: na hoti kammam pana ānantariya sadisam hoti bodhi rukkhassa pana thūpam vā sa dhātukam
translated: but the action is similar to a heinous deed. But if a branch of the Bodhi Tree is obstructing a shrine or a relic chamber,

original: paṭimaṃ vā bādhayamānaṃ sākhaṃ, cetiyavatthuṃ bhinditvā gacchantaṃ bodhimūlañca chinditvā
analyzed: paṭimam vā bādhayamānam sa akham cetiyavatthum bhinditvā gacchantam bodhi mūlañca chinditvā
translated: or if the Bodhi Tree is obstructing a path that leads to the shrine, or if the Bodhi Tree is obstructing the base of the shrine, then it is allowable to cut the branch.

original: harituṃ vaṭṭati. Sacepi sākhāya nilīnā sakuṇā cetiye vaccaṃ pātenti, chindituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: haritum vaṭṭati sace pi nilīnā sakuṇā cetiye vaccam chinditum vaṭṭati
translated: If birds roosting in the branch defecate on the shrine, then it is allowable to cut the branch.

original: Paribhogacetiyato hi sarīracetiyameva mahantataraṃ. Dhātunidhānarahitaṃ paṭimāgharaṃ
analyzed: paribhoga cetiyataḥ hi sarīra cetiyam eva mahantataram dhātu nidhāna rahitam paṭima agharam
translated: For a relic shrine is greater than a shrine for use. But if a branch of the Bodhi Tree is obstructing a relic chamber or a shrine for use,

original: vā bodhigharaṃ vā bādhentaṃ sākhaṃ chindituṃ na vaṭṭati, ojoharaṇasākhaṃ, panassa
analyzed: vā bodhigharam vā bādhentam sākham chinditum na vaṭṭati ojaḥ haraṇa sākham panassa
translated: or if it is obstructing a Buddha image house or a Bodhi shrine, then it is not allowable to cut the branch. But if the branch is sucking up the moisture,

original: pūtiṭṭhānaṃ vā chindituṃ vaṭṭati, sarīrapaṭijaggane viya puññameva hoti.
analyzed: pūtiṭṭhānam vā chinditum vaṭṭati sarīra paṭijaggane viya puññam eva hoti
translated: or if it is rotten, then it is allowable to cut it. It is a merit-making act, just like the care of the body.

original: Saṅghabhede samānasaṃvāsasīmāya samānasaṃvāsake saṅghe ekato ṭhite visuṃ vaggasaṅghaṃ
analyzed: saṅgha bhede samāna saṃvāsa sīmāya samāna saṃvāsake saṅghe ekatas ṭhite visum vagga saṅgham
translated: In the case of schism in the Sangha, if the Sangha of the same affiliation is united in one place, then a separate faction of the Sangha

original: gahetvā pañcahi kāraṇehi saṅghaṃ bhindantassa saṅghabhedo hoti ānantariyakammañca.
analyzed: gahetvā pañcahi kāraṇehi saṅgham bhindantassa saṅgha bhedaḥ hoti ānantariya kammaṃ ca
translated: He severs the Sangha by holding it and dividing it on the basis of five actions.🔽For it is said, “Upāli, the Sangha is split by means of five actions. What are the five?

original: Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “pañcahi, upāli, ākārehi saṅgho bhijjati. Katamehi pañcahi? Kammena
analyzed: vuttam ha etam pañcahi upāli ākārehi saṅghaḥ bhijjati katamehi pañcahi kammena
translated: By a legal procedure,

original: uddesena voharanto anussāvanena salākaggāhenā”ti. Tattha kammenāti apalokanādīsu
analyzed: uddesena voharantaḥ anussāvanena salākaggāhena ati tattha kammena ati apalokana ādīsu
translated: by recitation, by speaking, by proclamation, by voting with counting sticks.”

original: catūsu aññatarena kammena. Uddesenāti pātimokkhuddesena. Voharanto kathayanto tāhi
analyzed: catūsu aññatarena kammena uddesena ati pātimokkha uddesena voharanto kathayanto tāhi
translated: Herein, by a legal procedure means by any one of the four legal procedures beginning with the information procedure.🔽By recitation means by the recitation of the Monastic Code.

original: tāhi upapattīhi “adhammaṃ dhammo”tiādīni aṭṭhārasa bhedakaravatthūni dīpento. Anussāvanenāti🔽“nanu tumhe jānātha mayhaṃ bahussutādibhāvaṃ, kathaṃ hi nāma mādiso uddhammaṃ ubbinayaṃ
analyzed: tāhi upapattīhi adhammam dhamma uti ādīni aṭṭhārasa bheda kara vatthūni dīpentaḥ anussāvanena ati  nanu tumhe jānātha mayham bahu ssuta ādi bhāvam katham hi nāma mādisaḥ uddhammam ubbinayam
translated: By speaking means by speaking, by teaching, by explaining the eighteen bases for schism beginning with “What is contrary to the Teaching is the Teaching,”

original: satthusāsanaṃ gāheyya, kimahaṃ apāyato na bhāyāmī”tiādinā nayena kaṇṇamūle vacībhedaṃ
analyzed: satthu sāsanam gāheyya kim aham apāyataḥ na bhāyāmi itiādinā nayena kaṇṇa mūle vacī bhedam
translated: by proclamation means by whispering in the ear, saying, “Don’t you know that I’m learned and so on? How could someone like me hold a view that’s contrary to the Teaching and the training? Why should I be afraid of the lower realms?”

original: katvā anussāvanena. Salākaggāhenāti evaṃ vohārānussāvanehi tesaṃ cittaṃ upatthambhetvā
analyzed: katvā anussāvanena salākaggāhena ati evam vohāra anussāvanehi tesam cittam upatthambhetvā
translated: By voting with counting sticks means that, after encouraging their minds by speaking and whispering, they vote with counting sticks.

original: anivattidhammaṃ katvā “gaṇhatha imaṃ salāka”nti salākaggāhena.
analyzed: a nivatti dhammam katvā gaṇhatha imam salākam ti salākaggāhena
translated: and he makes them take up the ticket, saying, “Take up this ticket, ” then the schism in the Community is accomplished.

original: Ettha ca kammameva uddeso vā pamāṇaṃ, vohārānussāvanasalākaggāhā pana pubbabhāgā.🔽Tesu nipphannesupi abhinnova hoti saṅgho. Yadā pana vohārānussāvanehi cattāro vā
analyzed: ettha ca kammam eva uddesaḥ vā pamāṇam vohāra anussāvana salākaggāhā pana pubbabhāgā  tesu nipphannesu pi abhinnaḥ va hoti saṅghaḥ yadā pana vohāra anussāvanehi cattāraḥ vā
translated: And here the act itself is the proclamation or the measure, while the announcement, the motion, and the taking up of the ticket are the preliminaries.

original: atireke vā bhikkhū salākaṃ gāhetvā vaggaṃ saṅghaṃ gahetvā visuṃ kammaṃ vā uddesaṃ🔽vā karoti, tadā saṅgho bhinno nāma hoti. Abhedapurekkhārassa pana samaggasaññāya
analyzed: atireke vā bhikkhū salākam gāhetvā vaggam saṅgham gahetvā visum kammam vā uddesam  vā karoti tadā saṅghaḥ bhinnaḥ nāma hoti abheda purekkhārassa pana samagga saññāya
translated: And even when these are finished, the Community is still not split. But when four or more bhikkhus take up the ticket after the announcement and the motion and then perform the act or the proclamation separately from the Community, then the Community is said to be split.

original: vaṭṭati. Samaggasaññāya hi karontassa neva bhedo hoti, na ānantariyaṃ, tathā tato
analyzed: vaṭṭati samagga saññāya hi karontassa nā iva bhedaḥ hoti na ānantariyam tathā tatas
translated: But it is allowable for one who is intent on non-division to do it with the perception of unity. For if he does it with the perception of unity, there is no schism and no offence of immediate effect, nor is there if he does it with a number that is less than the requisite number.

original: ūnaparisāya karontassa. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “ekato, upāli, cattāro honti ekato cattāro,
analyzed: ūna parisāya karontassa vuttam ha etam ekatas upāli cattāraḥ honti ekatas cattāro
translated: For this is said: “There are four on one side, Upāli, and four on the other,

original: navamo anussāvetī”tiādi.
analyzed: navamaḥ anussāveti itiādi
translated: and a ninth one announces it” , and so on.

original: Imesu pana pañcasu ānantariyesu saṅghabhedo vacīkammaṃ, sesāni kāyakammāni, sabbāneva
analyzed: imesu pana pañcasu ānantariyesu saṅgha bhedaḥ vacī kammam sesāni kāya kammāni sabbān eva
translated: But of these five offences of immediate effect, schism in the Community is verbal action, while the rest are bodily action. All are

original: kho tāni kāyadvāratopi vacīdvāratopi samuṭṭhahanti. Saṅghabhedopi hi hatthamuddāya🔽bhedaṃ karontassa kāyadvāratopi samuṭṭhāti, saṅghabhedo cettha kappaṭṭhitiyo. Kappavināse🔽eva hi saṅghabhedato muccati, sesānaṃ pana tathā niyamo natthi. Yena ca pañcapetāni🔽kammāni katāni honti, tassa saṅghabhedova niraye vipaccati, sesāni “ahosi kammaṃ
analyzed: kho tāni kāya dvārataḥ api vacī dvārataḥ api samuṭṭhahanti saṅgha bhedaḥ upi hi hattham uddāya  bhedam karontassa kāya dvārataḥ pi samuṭṭhāti saṅgha bhedaḥ ca ittha kappa ṭṭhitiyaḥ kappa vināse  eva hi saṅgha bhedataḥ muccati sesānam pana tathā niyamaḥ natthi yena ca  kammāni katāni honti tassa saṅgha bhedaḥ uva niraye vipaccati sesāni ahosi kammam
translated: They arise through the door of the body and through the door of speech. For schism in the Community arises through the door of the body when one makes schism by raising one’s hand,🔽and through the door of speech when one makes schism by speech. Herein, schism in the Community lasts for the time being. For one is freed from schism in the Community only with the destruction of the aeon. But there is no such rule for the rest.🔽And of one who has done the five actions of immediate result, only schism in the Community ripens in hell. The rest are as follows:🔽🔽

original: nāhosi kammavipāko”ti evamādīsu saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Saṅghabhedābhāve lohituppādo,🔽tadabhāve arahantaghāto, tadabhāve mātughāto, pitughāto vā, tasmimpi sīlasampannatare.🔽Purimāni cettha cattāri sabbesaṃ gahaṭṭhapabbajitānaṃ sādhāraṇāni, saṅghabhedo pana🔽pakatattassa bhikkhunova, asādhāraṇo aññesaṃ, bhikkhunīpi hi saṅghaṃ na bhindati,
analyzed: evamādīsu saṅkhyam gacchanti saṅgha bheda abhāve lohita uppādaḥ 🔽tad abhāve arahantaghātaḥ tad abhāve mātughātaḥ pitughātaḥ vā tasmin pi sīla sampannatare 🔽purimāni ca ittha cattāri sabbesam gaha ṭṭha pabbajitānam sādhāraṇāni saṅgha bhedaḥ pana 🔽pakatattassa bhikkhuno va asādhāraṇaḥ aññesam bhikkhunī pi hi saṅgham na bhindati
translated: They arise through the door of the body and through the door of speech. Schism in the Community arises through the door of the body of one who makes schism by raising his hand. Schism in the Community lasts for an aeon. For one is freed from schism in the Community only with the dissolution of the aeon. But there is no such rule for the rest. And for one who has committed the five offences entailing expulsion, only schism in the Community will ripen in hell. The rest are reckoned thus: “There was action, but there was no ripening of the action” , etc. In the absence of schism in the Community, causing the blood to flow is the most serious. In the absence of that, killing an Arahant. In the absence of that, killing one’s mother. In the absence of that, killing one’s father. In the absence of that, killing an Arahant bhikkhu. In the absence of that, killing an Arahant bhikkhunī. In the absence of that, killing an Arahant male lay follower. In the absence of that, killing an Arahant female lay follower. In the absence of that, causing a schism in the Community. In the absence of that, causing a division in the Community. In the absence of that, causing a bhikkhu to lapse from moral habit. In the absence of that, causing a bhikkhunī to lapse from moral habit. In the absence of that, causing a male lay follower to lapse from moral habit. In the absence of that, causing a female lay follower to lapse from moral habit. In the absence of that, having wrong view. In the absence of that, stealing the Community’s property. In the absence of that, stealing the property of the four types of shrine. In the absence of that, stealing the property of the Community. In the absence of that, stealing the property of a group. In the absence of that, stealing the property of an individual. In the absence of that, taking what has not been given from the bhikkhus. In the absence of that, taking what has not been given from the bhikkhunīs. In the absence of that, taking what has not been given from the male lay followers. In the absence of that, taking what has not been given from the female lay followers. In the absence of that, taking what has not been given from the ascetics. In the absence of that,

original: pageva itare. Pañcapi cetāni dukkhavedanāsampayuttāni, dosamūlāni cāti veditabbāni.
analyzed: pageva itare pañca api cetāni dukkha vedanā sampayuttāni dosa mūlāni ca ati veditabbāni
translated: And all five should be understood as associated with pain and as rooted in hate.

original: Aṭṭhamaṃ bhavaṃ nibbatteyyāti ettha ariyasāvakassa aṭṭhamabhavāgahaṇaṃ kena niyāmitanti?
analyzed: aṭṭhamam bhavam nibbatteyya ti ettha ariya sāvakassa aṭṭhama bhava āgahaṇam kena niyāmitan ti
translated: As regards the phrase “he might take up an eighth existence,” by what is a noble disciple’s taking up of an eighth existence limited?

original: Vipassanāya. Yassa hi sā tikkhā, so ekaṃ eva bhavaṃ nibbattitvā arahattaṃ patvā ekabījī
analyzed: vipassanāya yassa hi sā tikkhā saḥ ekam eva bhavam nibbattitvā arahattam patvā ekabījī
translated: By insight. For one whose insight is keen takes up only one existence, is reborn once , and then attains Arahantship.

original: nāma hoti. Yassa mandā, so dutiye…pe… chaṭṭhe vā bhave arahattaṃ patvā kolaṃkolo🔽nāma hoti. Yassa pana atimandā, so sattamaṃ bhavaṃ nātikkamati, tattha niyamena arahattaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti yassa mandā saḥ dutiye pe chaṭṭhe vā bhave arahattam patvā kolaṃkolaḥ  nāma hoti yassa pana ati mandā so sattamam bhavam na atikkamati tattha niyamena arahattam
translated: One whose insight is sluggish takes up two … six existences, is reborn seven times , and then attains Arahantship.

original: pāpuṇitvā sattakkhattuparamo nāma hoti. Sacepi hissa sattame bhave niddaṃ okkantassa
analyzed: pāpuṇitvā sattakkhattuparamaḥ nāma hoti sace pi hissa sattame bhave niddam okkantassa
translated: But one whose insight is very sluggish does not exceed the seventh existence, and there he attains Arahantship with certainty. He is called “one who goes to perdition in seven existences at most.”

original: matthake asani vā pabbatakūṭo vā pateyya, tasmimpi kāle arahattaṃ patvāva parinibbāti.
analyzed: matthake asani vā pabbata kūṭaḥ vā pateyya tasmim pi kāle arahattam patvā ava parinibbāti
translated: For even if a thunderbolt were to fall on his head while he is asleep, he would still attain Arahantship at that moment.

original: Uttamakoṭiyā hi sattamabhavānatikkamanaññeva sandhāyeva “niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti vuttoti.
analyzed: uttama koṭiyā hi sandhāya iva niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti
translated: For it is only the exceeding of the seventh existence that is referred to by the words “he is certain of attaining enlightenment and is bound to do so in seven existences at most” .

original: Ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhātiādīsu dasasahassacakkavāḷasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahantaḥ sammāsambuddhā ati ādīsu dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa saṅkhātam
translated: In the case of the statements “two Arahant Perfect Buddhas in one world-sphere” and so on, a world-sphere is the field of a single great trisāhasra universe consisting of a thousand times a thousand times a thousand world-systems .

original: jātikhettaṃ ekā lokadhātu nāma āṇāvisayakhettesu buddhuppattisaṅkāya evābhāvato.
analyzed: jāti khettam ekā lokadhātu nāma āṇā visaya khettesu buddha uppatti saṅkāyaḥ eva abhāvato
translated: It is called a “world-sphere” because it is the sphere of a single great Brahmā’s sovereignty.

original: Tattha dvinnaṃ buddhānaṃ uppattipaṭisedhaṃ akatvā jātikhette eva kato. Ṭhapetvā imaṃ
analyzed: tattha dvinnam buddhānam uppatti paṭisedham a katvā jāti khette eva kato ṭhapetvā imam
translated: Herein, the statement is made without any distinction of field of birth, since there is no possibility of the arising of two Buddhas in the same field of sovereignty.

original: cakkavāḷaṃ aññasmiṃ cakkavāḷe buddhā na uppajjanti buddhattahetūnaṃ anādibuddhaparamparādīnaṃ🔽tathābhāvā. Tato eva hi sattā niravasesato nibbutiṃ na pāpuṇanti. Yadi hi sabbacakkavāḷesu
analyzed: cakkavāḷam aññasmin cakkavāḷe buddhāḥ na uppajjanti buddha tta hetūnam anādi buddha paramparā ādīnam  tathābhāvāḥ tatas eva hi sattāḥ niravasesataḥ nibbutim na pāpuṇanti yadi hi sabba cakkavāḷesu
translated: Buddhas do not arise in any other world-sphere than this one, because the conditions for Buddhahood, namely, the succession of Buddhas without interruption, etc.,

original: buddhā uppajjeyyuṃ, sabbe sattā ito pubbe niravasesato nibbutiṃ pāpuṇeyyuṃ, na ca
analyzed: buddhāḥ uppajjeyyum sabbe sattāḥ itas pubbe niravasesataḥ nibbutim pāpuṇeyyum na ca
translated: are not found there. For it is precisely because of this that beings there do not attain extinction without remainder. If Buddhas were to arise in all world-spheres, then all beings would have attained extinction without remainder long ago,

original: taṃ atthi, tasmā anādibuddhaparamparāya vivaṭṭūpanissayasampannānaṃ nivāsabhūte imasmiṃ
analyzed: tam atthi tasmai anādi buddha paramparāya vivaṭṭu upanissaya sampannānam nivāsa bhūte imasmin
translated: and that is not so. Therefore it should be understood that Buddhas arise only in this world-sphere, which is the abode of those who possess the conditions for the opening of the succession of Buddhas without interruption.

original: cakkavāḷe eva uppajjantīti veditabbā. Te cetthāpi dullabhā, tesaṃ dullabhattā evettha
analyzed: cakkavāḷe eva uppajjanti iti veditabbā te ca itthā api dullabhā tesam dullabha ttā eva itthā
translated: And even here they are rare, for it is rare that they should arise here.

original: kappānaṃ asaṅkhyeyyampi buddhuppādarahitaṃ hoti. Yadi ca te sulabhā bhaveyyuṃ, ekasmiṃ
analyzed: kappānam asaṅkhyeyyam pi buddhuppāda rahitam hoti yadi ca te sulabhāḥ bhaveyyum ekasmin
translated: and it is possible for a whole incalculable age to pass without a Buddha arising. And if Buddhas were easy to find,

original: vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyiasaṅkhyeyye catusaṭṭhibuddhānampi uppajjituṃ sakkā bhaveyya antarakappassa🔽buddhantarattā. Bhaddakappesu cettha pañca buddhā eva uppajjanti. Kathaṃ panetthāpi
analyzed: vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyi asaṅkhyeyye catur aṭṭhi buddhānam pi uppajjitum sakkā bhaveyya antara kappassa  buddhantarattāḥ bhaddakappesu ca ittha pañca buddhāḥ eva uppajjanti katham pana itthā api
translated: and it is possible for a whole asaṅkheyya of world-cycles to pass without a Buddha arising. And if Buddhas were easy to find, it would be possible for sixty-four Buddhas to arise in a single asaṅkheyya of world-cycles, because there is no Buddha in an intermediate world-cycle.🔽But in the fortunate world-cycles only five Buddhas arise.

original: dullabhatarā cakkavāḷantaresu uppajjeyyuṃ, buddhānañca dullabhatā kāraṇadullabhatāya,
analyzed: dullabhatarā cakkavāḷantaresu uppajjeyyum buddhānam ca dullabha tā kāraṇa dullabha tāya
translated: But how could they arise in the peripheral continents, which are even more difficult to reach? And the difficulty of a Buddha arising is due to the difficulty of the conditions.

original: tasmā imasmiññeva cakkavāḷe buddhā uppajjanti? Etthāpi na devabrahmalokesu, manussaloke
analyzed: tasmai imasmin ñeva cakkavāḷe buddhāḥ uppajjanti ettha api na deva brahma lokesu manussa loke
translated: Therefore Buddhas arise only in this Rose-Apple Continent. And here too they do not arise in the divine or Brahmā worlds,

original: eva pana uppajjanti ettheva sabbaso tividhasaddhammādhārassa saṅgharatanassa pātubhāvato,🔽itaralokesu niravasesato pakārāsambhavato ca.
analyzed: eva pana uppajjanti ettha iva sabbaso tividha saddhamma ādhārassa saṅgha ratanassa pātubhāvato  itara lokesu niravasesataḥ pakāra asambhavataḥ ca
translated: but only in the human world, because only here is the jewel of the Saṅgha, the bearer of the Triple Good, found in its entirety.

original: Yadi hi buddhā devalokādīsu uppajjeyyuṃ, manussā bhayena upasaṅkamitumeva na sakkonti,
analyzed: yadi hi buddhāḥ deva loka ādīsu uppajjeyyum manussāḥ bhayena upasaṅkamitum eva na sakkonti
translated: For if Buddhas were to arise in the divine world, etc., people would be afraid and would not even approach them.

original: pageva dhammasavanapabbajjādiṃ kātuṃ, teneva amhākaṃ bodhisatto attano rūpakāyānubhāvādisampattiyā
analyzed: pagā iva dhamma savana pabbajja ādim kātum tena iva amhākam bodhisatto attanaḥ rūpa kāya anubhāva ādi sampattiyā
translated: how much more so to listen to the Dhamma, to go forth, and so on. Therefore, our Bodhisatta, in order to satisfy the people who had become curious about his human nature,

original: uppannaamanussasaṅkākutūhalaṃ janaṃ nijjhāpetuṃ uttānaseyyakādiniyāmena vaḍḍhitvā🔽dārapariggahādiṃ akāsi, evaṃ katvā pabbajitampi naṃ rājagahe piṇḍāya pavisitvā paṇḍavapabbatapasse
analyzed: uppanna amanussa saṅkā kutūhalam janam nijjhāpetum uttānaseyyaka ādi niyāmena vaḍḍhitvā  dāra pariggaha ādim akāsi evam katvā pabbajitam pi nam rājagahe piṇḍāya pavisitvā paṇḍava pabbata passe
translated: grew up in the manner of an ordinary child, and then🔽took a wife, and so on. After he had done so, King Bimbisāra, who had observed his human nature in various ways,

original: nisīditvā piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjantaṃ bimbisāro nānappakārato manussabhāvaṃ vicinitvāva
analyzed: nisīditvā piṇḍapātam paribhuñjantam bimbisāraḥ nānappakārataḥ manussa bhāvam vicinitvā ava
translated: was able to approach him while he was sitting on the side of the Paṇḍava mountain,

original: upasaṅkamituṃ visahi, no aññathā. Lokanitthāraṇatthāya hi buddhā uppajjanti, na attano
analyzed: upasaṅkamitum no aññathā loka nitthāraṇa tthāya hi buddhāḥ uppajjanti na attanaḥ
translated: after having entered Rājagaha for alms, and eating his meal, but not otherwise. For the Buddhas appear in the world for the purpose of liberating the world, not for the purpose of their own

original: sakkārādiatthāya, tasmā manussesu eva uppajjantīti veditabbo. Tatthāpi imasmiṃ jambudīpe
analyzed: sakkāra ādi atthāya tasmā manussesu eva uppajjanti iti veditabbaḥ tattha api imasmim jambudīpe
translated: honour and so on. Therefore, it should be understood that they appear only among human beings. And even among human beings, they appear

original: eva, tatthāpi imasmiṃ majjhimapadese eva. Na kevalañca buddhāva, paccekabuddhā, aggasāvakamahāsāvakā
analyzed: eva tattha api imasmin majjhima padese eva na kevalañca paccekabuddhāḥ aggasāvaka mahāsāvakā
translated: only in this Rose-Apple Island. And even in this Rose-Apple Island, they appear only in the Middle Country. And not only Buddhas, but also Paccekabuddhas, chief disciples, great disciples,

original: ca cakkavattiādayo ca aññepi puññavantasattā ettheva uppajjanti.
analyzed: ca cakkavatti ādayaḥ ca aññe pi ettha iva uppajjanti
translated: and also Wheel-turning Monarchs and other meritorious beings.🔽“He has not gone before”: before the conception in the mother’s womb there is what is called “the past,”

original: Apubbaṃ acarimanti ettha mātukucchismiṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇato pure pubbaṃ nāma, dhātuantaradhānato🔽pacchā carimaṃ nāma, ubhinnamantarā apubbaṃ acarimaṃ nāma. Etthantare aññassa buddhassa
analyzed: a pubbam a cariman ti ettha mātukucchismim paṭisandhi ggahaṇataḥ pure pubbam nāma dhātu antara dhānataḥ  pacchā carimam nāma ubhinnam antarā apubbam acarimam nāma etthantare aññassa buddhassa
translated: and after the disappearance of the relics there is what is called “the future,”

original: uppatti nivāritā, dhātuantaradhāne pana jāte aññassa uppatti na nivāritā. Kiñcāpi
analyzed: uppatti nivāritā dhātu antara dhāne pana jāte aññassa uppatti na nivāritā kiñcā api
translated: but between these two there is what is called “the present.” In this interval the arising of another Buddha is prevented. But when the disappearance of the relics has taken place, the arising of another Buddha is not prevented.

original: na nivāritā, antarakappaṃ pana khepetvāva uppajjantīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: na nivāritāḥ antara kappam pana khepetvā ava uppajjanti iti veditabbam
translated: Although it is not prevented, it should be understood that he arises only after the lapse of an eon.

original: Pañca hi antaradhānāni nāma adhigamaantaradhānaṃ paṭipattiantaradhānaṃ pariyattiantaradhānaṃ
analyzed: pañca hi antaradhānāni nāma adhigama antaradhānam paṭipatti antaradhānam pariyatti antaradhānam
translated: For there are five kinds of disappearance, namely, disappearance of the attainment, disappearance of the practice, disappearance of the scriptures,

analyzed: liṅga antaradhānam dhātu antaradhānam ti tattha adhigamaḥ ti magga phala abhiññā paṭisambhidāyo 🔽saḥ parihāyamānaḥ paṭisambhidātaḥ paṭṭhāya parihāyati parinibbānataḥ hi vassa sahassam eva
translated: disappearance of the symbols, and disappearance of the relics. Herein, the attainment is the path, fruition, and higher knowledge.🔽The practice is the practice of the path. The scriptures are the three Piṭakas. The symbols are the going for alms, etc., and the wearing of the ochre robe, etc.🔽The relics are the bodily relics.

translated: and they are able to produce the analytical knowledges, then after that the kinds of direct knowledge, and they are able to produce these too,

translated: and the first is not interrupted. But the last bhikkhu’s practice is interrupted either by his breaking the virtue or by his death.

original: paṭipatti antarahitā nāma hoti. Idaṃ paṭipattiantaradhānaṃ nāma.🔽Pariyattīti sāṭṭhakathaṃ tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ, gacchante gacchante kāle adhammikehi🔽kaliyugarājādīhi vipannasassādisampattitāya paccayadāyakā duggatā honti, bhikkhū
analyzed: paṭipatti antarahitā nāma hoti idam paṭipatti antaradhānam nāma  pariyatti iti sa aṭṭhakatham tepiṭakam buddha vacanam gacchante gacchante kāle adhammikehi  kali yuga rāja ādīhi vipanna sassa ādi sampatti tāya paccaya dāyakāḥ duggatāḥ honti bhikkhū
translated: This is called the disappearance of the practice.🔽The disappearance of the scriptures: the eight-part sutta-piṭaka, the Buddha’s word, is the scriptures. As time goes on, the people who give requisites become poor because of the failure of the crops, etc., due to the unrighteousness of the kings of the Kali age, etc.,

analyzed: ca paccayehi kilamantāḥ antevāsike gahetum na sakkonti tatas aṭṭhakathā parihāyati  pāḷi vasena iva pariyattim dhārenti tatas pāḷim sakalam dhāretum na sakkonti paṭhamam

original: abhidhammapiṭakaṃ parihāyati, tañcassa parihāyanaṃ matthakato paṭhāya. Paṭhamameva
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭakam parihāyati tat ca assa parihāyanam matthakataḥ paṭhāya paṭhamam eva
translated: and its disappearance begins from the top. For the first

analyzed: hi mahā apakaraṇam parihāyati tatas yamakam kathā vatthu puggala paññatti dhātu kathā
translated: book, the great book, disappears first, then the Yamaka, the Kathāvatthu, the Puggalapaññatti, the Dhatukathā,

original: vibhaṅgo dhammasaṅgaho ca anukkamena parihāyanti, tato matthakato paṭṭhāya suttantapiṭakaṃ
analyzed: vibhaṅgaḥ dhamma saṅgaho ca anukkamena parihāyanti tatas matthakataḥ paṭṭhāya suttanta piṭakam
translated: and the Vibhaṅga and the Dhammasanganī gradually disappear, after which the Suttapiṭaka

original: parihāyati, paṭhamaṃ hi aṅguttaranikāyo ekādasakanipātato paṭṭhāya yāvaekakanipātā
analyzed: parihāyati paṭhamam hi aṅguttara nikāyaḥ ekādasaka nipātataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvaekaka nipātā
translated: disappears. For the first to disappear is the Aṅguttara Nikāya, beginning with the Ekādasaka section and ending with the Ekakanipāta.

original: parihāyati, tato matthakato paṭṭhāya saṃyuttanikāyo, paṭhamaṃ hi mahāvaggo parihāyati,
analyzed: parihāyati tatas matthakataḥ paṭṭhāya saṃyutta nikāyo paṭhamam hi mahā vaggo parihāyati
translated: After that the Saṃyutta Nikāya disappears. For the first to disappear is the Mahāvagga,

original: tato saḷāyatanavaggo khandhakavaggo nidānavaggo sagāthāvaggoti, evaṃ majjhimanikāyadīghanikāyādayo🔽ca matthakato paṭṭhāya parihāyanti, tato vinayapiṭakameva tiṭṭhati, tampi parivārato
analyzed: tatas saḷāyatana vaggo khandhaka vaggo nidāna vaggo sagāthā vaggo ti evam majjhima nikāya dīgha nikāya ādayo  ca matthakato paṭṭhāya parihāyanti tatas vinayapiṭakam eva tiṭṭhati tam pi parivārato
translated: after which the Saḷāyatanavagga, the Khandhakajātaka, the Nidānavagga, and the Sagāthāvagga disappear. In the same way the Majjhima Nikāya, the Dīgha Nikāya, etc.,

original: paṭṭhāya yāva mahāvibhaṅgā parihāyati, tato uposathakkhandhakato mātikāmattameva
analyzed: paṭṭhāya yāva mahāvibhaṅgā parihāyati tatas uposatha khandhakataḥ mātikā mattam eva
translated: disappear, beginning with the last sutta in each. After that only the Vinaya Piṭaka remains. That too disappears, beginning with the Parivāra and ending with the Mahāvibhaṅga. After that they preserve only the mātikā of the Uposathakkhandhaka.

original: dhārenti, tadāpi yāva catuppadikāpi gāthā manussesu pavattati, tāva pariyatti anantarahitāva
analyzed: dhārenti tadā api yāva catuppadikā api gāthā manussesu pavattati tāva
translated: Even then the tradition is not interrupted as long as the four pādas of a stanza are still current among human beings.

original: hoti, tāya antarahitāya pariyatti antarahitā nāma hoti. Idaṃ pariyattiantaradhānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: hoti tāya antarahitāya pariyatti antarahitā nāma hoti idam pariyatti antaradhānam nāma
translated: and when that has disappeared, the learning that is dependent on it has disappeared. This is called the disappearance of the learning.

original: Gacchante gacchante kāle pattacīvaraggahaṇādiākappaṃ na pāsādikaṃ hoti, nigaṇṭhādayo🔽viya alābupattādiṃ aggabāhāya pakkhipitvāpi olambitvāpi sikkāya olaggetvāpi vicaranti,
analyzed: gacchante gacchante kāle patta cīvara ggahaṇa ādi ākappam na pāsādikam hoti nigaṇṭha ādayaḥ  viya alābu patta ādim agga bāhāya pakkhipitvā api olambitvā api sikkāya olaggetvā api vicaranti
translated: As time goes on, the practice of carrying the bowl and robe, etc., becomes unseemly, like the practice of the Jains,🔽who carry their pots on their shoulders, hanging from their necks, and so on.🔽The dyeing of the robes becomes unseemly, and they wear them the colour of pumpkin gourd. Then the dyeing and the patching of the robes

original: cīvararajanampi na sāruppaṃ, oṭṭhaṭṭhikavaṇṇaṃ katvā dhārenti, tato rajanampi ovaṭṭikavijjhanampi
analyzed: cīvara rajanam pi na sāruppam oṭṭhaṭṭhika vaṇṇam katvā dhārenti tatas rajanam pi ovaṭṭika vijjhanam pi
translated: also disappear. They cut the edges and wear them like the wanderers. When that has disappeared,

original: na hoti, dasā chetvā paribbājakā viya kāsāvamattameva dhārenti, tato parikkhīṇe kāle
analyzed: na hoti dasā chetvā paribbājakāḥ viya kāsāva mattam eva dhārenti tato parikkhīṇe kāle
translated: in the last period of time they wear just the yellow colour, like the Jains. When that has disappeared,

original: khuddakakāsāvakhaṇḍaṃ hatthe vā gīvāya vā bandhitvā kasikammādīni katvā dārabharaṇādiṃ
analyzed: khuddaka kāsāva khaṇḍam hatthe vā gīvāya vā bandhitvā kasi kamma ādīni katvā dāra bharaṇa ādim

original: karonti, tadā dakkhiṇaṃ dento jano saṅghaṃ uddissa etesaṃ deti, idaṃ sandhāya bhagavatā

translated: When people give gifts at that time, they give to them, thinking: ‘To the Sangha.’ The Blessed One said this, referring to that.

original: vuttaṃ “bhavissanti kho panānanda, anāgatamaddhānaṃ gotrabhuno kāsāvakaṇṭhā dussīlā
analyzed: vuttam bhavissanti kho pana ānanda anāgata maddhānam gotrabhunaḥ kāsāvakaṇṭhāḥ dussīlāḥ
translated: It was said: “But, Ananda, in the future there will be those of clan who, with evil desires and evil thoughts, will wear the yellow robe round their necks.

original: pāpadhammā, tesu dussīlesu saṅghaṃ uddissa dānaṃ dassanti, tadāpahaṃ, ānanda, saṅghagataṃ
analyzed: pāpa dhammā tesu dussīlesu saṅgham uddissa dānam dassanti tadā apaham ānanda saṅgha gatam

original: tesaṃ vipattiyā paṭibāhitāni na vipaccanti, tesaṃ sampattiṃ āgamma vipaccantī”ti pajānāti.

original: Tattha gativipattīti cattāro apāyā. Gatisampattīti manussadevagatiyo. Upadhīti attabhāvo.

translated: Herein, the deficiency of the destination is the four states of deprivation. The excellence of the destination is the human and divine kinds of rebirth. The support is the individual essence. The excellence of the support is the excellence of the individual essence.

original: Tassa samiddhi sampatti nāma, asamiddhi vipatti nāma. Kālasampattīti surājasumanussakālasaṅkhāto
analyzed: tassa samiddhi sampatti nāma asamiddhi vipatti nāma kāla sampatti iti su rāja su manussa kāla saṅkhāto

original: sampannakālo, tappaṭipakkho kālavipatti nāma. Tassa tassa pana kammassa sammāpayogo🔽payogasampatti, micchāpayogo payogavipatti nāma. Tattha hi ekaccassa kusalakammena
analyzed: sampanna kālaḥ tad paṭipakkho kāla vipatti nāma tassa tassa pana kammassa sammāpayogo  payoga sampatti micchā apayogo payoga vipatti nāma tattha hi ekaccassa kusala kammena
translated: and the failure of the time is the opposite of that. The success of the performance is the right performance of this or that action,🔽and the failure of the performance is the wrong performance. original: devagatiādīsu gatiyaṃ nibbattassa taṃ gatisampattiṃ āgamma kusalāni eva vipaccanti.

analyzed: tāya pana gati sampattiyā paṭibāhitāni akusalāni tattha vipaccitum na sakkonti tāni

analyzed: puna niraya ādīsu apāyesu nibbattassa tam gati vipattim āgamma yathāsukham vipaccanti  tāya pana gati vipattiyā paṭibāhitāni kusalāni tattha vipaccitum na sakkonti ekaccassa
translated: they ripen in him there as much as they can.🔽But the profitables, being obstructed by the failure of his destiny, are unable to ripen in him there. When someone is endowed with a beautiful, comely, and pleasing body,

translated: even if he is a slave or of low birth,

original: upadhisampattiṃ āgamma kusalāni evassa vipaccanti. Tādisaṃ hi surūpaṃ “ayaṃ kiliṭṭhakammassa🔽nānucchaviko”ti uccesu amaccādiṭṭhānesu ṭhapenti, caṇḍālimpi surūpaṃ aggamahesiādiṭṭhānesu🔽ṭhapenti. Tāya pana upadhisampattiyā paṭibāhitāni akusalānassa vipaccituṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: upadhi sampattim āgamma kusalāni evassa vipaccanti tādisam hi surūpam ayam kiliṭṭha kammassa  uccesu amacca ādi ṭhānesu ṭhapenti surūpam aggamahesi ādi ṭṭhānesu  ṭhapenti tāya pana upadhi sampattiyā paṭibāhitāni vipaccitum na sakkonti
translated: and his profitable actions come to ripening. For they appoint such a one to high office as a counsellor, etc., saying, “This one is not worthy of the work of a sweeper,” and they appoint a sweeper who is good-looking to the office of a chief queen, etc. But his unprofitable actions are unable to ripen because they are obstructed by the excellence of his requisites.

original: Tāni pana upadhivipattiyaṃ ca ṭhitassa yathāsukhaṃ vipaccanti. Rājakulādīsu hi uppannampi🔽durūpaṃ hīnesu ṭhapenti. Ekaccassa pana paṭhamakappikānaṃ vā cakkavattirañño vā buddhānaṃ🔽vā surājasumanussānaṃ sampanne kāle nibbattassa taṃ kālasampattiṃ āgamma kusalāni
analyzed: tāni pana upadhi vipattiyam ca ṭhitassa yathāsukham vipaccanti rāja kula ādīsu hi uppannam pi  durūpam hīnesu ṭhapenti ekaccassa pana paṭhama kappikānam vā cakkavatti raññaḥ vā buddhānam  vā su rāja su manussānam sampanne kāle nibbattassa tam kāla sampattim āgamma kusalāni
translated: But when he is established in the failure of requisites, they ripen at their pleasure. For they appoint a man who is ugly to the service of a royal family, etc.,🔽and they appoint a sweeper who is good-looking to the service of a royal family, etc.,

original: eva vipaccanti, na akusalāni. Tāni puna durājadumanussānaṃ vipanne kāle taṃ kālavipattiṃ
analyzed: eva vipaccanti na akusalāni tāni puna du rāja du manussānam vipanne kāle tam kāla vipattim
translated: But when a man is reborn at a time when the first-mentioned kind of people are in power, or at a time of a Universal Monarch, or at a time of Buddhas, or at a time of a good king and good people, then his profitable actions come to ripening because of the excellence of the time, not his unprofitable actions. But when a man is reborn at a time when bad kings and bad people are in power, then his unprofitable actions come to ripening because of the failure of the time, not his profitable actions.

original: āgamma vipaccanti, na pana kusalāni tāya kālavipattiyā paṭibāhitattā. Ekaccassa pana
analyzed: āgamma vipaccanti na pana kusalāni tāya kāla vipattiyā paṭibāhita ttā ekaccassa pana
translated: and the unwholesome do not, because the opportunity for their fruition has been blocked by the wholesome. But in the case of some,🔽the wholesome only ripen and the unwholesome do not, because of the success of his performance of the duties of virtue, restraint, etc.,

original: sīlasaṃyamādianavajjapayogena ceva sāvajjena vā anavajjena vā desakālānusārena āyudhasippādipayogasāmatthiyena
analyzed: sīla saṃyama ādi anavajja payogena ca iva sāvajjena vā anavajjena vā desa kāla anusārena āyudha sippa ādi payoga sāmatthiyena
translated: whether blameless or blameworthy, and because of the success of his performance of the duties of the arts, crafts, and professions, etc., in accordance with the right time and place.

original: ca samannāgatassa taṃ payogasampattiṃ āgamma kusalāni eva vipaccanti, na akusalāni.🔽Tāni puna yathāvuttaviparītapayogavipattiṃ āgamma vipaccanti, na pana kusalāni tāya
analyzed: ca samannāgatassa tam payoga sampattim āgamma kusalāni eva vipaccanti na akusalāni  tāni puna yathā vutta viparīta payoga vipattim āgamma vipaccanti na pana kusalāni tāya
translated: But those wholesome kammas ripen in the case of some, and the unwholesome do not, because of the failure of the performance of the duties mentioned above.

original: paṭibāhitattā. Yuddhādīsu hi pāṇātipātādiakusalaṃ karontāpi taṃtaṃāyudhasippādipayogasampattiṃ
analyzed: yuddha ādīsu hi pāṇa atipāta ādi akusalam karontā api taṃ taṃ āyudha sippa ādi payoga sampattim
translated: For even though they commit such unwholesome actions as killing breathing things, etc., in war, etc., they obtain great success, such as the position of general, etc., only through the success of their performance of the duties of the arts of war, etc.,

original: nissāyeva senāpatiṭṭhānādimahāsampattiṃ labhanti, na pana taṃ akusalaṃ nissāya. Yathā
analyzed: nissāya iva senāpati ṭṭhāna ādi mahā sampattim labhanti na pana tam akusalam nissāya yathā
translated: and not through the unwholesome action. Just as,

original: dānaveyyāvaccādīsu kusalaṃ karontāpi adhimattavāyāmādipayogavipattiṃ nissāya anayabyasanampi
analyzed: kusalam karontā api adhimatta vāyāma ādi payoga vipattim nissāya anaya byasanam pi
translated: even though they perform such wholesome actions as giving, kindliness, etc., they obtain misfortune and failure only through the failure of their performance of the duties of exertion, etc.,

original: pāpuṇanti, na pana taṃ kusalaṃ nissāya. Evametāhi catūhi sampattīhi, vipattīhi ca

analyzed: kusala akusalānam vipaccana a vipaccana vibhāgam bhagavā yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam tā vettha
translated: Thus the Blessed One knows as it really is the profitable and unprofitable with their opposites and with their non-opposites by way of these four kinds of success and four kinds of failure.

original: vibhaṅganayena dutiyabalassa vibhāvanā.
analyzed: vibhaṅga nayena dutiya balassa vibhāvanā
translated: This, in the first place, is the elucidation of the second power by way of the exposition of the aggregates.

analyzed: aparena cassa  ahosi kammam ahosi kamma vipāko ahosi kammam na ahosi kamma vipāko ahosi kammam atthi
translated: And by means of another method too:

analyzed: natthi kamma vipākaḥ atthi kammam bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ atthi kammam na bhavissati
translated: there will be action, there will be no action’s ripening; there is action, there is no action’s ripening; there is action,

translated: there is action’s ripening; there is action, there is no action’s ripening; there will be action, there will be action’s ripening; there will be action, there will be no action’s ripening” .

original: Iminā paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttenāpi nayena vibhāvanā veditabbā. Tattha yaṃ atītattabhāve🔽āyūhitaṃ kammaṃ vuttaṃ, hetupaccayaṃ āgamma tattheva vipākaṃ adāsi. Idaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: iminā paṭisambhidā ayam vuttena api nayena vibhāvanā veditabbā tattha yam atīta tta bhāve  āyūhitam kammam vuttam hetu paccayam āgamma tattha eva vipākam adāsi idam sandhāya
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here in the Paṭisambhidā. Herein, the kamma that is said to have been performed in the past

original: “ahosi kammaṃ ahosi kammavipāko”ti paṭhamaṃ padaṃ vuttaṃ. Yaṃ atītesu pana diṭṭhadhammavedanīyādīsu
analyzed: ahosi kammam ahosi kamma vipāko ti paṭhamam padam vuttam yam atītesu pana diṭṭha dhamma vedanīya ādīsu
translated: gives its fruit there and then, coming into occurrence with the condition of cause. It is in reference to this that the first statement, “There was kamma, there was kamma-result,” is made. But when there are many kinds of kamma in the past, such as that to be experienced here and now, etc.,

original: bahūsu ekaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ laddhapaccayaṃ vipākaṃ deti, sesāni avipākāni.🔽Ekaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ pana paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhati, ekaṃ ānantariyaṃ nirayapaṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: bahūsu ekam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam laddha paccayam vipākam deti sesāni avipākāni  ekam upapajja vedanīyam pana paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhati ekam ānantariyam niraya paṭisandhim
translated: then it gives its fruit in the here-and-now order of experience to only one of them that has obtained the conditions, while the rest do not give fruit.

original: deti, sesāni avipākāni. Aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu ekāya brahmaloke nibbattati, sesā avipākā.🔽Idaṃ sandhāya “ahosi kammaṃ nāhosi kammavipāko”ti dutiyaṃ padaṃ vuttaṃ. Yaṃ atītaṃ
analyzed: deti sesāni avipākāni aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu ekāya brahma loke nibbattati sesā avipākā  idam sandhāya ahosi kammam na ahosi kamma vipāko ti dutiyam padam vuttam yam atītam
translated: But when there is kamma to be experienced after rebirth, it draws the rebirth-linking to itself, while the rest do not give fruit. When there is kamma of the kind that is effective in producing the next existence, it gives the rebirth-linking in hell, while the rest do not give fruit. When there are eight kinds of attainments, it leads to rebirth in the Brahmā-world through one of them, while the rest do not give fruit.

original: kammaṃ etarahi vipākaṃ deti, idaṃ sandhāya tatiyaṃ. Yaṃ purimanayena na vipaccati,
analyzed: kammam etarahi vipākam deti idam sandhāya tatiyam yam purima nayena na vipaccati
translated: It is in reference to this that the second statement, “There was kamma, there was not kamma-result,” is made. When there is kamma in the past that gives its fruit now, it is in reference to this that the third statement is made. When it does not give fruit in the way just stated,

original: idaṃ sandhāya catutthaṃ. Yaṃ anāgate vipākaṃ dassati, idaṃ sandhāya pañcamaṃ. Yaṃ🔽na vipaccati, idaṃ sandhāya chaṭṭhaṃ. Yaṃ etarahi āyūhitaṃ kammaṃ etaraheva vipākaṃ
analyzed: idam sandhāya catuttham yam anāgate vipākam dassati idam sandhāya pañcamam yam  na vipaccati idam sandhāya chaṭṭham yam etarahi āyūhitam kammam etarahā iva vipākam
translated: The fourth is stated with reference to that. The fifth is stated with reference to that which will give its result in the future.🔽The sixth is stated with reference to that which does not ripen.🔽The seventh is stated with reference to that action which is now being accumulated and which now gives its result.

original: deti, idaṃ sandhāya sattamaṃ. Yaṃ na vipaccati, idaṃ sandhāya aṭṭhamaṃ. Iminā nayena🔽sesapadānampi attho daṭṭhabbo. Idaṃ tathāgatassāti idaṃ sabbehi etehi pakārehi atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ
analyzed: deti idam sandhāya sattamam yam na vipaccati idam sandhāya aṭṭhamam iminā nayena  sesa padānam pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ idam tathāgatassa ati idam sabbehi etehi pakārehi atīta anāgata paccuppannānam
translated: The eighth is stated with reference to that which does not ripen. In this way

original: kammantaravipākantarānaṃ yathābhūtato jānanañāṇanti attho. Dutiyabalaṃ.
analyzed: yathā bhūtataḥ jānana ñāṇan ti atthaḥ dutiya balam
translated: the meaning of the remaining terms should be seen. This is the Tathagata’s: the meaning is, the knowledge of the Tathagata is the knowledge of the way things really are of all these kinds of action and result, whether past, future, or present, and whether the action is past, etc., and the result future, etc., or vice versa. This is the second power.

original: Tatiye sabbatthagāmininti sabbagatigāminiñca agatigāminiñca. Paṭipadanti maggaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye sabbattha gāminin ti sabba gati gāminin ca agati gāminin ca paṭipadanti maggam
translated: In the third, “leading everywhere” is leading to all destinations, both to destinations and not to destinations. “Path” is the path.

original: Yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti bahūsupi manussesu pāṇātipātādīsu ekameva akusalaṃ ekato karontesu
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti iti bahūsu pi manussesu pāṇātipāta ādīsu ekam eva akusalam ekatas karontesu
translated: “He understands as it really is”: although there are many people who commit one unwholesome action, such as killing a living being, in the same place,

original: imassa cetanā nirayagāminī bhavissati, imassa tiracchānayonigāminī, imassa pettivisayagāminī,
analyzed: imassa cetanā niraya gāminī bhavissati imassa tiracchāna yoni gāminī imassa pettivisaya gāminī
translated: he understands that the volition of this one will lead to hell, that of that one to the animal realm, that of the other to the realm of ghosts,

original: nirayādīsupi panesā evarūpe evarūpe ṭhāne evañcevañca vipākaṃ dassati, imassa paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: niraya ādīsu pi pana isā evarūpe evarūpe ṭhāne evañca ivañca vipākam dassati imassa paṭisandhim
translated: But this kamma, though it has such and such a result in such and such a place, in hell, and so on, cannot draw the rebirth-linking of this one,

original: ākaḍḍhituṃ na sakkoti, aññena kammena dinnapaṭisandhikassa dubbalaṃ upadhivepakkaṃ
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitum na sakkoti aññena kammena dinna paṭisandhikassa dubbalam upadhi vepakkam
translated: whose rebirth-linking has been given by another kamma. It will be a weak underlying tendency to rebirth in hell.

original: bhavissati. Bahūsu vā ekato dānādikusalaṃ, vipassanaṃ vā paṭṭhapentesu imassa cetanā
analyzed: bhavissati bahūsu vā ekatas dāna ādi kusalam vipassanam vā paṭṭhapentesu imassa cetanā
translated: Or when several people are practising generosity, virtue, and the rest, or insight together, the volition of this one will lead to the human world,

original: manussagatigāminī bhavissati, imassa devagatigāminī, tatthāpi evañcevañca vipākaṃ
analyzed: manussa gati gāminī bhavissati imassa deva gati gāminī tattha api evañca ivañca vipākam
translated: that of that one to the world of the gods, and so on. And it will have such and such a result there.

original: dassati, imassa vā vipassanā ekaṃ maggaṃ dve vā tayo vā cattāro vā paṭisambhidādisahite🔽vā rahite vā nipphādessati, imassa na kañci paṭivedhaṃ sādhessatītiādinā anantehi
analyzed: dassati imassa vā vipassanā ekam maggam dve vā tayaḥ vā cattāro vā paṭisambhidā ādi sahite  vā rahite vā nipphādessati imassa na kañci paṭivedham sādhessati iti ādinā anantehi
translated: Or this one’s insight will produce one path, two paths, three paths, four paths, with or without the discriminations, and so on,

original: ākārehi ekavatthusmimpi uppannaṃ kusalākusalasaṅkhātaṃ sabbatthagāminipaṭipadaṃ aviparītato
analyzed: ākārehi eka vatthusmim pi uppannam kusala akusala saṅkhātam sabbattha gāmini paṭipadam aviparītataḥ
translated: while that one’s will not reach any penetration at all. In this way he understands the way leading to all destinations, that is, the profitable and unprofitable thought called the way leading to all destinations, which arises in all the various ways in a single object, without confusion,

original: pajānātīti. Tatiyabalaṃ.
analyzed: pajānāti iti tatiya balam
translated: by means of the countless modes of knowing. This is the third power.

original: Catutthe anekadhātunti cakkhudhātuādīhi, kāmadhātuādīhi vā bahudhātuṃ. Nānādhātunti
analyzed: catutthe aneka dhātunti cakkhu dhātu ādīhi kāmadhātu ādīhi vā bahu dhātum nānā dhātunti
translated: In the fourth, “many elements” means many elements such as the eye element, etc., or the sense-desire element, etc. “Various elements” means🔽

original: tāsaññeva dhātūnaṃ vilakkhaṇattā nānappakāraṃ dhātuṃ. Lokanti khandhāyatanadhātulokaṃ.🔽Yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti tāsaṃ tāsaṃ dhātūnaṃ khandhāyatanadhātuvibhaṅgādīsu vuttanayena🔽anantappabhedaṃ nānattaṃ aviparītato pajānāti. Na kevalañca tathāgato upādinnakasaṅkhāralokasseva
analyzed: tāsaṃ eva dhātūnam vilakkhaṇa ttā nānappakāram dhātum lokanti khandha āyatana dhātu lokam  yathābhūtam pajānāti iti tāsam tāsam dhātūnam khandha āyatana dhātu vibhaṅga ādīsu vutta nayena  ananta ppabhedam nānattam a viparītataḥ pajānāti na kevalam ca tathāgataḥ upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa iva
translated: In the fourth, in the manifoldness of elements means in the many elements such as the eye element, etc., or in the many elements such as the sense-desire element, etc. In the diversity of elements means in the various kinds of elements, because those elements have different characteristics. In the world means in the world of aggregates, bases, and elements.🔽He understands as they really are means he understands without perverting the manifoldness of those elements, which has an infinite number of divisions, in accordance with the method stated in the description of the aggregates, bases, and elements, etc.
