original: nānattaṃ pajānāti, atha kho anupādinnakasaṅkhāralokassāpi paccekabuddhādīhi paṭivijjhituṃ🔽asakkuṇeyyaṃ nānattaṃ pajānātiyeva. Tehi upādinnakalokassāpi nānattaṃ ekadesatova
analyzed: nānattam pajānāti atha kho an upādinnaka saṅkhāra lokassa api paccekabuddha ādīhi paṭivijjhitum  asakkuṇeyyam nānattam pajānātiyā iva tehi upādinnaka lokassa api nānattam eka desataḥ va
translated: And not only does the Tathāgata understand the manifoldness of the world of formations that are clung to , but he also understands the manifoldness that cannot be penetrated even by the paccekabuddhas, etc., in the world of formations that are not clung to .

original: jānanti, anupādinnassa pana neva jānanti, sabbaññubuddhassevetaṃ visayo. Evaṃ hi
analyzed: jānanti anupādinnassa pana na iva jānanti sabbaññu buddhassa iva etam visayaḥ evam hi
translated: The others understand only a part of the manifoldness in the world of formations that are clung to, but they do not understand that of the world of formations that are not clung to. This is the province of the omniscient Buddha alone. Thus it is said:

original: imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannāya imesaṃ rukkhagacchalatādīnaṃ, khandhadaṇḍavallitacapattapupphaphalādino🔽saṇṭhānavaṇṇagandharasaojāhi, desakālehi ca anantappabhedaṃ nānattaṃ, pathavīpabbatādīnañca
analyzed: imāya nāma dhātuyāḥ ussannāya imesam rukkha gaccha latā ādīnam khandha daṇḍa valli taca patta puppha phala ādinaḥ  saṇṭhāna vaṇṇa gandha rasa ojāhi desa kālehi ca ananta ppabhedam nānattam pathavī pabbata ādīnam ca
translated: “By means of this element, the diversity of trees, creepers, etc., and of their parts such as trunk, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits,

original: nānattaṃ hotīti anantehi ākārehi jānituṃ sakkoti, nāññeti. Catutthabalaṃ.
analyzed: nānattam hoti iti anantehi ākārehi jānitum sakkoti na aññā iti catuttha balam
translated: and the diversity of earth, rocks, etc., is known in its infinite variety of aspects, namely, by shape, colour, smell, taste, nutritive essence, and by place and time. But this cannot be done by any other means. This is the fourth power.

original: Pañcame nānādhimuttikanti hīnādīhi adhimuttīhi nānādhimuttikabhāvaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: pañcame hīna ādīhi adhimuttīhi nānā adhimuttika bhāvam yathābhūtam
translated: In the fifth, “various faiths,” the diversity of faith is known in its various aspects as inferior, etc.,🔽and is understood as it actually is in the three times.

original: pajānātīti tīsupi kālesu hīnādhimuttikā hīnādhimuttike eva sevanti, paṇītādhimuttikā
analyzed: pajānāti iti tīsu pi kālesu hīna adhimuttikāḥ hīna adhimuttike eva sevanti paṇīta adhimuttikā
translated: Those of inferior faith resort only to those of inferior faith, and those of excellent faith to those of excellent faith.

original: ca paṇītādhimuttike. Tatthāpi assaddhā assaddhe, dussīlā dussīle, micchādiṭṭhikā
analyzed: ca paṇīta adhimuttike tattha api assaddhā assaddhe dussīlā dussīle micchādiṭṭhikā
translated: There too, the faithless to the faithless, the immoral to the immoral, those with wrong view to those with wrong view,

original: micchādiṭṭhike, saddhā saddhe, sīlasutacāgapaññādisampannā ca te te eva sevantīti
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhike saddhā saddhe sīla suta cāga paññā ādi sampannā ca te te eva sevanti iti
translated: the faithful to the faithful, and those endowed with virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom to those endowed with virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom resort only to their like.

original: nānappakārato jānāti. Saddhāsīlādisampannā hi tabbirahite attano ācariyupajjhāyepi
analyzed: nānā pakārataḥ jānāti saddhā sīla ādi sampannāḥ hi tad virahite attanaḥ ācariya upajjhāye pi
translated: Thus it is known in its various aspects. For those endowed with faith, virtue, etc., resort to their like even in the choice of their preceptors and teachers.

original: na sevanti, tepi itare, attanā attanā pana sadise eva sevantīti. Pañcamabalaṃ.
analyzed: na sevanti te api itare attanā attanā pana sadise eva sevanti iti pañcama balam
translated: and they do not associate with those who do, but they associate only with those who are like themselves. This is the fifth power.

original: Chaṭṭhe parasattānanti padhānasattānaṃ. Parapuggalānanti tato paresaṃ hīnasattānaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe para sattānam ti padhāna sattānam para puggalānam ti tatas paresam hīna sattānam
translated: In the sixth, “other beings” are the chief beings, and “other persons” are the inferior beings other than them.

original: Ekatthameva vā etaṃ padadvayaṃ veneyyavasena dvidhā vuttaṃ. Indriyaparopariyattanti
analyzed: ekattham eva vai etam pada dvayam veneyya vasena dvidhā vuttam
translated: Or the two terms are synonymous, used for the sake of different disciples. “The higher and lower faculties of others”:

original: saddhādīnaṃ indriyānaṃ parabhāvañca aparabhāvañca, vuddhiñca hāniñcāti attho. Yathābhūtanti🔽sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ āsayānusayacaritādhimuttiādīhi saddhādi tikkhindriyamudindriyataṃ
analyzed: saddhā ādīnam indriyānam para bhāvañca apara bhāvañca vuddhiñca hāniñca ati atthaḥ yathābhūtam ti  sabbesam sattānam āsaya anusaya carita adhimutti ādīhi saddhā ādi
translated: the higher and lower state of the faculties of faith, etc., in others. The meaning is: their increase and decrease. “As they really are”:

original: sabbākārato jānāti. Tattha āsayoti nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ, yattha sattānaṃ cittasantānaṃ niccaṃ🔽nivasati. So duvidho vaṭṭāsayo vivaṭṭāsayo ca. Tattha sassatucchedavasena pavattaṃ
analyzed: sabba ākārataḥ jānāti tattha āsayo ti nivāsa ṭṭhānam yattha sattānam citta santānam niccam  nivasati saḥ duvidhaḥ vaṭṭa āsayaḥ vivaṭṭa āsayaḥ ca tattha sassa tu cheda vasena pavattam
translated: he knows the state of the faculties of faith, etc., as keen or dull in all beings, according to their underlying tendencies, latent tendencies, temperament, etc. Herein, underlying tendency is the abode, where the mental continuum of beings always

original: sabbaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ vaṭṭāsayo nāma. Sappaccayanāmarūpapariggahato paṭṭhāya sabbaṃ
analyzed: sabbam diṭṭhi gatam vaṭṭāsayaḥ nāma sappaccaya nāma rūpa pariggahato paṭṭhāya sabbam
translated: dwells. It is twofold: the underlying tendency to the round and the underlying tendency to the outlet. Herein, all the views that occur in terms of eternalism and annihilationism are called the underlying tendency to the round. All the views that occur in terms of the four noble truths, etc., from the time of discerning the dependent origination with conditions, are called the underlying tendency to the outlet.

original: vipassanāñāṇaṃ, maggañāṇañca vivaṭṭāsayo nāma. Maggañāṇampi hi “dasayime, bhikkhave,🔽ariyāvāsā, yadariyā āvasiṃsū”tiādivacanato āsayova. Imaṃ pana bhagavā sattānaṃ āsayaṃ🔽jānanto ubhinnaṃ diṭṭhiñāṇānaṃ appavattikkhaṇepi jānāti eva. Kāmarāgādikilesādhimuttaññeva🔽hi puggalaṃ bhagavā tatheva jānāti. “Ayaṃ nekkhammādiabhirato vivaṭṭāsayo”ti nekkhammādiṃ
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇam magga ñāṇañca vivaṭṭa āsayaḥ nāma magga ñāṇam pi hi dasayime bhikkhave  imam pana bhagavā sattānam  jānantaḥ ubhinnam diṭṭhi ñāṇānam appavatti khaṇe pi jānāti eva kāma rāga ādi kilesa adhimutta ñā eva  hi puggalam bhagavā tathā iva jānāti ayam nekkhamma ādi abhirataḥ nekkhamma ādiṃ
translated: and insight-knowledge and path-knowledge are called “the state of turning away from the round of rebirths.” For path-knowledge is the state itself, since it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are these ten states of noble persons that are not to be abandoned” .🔽But the Exalted One knows this state of beings🔽even when neither insight nor knowledge is occurring. For the Exalted One knows just as it is that a person is devoted to the defilements of sense desire, etc.,🔽and that he is devoted to renunciation, etc.🔽

original: sevantaññeva jānāti, “ayaṃ kāmādiabhirato vaṭṭāsayo”ti anusayacaritādijānanepi eseva🔽nayo. Tattha anusayo kāmarāgānusayādito sattavidho. Caritanti tīhi dvārehi abhisaṅkhatalokiyakusalākusalaṃ.🔽Adhimuttīti ajjhāsayo. Evamettha āsayānusayañāṇaṃ, indriyaparopariyattañāṇañcāti🔽dve ñāṇāni ekato hutvā ekaṃ balañāṇaṃ nāma jātanti. Chaṭṭhabalaṃ.
analyzed: sevantam na eva jānāti ayam kāma ādi abhirataḥ anusaya carita ādi jānane pi esā iva 🔽nayo tattha anusayo kāma rāga anusaya āditaḥ sattavidho tīhi dvārehi 🔽adhimutti iti ajjhāsayaḥ evam ettha āsaya anusaya ñāṇam indriya para upari yatta ñāṇam ca ati 🔽dve ñāṇāni ekatas hutvā ekam balañāṇam nāma jātanti chaṭṭha balam
translated: And insight-knowledge and path-knowledge are called “knowledge of the way out.” For path-knowledge is the way out too, since it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are these ten noble tracks of the way out” , and so on. But the Blessed One knows this disposition of beings even when neither of these two kinds of knowledge is actually occurring in him. For he knows that a person is devoted to the defilements of lust, etc., just as he is, and he knows that one who is devoted to renunciation, etc., is of the kind called “of the way out” just as he is. And he knows that one who is devoted to renunciation, etc., is of the kind called “of the way out” just as he is. The knowledge of the seven kinds of dispositions, etc., should be understood in the same way as the knowledge of the way out. Herein, the underlying tendency is of seven kinds, namely, the underlying tendency to lust, etc., The temperament is the profitable and unprofitable volition in the three doors that has been stored up by the doing of profitable and unprofitable deeds. The devotion is the underlying disposition. So here the knowledge of the way out and the knowledge of the underlying tendency, and the knowledge of the seven kinds of dispositions, etc., are combined into one, which is called “knowledge of the strength of penetration.” This is the sixth power.

original: Sattame jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnanti paṭhamādīnaṃ catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ, “rūpī🔽rūpāni passatī”tiādīnaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ vimokkhānaṃ, savitakkasavicārādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ samādhīnaṃ,
analyzed: sattame jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam ti paṭhama ādīnam catunnam jhānānam rūpī  rūpāni passati iti ādīnam aṭṭhannam vimokkhānam sa vitakka sa vicāra ādīnam tiṇṇam samādhīnam
translated: In the seventh, the jhānas, liberations, concentrations, and attainments: the first four jhānas, the eight liberations beginning with “one who possesses form sees forms” , the three concentrations beginning with that accompanied by thought and discursive thinking ,

original: paṭhamajjhānasamāpattiādīnaṃ navannaṃ anupubbasamāpattīnaṃ. Saṃkilesanti hānabhāgiyadhammaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna samāpatti ādīnam navannam anupubba samāpattīnam saṃkilesanti hāna bhāgiya dhammam
translated: ‘The seven kinds of jhana, etc.,’ are the four jhanas beginning with the first, the eight deliverances beginning with ‘one who is bodily but perceives externally visible forms’ , the three kinds of concentration with thought and with evaluation, etc., and the nine successive cessations beginning with the first jhana. ‘Corruption’ is a state partaking of diminution.

original: Vodānanti visesabhāgiyaṃ dhammaṃ. Vuṭṭhānanti yena kāraṇena jhānādīhi vuṭṭhahanti,
analyzed: vodānanti visesa bhāgiyam dhammam vuṭṭhānanti yena kāraṇena jhāna ādīhi vuṭṭhahanti
translated: ‘Emergence’ is a state partaking of distinction. ‘Emergence’ is the reason for emerging from the jhanas, etc.

original: taṃ kāraṇaṃ. Taṃ pana duvidhaṃ vodānampi bhavaṅgampi. Heṭṭhimaṃ hi paguṇaṃ jhānaṃ🔽attano vodānavasena uparimassa jhānassa padaṭṭhānato “vuṭṭhāna”nti vuccati, tamhā🔽tamhā pana samādhimhā bhavaṅgavaseneva vuṭṭhānato bhavaṅgampi. Nirodhato pana phalasamāpattiyāva
analyzed: tam kāraṇam tam pana duvidham vodānam pi bhavaṅgam pi heṭṭhimam hi paguṇam jhānam  attanaḥ vodāna vasena uparimassa jhānassa padaṭṭhānataḥ vuṭṭhānanti vuccati tamhā  tamhā pana samādhimhā bhavaṅga vasena iva vuṭṭhānataḥ bhavaṅgam pi nirodhato pana phala samāpattiyā ava
translated: That is twofold as emergence from corruption and as emergence by means of the life-continuum. For the inferior jhana is called ‘emergence’ because it is the proximate cause for the superior jhana as its support for emergence.

original: vuṭṭhahanti. Idaṃ pāḷimuttakavuṭṭhānaṃ nāma, taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavā yathābhūtaṃ sabbākārena
analyzed: vuṭṭhahanti idam pāḷimuttakavuṭṭhānam nāma tat sabbam bhagavā yathābhūtam sabba ākārena
translated: But emergence by means of the life-continuum is so called because of emergence from that or that concentration by means of the life-continuum. And they emerge from the attainment of cessation by means of the fruition attainment. This is called ‘emergence’ in the sense of the text. The Blessed One knows all that as it really is in its individual essence, in its general characteristics, in its order, in its conditions, in its sequence, in its conformity and nonconformity, in its desirable and undesirable results, and in the escape from it.

original: pajānāti. Sattamabalaṃ.
analyzed: pajānāti sattama balam
translated: He understands. This is the seventh power.

original: Aṭṭhame pubbenivāsānussatīti pubbenivutthakkhandhānussaraṇaṃ, taṃ nāmagottavaṇṇāhārasukhadukkhādīhi
analyzed: aṭṭhame pubbenivāsa anussatī ti pubbenivuttha kkhandha anussaraṇam tam nāma gotta vaṇṇa āhāra sukha dukkha ādīhi
translated: The eighth is the ability to recall former lives. This is the recollection of the aggregates that existed in the past. It is the understanding of the aggregates that existed in the past in terms of their name, clan, complexion, food, happiness and suffering, etc.,

original: tattha tattha bhave vijjamānehi anantehi ākārehi yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti. Aṭṭhamabalaṃ.
analyzed: tattha tattha bhave vijjamānehi anantehi ākārehi yathābhūtam pajānāti iti aṭṭhama balam
translated: in accordance with reality, in terms of the infinite modes of existence in the various realms of existence. This is the eighth power.

original: Navame cutūpapātanti cutiñca upapātañca, taṃ cavamānaupapajjamānahīnapaṇītasuvaṇṇadubbaṇṇādito🔽anantapabhede yathākammūpage satte dibbacakkhuñāṇena vaṇṇāyatanaggahaṇamukhena disvā
analyzed: navame cutūpapātanti cutim ca upapātam ca tam cavamāna a upapajjamāna hīna paṇīta suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇa āditaḥ  ananta pabhede yathā kamma upage satte dibba cakkhu ñāṇena vaṇṇa āyatana ggahaṇa mukhena disvā
translated: The ninth is the ability to see the passing away and reappearance of beings. This is the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings, who are reborn in accordance with their kamma, in terms of their inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, etc.,

original: sabbākārato pajānātīti. Navamabalaṃ.
analyzed: sabba ākārataḥ pajānāti iti navama balam
translated: in the infinite modes of existence in the various realms of existence. Having seen them with the divine eye, he understands them in all their aspects. This is the ninth power.

original: Dasame āsavānaṃ khayanti āsavanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ, taṃ arahattamaggañāṇena catusaccapaṭivedhato pajānātīti. Dasamabalaṃ.
analyzed: dasame āsavānam āsava nirodham nibbānam tam arahatta magga ñāṇena catu sacca paṭivedhato pajānāti iti dasama balam
translated: The tenth is the ability to know the destruction of the taints. This is the knowledge of the destruction of the taints, which is the knowledge of the path of arahantship. This is the tenth power.🔽These are the ten powers of a Tathāgata.

original: Imānīti yāni heṭṭhā “tathāgatassa dasa tathāgatabalānī”ti avoca, imāni tānīti appanaṃ
analyzed: imāni iti yāni heṭṭhā tathāgatassa dasa tathāgata balāni iti avoca imāni tāni iti appanam
translated: The ten powers of a Tathāgata are the ten powers of a Buddha.

original: karoti. Yasmā cetopariyañāṇādīni sāvakādīnampi yathārahaṃ vijjamānānipi savisayaṃ
analyzed: karoti yasmā yathāraham vijjamānāni pi
translated: And because the knowledge of penetration of minds, etc., though existing in disciples, etc., as appropriate, know only a certain object,

original: kiñcideva jānanti, na ca sabbākārato. Buddhānaṃ pana sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ viya sabbadhammesu
analyzed: kiñcid eva jānanti na ca sabba ākārataḥ buddhānam pana sabbaññu ta ññāṇam viya sabba dhammesu
translated: not in all its modes, but the knowledge of the Tathāgata, like the knowledge of omniscience, proceeds unobstructed in all dhammas,

original: yathāsakaṃ visaye sabbattha sabbākārato ekakkhaṇe appaṭihataṃ pavattati, tasmā “tathāgatabalānī”ti
analyzed: yathāsakam visaye sabbattha sabba ākārataḥ eka khaṇe appaṭihatam pavattati tasmā tathāgata balāni iti
translated: in their respective spheres, in all modes, in a single moment, therefore it is called the “powers of the Tathāgata.”

original: vuccanti. Yadi evaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇassevāyaṃ pabhedo hoti, kasmā pana “dasabalañāṇānī”ti
analyzed: vuccanti yadi evam sabbaññuta ññāṇassa iva ayam pabhedaḥ hoti kasmā pana dasa balañāṇāni iti
translated: If that is so, then this is a mere analysis of the knowledge of omniscience. But why are the knowledges of the ten powers analyzed separately?

original: visuṃ vibhattānīti? Visayakiccabhūmibhedato nesaṃ aññattā. Dasabalañāṇesu hi paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: visum vibhattāni iti visaya kicca bhūmi bhedataḥ na īsam aññattā dasa bala ñāṇesu hi paṭhamam
translated: Because they are different in object, function, and plane. For in the ten powers, the first power

original: kāraṇākāraṇameva jānāti, dutiyaṃ kammantaravipākantarameva jānāti, tatiyaṃ kammaparicchedameva,
analyzed: kāraṇa akāraṇam eva jānāti dutiyam kamma antara vipāka antaram eva jānāti tatiyam kamma paricchedam eva
translated: knows only the productive and unproductive. The second power knows only the kamma-resultant and the non-kamma-resultant. The third power knows only the delimitation of kamma.

original: catutthaṃ nānattakāraṇameva, pañcamaṃ sattānaṃ ajjhāsayādhimuttimeva, chaṭṭhaṃ indriyānaṃ
analyzed: catuttham nānatta kāraṇam eva pañcamam sattānam ajjhāsaya adhimuttim eva chaṭṭham
translated: The fourth power knows only the manifold causes. The fifth power knows only the inclinations and convictions of beings. The sixth power knows only the faculties of others.

original: tikkhamudubhāvameva, sattamaṃ jhānādīhi saddhiṃ tesaṃ saṃkilesādimeva, aṭṭhamaṃ pubbenivutthakkhandhasantatimeva,
analyzed: tikkha mudu bhāvam eva sattamam jhāna ādīhi saddhim tesam saṃkilesa ādim eva aṭṭhamam pubbenivuttha kkhandha santatim eva
translated: The seventh is the defilement, etc., of those knowledges together with the jhānas. The eighth is the continuity of aggregates previously arisen.

original: navamaṃ sattānaṃ cutipaṭisandhimeva, dasamaṃ saccaparicchedameva, nāññaṃ.🔽Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana etehi jānitabbañca tato uttariñca sabbaṃ atītādibhedaṃ ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: navamam sattānam cuti paṭisandhim eva dasamam sacca paricchedam eva na aññam  sabbaññuta ññāṇam pana etehi jānitabbañca tatas uttariñca sabbam atīta ādi bhedam eka kkhaṇe
translated: The ninth is the passing away and reappearance of beings. The tenth is the knowledge of the kinds of sundering of resolve.🔽But the knowledge of omniscience knows all that and more besides in a single moment,

original: sabbākārato jānāti, etesaṃ pana kiccaṃ na sabbaṃ karoti. Taṃ hi jhānaṃ hutvā appetuṃ,
analyzed: sabba ākārataḥ jānāti etesam pana kiccam na sabbam karoti tam hi jhānam hutvā appetum
translated: knowing all the aspects of all that has happened, etc., in all its modes. But it does not perform all the functions of those knowledges. For that knowledge of omniscience cannot, as jhāna, cause the attainment to arise,

original: iddhi hutvā vikubbituṃ, maggo hutvā kilese khepetuṃ na sakkoti. Dasabalañāṇāni pana
analyzed: id hi hutvā vikubbitum maggaḥ hutvā kilese khepetum na sakkoti dasa bala ñāṇāni pana
translated: or, as supernormal power, cause manifestation of the various kinds of supernormal power, or, as the path, cause defilements to be abandoned. But the ten knowledges of the ten powers

original: taṃ sabbaṃ yathārahaṃ kātuṃ sakkonti. Tesu ca paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni kāmāvacarāni,
analyzed: tam sabbam yathāraham kātum sakkonti tesu ca paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni kāmāvacarāni
translated: can do all that as appropriate. And of these, seven knowledges are of the sense sphere,

original: tato dve rūpāvacarāni, avasāne ekaṃ lokuttaraṃ. Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana kāmāvacaramevāti
analyzed: tatas dve rūpāvacarāni avasāne ekam lokuttaram sabbaññuta ññāṇam pana kāmāvacaram eva ati
translated: two are of the fine-material sphere, and the last is supramundane. But the knowledge of omniscience is of the sense sphere only.

original: evaṃ visayakiccabhūmibhedato aññameva dasabalañāṇaṃ. Aññaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇanti. Ayaṃ
analyzed: evam visaya kicca bhūmi bhedataḥ aññam eva dasa bala ñāṇam aññam sabbaññuta ññāṇan ti ayaṃ
translated: So the knowledge of omniscience is different from the ten knowledges of the ten powers in its object, function, and plane.

original: tāva padatthānusārato vinicchayo. Dhammabhedādito pana sabbopi vinicchayo ekavidhakoṭṭhāsato
analyzed: tāva padattha anusārataḥ vinicchayaḥ dhamma bheda ādito pana sabbaḥ api vinicchayaḥ ekavidha koṭṭhāsato
translated: This is the exposition of the terms in order. But the exposition of all the terms in the Vibhanga by way of the analysis of the terms, etc., is given in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: paṭṭhāya ettha vuttānusāratova ñātabbo, suttantabhājanīyādayo hi vibhaṅganayabhedā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya ettha vutta anusārataḥ va ñātabbo suttanta bhājanīya ādayaḥ hi vibhaṅga naya bhedā
translated: This is the exposition according to the order of the words of the text. But the whole of the exposition should be understood according to the order of the text beginning with the section on the single items. For the suttas, the topics for scrutiny, etc., are the divisions of the method of the Vibhaṅga.

original: ettha, ito paresu ca vibhaṅgesu natthīti.
analyzed: ettha itas paresu ca vibhaṅgesu na atthi iti
translated: They are not found in this Vibhaṅga or in the other Vibhaṅgas.

original: Ñāṇavibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ñāṇa vibhaṅga mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section of the exposition of knowledge is ended.

original: Khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section of the exposition of the Minor Layings Down

original: Khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgamātikāya panāyaṃ nikkhepaparicchedena saddhiṃ atthato vinicchayo.🔽Mātikāya hi ādito tāva – jātimadotiādayo tesattati ekakā nikkhittā, tato kodho ca🔽upanāho cātiādayo aṭṭhārasa dukā, akusalamūlādayo pañcatiṃsa tikā, āsavacatukkādayo
analyzed: khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅga mātikāya pana ayam nikkhepa paricchedena saddhim atthataḥ vinicchayaḥ  hi āditas tāva ekakā nikkhittā tatas kodho ca  upanāho cāti ādayo aṭṭhārasa dukāḥ akusala mūla ādayo pañcatiṃsa tikāḥ āsava catukka ādayo
translated: As regards the section of the exposition of the Minor Layings Down, the exposition of the meaning of this with the first chapter on the Laying Down is as follows.

original: cuddasa catukkā, orambhāgiyasaṃyojanādayo pannarasa pañcakā, vivādamūlādayo cuddasa
analyzed: cuddasa catukkāḥ orambhāgiya saṃyojana ādayaḥ pannarasa pañcakāḥ vivāda mūla ādayaḥ
translated: For in the first place in the Mātikā the seventy-three items beginning with ‘ Conceit about birth ’ are laid down singly; then the eighteen pairs beginning with ‘ Anger and resentment ’; then the thirty-five triplets beginning with ‘ The unprofitable roots ’; then the fourteen quadruples beginning with ‘ The four ideas proclaimed by the Blessed One ’; then the fifteen quintuplets beginning with ‘ The fetters that are on the side of the lower world ’; then the fourteen sextets beginning with ‘ The bases of contention ’;

original: chakkā, anusayādayo satta sattakā, kilesavatthuādayo aṭṭha aṭṭhakā, āghātavatthuādayo
analyzed: chakkāḥ anusaya ādayo satta sattakā kilesa vatthu ādayo aṭṭha aṭṭhakāḥ āghāta vatthu ādayo
translated: the seven sets of seven, such as the underlying tendencies, the eight sets of eight, such as the bases for sensual lust,🔽the nine sets of nine, such as the grounds for resentment,

original: nava navakā, kilesavatthuādayo satta dasakā, channaṃ aṭṭhārasakānaṃ vasena aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni
analyzed: nava kilesa vatthu ādayo satta dasakā channam aṭṭhārasakānam vasena aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: The seven sets of seven, beginning with the underlying tendencies, are the seven sets of seven; the eight sets of eight, beginning with the bases of defilement, are the eight sets of eight; the nine sets of nine, beginning with the bases of resentment, are the nine sets of nine; the seven sets of ten, beginning with the bases of defilement, are the seven sets of ten; and the one hundred and eight kinds of relishing of wishes, according to the six times eighteen, are the one hundred and eight kinds of relishing of wishes.

original: ca yathākkamaṃ nikkhipitvā ante dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajālasutte atidassitānīti
analyzed: ca yathākkamam nikkhipitvā ante dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajāla sutte atidassitāni iti
translated: And the sixty-two kinds of views, which are mentioned last, are those shown in the Brahmajāla Sutta .

original: sabbānipi tesaṭṭhiadhikāni aṭṭhakilesasatāni nikkhittānīti veditabbāni. Ayaṃ tāva nikkhepaparicchedo.🔽Atthato pana “jātimado”tiādīsu jātiuccākulīnataṃ nissāya “khattiyādīnaṃ catunnampi🔽vaṇṇānaṃ ahaṃ uttamajātiko, ime na uttamajātikā”ti evaṃ attukkaṃsanaparavambhanavasena
analyzed: sabbāni api aṭṭha kilesa satāni nikkhittāni iti veditabbāni ayam tāva nikkhepa paricchedaḥ  atthato pana jāti mado ti ādīsu jāti ucca akulīna tam nissāya khattiya ādīnam catunnam pi  vaṇṇānam aham uttama jātikaḥ ime na uttama jātikā ati evam attukkaṃsana para vambhana vasena
translated: So all these, which amount to one hundred and eighty-three defilements, are given in the Schedule. This is the Schedule section.🔽But as to meaning, in the case of the words “conceit due to birth,” etc., it is the kind of conceit that occurs in the form of exalting oneself and despising others thus, “I belong to a high-born family of Khattiyas, etc.,

original: uppanno majjanākārappavatto māno jātimado nāma. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Tattha ādiccagottakassapagottādiuttamagottaṃ
analyzed: uppannaḥ majjana ākāra ppavattaḥ mānaḥ jātimadaḥ nāma sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha ādicca gotta kassapa gotta ādi uttama gottam
translated: I am of the highest caste, these others are not of the highest caste,” and so on, in dependence on a high-born family of Khattiyas, etc., that is called “conceit due to birth.” The same method applies in the case of the other terms. Herein, a high-born family of Khattiyas, etc., is a family of Khattiyas, etc., that is well-known, famous, and distinguished.

original: nissāya gottamado. Nirābādhataṃ, yobbaññaṃ, “ciraṃ sukhaṃ jīviṃ jīvāmi jīvissāmī”ti
analyzed: nissāya gottama daḥ nirābādha tam yobbaññam ciram sukham jīvim jīvāmi jīvissāmi iti
translated: “May I have the requisites of robes, alms food, resting place, and medicine when sick well provided” —🔽thus requisites. And the four beginning with honour are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with respect.🔽“May I be respected, revered, feared, and served” —🔽thus honour. And the four beginning with fame are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with praise.🔽“May I be famous, renowned, renowned for my virtues, and renowned for my wisdom” —

original: evaṃ jīvitaṃ, bahulābhañca nissāya yathākkamaṃ ārogyamadādayo vuttā. Sukatapaṇītapaccayalābhaṃ,
analyzed: evam jīvitam bahu lābham ca nissāya yathākkamam ārogya mada ādayaḥ vuttā su kata paṇīta paccaya lābham
translated: thus fame. And the four beginning with satisfaction are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with delight.🔽“May I delight in my own gains, honour, and fame, and may I envy the gains, honour, and fame of others” —🔽thus satisfaction. And the four beginning with conceit are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with beauty.

original: mānanavandanādigarukāraṃ maññeva pamukhaṃ katvā pañhaṃ pucchanti, parivāretvā gacchantīti
analyzed: mānana vandana ādi garukāram maññā iva pamukham katvā pañham pucchanti parivāretvā gacchanti iti
translated: “May I be beautiful, well-favoured, pleasing, and of distinguished bearing” —🔽thus beauty. And the four beginning with conceit are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with beauty.🔽“May I be conceited about my beauty, my virtue, my learning, and my state” —🔽thus conceit. And the four beginning with the search are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with conceit.🔽“May I search for beauty, virtue, learning, and the state” —

original: evaṃ purekkhāraṃ, mahāparivāraṃ, suciparivārañca nissāya yathākkamaṃ sakkāramadādayo🔽ca veditabbā. Bhogo pana kiñcāpi lābhaggahaṇeneva gahito, nihitadhanavasena panettha
analyzed: evam purekkhāram mahā parivāram suci parivāram ca nissāya yathākkamam  ca veditabbā bhogaḥ pana kiñcā api lābha ggahaṇena iva gahitaḥ nihita dhana vasena pana ittha
translated: thus the search. And the four beginning with the acquisition are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with the search.🔽“May I acquire beauty, virtue, learning, and the state” —🔽thus the acquisition. And the four beginning with the enjoyment are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with the acquisition.🔽“May I enjoy beauty, virtue, learning, and the state” —

original: lābho veditabbo, “annapānavatthābharaṇamālāgandhādiupabhogasamiddhivasenāpi vattuṃ
analyzed: lābhaḥ veditabbaḥ anna pāna vattha ābharaṇa mālā gandha ādi upabhoga samiddhi vasena api vattum
translated: thus the enjoyment. And the four beginning with the possession are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with the enjoyment.🔽“May I possess beauty, virtue, learning, and the state” —🔽thus the possession. And the four beginning with the display are stated respectively in dependence on the four beginning with the possession.🔽“May I display beauty, virtue, learning, and the state” —

original: vaṭṭatī”tipi vadanti. Sarīravaṇṇaṃ, guṇavaṇṇañca nissāya vaṇṇamado. Bāhusaccaṃ, paṭibhānaṃ,
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti pi vadanti sarīra vaṇṇam guṇa vaṇṇam ca nissāya vaṇṇa madaḥ bāhu saccam paṭibhānam
translated: thus the display. And the four beginning with the boast are stated respectively in dependence on

original: “vaṇṇaṃ buddhavaṃsaṃ rājavaṃsaṃ janapadavaṃsaṃ gāmavaṃsaṃ rattindivaparicchedaṃ nakkhattamuhuttayogaṃ🔽jānāmī”ti evaṃ rattaññutaṃ vā nissāya yathākkamaṃ sutamadādayo ca veditabbā. Jātipiṇḍapātikataṃ,
analyzed: vaṇṇam buddha vaṃsam rāja vaṃsam janapada vaṃsam gāma vaṃsam ratti indiva paricchedam nakkhatta muhutta yogam  jānāmi iti evam rattaññu tam vā nissāya yathākkamam suta mada ādayo ca veditabbāḥ jāti piṇḍapātika tam
translated: “I know the colour-caste, the Buddha-line, the king-line, the clan-line, the village-line, the division of day and night, the stars and constellations, the right moments and conjunctions,

original: anavaññātataṃ, iriyāpathapāsādikataṃ, mahiddhikatañca nissāya yathākkamaṃ piṇḍapātikamadādayo.
analyzed: an avaññāta tam iriyāpatha pāsādika tam mahiddhika tam ca nissāya yathākkamam
translated: I know the seasons,” and so on. The conceit “I am a forest-dweller” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being a forest-dweller, etc., and on the distinction of being a forest-dweller, etc., by birth. The conceit “I am an alms-food-eater” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being an alms-food-eater, etc., and on the distinction of being an alms-food-eater, etc., by birth.🔽The conceit “I am one who goes on unbroken tour of the villages in due order” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who goes on unbroken tour of the villages in due order, etc., and on the distinction of being one who goes on unbroken tour of the villages in due order, etc., by birth.

original: Kiñcāpi parivāra-ggahaṇena yaso gahito. Parivārassa pana savasavattakabhāvena patthaṭataṃ🔽kittiyasaññeva vā nissāya yasamado. Parisuddhasīlaṃ, upacārappanājhānaṃ, sippakosallaṃ,🔽sarīrassa ārohasampadaṃ, pariṇāhasampadaṃ, anūnaniddosaaṅgapaccaṅgatāya sarīrapāripūriñca
analyzed: kiñca api parivāra ggahaṇena yasaḥ gahito parivārassa pana  kittiya saññā iva vā nissāya yasa madaḥ parisuddha sīlam upacāra ppanā jhānam sippa kosallam  sarīrassa āroha sampadam pariṇāha sampadam anūna niddosa aṅga paccaṅga tāya sarīra pāripūriñca
translated: The conceit “I am one who wears rag-robes” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who wears rag-robes, etc., and on the distinction of being one who wears rag-robes, etc., by birth.🔽The conceit “I am one who wears robes of fine cloth” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who wears robes of fine cloth, etc., and on the distinction of being one who wears robes of fine cloth, etc., by birth.🔽The conceit “I am one who wears robes made of pieces” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of pieces, etc., and on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of pieces, etc., by birth.

original: nissāya sīlamadādayo veditabbā.
analyzed: nissāya sīla mada ādayaḥ veditabbā
translated: The conceit “I am one who wears robes made of strips” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of strips, etc., and on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of strips, etc., by birth.

original: Iminā ettakena ṭhānena savatthukaṃ mānaṃ dassetvā idāni avatthukameva sāmaññato mānaṃ
analyzed: iminā ettakena ṭhānena sa vatthukam mānam dassetvā idāni avatthukam eva sāmaññataḥ mānam
translated: The conceit “I am one who wears robes made of sweepings” and so on should be understood as based on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of sweepings, etc., and on the distinction of being one who wears robes made of sweepings, etc., by birth.🔽The conceit

original: dassento “mado”ti āha. Pamādotiādīsu pañcakāmaguṇesu cittavossaggasaṅkhāto sucaritāsevanāya,
analyzed: dassentaḥ mado ti āha pamādo ti ādīsu pañca kāmaguṇesu citta vossagga saṅkhāto su carita āsevanāya
translated: and so he said “conceit” . In the case of “negligence” , etc., negligence is a term for the arising of unprofitable cognizance in the form of a state of being negligent as cause for the practice of good conduct and for the practice of bad conduct in the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: duccaritasevanāya ca hetubhūto pamajjanākārappavatto akusalacittuppādo pamādo nāma,
analyzed: duccarita sevanāya ca hetu bhūto pamajjana ākāra ppavatto akusala cittuppādo pamādaḥ nāma
translated: This is called “negligence” . Its characteristic is the state of being negligent.

original: svāyaṃ sativossaggalakkhaṇo. Vātabharitabhattā viya mātāpitūsupi anoṇatabhāvasaṅkhāto
analyzed: su ayam sati vossagga lakkhaṇaḥ vāta bharita bhattā viya mātā pitūsu pi an oṇata bhāva saṅkhātaḥ
translated: Like a servant who is not respectful to his master, it is a state of being unrespectful to one’s mother and father.

original: kakkhaḷamāno thambho nāma, svāyaṃ cittassa uddhumātabhāvalakkhaṇo. Aññesaṃ gehādiupakaraṇasampadaṃ,
analyzed: kakkhaḷamāno thambhaḥ nāma svāyam cittassa uddhumāta bhāva lakkhaṇo aññesam geha ādi upakaraṇa sampadam
translated: This is called “stiffness” . Its characteristic is the state of being stiff in cognizance.

original: vijjāsampadaṃ vā disvā taddiguṇasamārambhanavasappavatto akusalacittuppādo sārambho
analyzed: vijjā sampadam vā disvā tad diguṇa samārambhana vasa ppavattaḥ akusala cittuppādaḥ sa ārambhaḥ
translated: When one sees the excellence of others’ houses, etc., or their excellence in the sciences, and one’s unprofitable cognizance occurs in the form of a state of being set on that excellence, this is called “being set on excellence” .

original: nāma. Ganthopi hi sārambhavasena uggahetuṃ na vaṭṭati, akusalameva hoti. Svāyaṃ karaṇuttariyalakkhaṇo.
analyzed: nāma ganthaḥ api hi sa ārambha vasena uggahetum na vaṭṭati akusalam eva hoti su āyam karaṇa uttariya lakkhaṇo
translated: For even the learning of a text by being set on excellence is not allowable, it is only unprofitable. Its characteristic is the state of being beyond what should be done.

original: Atra atra visaye icchā assāti atriccho, puggalo, tassa bhāvo atricchatā. Evaṃ mahicchatādīsupi
analyzed: atra atra visaye icchā assa ati atriccho puggalo tassa bhāvaḥ atricchatā evam mahicchata ādīsu pi
translated: Here and there is atricchā ; a person who has that is atricchā ; this is the meaning of atricchatā . So too with mahicchatā , etc.

original: attho veditabbo. Tattha yaṃ yaṃ laddhaṃ, tena tena asantussitvā aparassa aparassa🔽patthanāvasena pavatto lobho atricchatā. Yāya attanā laddhaṃ paṇītampi lāmakaṃ viya
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbo tattha yam yam laddham tena tena a santussitvā aparassa aparassa  patthanā vasena pavattaḥ lobhaḥ atricchatā yāya attanā laddham paṇītam pi lāmakam viya
translated: The meaning should be understood. Herein, discontent with what is acquired and the occurrence of greed by way of aspiration for more and more🔽is discontent. By means of this, even what is acquired as excellent appears as if it were poor,

original: khāyati, parena laddhaṃ lāmakampi paṇītaṃ viya khāyati. Sāyaṃ aparāparalābhapatthanālakkhaṇā.
analyzed: khāyati parena laddham lāmakam pi paṇītam viya khāyati sāyam apara apara lābha patthanā lakkhaṇā
translated: and what is acquired by another even if it is poor appears as if it were excellent. This is the characteristic of discontent.

original: Santaguṇavibhāvanāvasappavatto ceva taduppannehi atimahantehipi vatthūhi asantussanākārappavatto
analyzed: ca iva tad uppannehi ati mahantehi pi vatthūhi a santussana ākāra ppavatto
translated: Greed that occurs by way of the manifestation of the special qualities of the peaceful and by way of the occurrence of the mode of non-contentment with the very great things that arise from that

original: ca lobho mahicchatā. Yāya samannāgato puggalo paccayehi duppūro aggi viya upādānena,
analyzed: ca lobhaḥ mahiccha tā samannāgataḥ puggalo paccayehi duppūraḥ aggi upādānena
translated: is great greed. One who is endowed with this is difficult to satisfy with requisites like a fire with fuel,

original: samuddo viya ca udakena. Yā cāyaṃ santaguṇasambhāvanatā, paṭiggahaṇe ca paribhoge
analyzed: samuddaḥ viya ca udakena yā ca ayam santa guṇa sambhāvana tā paṭiggahaṇe ca paribhoge
translated: like the ocean with the water that flows into it from the four directions. And this manifestation of the special qualities of the peaceful and this lack of knowledge of moderation in receiving and using

original: ca amattaññutā, etaṃ mahicchatālakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca amattaññu tā etam mahiccha tā lakkhaṇam
translated: are the characteristic of great greed.

original: Asantānaṃ pana saddhāsīlānaṃ, maggaphalādīnañca lokiyalokuttarānaṃ guṇānaṃ vibhāvanāvasappavatto
analyzed: asantānam pana saddhā sīlānam magga phala ādīnam ca lokiya lokuttarānam guṇānam vibhāvanā vasa pavatto
translated: The manifestation of the special qualities of faith and virtue, of the path, fruit, etc., and of mundane and supramundane special qualities that are not continuous

original: ceva taduppannehi atimahantehipi paccayehi asantussanākārappavatto ca lobho pāpicchatā.
analyzed: ca iva tad uppannehi ati mahantehi pi paccayehi a santussana ākāra ppavattaḥ ca lobhaḥ pāpa icchā tā
translated: And greed is also covetousness in the form of discontent with the requisites even when they are abundant and of the highest quality.

original: Yā cāyaṃ asantaguṇasambhāvanatā, paṭiggahaṇe ca paribhoge ca amattaññutā etaṃ pāpicchatālakkhaṇaṃ.🔽Siṅganti vijjhanaṭṭhena siṅgaṃ, nāgarikabhāvasaṅkhātassa kilesasiṅgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ,
analyzed: yā ca ayam asanta guṇa sambhāvana tā paṭiggahaṇe ca paribhoge ca amattaññu tā etam pāpa iccha tā lakkhaṇam  siṅganti vijjhana ṭṭhena siṅgam nāgarika bhāva saṅkhātassa kilesa siṅgassa itam adhivacanam
translated: And the characteristic of covetousness is the esteeming of non-existent good qualities and lack of contentment in accepting and using .🔽“A rut” is a rut in the sense of a place for wallowing; it is a term for the defilement called “rutting like an elephant in rut” .

original: taṃ atthato siṅgārakaraṇavasappavatto lobhova. Tintiṇanti khīyanaṃ, taṃ atthato nivāsaṭṭhāne🔽sunakhānaṃ viya aññamaññaṃ sattānaṃ “tava santakaṃ, mama santaka”nti khiyyanākārappavatto
analyzed: tam atthatas siṅgāra karaṇa vasa ppavatto lobhaḥ uva khīyanam tam atthatas nivāsa ṭṭhāne  su nakhānam viya aññam aññam sattānam tava santakam mama santakam ti khiyyan ākāra ppavatto
translated: In fact it is greed that occurs as the act of wallowing in it. “A quarrel” is a dispute; in fact it is hate that occurs as the act of disputing with other beings over ownership of a dwelling place,

original: dosova. Cāpalyanti capalatā, taṃ pattacīvarādiparikkhārānaṃ, attabhāvassa ca maṇḍanavibhūsanakeḷāyanavasappavatto
analyzed: dosaḥ uva cāpalyanti capala tā tam atta bhāvassa ca maṇḍana vibhūsana keḷāyana vasa ppavatto
translated: like dogs over the ownership of a bone. “Frivolity” is fickleness; in fact it is greed that occurs as the act of adorning and beautifying the requisites such as the bowl and the robe and the body,

original: rāgova, yena samannāgato jiṇṇopi daharo viya hoti. Asabhāgavuttīti visabhāgavutti
analyzed: rāgaḥ uva yena samannāgataḥ jiṇṇaḥ api daharaḥ viya hoti asabhāga vuttī iti visabhāga vutti
translated: and by means of which one who possesses it appears young even though aged. “Improper search” is search that is not in accordance with the True Idea ;

original: visabhāgakiriyā, sā garuṭṭhāniyesupi anādaravasena vipaccanīkaggāhitāvasappavatto
analyzed: visa bhāga kiriyā sā anādara vasena
translated: Disliking is the opposite of liking. It is a kind of hate that occurs as non-acceptance of the opposite of what is disagreeable, as non-preference for it, as non-desire for it, as non-willing of it, as non-consent to it, as non- approval of it, as non-agreement to it, as non-acquiescence in it, as non-patience with it, as non-tolerance of it.

original: dosova, yāya samannāgato gilānepi mātāpituācariyupajjhāyādike na oloketi, tehi saddhiṃ🔽lābhasakkārakāraṇā kalahaṃ karoti, tesu hirottappaṃ, cetiyādīsu cittīkārañca na paccupaṭṭhapeti.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ gilāne api mātā pitu ācariya upajjhāya ādike na oloketi tehi saddhiṃ  lābha sakkāra kāraṇā kalaham karoti tesu hirottappam cetiya ādīsu cittīkāram ca na paccupaṭṭhapeti
translated: It is a kind of hate that occurs as non-regard for mother and father, teachers and superiors, etc., even when they are sick, through lack of respect and esteem.

original: Aratīti pantesu senāsanesu, samathavipassanāsu ca anabhiramaṇā ukkaṇṭhitatā, sā tathāpavatto🔽akusalacittuppādo. Tandīti ālasyaṃ. Vijambhitāti kāyassa ānamanādiākārena phandanā
analyzed: arati iti pantesu senāsanesu samatha vipassanāsu ca an abhiramaṇā ukkaṇṭhita tā sā tathā pavatto  akusala cittuppādo tandī iti ālasyam vijambhitā ati kāyassa ānamana ādi ākārena phandanā
translated: It is a kind of hate that occurs as quarrelling with mother and father, teachers and superiors, etc., through desire for gain and honour.🔽Discontent is dissatisfaction with the lodging, etc., and with serenity and insight. It is a kind of unprofitable consciousness that occurs as dissatisfaction with them.🔽Dullness is laziness. Yawning is the gaping of the mouth, etc., that occurs with the body.

original: vijambhanā. Bhattasammadoti bhattamucchāya kāyassa akammaññatā. Cetaso ca līnattanti
analyzed: vijambhanā bhatta sammado ti bhatta mucchāya kāyassa akammañña tā cetaso ca līnattanti
translated: It is a kind of unprofitable consciousness that occurs as the body’s unserviceability after eating.

original: cittasaṅkoco. Atthato panetāni sabbānipi thinamiddhavasena cittassa gilānākārova.
analyzed: citta saṅkocaḥ atthataḥ pana etāni sabbāni pi thinam iddha vasena cittassa gilāna ākāraḥ uva
translated: Depression is the contraction of the mind. But in fact all these are sicknesses of the mind that occur as depression and drowsiness.

original: Kuhanātiādīsu lābhasakkārasilokasannissitassa pāpicchassa tena tena upāyena vimhāpanā
analyzed: kuhanā ti ādīsu lābha sakkāra siloka sannissitassa pāpa icchassa tena tena upāyena vimhāpanā
translated: Scheming is the deceiving of others by various ruses on the part of one who is devoted to gain, honour and fame and who has evil desires.

original: kuhanā nāma. Sā tividhā paccayapaṭisevanasāmantajappanairiyāpathasaṇṭhāpanavasena.🔽Tattha cīvarādīhi nimantitassa tadatthikasseva sato pāpicchataṃ nissāya paṭikkhipanena,
analyzed: kuhanā nāma sā tividhā paccaya paṭisevana sāmanta jappana eriyāpatha saṇṭhāpana vasena  tattha cīvara ādīhi nimantitassa tad atthikassa iva sataḥ pāpicchatam nissāya paṭikkhipanena
translated: Hypocrisy is of three kinds: hypocrisy in receiving requisites, hypocrisy in hinting, and hypocrisy in making a display of conduct.

original: te ca gahapatike attani suppatiṭṭhitasaddhe ñatvā puna tesaṃ “aho ayyo appiccho na🔽kiñci paṭiggaṇhituṃ icchati, suladdhaṃ vata no assa, sace appamattakaṃ kiñci paṭiggaṇheyyā”ti
analyzed: te ca gahapatike attani suppatiṭṭhita saddhe ñatvā puna tesam aho ayyaḥ appicchaḥ na  kiñci paṭiggaṇhitum icchati su laddham vata no assa sace appamattakam kiñci paṭiggaṇheyya ati
translated: Herein, when one who is in need and deserves to be given robe-material, etc., refuses it out of greed for gain, thinking, “If I refuse, they will bring me other things,”

original: nānāvidhehi upāyehi paṇītāni cīvarādīni upanāmentānaṃ tadanuggahakāmataññeva āvikatvā
analyzed: nānāvidhehi upāyehi paṇītāni cīvara ādīni upanāmentānam āvika tvā
translated: and when the householders, seeing that he is well established in them, bring him various kinds of fine robe-material, etc., by various means,🔽and when he receives it, making his greed for offerings evident,

original: paṭiggahaṇena ca tato pabhuti api sakaṭabhārehi upanāmanahetubhūtaṃ vimhāpanaṃ paccayapaṭisevanasaṅkhātā
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇena ca tatas pabhuti api sakaṭa bhārehi upanāmana hetu bhūtam vimhāpanam paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātā
translated: the deception of causing them to bring even by the load is called hypocrisy in receiving requisites.

original: kuhanā nāma. Pāpicchasseva pana sato “yo evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ dhāreti, so samaṇo mahesakkho”tiādinā
analyzed: kuhanā nāma pāpa icchassa iva pana sataḥ yaḥ evarūpam cīvaram dhāreti saḥ samaṇaḥ mahesakkhaḥ iti ādinā
translated: But when one who is greedy for gain thinks, “Whoever wears such and such a kind of robe is held in esteem as a great man,” and he wears such a robe,

original: uttarimanussadhammādhigamaparidīpanavācāya tathā tathā vimhāpanaṃ sāmantajappanasaṅkhātā🔽kuhanā nāma. Pāpicchasseva pana sato samāhitasseva sambhāvanādhippāyakatena paṇidhāya
analyzed: uttari manussa dhamma adhigama paridīpana vācāya tathā tathā vimhāpanam sāmanta jappana saṅkhātā  kuhanā nāma pāpa icchassa iva pana sataḥ samāhitassa iva sambhāvanā adhippāya katena paṇidhāya
translated: The deceiving of others by means of speech that reveals the attainment of a superhuman state in such and such a way is called “dissimulation” .

original: saṇṭhapitena gamanādiiriyāpathena vimhāpanaṃ iriyāpathasaṇṭhapanasaṅkhātā kuhanā nāma.
analyzed: saṇṭhapitena gamana ādi iriyāpathena vimhāpanam iriyāpatha saṇṭhapana saṅkhātā kuhanā nāma
translated: But when one who is of evil wishes, though concentrated, deceives others by means of a posture that he has adopted with the intention of being thought concentrated, this is called “posturing” .

original: Ālapanātiādinā pana vuttapaccayapaṭisaṃyuttā vācāyeva dassitā. Anuppiyabhāṇitā, cāṭukamyatā,🔽muggasūpyatā, pāribhaṭayatā ca ālapanā nāma. Tattha ālapanātiāditova lapanā. Anuppiyabhāṇitāti🔽saccānurūpaṃ, dhammānurūpaṃ vā anapaloketvā punappunaṃ piyabhaṇanaṃ. Cāṭukamyatāti
analyzed: ālapana ati ādinā pana vutta paccaya paṭisaṃyuttā vācāya iva dassitā anuppiya bhāṇi tā cāṭu kamya tā  mugga sūpya tā pāribhaṭaya tā ca ālapanā nāma tattha lapanā anuppiya bhāṇitā ti  sacca anurūpam dhamma anurūpam vā an apaloketvā punappunam piya bhaṇanam cāṭu kamyatā ati
translated: But the speech connected with the conditions stated in the passage beginning, “Flattery” , is shown by the words “flattery” , “clamour” ,🔽“fawning” , and “servility” . Herein, flattery is speech that is the opposite of what is in one’s mind. Clamour is speech that is the opposite of what is in one’s mind and is intended to make others think that one is possessed of special qualities.

original: nīcavuttitā, attānaṃ heṭṭhato ṭhapetvā pavattanaṃ. Muggasūpyatāti muggasūpasadisatā,
analyzed: nīca vutti tā attānam heṭṭhatas ṭhapetvā pavattanam mugga sūpya tā ati mugga sūpa sadisa tā
translated: Fawning is speech that is the opposite of what is in one’s mind and is intended to make others think that one is possessed of special qualities and is humble. Servility is speech that is the opposite of what is in one’s mind and is intended to make others think that one is possessed of special qualities and is humble and is a slave.

original: apakkamuggasadisena appasaccena samannāgatavacanatā. Pāribhaṭayatāti kuladārakānaṃ
analyzed: a pakka mugga sadisena appasaccena samannāgata vacana tā pāribhaṭayatā ati kula dārakānam
translated: and the speech is accompanied by little truth, like a dung beetle. “Flattery” is the act of a pimp,

original: aṅkena pariharaṇādikaṃ paribhaṭassa kiccaṃ. Evamayaṃ sabbopi kiriyābhedo “lapanā”tveva
analyzed: aṅkena pariharaṇa ādikam paribhaṭassa kiccam evam ayam sabbaḥ api kiriyā bhedaḥ
translated: such as carrying a young man of good family on one’s hip. Thus all these different kinds of action are called “flattery.”

original: vuccati. Paresaṃ pana paccayadānasaññājanakaṃ kāyavacīkammaṃ nemittikatā nāma, yā🔽“parikathobhāsanimittakamma”nti vuccati. Akkosanavambhanagarahaṇādīhi yathā dāyako
analyzed: vuccati paresam pana paccaya dāna saññā janakam kāya vacī kammam nemittika tā nāma yā  parikathā ubhāsa nimitta kammanti vuccati akkosana vambhana garahaṇa ādīhi yathā dāyako
translated: But the bodily and verbal action of one who gives requisites to others in order to make them think he is generous is called “ostentation,”🔽which is said to be “the action of one who makes a sign by indirect talk.”

original: avaṇṇaṃ bhāyati, evaṃ taṃ nippīḷanaṃ nippesikatā nāma. Ayaṃ hi yasmā veḷupesikāya🔽viya abbhaṅgaṃ imāya parassa guṇaṃ nippeseti nipuñchati, yasmā vā gandhajātaṃ pisitvā
analyzed: avaṇṇam bhāyati evam tam nippīḷanam nippesika tā nāma ayam hi yasmai veḷu pesikāya  viya abbhaṅgam imāya parassa guṇam nippeseti nipuñchati yasmai vā gandha jātam pisitvā
translated: By scolding, threatening, and seizing, etc., one oppresses another in such a way that the giver becomes disreputable. This is called “oppression.”🔽For this “oppresses” the other’s virtue, as a bamboo-splitter does a bamboo, or it “oppresses” his virtue by “crushing” it, as a perfume-maker does a flower by crushing it to extract the scent.

original: gandhamagganā viya paraguṇe nippisitvā vicuṇṇetvā esā lābhamagganā hoti, tasmā “nippesikatā”ti
analyzed: gandha magganā viya para guṇe nippisitvā vicuṇṇetvā esā lābha magganā hoti tasmā
translated: Or it is called “oppression” because it is the “taking” of the “prize” of gain by “crushing” and “pulverizing” the other’s virtue, as a perfume-maker does a flower.

original: vuccati. Ekasmiṃ pana kule laddhāmisaṃ aññattha dānavasena lābhena lābhassa patthanā
analyzed: vuccati ekasmim pana kule laddha āmisam aññattha dāna vasena lābhena lābhassa patthanā
translated: But the act of hoping for gain by means of gain, by giving what has been received in one place in another,

original: lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanā nāma. Ime ca kuhanādayo pañcapi tathā tathā pavattā lobhādiakusalacittuppādāti
analyzed: lābhena lābham nijigīsanāḥ nāma ime ca kuhanā ādayaḥ tathā tathā pavattā lobha ādi akusala cittuppādā ti
translated: and “to seek gain with gain” are the five kinds of hypocrisy, etc., that occur in such and such a way as the production of unprofitable cognizance beginning with greed.

original: veditabbā. “Seyyohamasmī”tiādayo dvādasa mānā heṭṭhā saṃyojanagocchake vuttānusārena🔽suviññeyyāva. Tattha ca ādito tayo mānā puggalaṃ anissāya jātigottarūpabhogasippasutādimānavatthuvaseneva
analyzed: veditabbā seyyā uham asmi iti ādayaḥ dvādasa mānāḥ heṭṭhā saṃyojana gocchake vutta anusārena  tattha ca āditaḥ tayaḥ mānā puggalam a nissāya
translated: The twelve kinds of conceit beginning with “I am superior” are easily understandable in the way stated in the chapter on the fetters.

original: kathitā, tato paraṃ pana nava mānā seyyasadisahīnapuggale nissāya kathitā.
analyzed: kathitā tato param pana nava mānā seyya sadisa hīna puggale nissāya kathitā
translated: And here the first three kinds of conceit are stated in the way beginning, “On the part of one who has gone forth into homelessness” , and the rest are stated in the way beginning, “On the part of one who has gone forth into homelessness” .🔽So these twelve kinds of conceit are stated with a basis.

original: Evametehi dvādasahi padehi savatthuke māne kathetvā idāni avatthukaṃ dassetuṃ “māno”tiādi
analyzed: evam etehi dvādasahi padehi savatthuke māne kathetvā idāni avatthukam dassetum māna utiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the one without a basis, he said “conceit” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tato paraṃ atimānotiādīsu “jātiādīhi mayā sadiso natthī”ti atikkamitvā maññanāvasena
analyzed: vuttam tatas param atimānaḥ tiādīsu jāti ādīhi mayā sadisaḥ natthi iti atikkamitvā maññanā vasena
translated: After that, in the case of the “overweening conceit” , etc., the conceit that occurs by overstepping and by assuming “There is no one equal to me in respect of clan, etc.,” is called “overweening conceit.”

original: pavatto māno atimāno nāma. “Ime mayā pubbe sadisā, idāni ahaṃ seṭṭho, ime hīnatarā”ti
analyzed: pavattaḥ mānaḥ atimānaḥ nāma ime mayā pubbe sadisāḥ idāni aham seṭṭhaḥ ime hīnatarā ti
translated: “These were my equals formerly, but now I am the best, they are inferior,”

original: uppanno māno bhārātibhāro viya mānātimāno nāma. Attānaṃ pana avamaññanāvasena pavatto🔽māno omāno nāma, so “hīnohamasmī”ti pavattahīnamānasadisova. Anadhigatesu ariyadhammesu
analyzed: uppannaḥ mānaḥ bhāra atibhāraḥ viya māna atimānaḥ nāma attānam pana avamaññanā vasena pavatto  mānaḥ omānaḥ nāma saḥ hīnaḥ ham asmi iti pavatta hīna māna sadisaḥ uva anadhigatesu ariya dhammesu
translated: Conceit that has arisen is called “overweening conceit” as a burden that is too heavy a load.🔽Conceit that occurs by way of despising oneself is called “conceit of inferiority.” It is like the “conceit of inferiority” that occurs thus, “I am inferior.”

original: “adhigatā mayā”ti uppanno māno adhikamānattā adhimāno nāma, ayaṃ pana sotāpannādiariyasāvakānaṃ🔽“ahaṃ sakadāgāmī”tiādinā na uppajjati tesaṃ maggaphalanibbānapahīnakilesāvasiṭṭhakilesapaccavekkhaṇena
analyzed: adhigatā mayā ati uppannaḥ mānaḥ adhika mānattā adhimānaḥ nāma ayam pana sotāpanna ādi ariya sāvakānam  aham sakadāgāmī iti ādinā na uppajjati tesam magga phala nibbāna pahīna kilesa avasiṭṭha kilesa paccavekkhaṇena
translated: Conceit that occurs thus, “I have attained the noble states that I have not attained” is called “conceit of attainment” because of the excess of conceit. But this does not arise in noble disciples who are stream-enterers, etc.,🔽because they are free from doubt about the penetration of the noble qualities by reviewing the defilements that have been abandoned by the path and fruit and those that remain.

original: ariyaguṇapaṭivedhe nikkaṅkhattā. Dussīlassa pana na uppajjateva, sīlavatopi pariccattakammaṭṭhānassa
analyzed: ariya guṇa paṭivedhe nikkaṅkha ttā dussīlassa pana na uppajjatā iva sīlavato pi pariccatta kammaṭṭhānassa
translated: It does not arise in the unvirtuous either, nor in the virtuous who have neglected the meditation subject,

original: na uppajjati, parisuddhasīlasseva pana suddhasamathalābhino, suddhavipassanālābhino,
analyzed: na uppajjati parisuddha sīlassa iva pana suddha samatha lābhino suddha vipassanā lābhino
translated: but it arises in one who is pure in morality and has attained either serenity or insight,

original: tadubhayalābhino vā uppajjati. Tesu tadubhayalābhī arahatte eva adhimaññitvā patiṭṭhāti
analyzed: tad ubhaya lābhinaḥ vā uppajjati tesu tad ubhaya lābhī arahatte eva adhimaññitvā patiṭṭhāti
translated: or both. Of these, one who has attained both stands firm after surmounting conceit in arahantship.

original: suvikkhambhitakilesattā, parimadditasaṅkhārattā ca, itare sotāpannādīsupīti veditabbā.
analyzed: su vikkhambhita kilesa ttā parimaddita saṅkhāra ttā ca itare sotāpanna ādīsu pi iti veditabbā
translated: and because defilements are well suppressed in them and because they have trodden down the formations, they should be understood as the opposite of the stream-enterer and the others.🔽But the conceit “I am” that occurs in the five aggregates is called the conceit “I am.”

original: Pañcasu pana khandhesu “ahamasmī”tiādinā pavatto māno asmimāno nāma. Pāpakena pana🔽parūpaghātakena kammāyatanasippāyatanavijjāṭṭhānādinā attānaṃ seyyādito jappanavasena
analyzed: pañcasu pana khandhesu aham asmi iti ādinā pavatto mānaḥ asmimānaḥ nāma pāpakena pana  parūpaghātakena kamma āyatana sippāyatana vijjāṭṭhāna ādinā attānam seyya āditaḥ jappana vasena
translated: But the conceit that occurs by way of boasting oneself as better, etc., by means of evil,

original: pavatto māno micchāmāno nāma.
analyzed: pavattaḥ mānaḥ micchāmānaḥ nāma
translated: wicked deeds, by means of the bases of sensual pleasure, by means of the bases of craft and trickery, by means of the bases of learning, etc., is called the wrong conceit.

original: Ñātivitakkotiādīsu “mayhaṃ ñātakā sukhajīvino sampattiyuttā”ti evaṃ gehasitapemena🔽ñātake uddissa uppanno vitakko ñātivitakko nāma, “ñātakā khayaṃ gatā vayaṃ gatā saddhā
analyzed: ñāti vitakka uti ādīsu mayham ñātakā sukha jīvino sampatti yuttā ati evam geha sita pemena  ñātake uddissa uppannaḥ vitakkaḥ ñātivitakkaḥ nāma ñātakā khayam gatā vayam gatā saddhā
translated: As regards the thought of kinsmen, etc., the thought that occurs with the affection of a house- dweller, thinking “My kinsmen are happy, prosperous, and successful,”

original: pasannā”tiādinā pana nekkhammasito ñātivitakko nāma na hoti. Evaṃ janapadavitakkepi,
analyzed: pasannā ti ādinā pana nekkhamma sitaḥ ñāti vitakkaḥ nāma na hoti evam janapada vitakke pi
translated: is called the thought of kinsmen. But the thought of kinsmen that occurs with the affection of one gone forth, thinking “My kinsmen have passed away, have died, have gone to decay, have become cool,” is not called the thought of kinsmen. So too with the thought of the country.

original: tassa pana “amhākaṃ janapado subhikkho sundaro”tiādinā pavattiākāro veditabbo. Amaratthāya
analyzed: tassa pana amhākam janapadaḥ subhikkhaḥ sundaraḥ iti ādinā pavatti ākāraḥ veditabbaḥ amara atthāya
translated: But the mode of occurrence of that should be understood as follows: “Our country is prosperous, our country is happy.”

original: vitakko, amaro vā vitakkoti amaravitakko. Tattha yo ukkuṭikappadhānādīhi dukkhe nijjiṇṇe
analyzed: vitakkaḥ amaraḥ vā amaravitakko tattha yaḥ ukkuṭika padhāna ādīhi dukkhe nijjiṇṇe
translated: or the deathless is thought, thus it is the deathless thought. Herein, that which is worn out by the practice of the cross-legged posture, etc., in pain,

original: samparāye attā sukhī amaro hotīti evaṃ pavatto, so amaratthāya vitakko nāma. Yo pana🔽diṭṭhigatikassa ekasmiṃ pakkhe asaṇṭhahitvā “evampi me no, tathāpi me no, aññathāpi
analyzed: samparāye attā sukhī amaraḥ hoti iti evam pavattaḥ saḥ amara atthāya vitakkaḥ nāma yaḥ pana  diṭṭhigatikassa ekasmin pakkhe a saṇṭhahitvā evam pi me no tathā api me no aññathā api
translated: or it is the thought of the deathless, thus it is the thought of the deathless. Herein, that which occurs thus, “In the next existence let my self be happy and immortal,” is called the thought of the immortal.

original: me no”tiādinā amaramaccho viya gahetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya pavatto, so amaro vitakko
analyzed: me no ti ādinā amara macchaḥ viya gahetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya pavattaḥ saḥ amaraḥ vitakko
translated: But that which occurs as the inability to grasp by settling on one side, as happens in one who has views, thus, “It is not so for me, it is not so for me, it is not so for me,” like a man who cannot grasp a snake, is called the thought of the deathless.

original: nāma. Taṃ duvidhampi ekato katvā idha “amaravitakko”ti vutto.🔽Anuddayatā patirūpakena pana gihīhi sahasokisahananditādivasena gehasitapemena yutto🔽parānuddayatāpaṭisaṃyutto vitakko nāma. Lābhena ceva sakkārena ca kittisaddena ca
analyzed: nāma tam duvidham pi ekatas katvā idha amaravitakkaḥ ti vutto  an uddaya tā pati rūpakena pana gihīhi saha soki saha nanditā divasena geha sita pemena yuttaḥ  para anuddaya tā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ nāma lābhena ca iva sakkārena ca kitti saddena ca
translated: Both these kinds together are called “the thought of the deathless” here.🔽The thought associated with the non-aversion that is associated with the affection for a house-holder’s life that is accompanied by the ability to bear sorrow and the ability to enjoy happiness, etc., is called the thought associated with the non-aversion to others.

original: saddhiṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena yutto gehasito vitakko lābhasakkārasilokapaṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: saddhim ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena yuttaḥ gehasitaḥ vitakkaḥ lābha sakkāra siloka paṭisaṃyuttaḥ
translated: The thought associated with the affection for a house-holder’s life that is accompanied by the making of an object of gain, honour, and fame, is called the thought associated with gain, honour, and fame.

original: vitakko nāma, tassa pana “aho vata me lābhādayo uppajjeyyu”ntiādinā pavattiākāro
analyzed: vitakkaḥ nāma tassa pana aho vata me lābha ādayaḥ uppajjeyyun ti ādinā pavatti ākāraḥ
translated: The mode of occurrence of this is to be known thus: “Oh, may gain, honour, etc., arise for me!” “Oh, may others not despise me!” is the occurrence of the form of thought called “not being despised” .

original: veditabbo. “Aho vata maṃ pare na avajāneyyu”nti uppanno gehasito vitakko anavaññattipaṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: veditabbaḥ aho vata mama pare na avajāneyyun ti uppannaḥ gehasitaḥ vitakkaḥ anavaññatti paṭisaṃyutto
translated: This is the form of thought called “not being despised.”

original: vitakko nāma. Ekakaṃ.🔽Dukādīsu kodhādayo heṭṭhā vuttatthe vajjetvā avasesānaññeva vaṇṇanā hoti. Tattha
analyzed: vitakkaḥ nāma ekakam  duka ādīsu kodha ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta tthe vajjetvā avasesa anaññā iva vaṇṇanā hoti tattha
translated: The form of thought called “not being despised” is one.🔽In the case of the words beginning with “anger” in the section on the three roots, etc., the explanation is given only of those that are not included in the words already dealt with.

original: dukesu tāva upanāhotiādīsu pubbabhāge kodho “akkocchima”ntiādinā āsevanena aparakāle🔽veracitte daḷhataraṃ ābaddho upanāho nāma, yena samannāgato veraṃ nissajjituṃ na
analyzed: dukesu tāva upanāhaḥ ti ādīsu pubba bhāge kodhaḥ akkocchimanti ādinā āsevanena apara kāle  vera citte daḷhataram ābaddhaḥ upanāhaḥ nāma yena samannāgataḥ veram nissajjitum na
translated: Herein, in the case of the two words “enmity” and “spite,” etc., in the first place, anger is “the state of being closed” , etc., which occurs in the earlier stage.🔽Later on, when it has become firmly bound up with the mind, it is called “enmity,” by which one is unable to give up an enmity, just as a cloth soaked in oil is unable to give up a stain.

original: sakkoti vasātelamakkhitapilotikā viya, sodhiyamānampissa cittaṃ na parisujjhati,
analyzed: sakkoti vasā tela makkhita pilotikā viya sodhiyamānam pi ssa cittam na parisujjhati
translated: And when one is angry, one’s mind does not become clear,

original: svāyaṃ verupanibandhanalakkhaṇo.
analyzed: su ayam veḥ upanibandhana lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: and its characteristic is that of binding one to enmity.

original: Paraguṇaṃ pana vināsetvā tattha dosamakkhanavasena pavatto kodho makkho nāma. Ayaṃ
analyzed: para guṇam pana vināsetvā tattha dosa makkhana vasena pavatto kodhaḥ makkhaḥ nāma ayaṃ
translated: But spite is anger that occurs by way of a mental impression of hatred after destroying another’s special qualities. Its characteristic is

original: hi paṭhamataraṃ attano cittaṃ gūtho viya gūthaggāhakaṃ hatthaṃ makkheti, pacchā paranti
analyzed: hi paṭhamataram attanaḥ cittam gūthaḥ viya gūtha ggāhakam hattham makkheti pacchā paranti
translated: for he first smears his own mind as a privy-smearing man smears his hand, and afterwards others.🔽“Malice” is so called because of the characteristic of smearing others with one’s own faults. “Deceit” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing one’s own faults by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.

original: “makkho”ti vutto, svāyaṃ paraguṇamakkhanalakkhaṇo. Paḷāsetīti paḷāso, parassa guṇe🔽dassetvā attano guṇehi same karotīti attho. Tathāpavatto lobho, svāyaṃ yugaggāhalakkhaṇo.
analyzed: makkho ti vutto svāyam para guṇa makkhana lakkhaṇo paḷāseti iti paḷāsaḥ parassa guṇe  dassetvā attanaḥ guṇehi same karoti iti attho tathā pavattaḥ lobho yuga ggāha lakkhaṇo
translated: “Guile” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing one’s own good qualities.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.

original: Dvārattayepi vijjamānasseva dosassa paṭicchādanato cakkhumohanamāyā viyāti māyā,🔽sā katadosapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā. Saṭhassa bhāvo, kammaṃ vā sāṭheyyaṃ, kerāṭiyaṃ,
analyzed: dvāra ttaye pi vijjamānassa iva dosassa paṭicchādanato cakkhu mohana māyā viyāti māyā  sā kata dosa paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā saṭhassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā sāṭheyyam kerāṭiyam
translated: “Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.

original: taṃ avijjamānaguṇappakāsanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: tam a vijjamāna guṇa pakāsana lakkhaṇam
translated: “Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.🔽“Concealment” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing non-existent good qualities in oneself.

original: Anajjavādayo heṭṭhā vuttaajjavādipaṭipakkhaakusalavasena veditabbā. Ajjhattasaṃyojanantiādīsu🔽ajjhattanti kāmabhavo, tattha satte bandhanavasena pavattāni pañcorambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni
analyzed: anajjavā ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta ajjavā ādi paṭipakkha akusala vasena veditabbā ajjhatta saṃyojana nti ādīsu 🔽ajjhattam ti kāma bhavaḥ tattha satte bandhana vasena pavattāni pañca urambhāgiya saṃyojanāni
translated: “Fraud” is so called because of the characteristic of concealing faults that have occurred by revealing

original: ajjhattasaṃyojanaṃ nāma. Bahiddhāti rūpārūpabhavo. Tattha bandhanavasena pavattāni🔽pañca uddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni bahiddhāsaṃyojanaṃ nāma. Kāmabhave hi sattānaṃ ālayo
analyzed: ajjhatta saṃyojanam nāma bahiddhā ati rūpa arūpa bhavaḥ tattha bandhana vasena pavattāni  pañca uddhambhāgiya saṃyojanāni bahiddhāsaṃyojanam nāma kāma bhave hi sattānam ālayaḥ
translated: The five higher fetters are called external fetters because they occur in the form and formless worlds as bonds to those worlds.🔽The five lower fetters are called internal fetters because they are the abode of beings in the sense sphere.

original: bahuko, na itaresu, tasmā so ajjhattaṃ itare ca bahiddhāti veditabbā. Dukaṃ.🔽Tikesu pana lobhādīni tīṇi akusalamūlāni nāma. Kāmabyāpādavihiṃsāsampayuttā vitakkā🔽tayo akusalavitakkā nāma. Te eva saññāsīsena tisso akusalasaññā. Sabhāvaṭṭhena tisso🔽akusaladhātuyoti ca vuccanti. Kāyavacīmanoduccaritāni tīṇi duccaritāni nāma, tāni
analyzed: bahukaḥ na itaresu tasmā saḥ ajjhattam itare ca bahiddhā iti veditabbā dukam  tikesu pana lobha ādīni tīṇi akusala mūlāni nāma kāma byāpāda vihiṃsā sampayuttāḥ vitakkā  tayo akusalavitakkāḥ nāma te eva saññā sīsena tissaḥ akusala saññā sabhāvaṭṭhena tissaḥ  ca vuccanti kāya vacī manaḥ duccaritāni tīṇi duccaritāni nāma tāni
translated: “Internal” is the name for the fetters in oneself. “External” is the name for the fine-material and immaterial becoming. The five higher fetters that occur there by way of bondage are called “external” fetters. In the sense-desire becoming there is much attachment of beings, not so in the other two. Therefore the former should be understood as “internal” and the latter as “external.” The dyad is finished.

original: dvārattayappavattānaṃ pāṇātipātādīnaṃ, sabbākusalānaṃ vā vasena yojetabbāni. Suttantapariyāyena
analyzed: dvāra ttaya ppavattānam pāṇātipāta ādīnam sabba akusalānam vā vasena yojetabbāni suttanta pariyāyena
translated: As to the triads, the three roots of unprofit, namely, greed, hate, and delusion, are called “unprofitable roots.” The three unprofitable thoughts, namely, thought associated with sense-desire, with ill will, and with cruelty, are called “unprofitable thoughts.” These same three, when taken as the head of a class, are the three unprofitable perceptions. And they are called “unprofitable elements” in the sense of individual essence. The three kinds of misconduct, namely, bodily, verbal, and mental misconduct, are called “misconduct.” These should be construed as the basis for all the unprofitable things such as killing living things, etc., that occur by way of the three doors.

original: pana diṭṭhāsavavajjitā kāmāsavādayo tayo āsavā nāma. Sakkāyadiṭṭhivicikicchāsīlabbataparāmāsā
analyzed: pana diṭṭhāsava vajjitā kāma āsava ādayo tayo āsavāḥ nāma sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsā
translated: But according to the method of the suttas, the three taints, namely, the taint of sense desire, the taint of being, and the taint of ignorance, are called “taints.” The three kinds of clinging, namely, clinging to sense pleasures, clinging to views, and clinging to rules and vows, are called “clingings.”

original: tīṇi saṃyojanāni nāma.🔽Kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhā ca tisso taṇhā nāma. Tattha sassatadiṭṭhisahagato🔽rāgo bhavataṇhā, ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato rāgo vibhavataṇhā, avasesā pana sabbāpi taṇhā
analyzed: tīṇi saṃyojanāni nāma  kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā ca tisso taṇhā nāma tattha sassata diṭṭhi sahagato  rāgaḥ bhava taṇhā uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgaḥ vibhava taṇhā avasesā pana sabbā api taṇhā
translated: The three fetters are:

original: kāmataṇhā. Kāmadhātupaṭisaṃyutto vā rāgo kāmataṇhā, rūpārūpadhātupaṭisaṃyutto bhavataṇhā,
analyzed: kāma taṇhā kāmadhātu paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vā rāgaḥ kāma taṇhā rūpa arūpa dhātu paṭisaṃyuttaḥ bhava taṇhā
translated: The three cravings are craving for sense desires, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming. Herein, the greed associated with the eternalist view is craving for becoming, that associated with the annihilationist view is craving for non-becoming, and the rest is craving for sense desires. Or alternatively, greed associated with the sense-desire element is craving for sense desires, that associated with the form and formless elements is craving for becoming, and that associated with the annihilationist view is craving for non-becoming.

original: ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato vibhavataṇhāti veditabbā. Kāmataṇhā rūpataṇhā arūpataṇhā ca
analyzed: uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ vibhava taṇhā ti veditabbā kāma taṇhā rūpa taṇhā arūpa taṇhā ca
translated: The three cravings are craving for the visible-form element, craving for the feeling element, and craving for the perception and the determinations element.

original: aparāpi tisso taṇhā nāma. Rūpataṇhā arūpataṇhā nirodhataṇhā ca puna aparāpi tisso
analyzed: aparā api tissaḥ taṇhā nāma rūpa taṇhā arūpa taṇhā nirodha taṇhā ca puna aparā api tissaḥ
translated: There are also three cravings: craving for the form element, craving for the formless element, and craving for cessation.

original: taṇhā nāma. Tattha nirodhataṇhāti ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato. Kāmesanā bhavesanā brahmacariyesanā
analyzed: taṇhā nāma tattha nirodha taṇhā ti uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ kāma īsanā bhava īsanā brahmacariya īsanā
translated: Herein, craving for cessation is that associated with the annihilationist view.

original: ca tisso esanā nāma. Tattha brahmacariyesanāti sassatucchedadiṭṭhisaṅkhātabrahmacariyassa
analyzed: ca tissaḥ esanā nāma tattha brahmacariya īsanā ati sassatu cheda diṭṭhi saṅkhāta brahmacariyassa
translated: The three searches are the search for sense desires, the search for becoming, and the search for a holy life.🔽Herein, the search for a holy life is the search for a holy life consisting in the eternalist and annihilationist views.

original: gavesanā. “Seyyohamasmīti vidhā, sadisohamasmīti vidhā, hīnohamasmīti vidhā”ti evaṃ🔽vuttamānavidhā tisso vidhā nāma. Māno hi seyyādivasena vidahanato maññanato “vidhā”ti
analyzed: gavesanā seyyā uham asmi iti vidhā sadisā uham asmi iti vidhā hīnā uham asmi iti vidhāti evam  vutta mānavidhā tissaḥ vidhā nāma mānaḥ hi seyyā ādi vasena vidahanataḥ maññanataḥ vidhāti
translated: Searching. The three kinds of views are those stated thus: “I am better,” “I am equal,” “I am worse” .🔽For conceit is called “view” because it burns and conceives in the way beginning “I am better,” etc. The three fears are those arisen in dependence on birth, aging, and death.

original: vuccati. Jātijarāmaraṇāni paṭicca uppannāni bhayāni tīṇi bhayāni nāma. “Atītaṃ vā🔽addhānaṃ ārabbhā”tiādinā vuttāni tīṇi, buddhādīsu kaṅkhanavicikicchanavasena pavattā🔽tisso avijjā tīṇi tamāni nāma. Vicikicchāsīsena tassa vibhaṅge taṃsampayuttā avijjāva
analyzed: vuccati jāti jarā maraṇāni paṭicca uppannāni bhayāni tīṇi bhayāni nāma atītam vā  addhānam ārabbha ati ādinā vuttāni tīṇi buddha ādīsu kaṅkhana vicikicchana vasena pavattā  tissaḥ avijjā tīṇi tamāni nāma vicikicchā sīsena tassa vibhaṅge tad sampayuttā avijjā ava
translated: The three kinds of darkness are those stated thus: “With reference to the past … With reference to the future … With reference to the present” .🔽The three kinds of ignorance are those that occur with doubt and uncertainty about the Buddha, etc.

original: vuttā, tassā eva paṭicchādakattenapi tamabhāvatoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttā tassāḥ eva paṭicchādaka ttena api tama bhāvato ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: In the Vibhaṅga only the ignorance associated with doubt is called “darkness” because of its predominance. But it should be regarded as “darkness” because it conceals, too.

original: Yaṃ kiñci pana sattassa sukhādikaṃ uppajjati, taṃ sabbaṃ pubbekatahetūti ekaṃ titthāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: yat kiñci pana sattassa sukha ādikam uppajjati tat sabbam pubbekata hetū ti ekam titthāyatanam
translated: Whatever pleasure, etc., arises in a being, all that is due to kamma done in the past, is the first view.

original: issaranimmānahetūti dutiyaṃ, ahetuappaccayāti tatiyanti imāni tīṇi titthāyatanāni
analyzed: issara nimmāna hetū ti dutiyam ahetu appaccayā ti tatiyam ti imāni tīṇi titthāyatanāni
translated: It is due to the creation of a supreme god, is the second. It is without cause or condition, is the third. These are the three views.

original: nāma. Tattha paṭhamavādī kusalākusalakiriyautucittāhārādikaṃ, gatiupadhiādikaṃ, sappurisūpanissayasaddhammassavanādikañca🔽sabbaṃ paccayapaccayuppannaṃ paṭikkhipitvā ekaṃ kammavipākameva sampaṭicchati, itare
analyzed: nāma tattha paṭhamavādī kusala akusala kiriyā otu citta āhāra ādikam gati upadhi ādikam sappurisa upanissaya saddhamma ssavana ādikam ca  sabbam paccaya paccaya uppannam paṭikkhipitvā ekam kamma vipākam eva sampaṭicchati itare
translated: Herein, the first theorist denies all that is causally arisen, such as profitable and unprofitable kamma, temperature, nutriment, etc., destiny, the bases, etc., and the support of good people, the hearing of the True Idea, etc.,🔽and he admits only kamma-result. The other two theorists deny all cause and admit that things are caused by God or are causeless.

original: pana dvepi sabbaṃ hetuṃ paṭikkhipitvā issarahetukaṃ, ahetukañca sampaṭicchanti, tesaṃ🔽tiṇṇaṃ vādānaṃ vaseneva payojanābhāvādito yathānurūpaṃ doso ñātabbo. Ganthavitthārabhayena
analyzed: pana dve api sabbam hetum paṭikkhipitvā issara hetukam ahetukam ca sampaṭicchanti tesam  tiṇṇam vādānam vasena iva payojana abhāvāt itas yathānurūpam dosaḥ ñātabbaḥ gantha vitthāra bhayena
translated: The fault in each of these three theories should be understood according to circumstances as follows.

original: panettha na vitthārayimha.
analyzed: pana ittha na vitthārayimha
translated: But we have not expounded them here in detail for fear of making the book too long.

original: Rāgadosamohā pana tayo palibodhaṭṭhena kiñcanā nāma. Te eva hi kilesaṭṭhena aṅgaṇāni,
analyzed: rāga dosa mohā pana tayo palibodha ṭṭhena kiñcanā nāma te eva hi kilesa ṭṭhena aṅgaṇāni
translated: Craving, view, and conceit are called “possessions” in the sense of obstruction. For these are defilements in the sense of defilement,

original: malīnabhāvakaraṇaṭṭhena malāni, pakkhalanapātahetuto visamāni ca honti. Pāṇātipātādīni
analyzed: malīna bhāva karaṇa ṭṭhena malāni pakkhalana pāta hetutaḥ visamāni ca honti pāṇātipāta ādīni
translated: stains in the sense of staining, and unevenness in the sense of causing falling.

original: kāyavacīmanovisamāni aparānipi tīṇi visamāni nāma. Rāgadosamohā anudahanaṭṭhena tayo
analyzed: tīṇi visamāni nāma rāga dosa mohāḥ anudahana ṭṭhena
translated: The three kinds of unevenness are the unevenness of body, speech, and mind, and the other three kinds of unevenness are the unevenness of killing breathing things, etc.,🔽and the unevenness of greed, hate, and delusion.

original: aggī, kasaṭanirojaṭṭhena kasāvā ca honti. Pāṇātipātādīni kāyakasāvādayo pana aparepi
analyzed: ca honti pāṇa atipāta ādīni kāya kasāva ādayaḥ pana apare pi
translated: and they are yellow because of the yellowness of the dust and dirt in them. The other three kinds called “yellow” are the yellowness of the body, speech, and mind consisting in killing living things, and so on.

original: tayo kasāvā nāma. Assādadiṭṭhittike kāmaparibhoge “natthi kāmesu doso”ti evaṃ pavattā
