analyzed: pana dhātuyā vippayuttā ti evam sabbattha yojanā veditabbā
translated: The method of interpretation should be understood in this way in all instances.

original: Tattha te dhammāti rūpanibbānadhammā, te vedanāya sampayuttehi vippayuttā. Ekenāti
analyzed: tattha te dhammā ati rūpa nibbāna dhammā te vedanāya sampayuttehi vippayuttāḥ ekena ati
translated: Herein, the states are the states of materiality and Nibbāna. They are dissociated from those associated with feeling.🔽By one means by the mind base.

original: manāyatanena. Dutiyanaye te dhammāti sappītikā te dhammā. Na kehicīti paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭaṃ
analyzed: manāyatanena dutiya naye te dhammā ati te dhammā na kehici iti paṭhamam
translated: In the second method, the states are those states that are accompanied by rapture.

original: cakkhuviññāṇadhātuṃ ṭhapetvā sesā chaviññāṇadhātū, taṃsampayuttā, rūpaṃ, nibbānañca.
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa dhātum ṭhapetvā sesā cha viññāṇa dhātū tad sampayuttā rūpam nibbānam ca
translated: They are not dissociated from any means, omitting the eye-consciousness element mentioned first, the remaining six consciousness elements, and the materiality associated with them and Nibbāna.

original: Tehi sabbesaṃ khandhāyatanānaṃ saṅgahitattā na kehici khandhehi, āyatanehi vā vippayuttā.
analyzed: tehi sabbesam khandha āyatanānam saṅgahita ttā na kehici khandhehi āyatanehi vā vippayuttā
translated: They are not dissociated from any of the aggregates or from any of the bases, because they are included in all the aggregates and in all the bases.🔽For one does not become dissociated or associated with oneself.

original: Na hi sayaṃ attanā vippayujjati, sampayujjati vāti. Ekāyāti cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā.
analyzed: na hi sayam attanā vippayujjati sampayujjati vā ati ekāya ati cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyā
translated: By one means by the eye-consciousness element.

original: Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ sampayuttenavippayuttapade nayo.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam sampayuttena vippayutta pade nayo
translated: The rest is easy to understand. This is the method of the connected and the not-connected terms.

original: Vippayuttenasampayuttapadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vippayuttena sampayutta pada attha vaṇṇanā
translated: The connected and the not-connected terms

original: Vippayuttenasampayuttapade pana vippayuttena sampayutto nāma dhammo natthi, desanāsampadamattāya
analyzed: vippayuttena sampayutta pade pana vippayuttena sampayuttaḥ nāma dhammo natthi desanā sampada mattāya
translated: As to the connected and the not-connected terms, there is no state called “connected with the not-connected.” But the term is brought in🔽merely for the sake of the teaching order.

original: pana moghampetaṃ padaṃ uddhaṭaṃ, teneva pāḷiyaṃ sabbavāresupi “natthi natthi” icceva
analyzed: pana moghampetam padam uddhaṭam tena iva pāḷiyam sabba vāresu pi natthi natthi icca eva
translated: That is why in the text in all the sections the word “none” is repeated.

original: vuttaṃ. Rūpakkhandhādianārammaṇadhammehi vippayuttā cattāro khandhā, tesañca aññehi
analyzed: vuttam rūpa kkhandha ādi anārammaṇa dhammehi vippayuttā cattāro khandhā tesam ca aññehi
translated: The four aggregates that are not objects of the form aggregate, etc., are not connected with those states, and they are not connected with any others either.

original: sampayogo natthi. Vedanādīhipi rūpanibbānādīni vippayuttāni, tesañca kenaci sampayogova
analyzed: sampayogaḥ natthi rūpa nibbāna ādīni vippayuttāni tesam ca kenaci sampayogaḥ uva
translated: Feeling, etc., are not connected with form, Nibbāna, etc., and they are not connected with anything else either.

original: natthīti. Ayaṃ vippayuttenasampayuttapade nayo.
analyzed: natthi iti ayam vippayuttena sampayutta pade nayo
translated: This is the method of the connected and the not-connected terms.

original: Sampayuttenasampayuttapadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sampayuttena sampayutta pada attha vaṇṇanā
translated: The connected and the not-connected terms

original: Sampayuttenasampayuttapade pana yāni padāni rūpena asammissaṃ arūpakkhandhekadesameva
analyzed: sampayuttena sampayutta pade pana yāni padāni rūpena asammissam arūpa kkhandha ekadesam eva
translated: As to the connected and the not-connected terms, the states that are not mixed up with form are the immaterial aggregates and the immaterial part of the aggregates.

original: dīpenti, tesameva niddeso, na rūpārūpasammissānaṃ, sabbarūpakkhandhadīpakānaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: dīpenti tesam eva niddesaḥ na rūpa arūpa sammissānam sabba rūpa kkhandha dīpakānam tesam
translated: and they are the only ones that are demonstrated, not those mixed with materiality and the immaterial.

original: sampayuttatāyogābhāvā. Sabbārūpakkhandhenāpi hi kusalādinā añño sampayutto nāma natthi.
analyzed: sampayutta tā yoga abhāvā sabbārūpa kkhandhena api hi kusala ādinā aññaḥ sampayuttaḥ nāma natthi
translated: For there is no association by way of association with those that illuminate all the aggregates of materiality.

original: Idaṃ hettha lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭā, attanā sampayuttena puna sampayuttā,
analyzed: idam ha ittha lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭāḥ attanā sampayuttena puna sampayuttā
translated: This is the characteristic here: those things that are first mentioned are again associated with what is associated with themselves,

original: tesaññeva khandhādīhi sampayogo vuccati.
analyzed: tesam eva khandha ādīhi sampayogaḥ vuccati
translated: and their association with the aggregates, etc., is called association.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – vedanākkhandhena ye dhammā sampayuttā, tehi dhammehi ye dhammā sampayuttā,
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ vedanā kkhandhena ye dhammā sampayuttā tehi dhammehi ye dhammā sampayuttā
translated: Here is the method: the things associated with the feeling aggregate are associated with those things associated with those things,

original: te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena sattahi dhātūhi sampayuttā, ekenāyatanena…pe…
analyzed: te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena sattahi dhātūhi sampayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena pe
translated: they are associated with three aggregates, with one base, with seven elements, with one base, …

original: kehici sampayuttā. Samudayasaccena ye dhammā sampayuttā, tehi dhammehi ye dhammā
analyzed: kehici sampayuttā samudaya saccena ye dhammā sampayuttā tehi dhammehi ye dhammā
translated: with some. The things associated with the origin truth are associated with those things associated with those things,

original: sampayuttā, te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena ekāya manoviññāṇadhātuyā sampayuttā,
analyzed: sampayuttā te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena ekāya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā sampayuttā
translated: they are associated with three aggregates, with one base, with one mind-consciousness element,

original: ekena khandhena ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttāti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: ekena khandhena ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttā ati sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: with one aggregate, with one base, with one element, with some that are related and some that are not related. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Ayaṃ sampayuttenasampayuttapade nayo.🔽Vippayuttenavippayuttapadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ayam sampayuttena sampayutta pade nayaḥ  vippayuttena vippayutta padattha vaṇṇanā
translated: This is the method in the case of the related and unrelated terms.

original: Vippayuttenavippayuttapade pana sampayogapade vuttapadāneva niddisīyanti. Idaṃ hettha
analyzed: vippayuttena vippayutta pade pana sampayoga pade vutta padānā eva niddisīyanti idam ha ittha
translated: In the case of the not-related-to-the-not-related terms, the same terms as those stated in the case of the related terms are demonstrated. Herein,

original: lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭapadena vippayuttehi puna vippayuttā, tesaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭa padena vippayuttehi puna vippayuttā tesam
translated: this is the characteristic: those ideas that are first stated as not related to those not related are

original: khandhādīhi vippayogo vuccati.
analyzed: khandha ādīhi vippayogaḥ vuccati
translated: said to be not related to the aggregates, etc.,

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – rūpakkhandhena ye dhammā vippayuttā, tehi dhammehi ye dhammā vippayuttā,
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ rūpa kkhandhena ye dhammā vippayuttā tehi dhammehi ye dhammā vippayuttā
translated: Here is the method. Those ideas that are not related to the materiality aggregate are not related to those ideas that are not related to the materiality aggregate.

original: te dhammā catūhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttā, ekenāyatanena…pe…
analyzed: te dhammā catūhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena pe
translated: Those ideas are not related to four aggregates, to one base, to one element, to some that are related and some that are not related. With one base …

original: kehici vippayuttā. Vedanākkhandhena ye dhammā vippayuttā, tehi dhammehi ye dhammā
analyzed: kehici vippayuttāḥ vedanā kkhandhena ye dhammāḥ vippayuttā tehi dhammehi ye dhammā
translated: with some that are related and some that are not related. Those ideas that are not related to the feeling aggregate are not related to those ideas that are not related to the feeling aggregate.

original: vippayuttā, te dhammā ekena khandhena dasahāyatanehi dasahi dhātūhi vippayuttā, ekena…pe…
analyzed: vippayuttā te dhammā ekena khandhena dasahā āyatanehi dasahi dhātūhi vippayuttāḥ ekena pe
translated: These ideas are dissociated from one of the aggregates, from ten bases and from ten elements. They are associated with one of the aggregates, with one base and with one element.

original: kehici vippayuttāti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ vippayuttenavippayuttapade nayo.
analyzed: kehici vippayuttā ati sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam vippayuttena vippayutta pade nayo
translated: They are dissociated from some of the aggregates, from some of the bases and from some of the elements. The rest is easy to understand. This is the method in the case of the term dissociated.

original: Saṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapadatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The Meaning of the Terms Associated with and Dissociated from the Included

original: Saṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapade pana saṅgahitenasaṅgahitapade niddiṭṭhāni samudayasaccādipadāneva
analyzed: saṅgahitena sampayutta vippayutta pade pana saṅgahitena saṅgahita pade niddiṭṭhāni samudaya sacca ādi padānā eva
translated: In the case of the terms associated with and dissociated from the included, the terms included in the truth of origin, etc., shown in the exposition of the term included are shown again.

original: niddisīyanti. Idaṃ hettha lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭapadena khandhādīhi
analyzed: niddisīyanti idam ha ittha lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭa padena khandha ādīhi
translated: This is the characteristic here: those ideas that are included under the three, that is to say, under the aggregates, etc., shown first in the exposition of the term included,

original: tīhipi saṅgahitā, tesaṃ khandhādīhi sampayogo, vippayogo ca vuccati.
analyzed: tīhi pi saṅgahitā tesam khandha ādīhi sampayogaḥ vippayogo ca vuccati
translated: are said to be associated with and dissociated from the aggregates, etc.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – samudayasaccena ye dhammā khandhādīhi tīhipi saṅgahehi saṅgahitā,
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ samudaya saccena ye dhammā khandha ādīhi saṅgahehi saṅgahitā
translated: Here is the method. Those ideas that are included under the three, that is to say, under the aggregates, etc., by the truth of origin,

original: te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena sattahi dhātūhi sampayuttā, ekena khandhena
analyzed: te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena sattahi dhātūhi sampayuttāḥ ekena khandhena
translated: are associated with three aggregates, with one base and with seven elements. They are dissociated from one aggregate,🔽from ten bases and from ten elements.

original: ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttā. Ekena khandhena dasahāyatanadhātūhi
analyzed: ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttāḥ ekena khandhena dasahā āyatana dhātūhi
translated: They are associated with one base and one element. They are dissociated from one aggregate, from ten bases and from ten elements.

original: vippayuttā, ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici vippayuttā. Itthindriyena ye dhammā🔽khandhādīhi tīhipi saṅgahitā, te dhammā na kehici sampayuttā, catūhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena
analyzed: vippayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici vippayuttāḥ itthi indriyena ye dhammā  khandha ādīhi tīhi pi saṅgahitā te dhammā na kehici sampayuttā catūhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena
translated: They are dissociated from one base and from one element. They are associated with some of the remaining bases and elements.🔽They are associated with some of the remaining aggregates. They are dissociated from three aggregates. They are associated with one base and with one element. They are dissociated from one base and from one element.

original: sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttā, ekena…pe… kehici vippayuttāti.🔽Tattha ekenāti manāyatanena. Ekena khandhenāti saṅkhārakkhandhena. Kehicīti saṅkhārakkhandhe
analyzed: sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttā ekenape kehici vippayuttā ati  tattha ekena ati manāyatanena ekena khandhena ati saṅkhāra khandhena kehici iti saṅkhāra khandhe
translated: They are associated with some of the remaining bases and elements. They are dissociated from three aggregates, from one base and from one element. They are associated with some of the remaining bases and elements.🔽Herein, one means the mind base. One aggregate means the formations aggregate. Some of the remaining bases and elements means the feeling, perception, and formations aggregates, and the mental data base and element.

original: taṇhāya dhammāyatanadhammadhātūsu taṇhāvedanāsaññāhi. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ🔽saṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapade nayo.🔽Sampayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: taṇhāya dhamma āyatana dhamma dhātūsu taṇhā vedanā saññāhi sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam  saṅgahitena sampayutta vippayutta pade nayaḥ
translated: The rest is easily intelligible. This is the method in the case of the associated and the dissociated in the section on inclusion.🔽The unassociated in the section on inclusion

original: Sampayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapade pana sampayuttenasampayuttapade niddiṭṭhāni vedanākkhandhādipadāneva
analyzed: sampayuttena saṅgahita asaṅgahita pade pana sampayuttena sampayutta pade niddiṭṭhāni vedanā kkhandha ādi padānā eva
translated: In the case of the unassociated in the section on inclusion, the terms of the feeling aggregate, etc., stated in the associated in the section on inclusion,🔽are to be taken.

original: niddisīyanti. Idaṃ hettha lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭapadena sampayuttā,
analyzed: niddisīyanti idam ha ittha lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭa padena sampayuttā
translated: This is the characteristic here.

original: tesaṃ khandhādīhi saṅgaho, asaṅgaho ca vuccati.🔽Tatrāyaṃ nayo – vedanākkhandhena ye dhammā sampayuttā, te dhammā tīhi khandhehi dvīhi🔽āyatanehi aṭṭhahi dhātūhi saṅgahitā, sesehi asaṅgahitā. Viññāṇakkhandhena ye dhammā
analyzed: tesam khandha ādīhi saṅgahaḥ asaṅgaho ca vuccati  tatra ayam nayaḥ vedanā kkhandhena ye dhammā sampayuttā te dhammā tīhi khandhehi dvīhi  āyatanehi aṭṭhahi dhātūhi saṅgahitā sesehi asaṅgahitā viññāṇa kkhandhena ye dhammā
translated: The inclusion and non-inclusion of those states associated with the first heading as stated should be understood thus.

original: sampayuttā, te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā saṅgahitā, sesehi asaṅgahitāti.
analyzed: sampayuttā te dhammā tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā saṅgahitā sesehi asaṅgahitā ati
translated: Here is the method. Those states associated with the feeling aggregate are included in three aggregates, in two bases and in eight elements, and they are not included in the remainder. Those states associated with the perception aggregate … Those states associated with the formations aggregate … Those states associated with the consciousness aggregate are included in three aggregates, in one base and in one element, and they are not included in the remainder.

original: Tattha tīhīti saññākkhandhādīhi tīhi. Tehi vedanāya sampayuttā. Dvīhīti dhammāyatanamanāyatanehi. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ sampayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapade nayo.🔽Asaṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tattha tīhi iti saññā kkhandha ādīhi tīhi tehi vedanāya sampayuttāḥ dvīhi iti dhammāyatana manāyatanehi sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam nayo  asaṅgahitena sampayutta vippayutta pada attha vaṇṇanā
translated: Herein, “in three” means in the three beginning with the perception aggregate. They are associated with feeling. “In two” means in the mental-data base and in the mental-data element. The rest is easily understandable. This is the method in the case of the terms “included in” and “not included in” in the case of association.

original: Asaṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapade pana yāni padāni sukhumarūpaṃ aviññāṇaṃ, arūpaṃ
analyzed: asaṅgahitena sampayutta vippayutta pade pana yāni padāni sukhuma rūpam aviññāṇam arūpam
translated: As to the terms “not included in” and “associated with” and “not associated with”: the states called “subliminal matter” and “non-penetration” are not included in the aggregates, bases, and elements.

original: saviññāṇaṃ vā, kevalaṃ arūpaṃ vā thūlarūpassapi kevalaṃ vā, sukhumarūpaṃ dīpenti,
analyzed: sa viññāṇam vā kevalam arūpam vā thūla rūpassa api kevalam vā sukhuma rūpam dīpenti
translated: Or they illuminate only the gross materiality, or only the subtle materiality, or only the consciousness.🔽This is the definition here. The characteristic of these states is this:

original: tesameva niddeso. Idaṃ hettha lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭadhammehi khandhādīhi
analyzed: tesam eva niddesaḥ idam ha ittha lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭa dhammehi khandha ādīhi
translated: Those states that are not included among the first states mentioned, that is to say, among the aggregates, etc.,

original: tīhipi asaṅgahitā, tesaṃ khandhādīhi sampayogo, vippayogo ca vuccati.
analyzed: tīhi pi asaṅgahitā tesam khandha ādīhi sampayogaḥ vippayogo ca vuccati
translated: are said to be associated with and dissociated from the aggregates, etc.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – rūpakkhandhena ye dhammā khandhādīhi asaṅgahitā, te dhammā tīhi khandhehi
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ rūpa kkhandhena ye dhammā khandha ādīhi asaṅgahitā te dhammā tīhi khandhehi
translated: Here is the method. Those states that are not included among the aggregates, etc., by the form aggregate, are associated with three aggregates,

original: sampayuttā, ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttā, ekena khandhena dasahi
analyzed: sampayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttāḥ ekena khandhena dasahi
translated: with one base and with one element, and they are associated with some of a base and of an element. They are dissociated from one aggregate,

original: āyatanadhātūhi vippayuttā, ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici vippayuttā. Evaṃ dhammāyatanaitthindriyādīsupi yojanā.
analyzed: āyatana dhātūhi vippayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici vippayuttāḥ evam yojanā
translated: from one base and from one element, and they are dissociated from some of a base and of an element. So too with the other aggregates, etc., in each case.

original: Arūpabhavena ye dhammā khandhādīhi asaṅgahitā, te sampayuttāti natthi. Te catūhi
analyzed: arūpa bhavena ye dhammā khandha ādīhi asaṅgahitā te sampayuttā ati natthi te catūhi
translated: Those states that are not included among the aggregates, etc., by the immaterial aggregates, etc., are not associated. They are dissociated from four aggregates,

original: khandhehi ekenāyatanena sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttā, ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici
analyzed: khandhehi ekena āyatanena sattahi dhātūhi vippayuttāḥ ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici
translated: from one base and from seven elements, and they are dissociated from some of a base and of an element.

original: vippayuttā. Evaṃ iddhipādakusalādipadesupi yojanā.
analyzed: vippayuttā evam iddhipāda kusala ādi padesu pi yojanā
translated: So too with the terms “roots of success,” etc.

original: Tattha rūpakkhandhena viññāṇasseva tīhipi asaṅgahitattā tassa tīhi vedanādīhi sampayogo,
analyzed: tattha rūpa kkhandhena viññāṇassa iva tīhi pi asaṅgahita ttā tassa tīhi vedanā ādīhi sampayogaḥ
translated: Herein, since consciousness is not included by the aggregate of material form, its association with the three beginning with feeling

original: itarehi ca vippayogo ñātabbo. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ asaṅgahitenasampayuttavippayuttapade nayo.🔽Vippayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapadatthavaṇṇanā🔽Vippayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapade pana yāni padāni kevalānaṃ sārammaṇānaṃ, anārammaṇānaṃ🔽vā dhammānaṃ pakāsakāni ca sabhāvajātibhūmikālasantānavasena bhinnatāya kehici arūpakkhandhehi
analyzed: itarehi ca vippayogaḥ ñātabbaḥ sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam asaṅgahitena sampayutta vippayutta pade nayo              vippayuttena saṅgahita asaṅgahita pade pana yāni padāni kevalānam sa ārammaṇānam anārammaṇānam  vā dhammānam pakāsakāni ca sabhāva jāti bhūmi kāla santāna vasena bhinna tāya kehici arūpa kkhandhehi
translated: and its dissociation from the other three should be understood. The rest is easily understood. This is the method in the case of the terms “associated with” and “dissociated from” what is not included.🔽The unassociated, not included🔽As to the terms “unassociated with” and “not included,” the terms that are the means of access to only objects or to only states that are not objects

original: vippayuttānaṃ anārammaṇadhammamissārūpakkhandhānaṃ pakāsakāni dukkhasaccaabyākataparittaatītaajjhattādipadāni,
analyzed: vippayuttānam anārammaṇa dhamma missā rūpa kkhandhānam pakāsakāni dukkha sacca abyākata paritta atīta ajjhatta ādi padāni
translated: and that are the means of access to material dhammas dissociated from certain immaterial aggregates, which are mixed with states that are not objects, are the terms “dukkha,” “unformed,” “past,” “internal,” and so on, which are the means of access to material dhammas dissociated from certain immaterial aggregates, which are mixed with states that are not objects,

original: tesameva niddeso itaresaṃ dhammāyatanajīvitindriyanāmarūpasaḷāyatanajātijarāmaraṇaajjhattabahiddhāanidassanaappaṭighanahetuādīnaṃ
analyzed: tesam eva niddesaḥ itaresam
translated: Their definition is the same as that of the others, namely, the mental-data base, the life faculty, mentality-materiality, the sixfold base, birth, aging, death, internal and external, the not-so-visible, the not-so- obstructive, the cause, etc.,

original: tesaṃ kenaci vippayogāsambhavā. Idaṃ hettha lakkhaṇaṃ – ye dhammā paṭhamaṃ uddhaṭapadena
analyzed: tesam kenaci vippayoga asambhavāḥ idam ha ittha lakkhaṇam ye dhammā paṭhamam uddhaṭa padena
translated: because they cannot be dissociated from any of these. This is the characteristic here. Those ideas that are dissociated from the first term stated

original: vippayuttā, tesaṃ khandhādīhi saṅgaho, asaṅgaho ca vuccati.
analyzed: vippayuttā tesam khandha ādīhi saṅgahaḥ asaṅgaho ca vuccati
translated: are said to be included and not included in the aggregates, etc.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – rūpakkhandhena ye dhammā vippayuttā, te dhammā catūhi khandhehi dvīhāyatanehi
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ rūpa kkhandhena ye dhammā vippayuttā te dhammā catūhi khandhehi dvīhi āyatanehi
translated: Here is the method. Those ideas that are dissociated from the materiality aggregate are included in the four aggregates, in two bases,

original: aṭṭhahi dhātūhi saṅgahitā, ekena khandhena dasahi āyatanadhātūhi asaṅgahitā. Dukkhasaccena
analyzed: aṭṭhahi dhātūhi saṅgahitāḥ ekena khandhena dasahi āyatana dhātūhi asaṅgahitāḥ dukkha saccena
translated: in eight elements, and they are not included in one aggregate, in ten bases, in ten elements. Those ideas that are dissociated from the truth of suffering

original: ye dhammā vippayuttā, te dhammā catūhi khandhehi dvīhāyatanehi dvīhi dhātūhi saṅgahitā.
analyzed: ye dhammā vippayuttā te dhammā catūhi khandhehi dvīhi āyatanehi dvīhi dhātūhi saṅgahitā
translated: are included in the four aggregates, in two bases, in two elements.

original: Tattha dukkhasaccena vippayuttā nāma lokuttaracittacetasikāni, te ca dhammā vedanākkhandhādicatukkhandhehi
analyzed: tattha dukkha saccena vippayuttāḥ nāma lokuttara citta cetasikāni te ca dhammā vedanā kkhandha ādi catu khandhehi
translated: Herein, those ideas dissociated from the truth of suffering are supramundane consciousness and its concomitants. Those ideas are included in the four aggregates beginning with feeling,🔽in two bases, in two elements.

original: manoviññāṇadhammadhātuvasena dvīhi dhātūhi saṅgahitāti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ayaṃ🔽vippayuttenasaṅgahitāsaṅgahitapade nayo. Ayamettha saṅkhepato vibhaṅganayena saddhiṃ
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhammadhātu vasena dvīhi dhātūhi saṅgahitā ati sesam su viññeyyam eva ayam  nayaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepataḥ vibhaṅga nayena saddhim
translated: and it is included in two elements, namely, the mind element and the mind-consciousness element. The rest is easy to understand.🔽This is the method in the case of the clause “not included among those dissociated.”🔽This, in brief, is the “demonstration of the meaning” in this chapter together with the exposition of the analysis.

original: atthanicchayo, vitthāro pana dhātukathāpāḷiaṭṭhakathāsu gahetabboti.🔽Mohavicchedaniyā abhidhammamātikatthavaṇṇanāya
analyzed: attha nicchayaḥ vitthāraḥ pana dhātu kathā pāḷi aṭṭhakathāsu gahetabbo ti
translated: But the detailed explanation should be understood from the Dhammasaṅgaṇī and the commentary on the Dhammasaṅgaṇī.

original: Dhātukathāmātikatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhātukathā mātikattha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the demonstration of the meaning in the Dhammasaṅgaṇī is ended.

original: 4. Puggalapaññattimātikā
analyzed: puggala paññatti mātikā
translated: The Numerical Analysis of Persons

original: Ekakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the first section

original: Idāni puggalapaññattimātikāsaṃvaṇṇanānayo hoti. Tattha anuttānatthato tāva cha paññattiyoti🔽ettha “ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapetī”ti āgataṭṭhāne sandassanā pakāsanā paññatti
analyzed: idāni puggala paññatti mātikā saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ hoti tattha anuttāna tthato tāva cha paññattiyaḥ ti  ettha ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapeti iti āgata ṭṭhāne sandassanā pakāsanā paññatti
translated: Now there follows the method of commenting on the Numerical Analysis of Persons. Herein, firstly, in the section “As to the meaning of ‘analysis’ ” :🔽“Analysis” is the showing, the pointing out, in the passages beginning, “He describes, teaches, proclaims, lays down, specifies,

original: nāma. “Supaññattaṃ mañcapīṭha”nti āgataṭṭhāne ṭhapanā nikkhipanā paññatti nāma, idha
analyzed: nāma su paññattam mañca pīṭhanti āgata ṭṭhāne ṭhapanā nikkhipanā paññatti nāma idha
translated: exposes, explains, clarifies” . “Analysis” is the placing, the setting down, in the passages beginning, “The bed and chair are well analysed” . Herein,

original: ubhayampi vaṭṭati. Cha paññattiyoti hi cha paññāpanā cha sandassanā pakāsanātipi,🔽cha ṭhapanā nikkhipanātipi vuttaṃ hoti. Nāmapaññattiyeva hi te te vijjamānāvijjamāne
analyzed: ubhayam pi vaṭṭati cha paññattiyaḥ ti hi cha paññāpanā cha sandassanā pakāsanā atipi  cha ṭhapanā nikkhipanā tipi vuttam hoti nāma paññattiyā iva hi te te vijjamāna a vijjamāne
translated: Both are allowable. The six determinations are the six determinations, the six descriptions, the six explanations,🔽the six placements, the six depositions. For “determinations” is said with reference to the determinations of name, etc.,

original: dhamme sandassetītipi. Tena tena koṭṭhāsena ṭhapetītipi. Khandhapaññattītiādi pana
analyzed: dhamme sandasseti itipi tena tena koṭṭhāsena ṭhapeti itipi khandha paññatti itiādi pana
translated: since they determine, describe, explain, place, and deposit those things that exist and do not exist.

original: saṅkhepato tāsaṃ paññattīnaṃ sarūpadassanaṃ. Tattha khandhānaṃ “khandhā”ti paññāpanā
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ tāsam paññattīnam sarūpa dassanam tattha khandhānam khandhā ti paññāpanā
translated: The determination of aggregates, etc., is the mere showing of the individual essences of those determinations in brief.

original: sandassanā pakāsanā ca ṭhapanā nikkhipanā ca khandhapaññatti nāma…pe… puggalānaṃ
analyzed: sandassanā pakāsanā ca ṭhapanā nikkhipanā ca khandha paññatti nāmape puggalānaṃ
translated: Herein, the determination of aggregates is the determination, description, explanation, placement, and deposition of the aggregates as “aggregates.” …

original: “puggalā”ti paññāpanā sandassanā pakāsanā ca ṭhapanā nikkhipanā ca puggalapaññatti
analyzed: puggala ati paññāpanā sandassanā pakāsanā ca ṭhapanā nikkhipanā ca puggala paññatti
translated: The determination of persons is the determination, description, explanation, placement, and deposition of persons as “persons.”

original: nāma. Imā eva cha paññattiyo vijjanti. Aññāsampi sammutiparamatthakathānaṃ paññattīnaṃ
analyzed: nāma imāḥ eva cha paññattiyaḥ vijjanti aññāsam pi sammuti paramattha kathānam paññattīnam
translated: These are the six determinations. There are also other determinations of conventional and ultimate expressions,

original: anantattā, upalakkhaṇavasena pana padhānabhāvato ca etāva vuttā. Pāḷimuttakanayena
analyzed: ananta ttā upalakkhaṇa vasena pana padhāna bhāvato ca etāva vuttā pāḷimuttaka nayena
translated: but they are mentioned here as being the most important and as an illustration.

original: pana sabbasaṅgāhikā vijjamānapaññattiādayo cha nāmapaññattiyo aṭṭhakathāsu āgatā,🔽tā ca heṭṭhā vuttāti idha na vuttā. Tāsu idha puggalapaññattipadena avijjamānapaññatti,
analyzed: pana sabba saṅgāhikāḥ vijjamāna paññatti ādayo cha nāma paññattiyaḥ aṭṭhakathāsu āgatā  tā ca heṭṭhā vuttā ati idha na vuttā tāsu idha puggala paññatti padena avijjamāna paññatti
translated: But the six kinds of naming, namely, non-existent naming, etc., which include all, are given in the commentaries.🔽And since they are given below they are not given here.

original: sesehi vijjamānapaññatti cāti dve eva labbhanti.
analyzed: sesehi vijjamāna paññatti ca ati dve eva labbhanti
translated: Of these, only two are relevant here, namely, non-existent naming by the word “person” and existent naming by the rest.

original: Aṭṭhakathāmuttakena pana ācariyanayena aparāpi cha paññattiyo – upādāpaññatti upanidhāpaññatti
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā muttakena pana ācariya nayena aparā api cha paññattiyaḥ upādā paññatti upanidhā paññatti
translated: But there are another six kinds of naming, namely, naming by description, naming by location,🔽naming by combination, naming by what is contained, naming by what is produced, and naming by continuity, which are given in the commentaries by the method of the teachers.

original: samodhānapaññatti upanikkhittapaññatti tajjāpaññatti santatipaññattīti, yā “atthapaññattī”ti
analyzed: samodhāna paññatti upanikkhitta paññatti tajjā paññatti santati paññatti iti yā attha paññatti iti
translated: They are called “naming by meaning.”

original: vuccati. Tattha yā khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya nissāya sammatā sattādikā, aṅgāni upādāya
analyzed: vuccati tattha yā khandha pañcakam upādāya nissāya sammatā sattā ādikā aṅgāni upādāya
translated: Herein, that which is agreed upon in dependence on the five aggregates, etc., as a being, etc.,🔽that which is agreed upon in dependence on the parts as a chariot, etc.,

original: rathādikā, candādiparivattādayo upādāya kāladisādikā, taṃtaṃbhūtanimittaṃ, bhāvanāvisesañca
analyzed: upādāya kāla disā ādikā upādāya kāla disā ādikā taṃ taṃ bhūta nimittam bhāvanā visesaḥ ca
translated: that which is agreed upon in dependence on the revolution of the moon, etc., as time, direction, etc., that which is agreed upon in dependence on the sign of such and such an apparition and on a special development of consciousness as the sign apprehended by means of meditation, etc.,—

original: upādāya kasiṇādiuggahapaṭibhāganimittādikāti ayaṃ evarūpā sabhāvadhammehi ekattena
analyzed: upādāya kasiṇa ādi uggaha paṭibhāga nimitta ādikā ati ayam evarūpā sa bhāva dhammehi ekattena
translated: this is the kind of naming that is by the unity of individual essences.

original: vā sacchikaṭṭhaparamatthena anupalabbhasabhāvā upādāpaññatti nāma. Paññāpetabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: vā sacchikaṭṭha paramatthena anupalabbha sabhāvā upādā paññatti nāma paññāpetabba ṭṭhena
translated: Or else it is a description by assuming, in the ultimate sense of the word, that what is not found to exist is existent.🔽This description is said to be describable, but not to be a description.

original: cesā paññatti vuttā, na pana paññāpanaṭṭhena. Yā tassa tassatthassa paññāpanā, sā
analyzed: ca isā paññatti vuttā na pana paññāpana ṭṭhena yā tassa tassa atthassa paññāpanā sā
translated: The description of that meaning is

original: avijjamānapaññattiyeva.
analyzed: a vijjamāna paññattiyā iva
translated: a non-existent description.

original: Yā pana aññaṃ paṭhamādiṃ upanidhāya apekkhitvā dutiyaṃ rassaṃ dīghaṃ dūraṃ santikantiādikā
analyzed: yā pana aññam paṭhama ādim upanidhāya apekkhitvā dutiyam rassam dīgham dūram santikam ti ādikā
translated: But the description of the second as short, long, far, near, etc., by comparison with the first, etc.,🔽is a description by comparison with something else. The description of the hand-bearer, etc., is a description by comparison with what is held in the hand.

original: tadaññāpekkhūpanidhā, chattapāṇītiādikā hatthagatūpanidhā, kuṇḍalītiādikā sampayuttūpanidhā,
analyzed: tad aññā apekkhūpanidhā chatta pāṇī iti ādikā hattha gatūpanidhā kuṇḍalī iti ādikā sampayuttu upanidhā
translated: The description of the ear-ringed, etc., is a description by comparison with what is associated.

original: dhaññasakaṭanti ādikā samāropitūpanidhā, indasālaguhātiādikā avidūragatūpanidhā,
analyzed: ādikā samāropitu upanidhā inda sāla guhā ati ādikā avidūraga tu upanidhā
translated: The description of the cart-load of grain, etc., is a description by comparison with what is heaped up. The description of the Indasāla cave, etc., is a description by comparison with what is not far away.

original: suvaṇṇavaṇṇotiādikā paṭibhāgūpanidhā, brāhmaṇagāmotiādikā tabbahulūpanidhā, maṇikaṭakantiādikā
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ iti ādikā paṭibhāgā upanidhā brāhmaṇa gāmaḥ iti ādikā tad bahula upanidhā maṇi kaṭakanti ādikā
translated: The description of the golden-coloured, etc., is a description by comparison with what is similar. The description of the brahmin village, etc., is a description by comparison with what is abundant. The description of the gem-seal, etc.,

original: tabbisiṭṭhūpanidhāti evamādi anekappakārā paññāpanā, ayaṃ upanidhāpaññatti nāma.
analyzed: tad bisiṭṭhūpanidhā ti evamādi aneka ppakārā paññāpanā ayam upanidhā paññatti nāma
translated: is a description by comparison with what is well-known. This is called description by comparison.

original: Dhaññarāsītiādikā pana samodhānapaññatti nāma. Purimassa purimassa upanikkhipitvā
analyzed: dhañña rāsi iti ādikā pana samodhāna paññatti nāma purimassa purimassa upanikkhipitvā
translated: The designation of a heap of grain, etc., is called a designation of a collection.🔽The designation of two, three, etc., is called a designation of a combination.

original: dve tīṇītiādikā upanikkhittapaññatti nāma. Taṃtaṃsabhāvanissitā pathavīādikā tajjāpaññatti
analyzed: dve tīṇi iti ādikā upanikkhitta paññatti nāma taṃ taṃsa bhāva nissitā pathavī ādikā tajjā paññatti
translated: The designation of earth, etc., based on the respective natures is called a designation of that.

original: nāma. Āsītikotiādikā pana santatipaññatti nāma.
analyzed: nāma āsītikā iti ādikā pana santati paññatti nāma
translated: The designation of eighty, etc., is called a designation of a continuity.

original: Aṭṭhakathāmuttakeneva ācariyanayena aparāpi dhammakathikādikā kiccapaññatti, kisathūlādikā
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā muttakena iva ācariya nayena aparā api dhammakathikā ādikā kicca paññatti kisathūla ādikā
translated: By the method of the teachers, as given in the commentaries, there are also other designations, namely, the designation of a preacher of the Dhamma, etc., which is a designation of function;

original: saṇṭhānapaññatti, itthipurisādikā liṅgapaññatti, kāmāvacarādikā, kosalakādikā ca
analyzed: saṇṭhāna paññatti itthi purisa ādikā liṅga paññatti kāmāvacara ādikā kosalaka ādikā ca
translated: the designation of heavy, light, etc., which is a designation of shape; the designation of female, male, etc., which is a designation of sex; the designation of the sense sphere, etc., which is a designation of plane; the designation of Kosala, etc., which is a designation of place;

original: bhūmipaññatti, tisso nāgotiādikā paccattapaññatti, nirodhādikā asaṅkhatapaññatti
analyzed: bhūmi paññatti tissaḥ nāga uti ādikā paccatta paññatti nirodha ādikā asaṅkhata paññatti
translated: the designation of the three kinds of threads, etc., which is a designation of individual; the designation of cessation, etc., which is a designation of the unformed element.

original: cāti cha paññattiyo.
analyzed: ca ati cha paññattiyaḥ
translated: These are the six kinds of designation.

original: Etāsu pana dvādasasu tajjāpaññatti, ekaccā bhūmipaññatti, asaṅkhatapaññatti ca vijjamānapaññattisaṅkhātā
analyzed: etāsu pana dvādasasu ekaccā bhūmi paññatti asaṅkhata paññatti ca vijjamāna paññatti saṅkhātā
translated: But among these twelve, the designation of that, certain designations of plane, and the designation of the unformed element are called designations of what exists.

original: nāmapaññatti, tadaññā paramatthāvasesā, pana atthapaññattīti dīpitā avijjamānādipaññattiyo
analyzed: tad aññā paramattha avasesā pana attha paññatti iti dīpitāḥ avijjamāna ādi paññattiyaḥ
translated: The rest, which are designations of the ultimate, are shown to be designations of what does not exist, etc.

original: cāti. Ayaṃ tāvettha anuttānatthato saṃvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: ca ati ayam tāva ettha anuttāna atthataḥ saṃvaṇṇanā
translated: This, firstly, is the commentary on the word “unbounded” in the sense of “unboundedness.”

original: Atthanicchayo panetthāpi pāḷinayeneva saddhiṃ hoti, na vinā pāḷiṃ tassa vattumasakkuṇeyyattā.
analyzed: attha nicchayaḥ pana itthā api pāḷi nayena iva saddhim hoti na vinā pāḷim tassa vattum asakkuṇeyya ttā
translated: As regards the meaning of the words, however, it is only possible to explain them in accordance with the text, not without the text, because they cannot be explained otherwise.

original: Pāḷiyañca yasmā ādito pañca paññattiyo, tadatthabhūtā khandhādayo ca heṭṭhā vibhaṅgappakaraṇe
analyzed: yasmai āditaḥ pañca paññattiyaḥ tad attha bhūtā khandha ādayo ca heṭṭhā vibhaṅga ppakaraṇe
translated: And since the five categories of the fivefold classification and the aggregates, etc., which are their meanings, are given in the Vibhaṅga section below,

original: nippadesato kathitāti tā idha “kittāvatā khandhānaṃ khandhapaññatti, yāvatā pañcakkhandhā
analyzed: nippadesato kathitā ati tāḥ idha kittāvatā khandhānam khandha paññatti yāvatā pañca khandhā
translated: they are here stated in brief as follows: “In what sense is there a defining of the aggregates? In the sense of the five aggregates.

original: rūpakkhandho”tiādinā saṅkhepeneva niddiṭṭhā, tā cetthāpi vuttatthā. Puggalapaññatti🔽pana heṭṭhā na vuttāti “kittāvatā puggalānaṃ puggalapaññatti? Samayavimutto, asamayavimutto”tiādinā
analyzed: rūpa kkhandhaḥ ti ādinā saṅkhepena iva niddiṭṭhā tā ca itthā api vuttatthā puggala paññatti  pana heṭṭhā na vuttā ati kittāvatā puggalānam puggala paññatti samaya vimuttaḥ asamaya vimuttaḥ iti ādinā
translated: The form aggregate” , etc., and they are given here in the same way as there.🔽But the defining of persons is not given there, so it is given here in detail, after setting out the schedule in the fivefold classification, etc., as follows: “In what sense is there a defining of persons?

original: ekakādibhedena yāva dasakā dasadhā mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā vitthāreneva vibhattā, sā ca
analyzed: ekaka ādi bhedena yāva dasakāḥ dasadhā mātikam ṭhapetvā vitthārena iva vibhattā sā ca
translated: The person occasionally free from lust, the person not occasionally free from lust” , etc.

original: ñātabbapabhedato avuccamānā dubbiññeyyā, tasmā puggalapaññattiyā eva cettha pāḷinayānusārena
analyzed: ñātabba pabhedataḥ a vuccamānā dubbiññeyyā tasmā puggala paññattiyā eva ca ittha pāḷi naya anusārena
translated: And that is hard to understand if the various kinds of persons are not stated. So the meaning of the words in the text of the defining of persons is given here in accordance with the text as follows:

original: saṅkhepato atthanicchayo hoti, so cettha mātikāyaṃ vutte sabbapuggale anuddharitvā
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ attha nicchayaḥ hoti saḥ ca ittha mātikāyam vutte sabba puggale an uddharitvā
translated: The meaning-penetration is in brief. And that is stated in the Schedule.🔽But it is only after the persons have been extracted from the Schedule that

original: ñātabbānaṃ dubbiññeyyānaṃ puggalānaṃ ekakādibhedatova mātikaṃ uddharitvā vibhajanavasena
analyzed: ñātabbānam dubbiññeyyānam puggalānam ekaka ādi bhedataḥ va mātikam uddharitvā vibhajana vasena
translated: it is in brief by way of the analysis after extracting the Schedule by means of the single-pentad classification of the persons to be known who are hard to know.

original: saṅkhepatova hoti. Kathaṃ? “Samayavimutto asamayavimutto, kuppadhammo akuppadhammo,
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ u va hoti katham samaya vimuttaḥ a samaya vimuttaḥ kuppa dhammo a kuppa dhammo
translated: How? ‘One who is temporarily liberated, one who is not temporarily liberated, one of steadfastness subject to fall, one of steadfastness not subject to fall,

original: cetanābhabbo anurakkhaṇābhabbo, bhayūparato abhayūparato, bhabbāgamano abhabbāgamano,🔽niyato aniyato, paṭipannako phale ṭhito, samasīsī ṭhitakappī, sotāpanno sattakkhattuparamo
analyzed: cetanā bhabbaḥ anurakkhaṇā bhabbaḥ bhaya uparataḥ a bhaya uparataḥ bhabba āgamanaḥ a bhabba āgamanaḥ  niyataḥ aniyataḥ paṭipannakaḥ phale ṭhitaḥ samasīsī ṭhita kappī sotāpanno satta kkhattu paramaḥ
translated: one who is capable of discrimination, one who is capable of guarding, one who is guarded by virtue, one who is unguarded by virtue, one who is capable of going, one who is incapable of going,🔽one who is definite, one who is indefinite, one who is entered into the fixed course, one who is established in the fruit, one who is of equal flow, one who is of flow according to preparation, one who is a stream-enterer, one who is a once-returner,

original: kolaṃkolo ekabījī, sakadāgāmī, anāgāmī antarāparinibbāyī upahaccaparinibbāyī asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī
analyzed: kolaṃkolaḥ eka bījī sakadāgāmī anāgāmī antarā parinibbāyī upahacca parinibbāyī asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī
translated: one who is a non-returner, one who attains complete extinction in the interval, one who attains complete extinction on landing, one who attains complete extinction without prompting,

original: sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī, arahā”ti ekakamātikā.
analyzed: sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭha gāmī arahā ati ekaka mātikā
translated: one who attains complete extinction with prompting, one who goes upstream to the Highest Gods, and an Arahant’—this is the single pentad.

original: Tattha yo appanaṃ nibbattetuṃ yuttapattakāle rūpārūpasamāpattisaṅkhātehi aṭṭhahi
analyzed: tattha yaḥ appanam nibbattetum yutta patta kāle rūpa arūpa samāpatti saṅkhātehi aṭṭhahi
translated: Herein, one who is capable of discrimination is one who is fit to produce absorption at the time when he is fit to do so. He is so called because he is capable of discriminating the eight attainments called the fine-material and immaterial jhānas.

original: vimokkhehi paccanīkadhammato vimuccitvā tīsu maggesu yena kenaci yathāsakaṃ āsave
analyzed: vimokkhehi paccanīka dhammataḥ vimuccitvā tīsu maggesu yena kenaci yathāsakam āsave
translated: Having been liberated from the opposite states by means of the liberations, he is liberated from the defilements by means of the three paths, according as is appropriate.

original: khepetvā vuṭṭhito, ayaṃ samayavimutto nāma. “Ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā”tiādivacanato
analyzed: khepetvā vuṭṭhitaḥ ayam samayavimuttaḥ nāma ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā iti ādi vacanato
translated: He is called “temporarily liberated” because he is liberated from the opposing states by means of the jhānas and the path, and because he has temporarily expelled the defilements by means of any one of the three paths. He is called “temporarily liberated” because he is liberated from the opposing states by means of the jhānas and the path, and because he has temporarily expelled the defilements by means of any one of the three paths.

original: hi aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī puthujjano vā khīṇāsavo vā idha na gahito, samāpattilābhino
analyzed: hi aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī puthujjanaḥ vā khīṇa āsavaḥ vā idha na gahito samāpatti lābhino
translated: For the ordinary man who has attained the eight attainments and the one who is free from cankers are not included here because of the words: “Some defilements are destroyed” ,

original: pana phalaṭṭhasekhāva gahitāti veditabbā. Sukkhavipassakakhīṇāsavo, sabbepi ca ariyā🔽maggavimokkhaṃ sandhāya asamayavimuttā nāma. Bāhirānañhi aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ samāpajjantassa
analyzed: pana phala ṭṭha sekhā ava gahitā ti veditabbā sukkha vipassaka khīṇa asavaḥ sabbe pi ca ariyā  magga vimokkham sandhāya asamayavimuttā nāma bāhirānam hi aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam samāpajjantassa
translated: but only the trainee who has attained the fruition of the first path and the one who is free from cankers are included.🔽The dry insight meditator who is free from cankers and all the noble ones are called “liberated by the unincluded” in the sense of the path liberation.

original: pavivekaṭṭhānalābhādisamayopi atthi, vattakaraṇakālādiasamayopi atthi. Maggavimokkhena🔽vimuccanassa pana tādiso samayo vā asamayo vā natthi, yassa saddhā balavatī, vipassanā
analyzed: atthi vatta karaṇa kāla ādi asamayaḥ api atthi magga vimokkhena  vimuccanassa pana tādisaḥ samayaḥ vā asamayaḥ vā natthi yassa saddhā balavatī vipassanā
translated: For the one who attains the eight attainments of the external form-sphere jhānas has a time for entering jhāna, such as when he is in a secluded place, and a time that is not for entering jhāna, such as when he is in the midst of a crowd.🔽But for the one who is liberated by the path liberation there is no such time or time that is not for liberation.

original: ca āraddhā, tassa gacchantassa vā bhuñjantassa vā maggaphalapaṭivedho nāma na hotīti
analyzed: ca āraddhā tassa gacchantassa vā bhuñjantassa vā magga phala paṭivedhaḥ nāma na hoti iti
translated: For the one in whom faith is strong and insight is aroused, there is no such thing as the penetration of the path and fruition while he is walking or eating.

original: natthi, tasmā sabbe ariyā ariyavimokkhe asamayavimuttāti veditabbā. Purimapadepi
analyzed: na atthi tasmā sabbe ariyāḥ ariya vimokkhe a samaya vimuttā ati veditabbā purima pade pi
translated: In the first part of the verse,

original: lokiyasamāpattiññeva sandhāya sekhā samayavimuttā nāma jātā.
analyzed: lokiya samāpattiñca eva sandhāya sekhā samayavimuttā nāma jātā
translated: the “learners who are liberated by means of time” are those who have attained the mundane jhānas.

original: Avasibhāvā aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī pana puthujjano, sotāpannasakadāgāmino dve sekhā aṭṭhasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: avasi bhāvā aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī pana puthujjano sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ dve sekhāḥ aṭṭha samāpattim
translated: But the ordinary man who has attained the eight attainments is “liable to fall away” in virtue of his lack of mastery.🔽And the “liable to fall away” are of two kinds too, according as they are “liable to lose the attainment” or “liable to lose the path.”

original: sandhāya kuppadhammo nāma. Parihānadhammotipi duvidhā eva. Anāgāmiādayo suppahīnasamādhipāripanthikattā
analyzed: sandhāya kuppadhammaḥ nāma parihāna dhammaḥ ti pi duvidhāḥ eva anāgāmi ādayo su pahīna samādhi pāripanthika ttā
translated: The non-returner and the others, who have destroyed the hindrances to concentration,

original: vasibhāvā samāpattilābhī puthujjano, ariyā ca lokuttaradhammepi sandhāya akuppadhammo
analyzed: vasi bhāvā samāpatti lābhī puthujjanaḥ ariyā ca lokuttara dhamme pi sandhāya akuppa dhammo
translated: are “not liable to fall away” in virtue of their mastery of the attainment. And the ordinary man who has attained the eight attainments and the Noble Ones are “not liable to fall away” in virtue of their supramundane states.

original: nāma. Aparihānadhammoti te eva. Cetanābhabboti cetanāsaṅkhātena jhānasamāpattivaḷañjanena🔽aparihāniṃ āpajjituṃ bhabbo. Yo hi rūpārūpajjhānesu āciṇṇavasitāya cetanāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: nāma a parihāna dhammoti te eva cetanā bhabboti cetanā saṅkhātena jhāna samāpatti vaḷañjanena  a parihānim āpajjitum bhabbaḥ yaḥ hi rūpa arūpa jjhānesu āciṇṇa vasitāya cetanā saṅkhātāya
translated: “Possessed of resolution” is one who is able to attain the jhāna attainment called “resolution.”

original: jhānasamāpattiyā nirantaraṃ vaḷañjamāno tehi na parihāyati, avaḷañjamāno ca parihāyati,
analyzed: jhāna samāpattiyāḥ nirantaram vaḷañjamānaḥ tehi na parihāyati a vaḷañjamānaḥ ca parihāyati
translated: For one who has practiced and attained mastery in the fine-material and immaterial jhānas is not liable to fall away from them as long as he keeps renewing his “resolution” for their occurrence by thinking, “Let the jhāna arise,” and he is liable to fall away when he does not so renew his resolution.

original: ayaṃ vaḷañjamāno cetanābhabbo nāma. Anurakkhaṇābhabboti jhānassa upakārānupakāradhamme🔽jānitvā anurakkhaṇāya avaḷañjamānopi aparihāniṃ āpajjituṃ bhabbo, eso ca purimato🔽balavataro, āciṇṇavasino paññāsampadāya upakārānupakāradhamme jānitvā tadanurūpaṃ
analyzed: ayam vaḷañjamāno cetanābhabbaḥ nāma anurakkhaṇābhabbaḥ ti jhānassa upakāra an upakāra dhamme  jānitvā anurakkhaṇāya a vaḷañjamānaḥ api a parihānim āpajjitum bhabbaḥ esaḥ ca purimatas  balavataraḥ āciṇṇavasino paññā sampadāya upakāra an upakāra dhamme jānitvā tad anurūpam
translated: This is called the “one who is capable of non-forgetting.” “The one who is capable of guarding” is the one who, having known the things that are helpful and not helpful to the jhāna, is able to avoid falling away even though he is not one who does not forget. And he is stronger than the preceding one. The one who is capable of both is the one who, having known the things that are helpful and not helpful to the jhāna, guards accordingly and does not forget. He is stronger still.

original: paṭipajjanatoti veditabbo.🔽Bhayūparatoti bhayena pāpato uparato virato sekho, kalyāṇaputhujjano ca. Tesu pacchimo
analyzed: paṭipajjanataḥ ti veditabbaḥ  bhaya uparataḥ ti bhayena pāpataḥ uparataḥ virataḥ sekhaḥ kalyāṇa puthujjano ca tesu pacchimo
translated: This is called the one who is capable of non-forgetting. The one who is capable of guarding is the one who, having known the things that help and hinder the jhana, does not forget and is capable of non-decline. And he is stronger than the former. The one who is capable of re-entry should be understood as the one who is capable of re-entry by means of the attainment of understanding, having known the things that help and hinder the jhana.

original: duggativaṭṭakilesaupavādasaṅkhātehi catūhi bhayehi pāpato oramati, sekho duggativajjehi,
analyzed: duggati vaṭṭa kilesa aupavāda saṅkhātehi catūhi bhayehi pāpataḥ oramati sekhaḥ duggati vajjehi
translated: The one who is capable of avoiding fear is the trainer and the ordinary man who avoid evil by fear. Of these, the latter avoids evil by fear of the four fears called evil destinations, the round of rebirths, defilements, and censure. The trainer avoids evil by fear of the four fears called evil destinations, etc.,

original: apāyehi muttattā. Khīṇāsavo pana abhayūparato nāma samucchinnabhayattā, upavādato pana oramitabbo.
analyzed: apāyehi mutta ttā khīṇa āsavaḥ pana abhayūparataḥ nāma samucchinna bhaya ttā upavādataḥ pana oramitabbo
translated: because he is free from the bad destinations. But the one whose cankers are destroyed is called the one who has avoided fear because he has cut off fear. But he can be censured for not avoiding censure.

original: Abhabbāgamanoti sammattaniyāmāgamanassa abhabbo, ye ānantariyasaṅkhātena kammāvaraṇena,
analyzed: abhabba āgamano ti sammatta niyāma āgamanassa abhabbaḥ ye ānantariya saṅkhātena kamma āvaraṇena
translated: The one who is incapable of entering is the one who is incapable of entering upon the certainty of rightness. He is incapable of entering upon the certainty of rightness by means of the fourfold kamma- hindrance called the immediately successive cause.

original: niyatamicchādiṭṭhisaṅkhātena kilesāvaraṇena, ahetukaduhetukapaṭisandhisaṅkhātena
analyzed: niyatam icchā diṭṭhi saṅkhātena kilesa āvaraṇena ahetuka duhetuka paṭisandhi saṅkhātena
translated: They are “incapable of attainment” because they are obstructed by the defilement-obstacle called “fixed wrong view” and by the kamma-result-obstacle called “rebirth-linking without root-cause” or “with wrong root-cause” ,

original: vipākāvaraṇena ca samannāgatā, buddhādīsu ca saddhārahitā, maggabhāvanāya ca uttarakurukādayo
analyzed: vipāka āvaraṇena ca samannāgatāḥ buddha ādīsu ca saddhā rahitāḥ magga bhāvanāya ca uttarakuruka ādayaḥ
translated: because they are devoid of faith in the Buddha, etc., because they have no desire for the development of the path as have the beings of Uttarakuru, etc., and because they lack the previous root-cause .

original: viya acchandikā, pubbūpanissayarahitā ca, sabbete abhabbāgamanā nāma. Viparītā bhabbāgamanā
analyzed: viya a chandikā pubba upanissaya rahitā ca sabbete abhabba āgamanāḥ nāma viparītāḥ bhabba āgamanāḥ
translated: The opposite of these are “capable of attainment.”

original: nāma. Pañcānantariyaniyatamicchādiṭṭhikā nirayagamane, aṭṭha ariyapuggalā anupādāparinibbānādīsu
analyzed: nāma pañca ānantariya niyatam micchādiṭṭhikāḥ niraya gamane aṭṭha ariya puggalāḥ anupādā parinibbāna ādīsu
translated: Those who are fixed in the five immediate offenses are fixed on going to hell; the eight noble persons are fixed on the attainment of non-return, etc.

original: niyatā nāma. Avasesapuggalā anibaddhagatikatāya aniyatā nāma, uttarakurukā pana sugatiniyatāpi
analyzed: niyatāḥ nāma avasesa puggalāḥ anibaddha gatika tāya aniyatāḥ nāma uttarakurukā pana sugati niyatā api
translated: The remaining persons are not fixed on any destiny, and so they are called “unfixed.” The beings of Uttarakuru are fixed on a happy destiny,

original: micchattasammattaniyāmasseva idhādhippetattā “niyatā”ti na vuttā. Maggasamaṅgī puggalo
analyzed: micchatta sammatta niyāmassa iva idha adhippeta ttā niyatā ati na vuttā magga samaṅgī puggalo
translated: but they are not called “fixed” because they are fixed only on wrongness and not on rightness.

original: maggakkhaṇe phalatthāya paṭipannako nāma, phalasamaṅgī phalānuppattiyampi phale ṭhito nāma.
analyzed: magga kkhaṇe phala atthāya paṭipannakaḥ nāma phala samaṅgī phala anuppattiyam pi phale ṭhitaḥ nāma
translated: The person who possesses the path is called “one who is practicing for the fruit” at the moment of the path. The person who possesses the fruit is called “one who is established in the fruit” even when the fruit has not yet arisen.

original: Yassa pana apubbācarimaṃ āsavapariyādānañca hoti jīvitapariyādānañca, ayaṃ samasīsī
analyzed: yassa pana apubbācarimam āsava pariyādānam ca hoti jīvita pariyādānam ca ayam samasīsī
translated: But when there is exhaustion of both the cankers and life, this is called “equal-headed” .

original: nāma. So ca tividho hoti iriyāpathasamasīsī rogasamasīsī jīvitasamasīsīti. Tattha🔽yo catūsu iriyāpathesu ekasmiṃ vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ patvā tasmiññeva🔽iriyāpathe parinibbāti, ayaṃ iriyāpathasamasīsī nāma. Yo pana ekaṃ rogaṃ patvā antoroge
analyzed: nāma so ca tividhaḥ hoti iriyāpatha samasīsī roga samasīsī jīvita samasīsī iti tattha  yaḥ catūsu iriyāpathesu ekasmin vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam patvā tasmin ñeva  iriyāpathe parinibbāti ayam iriyāpathasamasīsī nāma yaḥ pana ekam rogam patvā antoroge
translated: And it is of three kinds as “equal-headed in posture,” “equal-headed in disease,” and “equal-headed in life.” Herein,

original: eva vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ patvā teneva rogena parinibbāti, ayaṃ rogasamasīsī🔽nāma. Yassa pana kilesasīsasaṅkhātā avijjā, arahattamaggena pavattasīsasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: eva vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam patvā tena iva rogena parinibbāti ayam roga samasīsī  nāma yassa pana kilesa sīsa saṅkhātā avijjā arahatta maggena pavatta sīsa saṅkhātam
translated: one who establishes insight by taking one of the four postures as object and then attains Arahantship and attains Nibbāna in that same posture is called “equal-headed in posture.” But one who, after falling sick, establishes insight by taking the internal disease as object, attains Arahantship and attains Nibbāna in that same disease is called “equal-headed in disease.”

original: jīvitindriyañca cuticittena samaṃ pariyādānaṃ gacchati, ayaṃ jīvitasamasīsī nāma.
analyzed: jīvitindriyam ca cuti cittena samam pariyādānam gacchati ayam jīvitasamasīsī nāma
translated: But when ignorance, called the “head” of defilements, is exhausted by means of the Arahant path, and the life faculty, called the “head” of occurrence, is exhausted simultaneously with the death consciousness, this is called “equal-headed in life.”

original: Kathamidaṃ samaṃ hotīti? Vārasamatāya. Yasmiṃ hi vāre maggena kilese khepite paccavekkhaṇañāṇāni
analyzed: katham idam samam hoti iti vāra samatāya yasmin hi vāre maggena kilese khepite paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇāni
translated: How is it equal? By equality of turn. For in the turn in which defilements are destroyed by the path, the reviewing knowledges

original: pavattanti, tassānantarameva parinibbāyato imāya vārasamatāya idaṃ ubhayasīsapariyādānampi
analyzed: pavattanti tassa anantaram eva parinibbāyato imāya vāra samatāya idam ubhaya sīsa pariyādānam pi
translated: and the other one attains Nibbāna immediately afterwards, then this relinquishment of both sides is equal in this respect.

original: samaṃ hoti nāma, ayameva jīvitasamasīsī idhādhippeto.
analyzed: samam hoti nāma ayam eva jīvita samasīsī idha adhippeto
translated: This is the one who is called “equal in life and relinquishment.”

original: Ṭhitakappīti ṭhito kappo ṭhitakappo, svāssa atthīti ṭhitakappī, kappamhi vinassamānamhi kappaṃ ṭhapetuṃ samatthoti attho.🔽Sace hi yesaṃ maggasamaṅgikkhaṇe kappavināso bhaveyya, neva tāva kappo vinasseyya,
analyzed: ṭhita kappī iti ṭhitaḥ kappo ṭhita kappo svā assa atthi iti ṭhita kappī kappamhi vinassamānamhi kappam ṭhapetum samatthaḥ ti attho  sace hi yesam magga samaṅgi kkhaṇe kappa vināsaḥ bhaveyya na iva tāva kappaḥ vinasseyya
translated: “One who can stop the aeon”: the aeon is stopped by him, thus he is one who can stop the aeon ; the meaning is that he is able to stop the aeon while it is in the process of dissolution.

original: yāvāyaṃ yathāsakaṃ phalaṃ na sacchikarotīti te vinassamānampi kappaṃ ṭhapentīti ṭhitakappino
analyzed: yāvā ayam yathāsakam phalam na sacchikaroti iti te vinassamānam api kappam ṭhapenti iti ṭhita kappinaḥ
translated: For if the aeon were to be destroyed at the moment of his possession of the path, the aeon would not be destroyed until he had realized the fruit corresponding to that path.🔽So they are called “those who can stop the aeon” because they stop the aeon while it is in the process of dissolution.

original: nāma jātāti. Kiñcāpi kappavināsanakāle sāsanaṃ natthi, gatakoṭike hi kāle kappavināso
analyzed: nāma jātā ati kiñcā api kappa vināsana kāle sāsanam natthi gata koṭike hi kāle kappa vināso
translated: Although there is no Dispensation at the time of the aeon’s destruction, since the aeon is destroyed at the time when the world has reached the end of its expansion,

original: hoti, evaṃ santepi maggānantaraphalassa anantarāyaṃ dīpetuṃ idaṃ abhūtampi kāraṇaṃ āhaṭaṃ.
analyzed: hoti evam sante pi magga anantara phalassa anantarāyam dīpetum idam abhūtam pi kāraṇam āhaṭam
translated: nevertheless this reason is given in order to illustrate the non-interruption of the fruit immediately after the path.

original: Sotāpannoti nibbānasamuddaninnatāya sotasaṅkhātassa maggassa paṭhamasamaṅgī vuccati,
analyzed: sotāpannaḥ ti nibbāna samudda ninna tāya sota saṅkhātassa maggassa paṭhama samaṅgī vuccati
translated: “Stream-enterer” is said of one who is endowed with the first path, which is called a “stream” because it flows on to the flood of Nibbāna.

original: idha pana phalaṭṭho adhippeto. Tasseva ca pabhedadassanatthaṃ “sattakkhattuparamo”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Sattavārā paramā assa bhavūpapattīti sattakkhattuparamo, tato paraṃ aṭṭhamaṃ
analyzed: idha pana phala aṭṭhaḥ adhippeto tassa iva ca pabheda dassana tham satta kkhattu paramaḥ tiādi  vuttam satta vārā paramā assa bhava upapatti iti satta kkhattu paramaḥ tatas param aṭṭhamam
translated: But here the meaning of “fruit” is intended. And in order to show its varieties, it is said, “At most seven times he will have reappeared.”

original: bhavaṃ nādiyatīti attho. Sotāpanno hi yo sattakkhattuṃ devesu, manussesu ca paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: bhavam na ādiyati iti attho sotāpannaḥ hi yaḥ sattakkhattum devesu manussesu ca paṭisandhim
translated: At most seven times he will have reappeared in existence as a god or a human : the meaning is that he will not go beyond the eighth existence.

original: gahetvā sattame bhave dukkhassantaṃ karoti, ayaṃ sattakkhattuparamo nāma. Kulato🔽kulaṃ bhavato bhavaṃ gacchatīti kolaṃkolo. So hi devamanussavasena dve gatiyo bhave
analyzed: gahetvā sattame bhave dukkhassantam karoti ayam sattakkhattuparamaḥ nāma kulataḥ  kulam bhavataḥ bhavam gacchati iti kolaṃkolo saḥ hi deva manussa vasena dve gatiyaḥ bhave
translated: For the stream-enterer who takes rebirth in the divine world and the human world seven times and makes an end of suffering is called “at most seven times.”

original: saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti, ayaṃ kolaṃkolo nāma. Kammapaṭisandhiyā ekaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam kolaṃkolaḥ nāma kamma paṭisandhiyā ekam kammaṃ
translated: He goes from family to family, from existence to existence : he is a “family-to-family” . For he makes an end of suffering after wandering among two destinations, the divine and the human, in two existences. This is called “family-to-family.”

original: kilesabījaṃ assāti ekabījī. So hi ekasmiññeva bhave khīṇāsavo hoti. Kiṃ panassa bhedassa
analyzed: kilesa bījam assāti ekabījī saḥ hi ekasmin ñeva bhave khīṇa āsavaḥ hoti kim panassa bhedassa
translated: He has one birth and one kamma-process of becoming : he is a “single-seeded” . For he becomes an Arahant in that very existence. But what is the difference between the “family-to-family” and the “single-seeded” ?

original: niyāmakanti? Vipassanābhiññābhedā. Sotāpannesu hi yo vipassanāya pamatto, so sattakkhattuparamo🔽hoti. Yo kiñci appamatto, so kolaṃkolo. Yo pana vipassanāya ativiya appamatto, so
analyzed: niyāmakan ti vipassanā abhiññā bhedā sotāpannesu hi yaḥ vipassanāya pamattaḥ so satta kkhattu paramaḥ  hoti yaḥ kiñci appamatto so kolaṃkolaḥ yaḥ pana vipassanāya ativiya appamatto so
translated: What is the determining factor? The difference in their insight and in their direct-knowledge. For among stream-enterers, the one who is negligent in insight is the one who has seven more births at most;🔽the one who is not negligent in any respect is the clan-to-clan;🔽but the one who is very diligent in insight is the one-seed.

original: ekabījī hoti. Ye pana abhiviya pamattā vaṭṭajjhāsayā anāthapiṇḍikavisākhāsakkādayo,
analyzed: eka bījī hoti ye pana abhiviya pamattāḥ vaṭṭa ajjhāsayāḥ anāthapiṇḍika visākha sakka ādayo
translated: But those who are negligent in insight and are inclined to the round of rebirths, such as Anathapindika, Visakha, Migara’s mother, and so on,

original: te punappunaṃ vaṭṭasmiṃyeva vicarantā ādito paṭṭhāya cha devaloke osāpetvā brahmalokesupi
analyzed: te punappunam vaṭṭasmiṃyeva vicarantāḥ āditas paṭṭhāya cha deva loke osāpetvā brahma lokesu pi
translated: wander again and again in the round of rebirths. Having passed through the six divine worlds from the beginning, they are reborn in the Brahmā-worlds,

original: yathākkamaṃ nibbattitvā akaniṭṭhe ṭhatvā parinibbanti, na te idha gahitā. Te hi manussagatiṃ
analyzed: yathākkamam nibbattitvā akaniṭṭhe ṭhatvā parinibbanti na te idha gahitā te hi manussa gatim
translated: and after standing as the highest in the Akaniṭṭha world, they attain Nibbāna. They are not included here. For they take up the human destiny

original: punappunaṃ ādiyanti. Ye pana manussagatiyampi bhavaṃ ādiyanti, tesaṃ vasena sattakkhattuparamo🔽kolaṃkolo mānusikabhavanibbattako eva ekabījī gahito. Te pana saddhādhurena āgatā
analyzed: punappunam ādiyanti ye pana manussa gatiyam pi bhavam ādiyanti tesam vasena satta kkhattu paramaḥ  kolaṃkolaḥ mānusika bhava nibbattakaḥ eva eka bījī gahitaḥ te pana saddhā dhurena āgatā
translated: again and again. But the one who has seven more births at most, the clan-to-clan, and the one-seed, who take rebirth in the human world, are included here.🔽They come by the vehicle of faith and by the vehicle of understanding.

original: tayo, paññādhurena āgatā tayoti sotāpanno chabbidho hotīti veditabbo.
analyzed: tayo paññā dhurena āgatā tayoti sotāpanno chabbidhaḥ hoti iti veditabbo
translated: The stream-enterer should be understood as of six kinds.

original: Paṭisandhivasena pana sakiṃ imaṃ manussagatiṃ āgacchatīti sakadāgāmī, dutiyamaggaphalasamaṅgī.🔽Iminā pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu cattāro vajjetvā ekova gahito. Ekacco hi sakadāgāmiphale
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena pana sakim imam manussa gatim āgacchati iti sakadāgāmī dutiya magga phala samaṅgī  iminā pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu cattāraḥ vajjetvā ekaḥ iva gahitaḥ ekaccaḥ hi sakadāgāmi phale
translated: But by rebirth he comes only once to this human world, thus he is a once-returner. He possesses the third path and fruit.

original: ṭhatvā puna dutiyabhave idheva parinibbāti, ekacco idha patvā devaloke parinibbāti,
analyzed: ṭhatvā puna dutiya bhave idha iva parinibbāti ekaccaḥ idha patvā deva loke parinibbāti
translated: By this means, omitting four among the five kinds of once-returner, only one is included here. For one kind of once-returner, after standing in the fruit of once-returning, attains Nibbāna in this very life in a second existence. Another attains Nibbāna in the heavenly world after coming here.

original: ekacco devaloke patvā dutiyabhave tattheva parinibbāti, ekacco devaloke patvā idhūpapajjitvā
analyzed: ekaccaḥ deva loke patvā dutiya bhave tattha iva parinibbāti ekaccaḥ deva loke patvā idhu upapajjitvā
translated: Another attains Nibbāna in a second existence there after being reborn in the heavenly world. Another is reborn here after being reborn in the heavenly world,

original: parinibbāti, ime cattāropi idha na gahitā. Yo pana idha patvā devaloke nibbattitvā
analyzed: parinibbāti ime cattāraḥ api idha na gahitāḥ yaḥ pana idha patvā deva loke nibbattitvā
translated: and attains Nibbāna here. These four are not included here. But the one who is reborn in the heavenly world after coming here,

original: puna idhūpapajjitvā parinibbāti, ayamekova idha gahito. Imassa ca dve paṭisandhiyo,
analyzed: punar idhūpapajjitvā parinibbāti ayam ekaḥ iva idha gahitaḥ imassa ca dve paṭisandhiyaḥ
translated: and attains Nibbāna after being reborn here again, is included here. And he has two rebirths.

original: ekabījissa pana ekāvāti idaṃ tesaṃ nānākaraṇanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ekabījissa pana ekāvā ti idam tesam nānākaraṇanti veditabbam
translated: But the single-seeded has only one. This is how their difference should be understood.

original: Paṭisandhivasena kāmabhavaṃ nāgacchatīti anāgāmī, tatiyamaggaphalasamaṅgī. Tasseva
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena kāma bhavam na āgacchati iti anāgāmī tatiya magga phala samaṅgī tassa eva
translated: He does not come to sense-desire existence by rebirth, thus he is a non-returner. He possesses the fourth path and fruit.

original: pana pabhedadassanatthaṃ “antarāparinibbāyī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha antarāparinibbāyīti
analyzed: pana pabheda dassana attham antarāparinibbāyi itiādi vuttam tattha antarāparinibbāyi iti
translated: But the words “one who attains nibbāna in the interval” and so on are said in order to show the different kinds.

original: āyuvemajjhassa antarā eva arahattamaggaṃ uppādetvā kilesaparinibbānena parinibbāyanasīlo🔽eko anāgāmī. So ca uppannasamanantaraṃ parinibbāyī, āyuvemajjhaṃ appatvā parinibbāyī,
analyzed: āyu vemajjhassa antarā eva arahatta maggam uppādetvā kilesa parinibbānena parinibbāyana sīlo  ekaḥ anāgāmī saḥ ca uppanna samanantaram parinibbāyī āyu vemajjham a patvā parinibbāyī
translated: But the words “one who attains Nibbāna in the interval” and so on are said in order to show the kinds of nonreturners. Herein, one who attains Nibbāna in the interval is a nonreturner of one kind who generates the path to arahantship in the middle of his life span and is of a nature to attain Nibbāna through the extinction of defilements.

original: āyuvemajjhaṃ patvā parinibbāyīti tividho hoti. Upahaccaparinibbāyīti āyuvemajjhaṃ🔽upahacca atikkamitvā, maraṇasamayaṃ vā upahacca upagantvā parinibbāyī, āyuvemajjhaṃ
analyzed: āyu vemajjham patvā parinibbāyi iti tividhaḥ hoti upahacca parinibbāyī iti āyu vemajjham  upahacca atikkamitvā maraṇa samayam vā upahacca upagantvā parinibbāyī āyu vemajjham
translated: He is threefold as one who attains Nibbāna immediately after arising, one who attains Nibbāna without having reached the middle of his life span, and one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the middle of his life span.

original: atikkamitvā yāva maraṇasamayā parinibbāyīti attho. Asaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti asaṅkhārena🔽appadukkhena adhimattappayogaṃ akatvā parinibbāyanasīlo. Sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti
analyzed: atikkamitvā yāva maraṇa samayā parinibbāyi iti atthaḥ asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti asaṅkhārena  appa dukkhena adhimatta ppayogam a katvā parinibbāyana sīlo sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti
translated: One who attains Nibbāna upon landing is one who attains Nibbāna after landing, after going beyond the middle of his life span, or after going beyond the middle of his life span and after reaching the time of death.🔽One who attains Nibbāna without prompting is one who is of a nature to attain Nibbāna without prompting, without difficulty, without great effort.

original: sasaṅkhārena dukkhena kasirena adhimattappayogena parinibbāyanasīlo. Uddhaṃsototi
analyzed: sa saṅkhārena dukkhena kasirena adhimatta ppayogena parinibbāyana sīlo
translated: One who attains Nibbāna with prompting is one who is of a nature to attain Nibbāna with prompting, with difficulty, with great effort.🔽One who goes upstream is one who goes to the plane of the stream-enterer, etc., in forward order.

original: uddhaṃvāhibhāvena uddhamassa taṇhāsotaṃ vaṭṭasotañca, uddhaṃ vā gantvā paṭilabhitabbato
analyzed: uddham vāhi bhāvena uddhamassa taṇhā sotam vaṭṭa sotam ca uddham vā gantvā paṭilabhitabbato
translated: As to the meaning of ‘ stream ’, it is a stream in the sense of a stream of craving and a stream of the round of rebirths that goes upwards, or🔽it is a stream in the sense of a path that has to be reached by going upwards.

original: uddhaṃ maggasotamassātipi uddhaṃsoto. Akaniṭṭhaṃ gacchatīti akaniṭṭhagāmī. Imesaṃ
analyzed: uddham uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭham gacchati iti akaniṭṭha gāmī imesam
translated: ‘ He goes to the Highest , thus he is a goer to the Highest ’.

original: pana anāgāmīnaṃ pabhedadassanatthampettha uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmītiādi catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Tattha yo avihato paṭṭhāya catūsu yathākkamaṃ uppajjitvā yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā cuto🔽akaniṭṭhe uppajjitvā parinibbāti, ayaṃ uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo pana akaniṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pana anāgāmīnam pabheda dassana tham pa ittha akaniṭṭha gāmī iti ādi catukkam veditabbam  tattha yaḥ avihataḥ paṭṭhāya catūsu yathākkamam uppajjitvā yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā cutaḥ  akaniṭṭhe uppajjitvā parinibbāti ayam uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ pana akaniṭṭham
translated: But in order to show the kinds of Non-Returners, the fourfold division beginning with ‘ one who goes upstream and is a goer to the Highest ’ should be understood.🔽Herein, one who, after arising in the four beginning with Aviha in due succession, and after living out his span of life there, passes away and is reborn in the Highest , and then attains extinction there, is called ‘ one who goes upstream and is a goer to the Highest ’.

original: appatvā antarā parinibbāti, ayaṃ uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo manussaloko
analyzed: a patvā antarā parinibbāti ayam uddhaṃsotaḥ na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ manussa loko
translated: But one who attains extinction without reaching the Highest is called ‘ one who goes upstream but is not a goer to the Highest ’.

original: akaniṭṭhameva gantvā parinibbāti, ayaṃ na uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo pana
analyzed: akaniṭṭham eva gantvā parinibbāti ayam naḥ uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ pana
translated: One who, after going to the Highest, attains extinction there, is called ‘ one who does not go upstream but is a goer to the Highest ’.

original: heṭṭhā catūsu suddhāvāsesu aññatarasmiṃ uppajjitvā tattheva parinibbāti, ayaṃ na
analyzed: heṭṭhā catūsu suddhāvāsesu aññatarasmin uppajjitvā tattha iva parinibbāti ayam na
translated: But one who is reborn in one of the other four kinds of Pure Abodes and attains extinction there is called ‘ one who neither goes upstream nor is a goer to the Highest ’.

original: uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Evamete anāgāmino aṭṭhacattālīsavidhā honti. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma evam ete anāgāminaḥ aṭṭhacattālīsavidhāḥ honti katham
translated: and one who goes upstream not bound for the highest. So these non-returners are of forty-eight kinds. How?

original: Avihesu tāva tayo antarāparinibbāyino, eko upahaccaparinibbāyī, eko uddhaṃsototi
analyzed: avihesu tāva tayo antarā parinibbāyinaḥ ekaḥ upahacca parinibbāyī ekaḥ
translated: There are five in the Aviha realm: three who attain Nibbāna in the interval, one who attains Nibbāna upon landing, and one who goes upstream.

original: pañca, te asaṅkhāraparinibbāyisasaṅkhāraparinibbāyivasena dasa honti, evaṃ atappasudassasudassīsūti
analyzed: pañca te asaṅkhāra parinibbāyi sasaṅkhāra parinibbāyi vasena dasa honti evam atappa sudassa sudassīsu iti
translated: They are ten in all with the division into those who attain Nibbāna without and with prompting. So too with the Atappa, Sudassa, and Sudassī realms.

original: cattālīsaṃ, akaniṭṭhe pana uddhaṃsoto natthi, tasmā tattha taṃ sasaṅkhārāsaṅkhāravasena
analyzed: cattālīsam akaniṭṭhe pana natthi tasmā tattha tam sa saṅkhāra asaṅkhāra vasena
translated: So there are forty. But in the Akaniṭṭha realm there is no one who goes upstream. Therefore, omitting that one who goes upstream with and without prompting,

original: duvidhaṃ uddhaṃsotaṃ vajjetvā aṭṭha cāti aṭṭhacattālīsa honti.
analyzed: duvidham vajjetvā aṭṭha ca ati aṭṭhacattālīsa honti
translated: there are eight there, making forty-eight in all.

original: Arahāti kilesārīnaṃ hatattādinā khīṇāsavo arahā nāma. So suññatādivimokkhattayavasena🔽tividho hutvā puna paccekaṃ paṭipadācatukkavasena dvādasavidhā honti. Yathā ca arahā
analyzed: arahā iti hata tta ādinā khīṇāsavaḥ arahā nāma so suññatā ādi vimokkha ttaya vasena  tividhaḥ hutvā puna paccekam paṭipadā catukka vasena dvādasavidhāḥ honti yathā ca arahā
translated: “Arahant” : one whose defilements are destroyed, who has abolished the enemies, is called an arahant. He is of three kinds according to the three liberations beginning with voidness.🔽He is of twelve kinds with the division into four paths each of the three kinds. And just as the arahant is of twelve kinds,

original: dvādasavidho, evaṃ dvādaseva sakadāgāmino, catuvīsati sotāpannā aṭṭhacattālīsa anāgāminova
analyzed: dvādasavidhaḥ evam dvādasa iva sakadāgāmino catuvīsati sotāpannāḥ aṭṭhacattālīsa anāgāmino va
translated: so too are the once-returners, the non-returners, and the stream-enterers.

original: paccekanti veditabbaṃ. Ime ca sabbe ariyā imasmiṃ sāsane eva uppajjanti, no bahiddhāti. Ekakanayo.🔽Dukādimātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paccekam ti veditabbam ime ca sabbe ariyāḥ imasmim sāsane eva uppajjanti no bahiddhā iti ekaka nayo
translated: and each one should be understood as a single person. And all these Noble Persons arise only in this dispensation, not outside it. This is the method of the single persons.🔽The exposition of the dyads, etc.,

original: Dukādīsu “dve puggalā – kodhano ca upanāhī ca makkhī ca paḷāsī cā”tiādinā dukañca,
analyzed: duka ādīsu dve puggalā kodhano ca upanāhī ca makkhī ca paḷāsī ca ati ādinā dukam ca
translated: In the dyads, etc., the dyads begin with “Two persons: the angry and the malicious, the envious and the slanderer” .🔽The triads begin with “Three persons: the faithless, the uncharitable, the unwise” .

original: “tayo puggalā – nirāso āsaṃso vigatāso”tiādinā tikañca, “cattāro puggalā – asappuriso,
analyzed: tayo puggalā cattāro puggalā asappuriso
translated: The tetrads begin with “Four persons: the untrue man,

original: asappurisenaasappurisataro, sappuriso, sappurisenasappurisataro”tiādinā catukkañca,
analyzed: a sappurisena a sappurisa taro sappurisaḥ sappurisena sappurisa taro ti ādinā catukkam ca
translated: the more untrue man, the true man, the more true man” .

original: “pañca puggalā – atthekacco puggalo ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṃ🔽paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā🔽aparisesā nirujjhanti, atthekacco puggalo ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hoti…pe… aparisesā
analyzed: pañca puggalāḥ attha ekaccaḥ puggalo ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti tam ca cetaḥ vimuttim 🔽paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ 🔽aparisesā nirujjhanti attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hoti pe aparisesā
translated: The penads begin with “Five persons: there is the case, friends, where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does not know, as it actually is, the release where the effluents come to an end.🔽There is the case where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does not know, as it actually is, the release where the effluents come to end. There is the case where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does not know, as it actually is, the release where the effluents come to end. There is the case where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does not know, as it actually is, the release where the effluents come to end.
