There is the case where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does not know, as it actually is, the release where the effluents come to end. There is the case where a person is a reactor & a repressor, but he does

original: nirujjhanti, atthekacco puggalo nārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hoti…pe… aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: nirujjhanti attha ekaccaḥ puggalo na ārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hoti pe aparisesā nirujjhanti
translated: and for another they cease without remainder.🔽For another they do not begin, and he does not regret it … and for another they cease without remainder.

original: Atthekacco puggalo nārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti…pe… aparisesā nirujjhantī”tiādinā
analyzed: attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti pe aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti itiādinā
translated: For another they do not begin, and he does not regret it … and for another they cease without remainder.”

original: pañcakañca vitthārato mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā sabbepi te puggalā niddiṭṭhā, idha pana
analyzed: pañcakam ca vitthārataḥ mātikam nikkhipitvā sabbe pi te puggalāḥ niddiṭṭhāḥ idha pana
translated: and the five groups in detail, and all those persons are demonstrated. But here

original: te ganthavitthārabhayena sabbe na uddiṭṭhā, pāḷiyā eva ñātabbāti.
analyzed: te gantha vitthāra bhayena sabbe na uddiṭṭhā pāḷiyā eva ñātabbā ati
translated: they are not mentioned for fear of being too wordy. They can be known from the texts themselves.

original: Tattha tike nirāsoti arahattāsāya virahito dussīlo. Tassa hi attano abhabbatāya bhabbasahāyakassa
analyzed: tattha tike nirāsaḥ ti arahat tāsāya virahitaḥ dussīlo tassa hi attanaḥ abhabba tāya bhabba sahāyakassa
translated: Herein, one without hope is a person without virtue who is without hope of reaching Arahantship. For when he hears of the attainment of Arahantship by a virtuous person capable of it,

original: sīlavato arahattappattiṃ sutvā, caṇḍālaputtassa viya kassaci rājaputtassa rajjābhisekaṃ
analyzed: sīlavataḥ arahatta ppattim sutvā caṇḍāla puttassa viya kassaci rāja puttassa rajja abhisekam
translated: like the son of a certain king who was anointed prince-royal on hearing of the attainment of anointment by another who was capable of it,

original: sutvā abhisekappattiyaṃ, “kudāssu nāmāhampi arahattaṃ pāpuṇeyya”nti arahattappattiyaṃ
analyzed: sutvā abhiseka ppattiyam kudāssu nāma aham pi arahattam pāpuṇeyyanti arahatta ppattiyam
translated: he does not even form the wish “When shall I attain Arahantship?” in regard to the attainment of Arahantship.

original: patthanāpi na uppajjati. Āsaṃsoti arahattaṃ āsīsamāno patthayamāno sīlavā. Tassa
analyzed: patthanā api na uppajjati āsaṃso ti arahattam āsīsamāno patthayamāno sīlavā tassa
translated: One with hope is a virtuous person who hopes for and wishes for Arahantship.

original: hi arahattapatthanāya sīlasampattiyā ṭhitattā kassaci arahattappattiṃ sutvā, ubhatosujātassa
analyzed: hi arahatta patthanāya sīla sampattiyāḥ ṭhita ttā kassaci arahatta ppattim sutvā ubhatosujātassa
translated: He is called “free from doubt” because he is free from doubt about his own attainment of arahatship,

original: rājakumārassa viya tādisassa kassaci rajjābhisekaṃ sutvā abhisekappattiyaṃ, arahattappattiyaṃ🔽patthanā uppajjati. Vigatāsoti arahā. So hi pattaarahattatāya tattha vigatāso hoti🔽pattābhiseko viya khattiyo abhisekappattiyanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: rāja kumārassa viya tādisassa kassaci rajja abhisekam sutvā abhiseka ppattiyam arahatta ppattiyam  patthanā uppajjati vigata aso ti arahā saḥ hi patta arahatta tāya tattha vigata aso hoti  patta abhisekaḥ viya khattiyaḥ abhiseka ppattiyan ti veditabbam
translated: like a prince who is free from doubt about his own consecration when he hears of the consecration of someone else.

original: Catukke pana pāṇātipātādiakusalakammapathasamannāgato asappuriso nāma. Yo pana sayampi
analyzed: catukke pana pāṇātipāta ādi akusala kammapatha samannāgato asappurisaḥ nāma yaḥ pana sayam pi
translated: In the fourfold case, the unrighteous man is one who possesses the unrighteous courses of action beginning with killing living beings.

original: pāṇātipātādīni katvā parañca tattha samādapeti, ayaṃ asappurisenaasappurisataro,
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīni katvā param ca tattha samādapeti ayam a sappurisena a sappurisa taro
translated: But one who himself commits killing, etc., and also induces others to do so is more unrighteous than the unrighteous man;

original: asappurisatopi asappurisataroti attho. Vuttapaṭipakkhakusalavasena sappuriso, sappurisenasappurisataro ca veditabbo.
analyzed: asappurisataḥ pi asappurisataro ti attho vutta paṭipakkha kusala vasena sappurisaḥ sappurisena sappurisataro ca veditabbo
translated: he is the most unrighteous of the unrighteous. The righteous man and the most righteous of the righteous should be understood in the opposite sense.

original: Pañcake ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hotīti ettha ārambha-saddo āpattivītikkame vattati,
analyzed: pañcake ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti iti ettha ārambha saddaḥ āpatti vītikkame vattati
translated: He is one who has begun and is remorseful: here the word begun refers to the transgression of an offense.

original: tasmā āpattivītikkamavasena ārabhati ceva tappaccayā ca vippaṭisārī hotīti attho.
analyzed: tasmai āpatti vītikkama vasena ārabhati ca iva tad paccayā ca vippaṭisārī hoti iti attho
translated: So the meaning is that he is one who has begun by transgressing an offense and is remorseful because of that.

original: Cetovimuttinti phalasampayuttasamādhiṃ. Paññāvimuttinti phalasampayuttañāṇaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: cetaḥ vimuttim ti phala sampayutta samādhim paññā vimuttim ti phala sampayutta ñāṇam yathābhūtam
translated: Liberation of mind: concentration associated with the fruition attainment. Liberation by wisdom: knowledge associated with the fruition attainment.

original: nappajānātīti anadhigatattā yathāsabhāvato nappajānāti. Yatthassāti yasmiṃ arahattaphalasaṅkhāte
analyzed: na ppajānāti iti anadhigata ttā yathā sabhāvataḥ na ppajānāti yattha ati yasmin arahatta phala saṅkhāte
translated: Does not understand: because he has not yet attained it, he does not understand it as it really is, according to its true nature.

original: jhāne adhigate assa puggalassa sabbe pāpakā akusalā dhammā niravasesā nirujjhanti,🔽te nappajānātīti sambandho. Kiñcāpi te maggakkhaṇe eva nirujjhanti nāma, phalakkhaṇe
analyzed: jhāne adhigate assa puggalassa sabbe pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ niravasesāḥ nirujjhanti  te na pajānāti iti sambandhaḥ kiñca api te magga kkhaṇe eva nirujjhanti nāma phala kkhaṇe
translated: Where: in the jhana called the fruition attainment of arahatship, when it is attained by that person, all bad unwholesome states cease without remainder.🔽Does not understand: this is the construction. Although they cease at the moment of the path,

original: pana niruddhā nāma honti, idha pana maggakiccavasena “phalakkhaṇe nirujjhantī”ti vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: pana niruddhāḥ nāma honti idha pana magga kicca vasena phala khaṇe nirujjhanti iti vuttā ati veditabbā
translated: at the moment of the fruition they are called ceased. But here they should be understood as “ceasing” in the sense of the function of the path.

original: Ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hotīti āpattiṃ āpajjati, taṃ pana desetuṃ sabhāgapuggalaṃ
analyzed: ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hoti iti āpattim āpajjati tam pana desetum sabhāga puggalam
translated: He does not offend and is not remorseful: he commits an offense, but he seeks out a person who is a proper match for him to confess it to,

original: pariyesati, vuṭṭhāpeti vā, tasmā na vippaṭisārī hoti. Nārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hotīti
analyzed: pariyesati vuṭṭhāpeti vā tasmai na vippaṭisārī hoti na ārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hoti iti
translated: and he clears himself of it. Therefore he is not remorseful. He does not offend and is remorseful:

original: āpattiṃ nāpajjati, vinayapaññattiyaṃ pana akovidattā anāpattiyā āpattisaññitāya vuṭṭhitāyapi
analyzed: āpattim na āpajjati vinaya paññattiyam pana a kovida ttā anāpattiyā āpatti saññitāya vuṭṭhitāya api
translated: he does not commit an offense, but because he is ignorant of the rules of training, he clears himself of an offense that is not an offense.

original: taṃ āpattiyā vippaṭisāraṃ vinodetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya vippaṭisārī hoti. Nārabhati na
analyzed: tam āpattiyāḥ vippaṭisāram vinodetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya vippaṭisārī hoti na ārabhati na
translated: Because he is unable to remove his remorse over that offense, he is remorseful. He does not offend

original: vippaṭisārī hotīti nārabhati neva āpattiṃ āpajjati, na vippaṭisārī hoti. Arahattañca
analyzed: vippaṭisārī hoti iti na ārabhati na iva āpattim āpajjati na vippaṭisārī hoti arahattam ca
translated: and is not remorseful: he does not commit an offense, nor is he remorseful. But he does not reach perfection.

original: na pāpuṇāti. Kataro panesa puggaloti? Sīlavā ossaṭṭhavīriyo puggalo. So hi “kiṃ me
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti kataraḥ pana esa puggalo ti sīlavā ossaṭṭha vīriyo puggalo so hi kim me
translated: Which person is this? It is a virtuous person who is slack in effort. For he thinks,

original: imasmiṃ buddhakāle parinibbānena, anāgate metteyyasammāsambuddhakāle parinibbāyissāmī”ti
analyzed: imasmin buddha kāle parinibbānena anāgate metteyya sammāsambuddha kāle parinibbāyissāmi iti
translated: “What is the point of my attaining perfection in this dispensation? I will attain it in the future dispensation of Metteyya.”

original: visuddhasīlopi paṭipattiṃ na pūreti. Ime cattāropi puggalā tathā tathā ovaditvā āsavakkhaye
analyzed: visuddha sīlaḥ api paṭipattim na pūreti ime cattāraḥ api puggalā tathā tathā ovaditvā āsava kkhaye
translated: Although he is virtuous, he does not complete the practice. These four kinds of persons, having been instructed in this way and that,🔽reach the destruction of the taints.

original: patiṭṭhāpetabbā. Evaṃ hi tepi yvāyaṃ pañcamo puggalo nārabhati na vippaṭisārī āraddhavīriyo
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpetabbāḥ evam hi te pi yvā ayam pañcamaḥ puggalo na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī āraddha vīriyaḥ
translated: and they should be established in the right view. For this is the fifth person who does not begin, who does not regret, who has begun with energy,

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, tena samasamāva bhavissantīti.
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇāti tena samasamāḥ va bhavissanti iti
translated: They should be established in this way. For in this way they will be equal to the fifth person who does not begin, who is not remorseful, who has aroused energy, and who attains Arahantship.

original: Chakkādīsu –
analyzed: chakka ādīsu
translated: In the case of the six kinds of direct knowledge, etc.,

original: “Cha puggalā – atthekacco puggalo pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu sāmaṃ saccāni abhisambujjhati,
analyzed: cha puggalāḥ attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu sāmam saccāni abhisambujjhati
translated: “There are six persons: One person discovers for himself the truths that have not been heard before,

original: tattha ca sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇāti balesu ca vasībhāvaṃ. Atthekacco puggalo…pe… abhisambujjhati,
analyzed: tattha ca sabbaññu tam pāpuṇāti balesu ca vasībhāvam attha ekaccaḥ puggala ope abhisambujjhati
translated: and he attains omniscience and mastery of the powers. Another person … discovers for himself the truths that have not been heard before,

original: na ca tattha sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇāti, na ca balesu vasibhāvaṃ. Atthekacco puggalo…pe…
analyzed: na ca tattha sabbaññu tam pāpuṇāti na ca balesu vasi bhāvam puggala upe
translated: but he does not attain omniscience or mastery of the powers. Another person …

original: anabhisambujjhati, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti, sāvakapāramiñca pāpuṇāti.🔽Atthekacco puggalo…pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti, na ca sāvakapāramiṃ pāpuṇāti. Atthekacco
analyzed: an abhisambujjhati diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti sāvaka pāramiñca pāpuṇāti  attha ekaccaḥ puggala ope dukkhassanta karaḥ hoti na ca sāvaka pāramim pāpuṇāti attha ekacco
translated: does not discover for himself the truths that have not been heard before, but he makes an end of suffering in this very life and he reaches the perfection of a disciple.🔽Another person … makes an end of suffering in this very life, but he does not reach the perfection of a disciple. Another person …

original: puggalo…pe… anabhisambujjhati, na ca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti, anāgāmī
analyzed: puggala ope an abhisambujjhati na ca diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti anāgāmī
translated: does not discover for himself the truths that have not been heard before, nor does he make an end of suffering in this very life, but he is a non-returner.

original: hoti anāgantā itthattaṃ. Atthekacco puggalo…pe… anabhisambujjhati, na ca diṭṭheva
analyzed: hoti anāgantā itthattam attha ekacco puggala ope an abhisambujjhati na ca diṭṭhā iva
translated: there is no more of this present state of being.

original: dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti, āgāmī hoti āgantā itthatta”nti –🔽Chakkaṃ, “satta puggalā – satta udakūpamā puggalā sakiṃ nimuggo nimuggova hoti, ummujjitvā🔽nimujjati, ummujjitvā ṭhito hoti, ummujjitvā vipassati viloketi, ummujjitvā patarati,🔽ummujjitvā paṭigādhappatto hoti, ummujjitvā tiṇṇo hoti pāraṅgato, thale tiṭṭhati🔽brāhmaṇo”tiādinā sattakaṃ, “aṭṭha puggalā – cattāro maggasamaṅgino, cattāro phalasamaṅgino
analyzed: dhamme dukkhassanta karaḥ hoti āgāmī hoti āgantā itthattanti  chakkam satta puggalā satta udaka upamā puggalā sakim nimuggaḥ nimuggaḥ uva hoti ummujjitvā  nimujjati ummujjitvā ṭhitaḥ hoti ummujjitvā vipassati viloketi ummujjitvā patarati  ummujjitvā paṭigādhappattaḥ hoti ummujjitvā tiṇṇaḥ hoti pāraṅgataḥ thale tiṭṭhati  brāhmaṇa uti ādinā sattakam aṭṭha puggalā cattāro magga samaṅgino cattāro phala samaṅgino
translated: There is another person who… penetrates… and does not make an end of suffering in this very life, but is a once-returner, one who returns only once more to this world to make an end of suffering.

original: puggalā”ti aṭṭhakaṃ, “nava puggalā – sammāsambuddho paccekasambuddho ubhatobhāgavimutto🔽paññāvimutto kāyasakkhī diṭṭhippatto saddhāvimutto dhammānusārī saddhānusārī”ti navakaṃ,

item, seven kinds of persons who are not worthy of the community’s material support for special use that is particularly good and

original: “dasa puggalā – pañcannaṃ idha niṭṭhā, pañcannaṃ idha vihāya niṭṭhā”ti dasakañca🔽mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā pāḷiyaṃ niddeso kato. Tattha chakke paṭhamena padena sammāsambuddho
analyzed: dasa puggalā pañcannam idha niṭṭhā pañcannam idha vihāya niṭṭhāti dasakañca  mātikam nikkhipitvā pāḷiyam niddeso kato tattha chakke paṭhamena padena sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: “Ten persons: five are perfected here, five having departed hence are perfected” ,

original: daṭṭhabbo. So hi anācariyako attanā uppāditena sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānena arahattamaggañāṇena
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ saḥ hi an ācariyakaḥ attanā uppāditena sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhānena arahatta magga ñāṇena
translated: and he set out the Schedule of the ten. Herein, the first term in the sixfold group should be taken as the Fully Enlightened One. For he, without a teacher, by means of the footing for success consisting in his own knowledge of the path of arahatship,

original: sabbākārato saccāni abhisambujjhitvā sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇi, dasañāṇabalesu ca vasibhāvanti.
analyzed: sabba ākārataḥ saccāni abhisambujjhitvā sabbaññu tam pāpuṇi dasa ñāṇa balesu ca vasi bhāvanti
translated: realized for himself the four truths in all their aspects and reached omniscience and mastery in the ten powers of knowledge.

original: Dutiyena pana paccekasambuddho daṭṭhabbo. Tatiyena aggasāvako, catutthena avasesā
analyzed: dutiyena pana paccekasambuddhaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tatiyena aggasāvakaḥ catutthena avasesā
translated: But the second term should be taken as the Hermit Enlightened One. The third as the chief disciple. The fourth as the rest of the Arahants.

original: arahanto, pañcamena anāgāmī, chaṭṭhena sotāpannasakadāgāmino daṭṭhabbā. Te hi “āgantā
analyzed: arahanto pañcamena anāgāmī chaṭṭhena sotāpanna sakadāgāmino daṭṭhabbā te hi āgantā
translated: The fifth as the non-returners. The sixth as the stream-enterers and once-returners. For these are called “those who come back”

original: itthatta”nti vuttāti.
analyzed: itthattanti vuttā iti
translated: and “those who come back once” .

original: Sattake paṭhamena padena sāsane aniviṭṭhasaddho niyatamicchādiṭṭhidhammehi ekantakāḷakehi
analyzed: sattake paṭhamena padena sāsane a niviṭṭha saddhaḥ niyatam icchā diṭṭhi dhammehi ekanta kāḷakehi
translated: In the sevenfold group the first term should be taken as one who has no faith in the Dispensation and is definitely of entirely black kamma-proclivities with the dhammas of wrong view.

original: samannāgato gahito. So hi samudde udakabhīrukapuriso viya saṃsāre apāye nimuggo nimuggova
analyzed: samannāgataḥ gahito so hi samudde udaka bhīruka puriso viya saṃsāre apāye nimuggo nimuggaḥ uva
translated: He is like the man afraid of the water who keeps sinking in the ocean of saṃsāra and never gets out of the states of loss.

original: hoti, na puna bhavato vuṭṭhāti, anantampi kālaṃ bhave eva vicarati sāsanasamāyogābhāvā.
analyzed: na puna bhavataḥ vuṭṭhāti anantam pi kālam bhave eva vicarati sāsana samāyoga abhāvā
translated: He wanders in existence for an endless time, because he has no connection with the Dispensation.

original: Dutiyena padena sāsane paṭiladdhasaddhopi devadattādayo viya saddhādiparihāniyaṃ
analyzed: dutiyena padena sāsane devadatta ādayaḥ saddha ādi parihāniyam
translated: The second line includes the unvirtuous person who has faith in the Dispensation but is established in the state of loss of faith, etc., like Devadatta.

original: ṭhito dussīlo gahito. So hi samudde kenaci kāraṇena ummujjitvā puna nimuggo viya
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ dussīlaḥ gahitaḥ saḥ hi samudde kenacid kāraṇena ummujjitvā puna nimuggaḥ viya
translated: He is like the man who rises up in the ocean for some reason and then sinks again.

original: sāsanasaddhāya ummujjitvāpi apāye nimujjati eva, ayaṃ pana cirakālātikkamena buddhādīhi,
analyzed: sāsana saddhāya ummujjitvā api apāye nimujjati eva ayam pana cira kāla atikkamena buddha ādīhi
translated: He rises up through faith in the Dispensation but sinks again in the states of loss. But this person is to be rescued from existence by the Buddhas, etc.,

original: attanā eva vā paccekabodhiñāṇena bhavato uddharaṇīyo hoti sāsane sakiṃ uppannāyapi
analyzed: attanā eva vā pacceka bodhi ñāṇena bhavataḥ uddharaṇīyaḥ hoti sāsane sakim
translated: after the lapse of a long period, or by his own knowledge of paccekabodhi.

original: saddhāya mokkhabhāvena niyamena nibbānāvahattā. Ayameva hissa purimapuggalato viseso,
analyzed: saddhāya mokkha bhāvena niyamena nibbāna āvaha ttā ayam eva hissa purima puggalataḥ visesaḥ
translated: For even though faith has arisen in him once in the Dispensation, it does not necessarily lead to Nibbāna, because it is not irreversible. This is the difference between him and the first person.

original: itarathā tassa visuṃ gahaṇe payojanameva na siyāti gahetabbaṃ. Tatiyena sāsane uppannasaddho
analyzed: itarathā tassa visum gahaṇe payojanam eva na siyā ti gahetabbam tatiyena sāsane uppanna saddho
translated: Otherwise there would be no point in including him separately, and so he should be included. The third line includes the person who has faith in the Dispensation and is virtuous.

original: ṭhitibhāgiyehi sīlādiguṇehi samannāgato gahito. So hi ummujjitvā tīraṃ adisvāva samuddamajjhe🔽nāvādiāgamanaṃ olokento puna animujjitvā uṇṇatappadese ṭhito viya sāsanasaddhāya
analyzed: ṭhiti bhāgiyehi sīla ādi guṇehi samannāgataḥ gahitaḥ saḥ hi ummujjitvā tīram a disvā ava samudda majjhe  olokento puna a nimujjitvā uṇṇata padese ṭhitaḥ viya sāsana saddhāya
translated: He is one who has emerged by means of faith in the Dispensation, but he is not one who has seen the further shore of Nibbāna. He is like the man who, after emerging, stands in mid-stream looking at the boat, not seeing the further shore.🔽He stands in the virtues, etc., of the Dispensation.

original: ummujjitvā nibbānaṃ adisvāva buddhādiṃ olokayamāno sagge, sīlādimhi ṭhito hoti. Catutthena🔽pana sotāpanno gahito. So hi ummujjitvā ṭhito tīraṃ disvā uttaraṇūpāyaṃ vilokayamāno
analyzed: ummujjitvā nibbānam a disvā ava buddha ādim olokayamāno sagge sīla ādimhi ṭhitaḥ hoti catutthena  pana sotāpannaḥ gahitaḥ saḥ hi ummujjitvā ṭhitaḥ tīram disvā uttaraṇūpāyam vilokayamānaḥ
translated: The fourth type is the stream-enterer. He is like the man who, after emerging, stands on the bank looking for a boat.

original: viya lokuttarasaddhāya ummujjitvā nibbānatīraṃ disvā uttaraṇopāyaṃ viloketi. Pañcamena
analyzed: viya lokuttara saddhāya ummujjitvā nibbāna tīram disvā uttaraṇa upāyam viloketi pañcamena
translated: In the same way, the stream-enterer, after emerging by means of supramundane faith, looks for a boat, that is, for the means of crossing over, in the form of the path of the once-returner.

original: sakadāgāmī gahito. So hi samudde tīraṃ disvā tadabhimukhaṃ pataramāno viya paṭhamamaggena
analyzed: sakadāgāmī gahitaḥ saḥ hi samudde tīram disvā tad abhimukham pataramānaḥ viya paṭhama maggena
translated: The fifth type is the once-returner. He is like the man who, after seeing the bank, swims across to it.🔽In the same way, the once-returner, after seeing the further shore of Nibbāna by means of the first path, crosses over to it by means of the second path.

original: nibbānatīraṃ disvā tadabhimukhaṃ dutiyamaggena patarati nāma. Chaṭṭhena anāgāmī gahito.
analyzed: nibbāna tīram disvā tad abhimukham dutiya maggena patarati nāma chaṭṭhena anāgāmī gahito
translated: The sixth type is the non-returner.

original: So hi pataritvā tīraṃ upaggamma kaṭippamāṇe udake ṭhito viya arahattasamīpe satikavāṭapatitthe
analyzed: saḥ hi pataritvā tīram upaggamma kaṭippamāṇe udake ṭhitaḥ viya arahatta samīpe satika vāṭa patitthe
translated: For he stands on the bank as it were, having gone down to the water level of the arahat stage,

original: anāvattidhammatāya tatiyamaggena tiṭṭhati. Sattamena pana arahā gahito, so hi taritvā
analyzed: an āvatti dhamma tāya tatiya maggena tiṭṭhati sattamena pana arahā gahitaḥ saḥ hi taritvā
translated: and he stands there by the third path, which is the path of no more training, since it is the path that leads to no more training.

original: pāraṃ patvā ṭhitapuriso viya cattāro oghe taritvā nibbānatthale ṭhito khīṇāsavabrāhmaṇo nāma hotīti.🔽Navake ubhatobhāgavimuttoti rūpārūpasamāpattiyā vikkhambhanavimokkhena, ariyamaggena
analyzed: pāram patvā ṭhita purisaḥ viya cattāraḥ oghe taritvā nibbāna thale ṭhitaḥ khīṇāsava brāhmaṇaḥ nāma hoti iti  navake ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti rūpa arūpa samāpattiyā vikkhambhana vimokkhena ariya maggena
translated: But the seventh is the Arahant, who is called a “Brahma-farer” because he has crossed the four floods and stands on the plane of extinction of cankers, like a man who has crossed to the further bank.🔽The eighth is the one who is “liberated in both ways,” that is, liberated from both the form and formless jhāna defilements by the suppression and the severing liberations respectively.

original: samucchedavimokkhena kilesato vimutto, arūpasamāpattiyā vā rūpakāyato, maggena ca🔽nāmakāyatoti imehi ubhatobhāgehi vimuttotipi ubhatobhāgavimutto, so catunnaṃ arūpasamāpattīnaṃ
analyzed: samuccheda vimokkhena kilesataḥ vimuttaḥ arūpa samāpattiyā vā rūpa kāyataḥ maggena ca  nāma kāyataḥ ti imehi ubhatobhāgehi vimuttaḥ atipi ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ saḥ catunnam arūpa samāpattīnam
translated: Or he is liberated in both ways because he is liberated from the form body by the formless jhāna and from the mental body by the path.

original: ekekato vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattappattānaṃ catunnaṃ, nirodhā vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: ekekatas vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahatta pattānam catunnam nirodhā vuṭṭhāya
translated: He is liberated from both of these two kinds of body. He is the one who, having emerged from each of the four immaterial states, comprehends formations and attains Arahantship, and who, having emerged from the attainment of cessation, attains Arahantship.

original: arahattappattaanāgāmino ca vasena pañcavidho, tesu pacchimova nippariyāyato ubhatobhāgavimutto
analyzed: ca vasena pañcavidho tesu pacchimaḥ uva nippariyāyato ubhatobhāga vimutto
translated: and the non-returner who has reached Arahantship. Of these, the last is called “liberated in both ways” in the true sense of the phrase,

original: nāma, sesā pariyāyena. Ettha ca rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ kilesakāyato vimuttampi🔽rūpakāyato avimuttaṃ, arūpāvacaraṃ pana tadabhayatopi vimuttaṃ, tasmā tadeva pādakaṃ
analyzed: nāma sesā pariyāyena ettha ca rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam kilesa kāyataḥ vimuttam pi  rūpa kāyataḥ avimuttam arūpāvacaram pana tat abhayataḥ api vimuttam tasmā tat eva pādakam
translated: while the rest are so only in a derived sense. And here the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is liberated from defilements,

original: katvā arahattappattova ubhatobhāgavimutto hoti, na rūpāvacaranti veditabbaṃ. Paññāvimuttoti
analyzed: katvā arahatta patto va ubhatobhāga vimutto hoti na rūpa avacaranti veditabbam paññā vimutto ti
translated: but not liberated from the material body. That of the immaterial sphere is liberated from both. Therefore only one who has reached Arahantship by making that jhāna the basis for the path is “liberated in both ways” in the fine-material sphere, not in the immaterial sphere.

original: arahattamaggapaññāya āsavehi vimutto. So hi sukkhavipassako, catūhi rūpāvacarajjhānehi
analyzed: arahatta magga paññāya āsavehi vimutto so hi sukkha vipassako catūhi rūpāvacara jhānehi
translated: Liberated by understanding: liberated from defilements by means of understanding consisting in the Arahant path. He is a bare-insight worker. He is of four kinds according to the four fine-material jhānas he has emerged in,

original: vuṭṭhāya arahattappattā cattāro cāti pañcavidho. Arūpāvacarajjhānesu hi ekasmimpi
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya arahatta pattā cattāro ca ati pañcavidhaḥ arūpāvacara jhānesu hi ekasmim pi
translated: and of five kinds according to the four fine-material jhānas and the immaterial jhānas. For when he has emerged in any one of the immaterial jhānas,

original: sati ubhatobhāgavimuttova nāma hoti.
analyzed: sati ubhatobhāga vimuttā uva nāma hoti
translated: he is called “liberated in both ways.”

original: Kāyasakkhīti rūpārūpajjhānalābhī ariyo. So hi sotāpattimaggaṭṭhavajjitānaṃ channaṃ
analyzed: rūpa arūpa jjhāna lābhī ariyo so hi sotāpatti magga ṭṭha vajjitānam channam
translated: One who has a body: a noble person who has obtained the fine-material and immaterial jhānas. For when he has reached the path of stream-entry, he is called “one who has a body” since he has a material body,

original: sekhānaṃ vasena chabbidho. Teneva hissa “ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā”ti niddese vuttaṃ.🔽Sotāpattimaggaṭṭhassa ca na kecipi āsavā parikkhīṇāti vattabbā, parikkhīyissantīti
analyzed: sekhānam vasena chabbidhaḥ tena iva hi ssa ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā ti niddese vuttam  sotāpatti magga ṭṭhassa ca na kecipi āsavā parikkhīṇā ati vattabbā parikkhīyissanti iti
translated: and sixfold according to the trainers. For it is said of him in the description: “Some of his cankers are destroyed” .🔽And of one who is on the stream-entry path none at all can be said to be destroyed, but they can be said to be being destroyed;

original: pana vattabbā, arahato pana sabbepi āsavā parikkhīṇā, na ekacceti. So hi phuṭṭhantaṃ🔽sacchikarotīti kāyasakkhī, phuṭṭhānaṃ paṭiladdhānaṃ jhānānaṃ anantaraṃ nāmakāyena
analyzed: pana vattabbā arahataḥ pana sabbe pi āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ na ekaccā iti so hi phuṭṭhantam  sacchikaroti iti kāya sakkhī phuṭṭhānam paṭiladdhānam jhānānam anantaram nāmakāyena
translated: and of one who is an Arahant all can be said to be destroyed, not some.🔽He realizes what is touched, thus he is a body-witness .🔽He realizes cessation with the mental body that has obtained the jhānas, thus he is a body-witness.🔽And here the word “body” is a designation for the fruition attainment, which includes the mental body, according to what is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “He realizes ultimate truth with the mental body and sees with understanding that penetrates” .

original: nirodhaṃ sacchikarotītipi kāyasakkhī, kāyenāti cettha “nāmakāyena ceva paramatthasaccaṃ
analyzed: nirodham sacchikaroti iti pi kāya sakkhī kāyena ati ca ittha nāma kāyena ca iva paramattha saccam
translated: So some say that he is a body-witness because he realizes Nibbāna with that body next to the first jhāna.🔽One who has reached by faith is a faith devotee. And one who has reached by seeing is a Dhamma devotee. One who has reached by faith and by seeing is a faith-and-Dhamma devotee.🔽One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.

original: sacchikaroti, paññāya ca ativijjha passatī”ti vacanato arahattaphalaṃ ṭhapetvā sesamaggaphalānametaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ, tena kāyena paṭhamajjhānānantaraṃ nibbānassa sacchikaraṇatopi kāyasakkhīti
analyzed: sacchikaroti paññāya ca ativijjha passati iti vacanataḥ arahatta phalam ṭhapetvā sesa magga phalānam etam  adhivacanam tena kāyena paṭhama jhāna anantaram nibbānassa sacchikaraṇataḥ pi kāya sakkhī iti
translated: One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.🔽One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.🔽One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.🔽One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.

original: keci. Diṭṭhippattoti sukkhavipassako, rūpajjhānalābhī ca yathāvutto chabbidho sekho
analyzed: keci diṭṭhi ppatto ti sukkha vipassakaḥ rūpa jhāna lābhī ca yathā vuttaḥ chabbidhaḥ sekho
translated: One who has reached by wisdom is a Dhamma-follower. One who has reached by faith is a faith-follower. One who has reached by both is a faith-and-Dhamma-follower.🔽One who has reached by wisdom is a

original: ca, ayaṃ diṭṭhantappattoti diṭṭhippatto. Dassanaṃ diṭṭhi, paṭhamamaggo, tassa anantaraṃ
analyzed: ca ayam diṭṭhanta ppatto ti diṭṭhi ppatto dassanam diṭṭhi paṭhama maggo tassa anantaram
translated: and he is one who has reached the seen, thus he is one who has reached view . Seeing is view , the first path, and what is next to that is the seen .

original: nirodhappattoti attho. Diṭṭhappattotipi pāṭho, tassa paṭhamamaggena diṭṭhaṃ nibbānaṃ puna pattoti attho.
analyzed: nirodha ppattoti atthaḥ diṭṭha ppatto tipi pāṭho tassa paṭhama maggena diṭṭham nibbānam puna pattoti attho
translated: and he has reached the seen, thus he is a “person who has reached the seen” . Seeing is the first path. The meaning is that he has reached cessation next to that. The reading is also diṭṭhappatto, which means that he has reached nibbāna seen by the first path.

original: Saddhāvimuttoti sukkhavipassako, rūpajjhānalābhī ca yathāvutto chabbidho sekho ca.
analyzed: saddhā vimuttaḥ ti sukkha vipassakaḥ rūpa jjhāna lābhī ca yathā vuttaḥ chabbidhaḥ sekho ca
translated: “Liberated in faith” : the dry-insight worker, and the six kinds of trainee mentioned under the heading of “one who obtains jhāna in the fine-material sphere” .

original: Ayaṃ hi saddahanto vimuttoti saddhāvimutto. Kathaṃ panetassa diṭṭhippattato nānattanti?🔽Āgamanīyapaṭipadāya. Diṭṭhippatto hi paññāsampadāya pubbabhāge vipassanāya kilese
analyzed: ayam hi saddahantaḥ vimuttaḥ ti saddhā vimuttaḥ katham pana etassa diṭṭhi ppattataḥ nānattanti  āgamanīya paṭipadāya diṭṭhi ppatto hi paññā sampadāya pubbabhāge vipassanāya kilese
translated: For this person is liberated by faith, thus he is “liberated in faith” . But how is he different from one who has reached the seen?

original: appadukkhena vikkhambhento āgato, saddhāvimutto pana saddhābahulatāya kilese dukkhena
analyzed: appa dukkhena vikkhambhento āgato saddhā vimutto pana saddhā bahula tāya kilese dukkhena
translated: By the difference in the way they come. For one who has reached the seen has come by suppressing the defilements with little difficulty in the preliminary part of insight, which is the development of understanding. But one liberated in faith has come by suppressing the defilements with difficulty because of the predominance of faith.

original: vikkhambhento āgato. Etameva hi bhedaṃ sandhāya niddese “ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā
analyzed: vikkhambhentaḥ āgataḥ etam eva hi bhedam sandhāya niddese ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā
translated: For it is this very difference that is referred to in the description thus, “Some taints are destroyed,

original: honti, no ca kho yathādiṭṭhippattassā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: honti no ca kho yathā diṭṭhi ppattassa iti vuttam
translated: but not as far as reaching the seen” .

original: Dhammānusārīti yassa sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe paññindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ hoti, ayaṃ paññāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: dhamma anusārī iti yassa sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe paññindriyam adhimattam hoti ayam paññā saṅkhātena
translated: One who follows the Dhamma is he in whom the understanding faculty is outstanding at the moment of the stream-entry path. This is the person called “one who follows the Dhamma” .

original: dhammena sarati anussaratīti dhammānusārī, sotāpattimaggaṭṭhassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Phale🔽pana patte diṭṭhippatto nāma hoti. Saddhānusārīti yassa sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe saddhindriyaṃ🔽adhimattaṃ hoti, ayaṃ saddhāya sarati anussaratīti saddhānusārī, sotāpattimaggaṭṭhassetaṃ
analyzed: dhammena sarati anussarati iti dhamma anusārī sotāpatti magga ṭṭhassa etam nāmam phale  pana patte diṭṭhippatto nāma hoti saddhā anusārī iti yassa sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe saddhi indriyam  adhimattam hoti ayam saddhāya sarati anussarati iti saddhā anusārī sotāpatti magga ṭṭhassa etam
translated: One who follows the Dhamma: at the moment of the stream-enterer’s path the faculty of wisdom is outstanding. He remembers, recalls, the Dhamma called wisdom. He is therefore called one who follows the Dhamma. This is a name for the person who stands on the stream-enterer’s path. But when he has reached the fruit he is called one who has vision.

original: nāmaṃ. Phale pana patte saddhāvimutto nāma hoti.
analyzed: nāmam phale pana patte saddhāvimuttaḥ nāma hoti
translated: One who follows faith: at the moment of the stream-enterer’s path the faculty of faith is outstanding. He remembers, recalls, through faith. He is therefore called one who follows faith. This is a name for the person who stands on the stream-enterer’s path. But when he has reached the fruit he is called one liberated by faith.

original: Lokuttaradhammaṃ hi nibbattentānaṃ dve dhurāni nāma, dve abhinivesā nāma, dve sīsāni🔽nāma. Tattha saddhādhuraṃ paññādhuranti dve dhurāni nāma. Eko pana samathābhiniveso,
analyzed: lokuttara dhammam hi nibbattentānam dve dhurāni nāma dve abhinivesāḥ nāma dve sīsāni  nāma tattha saddhādhuram paññādhuranti dve dhurāni nāma ekaḥ pana samatha abhiniveso
translated: For those who generate the supramundane Dhamma, there are two kinds of burden, two kinds of clinging, and two kinds of heads.

original: eko vipassanābhinivesoti dve abhinivesā. Eko ca arahattaṃ matthakaṃ pāpuṇanto ubhatobhāgavimutto
analyzed: ekaḥ vipassanā abhiniveso ti dve abhinivesāḥ ekaḥ ca arahattam matthakam pāpuṇantaḥ ubhatobhāga vimutto
translated: Herein, the two kinds of burden are the burden of faith and the burden of wisdom. But there are two kinds of clinging, namely, clinging to serenity and clinging to insight. And there are two kinds of heads, namely, one who reaches the peak with non-return and one liberated in both ways.

original: hoti, eko paññāvimuttoti imāni dve sīsāni nāma. Ye hi keci lokuttaraṃ dhammaṃ nibbattenti,
analyzed: hoti eko paññā vimutto ti imāni dve sīsāni nāma ye hi keci lokuttaram dhammam nibbattenti
translated: and one is liberated by understanding. These are the two kinds of heads.🔽Whoever produces supramundane states, all do so by making these two things their burden, by taking their stand on these two bases,

original: sabbe te dve ime dhamme dhuraṃ katvā imesu dvīsu ṭhānesu abhinivisitvā imehi dvīhi
analyzed: sabbe te dve ime dhamme dhuram katvā imesu dvīsu ṭhānesu abhinivisitvā imehi dvīhi
translated: by being liberated by these two means.

original: ṭhānehi vimuccanti. Tesu yo bhikkhu aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī paññaṃ dhuraṃ katvā samathavasena🔽abhiniviṭṭho aññataraṃ arūpasamāpattiṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānehi vimuccanti tesu yaḥ bhikkhu aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī paññam dhuram katvā samatha vasena  abhiniviṭṭhaḥ aññataram arūpa samāpattim padaṭṭhānam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam
translated: Among them, a bhikkhu who has attained the eight attainments, who has made understanding his burden, who has taken his stand on the side of serenity,

original: pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe dhammānusārī nāma. Parato pana chasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ayam sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe dhamma anusārī nāma paratas pana chasu ṭhānesu
translated: who has begun insight by making one of the immaterial states his proximate cause, and who has reached Arahantship, is called a Dhamma-follower at the moment of the path of stream-entry. But when he has reached the fruition attainment he is called a body-witness.

original: kāyasakkhī nāma. Arahattaphalaṃ patte ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma.🔽Aparo paññameva dhuraṃ katvā vipassanāvasena abhiniviṭṭho suddhasaṅkhāre vā rūpāvacarajjhānesu
analyzed: kāyasakkhī nāma arahatta phalam patte ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma  aparo paññam eva dhuram katvā vipassanā vasena abhiniviṭṭho suddha saṅkhāre vā rūpāvacara jhānesu
translated: And when he has reached Arahantship he is called one liberated in both ways.

original: vā aññataraṃ sammasitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, ayampi sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe dhammānusārī
analyzed: vā aññataram sammasitvā arahattam pāpuṇāti ayam pi sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe dhamma anusārī
translated: Another, who has made understanding his burden, who has taken his stand on the side of insight, who has reached Arahantship by comprehending either the formations or the immaterial states, is called a Dhamma-follower at the moment of the path of stream-entry.

original: nāma. Parato pana chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhippatto nāma, arahattaṃ patte paññāvimutto nāma.
analyzed: nāma paratas pana chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhippatto nāma arahattam patte paññāvimutto nāma
translated: But one who has reached the state of Stream-Entry by the other means is called “one who has vision in six bases” . And one who has reached Arahantship is called “one freed by understanding” .

original: Aparo pana aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī saddhaṃ dhuraṃ katvā samādhivasena abhiniviṭṭho aññataraṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ pana aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī saddham dhuram katvā samādhi vasena abhiniviṭṭhaḥ aññataram
translated: Another, who has attained the eight attainments, makes faith paramount and, by means of concentration, enters upon the way to dispassion for sensuality,

original: arūpasamāpattiṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ🔽sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe saddhānusārī nāma, parato chasu ṭhānesu kāyasakkhīyeva nāma.
analyzed: arūpa samāpattim padaṭṭhānam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti ayam  sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe saddhā anusārī nāma paratas chasu ṭhānesu kāyasakkhīyā iva nāma
translated: and he reaches Arahantship by developing insight with the base consisting of the immaterial as the proximate cause. He is called

original: Arahattaṃ patte ubhatobhāgavimuttoyeva nāma. Aparo saddhameva dhuraṃ katvā vipassanāvasena
analyzed: arahattam patte nāma aparaḥ saddham eva dhuram katvā vipassanā vasena
translated: “one following faith” at the moment of Stream-Entry. But one who has reached the state of Stream-Entry by the other means is called “one who has vision in six bases” . And one who has reached Arahantship is called “one freed in both ways” .

original: abhiniviṭṭho suddhasaṅkhāre vā rūpāvacarajjhānesu vā aññataraṃ sammasitvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: abhiniviṭṭhaḥ suddha saṅkhāre vā rūpāvacara jhānesu vā aññataram sammasitvā arahattam
translated: Another, who makes faith paramount and, by means of insight, enters upon the way to dispassion for the material septad, or in the fine-material jhānas, or in the immaterial jhānas,🔽and he reaches Arahantship by developing insight with the base consisting of the immaterial as the proximate cause. He is called

original: pāpuṇāti, ayampi sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe saddhānusārī nāma, parato chasu ṭhānesu saddhāvimutto
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ayam pi sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe saddhā anusārī nāma paratas chasu ṭhānesu saddhā vimuttaḥ
translated: “one following faith” at the moment of Stream-Entry. But one who has reached the state of Stream-Entry by the other means is called “one freed by faith” .

original: nāma. Arahattappatte paññāvimutto nāma. Ime satta puggalā sammāsambuddhapaccekasambuddhehi
analyzed: nāma arahatta ppatte paññāvimuttaḥ nāma ime satta puggalā sammāsambuddha paccekasambuddhehi
translated: And one who has reached Arahantship is called “one freed by understanding” . These seven persons, namely, the six beginning with the one following faith and the one freed by faith, and the one freed by understanding, are called “those ready-signalled by the Fully Enlightened Ones and the Paccekabuddhas” .

original: saddhiṃ nava loke aggadakkhiṇeyyā nāmāti.
analyzed: saddhim nava loke aggadakkhiṇeyyāḥ nāma ati
translated: and the nine Noble Ones together with them are called the foremost in the world to be honoured with gifts.

original: Dasake pañcannaṃ idha niṭṭhāti sattakkhattuparamo, kolaṃkolo, ekabījī, sakadāgāmī🔽kāmāvacarapaṭisandhiko, arahā cāti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ idha kāmāvacarabhūmiyaññeva anupādisesanibbānasaṅkhātā
analyzed: dasake idha satta kkhattu paramaḥ kolaṃkolo eka bījī sakadāgāmī  kāmāvacara paṭisandhikaḥ arahā ca ati imesam pañcannam idha kāmāvacara bhūmi yaññā iva anupādisesa nibbāna saṅkhātā
translated: The seven-times-at-most, the clan-to-clan, the one-seed, the once-returner,🔽and the perfected being who is reborn in the sense-desire world: these five are called “those who reach the end here.”🔽The meaning is that they reach the end called “the extinction element without trace left” here in the sense-desire world.

analyzed: puggala kathā vaṇṇanā  idāni kathā vatthu mātikāya attha saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ hoti tattha anuttāna tthato tāva puggalo

analyzed: paravādī paṭiññā ti evam vibhāgam dassetvā attha vaṇṇanam karissāma  puggalaḥ upalabbhati saccikaṭṭha paramatthena ati ayam sakavādīpucchā tāya ca ye  atthi puggalo ti evaṃladdhikā puggala vādinaḥ te evam pucchitabbā iti dīpeti ke pana  te puggala vādino ti sāsane vajji puttakā ca iva sammitiyā ca bahiddhā bahū añña titthiyā
translated: He set out the Schedule by way of Thread, making it out of the questions and answers and the faults of the questions and answers and the confutations and the confutations’ refutations, etc., of the proponent and opponent. original: ca. Kadā panete sāsane uppannāti? Parinibbānato dutiye vassasate. Bhagavati kira

They are the Vajjiputtakas in the Dispensation and many sectarians outside the Dispensation. But when did they arise in the Dispensation? In the second century after the Parinibbana. It seems that in the second century after the Parinibbana, two hundred and thirty-six years after the Blessed One’s Parinibbana, the Vajjiputtakas, who were called “the Pubbaseliyas” ,
