analyzed: kāyaḥ kāya āyatananti nāma kāyaḥ citta kāyaḥ uti ādi kāyaḥ na kāya āyatanam rūpam rūpa āyatananti
translated: The body is the body base? The body of mental factors, the body of consciousness, etc., are the body, but not the body base. Materiality is the materiality base?

original: Bhūtādi, piyarūpādi ca rūpaṃva, na rūpāyatanaṃ. Saddo saddāyatananti? Āmantā. Gandho🔽gandhāyatananti? Sīlagandhādayo gandhova, na gandhāyatanaṃ. Raso rasāyatananti? Attharasādayo
analyzed: bhūta ādi ca rūpam na rūpa āyatanam saddo sadda āyatananti āmantā gandho  gandha āyatananti sīla gandha ādayaḥ gandhaḥ uva na gandha āyatanam rasaḥ rasa āyatananti attha rasa ādayaḥ
translated: The primary elements, etc., and the materiality of the form of what is loved, etc., are materiality, but not the materiality base. Sound is the sound base?🔽Odour is the odour base? The odour of virtue, etc., are odour, but not the odour base. Taste is the taste base?

original: rasova, na rasāyatanaṃ. Dhammo dhammāyatananti? Pariyattidhammādayo dhammova, na
analyzed: rasaḥ uva na rasa āyatanam dhammaḥ dhamma āyatanan ti pariyatti dhamma ādayaḥ dhammaḥ uva na
translated: Meaning-flavour, etc., are taste, but not the taste base. The mental data of the mental-data base? The mental data of the categories of the scriptures, etc., are mental data, but not the mental-data base. The mental-data base is mental data?

original: dhammāyatanaṃ. Dhammāyatanaṃ dhammoti? Āmantā”ti ayaṃ paṇṇattivāre viseso.
analyzed: dhamma āyatanam dhamma āyatanam dhammo ti āmantā ati ayam paṇṇatti vāre viseso
translated: The mental-data base is mental data” . This is the difference in the case of the exposition of the categories.

original: Pavattivāre pana “yassa cakkhāyatanaṃ uppajjati, tassa sotāyatanaṃ uppajjatīti? Sacakkhukānaṃ
analyzed: pavatti vāre pana yassa cakkhāyatanam uppajjati tassa sotāyatanam uppajjati iti sa cakkhukānam
translated: In the case of the exposition of the occurrence of the bases, however, the following is said: “When the eye base arises, does the ear base arise?

original: asotakānaṃ upapajjantānaṃ tesaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ uppajjati, no ca tesaṃ sotāyatanaṃ
analyzed: a sotakānam upapajjantānam tesam cakkhāyatanam uppajjati no ca tesam sotāyatanam
translated: In the case of those possessing eyes who are not possessed of ears and are being reborn, the eye base arises in them, but not the ear base.

original: uppajjati. Sacakkhukānaṃ sasotakānaṃ upapajjantānaṃ tesaṃ cakkhāyatanañca uppajjati,
analyzed: uppajjati sa cakkhukānam sa sotakānam upapajjantānam tesam cakkha āyatanañca uppajjati
translated: the ear-base arise. …

original: sotāyatanañca uppajjati…pe… yassa rūpāyatanaṃ uppajjati, tassa manāyatanaṃ uppajjatīti?
analyzed: sotāyatanañca uppajjati pe yassa rūpāyatanam uppajjati tassa manāyatanam uppajjati iti
translated: “When the form-base arises, does the mind-base arise?

original: Acittakānaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ uppajjati, no ca tesaṃ manāyatanaṃ uppajjati. Pañcavokāre
analyzed: acittakānam rūpa āyatanam uppajjati no ca tesam manāyatanam uppajjati pañcavokāre
translated: For those without consciousness the form-base arises, but not their mind-base.🔽In the five-constituent kind of rebirth-linking, both arise.

original: uppādakkhaṇe tadubhayaṃ uppajjati. Yassa vā pana manāyatanaṃ uppajjati, tassa rūpāyatanaṃ
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe tat ubhayam uppajjati yassa vā pana manāyatanam uppajjati tassa rūpa āyatanam
translated: “When the mind-base arises, does the form-base arise?

original: uppajjatīti? Arūpabhavavajjite saññābhave upapajjantānaṃ…pe… uppajjati. Yassa rūpāyatanaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati iti arūpa bhava vajjite saññā bhave upapajjantānaṃ pe uppajjati yassa rūpa āyatanaṃ
translated: For those being reborn in the kinds of becoming without materiality, in the kinds of becoming with perception, …🔽it arises.

original: uppajjati, tassa dhammāyatanaṃ uppajjatīti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti?🔽Arūpabhavavajjite sabbattha uppajjati. Yassa manāyatanaṃ uppajjati, tassa dhammāyatanaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati tassa dhamma āyatanam uppajjati iti āmantā yassa vā panape uppajjati iti  arūpa bhava vajjite sabbattha uppajjati yassa manāyatanam uppajjati tassa dhammāyatanam
translated: “When the form-base arises, does the mental-data base arise?🔽Yes.🔽When the mental-data base arises, does the form-base arise?🔽For those being reborn in the kinds of becoming without materiality, in all cases it arises.

original: uppajjatīti? Āmantā, yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti? Asaññabhavavajjite sabbattha
analyzed: uppajjati iti āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti asañña bhava vajjite sabbattha
translated: “When the mind-base arises, does the mental-data base arise?🔽Yes.🔽When the mental-data base arises, does the mind-base arise?🔽For those being reborn in the kinds of becoming without perception, in all cases it arises.

original: uppajjatī”ti evaṃ saddāyatanavajjitā sesāyatanamātikāyamakayojanā yathānurūpaṃ veditabbā.
analyzed: uppajjati iti evam sadda āyatana vajjitā sesa āyatana mātikā yamaka yojanā yathānurūpam veditabbā
translated: and so on. The method of interpretation of the remaining bases should be understood as appropriate in the same way, omitting the sound base.

original: Saddāyatanaṃ hi paṭisandhikkhaṇe na labbhati, ayaṃ uppādavāre viseso, iminā nayena🔽nirodhavārādīsu, pariññāvāre ca yojanāviseso veditabbo, sabbattha ca khandhato āyatanānaṃ
analyzed: saddāyatanam hi paṭisandhi khaṇe na labbhati ayam uppāda vāre visesaḥ iminā nayena  nirodha vāra ādīsu pariññā vāre ca yojanā viseso veditabbo sabbattha ca khandhataḥ āyatanānam
translated: For the sound base is not found in the rebirth-linking consciousness. This is the difference in the case of the arising section.

original: bahutā ca yamakavārabahutā ca veditabbā. Sesaṃ tādisamevāti ayaṃ āyatanayamakamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo.🔽Dhātuyamakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bahu tā ca yamaka vāra bahu tā ca veditabbā sesam tādisam evā ti ayam āyatana yamaka mātikattha saṃvaṇṇanā anayaḥ
translated: And the difference in the method of interpretation in the case of the cessation section, etc., and in the case of the section on full understanding should be understood in the same way. And in all cases the difference in the number of bases should be understood as the difference in the number of aggregates. The rest is the same in each case. This is the method of explaining the method of interpreting the matrix of the dyads on the bases.

original: Dhātuyamakamātikāya pana pāḷivavatthānaṃ sabbaṃ āyatanayamakamātikāya vuttanayeneva veditabbanti ayaṃ dhātuyamakamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo.🔽Saccayamakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhātu yamaka mātikāya pana pāḷi vavatthānam sabbam āyatana yamaka mātikāya vutta nayena iva veditabban ti ayam dhātu yamaka mātika attha saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ
translated: In the case of the matrix of the dyads on the elements, the exposition of the text should be understood in the same way as that of the matrix of the dyads on the bases. This is the method of explaining the method of interpreting the matrix of the dyads on the elements.

original: Saccayamakamātikāya pana khandhayamake vuttanayena vārabhedā, kālādibhedā ca veditabbā,
analyzed: pana khandha yamake vutta nayena vāra bhedā kāla ādi bhedā ca veditabbā
translated: In the case of the matrix of the dyads on the truths, the classification of the dyads should be understood as in the case of the dyads on the aggregates, and the classification according to time, etc., should be understood in the same way.

original: pāḷivavatthāne panettha catunnaṃ saccānaṃ vasena padasodhanavāro padasodhanamūlacakkavāro
analyzed: pāḷi vavatthāne pana ittha catunnam saccānam vasena pada sodhana vāro pada sodhana mūla cakkavāro
translated: But in the exposition of the text, the section dealing with the words of the verse is the section dealing with the words of the four truths. The section dealing with the words of the root-cause is the section dealing with the words of the four truths and the root-cause.

original: suddhasaccavāro suddhasaccamūlacakkavāroti imesu catūsu vāresu yamakagaṇanā veditabbā.
analyzed: suddha sacca vāro suddha sacca mūla cakka vāro ti imesu catūsu vāresu yamaka gaṇanā veditabbā
translated: But in the exposition of the text, the calculation of the dyads should be understood in the four sections thus: the section on the analysis of the terms according to the four truths, the section on the analysis of the terms according to the root-cause of the truths,🔽the section on the truths in isolation, and the section on the root-cause of the truths in isolation.

original: Pucchāvissajjanesu pana “dukkhaṃ dukkhasaccanti? Āmantā. Dukkhasaccaṃ dukkhanti?
analyzed: pucchā vissajjanesu pana dukkham dukkha saccanti āmantā dukkha saccam dukkhanti
translated: But in the questions and answers, the following should be noted: “Is suffering the truth of suffering? Yes. Is the truth of suffering suffering?

original: Kāyikacetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ, na dukkhaṃ. Kāyikacetasikaṃ
analyzed: kāyika cetasikam dukkham ṭhapetvā avasesam dukkha saccam na dukkham kāyika cetasikam
translated: Except for bodily and mental pain, the rest of the truth of suffering is not suffering. But bodily and mental pain

original: dukkhaṃ pana dukkhañceva dukkhasaccañca. Samudayo samudayasaccanti? Taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: dukkham pana dukkham ca iva dukkha saccam ca samudayaḥ samudaya saccanti taṇham ṭhapetvā
translated: is both suffering and the truth of suffering. Is origin the truth of origin? Except for craving,

original: avasesā saccavibhaṅge niddiṭṭhā kusalādidhammā samudayo, na samudayasaccaṃ. Taṇhā
analyzed: avasesā sacca vibhaṅge niddiṭṭhā kusala ādi dhammā samudayaḥ na samudaya saccam taṇhā
translated: the rest of the profitable, etc., states shown in the analysis of the truths is origin, but not the truth of origin. But craving

original: pana samudayo ceva samudayasaccañca. Samudayasaccaṃ samudayoti? Āmantā. Nirodho nirodhasaccanti?
analyzed: pana samudayaḥ ca iva samudaya saccam ca samudaya saccam samudayaḥ iti āmantā nirodhaḥ nirodha saccanti
translated: is both origin and the truth of origin. Is the truth of origin origin? Yes. Is cessation the truth of cessation?

original: Tadaṅganirodhādayo, khaṇikanirodho ca nirodhova, na nirodhasaccaṃ. Nibbānaṃ pana
analyzed: tad aṅga nirodha ādayo ca nirodhaḥ uva na nirodha saccam nibbānam pana
translated: Except for the cessation of the associated states, etc., and momentary cessation, the rest is cessation, but not the truth of cessation. But Nibbāna🔽is

original: nirodho ceva nirodhasaccañca. Nirodhasaccaṃ nirodhoti? Āmantā. Maggo maggasaccanti?
analyzed: nirodhaḥ ca iva nirodha saccam ca nirodha saccam nirodho ti āmantā maggaḥ magga saccanti
translated: and cessation is also the truth of cessation. Is the truth of cessation cessation? Yes. Is the path the truth of the path?

original: Micchāmaggaṅgādayo maggo, na maggasaccaṃ. Ariyamaggo pana maggo ceva maggasaccañca.
analyzed: micchāmagga ga ādayaḥ maggaḥ na magga saccam ariya maggo pana maggo ca iva magga saccam ca
translated: The factors of the wrong path, etc., are the path, but not the truth of the path. But the noble path is both the path and the truth of the path.

original: Maggasaccaṃ maggoti? Āmantā”tiādinā paṇṇattivāre nayo veditabbo.
analyzed: magga saccam maggo ti āmantā ati ādinā paṇṇatti vāre nayaḥ veditabbo
translated: Is the truth of the path the path? Yes. ” This is the method in the case of the teaching of the names.

original: Pavattivāre pana “yassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati, tassa samudayasaccaṃ uppajjatīti?🔽Sabbesaṃ upapajjantānaṃ pavatte taṇhāvippayuttacittassa uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ
analyzed: pavatti vāre pana yassa dukkha saccam uppajjati tassa samudaya saccam uppajjati iti  sabbesam upapajjantānam pavatte taṇhā vippayutta cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tesam dukkha saccam
translated: In the case of the teaching of the occurrence of the truths, the following method should be understood: “When the truth of suffering occurs, does the truth of origination occur?

original: uppajjati, no ca tesaṃ samudayasaccaṃ uppajjati. Taṇhāya uppādakkhaṇe tadubhayaṃ🔽uppajjati. Yassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati, tassa maggasaccaṃ uppajjatīti…pe… pañcavokāre
analyzed: uppajjati no ca tesam samudaya saccam uppajjati taṇhāyaḥ uppāda kkhaṇe tat ubhayam  uppajjati yassa dukkha saccam uppajjati tassa magga saccam uppajjati itipe pañcavokāre
translated: When the truth of suffering occurs in the cognitive series of those who are being reborn, at the moment of their rebirth-linking, in the course of an existence devoid of the noble path, then the truth of suffering occurs but not the truth of origination.🔽But when craving occurs at the moment of rebirth-linking, then both truths occur. When the truth of suffering occurs, does the truth of the path occur? …

original: maggassa uppādakkhaṇe tadubhayaṃ uppajjati. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti? Arūpe
analyzed: maggassa uppāda kkhaṇe tat ubhayam uppajjati yassa vā uppajjati iti arūpe
translated: At the moment of the arising of the path in the five-constituent existence, both truths occur. When the truth of suffering occurs, does the truth of the path occur? … In the immaterial existence,

original: maggassa uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ maggasaccaṃ uppajjati, no ca tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: maggassa uppāda kkhaṇe tesam magga saccam uppajjati no ca tesam dukkha saccam uppajjati
translated: At the moment of the arising of the path, the truth of the path arises in them, but the truth of suffering does not arise in them.

original: Pañcavokāre tadubhayaṃ uppajjati. Yassa samudayasaccaṃ uppajjati, tassa maggasaccaṃ
analyzed: pañcavokāre tat ubhayam uppajjati yassa samudaya saccam uppajjati tassa magga saccam
translated: In the five-constituent becoming both arise.

original: uppajjatīti? No, yassa vā pana…pe… no”tiādinā puggalavāre, “yattha dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati,🔽tattha samudayasaccaṃ uppajjatīti? Asaññasatte tattha dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati, no🔽ca tattha tadaññaṃ, aññattha tadubhayampi. Yattha dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati, tattha
analyzed: uppajjati iti no yassa vā pana pe no ti ādinā puggala vāre yattha dukkha saccaṃ uppajjati  tattha samudaya saccam uppajjati iti asañña satte tattha dukkha saccam uppajjati no  ca tattha tad aññam aññattha tad ubhayam pi yattha dukkha saccaṃ uppajjati tattha
translated: As to the section on persons, “When the truth of the origination arises in anyone, does the truth of the path arise in him too? No. Or when the truth of the path … “

original: maggasaccaṃ uppajjatīti? Apāye, asaññasatte ca dukkhameva, no ca tattha tadaññaṃ,
analyzed: magga saccam uppajjati iti apāye asañña satte ca dukkham eva no ca tattha tad aññam
translated: As to the section on the planes, “When the truth of suffering arises in any given plane, does the truth of origination arise there too? In the case of the non-percipient beings, the truth of suffering arises there, but the other truth does not. In the other planes both arise. When the truth of suffering arises in any given plane, does the truth of the path arise there too? In the case of the states of loss and the non-percipient beings, only the truth of suffering arises there, but the other truth does not. In the other planes both arise” .

original: aññattha tadubhayampī”tiādinā okāsavāre, puggalokāsavārepīti evaṃ anulomanaye,
analyzed: aññattha tat ubhayam pi itiādinā okāsa vāre puggala ukāsa vāre pi iti evam anuloma naye
translated: So too in the section on persons and planes, in the forward order,

analyzed: yassa dukkha saccam nuppajjati tassa samudaya saccam nuppajjati iti āmantā yassa
translated: “When the truth of suffering does not arise in anyone, does the truth of origination not arise in him too? Yes. Or when the truth of origination … “

original: vā pana…pe… nuppajjatīti? Sabbesaṃ upapajjantānaṃ pavatte taṇhāvippayuttacittassa
analyzed: vā pana pe nuppajjati iti sabbesam upapajjantānam pavatte taṇhā vippayutta cittassa
translated: or the truth of origination does not arise where the truth of suffering does not arise?”

original: uppādakkhaṇe samudayasaccaṃ nuppajjati, no ca tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ nuppajjati. Sabbesaṃ
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe samudaya saccam nuppajjati no ca tesam dukkha saccam nuppajjati sabbesam
translated: In the case of all who are being reborn, the truth of origination does not arise in the course of an existence in the first moment of rebirth-linking consciousness devoid of craving,

original: cavantānaṃ pavatte cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe arūpe maggassa ca phalassa ca uppādakkhaṇe🔽tesaṃ samudayasaccañca nuppajjati, dukkhasaccañca nuppajjatī”tiādinā, “yattha dukkhasaccaṃ🔽nuppajjati, tattha samudayasaccaṃ nuppajjatīti? Natthi. Yattha vā pana samudayasaccaṃ🔽nuppajjati, tattha dukkhasaccaṃ nuppajjatīti? Uppajjatī”tiādinā ca, “yassa yattha
analyzed: cavantānam pavatte cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe arūpe maggassa ca phalassa ca uppāda kkhaṇe  tesam samudaya saccam ca nuppajjati dukkha saccam ca nuppajjati itiādinā yattha dukkha saccaṃ  nuppajjati tattha samudaya saccam nuppajjati iti natthi yattha vā pana samudaya saccam  nuppajjati tattha dukkha saccam nuppajjati iti uppajjati iti ādinā ca yassa yattha
translated: but the truth of suffering does arise. And in the case of all who are dying, the truth of origination does not arise in the last moment of consciousness, nor in the immaterial sphere, nor in the arising of the path and fruition.🔽“Where the truth of suffering does not arise, does the truth of origination not arise there too? There is none. Or where the truth of origination does not arise, does the truth of suffering not arise there too? It arises.”

original: dukkhasaccaṃ nuppajjati, tassa tattha samudayasaccaṃ nuppajjatīti? Āmantā. Yassa🔽vā pana yattha samudayasaccaṃ nuppajjati, tassa tattha dukkhasaccaṃ nuppajjatīti?
analyzed: dukkha saccam nuppajjati tassa tattha samudaya saccam nuppajjati iti āmantā yassa 🔽vā pana yattha samudaya saccam nuppajjati tassa tattha dukkha saccam nuppajjati iti
translated: “In the case of those in whom the truth of suffering does not arise, does the truth of origination not arise in them too? It does not. Or in the case of those in whom the truth of origination does not arise, does the truth of suffering not arise in them too?

original: Sabbesaṃ upapajjantānaṃ pavatte taṇhāvippayuttacittassa uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ tattha🔽samudayasaccaṃ eva nuppajjati, netaraṃ, sabbesaṃ pana cavantānaṃ pavatte cittassa🔽bhaṅgakkhaṇe arūpe maggassa ca phalassa ca uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ tattha tadubhayampi
analyzed: sabbesam upapajjantānam pavatte taṇhā vippayutta cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tesam tattha  samudaya saccam eva nu pajjati na itaram sabbesam pana cavantānam pavatte cittassa  bhaṅga kkhaṇe arūpe maggassa ca phalassa ca uppāda kkhaṇe tesam tattha tat ubhayam pi
translated: At the arising moment of the consciousness accompanied by craving in the course of an existence of all who are being reborn,🔽the truth of origination arises in them there and no other. But at the death moment of the consciousness in the course of an existence of all who are dying, and at the arising moment of the immaterial path and fruition,

original: nuppajjatī”tiādinā ca sabbattha paṭilomanaye ca,
analyzed: nuppajjati itiādinā ca sabbattha paṭiloma naye ca
translated: both of these arise in them there. ” And so on in the opposite order in all cases.

original: “Yassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjittha, tassa samudayasaccaṃ uppajjitthāti? Āmantā. Yassa
analyzed: yassa dukkha saccam uppajjittha tassa samudaya saccam uppajjittha ati āmantā yassa
translated: “When the truth of suffering has arisen in anyone, has the truth of origination arisen in him? Yes.

original: dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjittha, tassa maggasaccaṃ uppajjitthāti? Abhisametāvīnaṃ uppajjittha,
analyzed: dukkha saccam uppajjittha tassa magga saccam uppajjittha ati abhisametāvīnam uppajjittha
translated: When the truth of suffering has arisen in anyone, has the truth of the path arisen in him? In one who is fully understanding, it has arisen;

original: na itaresa”ntiādinā, “yassa yattha dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjittha, tassa tattha samudayasaccaṃ
analyzed: na itaresan ti ādinā yassa yattha dukkha saccaṃ uppajjittha tassa tattha samudaya saccaṃ
translated: in one who is not, it has not. ” And so on. “When the truth of suffering has arisen in anyone, has the truth of origination arisen in him there?

original: uppajjitthāti? Suddhāvāsānaṃ dutiye citte vattamāne asaññasattānaṃ tattha dukkhasaccaṃ
analyzed: uppajjittha ati suddhāvāsānam dutiye citte vattamāne asaññasattānam tattha dukkha saccaṃ
translated: In the second consciousness in the course of an existence in the Pure Abodes, and in the immaterial beings, the truth of suffering

analyzed: uppajjittha na itaram itaresam tat ubhayam uppajjittha ati ādinā yassa dukkha saccam
translated: “Will the other’s arise? Will both of the other’s arise?”

analyzed: uppajjissati tassa samudaya saccam uppajjissati iti aggamagga samaṅgīnam arahantānam
translated: “When the truth of suffering arises, will the truth of origination arise?🔽In the case of those possessing the path of highest fruition,

original: yassa cittassa anantarā aggamaggaṃ paṭilabhissanti, tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjissati,🔽netaraṃ, itaresaṃ tadubhayaṃ uppajjissatī”tiādinā ca, “yassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: yassa cittassa anantarā aggamaggam paṭilabhissanti tesam dukkhasaccam uppajjissati  na itaram itaresam tat ubhayam uppajjissati iti ādinā ca yassa dukkha saccam uppajjati
translated: and in the case of those who will attain the path of highest fruition immediately after the present consciousness, the truth of suffering arises,🔽but not the truth of origination. In the case of the rest, both truths arise.”

original: tassa samudayasaccaṃ uppajjitthāti? Āmantā, yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti? Sabbesaṃ
analyzed: tassa samudaya saccam uppajjittha ati āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti sabbesam
translated: “When the truth of suffering arises, has the truth of origination already arisen?

original: cavantānaṃ pavatte cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe arūpe maggaphaluppattikkhaṇe tesaṃ samudayasaccaṃ🔽uppajjittha, no ca tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati. Sabbesaṃ upapajjantānaṃ pavatte
analyzed: cavantānam pavatte cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe arūpe magga phala uppatti kkhaṇe tesam samudaya saccam  uppajjittha no ca tesam dukkhasaccam uppajjati sabbesam upapajjantānam pavatte
translated: In the case of those who are dying, at the moment of the arising of the last consciousness, the truth of origination has already arisen,🔽but not the truth of suffering. In the case of those who are being reborn, at the moment of the arising of the first consciousness,🔽both truths have already arisen.”

original: cittassa uppādakkhaṇe samudayasaccañca uppajjittha, dukkhasaccañca uppajjatī”tiādinā
analyzed: cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe samudaya saccaṃ ca uppajjittha dukkha saccaṃ ca uppajjati itiādinā
translated: “When the truth of suffering arises, will the truth of origination arise?🔽In the case of those who are dying, at the moment of the arising of the last consciousness, the truth of suffering has already arisen,🔽but not the truth of origination. In the case of those who are being reborn, at the moment of the arising of the first consciousness,🔽both truths arise.”

original: ca sesakālabhedesu ca anulomapaṭilomādīsu ca vuttānusārena uppādavāre sabbattha vissajjananayo
analyzed: ca sesa kāla bhedesu ca anuloma paṭiloma ādīsu ca vutta anusārena uppāda vāre sabbattha
translated: and in the remaining sections on the past, etc., and in the sections on the order and the reverse order, etc., the method of answering should be understood as stated there.

original: yathānurūpaṃ ñātabbo. “Yassa dukkhasaccaṃ nirujjhati, tassa samudayasaccaṃ nirujjhatīti…pe…
analyzed: yathānurūpam ñātabbaḥ yassa dukkha saccam nirujjhati tassa samudaya saccam nirujjhati iti pe
translated: “When the truth of suffering ceases in anyone, does the truth of origin also cease in him? …

original: taṇhāya bhaṅgakkhaṇe tesaṃ tadubhayaṃ nirujjhatī”tiādinā nirodhavāre, uppādanirodhavārepīti
analyzed: taṇhāya bhaṅga kkhaṇe tesam tat ubhayam nirujjhati iti ādinā nirodha vāre uppāda nirodha vāre pi iti
translated: At the moment of the dissolution of craving both cease in him” .

original: evaṃ pavattivāre sabbattha yathānurūpato yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: evam pavatti vāre sabbattha yathā anurūpataḥ yojanā veditabbā
translated: So too in the section on cessation and in the section on arising and cessation.

original: Tathā “yo dukkhasaccaṃ parijānāti, so samudayasaccaṃ pajahatīti? Āmantā”tiādinā pariññāvārepīti evamettha pāḷinayo ñātabbo.
analyzed: tathā yaḥ dukkha saccam parijānāti saḥ samudaya saccam pajahati iti āmantā ati ādinā pariññā vāre pi iti evam ettha pāḷi nayaḥ ñātabbaḥ
translated: So too in the section on full-understanding: “When anyone fully understands the truth of suffering, does he abandon the truth of origin? …🔽The method should be understood here as stated in the texts.

original: Atthavinicchaye panettha idaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ – pavatti vāre tāvettha nirodhasaccaṃ na
analyzed: attha vinicchaye pana ittha idam lakkhaṇam pavatti vāre tau ettha nirodha saccam na
translated: But the characteristic here in the exposition of the meaning is this. In the first place, the truth of cessation is not found in the section on occurrence.

original: labbhateva, sesesu pana tīsu saccesu samudayamaggasaccāni ekantena pavattiyaṃ eva
analyzed: labbha tā iva sesesu pana tīsu saccesu samudaya magga saccāni ekantena pavattiyam eva
translated: But in the remaining three truths the truths of origin and of the path are only found in occurrence.

original: labbhanti. Dukkhasaccaṃ cutipaṭisandhīsupi pavattepīti evamettha yaṃ yaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: labbhanti dukkha saccam cuti paṭisandhīsu pi pavatte pi iti evam ettha yam yam sabbattha
translated: and they are found. The truth of suffering is found in death and rebirth-linking, and also in the course of an existence.

original: labbhati, tassa tassa vasena atthavinicchayo veditabbo. Tatridaṃ nayamukhaṃ – sabbesaṃ
analyzed: labbhati tassa tassa vasena attha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ tatra idam naya mukham sabbesam
translated: and the truth of suffering in the death and rebirth-linking consciousnesses. So the exposition of the meaning should be understood here in accordance with what is possible in each instance. Here is the method:

original: upapajjantānanti antamaso suddhāvāsānampi. Tepi hi dukkhasacceneva uppajjanti. Taṇhāvippayuttacittassāti
analyzed: upapajjantānam ti antamasaḥ suddhāvāsānam pi te pi hi dukkha saccena iva uppajjanti taṇhā vippayutta cittassa ati
translated: All who are being reborn: even those in the Pure Abodes, for they are reborn by means of the truth of suffering. In a mind without craving:

original: idaṃ dukkhasaccasamudayasaccesu ekakoṭṭhāsassa uppattidassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: idam dukkha sacca samudaya saccesu eka koṭṭhāsassa uppatti dassana tham vuttam tasmā
translated: this is said in order to show the arising of one part of the truth of suffering and the truth of the origin. So it should be taken only as fivefold.

original: pañcavokāravaseneva gahetabbaṃ. Catuvokāre pana taṇhāvippayuttaphalasamāpattiyā uppādakkhaṇe
analyzed: pañcavokāra vasena iva gahetabbam catuvokāre pana taṇhā vippayutta phala samāpattiyāḥ uppāda kkhaṇe
translated: But in the case of the fourfold, not even one truth arises at the moment of arising of the fruition attainment without craving.

original: ekampi saccaṃ nuppajjati. Tadubhayanti dukkhasamudayasaccadvayaṃ. Tasmiṃ hi khaṇe
analyzed: ekam pi saccam nuppajjati tat ubhayanti dukkha samudaya sacca dvayam tasmin hi khaṇe
translated: Both of those: the two truths of suffering and of the origin. For at that moment

original: taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā sesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ nāma hotīti taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Maggassa uppādakkhaṇe
analyzed: taṇham ṭhapetvā sesam dukkhasaccam nāma hoti iti tam sandhāya itam vuttam maggassa uppāda khaṇe
translated: what is called the truth of suffering is all except craving. That is what is meant. At the moment of arising of the path

original: pana rūpameva dukkhasaccaṃ nāma, sesā maggasahajātā dhammā saccavinimuttāva. Teneva
analyzed: pana rūpam eva dukkha saccam nāma sesāḥ magga sahajātāḥ dhammāḥ sacca vinimuttāḥ ava tena iva
translated: But only materiality is called the truth of suffering; the rest of the states associated with the path are not included in any truth. That is why

original: kāraṇena “arūpe maggassa uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ maggasaccaṃ uppajjati, no ca tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ🔽uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ. Sabbesaṃ upapajjantānaṃ pavatte taṇhāvippayuttacittassa uppādakkhaṇe.
analyzed: kāraṇena arūpe maggassa uppāda kkhaṇe tesam magga saccam uppajjati no ca tesam dukkha saccam  uppajjati iti vuttam sabbesam upapajjantānam pavatte taṇhā vippayutta cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe
translated: it is said: “At the moment of arising of the path in the immaterial sphere, the truth of the path arises in them, but the truth of suffering does not arise in them” .🔽In the course of an existence, at the moment of the arising of the mind without lust.

original: Tesaṃ tatthāti tesaṃ tasmiṃ upapattikkhaṇe taṇhāvippayuttacittuppattikkhaṇe cāti
analyzed: tesam tattha ati tesam tasmin upapatti khaṇe taṇhā vippayutta citta uppatti khaṇe ca ati
translated: “In them there” means in them at the moment of rebirth-linking and at the moment of the arising of the mind without lust.

original: evamettha khaṇavasena okāso veditabbo. Aññesupi evarūpesu eseva nayo. Anabhisametāvīnanti
analyzed: evam ettha khaṇa vasena okāsaḥ veditabbo aññesu pi evarūpesu esā iva nayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here “as to occasion.” The same method of explanation applies also in the other cases. “Who have not yet discerned” :

original: anabhisamitasaccānanti iminā nayamukhena sabbattha atthavinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā naya mukhena sabbattha attha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: who have not yet discerned the truths. The exposition should be understood in this way in all the remaining cases.

original: Pariññāvāre pana ñātatīraṇapahānavasena tissopi pariññāyo labbhanti. Yasmā pana lokuttaradhammesu
analyzed: pariññā vāre pana ñāta tīraṇa pahāna vasena tissaḥ api pariññāyaḥ labbhanti yasmā pana lokuttara dhammesu
translated: But in the section on full understanding, the three kinds of full understanding come into consideration, that is to say, full understanding as the known, as investigation, and as abandoning . But since the supramundane states are not to be abandoned,

original: pariññānāma natthi, tasmā idha dve eva saccāni gahitāni. Tattha “dukkhasaccaṃ parijānātī”ti
analyzed: pariññā nāma natthi tasmai idha dve eva saccāni gahitāni tattha dukkha saccam parijānāti iti
translated: There is no full-understanding of them, and so only two Truths are stated here. Herein, he fully understands the Truth of Suffering means

original: ñātatīraṇapariññāvasena vuttaṃ, “samudayasaccaṃ pajahatī”ti ñātapahānapariññāvasena,
analyzed: ñāta tīraṇa pariññā vasena vuttam samudaya saccam pajahati iti ñāta pahāna pariññā vasena
translated: by the full-understanding as investigation and as abandoning. He abandons the Truth of Origin means by the full-understanding as investigation and as abandoning.

original: iti imāsaṃ pariññānaṃ vasena sabbattha attho veditabbo. Ayaṃ saccayamakamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo.
analyzed: iti imāsam pariññānam vasena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam sacca yamaka mātika ttha saṃvaṇṇanā anayaḥ
translated: So the meaning should be understood in each instance according to these full-understandings. This is the method of explaining the meaning of the dyad of Truths.

original: Saṅkhārayamakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅkhāra yamaka mātikattha vaṇṇanā
translated: The dyad of determinations

original: Saṅkhārayamakamātikāya pana heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva mahāvārantarādibhedā veditabbā.🔽Ayaṃ panettha viseso – mātikāya tāva yathā heṭṭhā khandhādayo dhamme uddisitvā “rūpaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra yamaka mātikāya pana heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva mahā vāra antara ādi bhedā veditabbā  ayam pana ittha visesaḥ mātikāya tāva yathā heṭṭhā khandha ādayaḥ dhamme uddisitvā rūpam
translated: In the dyad of determinations the divisions beginning with the Great References should be understood in the way already stated .🔽But there is this difference here. In the Schedule, instead of beginning with the words “Form is an idea” ,

original: rūpakkhandho”tiādinā padasodhanavāro āraddho, tathā anārabhitvā “assāsapassāsā kāyasaṅkhāro”tiādinā
analyzed: rūpa kkhandhaḥ tiādinā pada sodhana vāro āraddho tathā an ārabhitvā assāsa passāsā kāya saṅkhāraḥ iti ādinā
translated: as in the case of the dyad of the aggregates, etc., the exposition is begun straight away with the words “In-breath and out-breath are a determination of body” ,

original: paṭhamaṃ tayopi saṅkhārā vibhajitvā dassitā. Tattha kāyassa saṅkhāro kāyasaṅkhāro,
analyzed: paṭhamam tayo api saṅkhārāḥ vibhajitvā dassitā tattha kāyassa saṅkhāro kāya saṅkhāro
translated: and the three determinations are shown by dividing them up thus. Herein, a determination of the body is a determination of body ;

original: assāsapassāsā. “Kāyikā ete dhammā kāyapaṭibaddhā”ti vacanato kāraṇabhūtassa karajakāyassa🔽phalabhūto esa saṅkhāroti kāyasaṅkhāro. Aparo nayo – saṅkharīyatīti saṅkhāro. Kena🔽saṅkharīyati? Kāyena. Ayaṃ hi vāto viya bhastāya karajakāyena saṅkharīyati, evampi
analyzed: assāsa passāsā kāyikāḥ ete dhammāḥ kāya paṭibaddhā ati vacanataḥ kāraṇa bhūtassa karaja kāyassa  phala bhūtaḥ esa saṅkhāraḥ iti kāya saṅkhāraḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ saṅkharīyati iti saṅkhāraḥ kena  saṅkharīyati kāyena ayam hi vātaḥ bhastāya karaja kāyena saṅkharīyati evam pi
translated: In-breath and out-breath. Since it is said, “These states are bodily, bound up with the body” , it is a formation of the body because it is the fruit of the bodily kamma that is its cause. Another method: it is a formation because it is formed by the body .🔽By what is it formed? By the body. For this is formed by the bodily kamma that is its cause, as the wind is formed by the bellows.🔽

original: kāyassa saṅkhāroti kāyasaṅkhāro, kāyena kato assāsapassāsavātoti attho. Cetasā vitakketvā🔽vicāretvā pacchā vācaṃ bhindati, tasmā “vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhāro”ti vacanato pana🔽saṅkharotīti saṅkhāro, kiṃ saṅkharoti? Vaciṃ. Vaciyā saṅkhāroti vacīsaṅkhāro, vacībhedasamuṭṭhāpakassa
analyzed: kāyassa saṅkhāro ti kāya saṅkhāro kāyena kataḥ assāsa passāsa vāto ti attho cetasā vitakketvā  vicāretvā pacchā vācam bhindati tasmā vitakka vicārāḥ vacanataḥ pana  saṅkharoti iti saṅkhāro kim saṅkharoti vacim vaciyā saṅkhāro iti vacī saṅkhāro vacī bheda samuṭṭhāpakassa
translated: In-breath and out-breath. “These states are bodily, bound up with the body” , and so this is a formation in the sense of a result of the bodily formation that is the cause. Another method: it is formed , thus it is a formation . By what is it formed? By the body. For this in-breath and out-breath is formed by the bodily formation, which is like a bellows, thus it is a bodily formation. The meaning is: the in-breath and out-breath formed by the body. Another method: after thinking with the mind and exploring with the mind, one then breaks into speech. And since it is said, “Thinking and exploring are verbal formations” ,

original: vitakkavicāradvayassetaṃ nāmaṃ. “Saññā ca vedanā ca cetasikā ete dhammā cittapaṭibaddhā”ti
analyzed: vitakka vicāra dvayassa etam nāmam saññā ca vedanā ca cetasikāḥ ete dhammāḥ citta paṭibaddhā ati
translated: it is a formation in the sense of forming. What does it form? Speech. It is a formation of speech, thus it is a verbal formation. This is a name for the pair, thinking and exploring, that causes the arising of speech. “Perception and feeling are mental states, bound up with the mind” , and so this is a formation in the sense of a result of the mental formation that is the cause.

original: vacanatoyeva pana tatiyapade saṅkharīyatīti saṅkhāro, kena saṅkharīyati? Cittena,
analyzed: vacanatoyā iva pana tatiya pade saṅkharīyati iti saṅkhāraḥ kena saṅkharīyati cittena
translated: But in the third case the word is formed by adding the suffix -a to saṅkhāra and then adding the suffix -o to the compound, thus: saṅkhāra + o = saṅkhāro. By what is it made to occur? By consciousness.

original: iti cittassa saṅkhāroti cittasaṅkhāro, sabbesampi cittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ cetasikānaṃ
analyzed: iti cittassa saṅkhāro ti citta saṅkhāro sabbesam pi citta samuṭṭhānānam cetasikānam
translated: So it is a “mental formation” in the sense that it is a formation of consciousness. It is a term for all the states classed as mental factors.

original: dhammānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vitakkavicārānaṃ pana vacīsaṅkhārabhāvena visuṃ gahitattā
analyzed: dhammānam etam adhivacanam vitakka vicārānam pana vacī saṅkhāra bhāvena visum
translated: But applied thought and sustained thought are included separately as verbal formations.

original: “ṭhapetvā vitakkavicāre”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Idāni “kāyo kāyasaṅkhāro”ti padasodhanavāro āraddho, tassa anulomanaye tīṇi, paṭilomanaye🔽tīṇīti cha yamakāni. Padasodhanamūlacakkavāre ekekasaṅkhāramūlakāni dve dve katvā🔽anulomanaye cha, paṭilomanaye chāti dvādasa yamakāni. Suddhasaṅkhāravāre pana yathā
analyzed: ṭhapetvā vitakka vicāre iti vuttam  idāni kāyaḥ kāya saṅkhāro ti pada sodhana vāro āraddho tassa anuloma naye tīṇi paṭiloma naye  tīṇi iti cha yamakāni pada sodhana mūla cakkavāre ekeka saṅkhāra mūlakāni dve dve katvā  anuloma naye paṭiloma naye cha ati dvādasa yamakāni suddha saṅkhāra vāre pana yathā
translated: So “excluding applied and sustained thought” is said.

original: suddhakhandhavārādīsu “rūpaṃ khandho, khandhā rūpa”ntiādinā nayena yamakānivuttāni,
analyzed: suddha khandha vāra ādīsu rūpam khandhaḥ khandhāḥ rūpa nti ādinā nayena
translated: Now, the section on the analysis of the terms “body” and “mental-formation body” has been introduced. In the forward order there are three yokes, and in the reverse order there are three yokes, making six yokes. In the wheel-revolving method of analysis there are two yokes for each root formation, making six yokes in the forward order and six in the reverse order, making twelve yokes. But in the section on the mere formations, the yokes are stated in the same way as in the mere aggregates, etc., thus: “Material form is a category, categories are material form,” etc.

original: evaṃ “kāyo saṅkhāro, saṅkhārā kāyo”ti avatvā “kāyasaṅkhāro vacīsaṅkhāro”tiādinā nayena🔽kāyasaṅkhāramūlakāni dve, vacīsaṅkhāramūlakaṃ ekanti anulome tīṇi, paṭilome tīṇīti🔽cha yamakāni vuttāni. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Suddhikaekekapadavasena atthabhedābhāvato, kāyasaṅkhāroti
analyzed: evam avatvā kāyaḥ saṅkhāraḥ saṅkhārā kāyaḥ iti avatvā kāya saṅkhāraḥ vacī saṅkhāraḥ iti ādinā nayena  kāya saṅkhāra mūlakāni dve vacī saṅkhāra mūlakam ekanti anulome tīṇi paṭilome tīṇi iti  cha yamakāni vuttāni kim kāraṇā suddhika ekeka pada vasena attha bheda abhāvato kāya saṅkhāraḥ ti
translated: he says “bodily formation, verbal formation,” etc.,🔽and thus he states three yokes in the forward order and three in the reverse order, making six yokes.🔽Why? Because there is no difference in meaning by way of the individual terms.

original: pana dvīhipi padehi ekova attho labbhatīti ayaṃ visesova, tasmā ekekapadavasena na
analyzed: pana dvīhi pi padehi ekaḥ iva atthaḥ labbhati iti ayam visesaḥ uva tasmai ekeka pada vasena na
translated: But the meaning of the two terms “bodily formation” is the same, so this is the only difference. Therefore it is not stated by way of the individual terms.

original: vuttaṃ, “kāyo kāyasaṅkhāro”tiādi pana vattabbaṃ siyā, sopi nayo padasodhanavāre vināpi🔽atthena vacanaṃ yujjatīti tattheva vutto, idha pana kāyasaṅkhārādīnaṃ vacīsaṅkhārādīhi
analyzed: vuttam kāyaḥ kāya saṅkhāraḥ ti ādi pana vattabbam siyā saḥ api nayaḥ pada sodhana vāre vinā api  atthena vacanam yujjati iti tattha iva vuttaḥ idha pana kāya saṅkhāra ādīnam vacī saṅkhāra ādīhi
translated: But it might be argued that it should be stated thus: “The body is a bodily formation,” etc.🔽But that method is applicable even without any meaning in the case of the word-derivation, so it is stated there.

original: aññattā “kāyasaṅkhāro vacīsaṅkhāro”tiādināpi yamakāni vuttāni. Suddhasaṅkhāramūlacakkavāro
analyzed: aññattā kāya saṅkhāro vacī saṅkhāro ti ādinā api yamakāni vuttāni suddha saṅkhāra mūla cakkavāro
translated: But here the yokes are stated thus: “bodily formation, verbal formation,” etc., because the bodily formation, etc., are different from the verbal formation, etc.

original: panettha na gahitoti ayaṃ tāvettha pāḷivavatthāne viseso.
analyzed: pana ittha na gahitaḥ iti ayam tāva ettha pāḷi vavatthāne visesaḥ
translated: The wheel-reversal by way of the formations alone is not taken up here. This, firstly, is the difference in the text.

original: Pañhavissajjanesu pana “kāyo kāyasaṅkhāroti? No, kāyasaṅkhāro kāyoti? No”ti vā evaṃ🔽sabbattha paṭisedho. Vissajjanānaṃ kāyādīnaṃ eva kāyasaṅkhārādināmattā. Na hi kāyādayo
analyzed: pañha vissajjanesu pana kāyaḥ kāya saṅkhāro ti no kāya saṅkhāro kāyo ti no ti vā evam  sabbattha paṭisedhaḥ vissajjanānam kāya ādīnam eva kāya saṅkhāra ādi nāma attāḥ na hi kāya ādayaḥ
translated: “No,”🔽is a denial in every case.🔽The answers are given in terms of the bodily formation, etc., themselves, not in terms of body, etc.,

original: viya kāyasaṅkhārādīnaṃ nāmaṃ hoti, paṭilome pana na kāyo na kāyasaṅkhāroti yo kāyo
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāra ādīnam nāmam hoti paṭilome pana na kāyaḥ na kāya saṅkhāro ti yaḥ kāyaḥ

analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ evam ettha sabba vāresu tiṇṇam tiṇṇam yamakānam vasena yamaka gaṇanā veditabbā
translated: This is how the reckoning of the yokes should be understood here in all the sections by means of the three yokes in each case.

original: Atthavinicchaye panettha idaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ – imasmiṃ hi saṅkhārayamake “assāsapassāsānaṃ🔽uppādakkhaṇe, vitakkavicārānaṃ uppādakkhaṇe”tiādivacanato paccuppannādikālabhedo
analyzed: attha vinicchaye pana ittha idam lakkhaṇam imasmin hi saṅkhāra yamake assāsa passāsānam  uppāda kkhaṇe vitakka vicārānam uppāda kkhaṇa iti ādi vacanataḥ paccuppanna ādi kāla bhedaḥ
translated: But the definition here in the exposition of the meaning is this. For in this section on the yokes of formations, the distinction of time as present, etc.,🔽can be taken by occurrence as well as by death and rebirth-linking, since it is said, “At the moment of the arising of in-breaths and out-breaths, at the moment of the arising of applied and sustained thought” , etc.

original: pavattivasenāpi gahetabbo, na cutipaṭisandhivaseneva. “Dutiyajjhāne tatiyajjhāne
analyzed: pavatti vasena api gahetabbaḥ na cuti paṭisandhi vasena iva dutiya jhāne tatiya jhāne
translated: In the second jhāna, in the third jhāna,

original: tattha kāyasaṅkhāro uppajjatī”tiādivacanato ca jhānampi okāsavasena gahitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha kāya saṅkhāro uppajjati iti ādi vacanato ca jhānam pi okāsa vasena gahitan ti veditabbam
translated: and because of the words, “Herein, bodily formation arises,” it should be understood that the jhāna is included by way of the physical basis.

original: Evamettha yaṃ yaṃ labbhati, tassa tassa vasena atthavinicchayo veditabbo. Tatridaṃ
analyzed: evam ettha yam yam labbhati tassa tassa vasena attha vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: So the exposition should be understood here according to what is possible in each instance.

original: nayamukhaṃ – “vinā vitakkavicārehī”ti dutiyatatiyajjhānavasena vuttaṃ, na catutthajjhānavasena🔽tattha assāsapassāsānaṃ abhāvato. “Cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe”ti idaṃ kāyasaṅkhārassa
analyzed: naya mukham vinā vitakka vicārehi iti dutiya tatiya jhāna vasena vuttam na catuttha jhāna vasena  tattha assāsa passāsānam abhāvato cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe ti idam kāya saṅkhārassa
translated: Here is the method: “Without thinking and without exploring” is said with reference to the second and third jhānas, not with reference to the fourth jhāna,🔽because in the fourth jhāna there is no in-breath and out-breath.🔽“At the moment of the dissolution of the mind” is said because the bodily formation is a resultant only of consciousness;

original: ekantacittasamuṭṭhānattā vuttaṃ, uppajjamānameva hi cittaṃ rūpaṃ, arūpaṃ vā samuṭṭhāpeti,🔽na bhijjamānaṃ, ṭhitaṃ vā. “Pacchimacittasamaṅgīna”nti sabbapacchimena appaṭisandhikacittena
analyzed: ekanta citta samuṭṭhāna ttā vuttam uppajjamānam eva hi cittam rūpam arūpam vā samuṭṭhāpeti  na bhijjamānam ṭhitam vā pacchima citta samaṅgīnam ti sabbapacchimena appaṭisandhika cittena
translated: for it is only arising consciousness that generates materiality, not that which is dissolving or has done so, nor that which is present.🔽“One who is possessed of the last kind of consciousness” is one who is possessed of the last kind of consciousness that is not destined to reappear.

original: samaṅgīnaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ. “Avitakkaavicāraṃ pacchimacitta”nti ettha rūpāvacarānaṃ
analyzed: samaṅgīnam khīṇa āsavānam a vitakka a vicāram ettha rūpa avacarānam
translated: “The last kind of consciousness that is without thinking and exploring” is that of those of the fine-material sphere.

original: dutiyajjhānikādicuticittavasena, arūpāvacarānañca catutthajjhānikacuticittavasena attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: dutiya jjhānika ādi cuti citta vasena arūpāvacara ānam ca catuttha jjhānika cuti citta vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: and the meaning should be taken as the death consciousness of the fine-material sphere, and so on, and as the death consciousness of the fourth jhāna of the immaterial sphere.

original: “Yassa kāyasaṅkhāro nirujjhati, tassa cittasaṅkhāro nirujjhatī”ti ettha niyamato
analyzed: yassa kāya saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati tassa citta saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati iti ettha niyamato
translated: As regards the question, “When the bodily formation ceases, does the mental formation cease? ” the answer is given

original: kāyasaṅkhārassa cittasaṅkhārena saddhiṃ ekakkhaṇe nirujjhanato “āmantā”ti paṭivacanaṃ
analyzed: kāya saṅkhārassa citta saṅkhārena saddhim eka khaṇe nirujjhanataḥ āmantā ati paṭivacanam
translated: in the affirmative because the bodily formation ceases together with the mental formation in one moment.

original: dinnaṃ na ekacittakkhaṇikattā. Cittasaṅkhāro hi kāyasaṅkhārena vināpi uppajjati ca🔽nirujjhati ca. Kāyasaṅkhāro pana cittasamuṭṭhānattā yena cittena saddhiṃ uppajjati,🔽tato paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhiṃ nirujjhati, esā cittasamuṭṭhānarūpassa dhammatā.🔽Yaṃ pana vibhaṅgappakaraṇassa sīhaḷaṭṭhakathāya “cittasamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ sattarasamacittassa
analyzed: dinnam na eka citta khaṇika ttā citta saṅkhāraḥ hi kāya saṅkhārena vinā api uppajjati ca  nirujjhati ca kāya saṅkhāraḥ pana citta samuṭṭhāna ttā yena cittena saddhim uppajjati  tatas paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhim nirujjhati esā citta samuṭṭhāna rūpassa dhamma tā  yam pana vibhaṅga ppakaraṇassa sīhaḷaṭṭhakathāya citta samuṭṭhāna rūpam satta rasama cittassa
translated: But it is not because of the fact that they are in one moment only. For the mental formation arises and ceases without the bodily formation,🔽but the bodily formation arises together with a certain consciousness and ceases with the seventeenth. This is the nature of materiality originated by consciousness.

original: uppādakkhaṇe nirujjhatī”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati. “Yassa kāyasaṅkhāro
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe nirujjhati iti vuttam tam imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati yassa kāya saṅkhāro
translated: But what is said in the Sinhalese Commentary on the Vibhaṅga, namely, that “materiality originated by consciousness ceases at the moment of arising of the seventeenth consciousness,” is contradicted by this sutta.

original: uppajjati, tassa vacīsaṅkhāro nirujjhatī”ti ettha yasmā kāyasaṅkhāro cittassa uppādakkhaṇe
analyzed: uppajjati tassa vacī saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati iti ettha yasmā kāya saṅkhāro cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe
translated: For the bodily determinations arise at the moment of the arising of the thought,

original: uppajjati, na ca tasmiṃ khaṇe vitakkavicārā nirujjhanti, tasmā “no”ti paṭisedho kato.
analyzed: uppajjati na ca tasmin khaṇe vitakka vicārāḥ nirujjhanti tasmā no ti paṭisedho kato
translated: and at that moment applied thought and sustained thought have not ceased. That is why the denial “No” is stated.

original: Iminā nayamukhena sabbattha vinicchayo veditabbo. Ayaṃ saṅkhārayamakamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo.
analyzed: iminā naya mukhena sabbattha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam saṅkhāra yamaka mātikattha saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ
translated: The exposition should be understood in this way in all instances. This is the method of explanation in the case of the dyad of determinations.

original: Anusayayamakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The dyad of underlying tendencies

original: Anusayayamakamātikāya pana pāḷivavatthānaṃ tāva evaṃ veditabbaṃ. Anusayayamakepi
analyzed: anusaya yamaka mātikāya pana pāḷi vavatthānam tāva evam veditabbam anusaya yamake pi
translated: As to the dyad of underlying tendencies, the exposition of the text should be understood as follows.🔽In the dyad of underlying tendencies, too, the text is taught by a method different from that in the dyads of aggregates, etc.,

original: khandhayamakamātikādīsu viya desanaṃ akatvā aññena nayena pāḷidesanā katā. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: khandha yamaka mātikā ādīsu viya desanam a katvā aññena nayena pāḷi desanā katā katham
translated: without a teaching in the way beginning “In one who is subject to lust for sensual desires” . How?

original: Paṭhamaṃ tāva paricchedavāro paricchinnuddesavāroti dve vārā uddesavasena desitā,
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva dve vārāḥ uddesa vasena desitā
translated: First of all, the section on delimitation is taught by two sections, namely, the section on delimitation and the section on the meaning of the terms.

original: tato uppattiṭṭhānavāroti eko khuddakavāro. Tato anusayavāro sānusayavāro pajahanavāro
analyzed: tatas uppatti ṭṭhāna vāro ti ekaḥ khuddaka vāro tatas anusaya vāro sa anusaya vāro pajahana vāro
translated: Then the short section on the source of the underlying tendency. Then the section on the underlying tendency, the section on the underlying tendency and associatedness, the section on abandoning,

original: pariññāvāro pahīnavāro uppajjanavāro dhātuvāroti anusaye yojetvā yamakavasena papañcato
analyzed: pariññā vāro pahīna vāro uppajjana vāro dhātu vāro ti anusaye yojetvā yamaka vasena papañcato
translated: The section on full-understanding, the section on abandoning, the section on arising, and the section on elements,🔽are to be construed with the underlying tendencies.

original: niddiṭṭhā satta mahāvārāti aṭṭhakaniddesavasena desitā, evaṃ dasahi vārehi anusayayamakadesanā
analyzed: niddiṭṭhā satta mahāvārā ati aṭṭhaka niddesa vasena desitā evam dasahi vārehi anusaya yamaka desanā
translated: The teaching of the underlying tendencies and the dyads is done by means of these ten sections.

original: katā. Tesu ye ime hi paricchedavārotiādinā dve vārā uddesavasena vuttā, te idha anusayayamakamātikāti gahetabbā.
analyzed: katā tesu ye ime hi pariccheda vāra uti ādinā dve vārāḥ uddesa vasena vuttā te idha anusaya yamaka mātikā ati gahetabbā
translated: Of these, the two sections called “The section on delimitation” and so on, which are stated by way of the summary verses, should be taken here as the “mother” of the dyads on the underlying tendencies.

original: Tattha hi satta anusayāti ayaṃ gaṇanāya paricchinditvā anusayānaṃ desitattā paricchedavāro🔽nāma. Kāmarāgānusayo…pe… avijjānusayoti ayaṃ paricchedavasena paricchinnānaṃ nāmamattaṃ
analyzed: tattha hi satta anusayā ti ayam gaṇanāya paricchinditvā desita ttā pariccheda vāro  nāma ayam pariccheda vasena ayam
translated: For in the case of the “section on delimitation” the underlying tendencies are taught by delimiting them by means of a count, thus: “There are seven underlying tendencies” .🔽The “section on delimitation and indication” is so called because the mere names of the underlying tendencies delimited by delimitation are stated by way of indication, thus: “The underlying tendency to lust … the underlying tendency to ignorance” .

original: uddisitvā “ime nāma te”ti desitattā paricchinnuddesavāro nāma. Tattha anuttānatthato
analyzed: uddisitvā ime nāma te ti desita ttā paricchinnuddesavāraḥ nāma tattha anuttānatthato
translated: Herein, firstly, as to meaning of non-excess:

original: tāva anusayāti kenaṭṭhena anusayā? Anusayanaṭṭhena. Ko esa anusayanaṭṭho nāmāti?
analyzed: anusayā ti kena ṭṭhena anusayāḥ anusayana ṭṭhena kaḥ esa anusayana ṭṭhaḥ nāma ati
translated: What is the meaning of underlying tendency? It is underlying tendency in the sense of underlying. What is this underlying in the sense of underlying?

original: Appahīnaṭṭho. Kāmarāgānusayādayo hi appahīnaṭṭhena tassa tassa santāne anusenti nāma,
analyzed: appahīna ṭho kāma rāga anusaya ādayaḥ hi appahīna ṭṭhena tassa tassa santāne anusenti nāma
translated: The meaning of “lying in wait” is this. The underlying tendencies of lust, etc., lie in wait in the sense of not being abandoned in the various continua .

original: tasmā “anusayā”ti vuccanti, anusentīti ca taṃ taṃ anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantīti
analyzed: tasmai vuccanti anusenti iti ca tam tam anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti
translated: Therefore they are called “underlying tendencies” . And the meaning of “lying in wait” is that of occurring when a suitable object is encountered.

original: attho. Athāpi siyā – anusayanaṭṭho nāma appahīnākāro, appahīnākāro ca na uppajjati,
analyzed: attho atha api siyā anusayanaṭṭho nāma appahīna ākāro appahīna ākāro ca na uppajjati
translated: But it might be argued that the meaning of “lying in wait” is the mode of non-abandonment, and that mode of non-abandonment does not occur,

original: tasmā anusayā na uppajjantīti. Tatridaṃ paṭivacanaṃ – appahīnākāro anusayo, anusayoti
analyzed: tasmai anusayāḥ na uppajjanti iti tatra idam paṭivacanam appahīna ākāraḥ anusayaḥ anusayo ti
translated: so the underlying tendencies do not occur. The answer to that is this. The mode of non-abandonment is an underlying tendency,

original: pana appahīnaṭṭhena thāmagatakileso vuccati, so cittasampayutto sārammaṇo sappaccayaṭṭhena
analyzed: pana appahīna ṭṭhena thāma gata kileso vuccati so citta sampayuttaḥ sa ārammaṇaḥ sa paccaya ṭṭhena
translated: but an underlying tendency is said to be a defilement that has not been abandoned. And that is associated with consciousness, and it is a condition for the object in the sense of object condition.

original: sahetuko ekantākusalova hoti kathāvatthusmiṃ anusayānaṃ cittavippayuttabhāvassa paṭisedhitattā,
analyzed: sa hetukaḥ ekanta akusalaḥ u va hoti kathā vatthusmim anusayānam citta vippayutta bhāvassa paṭisedhita ttā
translated: It is a cause, and it is wholly unprofitable. For in the Description of Terms it is denied that the underlying tendencies are dissociated from consciousness.

original: so ca atītopi hoti, anāgatopi paccuppannopi, tasmā uppajjatīti vattuṃ yuttaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: saḥ ca atītaḥ api hoti anāgataḥ pi paccuppannaḥ api tasmai uppajjati iti vattum yuttam tathā
translated: And that underlying tendency is in the past, future, and present. Therefore it is proper to say that it occurs.

original: hi dhammasaṅgahe mohassa padabhājane 317 “avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ…pe… ayaṃ
analyzed: hi dhamma saṅgahe mohassa pada bhājane avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam pe ayaṃ
translated: For in the Description of Terms in the Dhammasanganī, in the analysis of delusion, it is said: “The underlying tendency to ignorance, the manifestation of ignorance …🔽This is called

original: tasmiṃ samaye moho hotī”ti. Imasmiñca yamake uppajjanavāre “yassa kāmarāgānusayo🔽uppajjati, tassa paṭighānusayo uppajjatī”tiādi vuttaṃ, tasmā “anusentīti taṃ taṃ
analyzed: tasmin samaye mohaḥ hoti iti imasmin ca yamake uppajjana vāre yassa kāma rāga anusayo  uppajjati tassa paṭigha anusayaḥ uppajjati itiādi vuttam tasmai anusenti iti tam tam
translated: and at that time delusion is present.

original: anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantī”ti yaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ suvuttanti veditabbaṃ. Kāmarāgānusayoti
analyzed: anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti yat vuttam tat su vuttam ti veditabbam kāma rāga anusayaḥ ti
translated: And in the case of the pair of questions on arising, it is said: “When the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure arises in a man, does the underlying tendency to resistance arise in him too? ” and so on. So it should be understood that what was said above, namely, “They underlie by following after, ” is well said, since they arise when they get a corresponding reason.

original: kāmarāgo ca so appahīnaṭṭhena anusayo cāti kāmarāgānusayo. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.🔽Ayaṃ tāvettha anuttānattho. Atthavinicchayo panetthāpi niddesanayamukhadassanavaseneva
analyzed: kāma rāgo ca so appahīna ṭṭhena anusayo ca ati kāma rāga anusayo sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo  ayam tāva ettha anuttāna atthaḥ attha vinicchayaḥ pana itthā api niddesa naya mukha dassana vasena iva
translated: The underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure: lust for sensual pleasure is an underlying tendency in the sense of not being abandoned. The same method applies in the other cases.🔽This, firstly, is the meaning of “underlying tendency.”

original: hoti, niddeso cettha heṭṭhā vutto.
analyzed: hoti niddesaḥ ca ittha heṭṭhā vutto
translated: The exposition should be understood here as given in the Description of the Dependent Origination.

original: Uppattiṭṭhānavārādayo aṭṭha vārā ca, tatrāyaṃ pāḷivavatthānānupubbikāmukhamattappakāsanā.
analyzed: uppatti ṭṭhāna vāra ādayaḥ aṭṭha vārā ca tatra ayam pāḷi vavatthāna anupubbikā mukha matta ppakāsanā
translated: The eight sections beginning with that on arising and the basis are given there in the method of the Description.🔽The exposition there is as follows:

original: Tesaṃ hi paṭhamo anusayānaṃ uppattiṭṭhānavāro nāma. Tattha vārabhedo yamakayojanavāre
analyzed: tesam hi paṭhamaḥ uppattiṭṭhānavāraḥ nāma tattha vāra bhedaḥ yamaka yojana vāre
translated: The first section is called that on the arising and the basis of the underlying tendencies. Herein, the classification of the sections is as follows:

original: natthi, itaresu pana sattasu mahāvāresu atthi. Tesu hi paṭhamo anusayavāro anulomapaṭilomanayavasena
analyzed: natthi itaresu pana sattasu mahāvāresu atthi tesu hi paṭhamaḥ anusayavāraḥ anuloma paṭiloma naya vasena
translated: But in the other seven great divisions it is. Herein, the first, the Division of Underlying Tendencies, is twofold as the Direction-Along-the-Tendencies Direction and the Direction-Against-the-Tendencies Direction.

original: duvidho hoti. Tattha anulomanaye “yassa yattha…pe… anusetī”ti puggalokāsatadubhayanāmavasena
analyzed: duvidhaḥ hoti tattha anuloma naye yassa anuseti iti puggala ukāsa tad ubhaya nāma vasena
translated: Herein, in the Direction-Along-the-Tendencies Direction there are three intermediate divisions called the Person Direction, the World Direction, and the Both Directions,

original: tayo antaravārā honti, tesu ekekasmiṃ ekamūlakadvimūlakatimūlakacatumūlakapañcamūlakachamūlakānaṃ
analyzed: tayaḥ antaravārāḥ honti tesu ekekasmin ekamūlaka dvimūlaka timūlaka catumūlaka pañcamūlaka chamūlakānam
translated: in each of which there are dyads classed according to the single root, the double root, the treble root, the quadruple root, the quintuple root, and the sextuple root.

original: vasena yamakabhedā honti. Yathā ca anulomanaye, evaṃ paṭilomanayepi veditabbā. Yathā🔽cettha anusayavāre, evaṃ sānusayavārapajahanavārapariññāvārapahīnavārauppajjanavāresu🔽pañcasupi. Ayaṃ panettha purimesu tīsu vāresu viseso. Okāsavāre “yattha tatthā”ti
analyzed: vasena yamaka bhedāḥ honti yathā ca anuloma naye evam paṭiloma naye pi veditabbāḥ yathā  ca ittha anusaya vāre evam sa anusaya vāra pajahana vāra pariññā vāra pahīna vāra uppajjana vāresu  pañcasu pi ayam pana ittha purimesu tīsu vāresu visesaḥ okāsa vāre yattha tattha ati
translated: And as in the Direction-Along-the-Tendencies Direction, so in the Direction-Against-the-Tendencies Direction.🔽And as in the case of the Division of Underlying Tendencies, so in the case of the five divisions beginning with the Division of Possessions and ending with the Division of Arising.

original: avatvā “yato tato”ti nissakkavacanena desanā katā. Sesaṃ tādisameva. Yo panāyaṃ sabbapacchimo
analyzed: a vatvā yatas tatas ti nissakka vacanena desanā katā sesam tādisam eva yaḥ pana ayam sabba pacchimo
translated: But there is this difference. In the case of the first three divisions the teaching is given in the Place Direction without the words “wherever … there” , but with the words “from wherever … there” , which are in the ablative case. The rest is the same. But in the case of the last division,

original: dhātuvāro nāma, so pucchāvāro vissajjanavāroti dvidhā ṭhito. Tattha pucchāvāro anulomapaṭilomavasena
analyzed: dhātuvāraḥ nāma so pucchāvāraḥ vissajjanavāro ti dvidhā ṭhitaḥ tattha pucchāvāraḥ anuloma paṭiloma vasena
translated: The chapter is called “The Elements” and it stands in two parts, namely, the question part and the answer part. Herein, the question part is twofold, in forward order and in reverse order.

original: duvidho. Tassāvasāne pucchānukkamena vissajjanaṃ katanti. Evaṃ tāvettha pāḷivavatthānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: duvidhaḥ tassa avasāne puccha anukkamena vissajjanam katan ti evam tāva ettha pāḷi vavatthānam veditabbam
translated: The answer is given in the same order as the questions. This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known here “as to text. ”

original: Tatridaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ vārānaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya mukhamattadassanaṃ. “Kattha kāmarāgānusayo🔽anuseti? Kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu ettha kāmarāgānusayo anuseti. Kattha paṭighānusayo🔽anuseti? Dukkhāya vedanāya…pe… mānānusayo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā🔽arūpadhātuyā ca anuseti. Diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo ca sabbasakkāyapariyāpannesu
analyzed: āditas paṭṭhāya mukha matta dassanam kattha kāma rāga anusayo  anuseti kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu ettha kāma rāga anusayaḥ anuseti kattha paṭigha anusayaḥ  anuseti dukkhāya māna anusayo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu rūpadhātuyā  arūpa dhātuyā ca anuseti diṭṭha anusayaḥ vicikicchā anusayaḥ ca sabba sakkāya pariyāpannesu
translated: Herein, the following is a mere indication of the face of the text of the first chapter, beginning with the question,

original: dhammesu, bhavarāgānusayo rūpārūpadhātūsu, avijjānusayo sabbasakkāyapariyāpannesu
analyzed: dhammesu bhava rāga anusayo rūpa arūpa dhātūsu avijjā anusayo sabba sakkāya pariyāpannesu
translated: “Where does the underlying tendency to lust underlie? It underlies in the sense-desire element and in the two kinds of feeling. Where does the underlying tendency to resistance underlie? It underlies in painful feeling. Where does the underlying tendency to conceit underlie? It underlies in the sense-desire element and in the two kinds of feeling, and it underlies in the fine-material and immaterial elements. Where does the underlying tendency to views underlie? It underlies in all ideas included in personality view. Where does the underlying tendency to craving for being underlie? It underlies in the fine-material and immaterial elements. Where does the underlying tendency to ignorance underlie? It underlies in all ideas included in personality view” .

original: dhammesu anusetī”ti ayaṃ tāva paṭhamavāre pāḷinayo.
analyzed: dhammesu anuseti iti ayam tāva paṭhama vāre pāḷinayo
translated: This is the text of the first chapter.

original: Tattha kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsūti kāmāvacarabhūmiyaṃ sukhāya ceva upekkhāya cāti
analyzed: tattha kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu iti kāmāvacara bhūmiyam sukhāya ca iva upekkhāya ca ati
translated: Herein, in the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element: in the sense-desire-element plane there are two kinds of feeling, namely, pleasant and equanimous.

original: dvīsu vedanāsu, kāmarāgānusayo pana sahajātavasena, ārammaṇavasena cāti dvīhākārehi🔽anuseti uppajjati, tattha akusalāhi sukhaupekkhāhi sahajātopi hutvā tā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: dvīsu vedanāsu kāma rāga anusayaḥ pana sahajāta vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca ati dvīhākārehi  anuseti uppajjati tattha akusalāhi sukha aupekkhāhi sahajātaḥ api hutvā tāḥ ārammaṇam
translated: But the underlying tendency to lust for sense desires underlies in two ways, namely, as conascence and as object.🔽It arises in the two kinds of feeling, namely, unwholesome pleasant and equanimous feeling, both as conascence and as object.

original: katvāpi uppajjati. Avasesā pana kāmāvacarakusalavipākakiriyavedanā ārammaṇameva katvā
analyzed: katvā api uppajjati avasesā pana kāmāvacara kusala vipāka kiriya vedanā ārammaṇam eva katvā
translated: But the rest of the sense-desire-element’s wholesome, resultant, and inoperative feelings arise only as object.

original: uppajjati, imāsu vedanāsu anusayamāno cesa tāhi vedanāhi sampayuttesu saññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇesupi🔽anusetiyeva. Imāsaṃ pana vedanānaṃ assādaṭṭhena kāmarāgānusayuppattiyā sesasampayuttehi
analyzed: uppajjati imāsu vedanāsu anusayamānaḥ ca isa tāhi vedanāhi sampayuttesu saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇesu pi  imāsam pana vedanānam assāda ṭṭhena kāma rāga anusaya uppattiyā sesa sampayuttehi
translated: When it underlies in these kinds of feeling, it underlies also in the perception, formations, and consciousness associated with those feelings.

original: padhānattā, oḷārikattena veneyyānaṃ subodhattā ca dvīsu vedanāsuyeva anusetīti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: padhāna ttā oḷārika ttena veneyyānam su bodha ttā ca dvīsu vedanāsu yā iva anuseti iti vuttam
translated: But it underlies only in the two kinds of feeling because of the predominance of the associated states in the occurrence of the underlying tendency to lust for sense desires as the gratification of those feelings, and because of the ease with which the disciples understand it in its gross form.🔽So too above.

original: evaṃ uparipi. Na kevalañcesa anusayamāno imāsu dvīsu vedanāsuyeva, vedanāsampayuttesu
analyzed: evam upari pi na kevalam ca isa anusayamānaḥ imāsu dvīsu vedanāsu yā iva vedanā sampayuttesu
translated: Not only does it underlie in these two kinds of feeling, but also in the associated states.

original: dhammesu ca anuseti, iṭṭhesu pana rūpādīsupi anuseti eva. Vuttampi cetaṃ vibhaṅgappakaraṇe
analyzed: dhammesu ca anuseti iṭṭhesu pana rūpa ādīsu pi anuseti eva vuttam pi ca itam vibhaṅga pakaraṇe
translated: And it lies latent in the kinds of form, etc., that are agreeable. For this is said in the Vibhaṅga:

original: “yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, ettha sattānaṃ kāmarāgānusayo anusetī”ti, etthānusayayamakepi🔽vuttaṃ “dukkhāya vedanāya rūpadhātuyā ettha kāmarāgānusayo nānusetī”tiādi. Etena🔽vuttāvasesarūpādīsu chasupi ārammaṇesu anusetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Idha pana taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: yam loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam ettha sattānam kāma rāga anusayaḥ anuseti iti ettha anusaya yamake pi  vuttam dukkhāya vedanāya rūpa dhātuyā ettha kāma rāga anusayaḥ na anuseti itiādi etena  vutta avasesa rūpa ādīsu chasu pi ārammaṇesu anuseti iti vuttam hoti idha pana tat sabbam
translated: “In the world, what is the form that is agreeable and what is the feeling that is agreeable? Herein, the underlying tendency to lust lies latent in beings with respect to that” . And in the section on underlying tendencies it is said:

original: avatvā kiñcideva padhānattādinā kāraṇena vuttanti gahetabbaṃ.🔽Dukkhāyāti ettha paṭighacittasampayuttā dve domanassavedanā, kāyaviññāṇasampayuttā
analyzed: a vatvā kiñcid eva padhāna tta ādinā kāraṇena vuttan ti gahetabbam  dukkhāya ti ettha paṭigha citta sampayuttā dve domanassa vedanā kāya viññāṇa sampayuttā
translated: “In painful feeling, in the form element, the underlying tendency to lust does not lie latent” , and so on. By this it is said that it lies latent in the remaining six objects of the underlying tendency to lust, that is, in the kinds of form, etc., mentioned above. But here all that is omitted and only some is mentioned, for some reason of emphasis, etc.

original: dukkhavedanā cāti tisso vedanā, taṃ sampayuttā ca dhammā, aniṭṭhā cha rūpādayo dhammā
analyzed: dukkha vedanā ca ati tissaḥ vedanā tam sampayuttā ca dhammā aniṭṭhāḥ cha rūpa ādayo dhammā
translated: In painful feeling: here the two kinds of grief associated with the receiving consciousness and the painful feeling associated with body-consciousness are the three kinds of feeling. The states associated with them and the six kinds of unloveliness beginning with the unlovely form are the objects of the underlying tendency to aversion, either as conascent or as object.

original: paṭighānusayasahajātavasena, ārammaṇavasena ca yathārahaṃ anusayanaṭṭhānaṃ. Kiṃ pana
analyzed: paṭigha anusaya sahajāta vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca yathāraham anusayana ṭṭhānam kim pana
translated: But what is the reason for the omission of the unlovely sound, etc., here?

original: itarā dve vedanā iṭṭhārammaṇaṃ vā paṭighassa ārammaṇaṃ na hontīti? No na honti. Parihīnajjhānassa
analyzed: itarā dve vedanā iṭṭha ārammaṇam vā paṭighassa ārammaṇam na honti iti no na honti parihīna jhānassa

original: hi naṭṭhaṃ iṭṭhaṃ sasampayuttadhammaṃ jhānamārabbha domanassaṃ uppajjati, taṃ pana
analyzed: hi naṭṭham iṭṭham sa sampayutta dhammam jhānam ārabbha domanassam uppajjati tam pana
translated: For when a man has lost his jhāna, sorrow arises in him about the pleasant object consisting in the jhāna together with its associated states,🔽but that is only an object, not a state of being an object by being a proximate cause.

original: ārammaṇamattameva, nānusayanaṭṭhānaṃ iṭṭhattā. Aniṭṭhameva hi iṭṭhato paṭihanananimittaṃ,
analyzed: ārammaṇa mattam eva na anusayana ṭhānam iṭṭhattā aniṭṭham eva hi iṭṭhataḥ paṭihanana nimittam

original: yaṃ pana tatthuppannaṃ, tassa paṭighamattameva hoti, na paṭighānusayoti. Paṭighānusayo

original: hi aniṭṭhārammaṇe paṭihananavasena uppanno thāmagato kileso, itaro domanassena saddhiṃ

analyzed: uppannaḥ api attanaḥ paṭihanana kiccassa a karaṇataḥ paṭigha anusayaḥ na hoti abbohārika ttam

original: gacchati. Yathā hi pāṇātipātacetanāya saddhiṃ uppannopi byāpādo manokammaṃ nāma na

original: hoti, abbohārikattaṃ gacchati, evanti gahetabbaṃ. Teneva nekkhammassitaṃ domanassaṃ
analyzed: hoti abbohārika ttam gacchati evam ti gahetabbam tena iva nekkhammassitam domanassam
