translated: How should it be taken? As to unabandonment.

original: hi sandhāya ayaṃ anusetīti vattamānavohāro vutto, na khaṇapaccuppannataṃ, tasmā imissā🔽pucchāya yassa kāmarāgānusayo appahīno, na anuppattidhammataṃ āpādito, tassa paṭighānusayo
analyzed: hi sandhāya ayam anuseti iti vattamāna vohāraḥ vuttaḥ na khaṇa paccuppanna tam tasmā imissā  pucchāya yassa kāma rāga anusayaḥ appahīnaḥ na anuppatti dhamma tam āpādito tassa paṭigha anusayo
translated: For the expression “occurs” is used here in the sense of unabandonment, not in the sense of occurrence in one moment.🔽Therefore the meaning of this question is this: “If lust is unabandoned in a given person, then so too is hate unabandoned in him;

original: appahīno, na anuppattidhammataṃ āpādito, tassa paṭighānusayo appahīnoti evamattho
analyzed: appahīnaḥ na anuppatti dhamma tam āpādito tassa paṭigha anusayaḥ appahīnaḥ ti evamattho
translated: if hate is unabandoned in him, then so too is lust unabandoned in him.”

original: gahetabbo. Yasmā ca tesu kāmarāgapaṭighesu yasseko appahīno, tassa itaropi appahīnova
analyzed: gahetabbaḥ yasmā ca tesu kāma rāga paṭighesu yassa ikaḥ appahīno tassa itaraḥ api appahīnaḥ va
translated: And since when one of these two, lust for sense desires and resentment, is unabandoned, the other is unabandoned too,🔽therefore it was said, “Friends, I will instruct you about abandoning and about what is subject to destruction. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: hoti, tasmā “āmantā”ti vuttaṃ. Ito paresupi evarūpesu uppajjativārādivissajjanesu
analyzed: hoti tasmai āmantā ati vuttam itas paresu pi evarūpesu uppajjati vāra ādi vissajjanesu
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the other sections beginning with the section on “arising.”🔽Three persons: the worldling, the stream-enterer, and the once-returner.

original: eseva nayo. Tiṇṇaṃ puggalānanti puthujjanasotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃ. Dvinnanti sotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃ.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tiṇṇam puggalānam ti puthujjana sotāpanna sakadāgāmīnam dvinnam ati sotāpanna sakadāgāmīnam
translated: Two: the stream-enterer and the once-returner.

original: Evaṃ uppajjanaṃ dīpitaṃ. Okāsavārassa paṭhamadutiyapucchāsu yasmā kāmarāgapaṭighā🔽ekacitte na uppajjanti, tasmā “no”ti paṭisedho kato. Dukamūlādīsu ca yasmā kāmarāgapaṭighādayo
analyzed: evam uppajjanam dīpitam okāsa vārassa paṭhama dutiya pucchāsu kāma rāga paṭighā  ekacitte na uppajjanti tasmā no ti paṭisedho kataḥ duka mūla ādīsu ca kāma rāga paṭigha ādayo
translated: Thus the arising is shown.🔽In the first and second questions of the section on the occasion, since lust for sense desires and resentment do not arise in a single consciousness,

original: ekasmiṃ ṭhānasaṅkhāte citte, ārammaṇe vā na uppajjanti, tasmā “natthī”ti tattha paṭikkhepo
analyzed: ekasmin ṭhāna saṅkhāte citte ārammaṇe vā na uppajjanti tasmā na atthi iti tattha paṭikkhepaḥ
translated: the denial “No” is given. And since lust for sense desires, etc., do not arise in a single consciousness called an “occasion” or in a single object,🔽the denial “There is none” is given in the section on the roots of dispute, etc.🔽The intention is that the questions are new.

original: kato, ayaṃ pucchā apubbā evāti adhippāyo. Puggalokāsavāre catunnanti puthujjanasotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmīnaṃ.
analyzed: kataḥ ayam pucchā apubbā evā ti adhippāyo puggala ukāsa vāre catunnam ti puthujjana sa utāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmīnam
translated: Four: the worldling, the stream-enterer, the once-returner, and the non-returner.

original: Paṭilome dvinnanti anāgāmiarahante sandhāya vuttanti ayaṃ anusayavāre nayo.
analyzed: paṭilome anāgāmi arahante sandhāya vuttanti ayam anusaya vāre nayo
translated: “In the opposite way, in two” is said with reference to the non-returner who is without lust. This is the method in the section on underlying tendencies.

original: Sānusayavāre pana “yo kāmarāgānusayena sānusayo, so paṭighānusayena sānusayoti? Āmantā…pe…🔽mānānusayena sānusayoti? Āmantā. Yo vā pana mānānusayena sānusayo, so kāmarāgānusayena
analyzed: sa anusaya vāre pana yaḥ kāma rāga anusayena sa anusayaḥ saḥ paṭigha anusayena sa anusayaḥ iti āmantāpe  māna anusayena sa anusayaḥ iti āmantā yaḥ vā pana māna anusayena sa anusayaḥ saḥ kāma rāga anusayena
translated: But in the section on underlying tendencies, “Is he who is with the underlying tendency of lust also with the underlying tendency of hate? Yes, he is. …🔽Is he who is with the underlying tendency of conceit also with the underlying tendency of lust? Yes, he is. …

original: sānusayoti? Anāgāmī mānānusayeneva, na kāmarāgānusayena, tayo pana puggalā tadubhayenāpi
analyzed: sa anusayaḥ ti anāgāmī māna anusayena iva na kāma rāga anusayena tayo pana puggalā tad ubhayena api
translated: Or is he who is with the underlying tendency of lust also with the underlying tendency of conceit? The non-returner is with the underlying tendency of conceit but not with the underlying tendency of lust. But the three persons are with both underlying tendencies. ”

original: anusayenā”ti iminā nayena sesesu dukamūlādīsu pucchāvissajjananayo ñātabbo, ayaṃ puggalavāre nayo.🔽“Yato kāmarāgānusayena sānusayo, tato paṭighānusayena sānusayoti? No…pe… mānānusayena
analyzed: anusayena ati iminā nayena sesesu duka mūla ādīsu pucchā vissajjana nayaḥ ñātabbaḥ ayam puggala vāre nayo  yatas kāma rāga anusayena sa anusayaḥ tatas paṭigha anusayena sa anusayaḥ iti no upe māna anusayena
translated: In this way the method of the questions and answers should be known in the remaining dyads beginning with the underlying tendency of conceit. This is the method in the section on persons.🔽“From which he is with the underlying tendency of lust he is also with the underlying tendency of hate? No. …

original: sānusayoti? Āmantā. Yato vā pana mānānusayena sānusayo, tato kāmarāgānusayena sānusayoti?
analyzed: sa anusayaḥ iti āmantā yatas vā pana māna anusayena sa anusayaḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayena sa anusayaḥ iti
translated: From which he is with the underlying tendency of conceit he is also with the underlying tendency of lust? Yes, he is. …

original: Rūpārūpadhātuyā mānānusayeneva, netarena, kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu tadubhayenāpī”tiādinā okāsavāre ca,
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhātuyāḥ māna anusayena iva na itarena kāmadhātuyāḥ dvīsu vedanāsu tad ubhayena api iti ādinā okāsa vāre ca
translated: In the section on the plane of existence, “In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas there is only the underlying tendency to conceit, not the others. In the sense-sphere dhammas there is both in the case of the two kinds of feeling” .🔽In the section on the person and the plane of existence, “One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of hate, is he? No” .

original: “Yo yato kāmarāgānusayena sānusayo, so tato paṭighānusayena sānusayoti? No”tiādinā🔽puggalokāsavāre cāti evaṃ anulomanaye ca, “yo kāmarāgānusayena niranusayo, so paṭighānusayena
analyzed: yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayena sa anusayaḥ saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayena sa anusayaḥ iti na uti ādinā  puggala ukāsa vāre ca ati evam anuloma naye ca yaḥ kāma rāga anusayena niranusayaḥ saḥ paṭigha anusayena
translated: In the section on the underlying tendencies in the reverse order, “One who is without the underlying tendency of lust is also without the underlying tendency of hate, is he? Yes” .🔽The method of the questions and answers should be understood in all instances according to the method of the forward order in the section on the underlying tendencies.🔽Herein, “One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of hate, is he? No” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of conceit, is he? Yes” .

original: niranusayoti? Āmantā”tiādinā paṭilomanayepi sabbattha anusayavāre vuttānusārato pucchāvissajjananayo ñātabbo.🔽Tattha yato kāmarāgānusayena sānusayoti yato kāraṇato uppannena kāmarāgānusayena
analyzed: niranusayaḥ ti āmantā ati ādinā paṭiloma naye pi sabbattha anusaya vāre vutta anusārato pucchā vissajjana nayaḥ ñātabbaḥ  tattha yatas kāma rāga anusayena sa anusayaḥ ti yatas kāraṇataḥ uppannena kāma rāga anusayena
translated: “One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the false view of individuality, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the false view of holding to rules and observances, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of becoming, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of craving for becoming, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of craving for non-becoming, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of craving for annihilation, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of annihilation, is he? Yes” .🔽“One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of annihilationism, is he? Yes” .

original: sānusayo, kiṃ so tato kāraṇato uppannapaṭighānusayenapi sānusayoti vuccati. Yasmā🔽panete dve ekasmā ṭhānā na uppajjanti, tasmā “no”ti paṭisedho kato sesaṃ tādisamevāti
analyzed: sa anusayaḥ kim saḥ tatas kāraṇataḥ uppanna paṭigha anusayena api sa anusayaḥ ti vuccati yasmā  pana ete dve ekasmā ṭhānā na uppajjanti tasmā no ti paṭisedho kataḥ sesam tādisam eva ati
translated: “One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view of eternalism, is he? Yes” .

original: ayaṃ sānusayavāre nayo.
analyzed: ayam sa anusaya vāre
translated: “One who is with the underlying tendency of lust is also with the underlying tendency of the view

analyzed: pajahana vāre pana yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam pajahati saḥ paṭigha anusayam pajahati iti āmantāpe  māna anusayam pajahati iti tat ekaṭṭham pajahati yaḥ vā pana māna anusayam pajahati saḥ
translated: But in the section on abandoning, “Does he who abandons the underlying tendency to lust abandon the underlying tendency to aversion? He may or he may not. …

original: kāmarāgānusayaṃ pajahatīti? No…pe… so diṭṭhānusayaṃ vicikicchānusayaṃ pajahatīti?🔽No. Yo vā pana vicikicchānusayaṃ pajahati, so kāmarāgānusayaṃ pajahatīti? Tadekaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam pajahati iti na upe saḥ diṭṭha anusayam vicikicchā anusayam pajahati iti  no yaḥ vā pana vicikicchā anusayam pajahati saḥ kāma rāga anusayam pajahati iti tat ekaṭṭham
translated: Does he who abandons the underlying tendency to conceit abandon the underlying tendency to lust? He abandons the one that is abandoned by that path. But does he who abandons the underlying tendency to lust abandon the underlying tendency to conceit? He may or he may not. … Does he who abandons the underlying tendency to conceit abandon the underlying tendency to false view? … the underlying tendency to uncertainty?

original: pajahati. Yo…pe… bhavarāgānusayaṃ avijjānusayaṃ pajahatīti? Tadekaṭṭhaṃ pajahati…pe…
analyzed: pajahati bhava rāga anusayam avijjā anusayam pajahati iti tat ekaṭṭham
translated: He may or he may not. But does he who abandons the underlying tendency to uncertainty abandon the underlying tendency to conceit? He abandons the one that is abandoned by that path. … Does he who abandons the underlying tendency to conceit abandon the underlying tendency to lust? … the underlying tendency to aversion? … the underlying tendency to the lust for non-existence? … the underlying tendency to ignorance? He abandons the one that is abandoned by that path. …

original: yo kāmarāgānusayañca paṭighānusayañca mānānusayañca…pe… pajahatīti? Natthī”tiādinā puggalavāre,
analyzed: yaḥ kāma rāga anusayañca paṭigha anusayañca māna anusayañca pe pajahati iti natthi itiādinā puggala vāre
translated: Does he who abandons the underlying tendency to lust and the underlying tendency to aversion and the underlying tendency to conceit … abandon the underlying tendency to ignorance? There is none who abandons thus.” In the section on persons,

analyzed: yatas kāma rāga anusayam pajahati tatas paṭigha anusayam pajahati iti na upe yatas kāma rāga anusayam
translated: “When he abandons the underlying tendency to lust, does he then abandon the underlying tendency to aversion? He may or he may not. … When he abandons the underlying tendency to lust,

analyzed: pajahati tatas māna anusayam pajahati iti āmantā yatas vā pana māna anusayam pajahati
translated: does he then abandon the underlying tendency to conceit? He may or he may not. But when he abandons the underlying tendency to conceit,

analyzed: tatas kāma rāga anusayam pajahati iti rūpa a rūpa dhātuyā tatas māna anusayam eva kāmadhātuyā
translated: and then the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires? In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas, only the underlying tendency to conceit; in the sensual-desire element,

analyzed: dvīsu vedanāsu tatas māna anusayam okāsa vāre ca  yaḥ yatas kāma rāga anusayam pajahati saḥ tatas paṭigha anusayam pajahati iti na upe māna anusayam  pajahatīti tat ekaṭṭham vicikicchā anusayam pajahatīti no yaḥ vā pana
translated: and then the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires? In the fine-material and immaterial dhammas he abandons only the underlying tendency to conceit, but in the two kinds of feeling in the sense sphere he abandons the underlying tendency to conceit and the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires. ”

original: yato vicikicchānusayaṃ pajahati, so tato kāmarāgānusayaṃ pajahatīti? Aṭṭhamako dukkhāya🔽vedanāya rūpārūpadhātuyā so tato vicikicchānusayaṃ pajahati, no ca so tato kāmarāgānusayaṃ🔽pajahati, sveva puggalo kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu so tato vicikicchānusayaṃ pajahati,
analyzed: yatas vicikicchā anusayam pajahati so tatas kāma rāga anusayam pajahati iti aṭṭhamakaḥ dukkhāya  vedanāya rūpa a rūpa dhātuyā saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayam pajahati no ca saḥ tatas kāma rāga anusayam  pajahati su eva puggalaḥ kāmadhātuyā dvīsu vedanāsu saḥ tatas vicikicchā anusayam pajahati
translated: And in the section on the faculties, in the passage beginning, “When someone abandons the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires by the contemplation of reflection, does he then abandon the underlying tendency to aversion? … the underlying tendency to conceit? … the underlying tendency to lust for existence? … the underlying tendency to wrong view? … the underlying tendency to uncertainty? … the underlying tendency to ill will? … the underlying tendency to stiffness? … the underlying tendency to agitation? … the underlying tendency to ignorance? ”

original: kāmarāgānusayaṃ tadekaṭṭhaṃ pajahatī”tiādinā puggalokāsavāre cāti evaṃ anulomanaye
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayam tad ekaṭṭham pajahati itiādinā puggala ukāsa vāre ca ati evam anuloma naye
translated: And in the section on faculties and planes, in the passage beginning, “When someone abandons the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires in a certain plane, does he then abandon the underlying tendency to aversion in that plane? … the underlying tendency to conceit? … the underlying tendency to lust for existence? … the underlying tendency to wrong view? … the underlying tendency to uncertainty? … the underlying tendency to ill will? … the underlying tendency to stiffness? … the underlying tendency to agitation? … the underlying tendency to ignorance? ”🔽Thus in the forward order and in the reverse order,

original: ca, “yo kāmarāgānusayaṃ na pajahati, so paṭighānusayaṃ na pajahatīti? Āmantā…pe…
analyzed: ca yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam na pajahati saḥ paṭigha anusayam na pajahati iti āmantāpe
translated: “One who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures does not abandon the underlying tendency to resentment” ? …🔽“One who does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence does not abandon the underlying tendency to wrong view” ? …🔽“One who does not abandon the underlying tendency to uncertainty does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for existence” ? …

original: vicikicchānusayaṃ na pajahatīti? Aṭṭhamako kāmarāgānusayaṃ na pajahati, netaraṃ,
analyzed: vicikicchā anusayam na pajahati iti aṭṭhamakaḥ kāma rāga anusayam na pajahati na itaram
translated: “The eighth person does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures, but not the others.

original: anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiṃ, aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā tadubhayaṃ na pajahantī”tiādinā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga samaṅgim aṭṭhamakañca ṭhapetvā avasesā puggalā tat ubhayam na pajahanti itiādinā
translated: Excepting the person who possesses the path of non-return and the eighth person, the remaining persons do not abandon both” .

original: paṭilomanaye ca sabbattha pucchāvissajjananayo ñātabbo.
analyzed: paṭiloma naye ca sabbattha pucchā vissajjana nayaḥ ñātabbaḥ
translated: And in the reverse order, the method of question and answer should be understood in all cases.🔽Herein, “he abandons” is said with reference to the abandoning-as- full-understanding by means of each of the paths.

original: Tattha pajahatīti tena tena maggena pahānapariññāvasena pajahati. Tadekaṭṭhanti pahānekaṭṭhataṃ
analyzed: tattha pajahati iti tena tena maggena pahāna pariññā vasena pajahati tat ekaṭṭhanti pahāna ekaṭṭhatam
translated: “They are of the same abandoning” is said with reference to the fact that they are of the same abandoning.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Paṭhamamaggādinā hi na kevalaṃ diṭṭhādikā eva dhammā pahīyanti,🔽atha kho apāyagamaniyā tena kāmarāgapaṭighamānādayopi pahīyanti eva. Paṭhamamaggavajjhā
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam paṭhama magga ādinā hi na kevalam diṭṭha ādikāḥ eva dhammāḥ pahīyanti  atha kho apāya gamaniyā tena kāma rāga paṭigha māna ādayaḥ pahīyanti eva paṭhama magga vajjhā
translated: For it is not only views, etc., that are abandoned by the first path, etc.,🔽but also the unprofitable consciousnesses that lead to the unhappy destiny, such as lust, resentment, conceit, etc., are abandoned.

original: hi kāmarāgā, apāyagamaniyā ca mānāvijjādayopi, tatiyamaggavajjhāti pahānekaṭṭhā hutvā
analyzed: hi kāma rāgāḥ apāya gamaniyā ca māna avijja ādayaḥ pi tatiya magga vat jhā ti hutvā
translated: For the first path abandons lust, and the conceit, ignorance, etc., that lead to the unhappy destiny are abandoned by the third path.

original: pahīyanti evāti “no”ti arahattamaggaṭṭhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. So hi kāmarāgānusayaṃyeva
analyzed: pahīyanti eva ati no ti arahatta magga ṭṭham sandhāya vuttam saḥ hi kāma rāga anusayam yā iva
translated: “No” is said in reference to the plane of the path of arahatship, for he does not abandon the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures.

original: pahīnattā na pajahatīti. Yato kāmarāgānusayaṃ pajahatīti yato uppajjanakaṃ kāmarāgānusayaṃ
analyzed: pahīna ttā na pajahati iti yatas kāma rāga anusayam pajahati iti yatas uppajjanakam kāma rāga anusayam
translated: “When he abandons the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures” means when he abandons the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures that is capable of arising.

original: pajahatīti attho, aṭṭhamakoti sotāpattimaggaṭṭho. So hi dakkhiṇeyyakkamena arahattaphalaṭṭhato
analyzed: pajahati iti attho aṭṭhamako ti sotāpatti magga ṭṭho so hi dakkhiṇeyya kkamena arahatta phala ṭṭhato
translated: The eighth person is the one on the path of stream-entry. For he is called the eighth when counted from the plane of the fruit of arahatship in the order of those worthy of gifts.

original: paṭṭhāya gaṇiyamāno aṭṭhamako nāma. Paṭilomanaye anāgāmimaggasamaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca🔽ṭhapetvā avasesāti puthujjanasesasekhāsekhā. Tesu hi puthujjanā pahānapariññāya abhāvena
analyzed: paṭṭhāya gaṇiyamānaḥ aṭṭhamakaḥ nāma paṭiloma naye anāgāmi magga samaṅgiñca aṭṭhamakañca  ṭhapetvā avasesā ati puthujjana sesa sekhā asekhā tesu hi puthujjanā pahāna pariññāya abhāvena
translated: Excepting the one on the path of non-return and the eighth person, the rest are the ordinary men and the trainees and adepts.

original: na pajahanti, sesā tesaṃ pahīnattāti iminā nayena sabbattha vinicchayo veditabboti
analyzed: na pajahanti sesā tesam pahīna ttā ati iminā nayena sabbattha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: For the ordinary men do not abandon because they do not possess the full understanding by abandoning. The rest have abandoned them. In this way the exposition should be understood in all instances.

original: ayaṃ pajahanavāre nayo.
analyzed: ayam pajahanavāre
translated: This is the method of explanation in the section on abandoning.

original: Pariññāvāro pana “yo kāmarāgānusayaṃ parijānāti, so paṭighānusayaṃ parijānātī”tiādinā
analyzed: pariññā vāraḥ pana yaḥ kāma rāga anusayam parijānāti saḥ paṭigha anusayam parijānāti itiādinā

original: anusayo uppajjati, magge bhāvite tattheva so pahīno nāma hoti, tasmā so tattha pahīnoti🔽vā, appahīnoti vā na vattabbo, sabbatthāpi pana sayaṃ abhāvena tattha appahīnoti

translated: and a latent tendency arises, then when the path is developed it is said to be abandoned there. Therefore it should not be said that it is abandoned there or not abandoned there. But everywhere it should be said that it is not abandoned there because of its non-existence there.🔽

original: na vattabbo. Ubhinnaṃ pana sādhāraṇaṭṭhānaṃ sandhāya “āmantā”ti vuttaṃ. Mānānusayo
analyzed: na vattabbaḥ ubhinnam pana sādhāraṇa ṭhānam sandhāya āmantā ti vuttam māna anusayaḥ
translated: and the underlying tendency arises, then when the path is developed it is said to be abandoned there. So it cannot be said of it that it is either abandoned there or not abandoned there. But since it is non-existent there by its own true nature, it cannot be said that it is not abandoned there. But the words “Yes, friends” are said with reference to the place that is common to both.

original: hi kāmadhātuyā vedanādvayasaṅkhāte sādhāraṇaṭṭhāne kāmarāgena saddhiṃ pahīno nāma
analyzed: hi kāmadhātuyā vedanā dvaya saṅkhāte sādhāraṇa ṭṭhāne kāma rāgena saddhim pahīnaḥ nāma
translated: For the underlying tendency to conceit is said to be abandoned in the place that is common to both, that is to say, in the two kinds of feeling in the sense-desire element.

original: hoti. Yassa kāmarāgānusayo appahīnoti puthujjanassa, sotāpattisakadāgāmiphalaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: hoti yassa kāma rāga anusayaḥ appahīno ti puthujjanassa sotāpatti sakadāgāmi phala ṭṭhānañca
translated: The meaning should be taken as stated in the case of the person who has not abandoned the underlying tendency to lust for sense desires and who is a worldling, a stream-enterer, and a once-returner.

original: vasena attho gahetabbo. “Tiṇṇaṃ puggalāna”nti hi vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyamevāti ayaṃ pahīnavāre nayo.
analyzed: vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo tiṇṇam puggalānam ti hi vuttam sesam su viññeyyam eva ati ayam pahīna vāre nayo
translated: For it is said “of three persons.” The rest is easily understood. This is the method in the section on “abandoned.”

original: Uppajjanavāre pana “yassa kāmarāgānusayo uppajjati, tassa paṭighānusayo uppajjatī”tiādinā sabbattha anusayavārasadisovāti ayaṃ uppajjanavāre nayo.
analyzed: uppajjana vāre pana yassa kāma rāga anusayaḥ uppajjati tassa paṭigha anusayaḥ uppajjati iti ādinā sabbattha anusaya vāra sadisaḥ uvā ati ayam uppajjana vāre nayo
translated: In the section on “arisen,” however, the method is the same as in the section on “underlying tendencies” in all the cases beginning with “If the underlying tendency to lust for sense desires arises in anyone, the underlying tendency to resistance arises in him too.” This is the method in the section on “arisen.”

original: Dhātuvāre pana “kāmadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kati anusayā anusenti,
analyzed: dhātu vāre pana kāmadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa kati anusayāḥ anusenti
translated: But in the plane of elements, the questions are asked thus: “When one who has died in the sense-desire element is reappearing in the sense-desire element, how many kinds of underlying tendency accompany him as reappearing?

original: kati anusayā nānusenti, kati anusayā bhaṅgā? Kāmadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa…pe…
analyzed: kati anusayāḥ na anusenti kati anusayāḥ bhaṅgā kāmadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātum upapajjantassa pe
translated: How many kinds of underlying tendency do not accompany him as reappearing? How many kinds of underlying tendency are abandoned? When one who has died in the sense-desire element is reappearing in the fine-material element …

original: kati bhaṅgā? Kāmadhātuyā cutassa arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa…pe… rūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa
analyzed: kati bhaṅgā kāmadhātuyā cutassa a rūpadhātum upapajjantassa pe rūpadhātum upapajjantassa
translated: how many are abandoned? When one who has died in the sense-desire element is reappearing in the immaterial element … reappearing in the fine-material element …

original: na arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa…pe… kati bhaṅgaṃ? Kāmadhātuyā cutassa na kāmadhātuṃ,
analyzed: na arūpadhātum kati bhaṅgam kāmadhātuyā cutassa na kāmadhātum
translated: not reappearing in the immaterial element … how many are abandoned? When one who has died in the sense-desire element is not reappearing in the sense-desire element,

original: na arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa…pe… na rūpadhātuṃ na arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa. Na
analyzed: na arūpa dhātum upapajjantassa pe na rūpa dhātum na arūpa dhātum upapajjantassa na
translated: not reappearing in the immaterial element … not reappearing in the fine-material element and the immaterial element …

original: kāmadhātuṃ na rūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kati bhaṅgā”ti evaṃ kāmadhātumūlakā nava
analyzed: kāmadhātum na rūpadhātum upapajjantassa kati bhaṅgāḥ ati evam kāmadhātu mūlakāḥ nava
translated: not reappearing in the sense-desire element and the fine-material element … how many are abandoned?” So there are nine questions based on the sense-desire element.

original: pucchā, tathā “rūpadhātuyā cutassā”tiādinā rūpadhātumūlakā nava, arūpadhātuyā nava
analyzed: pucchā tathā rūpadhātuyā cutassa ati ādinā rūpadhātu mūlakāḥ nava arūpadhātuyāḥ nava
translated: Similarly there are nine based on the fine-material element beginning with “When one who has died in the fine-material element … ” and nine based on the immaterial element.🔽So there are twenty-two questions in forward order.

original: cāti sattavīsati anulomapucchā, tathā “na kāmadhātuyā cutassā”tiādinā sattavīsati
analyzed: ca ati sattavīsati anuloma pucchā tathā na kāmadhātuyā cutassa ati ādinā sattavīsati
translated: Similarly there are twenty-two in reverse order beginning with “When one who has died not in the sense-desire element … ”

original: paṭilomapucchā ca, tathā “na kāmadhātuyā na arūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassā”tiādinā🔽sattavīsati dukamūlakā pucchā cāti evaṃ pucchāvāre ekāsīti pucchā veditabbā.🔽Tattha anusentīti cittasantāne anugatā hutvā kati anusenti, bhaṅgāti anusenti ca
analyzed: paṭilomapucchā ca tathā na kāmadhātuyā na arūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa ati ādinā  sattavīsati duka mūlakā pucchā ca ati evam pucchāvāre ekā asi iti pucchā veditabbā  tattha anusenti iti citta santāne anugatāḥ hutvā kati anusenti ca
translated: and the reverse order of questioning, and also the twenty-seven questions based on the two terms “not in the sense-desire element” and “not in the fine-material element” and so on,🔽thus there are eighty-one questions in the section on questioning.

original: nānusenti cāti evaṃ kati vibhajitabbāti attho. Na kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassāti kāmadhātuvirahitā🔽dve rūpārūpadhātuyo upapajjantassa. Na kāmadhātuṃ na rūpadhātunti arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa.
analyzed: na anusenti ca ati evam kati vibhajitabbā ti atthaḥ na kāmadhātum upapajjantassa ati kāmadhātu virahitā  dve rūpa arūpa dhātuyaḥ upapajjantassa na kāmadhātum na rūpadhātum ti arūpadhātum upapajjantassa
translated: Herein, the meaning is this: how many of the kinds of death are there that are called “death in the sense-desire element” and so on, and how many of the kinds of reappearance that are called “reappearance in the sense-desire element” and so on?🔽“Not in the sense-desire element” means not in the sense-desire element and not in the fine-material element.🔽“Not in the sense-desire element and not in the fine-material element” means not in the immaterial element.

original: Na kāmadhātuyāti rūpārūpadhātūhi cutassa, evaṃ sesesupi sabbattha paṭisandhivasena,
analyzed: na kāmadhātuyā ati rūpa arūpadhātūhi cutassa evam sesesu pi sabbattha paṭisandhi vasena
translated: “Not in the sense-desire element” means not in the sense-desire element and not in the fine-material element.

original: dhātuvasena ca attho veditabboti ayaṃ uddesavāre nayo.
analyzed: dhātu vasena ca atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti ayam uddesavāre nayo
translated: The meaning should be understood here in each instance according to the kind of rebirth-linking and the kind of element. This is the method in the section on the Rehearsal of Elements.

original: Niddesavāre panassa “kāmadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kassaci satta
analyzed: niddesa vāre panassa kāmadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa kassaci
translated: But in the section on the Description of Death in the Sense-Desire Element, etc., “When someone dying in the sense-desire element …🔽… and so on with the rest of the section on the Description of Death in the Sense-Desire Element, etc.,

original: anusayā anusenti, kassaci pañca anusayā anusenti, anusayā bhaṅgā natthi, kāmadhātuyā
analyzed: anusayā anusenti kassaci pañca anusayā anusenti anusayāḥ bhaṅgāḥ natthi kāmadhātuyā
translated: the underlying tendencies underlie, for some there are five underlying tendencies that underlie, there is no breaking up of the underlying tendencies, in the sense-desire element🔽

original: cutassa rūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kassaci satta anusayā anusenti, kassaci pañca,
analyzed: cutassa rūpadhātum upapajjantassa kassaci satta anusayāḥ anusenti kassaci pañca
translated: The underlying tendencies underlie in him. In some it is five underlying tendencies that underlie. There is no breaking up of the underlying tendencies. When one who has died in the sense-desire element is reappearing in the fine-material element, in some it is seven underlying tendencies that underlie, in some it is five,

original: kassaci tayo …pe… bhaṅgā natthī”ti iminā nayena sabbattha vissajjanaṃ veditabbaṃ,
analyzed: kassaci tayo pe bhaṅgā natthi iti iminā nayena sabbattha vissajjanam veditabbam
translated: in some it is three … there is no breaking up of the underlying tendencies. The answer should be understood in this way in all the remaining cases.

original: ayaṃ panettha viseso – rūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassa satteva anusayā
analyzed: ayam pana ittha visesaḥ rūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa sattā iva anusayā
translated: But there is this difference here: when one who has died in the fine-material element is reappearing in the sense-desire element, it is only the five underlying tendencies that underlie.

original: anusenti, tathā “arūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassā”tiādīsupi, arūpadhātuyā
analyzed: anusenti tathā a rūpa dhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa ati ādīsu pi a rūpa dhātuyā
translated: So too in the cases beginning, “When one who has died in the immaterial element is reappearing in the sense-desire element” .

original: pana cutassa rūpadhātuyā upapatti natthi, heṭṭhā upapajjamāno kāmadhātuṃ eva upapajjati,🔽satteva anusayā anusentīti evaṃ aññesupi evarūpesu vissajjananayo veditabboti ayaṃ
analyzed: pana cutassa rūpadhātuyāḥ upapatti natthi heṭṭhā upapajjamānaḥ kāmadhātum eva upapajjati  sattā iva anusayāḥ anusenti iti evam aññesu pi evarūpesu vissajjana nayaḥ veditabbaḥ ti ayam
translated: But when one who has died in the immaterial element is reappearing in the fine-material element, there is no reappearance in the fine-material element. He reappears only in the sense-desire element,🔽and it is only the five underlying tendencies that underlie. This is how the method of answering should be understood in the other cases as well.

original: viseso, sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti ayamettha pāḷinayo.
analyzed: visesaḥ sesam vutta nayam evā ti ayam ettha pāḷi nayaḥ
translated: This is the difference. The rest is as already stated. This is the method in the text.

original: Tattha kassaci sattāti puthujjanavasena vuttaṃ, pañcāti sotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃ vasena.
analyzed: tattha kassaci sattā ti puthujjana vasena vuttam pañca iti sotāpanna sakadāgāmīnam vasena
translated: Herein, “some” is said with reference to ordinary men, and “five” with reference to stream-enterers and once-returners.

analyzed: tesam hi diṭṭhi vicikicchā anusayā pahīnā ati kāmadhātuyā pana anāgāmīnam upapatti abhāvato

original: paṭhamavāre “kassaci tayo”ti na vuttaṃ, rūpārūpadhātūsu uppajjanavāresu eva vuttaṃ…pe…
analyzed: paṭhama vāre kassaci tayo ti na vuttam rūpa arūpa dhātūsu uppajjana vāresu eva vuttam pe
translated: “some” is not said in the first section with reference to three. It is said only with reference to reappearance in the form and formless elements. …

original: anāgāmīnaṃ hi kāmarāgapaṭighānampi pahīnattā tayova anusayā anusenti, idha ca anusayānaṃ
analyzed: anāgāmīnam hi anusayāḥ anusenti ca
translated: For non-returners, only three inherent tendencies remain, since they have abandoned the inherent tendencies to lust and to resentment. And here the method is by way of the arising of the inherent tendencies.

original: uppattivasena nayo, anusayānaṃ anusayanaṃ aggahetvā appahīnabhāvena paṭisandhikkhaṇe🔽api anusayanaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Sattevāti ariyasāvakassa rūpārūpadhātuyā cutassa heṭṭhā
analyzed: uppatti vasena nayaḥ anusayānam anusayanam aggahetvā appahīna bhāvena paṭisandhi kkhaṇe  api anusayanam gahetabbam sattevāti ariya sāvakassa rūpa arūpa dhātuyā cutassa heṭṭhā
translated: Without taking the inherent tendencies’ inherent tendency, their remaining unabandoned, they should be taken as inherent tendencies at the moment of rebirth-linking.🔽“Seven” is said by way of the non-returner who dies in the form or formless element and is not reborn below in the sense-desire element or the fine-material element.

original: kāmabhavādīsu upapatti nāma natthi, puthujjanasseva hoti, tasmā “sattevā”ti niyametvā
analyzed: kāma bhava ādīsu upapatti nāma natthi puthujjanassa iva hoti tasmā sattā iva ati niyametvā
translated: This is only for the ordinary man, not for the noble disciple. Therefore “seven” is said by way of limitation.🔽There is no reappearance in the fine-material element for one who dies in the formless element. Why is there none?

original: vuttaṃ, arūpadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātuyā upapatti natthīti. Kasmā natthi? Arūpīnaṃ
analyzed: vuttam arūpa dhātuyā cutassa rūpa dhātuyā upapatti natthi iti kasmā natthi arūpīnam
translated: Because the formless are not capable of it.

original: rūpajjhānassa abhāvā. Te hi sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamanarūpadhātuṃ upapannāti.
analyzed: rūpa jhānassa abhāvā te hi sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamana rūpa dhātum upapannā ati
translated: because there is no material-jhana consciousness. For they are reborn in the immaterial world by surmounting all material-form perception.

original: Sesaṃ nayato suviññeyyamevāti ayaṃ dhātuvāre nayo. Ayaṃ anusayayamakamātikatthasaṃvaṇṇanānayo.
analyzed: sesam nayataḥ su viññeyyam evā ti ayam dhātu vāre nayaḥ ayam anusaya yamaka mātikattha saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ
translated: The rest can be understood in the same way. This is the method in the case of the element triad. This is the method of explaining the exposition of the dyads in the case of the underlying tendencies.

original: Cittayamakamātikatthavaṇṇanā
translated: The dyads in the case of consciousness

original: Cittayamakamātikāyaṃ pana pāḷivavatthānaṃ tāva evaṃ veditabbaṃ. Imissaṃ hi mātikāyaṃ
analyzed: citta yamaka mātikāyam pana pāḷi vavatthānam tāva evam veditabbam imissam hi mātikāyam
translated: As regards the dyads in the case of consciousness, the exposition of the text should be understood in this way. For in this dyad-exposition

original: puggalavāro dhammavāro puggaladhammavāroti āditova tayo suddhikamahāvārā honti, tattha🔽“yassa cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhatī”ti evaṃ puggalavasena cittassa uppajjananirujjhanādibhedaṃ🔽dīpento gato puggalavāro nāma. “Yaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhatī”ti evaṃ dhammavaseneva
analyzed: puggalavāro dhammavāro puggala dhammavāro ti āditas va tayo suddhika mahāvārāḥ honti tattha  yassa cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati iti evam puggala vasena cittassa uppajjana nirujjhana ādi bhedam  dīpentaḥ gataḥ puggalavāraḥ nāma yat cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati iti evam dhamma vasena iva
translated: there are three principal dyads at the beginning: the person dyad, the state dyad, and the person-state dyad.🔽The person dyad is the dyad beginning, “Whose consciousness arises and does not cease” . It is so called because it deals with the arising and ceasing, etc., of consciousness by way of the person.🔽The state dyad is the dyad beginning, “Which consciousness arises and does not cease” . It is so called because it deals with the arising and ceasing, etc., of consciousness by way of the state only.

original: cittassa uppajjananirujjhanādibhedaṃ dīpento gato dhammavāro nāma. “Yassa yaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: cittassa uppajjana nirujjhana ādi bhedam dīpentaḥ gataḥ dhammavāraḥ nāma yassa yam cittam
translated: The person-state dyad is the dyad beginning, “Whose consciousness arises and does not cease in regard to which states” .

original: uppajjati na nirujjhatī”ti evaṃ ubhayavaseneva cittassa uppajjananirujjhanādibhedaṃ🔽dīpento gato puggaladhammavāro nāma.
analyzed: uppajjati na nirujjhati iti evam ubhaya vasena iva cittassa uppajjana nirujjhana ādi bhedam  dīpentaḥ gataḥ puggaladhammavāraḥ nāma
translated: and it arises and does not cease” , and so on, he has gone into the section on persons and ideas.

original: Tato “yassa sarāgaṃ citta”ntiādīnaṃ soḷasannaṃ padānaṃ vasena apare sarāgādipadavisesitā
analyzed: tatas yassa sa rāgam citta ti ādīnam padānam vasena apare
translated: Then, with the sixteen terms beginning with “Whose cognizance is affected by greed” , there are other sections on persons and ideas distinguished by the terms affected by greed, etc.,

original: soḷasa puggalavārā, soḷasa dhammavārā, soḷasa puggaladhammavārāti aṭṭhacattālīsa🔽missakavārā honti, te sarāgādipadamattaṃ dassetvā saṃkhittā. Tato “yassa kusalaṃ
analyzed: soḷasa puggala vārā soḷasa dhamma vārā soḷasa puggala dhamma vārā ati aṭṭha cattālīsa  missaka vārāḥ honti te sa rāga ādi pada mattam dassetvā saṃkhittā tatas yassa kusalam
translated: namely sixteen sections on persons, sixteen sections on ideas, and sixteen sections on persons and ideas, making forty-eight mixed sections.

original: citta”ntiādinā nayena chasaṭṭhidvisatasaṅkhātānaṃ abhidhammamātikāpadānaṃ vasena
analyzed: citta nti ādinā nayena cha saṭṭhi dvi sata saṅkhātānam abhidhamma mātikā apadānam vasena
translated: They are abbreviated by showing only the terms affected by greed, etc., and so on. Then, with the terms of the Abhidhamma Schedule consisting of sixty-six pairs called “Whose cognizance is profitable” , etc.,

original: apare kusalādipadavisesitā chasaṭṭhidvisatapuggalavārā, chasaṭṭhidvisatadhammavārā,
analyzed: apare kusala ādi pada visesitā cha saṭṭhi dvisata puggala vārā cha saṭṭhi dvisata dhamma vārā
translated: there are other sections on persons and ideas distinguished by the terms profitable, etc.,🔽namely sixty-six pairs of sections on persons, sixty-six pairs of sections on ideas, and sixty-six pairs of sections on persons and ideas, making two hundred and sixty-four mixed sections.

original: chasaṭṭhidvisatapuggaladhammavārāti aṭṭhanavutisattasatā missakavārā honti, tepi
analyzed: cha saṭṭhi dvi sata puggala dhamma vārā ti aṭṭhanavuti satta satāḥ missaka vārāḥ honti te pi
translated: They are abbreviated by showing only the terms profitable, etc., and so on.

original: kusalādipadamattaṃ dassetvā saṃkhittāyeva, yānipettha sanidassanādīni padāni cittena🔽saddhiṃ na yujjanti, tāni moghapucchāvasena gahitānīti.
analyzed: kusala ādi pada mattam dassetvā saṃkhittāya iva yāni pa ittha sa nidassana ādīni padāni cittena  saddhim na yujjanti tāni mogha pucchā vasena gahitāni iti
translated: and after showing the mere words “wholesome” and so on, he has given a brief explanation of the questions that do not go with the words “visible” and so on in the mind-door process.🔽In the case of these three sections, there are fourteen intermediate sections in the first pure-human-penetration section:

original: Tesu pana tīsu vāresu sabbapaṭhame suddhikapuggalamahāvāre tāva uppādanirodhakālasambhedavāro
analyzed: tesu pana tīsu vāresu sabba paṭhame suddhika puggala mahāvāre tāva uppāda nirodha kāla sambheda vāro
translated: the section on the distinction of the times of arising and of ceasing,

original: uppāduppannavāro nirodhuppannavāro uppādavāro nirodhavāro uppādanirodhavāro uppajjamānananirodhavāro
analyzed: uppāda uppanna vāraḥ nirodha uppanna vāraḥ uppāda vāraḥ nirodha vāraḥ uppāda nirodha vāraḥ uppajjamānana nirodha vāraḥ
translated: the section on arisen and not-yetan arisen, the section on ceased and arisen, the section on arising, the section on ceasing, the section on arising and ceasing, the section on arising and ceasing that is occurring,

original: uppajjamānuppannavāro nirujjhamānuppannavāro uppannuppādavāro atītānāgatavāro uppannuppajjamānavāro🔽niruddhanirujjhamānavāro atikkantakālavāro cāti cuddasa antaravārā, tesu uppādavāro
analyzed: uppajjamāna uppanna vāraḥ nirujjhamāna uppanna vāraḥ uppanna uppāda vāraḥ atīta anāgata vāraḥ uppanna uppajjamāna vāraḥ  niruddhanirujjhamānavāro atikkantakālavāro ca ati cuddasa antaravārā tesu uppādavāro
translated: the section on arisen and arisen that is occurring, the section on ceased and arisen that is occurring, the section on arisen and arisen that has arisen, the section on past and future, the section on arisen and arisen that is occurring,🔽the section on ceased and ceased that is occurring, and the section on the time that has passed.

original: nirodhavāro uppādanirodhavāroti imesu tīsu vāresu paccekaṃ vattamānātītassa, vattamānānāgatassa,
analyzed: nirodha vāro uppāda nirodha vāro ti imesu tīsu vāresu paccekam vattamāna atītassa vattamāna anāgatassa
translated: In the case of these three sections, namely, the section on arising, the section on ceasing, and the section on arising and ceasing, in each section there are three triads, that is to say, the present past of the present, the present future of the present,🔽and the present present of the present.

original: atītānāgatassa cāti tiṇṇaṃ kālabhedānaṃ vasena anulomapaṭilomato cha cha katvā aṭṭhārasa
analyzed: atīta anāgatassa ca ati tiṇṇam kāla bhedānam vasena anuloma paṭilomato cha cha katvā aṭṭhārasa
translated: and of the past and future, making six by way of the forward and reverse order in each of the three divisions of time, there are eighteen

original: yamakāni, uppannuppādavāre atītānāgatakālavasena anulomato dve, paṭilomato dveti🔽cattāri yamakāni, sesesu ādito niddiṭṭhesu tīsu, antare niddiṭṭhesu tīsu, avasāne🔽niddiṭṭhesu catūsūti dasasu vāresu anulomato ekaṃ, paṭilomato ekanti dve dve katvā
analyzed: yamakāni uppanna uppāda vāre atīta anāgata kāla vasena anulomataḥ dve paṭilomataḥ dve iti  cattāri yamakāni sesesu āditaḥ niddiṭṭhesu tīsu antare niddiṭṭhesu tīsu avasāne  niddiṭṭhesu catūsu iti dasasu vāresu anulomataḥ ekam paṭilomataḥ ekam ti dve dve katvā
translated: sets of two. In the case of the section on “arisen and arising,” there are two forward and two reverse sets of two in each of the three divisions of time,🔽making twelve sets of two. In the case of the remaining three sections, which are mentioned at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end,

original: vīsati yamakāni, evaṃ sabbesupi cuddasasu antaravāresu dvācattālīsa yamakāni, caturāsīti
analyzed: vīsati yamakāni evam sabbesu pi cuddasasu antaravāresu dvācattālīsa yamakāni caturāsīti
translated: there is one forward and one reverse set of two in each of the ten sections, making twenty sets of two. Thus in all fourteen sections there are forty-two sets of two,

original: pucchā, aṭṭhasaṭṭhiatthasataṃ hoti. Yathā ca ekasmiṃ suddhikapuggalamahāvāre, tathā🔽suddhikadhammamahāvāre, suddhikapuggaladhammamahāvārepīti tīsu mahāvāresu chabbīsatiyamakasataṃ,
analyzed: pucchā aṭṭha saṭṭhi attha satam hoti yathā ca ekasmin suddhika puggala mahāvāre tathā  suddhika dhamma mahāvāre suddhika puggala dhamma mahāvāre pi iti tīsu mahāvāresu chabbīsati yamaka satam
translated: eighty-four questions, and eighty-six answers. And just as in the case of the one section on the person in training,🔽so too in the case of the section on the ideas of the person in training, and in the case of the section on the person and ideas of the person in training,

original: tato diguṇā pucchā, diguṇā atthā ca veditabbā, idaṃ pana vārattayaṃ sarāgādivasena
analyzed: tatas diguṇā pucchā diguṇāḥ atthāḥ ca veditabbāḥ idam pana vārattayam sa rāga ādi vasena
translated: there are three hundred and twenty-six sets of two, and the questions and the answers are twice that number. But in this section on the three times,

original: soḷasaguṇaṃ, kusalādivasena chasaṭṭhidvisataguṇaṃ katvā imissā cittayamakamātikāya
analyzed: soḷasaguṇam kusala ādi vasena cha saṭṭhi dvi sataguṇam katvā imissā citta yamaka mātikāya
translated: and sixteen times that, and so on, by way of the profitable, etc., making thirty-six times that, and seventy-two times that, and so on, in this stanza-couplet’s schedule.

original: anekāni yamakasahassāni, taddiguṇā pucchā, taddiguṇā atthā ca honti, pāṭho pana saṃkhitto.
analyzed: anekāni yamaka sahassāni tad diguṇā pucchā tad diguṇāḥ atthāḥ ca honti pāṭhaḥ pana saṃkhitto
translated: There are many thousands of couplets, and the questions are twice that number, and the answers are twice that number too, but the text is concise.

original: Evamettha pāḷivavatthānaṃ viditvā idāni anuttānapadatthānusārena vibhaṅganayasahito
analyzed: evam ettha viditvā idāni anuttāna padattha anusārena
translated: So when the text has been thus defined, now, in order to follow up the meaning of the words not already dealt with,

original: saṅkhepatthavaṇṇanānayo evaṃ veditabbo.
analyzed: saṅkhepa attha vaṇṇanā anayaḥ evam veditabbo
translated: the method of exposition should be understood as follows, with the brief explanation.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjatīti yassa puggalassa cittaṃ uppādakkhaṇasamaṅgitāya uppajjati.
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjati iti yassa puggalassa cittam uppāda khaṇa samaṅgi tāya uppajjati
translated: Whose cognizance arises: whose person’s cognizance arises in the moment of its arising.

original: Na nirujjhatīti nirodhakkhaṇaṃ appattatāya na nirujjhati. Tassa cittanti kiṃ tassa
analyzed: na nirujjhati iti nirodha kkhaṇam appatta tāya na nirujjhati tassa cittam ti kim tassa
translated: Does not cease: it does not cease because it has not yet reached the moment of its cessation. Whose cognizance: what is that?

original: puggalassa tato paṭṭhāya cittaṃ nirujjhissatīti pucchā, tassā ca, “pacchimacittassa
analyzed: puggalassa tatas paṭṭhāya cittam nirujjhissati iti pucchā tassā ca pacchimacittassa
translated: Will cease: will that person’s cognizance cease from then on? This is the question. And the answer is:

original: uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati, nirujjhissati nuppajjissati, itaresaṃ
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe tesam cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati nirujjhissati na uppajjissati itaresam
translated: At the moment of the arising of the last cognizance, their cognizance arises and does not cease; it will cease and will not arise, but the rest

original: cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhati, nirujjhissati ceva uppajjissati
analyzed: cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tesam cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati nirujjhissati ca iva uppajjissati
translated: At the arising moment of their cognizance their cognizance arises and does not cease, and it will cease and will arise.

original: cā”ti vissajjanaṃ. Tattha tesaṃ cittanti yesaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ pacchimacittasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: ca ati vissajjanam tattha tesam cittam ti yesam khīṇāsavānam pacchima citta saṅkhātassa
translated: Herein, their cognizance: that of those whose cognizance is called the last cognizance,

original: cuticittassa uppādakkhaṇe vattati, tesaṃ tadeva cuticittaṃ uppādappattatāya uppajjati🔽nāma, bhaṅgaṃ appattatāya na nirujjhati nāma, idāni pana bhaṅgaṃ patvā taṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: cuti cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe vattati tesam tat eva cuti cittam uppāda ppatta tāya uppajjati  nāma bhaṅgam appatta tāya na nirujjhati nāma idāni pana bhaṅgam patvā tam tesam
translated: which occurs at the arising moment of the cognizance of those whose cankers are destroyed. That last cognizance arises because it has reached arising,

original: cittaṃ nirujjhissati, tato appaṭisandhikattā aññaṃ nuppajjissati. Itaresanti pacchimacittasamaṅgiṃ🔽khīṇāsavaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesānaṃ sekhāsekhaputhujjanānaṃ nirujjhissati ceva aññaṃ pana
analyzed: cittam nirujjhissati tatas appaṭisandhika ttā aññam nuppajjissati itaresanti pacchima citta samaṅgiṃ  khīṇāsavam ṭhapetvā avasesānam sekha asekha puthujjanānam nirujjhissati ca iva aññam pana
translated: and it does not cease because it has not reached dissolution. But now, having reached dissolution, that cognizance of theirs will cease, and because it will not be followed by rebirth-linking, it will not arise. The rest: except for those whose cankers are destroyed who are possessed of the last cognizance,

original: tasmiṃ vā attabhāve uppajjissati cāti attho.
analyzed: tasmin vā atta bhāve uppajjissati ca ati atthaḥ
translated: the rest, who are in the three planes, have cognizance that both ceases and arises. The meaning is that their cognizance ceases in the present becoming and arises in a next becoming.

original: “Yassa vā pana cittaṃ nirujjhissati nuppajjissati, tassa cittaṃ uppajjati na nirujjhatī”ti
analyzed: yassa vā pana cittam nirujjhissati na uppajjissati tassa cittam uppajjati na nirujjhati iti
translated: “Whose cognizance will cease and will not arise, his cognizance arises and does not cease”

original: imissā dutiyapucchāya pacchimacittasamaṅgino khīṇāsavassa cittaṃ sandhāya “āmantā”ti🔽vissajjanaṃ. “Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjati nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhissati uppajjissatī”ti
analyzed: imissā dutiya pucchāya pacchima citta samaṅgino khīṇāsavassa cittam sandhāya āmantā ti  vissajjanam yassa cittam na uppajjati nirujjhati tassa cittam na nirujjhissati uppajjissati iti
translated: is the answer to the question about the consciousness of one who is an Arahant and has reached his last-consciousness.🔽In the answer to the question, “Is there any consciousness that does not cease and arise? ”🔽the answer is “No,” because the consciousness of an Arahant at the moment of his attaining Arahantship does not cease and arise.

original: pucchāya “no”ti paṭisedhova vissajjanaṃ. Na uppajjati nirujjhatīti hi bhaṅgakkhaṇe🔽arahato pacchimacittampi sesānaṃ bhijjamānacittampi pucchati, tato paṭṭhāya pana
analyzed: pucchāya no ti paṭisedhaḥ uva vissajjanam na uppajjati nirujjhati iti hi bhaṅga kkhaṇe  arahataḥ pacchima cittam pi sesānam bhijjamāna cittam pi pucchati tatas paṭṭhāya pana
translated: But in the question, “Is there any consciousness that does not cease and arise? ”

original: arahato tāva cittaṃ na nirujjhissatīti sakkā vattuṃ, uppajjissatīti pana na sakkā,
analyzed: arahataḥ tāva cittam na nirujjhissati iti sakkā vattum uppajjissati iti pana na sakkā
translated: the consciousness of an Arahant at the moment of his attaining Arahantship is not intended, but rather the consciousness of an Arahant at the moment of his death and the consciousness of other persons at the moment of their death.🔽Therefore the answer is “No.”

original: tasmā “no”ti ettha paṭisedho kato, “yassa vā pana cittaṃ na nirujjhissati uppajjissati,🔽tassa cittaṃ nuppajjati nirujjhatī”ti pucchāya “natthī”ti paṭikkhepova vissajjanaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā no ti ettha paṭisedhaḥ kataḥ yassa vā pana cittam na nirujjhissati uppajjissati  tassa cittam nu uppajjati nirujjhati iti pucchāya natthi iti paṭikkhepaḥ uva vissajjanam
translated: In the answer to the question, “Is there any consciousness that does not arise and cease? ”🔽the answer is “No,” because the consciousness of an Arahant at the moment of his attaining Arahantship does not arise and cease.

original: Yassa hi cittaṃ na nirujjhissati uppajjissati, so ca puggalo natthīti.
analyzed: yassa hi cittam na nirujjhissati uppajjissati saḥ ca puggalaḥ natthi iti
translated: But in the question, “Is there any consciousness that does not arise and cease? ”🔽the consciousness of an Arahant at the moment of his death and the consciousness of other persons at the moment of their death are intended.🔽Therefore the answer is “No.”

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ uppannanti? Āmantā, yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam uppannanti āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti
translated: Is there any consciousness that arises in one whose consciousness has arisen? Or is there any consciousness that arises in one whose consciousness has not arisen?

original: Sabbesaṃ cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe taṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ, no ca uppajjati, sabbesaṃ cittassa
analyzed: sabbesam cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tam cittam uppannam no ca uppajjati sabbesam cittassa
translated: At the moment of dissolution of all consciousness that consciousness has arisen but does not arise.

original: uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ cittaṃ uppannañceva uppajjati ca, yassa cittaṃ nuppajjati, tassa🔽cittaṃ nuppannanti? Cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe cittaṃ nuppajjati, no ca nuppannaṃ, nirodhasamāpannānaṃ
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe tesam cittam uppannam ca iva uppajjati ca yassa cittam na uppajjati tassa  cittam nuppannanti cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe cittam nuppajjati no ca nuppannam nirodha samāpannānam
translated: At the moment of arising of all consciousness that consciousness has arisen and arises. Is there any consciousness that does not arise in one whose consciousness has arisen?🔽At the moment of dissolution of consciousness consciousness does not arise but has arisen. In one who has attained cessation or the base of nothingness consciousness does not arise and has not arisen.

original: asaññasattānaṃ cittaṃ nuppajjati ceva nuppannañca. Yassa vā pana…pe… nuppajjatīti?
analyzed: asaññasattānam cittam nuppajjati ca iva nuppannam ca yassa vā pana pe nuppajjati iti
translated: Is there any consciousness that arises in one whose consciousness has not arisen?

original: Āmantā. Ettha ca uppannanti uppādasamaṅginopetaṃ nāmaṃ, uppajjatīti ca uppādasamaṅginova.
analyzed: āmantāḥ ettha ca uppannanti uppāda samaṅginā upetam nāmam uppajjati iti ca uppāda samaṅginā uva
translated: Herein, “has arisen” is a name for what is associated with arising; “arises” is only what is associated with arising.

original: Yassa cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ uppannanti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… nirujjhatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam nirujjhati tassa cittam uppannanti āmantā yassa vā pana pe nirujjhati iti
translated: Is there any consciousness that ceases in one whose consciousness has arisen? Or is there any consciousness that ceases in one whose consciousness has not arisen?

original: Bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ na nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ nuppannanti? Nirodhasamāpannādīnaṃ
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittam na nirujjhati tassa cittam na uppannanti nirodha samāpanna ādīnam
translated: it has arisen in those who have entered upon the attainment of cessation, etc.,

original: cittaṃ. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā.
analyzed: cittam yassa vā panape āmantā
translated: or it has arisen in any other case.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ uppajjitthāti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti?🔽Sabbesaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Ettha ca uppādappattattā uppajjittha, taṃ anatītattā
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam uppajjittha ati āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti  sabbesam cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tathā ettha ca uppāda ppatta ttā uppajjittha tam anatīta ttā
translated: As to “If his cognizance has arisen, has his cognizance arisen? “ :🔽it has arisen in all cases. And here “has arisen” is said of that which has reached arising, and “has arisen” is said of that which has not reached the past.

original: uppajjati nāmāti atthoti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ khaṇapaccuppannavasena attho vutto. Uppajjitthāti
analyzed: uppajjati nāma ati attho ti aṭṭhakathāyam khaṇa paccuppanna vasena atthaḥ vuttaḥ uppajjittha ati
translated: The meaning is stated in the Commentary as “present by momentary repetition” .

original: pana imassa atītacittakkhaṇavasena atthe gayhamāne eva uparipāḷiyā na virujjhati,
analyzed: pana imassa atīta citta kkhaṇa vasena atthe gayhamāne eva upari pāḷiyā na virujjhati
translated: But if the meaning of “has arisen” is taken as referring to the past moment of cognizance, then it is not contradicted by the text above,

original: na aññathāti paññāyati, tasmā pubbāparaṃ oloketvā pāḷiavirodhena attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: na aññathā iti paññāyati tasmā pubba aparam oloketvā pāḷi avirodhena atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: and it is not contradicted by the text below either. So the meaning should be taken in such a way as not to contradict the text.🔽As to “If his cognizance has not arisen, has his cognizance arisen? “ :

original: Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjati, tassa cittaṃ nuppajjitthāti? Uppajjittha. Yassa vā pana…pe…
analyzed: yassa cittam nuppajjati tassa cittam nuppajjittha ati uppajjittha yassa vā panape
translated: it has arisen. Or it has not arisen in any other case.

original: nuppajjatīti? Natthi. Yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ uppajjissatīti? Pacchimacittasamaṅgikhīṇāsavavirahitānaṃ
analyzed: nuppajjati iti natthi yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam uppajjissati iti pacchima citta samaṅgi khīṇa āsava virahitānam
translated: Is there any such person? No.🔽If anyone’s consciousness arises, will his consciousness have arisen?🔽In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness arises, but their consciousness has not arisen.

original: cittaṃ tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti? Uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ…pe…🔽nuppajjissatīti? Asekhānaṃ pacchimacittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe…
analyzed: cittam tathā yassa vā uppajjati iti uppāda kkhaṇe tathā yassa  nuppajjissati iti asekhānam pacchimacittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa vā
translated: Or, if anyone’s consciousness has arisen, will his consciousness be arising?

original: nuppajjatīti? Pacchimacittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ uppajjittha, tassa🔽cittaṃ uppajjissatīti? Pacchimacittasamaṅgiṃ ṭhapetvā sesānaṃ tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe…
analyzed: na uppajjati iti pacchimacittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittam uppajjittha tassa  cittam uppajjissati iti pacchima citta samaṅgim ṭhapetvā sesānam tathā yassa vā
translated: In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness has arisen, but their consciousness is not arising.🔽Or, if anyone’s consciousness is arising, has his consciousness arisen?🔽In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness is arising, but their consciousness has not arisen.

original: āmantā. Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjittha, tassa cittaṃ nuppajjissatīti? Natthi. Yassa vā
analyzed: āmantā yassa cittam nuppajjittha tassa cittam nuppajjissati iti natthi yassa vā
translated: Or, if anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, is his consciousness arising?🔽In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness has not arisen, but their consciousness is arising.

original: pana…pe… nuppajjitthāti? Uppajjittha.
analyzed: panape nu uppajjittha ati uppajjittha
translated: If anyone’s consciousness ceases, has his consciousness ceased?🔽In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness ceases, but their consciousness has not ceased.🔽Or, if anyone’s consciousness has ceased, does his consciousness cease?

original: Yassa cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhitthāti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… nirujjhatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam nirujjhati tassa cittam nirujjhittha ati āmantā yassa vā pana pe nirujjhati iti
translated: In the case of those without cankers who are in their last existence, their consciousness has ceased, but their consciousness does not cease.

original: Bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ…pe… na nirujjhitthāti? Nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana…pe…🔽natthi. Yassa cittaṃ nirujjhati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhissatīti? Pacchimacittasamaṅgiṃ🔽ṭhapetvā sesānaṃ cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… sesānaṃ bhaṅgakkhaṇe🔽tathā. Yassa cittaṃ…pe… nirujjhissati. Yassa vā pana…pe… nirujjhati.🔽Yassa cittaṃ nirujjhittha, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhissatīti? Pacchimacittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe🔽ṭhapetvā sesānaṃ cittaṃ tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā. Yassa cittaṃ na nirujjhittha,🔽tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhissatīti? Natthi. Yassa vā pana…pe… na nirujjhitthāti? Nirujjhittha.
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittaṃpe na nirujjhittha ati nirujjhittha yassa vā  natthi yassa cittam nirujjhati tassa cittam nirujjhissati iti pacchima citta samaṅgiṃ  ṭhapetvā sesānam cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa vā pana pe sesānam bhaṅga kkhaṇe  tathā yassa cittaṃpe nirujjhissati yassa vā panape nirujjhati  yassa cittam nirujjhittha tassa cittam nirujjhissati iti pacchimacittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe  ṭhapetvā sesānam cittam tathā yassa vā panape āmantā yassa cittam na  tassa cittam na nirujjhissati iti natthi yassa vā pana pe na nirujjhittha ati nirujjhittha
translated: At the time of their dissolution, it is the same. As to “whose consciousness … does not cease”: it ceases. As to “whose … does not cease”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness ceases, will his consciousness have ceased?” Excepting one who is possessed of the final consciousness, in the case of the rest, at the time of the arising of their final consciousness, it is the same. As to “whose … will have ceased”: in the case of the rest, at the time of the arising of their final consciousness, it is the same. As to “whose consciousness ceases, does his consciousness cease?” As to “whose … does not cease”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness has ceased, will his consciousness have ceased?” Excepting at the time of the arising of the final consciousness of those who are possessed of the final consciousness, in the case of the rest, at the time of the arising of their final consciousness, it is the same. As to “whose … has not ceased”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness has not ceased, will his consciousness not have ceased?” As to “whose … does not cease”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness has not ceased, does his consciousness not cease?” It ceases.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhitthāti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam nirujjhittha ati āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti
translated: At the time of dissolution, it is the same. As to “whose consciousness … does not cease”: it ceases. As to “whose … does not cease”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness ceases, will his consciousness have ceased?” Excepting the one possessing the last consciousness, it is the same for the rest at the moment of the dissolution of their consciousness. As to “whose … will have ceased”: it is the same for the rest at the moment of their dissolution. As to “whose consciousness ceases, does his consciousness cease?” As to “whose … does not cease”: there is none. As to “whose consciousness has ceased, will his consciousness have ceased?” Excepting the moment of the dissolution of the last consciousness, it is the same for the rest. As to “whose … will have ceased”: it is the same for the rest at the moment of their dissolution. As to “whose consciousness has ceased, does his consciousness cease?” As to “whose consciousness has not ceased, will his consciousness not have ceased?” There is none. As to “whose … does not cease”: it ceases. As to “whose consciousness arises, has his consciousness ceased?” The one consenting. As to “whose … arises”:

original: Sabbesaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjati, tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhitthāti?
analyzed: sabbesam cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittam na uppajjati tassa cittam na nirujjhittha ati
translated: And so with the arising of consciousness of all.🔽“When consciousness does not arise, does consciousness cease?”

original: Nirujjhittha. Yassa vā pana…pe… natthi, yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhissatīti?🔽Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti? Sabbesaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa🔽cittaṃ nuppajjati, tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhissatīti? Pacchimacittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: nirujjhittha yassa vā panape natthi yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam nirujjhissati iti  āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti sabbesam cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tathā yassa  cittam nuppajjati tassa cittam na nirujjhissati iti pacchimacittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: It ceases. “When consciousness does not arise, does consciousness not cease?”🔽It does not cease. “When consciousness arises, will consciousness cease?”🔽It will cease. “When consciousness arises, will consciousness not cease?”🔽It will not cease. “When consciousness does not arise, will consciousness cease?”🔽It will not cease. “When consciousness does not arise, will consciousness not cease?”

original: tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā. Yassa cittaṃ uppajjittha, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhissatīti?🔽Nirujjhamānaṃ pacchimacittaṃ ṭhapetvā tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā. Yassa cittaṃ
analyzed: tathā yassa vā panape āmantā yassa cittam uppajjittha tassa cittam nirujjhissati iti  nirujjhamānam pacchima cittam ṭhapetvā tathā yassa vā panape āmantā yassa cittam
translated: It does not not cease. “When consciousness arises, will consciousness cease?”🔽It will cease. “When consciousness arises, will consciousness not cease?”🔽It will not cease. “When consciousness does not arise, will consciousness cease?”

original: nuppajjittha, tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhissatīti? Natthi. Yassa vā pana…pe… nuppajjitthāti? Uppajjittha.
analyzed: nuppajjittha tassa cittam na nirujjhissati iti natthi yassa vā pana pe nuppajjittha ati uppajjittha
translated: It will not cease. “When consciousness does not arise, will consciousness not cease?”🔽It does not not cease.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjati, tassa cittaṃ na nirujjhatīti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjatīti?🔽Sabbesaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjati, tassa cittaṃ nirujjhatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjati tassa cittam na nirujjhati iti āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjati iti  sabbesam cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittam na uppajjati tassa cittam nirujjhati iti
translated: Is there any consciousness that arises without there being a cessation of consciousness?🔽Yes, of all who are at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: Sabbesaṃ cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… nuppajjatīti? Āmantā.
analyzed: sabbesam cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tathā yassa vā pana pe nuppajjati iti āmantā
translated: Or is there any consciousness that ceases without there being an arising of consciousness?🔽Yes, of all who are at the moment of death.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppannanti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppajjamānanti?🔽Sabbesaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe tathā. Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjamānaṃ, tassa cittaṃ nuppannanti?
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjamānam tassa cittam uppannanti āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppajjamānanti  sabbesam cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe tathā yassa cittam na uppajjamānam tassa cittam na uppannanti
translated: Is there any consciousness that arises and is that same consciousness that ceases?🔽Yes, of all who are at the moment of death.🔽Or is there any consciousness that arises and is not that same consciousness that ceases?

original: Nirodhasamāpannādīnaṃ cittaṃ tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā.
analyzed: nirodha samāpanna ādīnam cittam tathā yassa vā panape āmantā
translated: Yes, of all who are at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: Yassa cittaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppannanti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: yassa cittam nirujjhamānam tassa cittam uppannanti āmantā yassa vā panape bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: Is there any consciousness that ceases and is that same consciousness that arose?🔽Yes, of all who are at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: tathā. Yassa cittaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ, tassa cittaṃ nuppannanti? Nirodhasamāpannādīnaṃ
analyzed: tathā yassa cittam na nirujjhamānam tassa cittam na uppannanti nirodha samāpanna ādīnam
translated: Or is there any consciousness that ceases and is not that same consciousness that arose?🔽Yes, of all who are at the moment of death.

original: cittaṃ tathā. Yassa vā pana…pe… āmantā.
analyzed: cittam tathā yassa vā panape āmantā
translated: so too is consciousness. Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness has arisen has arisen…

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjitthāti? Āmantā. Yassa vā pana…pe… uppannanti?🔽Cittasamaṅgīnaṃ tathā. Yassa cittaṃ nuppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ nuppajjitthāti? Uppajjittha.
analyzed: yassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjittha ati āmantā yassa vā pana pe uppannanti  citta samaṅgīnam tathā yassa cittam na uppannam tassa cittam na uppajjittha ati uppajjittha
translated: “If anyone’s consciousness has arisen, has his consciousness arisen?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness has not arisen has not arisen’…🔽“If anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, has his consciousness not arisen?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness has not arisen will not arise’…

original: Yassa vā pana…pe… nuppannanti? Natthi…pe… yassa cittaṃ nuppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ nuppajjissatīti?🔽Uppajjissati. Yassa vā pana…pe… nuppannanti? Uppannaṃ.🔽Yassa cittaṃ uppajjittha no ca tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ uppajjissatīti?
analyzed: yassa vā panape nuppannanti yassa cittam nuppannam tassa cittam nuppajjissati iti  uppajjissati yassa vā panape na uppannanti uppannam  yassa cittam uppajjittha no ca tassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam uppajjissati iti
translated: “If anyone’s consciousness has not arisen, will his consciousness not arise?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness will not arise has not arisen’…🔽“If anyone’s consciousness has arisen but his consciousness is not now arising, will his consciousness arise?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness will arise but is not now arising has arisen’…

original: Āmantā. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ uppajjissati no ca tassa cittaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ🔽uppajjitthāti? Āmantā. Ettha “no ca tassa cittaṃ nuppanna”nti idaṃ asaññādiacittake
analyzed: āmantā yassa vā pana cittam uppajjissati no ca tassa cittam uppannam tassa cittam 🔽uppajjittha ati āmantā ettha no ca tassa cittam na uppannanti idam asaññā ādi acittake
translated: “If anyone’s consciousness is not now arising but his consciousness has arisen, has his consciousness arisen?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness has arisen but is not now arising has not arisen’…🔽“If anyone’s consciousness has arisen but is not now arising, has his consciousness arisen?” “Yes.” “Or, if anyone should say, ‘The consciousness of one in whom consciousness has not arisen but is now arising has not arisen’…

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ niyamena cittuppattiyā abhāvato “āmantā”ti ubhayattha vissajjanaṃ
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam tesam niyamena cittuppattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ āmantā ati ubhayattha vissajjanam
translated: “Yes, venerable sir,” is the reply in both cases.

original: vuttaṃ. Ayañca vāro kālattaye gahetvā samatthitoti gahetabbo.
analyzed: vuttam ayam ca vāro kālattaye gahetvā samatthitaḥ iti gahetabbo
translated: And this section should be taken as completed by taking it in the three times.

original: “Yassa cittaṃ nuppajjittha no ca tassa cittaṃ nuppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ nuppajjissatīti?
analyzed: yassa cittam nuppajjittha no ca tassa cittam nuppannam tassa cittam nuppajjissati iti
translated: “If a man’s consciousness has not arisen, has his consciousness ceased?

original: Natthi. Yassa vā pana cittaṃ nuppajjissati no ca tassa cittaṃ nuppannaṃ, tassa cittaṃ
analyzed: natthi yassa vā pana cittam nuppajjissati no ca tassa cittam nuppannam tassa cittam
translated: No. Or if a man’s consciousness has ceased, has his consciousness arisen?

original: nuppajjitthāti? Uppajjittha.🔽Uppannaṃ uppajjamānanti? Uppādakkhaṇe cittaṃ tathā. Uppajjamānaṃ uppannanti? Āmantā. Nuppannaṃ nuppajjamānanti? Āmantā. Nuppajjamānaṃ nuppannanti? Atītānāgatacittaṃ tathā.
analyzed: na uppajjittha ati uppajjittha  uppannam uppajjamānanti uppāda kkhaṇe cittam tathā uppajjamānam uppannanti āmantā nuppannam nuppajjamānanti āmantā nuppajjamānam nuppannanti atīta anāgata cittam tathā
translated: It has arisen.🔽Is what has arisen what is arising? Consciousness at the moment of arising is so. Is what is arising what has arisen? “Yes, venerable sir.” Is what has not arisen what is not arising? “Yes, venerable sir.” Is what is not arising what has not arisen? So too with past and future consciousness.

original: Niruddhaṃ nirujjhamānanti? No, nirujjhamānaṃ niruddhanti? No, naniruddhaṃ nanirujjhamānanti? Uppādakkhaṇe anāgatañca cittaṃ tathā. Nanirujjhamānaṃ naniruddhantipi tatheva.
analyzed: niruddham nirujjhamānanti no nirujjhamānam niruddhanti no na niruddham na nirujjhamānanti uppāda kkhaṇe anāgatam ca cittam tathā na nirujjhamānam na niruddhanti pi tathā iva
translated: Is what has ceased what is ceasing? No. Is what is ceasing what has ceased? No. Is what has not ceased what is not ceasing? No. Is what is not ceasing what has not ceased? So too with future consciousness.

original: Yassa cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, nirujjhamānaṃ
analyzed: yassa cittam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam nirujjhamānam
translated: Whose consciousness, when it arises, does not go beyond the moment, the instant, the occasion of its arising,

original: khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, tassa cittanti? No ca bhaṅgakkhaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ,🔽atītaṃ cittaṃ tadubhayaṃ vītikkantaṃ, yassa vā pana cittaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ
analyzed: khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam tassa cittanti no ca bhaṅga khaṇam vītikkantam  atītam cittam tat ubhayam vītikkantam yassa vā pana cittam nirujjhamānam khaṇam khaṇam
translated: and when it ceases, does not go beyond the moment, the instant, the occasion of its ceasing, is that consciousness his? No, it is not. But when it has gone beyond the moment of its dissolution,🔽or past consciousness has gone beyond both,

original: vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ, uppajjamānaṃ khaṇaṃ khaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālaṃ,
analyzed: vītikkantam atikkanta kālam uppajjamānam khaṇam khaṇam vītikkantam atikkanta kālam
translated: whose consciousness, when it ceases, goes beyond the moment, the instant, the occasion of its ceasing, and when it arises, goes beyond the moment, the instant, the occasion of its arising,🔽is that consciousness his? Past consciousness.”

original: tassa cittanti? Atītaṃ citta”nti iminā nayena puggalavāre sabbattha vissajjananayo veditabbo.
analyzed: tassa cittan ti atītam cittan ti iminā nayena puggala vāre sabbattha vissajjana nayaḥ veditabbo
translated: In this way the method of answering should be understood in all the sections of the chapter on the person.

original: Tattha uppajjamānaṃ khaṇanti uppajjamānassa khaṇaṃ, uppādakkhaṇanti attho. Khaṇaṃ🔽vītikkantaṃ atikkantakālanti na ciraṃ vītikkantaṃ, tameva pana uppādakkhaṇaṃ vītikkantaṃ
analyzed: tattha uppajjamānam khaṇanti uppajjamānassa khaṇam uppāda khaṇanti atthaḥ khaṇaṃ  vītikkantam atikkanta kālanti na ciram vītikkantam tam eva pana uppāda kkhaṇam vītikkantam
